generated_summary: Seasonal epidemics of influenza virus occur annually, with peak pandemic flu epidemics occurring between 3 and 5 million people. The primary strategy for influenza vaccine development is to elicit antibodies specific for the envelope glycoproteins of influenza virus. However, influenza virus causes high mutation rates, resulting in the emergence of new viral serotypes that are resistant to antibodies. T lymphocytes have been reported to be capable of mediating heterosubtypic protection through recognition of internal, more conserved, influenza virus proteins. Here, we demonstrate that influenza virus-specific CD8 T cells and virus-specific non-neutralizing antibodies cooperatively elicit protective immunity. Our data suggests that an influenza vaccine capable of eliciting both CD8 T cells and antibodies specific for highly conserved influenza proteins may be able to provide protection in humans.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease that can cause permanent nerve damage and deformities. It is caused by Mycobacterium leprae and is transmitted from person to person through skin to skin contact. In Brazil, the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Housing and Services ( MHS ) together with the Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Services ( MES ) together govern the national control program that promotes access to treatment and the inclusion of a minimum of 10% of the population at risk of contracting the disease. The study investigated the role of migration as a risk factor for leprosy. The study found that people who were recently diagnosed with leprosy migrate 5 years earlier than people who did not. People who were also recently diagnosed with leprosy in their family were more likely to migrate than people who did not. People who were also recently diagnosed with leprosy in their household and their relatives were also more likely to migrate than people who did not. People who were also recently diagnosed with leprosy in their family and their relatives were more likely to migrate than people who did not. People who were also recently diagnosed with leprosy in their household and their relatives were more likely to migrate than people who did not. Alcohol consumption was also associated with leprosy, a relevant risk factor in susceptibility to infection that should be explored in future research.

Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by parasites of the genus Leishmania. Infection with L. major causes a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations, from a mild form to a deadly form. While the causes of disease remain unknown, a host response to infection with L. major is thought to play an important role in the disease process. In this study, we used a mouse model of leishmaniasis to investigate what cytokines contribute to increased pathology when IL-10-mediated regulation is absent. We found that mice lacking IL-10 expression develop larger lesions than controls, but fewer parasites. Surprisingly, we found that IL-17, a cytokine that promotes inflammation, is also involved in increased pathology. IL-17 was found to regulate the IL-17 response and the production of IL-17 by immune cells from leishmaniasis patients. Thus, IL-17 may be a useful target for controlling immunopathology in leishmaniasis.

When organisms form new species, one of the fundamental questions in evolutionary biology is how they manage to adapt to the presence of natural variation in the environment. Here, we address this question by studying the process of adaptation in Drosophila melanica and D. robusta species groups, which have independently formed sex chromosomes. Each species has evolved a complex of 13 genes that function to compensate for the lack of genes on the other sex chromosome in both species. These genes recognize a conserved binding motif, which is enriched on the X chromosome. We infer that the diverse mutations that have evolved to compensate for the absence of genes on the other sex chromosome have taken different paths in each species. However, the propensity to use the same mutational pathway differs between independently formed X chromosomes and appears to be contingent on genomic properties of each species. This establishes the “genomic environment” as an important determinant in predicting the outcome of evolutionary adaptations.

Prions are infectious agents that cause heritable diseases and are often associated with human and animal suffering. Yeast prions are unique among model organisms in that they can be replicated in the absence of host cell machinery, and they can be propagated in a test tube by controlled temperatures. Yeast prions contain a domain rich in glutamine ( Q ) and asparagine ( N ), which have the potential to facilitate the propagation of the infectious aggregates that are formed. We have identified 11 proteins with Q/N-rich domains that can promote the de novo aggregation of the Sup35 protein into the [PSI+] prion state. Here, we show that overexpression of many of the same 11 Q/N-rich proteins can also destabilize pre-existing [PSI+] or [URE3] prions. We explore in detail the mechanism by which the [PSI+] protein overexpression leads to the loss of [PSI+]. We show that the [PSI+] protein overexpression triggers the separation of Hsp104 and Sis1 chaperones from the diffuse cytoplasmic pool. Thus, a mechanism by which heterologous Q/N-rich proteins interfere with prion propagation appears to be the loss of cytoplasmic Hsp104 and Sis1 chaperones available to sever [PSI+].

Kcnq1 is an imprinted gene that is expressed from only one parental copy, and whose expression depends on the activity of a cis-acting regulatory element. Previous studies have shown that Kcnq1 is imprinted in the heart, but the effect of tissue-specific loss of imprinting on this gene, as well as the role of Kcnq1 in heart development, has remained unknown. Here, we show that tissue-specific loss of imprinting affects expression of Kcnq1 in the heart. This effect is independent of Kcnq1 expression, as the expression of the paternally expressed Kcnq1 is unaffected by tissue-specific loss of Kcnq1ot1. We also find that, unlike in the mammalian genome, Kcnq1ot1 expression in the heart is established and maintained independently of Kcnq1 expression, thus excluding a role for Kcnq1ot1 in repressing Kcnq1. Surprisingly, we find that Kcnq1ot1 itself switches to biallelic expression specifically in the heart, suggesting that tissue-specific loss of imprinting may be common during embryogenesis. We also find that in later developmental stages, however, Kcnq1ot1 has a role in modulating Kcnq1 levels, such that its absence leads to overexpression of Kcnq1. Thus, our studies reveal novel mechanisms within the Kcnq1 imprinted domain that operate exclusively in the heart on Kcnq1.

Why do some amino acid mutations in the human genome look more or less deleterious than others? Quantifying this ‘fitness effect’ is key to resolving important medical and evolutionary questions. Here, we present a method for inferring the relative contribution of demographic and selective effects to patterning amino acid variation in the human genome. We find evidence of an ancient population expansion in the sample with African ancestry and a relatively recent bottleneck in the sample with European ancestry. After accounting for these demographic effects, we find evidence for strong evidence for great variability in the selective effects of new amino acid replacements. In both populations, the patterns of variation are consistent with a leptokurtic distribution of selection coefficients. Specifically, we predict 27–29% of amino acid changing ( nonsynonymous ) mutations are neutral or nearly neutral, 30–42% are moderately deleterious, and nearly all the remainder are highly deleterious or lethal. Our results are consistent with 10–20% of amino acid differences between humans and chimpanzees having been fixed by positive selection with the remainder of differences being neutral or nearly neutral.

Meiosis is a unique cell division that generates haploid gametes. To ensure proper chromosome segregation, the meiotic divisions must be tightly regulated. In humans, the genes involved in meiotic initiation are highly conserved between mouse and human. However, the mechanisms of meiotic initiation are still not fully understood. Here, we demonstrated that Wdr62 is required for the proper activation of JNK signaling in germ cells, which leads to the activation of POI, an important mutation in humans. The WDR62 gene was also found in patients with premature ovarian insufficiency, and these mutations had a dominant-negative effect on regulating Stra8 expression. We thus found a novel role of WDR62 in meiotic initiation.

Heart disease affects millions of people worldwide. In the past 30 years, there has been a significant increase in the use of non-cardiac drugs to treat patients with heart disease. In some cases, these drugs act on non-cardiac targets and cause severe side effects. In fact, they are associated with the development of cardiomyopathies, a group of disorders characterized by progressive heart failure. Understanding the cellular-molecular substrates of heart disease is key to the development of cardiac specific therapies and to the prevention of off-target effects by non-cardiac targeted drugs. One of the primary targets for therapeutic intervention is the human ether a go-go ( hERG ) K+ channel, which, together with the KCNQ channel, controls the rate and efficiency of repolarization in human heart cells. Here, we show that, in Drosophila, mutations in or cardiac knockdown of Seizure ( Se ), along with KCNQ, both contribute significantly to adult heart function as they do in humans. In humans, mutations in Se and KCNQ cause severe arrhythmias, which are similar to those observed in humans. In contrast to KCNQ, however, mutations in Se also cause extensive structural remodeling of the myofibrillar organization, which suggests that hERG channel function has a novel link to sarcomeric and myofibrillar integrity.

Recent advances in medical research have led to an increased understanding of the mechanisms of how the human microbiota impacts health. However, the role of the host immune system remains poorly understood, especially in diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease ( IBD ). IBD is a major cause of morbidity and mortality, and current therapies fail to address the underlying mechanisms. In this study, we investigated the role of the CD4 CD8 T cell subset, a well-characterized component of the immune response that is responsible for the regulation of the immune system. We found that CD4 CD8 T cells, a subset of which are highly enriched in IBD, are highly specific for the human intestinal microbiota and function as potent inducers of regulatory T cells, which have the potential to control or prevent the detrimental effects of inflammatory bowel disease. Strikingly, we found that the specific regulatory T cells of IBD patients fail to respond to the common human intestinal bacteria, Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, and that these patients are unable to control IBD symptoms. Together, our data reveal that CD4 CD8 T cells are an important component of the human immune system and that they function to prevent IBD symptoms by regulating the human microbiota.

Lying at the heart of many vital cellular processes such as photosynthesis and respiration, biological electron transfer ( ET ) is mediated by transient interactions among proteins that recognize multiple binding partners. Accurate description of the ET complexes – necessary for a comprehensive understanding of the cellular signaling and metabolism – is compounded by their short lifetimes and pronounced binding promiscuity. Here, we used a computational approach relying solely on the steric properties of the individual proteins to predict the ET properties of protein complexes constituting the functional interactome of the eukaryotic cytochrome c ( Cc ). Cc is a small, soluble, highly-conserved electron carrier protein that coordinates the electron flow among different redox partners. Starting from the structures of individual proteins, we performed extensive conformational sampling of the ET-competent binding geometries, mapping out functional epitopes in the Cc complexes, estimating the upper limit of the ET rate in a given system, assessing ET properties of different binding stoichiometries, and gauging the effect of domain mobility on the intermolecular ET. The resulting picture of the Cc interactome 1 ) reveals that most ET-competent binding geometries are located in electrostatically favorable regions, 2 ) indicates that the ET can take place from more than one protein-protein orientation, and 3 ) suggests that protein dynamics within redox complexes, and not the electron tunneling event itself, is the rate-limiting step in the intermolecular ET. Further, we show that the functional epitope size correlates with the extent of dynamics in the Cc complexes and thus can be used as a diagnostic tool for protein mobility.

Q fever is a zoonotic disease caused by a bacterium, Coxiella burnetii. Q fever is responsible for high fever, headache, cough, and fever, and is transmitted through respiratory or throat secretions. Q fever can be asymptomatic or may progress to a chronic form, mainly associated with liver and spleen. In this work, we describe a series of Q fever cases in Galicia ( Spain ). We included 32% of Q fever cases that do not report contact with traditional risk factors, and 18% that are linked to the disease. Our results show that Q fever in Galicia is a rare disease, but is linked to a high mortality and that most patients present early in the course of the illness. In the North of Spain, 71% of patients have pneumonia, 13. 2% isolated fever and 13% hepatitis. In the Central and Southern areas, only 31. 7% of patients have risk factors, and an urban-environment was the most frequent origin of infection.

Insulin is a hormone that regulates the secretion of insulin from pancreatic β-cells. The physiological action of insulin is to stimulate glucose uptake and thereby reduce blood glucose. Insulin is also secreted by other cell types. While insulin is secreted from the pancreas, the pancreas is a major endocrine organ involved in the regulation of glucose and insulin secretion. There is evidence that insulin secretion can be regulated by 5-HT, a neurotransmitter that regulates glucose release from the brain. However, the mechanism of action of 5-HT on insulin secretion remains unclear. Using mice selectively deficient in 5-HT receptor, we show that 5-HT regulates insulin secretion by controlling the stability and activation of insulin receptors. We also show that 5-HT can regulate insulin secretion by coupling its action with a second receptor, which is known as serotonylation. Serotonylation is a posttranslational modification that can regulate signaling within a receptor-independent signaling mechanism. We also show that 5-HT can inactivate the Rab3a-Rab27a pathway, which is known to be involved in the inhibition of serotonylation. We also show that the loss of serotonylation of Rab3a in pancreatic β-cells causes the inhibition of insulin secretion. Our results suggest that 5-HT regulates insulin secretion by controlling the stability and activation of insulin receptors and, in doing so, also by modulating the action of other endocrine regulators.

Human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ) is a neglected tropical disease targeted for elimination ‘as a public health problem’ by 2020. The indicators to monitor progress towards the target are based on the number of reported cases, the related areas and populations exposed at various levels of risk, and the coverage of surveillance activities. Data from the National Sleeping Sickness Control Programme, Non-Governmental Organizations, and research institutions are analysed in this paper to update 2016 for these indicators, and to assess the epidemiological situation. Trends for the two primary indicators are on track for the 2020 goal: 2, 164 cases of HAT were reported in 2016 ( as compared to the milestone of 4, 000 cases ), and for the period 2012–2016 280, 000 km2 are estimated to be at moderate risk or higher ( i. e. ≥ 1 case/10, 000 people/year ), as compared to the milestone of 230, 000 km2. An overall improvement in the coverage of at risk populations by surveillance activities was observed. Concerning rhodesiense HAT, 124 health facilities currently provide diagnosis and treatment. We conclude that elimination of HAT as a public health problem by 2020 seems within reach, as the epidemiological trends observed in previous years are confirmed in this latest 2016 monitoring update. However, looking beyond 2020, and in particular to the 2030 goal of elimination of transmission as zero cases for the gambiense form of the disease only, there is no room for complacency.

Sideroblastic anemia is a rare genetic disease that causes the breakdown of red blood cells and results in the presence of iron deposits in the mitochondria of these cells. A common subtype of congenital sideroblastic anemia is due to mutations in the SLC25A38 gene. The current treatment for SLC25A38 congenital sideroblastic anemia is chronic blood transfusion coupled with iron chelation. Here, we show that the SLC25A38 protein, and its yeast homolog Hem25, are mitochondrial glycine transporters required for the initiation of heme synthesis. To do so, we took advantage of the fact that mitochondrial glycine has several roles beyond the synthesis of heme, including the synthesis of folate derivatives through the glycine cleavage system. We identified that high levels of exogenous glycine, or 5-aminolevulinic acid ( 5-Ala ) a metabolite downstream of Hem25 in heme biosynthetic pathway, were able to restore heme levels to normal in yeast cells lacking Hem25 function. While neither glycine nor 5-Ala could ameliorate SLC25A38 congenital sideroblastic anemia in a zebrafish model, we determined that the addition of folate with glycine was able to restore hemoglobin levels. Given the tolerability of glycine and folate in humans, this study points to a potential novel treatment for SLC25A38 congenital sideroblastic anemia.

Skin defects affect millions of people worldwide and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. While many genes involved in skin development and homeostasis have been identified, there are still many questions to be answered. Here, we describe a large scale screen undertaken to identify genes important in skin development using the mouse model. We have screened 562 different mouse lines to assess the importance of each gene for skin development. Many of the genes identified were not previously associated with skin disease in the organ, and others were new cutaneous functions. We also investigated the role of these genes in skin development and function. The results obtained will be used to aid future work in this area, and to maximise future projects of this type.

During plant development, genes are often expressed in a coordinated manner in a specific temporal and spatial manner. The precise regulation of gene expression is often modulated by various factors. In this study, we show that mutations in ATR, a DNA replication checkpoint gene, and in ARF3, a gene involved in homologous recombination, enhance the phenotypes of plants defective in TEBICHI ( TEB ) gene. We also show that these phenotypes of plants defective in ATR and ARF3 genes are caused by the upregulation of ETTIN/ARF3 in plants, which is caused in part by the upregulation of ETTN in plants. Our study demonstrates that TEB and ARF3 function in a coordinated manner during development.

Buruli ulcer, a neglected, emerging, tropical disease, is an important cause of chronic, debilitating, and often chronic wounds. It is a significant threat to the health of people who live in poor, rural, and peri-rural conditions. Despite this, the disease is under-reported, under-studied, and under-resourced, often failing to receive public attention. We conducted a detailed ethnographic study of Buruli in northwest Uganda and present here the first biopsies of this neglected disease from people who sought treatment. We show that the disease was present in 1996, and that people who sought treatment were still in the process of presenting their lesions. We also show that a biosocial history of ‘Buruli’ provides insights into the nature of this affliction and the historical and contemporary contexts in which people seek care. This knowledge, in turn, can guide policy and policy makers to better understand Buruli in this region, and to improve care for this important disease.

The foreskin is the site of most HIV acquisition in men. While HIV infection is associated with this anatomical site of exposure, the immune correlates of this phenomenon have not been assessed. To determine the mucosal immune correlates of HIV acquisition, we measured levels of antibodies to antimicrobial peptides and IgA in the foreskin of 99 men who acquired HIV and 109 randomly selected controls who remained HIV seronegative. We found that, while the levels of IgA and antimicrobial peptides were increased in the foreskin of cases, levels of IgA were decreased. This finding suggests that levels of IgA may be a biomarker of protection from HIV infection, but other HESN associations may also influence HIV risk.

V. cholerae is a bacterial pathogen that causes a diarrheal disease that can be life-threatening if left untreated. V. cholerae is divided into two major types: O1 serogroup and E1 serogroup. The O1 serogroup encodes a toxin that is responsible for the deadly diarrheal disease cholera. The E1 serogroup, which is found in all strains of the O1 serogroup, encodes a different toxin that is not responsible for the deadly diarrheal disease cholera. The E1 serogroup has 2 biotypes, classical and El Tor, and the third biotype, atypical El Tor, is responsible for the recent pandemic. We have shown that atypical El Tor strains are generated by recombination between 2 types of CTX phages. We have also analyzed the molecular mechanisms that underlie the emergence of El Tor strains carrying two different CTX phages. We isolated an intermediate V. cholerae strain that carries two different CTX phages that encode El Tor and classical cholera toxin. We show that the intermediate strain can be converted into various El Tor strains by recombination with the new CTX phages. Our data also suggest that inter-chromosomal recombination is possible when a host bacterial cell is infected by multiple CTX phages. Our study provides novel insights into the population changes in V. cholerae in the absence of significant changes to the genome but by replacement of the CTX prophage that they harbor.

Infertility is the most common male health concern in the Western world. While the molecular causes of infertility are complex, some cases are known to result from mutations in the genes that control this process. Here we identified a new syndrome in three brothers with a loss of GnRH neurons in the hypothalamus. The homozygous deletion of the Dmxl2 gene was associated with lower levels of the Dmxl2 mRNA in the blood cells of the patients. DMXL2 encodes the synaptic protein Rabconnectin-3α. The deletion of Dmxl2 from mouse neurons delayed puberty and resulted in very low fertility. We also found that Dmxl2 knockdown in an insulin-secreting cell line showed that rabconnectin-3α controlled the constitutive and glucose-induced secretion of insulin. Our findings identify Rabconnectin-3α as a key controller of neuronal and endocrine homeostatic processes.

Allicin is a natural compound produced by plants and algae, and has been used as an effective drug against parasitic protozoa. Although allicin has been shown to have antileishmanial activity in vitro and in vivo, the mechanism of action underlying its antiproliferative effect against Leishmania has been virtually unexplored. We have addressed this issue in L. infantum, and have developed a model for the first time in this parasite. Exposure of L. infantum to allicin induced high calcium levels and mitochondrial reactive oxygen species ( ROS ), collapse of the mitochondrial membrane potential, and increased cytosolic ROS levels. The incubation of the promastigotes with SYTOX Green revealed that decrease of ATP was not associated with plasma membrane permeabilization. Moreover, DNA agarose gel electrophoresis and TUNEL analysis demonstrated that allicin did not induce phospholipid exposure on the plasma membrane. Moreover, we found that allicin induced cell cycle arrest in the G2/M phase. We conclude that allicin induces dysregulation of calcium homeostasis and oxidative stress, uncontrolled by the antioxidant defense of the cell, which leads to mitochondrial dysfunction and a bioenergetic catastrophe leading to cell necrosis and cell cycle arrest in the premitotic phase.

The cell division that gives rise to gametes is called meiosis. During meiosis, the number of chromosome sets is reduced by two, but the chromosome number remains high, because each gamete contains the same complement of chromosomes. This is achieved through the pairing and recombination of maternal and paternal chromosomes. These recombination events ensure that homologous chromosomes associate and then they recombine to give rise to gametes. The cytological manifestations of recombination are called chiasmata, and they provide the physical link between the homologs. We have studied mouse HFM1, a member of the HFM1/Mer3 protein family. We have shown that Hfm1 is required for the normal progression of recombination and proper synapsis between homologous chromosomes. Chromosome localization of MSH4 is altered in the absence of Hfm1, and MLH1foci are drastically reduced. In agreement, chiasma formation is reduced, and cells arrest with subsequent apoptosis at diakinesis. We propose that Hfm1 is required to form normal numbers of crossover ( CO ) and to complete synapsis.

Epilepsy is a common neurological disorder that is found in developing countries. It is also often associated with parasitic infections. We investigated whether exposure to parasitic infections was associated with an increased prevalence of active convulsive epilepsy ( ACE ) in five sub-Saharan African sites. A case-control design was used to collect blood from patients and age-matched controls. We found that exposure to multiple infections, and in particular to the filarial parasite Onchocerca volvulus, was associated with an increased prevalence of ACE. Exposure to multiple infections was common ( 73. 8% of cases and 65. 5% of controls had been exposed to two or more infections ), and for T. gondii and O. volvulus co-infection, their combined effect on the prevalence of ACE, as determined by the relative excess risk due to interaction ( RERI = 1. 19 ), was greater than additive ( T. gondii and O. volvulus, RERI = 1. 19 ). The prevalence of T. solium antibodies was low ( 2. 8% of cases and 2. 2% of controls ) and was not associated with ACE in the study areas. This study investigates how the degree of exposure to parasites and multiple parasitic infections are associated with ACE and may explain conflicting results when only seropositivity is considered.

Circadian clocks are timekeepers that determine daily rhythms in many biological processes, including the sleep–wake cycle, circadian clock timing, and the timing of physiological, biochemical, and behavioral changes. Although many of the components of the circadian clock are known, we still know much less about how they interact with each other and the external 24-h time cycle. In this study, we use the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster as a model organism to study the interaction of CRY, a key circadian photoreceptor, with the PER and TIM proteins, the major components of the 24-h time cycle. We show that CRY and PER interact with each other in a way that is dependent on the temperature of the temperature of the photoreceptor. We also show that CRY is critical for the ability of perL to respond to changes in temperature, and that CRY is required for proper behavioral responses to light. Finally, we show that light and temperature act together to affect circadian rhythms in wild-type flies. These results suggest that CRY, PER, and TIM interact with each other to regulate the circadian clock.

Our visual perception of the outside world comes from the sensory input that is transmitted from the primary visual cortex ( V1 ) to the secondary visual cortex ( V2 ). The primary visual cortex is the target of the visual input and the secondary visual cortex is responsible for sensory processing and integration. Although the primary visual cortex is a well-studied model of sensory processing, it has not been used to investigate the role of the feedback connections in cortical plasticity. In this study, we investigate the hypothesis that the plasticity of visual orientation discrimination in the primary visual cortex involves changes in the connectivity of higher cortical areas, serving a different function from plasticity due to changes in the connectivity of the primary visual cortex. We show that modulation of feedback inputs to V1 from higher cortical areas results in shunting inhibition in V1 neurons, which changes the response properties of V1 neurons. The orientation selectivity of V1 neurons is enhanced without changing orientation preference, preserving the topographic organizations in V1. These results provide new insights to the mechanisms of plasticity in the adult brain, reconciling apparently inconsistent experiments and providing a new hypothesis for a functional role of the feedback connections.

Mosquitoes in the Culex pipiens complex transmit human lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, a filarial nematode, in South Asia and the West Indies. In the absence of the vector mosquito, Brugia spp., the causative agents of lymphatic filariasis, are transmitted to humans via mosquitoes. Previous work with the Iowa strain of Culex pipiens pipiens shows that this mosquito is as susceptible to W. bancrofti as is the natural Cx. p. pipiens vector in the Nile Delta. Here we report that the infectivity barrier for Brugia spp. in Cx. p. pipiens is the mosquito midgut, which inflicts internal and external damage to ingested microfilariae. Following per os exposure to Brugia, the prevalence of infection is significantly lower in Cx. p. pipiens compared to controls, and differs between parasite species with <50% and <5% of Cx. p. pipiens becoming infected with B. pahangi and B. malayi, respectively. Examination of parasites recovered from the Cx. p. pipiens midgut by vital staining, and those exsheathed with papain, suggest that the damage inflicted by the midgut is subcuticular and disrupts internal tissues. Microscopic studies of these worms show compromised motility and sharp bends in the body; and ultrastructurally the presence of many fluid-filled vacuoles in the hypodermis, body wall, and nuclear column. Incubation of Brugia with Cx. p. pipiens midgut extracts produces similar internal damage phenotypes; indicating that the Cx. p. pipiens midgut factor ( s ) that damage mf in vivo are soluble and stable in physiological buffer, and inflict damage on mf in vitro.

Microorganisms have a central place in our health and wellbeing, and are an increasingly important source of disease burden. Genome-Wide Association Studies ( GWAS ) in microbial organisms have the potential to improve the way we understand, manage, and treat infectious diseases. However, existing GWAS methods are only able to perform limited analysis of the variation in a population genome. In this paper, we introduce a new phylogenetic approach that has been tailored for microbial GWAS, which is applicable to organisms ranging from purely clonal to frequently recombining. Our approach is robust to the confounding effects of both population structure and recombination, while maintaining high statistical power to detect associations. Thorough testing via application to simulated data provides strong support for the power and specificity of our approach and demonstrates the advantages offered over alternative clustering and dimension-reduction methods. We also illustrate the versatility and potential of our method, demonstrating the ability to identify both well-characterised and novel drivers of invasive disease. Our method is implemented as an open-source R package that is freely available at https://github. com/metrixwAS.

Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a severe parasitic disease caused by the intracellular protozoan Leishmania donovani. The disease is transmitted to humans via sandflies, and it is considered to be a potentially deadly zoonosis. Arginase 1 ( arg1 ) is a critical enzyme in the Leishmania parasite life cycle, and its expression is increased in the presence of anti-leishmanial drugs, suggesting that it is a target for drug development. We previously found that IL-4, a key cytokine in the parasite life cycle, is required for the induction of arg1 expression in macrophages. To better understand the mechanism of arg1 induction, we screened a panel of growth factor inhibitors and found that inhibition of growth factor signaling reduced arg1 expression in infected macrophages, and that this process was dependent on IL-4. Recombinant FGF-2 and IGF-1 increased the expression of arg1 in infected macrophages, and this induction was augmented by IL-4. Inhibition of the downstream signaling molecules JAK and AKT also reduced the activation of STAT6 in infected macrophages. Our data demonstrate that the Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor 1 ( FGF-2 ) and Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 Receptor ( IGF-1R ) and IL-4 signaling pathways converge at STAT6 to promote the pathologic arg1 expression and intracellular survival in VL. Targeted interruption of these pathological processes offers an approach to restrain this relentlessly progressive disease.

Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide. The WHO recommends annual mass drug administration ( MDA ) of antibiotics with the aim of at least 80% coverage of children ages 1–9 years. In communities where the prevalence of trachomatous inflammation-follicular among children ages 1–9 years is ≥5%, WHO recommends annual MDA coverage of 10%. Population-based coverage surveys are essential to understand the effectiveness of MDA programs, but published reports from trachoma programs are rare. In the Amhara region of Ethiopia, a population-based MDA coverage survey was conducted 3 weeks following the 2016 MDA to estimate the zonal prevalence of self-reported drug coverage in all 10 administrative zones. The estimated coverage was 24, 248 individuals ( 86. 4% ), of which, 20, 942 ( 86. 4% ) were present. The regional coverage was 76. 8% ( 95% Confidence Interval ( CI ) :69. 3–82. 9% ) and 77. 4% ( 95%CI = 65. 7–85. 9% ) among children ages 1–9 years. Zonal coverage ranged from 67. 8% to 90. 2%. Five out of ten zones achieved a coverage >80%. In all zones, the reported administrative coverage was considerably higher than 90% and was considerably higher than self-reported coverage. Although the reported coverage was greater than 80% in some zones, programmatic improvements are warranted throughout Amhara to achieve higher coverage. These results will be used to enhance community mobilization and improve training for MDA distributors and supervisors to improve coverage in future MDAs.

Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ), a herpesvirus, is a leading cause of birth defects in newborns and a leading cause of congenital viral infections. Despite the fact that HCMV causes morbidity in people with compromised immune systems, it is a leading infectious cause of childhood deaths and is a leading cause of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome ( AIDS ). HCMV infection begins with entry of the virus into target cells, which is mediated by the viral glycoproteins. In this study, we report the crystal structure of the HCMV glycoprotein B ( gB ), which is similar to the human counterparts of HSV-1 and EBV. Despite structural similarity, each gB has a unique domain arrangement, which has implications for its function. We were able to determine how extensive glycosylation of the gB ectodomain influences antibody recognition. While antigenic sites that elicit neutralizing antibodies are more heavily glycosylated than those that elicit non-neutralizing antibodies, which suggests that HCMV gB uses glycans to shield neutralizing epitopes while exposing non-neutralizing epitopes. Our study provides a starting point for elucidation of the antigenic and immunogenic properties of HCMV gB and aid in the design of recombinant vaccines and monoclonal antibody therapies.

Soil-transmitted helminths ( STHs ) affect millions of people worldwide and cause significant morbidity. Infection with STHs is linked to poor water supply and sanitation systems, which are the primary means of controlling STH infections. Regular drug administration is the cardinal recommendation for the control of STH infections; however, the impact of joint WASH interventions on STH infections is not well characterized. The aim of this study was to assess the association of lacking access to water and sanitation with STH infections, taking into account the differences in route of entry of STH species among the organisms. Our study was conducted in Salta province, Argentina. We enrolled 6957 individuals and selected for stool/serum sampling for parasitological and serological diagnosis of STH infections. Our results indicate that unimproved drinking water and poor access to sanitation are distinct risk factors for STH infections. These results provide valuable information to improve the control of STH infections and should help in designing the optimal control strategy for STH.

Giardiasis is a disease caused by the protozoan Giardia duodenalis. It is a common diarrheal disease in children living in developing countries. In Brazil, the government has supported the construction of a large number of rainwater cisterns for the benefit of the community. However, few epidemiological studies have been conducted to assess the health risks or protection effects associated with the use of this water source. The aim of this study was to evaluate whether access to rainwater cisterns is associated with the decrease in the prevalence of Giardia duodenalis infections in children, compared to other children living in households supplied by other water supplies. A quasi-experimental study was developed in two rural municipalities of the semiarid region of Brazil. A sample of 664 children aged between 4 months and 5 years old were followed up, of which 332 had access to rainwater cisterns ( cistern group ) and 332 did not, having water supplied from alternative sources ( comparison group ). In a period of approximately one year ( 2010 ) intestinal parasites were investigated in feces of children from the cistern group. The prevalence of G. duodenalis in children from the cistern group ranged from 4. 8 to 10. 5%, while the prevalence in the comparison group ranged from 7. 6 to 16. 7%. Multivariate analysis ( GEE ) showed a higher risk of G. duodenalis infection in children who did not have access to rainwater cisterns, when compared to children who did. The other variables associated with G. duodenalis infection were: number of rooms per house ( OR 0. 89; 95% CI 1. 17–2. 51 ) ; family income ( OR0. 48; 95% CI 0. 26–0. 88 ) ; preterm children ( OR 1. 70; 95% CI 1. 19–2. 43 ) ; and improper hand hygiene prior to food preparation ( OR 4. 78; 95% CI 1. 95–11. 76 ). Our results suggest that a large scale rainwater cistern is a good choice for children in rural areas with access to a water source. However, it is important to complement physical interventions with actions related to personal and domestic hygiene to enable further reductions in parasite infections affecting mainly the underprivileged populations.

Chagas disease ( CD ) is a major health problem in Latin America. The CD parasite, Trypanosoma cruzi, is transmitted to humans by insects. The CD symptoms are often chronic and patients may develop heart disease, which is considered one of the most important life threatening manifestations. CD is caused by the parasite’s sugar moieties that are recognized by mannan binding lectin ( MBL ), a soluble pattern-recognition molecule that activates the complement pathway of complement. MBL levels and activity are affected by genetic polymorphisms in the MBL2 gene. We sequenced the MBL2 promoter and exon 1 in 196 chronic CD patients and 202 controls. The MBL2*C allele, which causes MBL deficiency, was associated with protection against CD ( P = 0. 007, OR = 0. 32 ). Compared with controls, genotypes with this allele were completely absent in patients with the cardiac form of the disease. Furthermore, cardiac patients with genotypes causing MBL deficiency presented less heart damage, compared with cardiac patients having the XA haplotype causing low MBL levels, but fully capable of activating complement. Among the patients, those with alleles causing MBL deficiency presented lower levels of cytokines and chemokines possibly implicated in symptom development. These findings suggest a protective effect of genetically determined MBL deficiency against the development and progression of chronic CD cardiomyopathy.

Hepatitis B virus ( HBV ) is a major cause of liver disease in humans and leads to 250, 000 deaths annually. Interferons are a family of cytokines that are produced by the host to control viral infection. Interferon α ( IFN-α/β ) is a type I interferon produced by the host to control the replication of viruses, such as HIV. Interferon β ( IFN-β ) is a member of the same family of cytokines and is used to treat hepatitis B virus ( HBV ) infection in patients with sustained response to only a minority of patients. HBV is a positive-strand RNA virus and replicates via a reverse-transcription mechanism. We used HBV transgenic mice to study the effects of IFN-α/β on HBV in vivo. Our results indicated that IFN-α/β could suppress HBV replication when viral load is high and enhanced HBV replication when viral load is low. Further studies revealed an important role of IFN-α/β in stimulating viral growth and prolonging viremia when viral load is low. This use of an innate immune response to enhance its replication and persistence may represent a novel strategy that HBV uses to enhance its growth and spread in the early stage of viral infection when the viral load is low.

Recent studies on the evolution of viruses have shown that the number of viral genomes that establish cell infection is unexpectedly small ( 1–20 genomes ). This aspect of viral infection appears to be important for the adaptation and survival of viruses. We developed a simulation model of cell infection for tomato mosaic virus ( ToMV ), a positive-strand RNA virus. The model showed that the stochastic processes that govern the replication or degradation of individual genomes result in the infection by a small number of genomes, while a large number of infectious genomes are introduced in the cell. We also predicted two interesting characteristics regarding cell infection patterns: stochastic variation among cells in the number of viral genomes that establish infection and stochastic inequality in the accumulation of their progenies in each cell. We confirmed both characteristics experimentally, demonstrating the robustness of the model to changes in the parameter values, suggesting that other viruses could adopt similar adaptation mechanisms. Taken together, these data reveal a comprehensive picture of viral infection processes including replication, cell-to-cell transmission, and evolution.

The incidence of soil-transmitted helminth ( STH ) infections has increased in the last decade. This increase has been linked with the use of benzimidazole ( BZ ) drugs, a very common treatment in both children and adults. There is a concern that the use of BZ in areas co-endemic with other helminths ( e. g., schistosomes and roundworms ) may result in the development of BZ-resistant parasites. We investigated the operational value of including the use of BZ in areas co-endemic with other helminths ( i. e., A. lumbricoides, hookworm, and S. mansoni ). We used a cross-sectional study in children aged 4-18 years in the northeastern region of the State of Minas Gerais ( Brazil ), where three different techniques were used for the diagnosis of these helminths: formalin-Ether Sedimentation ( FES ), the Kato-Katz ( KK ) fecal thick smear, and the MM and KK. The sensitivity of each technique was calculated using the two quantification techniques as the composite standard. We found that the use of the MM did not add any diagnostic value over the KK in areas where both STHs and trematodes were co-endemic. The lower sensitivity of the MM would have an important impact on the administration of selective school-based treatment in these areas.

Perceptual integration is a fundamental process that allows the rapidly grouping local visual elements into an organized object ( i. e., perceptual integration ). Despite its importance, the underlying neuronal mechanisms remain poorly understood. In this study, we used magnetoencephalography ( MEG ) recordings in combination with a temporal response function ( TRF ) approach to dissociate the time-resolved neuronal response that specifically tracks the perceptual grouping course. We demonstrate that perceptual integration initiates robust and rapid responses along the dorsal visual pathway in a hierarchical manner, faster than the ventral pathway. Specifically, the anterior intraparietal sulcus ( IPS ) responds first ( i. e., within 100 ms ), followed by activities backpropagating along the dorsal pathway to early visual areas ( EVAs ). The IPS-to-EVA response profile fails to appear when the global form could not be perceived. Our results support the crucial function of the dorsal visual pathway in perceptual integration by quickly extracting a coarse global template ( i. e., an initial object representation ) within first 100 ms to guide subsequent local sensory processing so that the ambiguities in the visual inputs can be efficiently resolved.

Recent research has provided mechanistic insight into the important contributions of the gut microbiota to vertebrate biology, but questions remain about the evolutionary processes that have shaped this symbiosis. In the present study, we identified in the mouse model a high degree of genomic plasticity among strains of the bacterial species Lactobacillus reuteri. We also identified genomic differences between strains originating from different vertebrate hosts that have been experimentally and theoretically shown to be functionally distinct. These results provided experimental evidence and a molecular basis for the evolution of host specificity in a vertebrate gut symbiont.

The mosquito immune system utilizes the activation of the Akt protein to control blood feeding and the immune response to the parasite Plasmodium falciparum. In the insect, this combined effect is necessary to eliminate the infection. Yet, the mechanisms underlying the physiological effect of Akt activation in mosquito midgut are poorly understood. In this study, we have discovered that the mosquito immune response is initiated by a sustained activation of the Akt protein, which triggers a cascade of events to alter the mitochondrial function and induce cell death. In addition, we found that the mosquito immune response is initiated by a combination of high levels of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species ( RNOS ) production and decreased levels of oxidative phosphorylation. These results provide novel insights into how the mosquito immune response operates to control blood feeding and malaria parasites.

HIV-1 is a very successful human pathogen, able to integrate its genome into the host DNA. This process is difficult to control, because it involves a series of interactions between the viral proteins and the cellular DNA. We have previously shown that remodeling of the chromatin structure is an important part of the integration process. However, it is not known if and how the chromatin structure affects the function of the viral integrase. We found that remodeling of chromatin by the SWI/SNF complex reorganizes the chromatin structure in such a way that the viral integrase is less efficient. However, we also show that in addition to the role of the SWI/SNF complex, the remodeling also has a direct effect on the integration process. We found that remodeling of chromatin by the SWI/SNF complex is required for efficient integration of the viral genome in the stable nucleosome region. Finally, we used a large number of cellular integration sites from diverse organisms and identified a correlation between chromatin remodeling and integration. Our data indicate that some chromatin structures are refractory for integration and that coupling between nucleosome remodeling and HIV-1 integration is required to overcome this natural barrier.

Leprosy is an infectious disease that causes deformities and disabilities. It is caused by a bacterium, Mycobacterium leprae, which can infect skin and nerves. It is thought that the infection may be chronic and that the skin and nerve lesions are the result of immune activation in the skin and the nerves. The role of immune activation in the disease is poorly understood, and previous studies have shown that both cytokines and immune activation are important for leprosy development. In this study we analysed the role of immune activation in the development of skin and nerve lesions. We found that 46% of skin biopsies showed evidence of Type 1 reaction ( T1R ) and 13% showed evidence of Type 2 reaction ( T2R ). We also found that cytokines and immune activation are associated with T1R. The three cytokines, iNOS, TGF-β and TNF-α, were all detected at higher levels in patients with BT leprosy. TNF-α was detected in 28% of the biopsies, and iNOS and TGF-β were detected in 88%. The results of this study show that cytokine and immune activation are associated with T1R.

The microtubule ( MT ) cytoskeleton is a molecular scaffold that is essential for many aspects of cell function. The precise nature of this function depends on the nature and nature of the MT-binding proteins. These include proteins that bind MTs in a way that alters their properties, or proteins that interfere with MT-binding. In this study, we have used a combination of bioinformatic and cellular approaches to identify novel MT-binding proteins and to characterize the interactions of these proteins with MT-binding proteins. We have identified 21 genes whose expression is dependent on the MT-binding proteins, and have validated their roles in MT-binding by combining this approach with RNAi, a method that identifies genes with reduced or absent expression levels. We have also used 2D PAGE and 1D PAGE to identify the cellular function of MT-binding proteins. We have combined these approaches to identify and characterise novel MT-binding proteins from a range of cell types. Our results demonstrate the utility of a multi-disciplinary approach in identifying novel MT-binding proteins.

Wolfram syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by loss of function mutations in the Wolfram syndrome 1 gene ( WFS1 ) that cause age-associated neurodegeneration and diabetes mellitus. Wolfram syndrome is characterized by neurodegeneration and behavioral deficits. The WFS1 protein is predicted to be a membrane-resident protein and resides in the endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ). wfs1 is the Drosophila homolog of Wolfram syndrome 1 ( WFS1 ), which is expressed in neurons and glial cells. Previous studies have shown that WFS1 is a transcription factor that regulates neuronal gene expression, but the mechanism by which WFS1 influences neuronal survival and function remains unclear. Here, we show that neuronal and glial cell knockdown induced behavioral deficits and neurodegeneration in the fly brain, and neurodegeneration was accompanied by increased susceptibility to oxidative stress-, excitotoxicity- or tauopathy-induced behavioral deficits and neurodegeneration. Our results indicate that wfs1 has important functions in both cell types. These findings provide important information for understanding the mechanisms underlying age-associated neurodegeneration and for developing disease-modifying strategies against age-associated neurodegenerative diseases.

In birds, the order in which birds sing is controlled by a combination of neural, auditory, and cognitive factors. In this study, we examine the song of the domesticated canary, a complex Melian mimic whose song consists of syllables, grouped into phrases that are arranged in flexible sequences. We show that the organization of phrases is determined by long-range rules: the choice of what phrase to sing next in a given context depends on the history of the song, and for some syllables, highly specific rules produce correlations in song over timescales of up to ten seconds. The neural basis of these long-range correlations may provide insight into how complex behaviors are assembled from more elementary, stereotyped modules.

The frequent interactions of rodents with humans make them a common source of zoonotic infections. To obtain an unbiased measure of the viral diversity in the enteric tract of wild rodents we sequenced, amplified, and analyzed the complete viral RNA and DNA in the feces of 105 wild rodents. We identified in decreasing frequency sequences related to the mammalian viruses families Circoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Parvoviridae, Papillomaviridae, Adenoviridae, and Coronaviridae. Seventeen small circular DNA genomes containing one or two replicase genes distantly related to the Circoviridae representing several potentially new viral families were characterized. The next largest fraction of the rodent fecal virome was related to insect viruses of the Densoviridae, Iridoviridae, Polydnaviridae, Dic mong virus, and Bromoviridae families followed by plant virus-related sequences in the Nanoviridae, Geminiviridae, Phycodnaviridae, Secoviridae, Tymoviridae, Alphaflexiviridae, and Tombusviridae families reflecting the largely insect and plant rodent diet. Phylogenetic analyses of full and partial viral genomes therefore revealed many previously unreported viral species, genera, and families. Our results demonstrate that the large number of still uncharacterized viruses in mammals might reflect past zoonoses.

Repetitive DNA sequences are often associated with altered gene expression, including the utilization of iron-binding proteins. Several of these modifications are thought to affect the stability or the activity of proteins encoded by these sequences, but the precise effect of the DNA expansion is poorly understood. Here, we investigated the replication of a gene called Frataxin, in the presence of an expanded repeat. We found that the DNA sequence of the mutant gene is not completely different from the normal one, but the two genes are differentially distributed along the replication pathway. This is the first time the effect of an expanded repeat on a human gene is assessed, and the presence of an expanded repeat is shown to affect the replication of a gene carrying the mutation.

Schistosomiasis is a major public health problem in the tropics and subtropics. The transmission cycle requires a freshwater snail host, and people get reinfected rapidly after treatment. As the entire population does not get reinfected at the same rate, it is possible that host factors may play a dominant role in determining resistance or susceptibility to reinfection with schistosomes. Here, we systematically reviewed and meta-analyzed studies that reported associations between reinfection with the principal human-infecting species ( S. mansoni, S. japonicum and S. haematobium ) and host socio-demographic, epidemiological, immunological and genetic factors. We also assessed quality and identified several important factors to determine which are the major determinants of reinfection. These factors are major determinants of exposure and disease transmission. This study contributes to the understanding of host-parasite interaction as it affects reinfection, and is a potential tool to guide planning and tailoring of community interventions to target high-risk groups.

Human African trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness is a parasitic disease that causes chronic and often fatal encephalitis in the African continent. The progression of the disease from a chronic to an encephalitic stage is accompanied by alterations in the serum and cerebrospinal fluid levels and by alterations in the expression of genes coding for interferon ( IFN ) -γ, Cxcl9, Cxcl10, Cxcl11, and CXCL10 in the serum and cerebrospinal fluid, respectively. However, the role of IFN-γ, Cxcl9, Cxcl10, and Cxcl11 in the initiation of the early encephalitic stage of the disease, including the development of neuroinflammation, remains unclear. In this study, we investigated the expression of IFN-γ, CXCL10, and Cxcl9 in the brain, and the levels of CXCL10 in the cerebrospinal fluid before and during the encephalitic stage of trypanosome infection, and correlated these with the levels of sleep/wake changes in a rat model of the disease. Our results show a modest increase in Cxcl9 and Cxcl11 transcripts in the brain and the emergence of sleep/wake cycle fragmentation at 14 dpi. The latter could provide combined biomarkers of the early encephalitic stage of the disease.

Cyclic nucleotide-modulated ( HCN ) channels are membrane receptors that control electrical rhythmicity in specialized brain and heart cells. We investigated how the second messenger cAMP, a ubiquitous intracellular signal, modulates the voltage-dependent activation of HCN channels. We quantitatively analysed the voltage-dependent activation of HCN channels and its modulation by cAMP using global fits of hidden Markovian models to complex experimental data. We show that voltage-dependent activation is essentially governed by two separable voltage-dependent steps followed by voltage-independent opening of the pore. According to this model analysis, the binding of cAMP to the channels exerts multiple effects on the voltage-dependent gating: It stabilizes the open pore, reduces the total gating charge from ~8 to ~5, makes an additional closed state outside the activation pathway accessible and strongly accelerates the ON-gating but not the OFF-gating. Furthermore, the open channel has a much slower computed OFF-gating current than the closed channel, in both the absence and presence of cAMP. Together, these results provide detailed new insight into the voltage- and cAMP-induced activation gating of HCN channels.

Microbial pathogens have evolved diverse strategies to survive inside and outside of host cells. Many intracellular pathogens, including Salmonella enterica and Mycobacterium tuberculosis, have acquired the MgtC virulence factor to enable multiplication inside macrophages. MgtC is also found in Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a major opportunistic pathogen, and here we investigate for the first time the role of MgtC in the virulence of an extracellular pathogen, P. aeruginosa. Our results indicate that the P. aeruginosa mgtC mutant is attenuated in the systemic infection model of zebrafish embryos, and strikingly, the attenuated phenotype is dependent on the presence of macrophages. In ex vivo experiments, the P. aeruginosa mgtC mutant is more sensitive to macrophage killing than the wild-type strain. However, wild-type and mutant strains behave similarly toward macrophage killing when macrophages are treated with an inhibitor of the vacuolar proton ATPase. Importantly, P. aeruginosa mgtC gene expression is strongly induced within macrophages and phagosome acidification contributes to an optimal expression of the gene. Thus, our results support the implication of a macrophage intracellular stage during P. aeruginosa acute infection and suggest that Pseudomonas MgtC requires phagosome acidification to play its intracellular role.

The American visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania infantum, is the most important vector-borne disease in the American continent. In Brazil there are more than 50, 000 cases per year of this disease. The Lutzomyia longipalpis species complex is the vector of this disease, but there is still no consensus regarding the number of species occurring in this complex. This raises several issues that are important to the Brazilian Ministry of Health, such as the need to consider the different Brazilian Lutzomyia longipalpis populations and the possibility of a species complex coexisting in Brazil, if the species complex is composed of a small number of closely related species. In this study we present results from a Brazilian population of L. longipalpis that represent different species but, so far, the number of species is still unknown. We also present results from a study of the male courtship songs and pheromones of some Brazilian populations, in order to compare the genetic differences among these populations and to compare them with our previous results.

In this paper, we present a novel algorithm for identifying subtypes of heterogeneous cancer. The algorithm combines information from multiple data sources to identify subtypes that are clinically relevant. We applied the algorithm to cancer subtyping data from TCGA, identifying subtypes of cancer based on gene expression profiles, miRNA expression profiles, DNA methylation and proteomics. We also applied the algorithm to other cancer subtyping data, and found clinically relevant subtypes of both TCGA and PCL. We showed that the algorithm is scalable, and thus can be applied to large heterogeneous datasets such as TCGA, which have high dimensionality. We also demonstrated that the algorithm can be used on heterogeneous datasets with heterogeneous subtypes, and that it can identify clinically relevant subtypes.

In order to persist and cause disease, ( herpes ) viruses have evolved sophisticated strategies to evade host immunity. Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ), a herpesvirus associated with several human malignancies, can cause severe disease in humans. The virus reprograms the host immune response by activating cellular receptors involved in recognition of viral elements. TLRs sense viral infection and activate host antiviral immune responses. We have previously shown that TLRs are subject to regulation by ubiquitination, a process in which proteins are conjugated to cellular receptors. Ubiquitination controls activation of TLRs, which is critical to the early innate immune response. Here, we have investigated how EBV suppresses TLR signaling. We show that the large tegument protein BPLF1, a component of the EBV particle, acts as a functional deubiquitinase and suppresses activation of TLRs. This results in reduced activation of NF-κB, a critical antiviral immune response gene. Our results show that EBV uses deubiquitination to counteract innate immune responses.

Plague is a deadly infection that is still spreading in several countries despite modern medical and veterinary care. The virulence factors are encoded by Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that replicates inside host macrophages. Yersinia virulence factor Y ( YopM ) is a crucial virulence factor of the Yersinia pestis, which causes bubonic plague. YopM enters the nucleus of host cells and can interact with the cellular factors to affect the host cell physiology. In this work we show that YopM interacts with the cellular factor DDX3. We also provide the structure of the YopM:DDX3 complex. Our results suggest that the interaction of YopM with DDX3 determines the extent of phosphorylation of RSK1 in the nucleus to control transcription of immunosuppressive cytokines.

Eukaryotic cells have evolved various mechanisms to control viral infection. Among them, RNA silencing is a highly conserved mechanism that prevents viral infection and restricts the spread of viral RNA. Viruses, however, encode proteins that counteract or evade this silencing mechanism. We have addressed the role of one of the viral proteins, movement protein, in counteracting RNA silencing. Our results show that movement protein enhances the spread of RNA silencing. We also provide evidence that movement protein is required for the propagation of RNA silencing in the infected host. Our results suggest that movement protein enhances the spread of silencing signal, while suppressing or enhancing its spread.

The differentiation of megakaryocytes is a complex process that involves the action of multiple extracellular signals. We have shown that a senescence-like arrest occurs during megakaryocytic maturation, leading to the arrest of cell proliferation in the normal cell-cycle and inhibition of DNA replication. This arrest was observed in the normal cell-cycle, as well as in the malignant myeloid cell-lineage derived from patients with myeloproliferative neoplasms, suggesting that the physiological arrest occurs during the normal maturation of the cell-cycle and differentiation of the myeloid cell-cycle. We also showed that the senescence-like arrest was not observed in the malignant megakaryocytes, suggesting that the physiological arrest is not required for the progression to the malignant state. Our data provide new insights into the regulation of cell-cycle arrest and the physiological arrest during megakaryocytic maturation.

The actin cytoskeleton plays a fundamental role in cell shape and motility, and its dysfunction causes a variety of diseases such as muscular dystrophy and cancer. The force generation by actin polymerization is a complex process that involves both biochemical and mechanical interactions between actin molecules. We present a mathematical model for the evolution of the F-actin distribution in three dimensions. The model is used to calculate the effects of mutations in the actin cytoskeleton and to evaluate the effects of variations in molecular branching and polymerization rates.

The opsin genes of the rod and cone photoreceptors are the light sensing cells of the retina. The opsin genes are duplicated in the fish, and their expression is regulated in a similar manner. In this study, we used the zebrafish model to investigate the role of retinoic acid ( RA ), a major light-regulating molecule in the retina, in regulating opsin gene expression. We found that RA regulates differential expression of the opsin genes in the zebrafish embryo, and that RA signaling in cones regulates opsin gene expression. This is the first evidence that RA signaling regulates differential expression of opsin genes in a tandemly duplicated array.

Many fungal pathogens transition between a yeast and filamentous state upon host cell contact. These morphological changes alter host-microbe interactions, and are critical for pathogenesis. While some fungi switch to a yeast form, others switch to a filamentous form. This switch is critical for fungal pathogenicity, but whether this morphological change contributes to virulence is unclear. Here, we use the human fungal pathogen Mucor circinelloides to show that the calcineurin pathway plays key roles in the transition between yeast and filamentous forms. In the presence of the calcineurin inhibitor FK506, Mucor exhibits exclusively multi-budded yeast growth. We also show that the calcineurin pathway is required for hyphal growth and encodes a novel calcineurin regulatory subunit. Disruption of the cnbR gene encoding the sole calcineurin B subunit resulted in a series of mutant strains, each lacking the only calcineurin B subunit. Furthermore, the cnaA mutant is hypersensitive to calcineurin inhibitors and produces a mixture of yeast and hyphae in aerobic culture. The cnaA mutant also produces spores that are larger than wild-type, and spore size is correlated with virulence potential. Our results demonstrate that the calcineurin pathway orchestrates the yeast-hyphal and spore size dimorphic transitions that contribute to virulence of this common zygomycete fungal pathogen.

Anopheline mosquitoes are the primary vectors of human malaria parasites, yet a comprehensive understanding of their interaction with the parasite, including the role of hemolysis, in malaria parasite development and transmission is still lacking. We have developed transgenic Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes that express the C-type lectin CEL-III from the sea cucumber, Cucumaria echinata, in a midgut-specific manner. In the present study, we demonstrate that CEL-III exhibits strong and rapid hemolytic activity toward human and rat erythrocytes in the presence of serum. Moreover, CEL-III exhibits cytotoxicity toward ookinetes, demonstrating that C-type lectin is a potent cytolytic molecule. In the presence of serum, the hemolysis activity of CEL-III is significantly reduced, but significant inhibition of ookinete development is still observed in the presence of serum. Thus, our data reveal a novel role of hemolysis in the malaria parasite development. We also show that CEL-III inhibits sporogonic development of Plasmodium berghei, the most prevalent human malaria parasite. Our results provide a comprehensive understanding of the hemolysis mechanism of C-type lectin, and provide the first evidence of stably engineered Anopheline mosquitoes that affect the Plasmodium transmission dynamics.

Human herpesviruses, such as Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ) and Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ), have the potential to cause a wide variety of diseases including cancer. Activation of human oncogenic herpesvirus lytic replication is crucial for viral tumorigenesis. We found that the host protein STAT6 is important for the activation of KSHV lytic replication. STAT6 promotes degradation of its own protein via the proteasome and lysosome systems. Moreover, ubiquitylation of STAT6 is dramatically associated with the increased ubiquitylated form of tripartite motif family like 2 ( TRIML2 ) for prolonged cell survival and virion production, which is also commonly observed in lytic activation of EBV, KSHV and cytomegalovirus. Our study suggests that degradation of STAT6 is important for the lytic activation of KSHV and as such, may be an attractive therapeutic target.

The flexibility of gene expression is an essential attribute for all living organisms and yet the molecular bases of this flexibility remain poorly understood. The evolution of transcriptional regulation is a particularly important source of such variation, since it can be directly linked to phenotypic variation. Here, we investigated the evolution of transcriptional regulation by analyzing the functions of the general transcription factors in two model yeasts: S. cerevisiae and C. albicans. We show that each of these transcription factors has a complex regulatory network that has been massively reshaped in cis and trans. While the transcription factors in both species are able to activate genes involved in ribosome biogenesis and function, the general transcription factors in S. cerevisiae and C. albicans do not have a similar function in controlling ribosomal gene expression, but instead activate ribosomal genes and rDNA expression. We show that these changes occurred in transcription factor wiring with cellular functions, movements in transcription factor hierarchies, DNA-binding specificity, and regulatory complexes assembly to promote global changes in the architecture of the fungal transcriptional regulatory network.

The human brain is a complex system with many differences that are determined by a variety of genetic and environmental factors. We investigated whether specific genetic variants, associated to psychiatric disorders, were under selection during human evolution. We analyzed the genetic code from five psychiatric disorders: attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, autism spectrum disorder ( ASD ), bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder, and schizophrenia ( SCZ ). The analysis focused on the genetic code of common genetic variants and the presence or absence of selected variants. We found that ASD-associated variants were significantly more frequent in the top-5% of the genome than other genetic variants. We also identified genes and biological processes that may have been under selection in the human brain. In particular, we found that some ASD-associated variants were enriched in brain and pituitary tissues. In addition, we found that genes involved in the development of the brain and in the synapse, as well as axon guidance, were also strongly enriched in these tissues. These results suggest that ASD risk alleles may have been under positive selection during human evolution due to their involvement in neurogenesis and cognitive ability.

Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacteria Brucella serovar Typhimurium and Brucella prowazekii. The diagnosis of brucellosis is difficult and requires a prolonged course of treatment. This makes the interpretation of the serologic results of the tests crucial. Here, we evaluated 5307 patients for serologic evidence of IgG and IgM antibodies to Brucella antigens. A serologic assay ( IgM antibody detection in the absence of immunoglobulin ) was performed using the Brucella antigen-specific antibodies as a gold standard. We found that the serologic evidence of IgM antibodies per se does not necessarily indicate the presence of Brucella antigen in the blood. The serologic evidence of IgM antibodies and not IgG antibodies is highly important in the diagnosis of human brucellosis. We found that the serologic evidence of IgM antibodies per se is not enough to confirm the diagnosis of brucellosis. We also found that serologic evidence of IgM antibodies per se is not a useful parameter in the diagnosis of human brucellosis. Taken into account the clinical history of the patients and the epidemiological context, the serologic evidence of IgM antibodies per se is probably not enough to diagnose the disease.

A major challenge in vector control and malaria elimination is to prevent the mosquito vector from transmitting the disease to humans. Vector control is often attempted by reducing mosquito populations, such as adult mosquito populations or offspring development. Anopheles gambiae mosquitoes transmit malaria, a disease that kills nearly half a million people annually. In this study, we use behavioral analyses and gene silencing to show that a large family of odorant receptors ( AgORs ), as well as a newly identified family of candidate chemosensory genes, are required for proper olfactory behavior in this species. Our results provide novel insight into the mechanism of olfaction in An. gambiae. Our results also reveal the existence of at least two distinct olfactory signaling pathways that are active in An. gambiae: one system requires direct AgOR-mediated olfaction, while the other system does not. These advances may ultimately enhance the development of vector control strategies, targeting olfactory pathways in mosquitoes to reduce the catastrophic effects of malaria and other mosquito-borne diseases.

Hypophosphatemia ( XLH ) is the most frequent inherited rickets in humans, and mutations in the phosphate-regulating gene with homologs to endopeptidases on the X-chromosome ( PHEX ) cause hypophosphatemia and a wide range of other phenotypes. Hyp mice, a murine homologue of XLH, are characterized by hypophosphatemia, increased serum fibroblast growth factor-23 ( Fgf23 ), and osteomalacia. Although Fgf23 is known to be responsible for hypophosphatemia and reduced vitamin D hormone levels in Hyp mice, its putative role as an auto-/paracrine osteomalacia-causing factor has not been explored. We recently reported that Fgf23 is a suppressor of tissue nonspecific alkaline phosphatase ( Tnap ) transcription via FGF receptor-3 ( FGFR3 ) signaling, leading to inhibition of mineralization through accumulation of the TNAP substrate pyrophosphate. Here, we report that the pyrophosphate concentration is increased in Hyp bones, and that Tnap expression is decreased in Hyp-derived osteocyte-like cells but not in Hyp-derived osteoblasts. Blocking of increased Fgf23-FGFR3 signaling with anti-Fgf23 antibodies or an FGFR3 inhibitor partially restored the suppressed TNAP activity, phosphate production, and mineralization in Hyp mice. Moreover, treatment of wild-type osteoblasts or mice with recombinant FGF23 suppressed T Nap-related TNAP activity and increased pyrophosphate concentrations. In conclusion, we have identified a novel mechanism contributing to the mineralization defect in Hyp mice.

Long Interspersed Element ( L1 ) elements are transposable elements that have accumulated in the human genome since the onset of genome evolution. Some of them have been hypothesised to be involved in X inactivation, a mechanism by which the host protects itself from DNA damage. We analysed the effect of L1 interruption on the human genome and found that L1 elements are significantly less frequently interrupted than on the autosomes, while L1s near genes that escape inactivation are more frequently interrupted, supporting the hypothesis that L1s on the X chromosome play a role in its inactivation. In addition, we show that TEs are less frequently interrupted in introns than in intergenic regions, probably due to selection against the expansion of introns, but the insertion pattern of Alus is similar to other repeats.

Many pathogens are able to persist in the presence of their host's immune system. Evolutionary biologists have hypothesized that such persistence serves as a means to increase the likelihood of transmission by a pathogen to a new host. The most commonly invoked benefit of such persistence is increased likelihood of transmission by a long-lived host, which is called premunition. Here we investigate a different benefit: immunity to disease, which is termed concomitant immunity, or premunition. We show that in the protozoan parasite Leishmania major, premunition does not exclude transmission of the original infecting organism. Indeed, we show that super-infection, which would favor transmission of the original infecting organism, can be achieved with minimal pathology. This finding has important consequences to the maintenance and generation of parasite diversity in the natural Leishmania infectious cycle alternating between mammalian and sand fly hosts.

E. festucae is an endophytic fungus which maintains symptomless infection in the plant host. However, this is a key requirement for endophytes, a feature which distinguishes them from pathogenic fungi. Epichloë festucae is an obligate biotroph, making it difficult to manipulate the host plant. In this study, we investigated the roles of Cdc42 and RacA, two closely related Rho GTPases, in controlling endophytic growth. We found that Cdc42 and RacA regulate the formation of the primary hyphae ( conidial germination ) and are involved in the control of the intercalary ( primary hyphal ) growth. We also demonstrate that Cdc42 and RacA are involved in the regulation of hyphal growth and the production of ROS, which are key components of the plant defense system. Our results suggest that the specific interactions of these Rho GTPases with BemA and NoxR are important for their functional differentiation during endophytic infection.
