Depletion of HDAC8 caused loss of centrosome cohesion, disrupted the microtubule organization, and enhanced infection of the cell. HDAC1, on the other hand, promoted infection of Uukuniemi virus ( a bunyavirus ). Our results suggest that HDACs are important regulators of influenza virus infection and other late penetrating viruses.

A 2/5 dose of melarsomide is recommended by the WHO for treatment of Human African Trypanosomiasis ( HAT ). Melarsomide is a highly effective drug, but may cause severe side effects. The Gambia is a large equine and human population, and the Gambia government supports the use of melarsomide for HAT treatment. The treatment for HAT in The Gambia has reduced the number of treated equines in the 1970s and the number of new human cases now reduced to a low level. Working equines are considered to be a significant proportion of the population that are not included in this study. This study was conducted to determine whether treatment with the three trypanocides ( isometamidium, melarsomide and diminazene ) could be safely used in equines, and to determine the efficacy and safety of each drug. The study was conducted on horses and donkeys to assess the efficacy of the treatment and the safety of each drug. The results showed that all three treatments performed well in the treated equines. There was no significant difference in efficacy between the three treatments, and treatment duration of action was similar. The data support the continued use of isometamidium following careful dose titration in donkeys and diminazene for trypanosomiasis in equines using the doses and routes of administration reported.

In this study, we investigated the utility of virus diversity obtained by next-generation sequencing ( NGS ) in estimating the time since HIV-1 infection in newly diagnosed patients. The results were validated on two additional NGS datasets from 31 patients. The results showed that NGS can be used to estimate time since HIV-1 infection in a much more efficient way than the existing methodologies. The NGS method, which estimates diversity based on the number of ambiguous sites in the Sanger sequences, has a much higher precision than the current methodologies. We also showed that the NGS method had a much higher error rate than other methods. Our results show that NGS can be used to estimate time since HIV-1 infection in a much more efficient manner than other methodologies.

Systems biology aims at understanding the function and dynamics of the components of biological systems, from the gene to the cell, in a context that is relevant to the disease process. In this context, the integration of experimental data with the knowledge of the underlying metabolic network can be a key approach to establish a systems biology view of the disease process. In this work, we present a method for the integration of extracellular and intracellular data sets, which is referred to as the integration of information from two sources. Our method uses the knowledge of the Human Proteome Atlas ( HPA ), which contains the complete list of genes in the human cell, as the main source of evidence. This information is used to infer the HPA-based metabolic network of a given cell type. We applied this method to 69 different human cell types and 16 different cancer types, which allowed for the identification of potential drug targets for cancer treatment.

Alu elements are one of the most important sources of structural variation in primate genomes. Here, we compare the chimpanzee and human genomes to determine the extent of Alu recombination-mediated deletion ( ARMD ) in the chimpanzee genome since the divergence of the chimpanzee and human lineages ( ∼6 million y ago ). Combining computational data analysis and experimental verification, we have identified 726 deletions in the human lineage, and 660 deletions in the chimpanzee lineage. The ARMD events essentially counteract the genomic expansion caused by chimpanzee-specific Alu inserts. The RefSeq databases indicate that 13 exons in six genes, annotated as either demonstrably or putatively functional in the human genome, and 299 intronic regions have been deleted through ARMDs in the chimpanzee lineage. Therefore, our data suggest that this process may contribute to the genomic and phenotypic diversity between chimpanzees and humans. In addition, we found four independent ARMD events at orthologous loci in the gorilla or orangutan genomes. This suggests that human orthologs of loci at which ARMD events have already occurred in other nonhuman primate genomes may be “at-risk” motifs for future deletions, which may subsequently contribute to human lineage-specific genetic rearrangements and disorders.

Chagas disease, a chronic condition caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, affects 8 million people worldwide, and it is considered the most important in Latin America. During the chronic phase, the disease is also an important health problem in industrialized countries, since it has been linked to the industrialized lifestyle. T. cruzi infection is characterized by an impairment of the peripheral immune system, as evidenced by the lack of CD4+ T cells and their effector functions. We previously demonstrated that T. cruzi infection induces an impairment of the Th1-like T cell compartment, a population that is crucial for the generation of T helper type 1 cytokines and for the development of T cell regulatory functions. In this study, we investigated the effect of T. cruzi infection upon the T cell regulatory compartment. We confirmed that T. cruzi infection induces a marked loss of T cell regulatory cell number associated to cell precursor exhaustion, partially avoided by glucocorticoid ablation- and IL-2 survival factor depletion. At the same time, we observed alterations in the T cell regulatory compartment. Moreover, we found that tTregs accumulate within the CD4 single-positive compartment, enhancing after the infection the expression of signature markers ( CD25, CD62L and GITR ) and they also displaying alterations in the expression of migration-associated molecules ( α chains of VLAs and chemokine receptors ). Our data indicate that the evident loss of T cell regulatory cell number may compromise the composition of T cell regulatory compartment, and such alterations over time may be partially related to the immune dysregulation observed in the chronic phase of the disease.

The study of the three-dimensional structure of chromosomes has been advancing rapidly in recent years. While a number of methods for 3D reconstruction of genomic models based on Hi-C data were proposed, most of the analyses in the field have been performed on different 3D representation forms ( such as graphs ). Here, we reproduce most of the previous results on the 3D genomic organization of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, based on analysis of 3D reconstructions. We show that many of these results can be reproduced in sparse reconstructions, generated from a small fraction of the experimental data ( 5% of the data ), and study the properties of such models. Finally, we propose for the first time a novel approach for improving the accuracy of 3D reconstructions by introducing additional predicted physical interactions to the model, based on orthologous interactions in an evolutionary-related organism and based on predicted functional interactions between genes. We demonstrate that this approach indeed leads to the reconstruction of improved models.

A new wave of portable biosensors allows for frequent measurement of health-related physiology. We investigated the use of these devices to monitor human physiological changes during various activities and their role in managing health and diagnosing and analyzing disease. We found that health-related changes in particular environments are associated with physiological macro-phenotypes such as fatigue. Importantly, we used these data to develop a framework to identify abnormal physiological signals from longitudinal data for facile disease detection. We also used this information to develop and test a new algorithm that can distinguish between insulin-sensitive and -resistant individuals. Overall, these results indicate that portable biosensors provide useful information for monitoring personal activities and physiology and are likely to play an important role in managing health and enabling affordable health care access to groups traditionally limited by socioeconomic class or remote geography.

Facial attractiveness is a complex human trait that is of great interest in both academia and industry. Previous studies have shown that genes underlies the variability in human facial attractiveness. However, it is difficult to identify which genetic variants are responsible for the observed differences in human facial attractiveness. Here, we performed a genome-wide association study to identify genetic variants associated with human facial attractiveness. Our analysis identified two loci, one near the IIS gene and another near the CASP12 gene. We also demonstrated that human facial attractiveness is under strong genetic control in both sexes. Our results revealed sex-specific genetic architecture of facial attractiveness and provided fundamental new insights into its genetic basis.

Plague is one of the most devastating infectious diseases of mankind. During its history, the Black Death has killed tens of millions of people in Europe, leaving misery and devastation in its wake. We investigated the Black Death in the context of ancient human skeletons from Northern, Central and Southern Europe. We found that the Black Death was caused by Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague. We confirmed that Y. pestis caused the Black Death and that it later epidemics on the entire European continent over the course of centuries. Furthermore, by comparing the DNA and protein sequences of Y. pestis strains isolated from patients and from Black Death victims, we identified two previously unknown but related clades of Y. pestis that are ancestral to modern strains of Y. pestis biovars Orientalis and Medievalis. Our results clarify the etiology of the Black Death and provide a framework for a detailed historical reconstruction of the infection routes followed by this disease.

Entamoeba histolytica is the most common protozoan parasite causing amebic dysentery in humans. However, E. histolytica is capable of infecting a much wider range of individuals, and the close relationship between this organism and its close relative Entamoeba dispar, which is a non-pathogenic parasite, makes it difficult to directly link the molecular basis of these differences. In this study, we used a two-dimensional proteomic approach to compare the abundance of 141 and 189 proteins from E. histolytica, respectively, in the presence and absence of E. histolytica in human cells. We found that E. histolytica has a higher level of NADPH-dependent alcohol dehydrogenase activity than E. dispar and that some of its proteins can be localized to the surface of E. histolytica. Episomal overexpression of one of these proteins, E. histolytica alcohol dehydrogenase 3, in E. histolytica trophozoites resulted in only subtle phenotypic differences in E. histolytica virulence in animal models of amebic colitis and amebic liver abscess, making it difficult to directly link EhADH3 levels to virulence differences between E. histolytica and less-pathogenic Entamoeba.

How the brain drives cognitive and motor systems in response to incentive motivation is an important question in neuroscience. We used functional MRI to characterize the brain activity associated with incentive motivation, cognitive and motor performance, and we identified a brain region, the ventral prefrontal cortex and the ventral basal ganglia, as the common motivational center for both cognitive and motor systems. We then used computational modeling to identify the neural mechanisms underpinning this motivational system and its role in cognitive and motor performance. Our results suggest that the interaction between cognitive and motor systems is mediated by a common motivational center.

B. bovis, the etiological agent of babesiosis, is a blood-feeding ectoparasite responsible for massive losses in animal production. A novel vaccine is urgently needed to control the parasite. To achieve this, the protective antigens from the parasite must be expressed in the vector. Here we describe the development and evaluation of a novel live B. bovis vaccine expressing the protective antigen glutathione-S-transferase from H. longicornis ( HlGST ). The recombinant parasite line was electroporated with a plasmid containing the effector protein Ef-1α ( HlGST ). Electroporation and selection of the two independent genes into a single transfecting line resulted in the emergence of a mixed B. bovis line ( HlGST-Cln ) containing both genes in the surface of the merozoite ( HlGST ). The HlGST-Cln line was used to immunize calves. The results show that HlGST-Cln is highly effective at inducing anti-glutathione-S-transferase antibodies, and also reduces the tick lifespan and fecundity of R. microplus feeding in experimentally inoculated animals.

Humans have a number of unusual biological characteristics in common with other species. These include the fact that, like other species, humans possess two copies of most of the genes that encode proteins in our cells, and that these two genes are very different. A consequence of this difference is that the body asymmetry that characterizes humans and other species is largely due to structural differences between the two genes. However, it is not known how these differences cause asymmetry in the human hand. We have used a large meta-analysis of genetic variation in individuals with severe hand problems ( dyslexia ) to identify the genetic locus responsible for this asymmetry. We identified a single genetic variant, which is highly associated with hand skill, in a gene called PCSK6. We also found that this same genetic variant was also associated with hand skill in a large group of other species, including mice. We then identified a new locus of hand skill, which is also highly associated with mouse hand skill, but is not a genetic variant in humans. This finding suggests that humans are doing far less of a genetic task than mice, but that there is an important difference in hand function between humans and other species.

Apicomplexan parasites are a large group of parasites that cause disease in humans, animals and other vertebrates. They are able to invade and multiply inside the host cells that they infect. To do this, they need to bind to the parasite surface molecules, which they have recently identified as the ‘moving junction’ ( MJ ). Here we show that a protein called AMA1, which is secreted from the parasite and is involved in the MJ formation, binds to the MJ complex, and that this interaction is crucial for invasion by Apicomplexa parasites. We also show that the interaction is conserved between Plasmodium falciparum, which causes malaria, and Toxoplasma gondii, which causes toxoplasmosis. These findings suggest that AMA1 is a crucial receptor for invasion by Apicomplexa parasites.

Organoid cultures derived from colorectal cancer ( CRC ) samples are increasingly used as preclinical models for studying tumor biology and the effects of targeted therapies under conditions capturing in vitro the genetic make-up of heterogeneous and even individual neoplasms. While several studies have focused on the effect of targeted therapies on cell populations, little is known about how cell heterogeneity impacts the activity of the signaling pathway and the consequences of treatment. Here we have studied the effect of targeted therapies on heterogeneous subpopulations of colorectal cells using a cohort of well-characterized CRC organoids and performed a comparative analysis of drug response. We show that the heterogeneity of the subpopulations does not influence the activity of the KRAS/MAPK-signaling pathway and that the effects of EGFR inhibition are not influenced by the heterogeneity of the subpopulations. In addition, we obtained evidence for heterogeneity in drug response among parallel “s sibling” 3D cultures established from a single KRAS-mutant CRC. Our results imply that separate testing of drug effects in multiple subpopulations may help to elucidate molecular correlates of tumor heterogeneity and to improve therapy response prediction in patients.

Human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) is a retrovirus that infects about 20 million people worldwide. Most infected individuals remain asymptomatic despite a lifetime of exposure to the virus. The virus persists in a latent form in the T cells of the infected individual. The virus can be reactivated and multiply, a process that leads to the production of new virus particles. The pattern of viral gene expression is a key determinant of viral persistence and reactivation. We have recently developed a method to identify the integration site of the viral genome in the HTLV-1 infection. Here, we used this method to test two major predictions. First, that the viral integrations are associated with the expression of the viral gene product, proviral gene. Second, that the orientation of the provirus relative to its host gene determines proviral gene expression and in vivo clonal abundance. We found that integration targeting is strongly associated with the presence of a binding site for host transcription factors, especially for the transcription factor STAT1. The presence of the chromatin remodelling factors BRG1 and INI1 and certain host transcription factors either upstream or downstream of the provirus were strongly associated with silencing or spontaneous expression of the provirus. Cells expressing HTLV-1 Tax protein were significantly more frequent in clones of low abundance in vivo. We conclude that transcriptional interference and chromatin remodelling are critical determinants of proviral latency in natural HTLV-1 infection.

Biological processes are governed by oscillatory gene expression at different time scales. Recently, single-cell live imaging has been used to quantify the proportion of cells expressing different genes at different times. However, the analysis of this kind of time series is complicated by the fact that the expression of many genes is stochastic. We show how to overcome this difficulty by developing a method that can distinguish oscillatory gene expression from random fluctuations of non-oscillatory expression. Our method can be used to classify whether a cell is oscillatory or non-oscillatory. We show that our method outperforms the peak-to-peak variability of single-cell oscillations in the simulated data, and we apply it to experimental time series from a simple genetic oscillator model and a different gene expression profile ( such as those of a constitutive promoter and an oscillator ). The method can be applied to time series from any gene network to both quantify the proportion of oscillating cells within a population and measure the period and quality of oscillations.

LncRNA-protein interactions are important regulators of gene expression. They play important roles in post-transcriptional gene regulation, splicing and translation. LncRNA sequence-based features are used to predict new lncRNA-protein interactions. Existing methods do not predict interactions for new lncRNAs ( or proteins ), which don’t have known interactions. In this paper, we propose the sequence-based feature projection ensemble learning method, “SFPEL-LPI”, to predict lncRNA-protein interactions. First, SFPEL-LPI extracts multiple lncRNA sequence-based features and protein sequence-based features. Second, SFPEL-LPI calculates multiple similarities and multiple features with a feature projection ensemble learning frame. Finally, SFPEL-LPI combines multiple similarities and multiple features with a feature projection ensemble learning frame. In computational experiments, SFPEL-LPI accurately predicts lncRNA-protein interactions and outperforms other state-of-the-art methods. More importantly, SFPEL-LPI can be applied to new lncRNAs ( or proteins ). The case studies demonstrate that our method can find out novel lncRNA-protein interactions, which are confirmed by literature. Finally, we construct a user-friendly web server, available at http://www. bioinf-tech. cn/SFPEL-LPI/.

Latin America comprises a large number of countries with a diverse population mix and a great diversity of traits. One important consequence of Latin American admixture is the mixing of European genes and local Native American genes, creating genetic diversity across the region. To identify genetic differences that are important for the development of disease and to better understand the origin of disease, a number of genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have been conducted in the region. However, there is a lack of information on the extent of admixture in Latin America. Here, we use a set of 678 genome-wide markers to study the extent of admixture across 13 Mestizo populations from seven countries in Latin America. We found evidence of different ancestry for the region in the Native American, European, and African populations. We also found evidence of different ancestry for the region in populations of both European and Native American ancestry. These results provide a better understanding of the genetic diversity in Latin America and have implications for designing future association studies.

Specialized protein translocation systems are used by many bacterial pathogens to deliver effector proteins into host cells that interfere with normal cellular functions. How the host immune system recognizes and responds to this intrusive event is not understood. Using the virulence-associated type III secretion system ( T3SS ) of Y. pseudotuberculosis, a human pathogen associated with a variety of human diseases, we investigated the mammalian host response to this secretion system. We found that macrophages devoid of Toll-like receptor ( TLR ) signaling regulate expression of 266 genes following recognition of the T3SS. This analysis revealed two temporally distinct responses that could be separated into activation of NFκB- and type I IFN-regulated genes. Extracellular bacteria were capable of triggering these signaling events, as inhibition of bacterial uptake had no effect on the subsequent innate immune response. The cytosolic peptidoglycan sensors Nod1 and Nod2 and the inflammasome component caspase-1 were not involved in NFκB activation following recognition of the T3SS. However, caspase-1 was required for secretion of the inflammatory cytokine IL-1β in response to T3SS-positive Y. pseudotuberculosis. In order to characterize the bacterial requirements for induction of this novel TLR-, Nod1/2-, and caspase-1-independent response, we used Y. pseudotuberculosis strains lacking specific components of the T3SS. This analysis provides new insight into the host cell recognition and response to this intriguing event.

Malaria is one of the most important tropical diseases and P. vivax is the most prevalent human parasite species. Understanding the biology of P. vivax is important for developing new therapies and developing the most effective Plasmodium culture system for research. We have developed a P. vivax Aotus-adapted P. vivax strain to use in vitro culture for the first time and to investigate the differences between different parasite cultures. We show that the P. vivax Aotus-adapted strain can grow and invade a given red blood cell type and that the culture conditions it was tested in are much more favorable than what has been previously reported. Our results also suggest that P. vivax is sensitive to different host cell nutrients and that the parasite growth and invasion can be optimised by modifying the culture medium.

Drosophila melanogaster has been a model for the study of invertebrate immunity for many years. However, there are still still gaps in our knowledge of host-virus interaction, particularly in the context of DNA viruses, which have only recently been described in Drosophila. Here, we describe the isolation and comprehensive characterisation of Kallithea virus, a large double-stranded DNA virus, and the first DNA virus to have been described from wild populations of D. melanogaster. We find that Kallithea virus infection is costly for adult flies, reaching high titres in both sexes and disproportionately reducing survival in males, and movement and late fecundity in females. Using the Drosophila Genetic Reference Panel, we quantify host genetic variance for virus-induced mortality and viral titre and identify candidate host genes that may underlie this variation. Using full transcriptome sequencing of infected males and females, we examine the transcriptional response of flies to Kallithea virus infection and describe differential regulation of virus-responsive genes. This work establishes Kallithea virus as a tractable model to study the natural interaction between D. melanogaster and DNA viruses, and we hope it will serve as a basis for future studies of immune responses to DNA viruses in insects.

General anesthetics are known to modulate the activity of ion channels in the Cys-loop superfamily, but there is at present no consensus on the underlying mechanisms. To investigate the role of pore block inhibition by isoflurane and propofol, we employ molecular simulations to calculate affinities of these compounds to the GLIC pore. Our results show that pore block by propofol is significantly lower than that of isoflurane, and suggest that this difference may result from binding of propofol to an allosteric site recently identified by X-ray crystallography, which may cause a competing gain-of-function effect.

Opportunistic fungal pathogens are a serious clinical threat to patients with compromised immune systems, who are susceptible to infection by environmental sources, such as those encountered in the hospital setting. Azole drugs are widely used to treat fungal infections, but resistance to these drugs has been observed in patients treated with these drugs. The antifungal drug azole is a primary agent against fungal infections, and azole resistance has recently been identified as a serious clinical concern. Here, we have constructed a large-scale library of C. glabrata strains with individually barcoded deletion mutations, which has allowed the identification of numerous genes required for growth of this opportunistic pathogen in the presence of azole. We have also identified a number of novel genes involved in tolerance to clinically important antifungal drugs. We have demonstrated the utility of this collection of C. glabrata mutants as a valuable resource in functional genomics studies of this important fungal pathogen of humans, and to facilitate the identification of putative novel antifungal drug target and virulence genes.

Proteins are the major targets of drugs. Drugs that target proteins can kill the cancer cells, or they can prevent the growth of the cancer cells. Such drugs, however, are often toxic or expensive. Therefore, identifying and treating specific proteins is important for improving the cancer treatment. We have developed an algorithm that uses public cancer gene expression data to predict the effects of drugs on protein function. We then tested our algorithm on the largest and most comprehensive set of lung cancer gene expression data collected to date. Our algorithm predicted many drugs that can reverse the growth of the lung cancer cells. We also identified two promising protein targets for lung cancer. Our algorithm can be applied to other complex diseases, and will help in improving the results of signature-based drug repurposing.

The pancreas is a vital organ in the pancreas, which is a vital organ for the exocrine production of hormones that controls the pancreas. The integrity of the pancreas is maintained by the action of a cell layer, the stellate cells, which have to be constantly replaced by new cells to maintain the structure and function of the pancreas. One of the most important functions of the pancreas is to regulate the production of hormones, which are secreted proteins that control the functioning of the pancreas. The Wilms’ tumor suppressor gene ( Wt1 ) is involved in the development of the pancreas, but recent findings suggest that WT1 could also be playing physiological roles in adults. Using mice lacking WT1, we show that Wt1 is involved in the regeneration of the pancreas after damage, thus suggesting that WT1 plays novel and essential roles for the homeostasis of the adult pancreas.

Zika virus ( ZIKV ) infection during pregnancy has been associated with a wide range of congenital abnormalities. Since its emergence in the American continent in 2014, ZIKV infection has been linked to a large number of birth defects. ZIKV is a mosquito-borne virus transmitted by mosquitoes. There are no approved vaccines or antivirals to prevent ZIKV infection. We developed Zika virus-like particles ( VLPs ) and evaluated their immunogenicity and protective efficacy in mouse models. ZIKVLPs formulated with alum were injected into 6-8-week-old interferon deficient mice as well as wild type BALB/c mice. Control mice received PBS/alum. Animals were challenged with 200 PFU ( >1000 AG129 LD50s ) of ZIKV strain H/PF/2013. All vaccinated mice survived with no morbidity or weight loss while control animals either died at 9 days post challenge ( AG129 ) or had increased viremia ( BALB/c ). We also demonstrate the protective efficacy of the ZIKVLP vaccine in mice. Our findings demonstrate the protective efficacy of the ZIKVLP vaccine and highlight the important role that neutralizing antibodies play in protection against ZIKV infection.

Dyslexia is a common childhood disorder characterized by difficulty in making up the correct number of secreted and expressed words. Dyslexia is a heterogeneous disorder, which is often caused by genetic mutations. Copy number variants ( CNVs ) are a large class of genetic mutations, which are thought to increase the impact of genetic mutations on disease severity. However, the impact of CNVs on disease severity is not well understood due to limited phenotypic and genotypic data. Here, we present data on the frequency and impact of CNVs on a range of neurodevelopmental phenotypes. We show that large CNVs are more common in individuals with intellectual disability ( ID ) and multiple congenital anomalies ( MCA ) compared to controls. We also show that the impact of CNVs on dyslexia severity is independent of autism and MCA. Our data provide new insight into the genetic basis of neurodevelopmental disorders.

A well-established synaptic modification mechanism, spike-timing dependent plasticity ( STDP ), is sensitive to correlations between excitatory and inhibitory inputs, and it can generate competition among synapses. Although it is known that STDP can be implemented both analytically and numerically, it is still unclear how these mechanisms are controlled so that they can generate stable, long-term changes in synaptic strength. We have previously shown that the time window of STDP is shaped by a pre- and postsynaptic firing rate fluctuation. Here we show that a small temporal shift in the STDP window causes synchronous or nearly synchronous action potentials to induce long-term depression. We also show that the strength of the pre- and postsynaptic inputs, and the Hebbian and anti-Hebbian forms of STDP, can be implemented with the same temporal shift in the pre- and postsynaptic firing rate. Interestingly, the level of inhibition determines whether plasticity is Hebbian or anti-Hebbian. Even a random symmetric jitter of a few milliseconds in the STDP window can stabilize synaptic strengths while retaining these features. The same results hold for a shifted version of the more recent “triplet” model of STDP. Our results indicate that the detailed shape of the STDP window function near the transition from depression to potentiation is of the utmost importance in determining the consequences of STDP, suggesting that this region warrants further experimental study.

Lightness illusions are an important feature of human experience: we tend to think that the world is completely regular and that the image we see is identical. However, it is still unclear whether this is the case, and whether this is what we see. Here we have built artificial neural networks that can predict the reflectance of surfaces in a synthetic ecology from the statistical properties of images. We then applied these networks to “see” and “dont see” in the human visual system: we used images that were ambiguous and that did not appear to have a clear source, or that did, and that were identical at the same time. We found that “illusions” arise when natural stimuli are ambiguous, and that they only appear if the images are in the same environment as the one that we see. Since resolving stimulus ambiguity is a challenge faced by all visual systems, a corollary of these findings is that human illusions must be experienced by all visual animals regardless of their particular neural machinery.

The APOBEC3 gene family plays a role in immune defense against retroviral infection, hepatitis B virus propagation, and the retrotransposition of endogenous elements. The deletion of the APOBEC3B gene is very common in humans and the majority of European populations. The deletion is rare in Africans and Europeans, but more common in East Asians and Amerindians. We investigated the frequency of the deletion in a large number of human populations and found that it is variable among populations. Our data show that the deletion is rare in Africans and Europeans, more common in East Asians and Amerindians, and almost fixed in Oceanic populations. Despite a worldwide frequency of 22. 5%, we found no single existing tag single nucleotide polymorphism to serve as a surrogate for the deletion variant. Our results emphasize the importance of directly genotyping structural variation in association studies and of accurately resolving variant breakpoints before proceeding with more detailed population-genetic analysis.

Schistosomiasis is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the developing world. The control of schistosomiasis depends on the use of a single drug, praziquantel, with a low toxicity and a long-term treatment regime. The development of drug resistance has stimulated interest in developing new drugs. To date, RNAi has emerged as a powerful tool to interrogate the function of gene targets in schistosome parasites. However, to date, RNAi studies in schistosome stages infecting humans have focused on single ( or up to 3 ) genes of interest. Therefore, in the context of standardizing RNAi screens, data are limited on the extent of possible off-targeting effects, gene-to-gene variability in RNAi efficiency and the operational capabilities and limits of RNAi. We investigated the sensitivity and selectivity of RNAi using double-stranded ( ds ) RNA ( approximately 500 bp ) designed to target 11 genes of Schistosoma mansoni. We employed a method of mechanical transformation, enabling us to screen parasites that are relevant to parasitism in humans, amenable to screen automation and easy to obtain in greater numbers than adult parasites. We found that RNAi was sensitive to the gene target ( s ) in the pools of transcripts representative of each tissue. The sensitivity of individual gene targets varied. Based on the results, we propose the operational parameters for large-scale RNAi screens.

In the mammalian cortex, excitatory and inhibitory inputs to a single neuron are balanced, i. e., they are excitatory and inhibitory. It has been suggested that this balance is important for the irregular firing observed in the cortex. However, it is not known which mechanism underlies the fine tuning required for balancing excitatory and inhibitory inputs. Here we show that inhibitory Hebbian synaptic plasticity, a form of synaptic plasticity that is induced by a particular stimulus, can account for the fine tuning required for balancing feed forward excitatory and inhibitory inputs. However, it remains unclear what mechanism underlies the fine tuning required for balancing feed forward excitatory and inhibitory inputs. Our results show that the inhibitory synaptic plasticity can be understood as a form of feed forward inhibition.

Myopia is the most common vision disorder worldwide and the leading cause of vision loss. Although the identification of the genes responsible for myopia has been a major challenge in the past 50 years, no single gene has been identified to date. Here, we report the first large-scale study of myopia in a human cohort and a panel of mouse models. Our results demonstrate that the gene APLP2 is associated with myopia in humans. We also show that APLP2 is important for myopia development in mice and humans. Our work provides important insight into the role of APLP2 in the development of human myopia.

Transcription factor ( TF ) proteins are central to many cellular processes, e. g., in gene regulation. They are often involved in numerous human diseases. To understand the underlying biology of TFs we need to have a good understanding of how they function. One way to study these functions is to compare DNA sequences from multiple genes. One way to find groups of similar sequences is to find a motif ( i. e., a short DNA sequence pattern ) that is present in many genes. In this work we have focused on motifs that are not found in the gene of interest. We have developed a novel algorithm that can find motif families that are conserved across different species and that are not found in a motif of interest in a given gene. Our algorithm requires only the sequence of the motif of interest to be available, and can therefore be applied to a motif of interest in any gene. We have applied this algorithm to a set of TF motifs and have found that it is able to identify motif families that are conserved across different species and are not found in a motif of interest in a given gene. Our results show that the method can be used to find motif families that are specific to a gene, e. g., a DNA-binding motif is found only in a gene.

Human beings are at risk of infection by the parasite E. multilocularis, which infects the intestines of about 50 million people worldwide. Every year, there are about 1 million deaths from the infection, mostly in the United States. The current drug of choice is the metacestode-specific benzimidazole, but the parasite is developing resistance. The current research seeks to find new drugs for the treatment of E. multilocularis metacestodes. To this end, we screened a library of 426 FDA-approved drugs for their anti-metacestode activity. We found that bortezomib, a drug developed for the treatment of myeloma, is effective against the parasite and can be easily administered. However, the drug also causes severe side effects in mice. We next used bortezomib to test the efficacy of BTZ, a proteasome inhibitor developed for the chemotherapy of myeloma. BTZ treatment induced severe damage to the parasites and induced death of the parasites. BTZ was also effective against the parasite in vivo. However, additional studies are needed to verify its efficacy in vivo.

Fusions of specific proteins have been recognized in cancer for over 50 years. Yet, the development of computational methods to predict the occurrence of gene fusions is still a challenge. Here, we developed a “breakpoint analysis” pipeline to discover gene fusions by analyzing diverse cancer samples. We then validated the candidates with additional genomic alterations, which allowed validation of novel gene fusions. This approach can be used to identify new gene fusions in other cancer types, including those involved in immunodeficiency, hepatocellular carcinoma and colorectal cancer.

Protozoa are important human pathogens that cause malaria, toxoplasmosis, and several other diseases. Many of these parasites possess unique life cycles that include both a lytic replicative stage and an asexual stage. Toxoplasma gondii, the most common human protozoan parasite, replicates a complex life cycle in both a lytic replicative form and an asexual, nonreplicative form. The completion of the lytic cycle requires that the parasite senses changes in its environment and switches between the non-motile ( for intracellular replication ) and motile ( for invasion and egress ) states appropriately. Although the signaling pathway that regulates the motile state switch is critical to the pathogenesis of these diseases, it is not well understood. Here we show that a novel protein, AKMT, which is involved in the regulation of the parasite cell polarity, controls the activation of the motility switch in Toxoplasma. AKMT reduces the rate of parasite motility and compromises parasite invasion and egress. Interestingly, AKMT redistributes rapidly from the parasite body to the apical complex, suggesting that AKMT regulation of parasite motility might be accomplished by the precise temporal control of its localization in response to environmental changes.

The ability to recognize the pitch of simple sounds ( e. g., the familiar over earphones ) and the rhythm of complex sounds ( e. g., the jazz and the orchestra playing on the flute ) is important for understanding speech, identifying instruments playing, and identifying the instruments playing in a musical ensemble. There is a longstanding question in neuroscience as to how the brain can recognize the pitch of complex sounds. One prevailing hypothesis posits the importance of the temporal pattern of the action potentials ( spikes ) of the peripheral auditory system. This theory predicts that the brain must be able to extract meaningful information from spike times. However, it is difficult to test such a hypothesis experimentally. Here, we describe a biophysical model of auditory processing that can explain the development of neural structures specialized in capturing synchronous or correlated activity from amongst neural events. We show that a correlation-based neural mechanism can explain the development of neural structures required for recognizing the pitch of simple sounds, with or without the fundamental frequency. This mechanism can also explain the phenomenon of pitch constancy, which has been observed experimentally in animals.

Cytomegalovirus is a herpesvirus that infects approximately 50% of the world population. The virus can persist in the host, for example, in a latent form or as an active form. The virus causes life-long infections and can be associated with a wide range of symptoms including encephalitis, arthritis, and viral hepatitis. There is no approved treatment or vaccine for cytomegalovirus. We used a dual analysis to identify both viral and host gene products that are transcribed and regulated during the acute lytic infection. This analysis allowed us to identify numerous novel viral genes, some of which are of unknown function. We also found that the most abundant viral transcript, recently identified as a noncoding RNA, also codes for a novel protein. We also identified many other unexpected viral transcripts and host genes that were induced during lytic infection. Many of these genes are related to functions that may shed new light on cytomegalovirus pathogenesis. Together, these findings provide new insights into the molecular warfare at the virus-host interface and suggest new areas of research to advance the understanding and treatment of cytomegalovirus-associated diseases.

The duplication of the eukaryotic genome is a highly conserved process that ensures genomic integrity and prevents genetic instability. DNA replication initiates at discrete sites called replication origins. The DNA replication process is tightly regulated to ensure that all replication origins are properly activated and that the initiation of replication is strictly prevented. Here, we show that the eukaryotic cell cycle is able to inhibit the initiation of DNA replication by untimely activation of replication origins. We show that multiple pathways are involved in this process and that deregulation of multiple pathways can cause severe genomic instability. Our results highlight the importance of multiple inhibitory mechanisms to prevent the untimely initiation of DNA replication.

Dengue disease, a reemerging, rapidly spreading, and growing problem, is estimated to be the world's second largest cause of morbidity and mortality. The disease is caused by four different viruses that are transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. There are three different routes of transmission, which vary across time, geography, and population. Variations in the transmission and cost of illness are significant, and national reporting systems show a great diversity in design and implementation. Efforts to improve estimates of dengue episodes and cost of illness have not been successful, and estimates of global burden remain uncertain. Here, we develop evidence to support and improve current reporting methods. Our recommendations include refining analysis of existing data to adjust reported episodes of dengue and expanding data collection to estimate the accuracy of reporting rates ( by health sector, treatment, severity, etc. ), and using covariates to extrapolate dengue incidence to locations with no or limited reporting. As promising tools are being developed, these recommendations should improve objective, systematic measures of dengue burden to strengthen health policy decisions.

In humans, the kidney is composed of two cell types, the ureteric bud and the collecting ductal and caloric tubular unit. The ureteric bud is the functional unit of the kidney while the collecting duct is the functional unit of the proximal tubular unit. The final ureteric bud and collecting duct are separated by an intricate morphogenetic process known as ureteric bud branching. The precise nature of this process is poorly understood and the identification of the genes and genetic variants that control its process has been a major challenge in the field. Here, we demonstrate that the transcription factor MITF-A is required for the normal branching pattern of the ureteric bud. We show that overexpression of MITF-A leads to an increase in the number of nephrons, the functional units of the kidney. This is the first time that a specific transcription factor is shown to be required for ureteric bud branching.

Snakebite envenoming is a public health problem in the region of the world. Currently, there are no specific antivenoms licensed for use in Nepal. There is a need for evidence on which to base clinical management of neurotoxic snakebite envenoming. This study compared the effectiveness and safety of high and low initial antivenom dosage in victims of neurotoxic envenoming. Our study was conducted in the Terai plains of Nepal, with a total of 157 snakebite victims enrolled. We found that the antivenom currently used in Nepal performs poorly, although the high initial dose regimen is not more effective than the low initial dose. However, the fact that the high dose regimen can have a high risk of adverse events, and the fact that antivenom can be administered as a single dose, make it an attractive option in terms of improving future patients’ outcomes. The development of new and more effective antivenoms that better target the species responsible for bites in the region will help improve future patients’ outcomes.

Cholera is a severe diarrheal disease that kills many thousands of people each year. Recurrent cholera outbreaks have been reported in Cameroon since 1971, however the disease is difficult to control, as the natural and built environment influences the transmission patterns. We analyzed reported case numbers and deaths from 2000–2012 at the operational ( health district ) and subclimate ( subclimate ) levels in Cameroon, and we found that the disease is most severe in northern Sudan and that the risk of transmission varies according to climate. We also identified specific factors that affect the risk of transmission, including the presence of major waterbody or highway, as well as the average daily maximum temperature and precipitation levels over the preceding two weeks. The epidemiology of cholera in Cameroon differs substantially between climate sub zones. We believe this research contributes to an improved understanding of the natural and built environment on the transmission of this disease, which will help to develop an optimal control strategy for this important disease.

Recent advances in the field of longevity medicine have led to a surge in the use of dietary restriction, a regimen that caloric intake is reduced by up to 40%. Studies have shown that dietary restriction is beneficial for a variety of health issues, including increased learning. The beneficial effects of dietary restriction on learning are due to the effects on numerous mechanisms that collectively confer improved cellular health and extension of organismal lifespan. However, it remains unclear whether the beneficial effects of dietary restriction are due to specific neural mechanisms or whether the beneficial effects on learning are due to indirect or secondary consequences of improved health and extended lifespan. Here, we show that the beneficial effects of dietary restriction are mediated by changes in kynurenic acid, a neuroinhibitory metabolite, through activation of specific interneurons. Thus, fluctuations in kynurenic acid levels do not alter lifespan in any of the conditions tested, suggesting that the beneficial effects of dietary restriction on learning can be attributed to changes in a nutritionally sensitive metabolite with neuromodulatory activity rather than indirect or secondary consequences of improved health and extended longevity.

The assembly of a functional mitotic spindle requires the separation of the two spindle poles from a single centrosome. In many organisms, this requires that the centrosomes or the mitotic spindle attach to the spindle poles, or that the spindle attach to the spindle poles. Little is known about how this attachment occurs. Here, we have used the model organism Drosophila melanogaster to perform a genome-wide RNA interference screen to identify proteins that are required for centrosome attachment. We identified 32 genes that are required for centrosome function. These genes have previously described roles in centrosome function, and we show that some of them have human homologs. We also show that centrosome attachment is mediated by the Polo kinase Cnn. Cnn is phosphorylated during mitosis in a Polo-dependent manner, suggesting that the Polo-dependent phosphorylation of Cnn initiates centrosome maturation.

Cells have a variety of shapes that are determined by their internal organization and the external environment. Understanding how these internal and external forces are integrated to give rise to cell shape is crucial for understanding many cellular behaviors, including cell migration, proliferation and differentiation. We have developed a model to investigate how internal and external forces interact to give rise to cellular shape. We show that the evolution of a periodic cellular contour can be driven by either adhesion or protrusive forces. These results have important implications for understanding cellular shape dependence on the properties of the extra-cellular matrix.

Syngnathia ( bony fusion of the upper and lower jaw ) is a rare human congenital condition, with fewer than sixty cases reported in the literature. Syngnathia typically presents as part of a complex syndrome comprising widespread oral and maxillofacial anomalies, but it can also occur in isolation. Most cartilage, bone, and connective tissue of the head and face is derived from neural crest cells. Hence, congenital craniofacial anomalies are often attributed to defects in neural crest cell formation, survival, migration, or differentiation. The etiology and pathogenesis of syngnathia however remains unknown. Here, we report that Foxc1 null embryos display bony syngnathia together with defects in maxillary and mandibular structures, and agenesis of the temporomandibular joint ( TMJ ). In the absence of Foxc1, neural crest cell derived osteogenic patterning is affected, as osteoblasts develop ectopically in the maxillary prominence and fuse with the dentary bone. Furthermore, we observed that the craniofacial musculature is also perturbed in Foxc1 null mice, which highlights the complex tissue interactions required for proper jaw development. Together our data demonstrates that Foxc1 – Fgf8 signaling regulates mammalian jaw patterning and provides a mechanistic basis for the pathogenesis of syngnathia. Furthermore, our work provides a framework for understanding jaw patterning and the etiology of other congenital craniofacial anomalies, including temporomandibular joint agenesis.

Leishmaniasis is a neglected parasitic disease transmitted by sandflies in the Old World. It is a major public health concern that is currently endemic in 98 countries. In addition to the clinical symptoms caused by the disease, Leishmania parasites are considered to be the main causative agents of human disease. The emergence of drug resistance in the treatment of human infections is a growing concern. In the present work, we analyzed the genetic diversity of Leishmania RNA virus type 1 ( LRV1 ) strains circulating in French Guiana, South America. Our results show that LRV1 strains from Leishmania guyanensis parasites collected throughout French Guiana were genetically diverse and phylogenetically related. Based on these data, we developed and analyzed LRV1 strains from French Guiana parasites and identified that LRV1 strains from several Leishmania species were closely related. Overall, our results indicate that LRV1 strains circulating in South America are genetically diverse and phylogenetically closely related.

Candida albicans is the most common fungal pathogen of humans, and is a major cause of nosocomial infections. This fungal pathogen is able to sequester essential nutrients from its hosts, which is critical for its virulence. We have previously shown that this pathogen can sequester zinc, a nutrient that is essential for fungal growth and virulence. In this study, we have identified a novel zinc acquisition system in C. albicans. We have shown that this system is highly conserved across all sequenced fungal genomes and that it is required for host cell invasion. Our findings provide a novel insight into the biology of this important human fungal pathogen.

West Nile virus ( WNV ) and Zika virus ( ZIKV ) are mosquito-borne viruses that have been associated with several outbreaks involving high numbers of neuroinvasive diseases among humans. Over the past few decades, WNV has been associated with several outbreaks involving high numbers of neuroinvasive diseases among humans. The recent re-emergence of ZIKV has been associated with congenital malformation and also with Guillain–Barre syndrome in adults. The geographic range of arthropod-borne viruses has been rapidly increasing in recent years. In this study, we provided evidence of the establishment of WNV in southern Iran and no proof of ZIKV in serum samples or in mosquito vectors. The presence of WNV in southern Iran seems to be a result of the local socio-economic environment and the presence of susceptible vector species. Our findings show that WNV in southern Iran may have been established in the past or in the present or future.

Several horse breeds have been specifically selected for the ability to exhibit alternative patterns of locomotion, or gaits. We analyzed a genome-wide association analysis for the ability to pace in 542 Standardbred horses ( n = 176 pacers, n = 366athlon athletes ) with genotype data imputed to ~74, 000 single nucleotide polymorphisms ( SNPs ). A set of 303 variants from 22 chromosomes ( ECA1, 2, 6, 9, 17, 19, 23, 25, 31 ) reached genome-wide significance ( p < 1. 44 x 10−6 ). A conditional inference tree containing seven SNPs predicted status as a pacer or thunderer with 99. 1% accuracy and subsequently performed with 99. 4% accuracy in an independently sampled population of 166 Standardbred horses ( n = 83 pacers, n = 83 tarders ). This highly accurate algorithm could be used by breeders to identify Standardbred horses with the potential to race as pacers or as treadmillers, according to the genotype identified, prior to initiating training and would enable fine-tuning of breeding programs with designed matings.

Co-infections of helminth and bacterial pathogens continue to be a major health concern for children. We have previously demonstrated that helminth parasites can directly influence the function of the innate immune system by interfering with host immunity. Our current study demonstrates that MyD88, a critical innate immune effector in mammals, is important for host defense against enteric bacterial pathogens, such as enteropathogenic Escherichia coli. We also show that MyD88 knockout mice are highly susceptible to C. rodentium, a bacterial enteropathogen, indicating that MyD88 is important for host defense against bacterial infections. We also demonstrate that MyD88 knockout mice are more susceptible to bacterial infection than wild-type mice. Our study provides new insights into the pathogenesis of MyD88 knockout mice and the role of the MyD88 signaling pathway in host immunity.

Replication helicases are required for replication of DNA double strand breaks, a highly deleterious form of DNA damage. A checkpoint kinase called ATR is required for repair of replication stress and is a good candidate for modulating the replication helicase activity. In this study, we have identified a new role for the replication helicase Mcm2-7 in preventing the replication of DNA damage induced by HU treatment. We find that a specific mcm mutation causes elevated levels of DNA damage and results in numerous DNA-damage associated foci, which appear only after replication forks are completed and are dependent upon progression into metaphase. In addition, we show that the DNA damage is not due to spontaneous replication fork collapse. Our data suggest that Mcm2-7 activity is required for the surveillance-mediated DNA replication checkpoint to effectively repair replication stress.

Mosquito-borne yellow fever virus ( YFV ) is the most lethal arbovirus infection of humans and non-human primates and is a leading cause of death due to arbovirus infection. The current live-attenuated YF vaccine strains, 17D-204 and 17DD, have been developed by serial passage of a YFV isolate derived from a non-human primate primate infection. While the disease caused by wild-type YFV infection in humans and non-human primates ranges from encephalitis to hemorrhagic fever, no small animal models have been developed for studying the molecular determinants of YFV immunogenicity and disease. Here, we describe a small animal model for wild-type YFV infection and disease in A129 mice, which are highly susceptible to infection, whereas the related virus, 17D-204, does not. We show that the ability of wild-type YFV to evade and/or disable components of the interferon ( IFN ) α/β response may be primate-specific such that infection of mice with a functional IFN-α/β antiviral response is attenuated. Consequently, subcutaneous YFV infection of A129 mice represents a biologically relevant model for studying viscerotropic infection and disease development following wild-type virus inoculation, as well as mechanisms of 17D-204 vaccine attenuation.

The Wingless ( Wg/Wnt ) signaling pathway is essential for metazoan development, where it is central to tissue growth and cellular differentiation. Deregulated Wg pathway activation underlies severe developmental abnormalities, as well as carcinogenesis. We discovered a novel Wg/Wnt pathway component, Armless ( Als ), which is required for Wg target gene expression in a cell-autonomous manner. We show that Als functions downstream of the destruction complex, a key component of the Wg signaling pathway. In the absence of Als, Arm levels are severely reduced. We show by biochemical and in vivo studies that Als interacts directly with Ter94, an AAA ATPase known to associate with E3 ligases and to drive protein turnover. We suggest that Als antagonizes Ter94's positive effect on E3 ligase function and propose that Als promotes Wg signaling by rescuing Arm from proteolytic degradation, spotlighting an unexpected step where the Wg pathway signal is modulated.

Recent advances in genomics and sequencing technologies have enabled the analysis of large numbers of DNA sequences from multiple individuals. However, these sequences are often incomplete, missing important functional sequences and potentially variants that confer different phenotypic effects. In order to understand why this might be the case, we analysed two publicly available datasets and observed that a large fraction of the variants that have been called in A. thaliana and D. melanogaster populations are misrepresented as multiple alleles with different functional annotations, i. e. where the same underlying variant is represented by inconsistent alignments leading to different variant calls. To address this issue, we developed the software Irisas to re qualifies and re-annotate these variants. We also integrated them to predict the functional impact of SNPs, INDELs, and structural variants for burden testing. We show the value of the association test with INDELs and integrating multiple types of variants in association studies in plants and animals.

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly in developing countries. It is transmitted by the Plasmodium parasite, which preferentially lives in macrophages of the immune system. Acute episodes of malaria are usually clinically asymptomatic but may progress to severe disease and death. Our study examined the activation and function of neutrophils during acute episodes of malaria. We found that blood samples from malaria patients were highly activated, while those from healthy donors were not. We also found that neutrophils from malaria patients showed enhanced phagocytic activity and superoxide production, suggesting that neutrophils may be a good target for anti-malarial chemotherapy. Interestingly, neutrophils from malaria patients expressed high levels of G protein-coupled receptor ( GRK2 ), low levels of CXCR2, and displayed impaired chemotaxis towards IL-8 ( CXCL8 ). Our data suggest that neutrophils from malaria patients may be a poor source of pro-inflammatory cytokines and display reduced chemotactic activity, suggesting a possible mechanism for an enhanced susceptibility to secondary bacterial infection during malaria.

Parasitic nematodes are a major health concern worldwide. Understanding the biology of reproductive processes in these parasites may help develop new drug-based treatments and control strategies. We have used the filarial nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to identify genes important for reproduction. The Version 2 Filarial Microarray with 18, 104 elements representing ∼85% of the filarial genome was used to identify genes important for female reproduction. Approximately 19% of 14, 293 genes were identified as female genes. Many female genes have potential Caenorhabditis elegans homologues annotated as germline-, oogenesis-, spermatogenesis-, and early embryogenesis- enriched. Peptidase, ligase, transferase, regulator activity for kinase and transcription, and rRNA and lipid binding were associated with female reproduction. In contrast, catalytic activity from kinase, ATP, and carbohydrate binding were associated with male reproduction. Significantly enriched pathways in females were associated with cell growth and protein synthesis, whereas metabolic pathways such as pentose phosphate and energy production pathways were enriched in males. Many proteins encoded by female reproduction genes are secreted by Brugia malayi, and these encode immunomodulatory molecules such as antioxidants and host cytokine mimics. Our localization of reproduction genes in filarial reproductive organs supports the hypothesis that these genes encode proteins involved in reproduction.

The vascular system, comprised of blood vessels lined with endothelial cells, is the functional unit of blood flow. Endothelial cells sense and respond to the vascular environment by stimulating vascular growth factor ( VEGF ) signaling and trafficking. In this study, we develop a computational model of the VEGF receptor 2 ( VEGFR2 ), the trafficking of VEGF receptors, and the downstream effectors, to investigate differences in VEGF-induced signaling and trafficking. The model predicts that changes in the trafficking of VEGF receptors, as well as changes in the strength of downstream effects, can account for differences in downstream signaling. We show that VEGF receptors are localized on the surface of endosomal cells differently, and that differences in their trafficking can be accounted for by changes in receptor activation. Our model predicts that changes in the trafficking of VEGF receptors, and the effects of these changes, can result in changes in the strength of downstream effects. Our results also show that a key receptor, Neuropilin-1, can alter the strength of downstream effects by controlling how receptors are trafficked.

Approximately 5–10% of colorectal cancer ( CRC ) cases are expected to result from a genetic predisposition, but in only 5–10% of these cases highly penetrant germline mutations are found. The remaining CRC heritability is still unexplained, and may be caused by a hitherto-define set of rare variants with a moderately penetrant risk. Here, we aimed to identify novel genes for early-onset CRC using whole-exome sequencing, which was performed on a cohort of CRC individuals with a disease onset before 45 years of age. We searched for genes that were recurrently affected by rare variants with potentially damaging effects and, subsequently, re-sequenced the candidate genes in a replication cohort of 174 early-onset or familial CRC individuals. We identified two genes, PTPN12 and LRP6, which are involved in cell motility and WNT signaling. In vitro assays showed that both variants are able to stimulate Wnt signaling. In summary, we present PTPN12 and LRP6 as novel candidates for early-onset CRC susceptibility.

Increasing evidence indicates that oligomeric protein assemblies may represent the molecular species responsible for cytotoxicity in a range of neurological disorders including Alzheimer and Parkinson diseases. We use all-atom computer simulations to reveal that the process of oligomerization can be divided into two steps. The first is characterised by a hydrophobic coalescence resulting in the formation of molten oligomers in which hydrophobic residues are sequestered away from the solvent. In the second step, the oligomers undergo a process of reorganisation driven by interchain hydrogen bonding interactions that induce the formation of β sheet rich assemblies in which hydrophobic groups can become exposed. Our results show that the process of oligomerization can be divided into two stages, characterised by a hydrophobic coalescence and a subsequent reorganisation of the protein structure.

Trypanosoma brucei is an important parasite that causes human sleeping sickness in sub-Saharan Africa. Functional annotation of the genome has been a longstanding problem in trypanosomatids because their genes are poorly conserved. Recently, several large-scale studies have been performed to profile the gene expression of T. brucei in various life stages. However, the data from these studies do not provide a thorough overview of gene function. Here, we present a novel computational approach that combines the expression profiles from three different microarray studies of T. brucei. Our analysis identifies the coregulatory elements that are functional in the trypanosome genome. We also identify potential regulatory elements that may be involved in gene regulation. Our results provide a powerful means to improve the functional annotation of T. brucei genome.

Rift Valley fever virus ( RVFV ), transmitted by mosquitoes, is an important disease in ruminants often transmitted to humans after outbreaks in African and Arabian countries. To help combat the disease, prophylactic measures need to be developed and/or improved. In this work, we evaluated the immunogenicity and protective efficacy of recombinant plasmid DNA and modified vaccinia virus Ankara ( rMVA ) vectors against RVFV in mice. These recombinant vaccines encode either of two components of the Rift Valley fever virus: the viral glycoproteins ( Gn/Gc ) or the nucleoprotein ( N ). Following lethal challenge with live RVFV, mice immunized with a single dose of the rMVA-Gn/Gc vaccine showed no viraemia or clinical manifestation of disease, but mounted RVFV-neutralizing antibodies and glycoprotein specific CD8+ T-cell responses. Neither DNA-Gn/Gc alone nor a heterologous prime-boost immunization schedule ( DNA-Gn/Gc followed by rMVAGn/Gc ) was better than the single rMVA-Gn/Gc immunization schedule with regards to protective efficacy. Given the excellent safety profile of rMVA based vaccines in humans and animals, our data supports further development of rMVA-Gn/Gc as a vaccine strategy that can be used for the prevention of Rift Valley fever in both humans and livestock.

During animal development, cell populations are compartmentalized, and compartmentalization is thought to be crucial for proper organ formation. In Drosophila, the gene apterous ( ap ) divides the wing imaginal disc in dorsal vs ventral cell lineages. While the role of ap in controlling wing development is well established, the regulation of its expression during wing development is poorly understood. We have identified three transcriptional regulatory modules essential for ap ( CRMs ) that are required for wing development. We show that these three CRMs interact with the transcription factors that regulate them. We then demonstrate that the combination of the three CRMs is necessary for robust ap expression. In addition, we show that the interaction of the transcription factors with the three CRMs is necessary for the proper maintenance of ap expression through cell divisions. Our results suggest a three-step mechanism for the cell lineage compartment expression of ap that includes initial activation, positive autoregulation and Trithorax-mediated maintenance through separable CRMs.

Fibronectin attachment protein ( FAP ) is a bacterial adjuvant that is used to stimulate immune responses against a wide variety of pathogens. FAP is also a promising adjuvant candidate for the development of safe and efficient vaccines against human pathogens. However, the co-administered FAP with other antigens has not been assessed. We have recently shown that FAP and Echinococcus multilocularis tetraspanin 3 ( Em-TSP3 ) can induce systemic and mucosal antibodies in mice. In the present study, we investigated the immunogenicity of Em-TSP3 peptide ( FBP ) fused with Em-TSP3, using the immunized BALB/c mice. The results showed that i. n. administration of rEm-TSP3-FBP induced strong systemic and mucosal antibody responses in immunized BALB/c mice, suggesting that FAP and Em-TSP3 are suitable antigens for the development of effective vaccines against alveolar echinococcosis ( AE ).

Inference of relationships among individuals is important in many areas of genetics, including many areas of genealogical studies. Existing methods to infer relationships are limited to inferring a single individual’s relationship or analyze a small number of individuals. We present a new method that infers relationships among many individuals and use it to infer relationships among a sample of Greenlandic Inuit. Our method can be utilized on a sample of any length of the pedigree, including cases in which the genealogical relationships among all members are known.

Transposable elements are selfish mobile genetic elements that have a high activity rate. Their activity has important consequences on genome evolution and adaptation. In this study, we investigated the TE activity dynamics of transposons in Drosophila melanogaster and D. simulans. Our results indicate that TE activity is mostly of recent origin in both species and a consequence of the demographic history, with habitat expansion triggering a period of rapid evolution.

How the human auditory system extracts perceptually relevant acoustic features of speech is unknown. To address this question, we used intracranial recordings from nonprimary auditory cortex in the human superior temporal gyrus to determine what acoustic information in speech sounds can be reconstructed from population neural activity. We found that slow and intermediate temporal fluctuations, such as those corresponding to syllable onsets and offsets, can be accurately reconstructed using a linear model based on the auditory spectrogram. However, reconstruction of fast temporal fluctuations, such as syllable onsets and offsets, required a nonlinear sound representation based on temporal modulation energy. Reconstruction accuracy was highest within the range of spectro-temporal fluctuations that have been found to be critical for speech intelligibility.

Developmental abnormalities frequently occur together with other birth defects, but the underlying genetic causes are often unclear. In this study, we describe five individuals with complex central nervous system ( CNS ) malformations and in some cases urinary tract defects, and we examine the genetic causes of each. Two individuals have balanced translocations that disrupt NFIA. A third individual and two half-siblings in an unrelated family have interstitial microdeletions that include NFIA. All five individuals exhibit similar CNS malformations, including a thin, hypoplastic, or missing corpus callosum, and hydrocephalus or ventriculomegaly. The majority of these individuals also exhibit Chiari type I malformation, tethered spinal cord, and urinary tract defects that include vesiculate and anorectal malformations. Previous analyses of Nfia−/− mice indicate that Nfia deficiency also results in hydrocephalus and agenesis of the corpus callosum. Here, we show that, at reduced penetrance, Nfia is also required in a dosage-sensitive manner for ureteral and renal development. Collectively, the mouse Nfia mutant phenotype and the common features among these five human cases indicate that NFIA haploinsufficiency contributes to a novel human CNS malformation syndrome that can also include ureteral and renal defects.

Multiple sequence comparisons are an important tool for inferring evolutionary relationships. However, most existing alignment programs are either slow or consider only one sequence at a time, making them difficult to run on large datasets. We describe a new alignment program which is both fast and accurate, and is able to handle the entire process of alignment on a large number of sequences. Our program is designed to be fast, and is also accurate, making it a useful tool for inferring evolutionary relationships.

Necrotic enteritis is a serious infectious disease that causes significant morbidity and mortality in humans. Clostridium perfringens is a major cause of human necrotic enteritis worldwide. C. perfringens strains are thought to cause disease by a variety of mechanisms including a role as a virulence factor. Our recent work has shown that the alpha-toxin is not essential for pathogenesis. In this study we have identified a novel toxin from C. perfringens strains. The toxin was only found in C. perfringens strains that cause chicken necrotic enteritis ( NE ). Both purified native toxin and recombinant toxin displayed cytotoxic activity against the chicken liver cell line LMH. To determine the role of NetB in NE a netB mutant of a virulent C. perfringens chicken isolate was constructed by homologous recombination. This mutant was unable to cause disease whereas the netB mutant complemented with a netB gene and caused significant levels of NE. The netB mutant was also unable to cause disease in a chicken disease model. This is the first time a C. perfringens toxin has been identified in an NE-causing isolate. The netB toxin has significant vaccine potential as it is the first rationally attenuated strain obtained in an NE-causing isolate of C. perfringens.

The use of bioluminescence has been successful in drug discovery against parasitic diseases. The current standard method to screen for new compounds for these diseases involves the use of parasites to light up the target enzymes to produce a signal which the cell can then use to detect the presence of the target enzyme. However, this method can be expensive, time-consuming, and requires large amounts of materials. Here, we have developed a screening method to light up the target enzymes of both Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium parvum parasites. We report the development of a method that utilizes the firefly luciferase, which has been modified to be more sensitive than the standard protocol. We have used this method to screen a small set of compounds for their ability to inhibit both parasites. We have also validated our assay against human cells and have determined that some of the compounds are effective at inhibiting both parasites. This method of screening will be very valuable for the development of new drugs against both Giardia and Cryptosporidium infections.

Fungal infections are a serious problem, especially for immunocompromised patients and people with chronic infections. Many fungi are obligate biotrophs, meaning they cannot synthesize their own nutrients and rely on living host cells for carbon and nitrogen. The Dothideomycetes is a large group of fungi that include many plant pathogens, many of which are pathogenic for a wide variety of hosts. The 18 genome sequences of this group represent the largest group of sequenced fungal genomes to date and have enabled the analysis of genome evolution and the diversification of genes involved in the interaction of this large group with their hosts. The 18 genomes differ only in the number and content of genes, but differ in the arrangement of genes within the chromosomes. The 18 genomes represent a catalogue of genes involved in a wide range of functions, including those involved in degradation of cell walls, proteolysis, secondary metabolism, and cysteine-rich small secreted proteins. The two major groups of plant pathogens in the Dothideomycetes, the Capnodiales and Pleosporales, share features of genome organization and gene organization, but differ in their modes of pathogenesis. We suggest that some of the genes identified in this study are involved in the response to oxidative stress, a common feature of many fungal infections.

Sirtuins are a large family of proteins that regulate gene expression by deacetylating histone proteins. Sirt6 is one of the most well-studied sirtuins and has been shown to be important for the regulation of many genes, including some that are involved in aging. Sirt6 is also implicated in the control of transcriptional activation in response to stress.
