These results suggest that cellular proteins, which are known to be important for a variety of cellular activities, can also be important for the development of cancer.

IL-1β is a potent pro-inflammatory cytokine that promotes host defense and its dysregulation is associated with immune pathology. Toxoplasma gondii infection of myeloid cells triggers the production and release of IL-1β; however, the mechanisms regulating this pathway, particularly in human immune cells, are incompletely understood. Here we report that T. gondii infection of primary human monocytes triggers the activation of a novel signaling pathway that is upstream of the NF-κB-dependent pro-inflammatory signaling pathway. This pathway is activated via a Syk-CARD9-NF-κB signaling axis and requires the NLRP3 inflammasome. Interestingly, pyroptotic cell death is not required for pro-inflammatory cytokine release from T. gondii-infected primary human monocytes. Furthermore, GSDMD, a protease that induces IL-1β production, is not required for pro-inflammatory cytokine release from T. gondii-infected human monocytes. Our data expand our understanding of the molecular basis for human innate immune regulation of inflammation and host defense during parasite infection.

The Turkic peoples represent a diverse collection of ethnic groups with a rich history of migrations across Eurasia. They were present in the Transcaspian steppe, East Africa, Central Asia, East Europe, the Caucasus, and Afghanistan. The origin and early dispersal history of the Turkic peoples is controversial, with some arguing that the present-day Turkic languages originated from a common founder and subsequent migration from the steppe to current times. One of the most popular hypotheses for the origin and early dispersal of the Turkic peoples is the hypothesis that they were the product of a language expansion that occurred in the 5th–16th century. The 5th century was characterized by wavefront migrations from the Steppe into Central Asia, the Middle East, and Central Africa. The second half of the century was characterized by wavefront migrations from the Steppe into Europe, Central Asia, and Central Africa. The third century was characterized by wavefront migrations from Asia and Africa into Europe, Asia, and Africa. The fourth century began in Asia, Central Asia, East Europe, Central and Northern Africa, and Europe. Our analysis of 373 individuals from 22 Turkic-speaking populations, representing their current geographic range, confirms that the Turkic peoples originated from a common founder and shared a recent common ancestor.

Most natural populations are characterized by substantial variation in traits. This variation is typically explained by the effects of natural selection on trait variation. Recent work has shown that, in some cases, traits may be influenced by natural selection on genetic variation in the trait itself. For traits with a strong genetic component, these traits are often referred to as quantitative trait loci ( QTL ). While some have suggested that these three traits are different views of similar concepts, it is not yet clear whether they have the same underlying genetic mechanism. Here, we identify a QTL affecting the ( co ) variance of the ( n ) phenotypes of the model flowering plant Boechera stricta, a closely related relative of Arabidopsis. The magnitude and direction of the effects depend on the environment, and to our knowledge, this reversibility of canalization effects across environments has not been reported previously. We demonstrate that the magnitude and direction of nFT effects depend on the environment, and on the genetic background, which we show to have a major influence on trait variation. We also show that the genetic background can affect the effects of nFT on the trait covariance structure, as well as on the effects of the candidate gene FT on the trait. Our results suggest that the genetic background and the trait can have related effects on the evolution of traits.

Cilia are the smallest sensory organelles present in almost all vertebrate cells. Cilia are required for many functions, and cilia length is constant in different cell types. In addition, cilia play an important role in cellular signaling pathways. The mechanisms controlling cilia length are not well understood. In this study, we found that cilia length is regulated by a protein transport system in C. elegans. The protein transport system was also found to be involved in microtubule stability. Endocytosis is an important cellular process that transports various cargoes to the cell. Our results reveal that cilia length is regulated by a microtubule-based endocytic pathway. This pathway, which was found to be important for cilia function, is also important for microtubule-based endocytosis. Our results suggest that cilia length is controlled by a microtubule-based endocytic pathway. This work may help to better understand how cilia are regulated in other cell types.

Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a neglected tropical disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. BU is the third most common mycobacterial infection in the world and the third leading cause of mycobacterial infection-related death. There are no vaccines against BU and the only available drugs are toxic and expensive. We developed a novel tool to measure drug efficacy in real time, enabling rapid and precise evaluation of the efficacy of new drugs against BU. This tool is based on light-emitting luminescent bacteria that are reporter strains of M. ulcerans. The light-emitting bacteria are not in the form of the virulent strain, which is the infectious agent, but are the stable form of the drug-sensitive, non-infectious state. The reporter strain has been engineered to express the entire lux operon, enabling rapid and in vivo assessment of the efficacy of a panel of drugs, including in vivo evaluation of the efficacy of the drug combinations. This novel tool is unique and robust, enabling pre-clinical evaluation of a panel of antibiotics, including BU-specific drugs, in real time.

The impacts of climate change on biodiversity have frequently been demonstrated, including shifts in phenology and life-history traits. One potential major impact of climate change is the modification of synchronization between the phenology of different trophic levels. High phenotypic plasticity in laying date has allowed many bird species to track the increasingly early springs resulting from recent environmental change, but although changes in the timing of reproduction have been well studied in birds, these questions have only recently been addressed in mammals. Here, we provide a rare quantification of the demographical impacts associated with the failure of a species to modify its phenology in response to a changing world. Our study provides a rare quantitative understanding of the demographic costs associated with the failure of a species to modify its phenology in response to a changing world. Given these fitness costs, the lack of response of roe deer birth dates to match the increasingly earlier onset of spring is in stark contrast with the marked phenotypic responses to climate change reported in many other mammals. We suggest that the lack of phenotypic plasticity in birth timing is linked to its inability to track environmental cues of variation in resource availability for the timing of parturition.

Salmonella is a major cause of foodborne disease worldwide, particularly in tropical countries. The bacteria are transmitted from animals to humans through a variety of carrier animals, such as rats, mice, and sheep. Invasive nontyphoidal Salmonella disease ( iNTS ) is the most severe and often life threatening type of Salmonella infection. We analyzed data from 2007–2016 for iNTS cases in Queensland, Australia. We found an increase in iNTS cases, with a peak in the summer months. The notification rate for iNTS was 17. 3 cases per 100, 000 population in the endemic year. The majority of iNTS cases were among children and young adults. This is the first study to analyze iNTS incidence rates in Queensland, Australia, and we believe this is important for the design of control measures and epidemiological surveillance.

Ethylene and abscisic acid ( ABA ) are important plant hormones involved in plant growth and development. Ethylene induces the production of phytohormone ethylene-responsive hormone, which is involved in plant growth and development. ABA also acts on ethylene receptors and mediates root growth inhibition. The ABA pathway is known to be involved in the ethylene response pathway in rice, but the mechanism of ABA-mediated ethylene response is still unclear. Here, we identified a novel ABA pathway in rice, which is different from the previously reported ethylene pathway in Arabidopsis. We found that the mhz4 mutant exhibited reduced ethylene response in roots but enhanced ethylene response in coleoptiles of etiologic seeds. We identified that MHZ4 is involved in ABA accumulation in roots. Further, we show that MHZ4-mediated ethylene response acts downstream of ethylene receptors to positively regulate root ethylene response. Our findings reveal a novel mode of ABA-mediated ethylene response in rice, which is different from the previously reported ethylene-ABA interaction mode.

Cytomegalovirus ( CMV ), which is a ubiquitous herpesvirus that infects most humans, is a pathogen that can cause severe disease in immunocompromised patients. The replication and maintenance of the latent infection in the host is thought to be the basis for the virus reemerging from latency. One of the viral proteins of CMV, UL70, is known to play a crucial role in the early steps of CMV replication. In this study, we show that UL70 interacts with and enhances the cellular accumulation of the DNA replication machinery in the nucleus. In addition, UL70 interacts with DNAJB6, which is a highly conserved member of the heat shock protein ( HSP ) family of proteins, and DNAJ, which is a ubiquitously expressed member of the DNAJ family. UL70 and DNAJ were found to interact with different isoforms of DNAJ, which is able to modulate the intracellular accumulation of UL70. Our results thus provide new insight into the role of DNAJ in regulating the cellular localization of UL70, leading to modulation of CMV replication and lytic infection.

Neglected diseases are a group of infectious diseases that are under-resourced and under-researched. They cause a significant burden to global health and an economic loss of several billion dollars a year. New chemical entities are desperately needed that overcome the limitations of existing drugs for neglected diseases. We have integrated a large collection of 10, 000 drug-like compounds against 7 neglected disease pathogens to obtain a comprehensive view of compound activity against all known and novel pathogens. Our work suggests that the efficiency of early drug discovery for neglected diseases can be enhanced through a collaborative, multi-pathogen approach.

Schistosomiasis is a major public health problem worldwide and the World Health Organization has endorsed the use of praziquantel in morbidity reduction programs since 1984. In this systematic review, we evaluated the impact of reductions in intensity of infection on morbidity in the population using data collected from 2005–2016. We identified that the prevalence of morbidity was reduced by 54%, 47%, 36%, 78%, and 67% respectively for S. mansoni and S. japonicum infections. While reductions in egg output were the most significant impact on morbidity, some morbidities occur at all levels of infection, suggesting that reductions in intensity of infection are not always curative.

Papillorenal syndrome ( PRS ) is a congenital disorder characterized by recurrent ocular and renal abnormalities. Patients with PRS have mutations in the PAX2 gene, but the molecular mechanisms by which these mutations cause disease remain to be explored. Here, we describe a novel mouse model of PRS that recapitulates key features of the disease. We show that all three missense mutations in PAX2 disrupt critical hydrogen bonds in atomic models and lower the transactivation capacity of Pax2 in vitro. Moreover, we show that hypomorphic alleles of PAX2/Pax2 can result in reduced steady-state levels of Pax2 protein, which likely contributes to the lower expression of the PAX2 protein in vivo. These results suggest that hypomorphic alleles of PAX2/Pax2 can cause disease in humans and mice.

Influenza A viruses cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. Infection with influenza A viruses is typically transient and the body’s immune response acts to limit infection. However, the duration of protection is limited and infection frequently returns after the initial immune response is waning. This makes it difficult to predict the duration of protection or the impact of an infection based on serological data. Here, we use a mathematical model to analyse serological data from infection history and immune response dynamics during the course of an influenza infection in southern China and Vietnam. We show that the duration of protection is a function of the initial immune response and that it decays over time. We also show that dynamic immune responses alongside infection history can provide a more accurate alternative to traditional measures of seroconversion. This approach to analysing multiple timescales for immune responses could also be applied to other multistrain pathogens such as dengue and related flaviviruses.

Sterility and inviability are important features of hybrid sterility and inviability. The latter is a phenomenon where a mutation in one species can result in sterility or inviability in another species. Although this phenomenon is well documented, the molecular basis for sterility and inviability remains poorly understood. Here, we develop a screening platform for the comparison of protein–protein interactions ( PPIs ) among closely related species and their hybrids. We examine in vivo the architecture of protein complexes in two yeast species ( Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Saccharomyces kudriavzevii ) that diverged 5–20 million years ago and in their F1 hybrids. We focus on 24 proteins of two large complexes: the RNA polymerase II and the nuclear pore complex ( NPC ). We found that, with the exception of one PPI in the NPC sub-complex, PPIs were highly conserved between species, regardless of protein divergence. Unexpectedly, we found that the architecture of the complexes in F1 hybrids could not be distinguished from that of the parental species. Our results suggest that the conservation of PPIs in hybrids likely results from the slow evolution taking place on the very few protein residues involved in the interaction or that protein complexes are inherently robust and may accommodate protein divergence up to the level that is observed among closely related species.

Malaria is a major health problem worldwide. In 2011, an outbreak of P. vivax malaria was reported in Evrotas, Greece, where a large number of immigrants from endemic countries live and work. A total of 46 locally acquired and 38 imported malaria cases were detected. During 2013 and 2014, a combination of 3-day chloroquine and 14-day primaquine treatment was administered under direct observation to immigrants living in the epicenter of the 2011 outbreak. Adverse events were managed and recorded on a daily basis. The control measures implemented since 2011 continued during the period of 2013–2014 as a part of a national integrated malaria control program that included active case detection ( ACD ), vector control measures and community education. The MDA program was started prior to the transmission periods ( from May to December ). One thousand ninety four ( 1094 ) immigrants successfully completed the treatment, corresponding to 87. 3% coverage of the target population. A total of 688 adverse events were recorded in 397 ( 36. 2%, 95% C. I.: 33. 4–39. 1 ) persons, the vast majority minor, predominantly dizziness and headache for chloroquine ( 284 events ) and abdominal pain ( 85 events ) for primaquine. Preventive antimalarial MDA to a high-risk population in a low transmission setting appears to have synergized with the usual antimalarial activities to achieve malaria elimination.

Macrophages are a type of white blood cell that can detect a variety of pathogen-associated molecular patterns through their Toll-like receptors ( TLRs ). Upon microbial challenge, the TLR-stimulated macrophage undergoes an activation program controlled by a dynamically inducible transcriptional regulatory network. Mapping a complex mammalian transcriptional network poses significant challenges and requires the integration of multiple experimental data types. In this work, we inferred a transcriptional network underlying TLR-stimulated murine macrophage activation. We analyzed expression profiles and transcription factor binding sites from the time-lagged correlation to identify potential causal influences in the network. The time-lagged correlation was used to analyze temporal expression data in order to identify potential causal influences in the network. A novel statistical test was developed to assess the significance of the time-lagged correlation. Several associations in the resulting inferred network were validated using targeted ChIP-on-chip experiments. The network incorporates known regulators and gives insight into the transcriptional control of macrophage activation.

In the past, genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have been used to identify genetic variants that increase or decrease risk for a given disease. However, because of the individual nature of the genetic variants, the study cannot distinguish which variant is associated with the disease, since the variants are likely to have a large number of effects on disease risk. Here, we present a method that uses GWAS data and known pathway–gene and gene–SNP associations to identify pathways that may be relevant to the disease. The method is based upon the hypothesis that, if a pathway is related to disease risk, cases will appear more similar to other cases than to controls for the SNPs associated with that pathway. We apply this method to two different diseases, one of breast cancer and the other of liver cancer. The results strongly suggest that there exist pathway-wide genomic differences that contribute to disease susceptibility. PoDA thus provides an analytical tool that is complementary to existing techniques and has the power to enrich our understanding of disease genomics at the systems-level.

Proteins that are subcellularly localized have been characterized in budding yeast by analyzing fluorescently tagged proteins, which are used to detect proteins in cells in the presence of light. However, a large number of proteins are known to be subcellularly localized based on their protein-protein interactions. Here, we present an unsupervised analysis of protein expression patterns in a set of high-throughput, high-resolution, high-throughput microscope images. Our analysis is based on 7 biologically interpretable features which are evaluated on automatically identified cells, and whose cell-stage dependency is captured by a continuous model for cell growth. We show that it is possible to identify most previously identified localization patterns in a cluster analysis based on these features and that similarities between the inferred expression patterns contain more information about protein function than can be explained by a previous manual categorization of subcellular localization. Furthermore, the inferred cell-stage associated to each fluorescence measurement allows us to visualize large groups of proteins entering the bud at specific stages of bud growth. Our results suggest that biologically interpretable features based on explicit models of cell morphology will yield unprecedented power for pattern discovery in high-throughput, high-throughput microscopy images.

Usutu virus ( USUV ) is a flavivirus that is endemic in birds and can be transmitted to humans. USUV has emerged in North America and Europe, creating significant disease burdens in humans. USUV transmission has also been linked to the potential zoonotic transmission from wild birds to humans. The objective of this study was to determine vector competence of potential mosquito vectors in North America for USUV. The presence of viral RNA in the saliva of infected Cx. pipiens and Cx. quinquefasciatus mosquitoes indicated that these species are competent for transmission of USUV. Results indicate that members of the Cx. pipiens complex are susceptible to USUV and competent for its transmission potential in North America in the event of its introduction. In contrast, Ae. albopictus were highly refractory to USUV infection, suggesting that this species is unlikely to contribute to USUV transmission in North America.

In eukaryotes, cell cycle progression is coupled with the synthesis of cell cycle regulators that regulate entry into the cell cycle. The cell cycle network has two major periods, one during G1 and one during G2. Period 2 is defined by the fact that the cell cycle inhibits progression through the cell cycle. Period 1, on the other hand, is defined as the time when the cell cycle is completely synchronized with the circadian clock. The cell cycle and the circadian clock are coupled in multiple ways, giving that several molecular components of the cell cycle network are controlled in a circadian manner. For example, in the network of cyclin-dependent kinases ( Cdks ) that governs progression along the cell cycle, the synthesis of the kinase Wee1, which inhibits the G2/M transition, is enhanced by the complex CLOCK-B MAL1 that plays a central role in the circadian clock network. We investigate the conditions in which the mammalian cell cycle can be entrained by the circadian clock. We show that the cell cycle can be brought to oscillate at a period of 24 h or 48 h when its autonomous period prior to coupling is in an appropriate range. The model indicates that the cell cycle can be entrained by the circadian clock if the coupling is in an appropriate range.

Arenaviruses are a significant cause of hemorrhagic fever in humans and are endemic in West Africa. Currently, there are no approved antiviral therapies available for treating arenavirus infection. In this study, we discovered that the LHF-535 arenavirus entry inhibitor, which targets the arenavirus envelope glycoproteins, is highly potent against all Lassa virus strains tested, but also potently inhibits Junín virus, the virus used to prevent the arenavirus-mediated hemorrhagic fever in the Americas. These results provide a framework for the clinical development of LHF-535 as a broad-spectrum inhibitor of arenavirus entry.

Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ), the causative agent of a major epidemic spanning five continents, replicates using the cell’s cap-dependent translation machinery. Despite viral infection inhibiting mTOR, a metabolic sensor controls cap-dependent translation, viral proteins are efficiently translated. Rapalog treatment, silencing of mtor or raptor genes, but not rictor, further enhanced CHIKV infection in culture cells. Using biochemical assays and real time imaging, we demonstrate that this effect is independent of autophagy or type I interferon production. In addition, we demonstrate that inhibition of mTORC1 has a specific positive effect on viral proteins, enhancing viral replication by increasing the translation of both structural and nonstructural proteins. We also demonstrate that in the context of CHIKV inhibition of mTORC1, viral replication is prioritized over host translation via a similar mechanism. Our study reveals an unexpected bypass pathway by which CHIKV protein translation overcomes viral induced mTORC1 inhibition.

EBOV causes hemorrhagic fever in humans and nonhuman primates, but not in people infected with other species of filovirus. The basis for this difference is unclear, but it is likely that the pathogenesis of EBOV is influenced by host factors. While there is a strong body of evidence implicating GP as a major virulence factor in the context of EBOV infection, direct evidence for its role in vivo is lacking. We have developed a system to investigate the role of GP in EBOV infection and to examine its contribution to virulence in vivo. Using this system, we have developed chimeric viruses containing the glycoprotein ( GP ) from Zaire ebolavirus and the glycoprotein from EBOV. These chimeric viruses were not only capable of rescuing cell culture-based replication of the full-length EBOV, but were also attenuated in a mouse model of infection. Surprisingly, GP was found to be important for full virulence in both chimeric and wild-type virus infections, and this effect was dependent on the chimeric virus. Together, these results indicate that GP is important for full virulence and suggest that other factors may be needed for the acquisition of full virulence.

Hypoxia-inducible factor 1 ( HIF-1 ), a transcription factor that controls energy metabolism and angiogenesis under hypoxic conditions, is a potent regulator of innate immunity. Despite the fact that HIF-1 is a key regulator of immune responses, the role of HIF-1 in disease resolution in mice after ocular infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is not well understood. Here, we examined the role of HIF-1 in the resolution of chronic P. aeruginosa infection in mice. We found that HIF-1 is essential for the clearance of bacteria from the cornea and the resolution of inflammation. Furthermore, we found that HIF-1 is required for the production of antimicrobial peptides that are known to kill bacteria. Our results indicate that HIF-1 is a key regulator of the inflammatory response to bacterial infection, and may be a potential target for therapeutic intervention in the treatment of chronic bacterial infections.

The eye primordium arises as a lateral outgrowth of the forebrain, with a transient fissure in the inferior side of the optic cup providing an entry point for developing blood vessels. Incomplete closure of the inferior ocular fissure results in coloboma, a disease that is called a congenital ocular anomaly and recognized as a significant cause of childhood blindness. We identified eight patients with defects in tissues of the superior eye, a congenital disorder that we term superior coloboma. Our studies revealed the presence of the superior ocular sulcus ( SOS ), a transient division of the dorsal eye conserved across fish, chick, and mouse. Exome sequencing of superior coloboma patients identified rare variants in a Bone Morphogenetic Protein ( Bmp ) receptor ( BMPR1A ) and T-box transcription factor ( TBX2 ). Consistent with this, we find sulcus closure defects in zebrafish lacking Bmp signaling or Tbx2b. In addition, loss of dorsal ocular Bmp is rescued by concomitant suppression of the ventral-specific Hedgehog pathway, arguing that sulcus closure is dependent on dorsal-ventral eye patterning cues. Our findings explain the existence of superior coloboma, a congenital ocular anomaly resulting from aberrant morphogenesis of a developmental structure.

RNA-directed DNA methylation ( RdDM ) is a conserved epigenetic process that represses transposons and affects the expression of protein-coding genes. It is also involved in gene silencing and is involved in plant development. Although it is well documented, the mechanism of RdDM is not well understood. We show here that RdDM can repress the activity of distant genes, but it is unable to do so in the absence of transcriptional silencing. This suggests that RdDM acts via chromosomal interactions between distant genes. Our results also suggest that RdDM may be recruited to genomic sequences that are distant from genes, and that this process prevents the formation of chromosomal interactions between genes and their distant regulatory elements.

Hereditary Multiple Exostoses ( HME ) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by formation of cartilaginous outgrowths in the bones and joints. It is a genetic disease that is characterized by loss-of-function mutations in the genes encoding the heparan sulfate ( HS ) -synthesizing enzymes. The disease is heterogeneous, and its subtypes are classified as type 1 ( HME I ) and type 2 ( HME II ) based on their pathological features. HME patients are also affected by changes in the cranial base of the growth plates, which is the site of future cartilage biopsies. The present study is the first to analyze the cranial base of the growth plates in HME patients and to investigate the effect of osteochondroma growth on the growth of cartilage cells. Interestingly, osteochondroma was found in patients with HME in the cranial base and we identified the mechanisms that could lead to osteochondroma formation. We also found that the growth plate of HME in mice can be blocked by systemic administration of a BMP antagonist.

Brain activity is a complex phenomenon, in which activity is similar across time scales. This is beneficial with respect to information flow. If subcritical, activity can die out, if supercritical epileptiform patterns may occur. Little is known about how developing networks will reach and stabilize criticality. Here we investigate the development between 13 and 95 days in vitro ( DIV ) of cultured cortical cell cultures ( n = 20 ). We find four different phases, related to their morphological maturation: An initial low-activity state ( ≈19 DIV ) is followed by a supercritical ( ≈20 DIV ) and then a subcritical one ( ≈36 DIV ) until the network finally reaches stable criticality ( ≈58 DIV ). Based on physiological observations, the connectivity of the model neurons to the developing network is determined by the drive of the neurons to adjust their connectivity for reaching on average firing rate homeostasis. We predict a specific time course for the development of inhibition, with strong onset and delayed pruning, and that total synaptic connectivity should be strongly linked to the relative levels of excitation and inhibition. Our results suggest that the interplay between activity and connectivity guides developing networks into criticality suggesting that this may be a generic and stable state of many neural networks in vivo and in vitro.

Plastid and mitochondrial genomes are often unstable, and their instability is crucial for photosynthesis and respiration. Recently, we have reported that RECA1, a nucleotide helicase, controls mitochondrial genome stability by suppressing aberrant recombination between short dispersed repeats in the moss P. patens plastid and mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ). In this study, we investigated the effects of the RECA1 knockout ( KO ) mutation on the stability of mitochondrial genome and the plastid genome. The RECG ( Escherichia coli RECA1 homolog ) knockout ( KO ) mutation caused characteristic phenotypes including growth delay and developmental and mitochondrial defects. Analyses of RECG KO plants showed that mitochondrial genome was destabilized due to a recombination between 8–79 bp repeats and the pattern of the recombination partly differed from that observed in the RECA1 KO mutants. We found that the mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) instability was greater in severe phenotypic RECG KO cells than that in mild phenotypic ones. This result suggests that mitochondrial genomic instability is responsible for the defective phenotypes of RECG KO plants. We also found that the RECG KO mutation induced remarkable plastid abnormalities and induced recombination between short repeats in the plastid DNA. Our results suggest that RECG plays a role in the maintenance of both plastid and mitochondrial genome stability by suppressing aberrant recombination between dispersed short repeats.

Rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting millions of people worldwide. The primary cause of RA is unknown, although it is believed to result from a complex interaction between environmental and genetic factors. One of the most common causes of RA is periodontal infection. Periodontal bacteria are known to induce an autoantibody response, which is thought to be important for the development of RA. Here, we used a rodent model of RA and periodontal infection to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the pro-inflammatory response. We found that P. gingivalis, a common bacterium in the mouth, was able to enhance the severity of RA and to progress to the most common type of RA. The ability of P. gingivalis to increase the severity of RA was dependent on the expression of a unique bacterial enzyme called peptidylarginine deiminase ( PAD ), which converts arginine residues in proteins to citrulline. Infection with P. gingivalis was responsible for significantly increased levels of autoantibodies to collagen type II and citrullinated epitopes as a P. gingivalis mutant did not elicit similar host response. We also showed that citrullinated proteins were also detected at the site of infection with P. gingivalis. Our results suggest bacterial PAD as the mechanistic link between P. gingivalis periodontal infection and rheumatoid arthritis.

In cullin-RING E3 ubiquitin ligases, the substrate binding proteins, such as VHL-box, SOCS-box or the F-box proteins, bind to the substrate and are recruited for ubiquitination, accurately orienting the substrates for ubiquitin transfer. Yet, how the E3 machinery precisely positions the substrate is unknown. Here, we simulated nine substrate binding proteins: Skp2, Fbw7, β-TrCP1, Cdc4, Fbs1, TIR1, pVHL, SOCS2, and SOCS4, in the unbound form and bound to Skp1, ASK1 or Elongin C. All nine proteins have two domains: one binds to the substrate; the other to E3 ligase modules Skp1/ASK1/Elongin C. We found that in all cases the flexible inter-domain linker serves as a hinge, rotating the substrate binding domain, optimally and accurately positioning it for ubiquitin transfer. We observed a conserved proline in the linker of all nine proteins. In all cases, the prolines pucker substantially and the pucker is associated with the backbone rotation toward the E2/ubiquitin. Our findings provide a mechanism for ubiquitination and polyubiquitination, illustrating that these processes are under conformational control.

Strongyloidiasis is a zoonotic infection that can cause life-threatening disease in immunosuppressed patients. Ivermectin is the drug of choice for treatment of strongyloidiasis, but efficacy of single dose is suboptimal. Different dose schedules should be assessed by future, larger studies. We randomized 198 patients with strongyloidiasis to one of the two arms, and followed them up every 4 to 6 months for 12 months. The results show that efficacy of ivermectin is much higher than that of thiabendazole in most patients and, therefore, ivermectin should be included in all treatment regimens. If the analysis is restricted to 92 patients with IFAT titer 80 or more before treatment ( virtually 100% specific ), efficacy would be 85. 7% for ivermectin and 94. 6% for thiabendazole ( 0. 5% difference ). Ivermectin is the drug of choice, but efficacy of single dose is suboptimal. Different dose schedules should be assessed by future, larger studies.

Fish-borne zoonotic trematodes ( FZT ) are a food safety and health concern in Vietnam. Humans and other final hosts acquire these parasites from eating raw or under-coiled fish with FZT metacercariae. Fish raised in ponds are exposed to cercariae shed by snail hosts that are common in fish farm ponds. Previous risk assessment on FZT transmission in the Red River Delta of Vietnam identified carp nurseries as major transmission sites. In this study, we analyzed the association between snail population density and heterophyid trematode infection in snails with the rate of FZT transmission to juvenile fish. We also investigated the association between the intensity of fish FZT infections and the total number and density of potential host snails and the prevalence of host snails infected with heterophyid trematodes. Our results show that the total number and density of potential host snails and density of host snails infected with heterophyid trematodes in the aquaculture pond is a useful predictor for the infection status of juvenile fish. We also found that some of the snails in the pond with no or few infected snails were collected also had high prevalence and intensity of FZT in juvenile fish. Our results suggest that intervention programs to control FZT infection of fish should include not only intra-pond snail control, but also include water sources of allochthonous cercariae, i. e. canals supplying water to ponds as well as snail habitats outside the pond such as rice fields and surrounding ponds.

The MST2-RASSF pathway is a major pathway for the regulation of cell death in many human cancers, and its deregulation is often found in tumorigenesis. A key event in this pathway is the interaction of the RASSF1A, RASSF5, and MST2 kinases. The binding of RASSF1A to the RASSF5/MST2 dimer is thought to be a critical step for the regulation of the RASSF1A-MST2 interaction. However, the molecular interactions between RASSF1A, RASSF5, and MST2 are not known. In this study, we use a combination of atomistic molecular simulation techniques to study the interactions between RASSF1A, RASSF5, and MST2 domains. The results show that the specific interactions between RASSF1A, RASSF5, and MST2 are largely mediated by the SARAH domains, which are present in most RASSF1A and RASSF5 proteins. In addition, we also provide evidence that the interaction of RASSF1A, RASSF5, and MST2 domains with synthetic peptides designed to bind to it can be used to identify potential therapeutic targets for anticancer drug development.

Chlamydia are bacterial pathogens that infect nearly all humans and animals worldwide, and cause a variety of diseases in humans. The infectious particle of these organisms consists of a complex of proteins, termed the chlamydial inclusion, which is assembled in a vesicle-like structure in the cell. This structure is protected from the immune system and can survive in a variety of different cellular environments. The chlamydial inclusion is assembled in the Golgi apparatus, a cellular structure that is composed of Golgi apparatus proteins and is composed of Golgi membranes and Golgi-associated proteins. It has been shown that the chlamydial inclusion functions to target proteins involved in cellular trafficking pathways. In this study, we demonstrate that two members of the Rab protein family, Rab6 and Rab11, are key regulators of Golgi structure and function. We also show that Rab6 and Rab11 are required for efficient replication of Chlamydia in infected cells. Finally, we show that Rab6 and Rab11 are required for Golgi fragmentation, a process that is essential for chlamydial replication. Collectively, our results demonstrate that Rab6 and Rab11 are key regulators of Golgi structure and function, which is important for the efficient replication of Chlamydia in infected cells.

The dynamics of contact patterns are highly variable, and thus create diverse temporal structures. We investigate the impact of these heterogeneities in the spread of an infection from a theoretical perspective. We propose a model to generate temporal networks where vertices make instantaneous contacts following heterogeneous inter-event intervals, and may leave and enter the system. We find that heterogeneous contact patterns cause earlier and larger epidemics in the SIR model in comparison to homogeneous scenarios for a vast range of parameter values, while smaller epidemics may happen in some combinations of parameters. In the case of SI and heterogeneous patterns, epidemics develop faster in the earlier stages followed by a slowdown in the asymptotic limit. For increasing vector turnover rates, heterogeneous patterns generally cause higher prevalence in comparison to homogeneous scenarios with the same average inter-event interval. We find that is generally higher for heterogeneous patterns, except for sufficiently large infection duration and transmission probability.

Zika virus ( ZIKV ) is a flavivirus that is transmitted by mosquitoes, and causes human disease by infecting and replicating in the brain of the infected individual. ZIKV infection is mostly asymptomatic in adults but can cause severe disease in newborns, in adults and in individuals with compromised immune systems. In this study, we have developed a mouse model that supports ZIKV infection and study the pathogenesis induced by different ZIKV strains of a range of spatiotemporal history of isolation and representing African and Asian lineages. We observed that African ZIKV strains induce short episodes of severe neurological symptoms followed by lethality. In contrast, Asian strains cause prolonged signs of neurological dysfunction and frequently lead to death of the Stat2-/- mice. Additionally, we exploited this model to compare ZIKV pathogenesis caused by a panel of ZIKV strains of a range of spatiotemporal history of isolation and representing African and Asian lineages. We observed that African ZIKV strains induce higher levels of inflammatory cytokines and markers associated with cellular infiltration in the infected brain in mice, which may explain exacerbated pathogenesis in comparison to those of the Asian lineage. This study paves the way for the future interrogation of strain-specific changes in the ZIKV genome and their contribution to viral pathogenesis.

Optimization is a ubiquitous feature of biological systems, and many of our current models of cell signaling, metabolism, and development are based on optimization theory. Here, we present a general framework to investigate how different types of optimization affect plant growth and development. In particular, we show that the optimization trade-offs between competing objectives can be captured as strikingly simple relationships that can be captured by simple models of growth and development. We show that these simple relationships can be further exploited to identify genes whose mutations can shift the trade-offs between competing objectives. These results provide a framework to understand optimization trade-offs made by shoot architectures and provide evidence that these trade-offs can be modified genetically, which may help plant breeding and selection efforts.

Two dimensional polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis ( 2D PAGE ) is used to identify differentially expressed proteins and may be applied to biomarker discovery. A limitation of this approach is the inability to detect a protein when its concentration falls below the limit of detection. Consequently, differential expression of proteins may be missed when the level of a protein in the cases or controls is below the limit of detection for 2DPAGE. Standard statistical techniques have difficulty dealing with undetected proteins. To address this issue, we propose a statistical model that takes into account both detected and non-detected proteins. Non-detected proteins are classified either as ( a ) proteins that are not expressed in at least one replicate, or ( b ) proteins that are expressed but are below the limit of detection. We obtain maximum likelihood estimates of the parameters of the mixture model, including the group-specific probability of expression and mean expression intensities. Differently expressed proteins can be detected by using a Likelihood Ratio Test ( LRT ). Our simulation results, using data generated from biological experiments, show that the likelihood model has higher statistical power than standard statistical approaches to detect differentially expressed proteins. An R package, Slc ( Statistical-Like Analysis for Identifying Differential Expression in R ), is freely available at http://www. cebl. auckland. ac. nz/session/software/ is used to demonstrate how the likelihood model can be used to identify differentially expressed proteins.

In recent years, the search for new drugs to control neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ) has become more and more important, especially for the malaria and neglected helminths. This study focuses on a novel class of drug targets, Lysine deacetylases ( KDACs ), with a focus on the use of small molecules to target these enzymes. The use of small molecules to inhibit these enzymes has the potential to reduce the cost of drug development and accelerate the process of developing novel drug candidates for parasite control. We screened a small compound library of 23 hydroxamate- or benzamide-based small molecules for their ability to inhibit the activity of one or more of the known KDACs in human cells. We found that some of these compounds have good selectivity for different parasitic species, supporting the use of this approach to find novel drug targets.

We present RAVEN, a software package that allows for semi-automated reconstruction of genome-scale metabolic models. The software suite includes a number of methods for visualizing simulation results and omics data, as well as a range of methods for performing simulations and analyzing the results. The software is a useful tool for system-wide data analysis in a metabolic context and for streamlined reconstruction of metabolic networks based on protein homology. The software is also a useful tool for analyzing the roles of ATP and NADPH in the biosynthesis of penicillin, and to identify metabolic engineering targets for maximizing penicillin production.

Organisms have evolved a number of mechanisms for generating the two sexes. The honeybee is an excellent model organism for investigating how mechanisms interact to determine sex. The honeybee has a system in which sex is determined by heterozygosity at the Sex Determination Locus. Little is known, however, about how this system regulates sexual development. To investigate the control of sexual development in honeybees, we analyzed genes involved in the sex determination pathway. We show that heterozygous females only need to process the Sex Determination Locus to induce the female pathway, while the feminizer is required to maintain the female determined pathway throughout development. We also show that the feminizer is essential for the splicing of conserved male-specific transcripts that control sexual differentiation. Our findings reveal how the sex determination process is realized in honeybees differing from Drosophila melanogaster.

Hox genes are involved in the patterning of animal body parts in multiple ways. They establish a segmental or regional identity in the anterior region of the fly leg and are required later in development for the formation of the sex determination organs, such as the antennae and bristles, or for the posterior abdominal segments. In insects, Hox genes regulate the expression of other genes in a spatially restricted manner, including the sex determination gene sex combs reduced. In Drosophila, the expression of sex combs reduced is determined by the spatially localized expression of Scr, a transcription factor that is activated in a restricted spatial domain of the first thoracic ( T1 ) leg. Scr is required for the development of T1-specific bristle cells in both sexes and sex combs. However, it is unclear how Scr is integrated into the gene regulatory network required for T1-specific organ development. Here, we identified two cis-regulatory elements that control spatially localized Scr expression. One of these enhancers directs sexually dimorphic expression and is required for the development of T1-specific bristle patterns. We show that the Distalless and Engrailed homeodomain transcription factors act through sequences in this enhancer to establish elevated Scr expression in spatially defined domains. This enhancer functions to integrate Scr into the gene regulatory network, such that Scr serves as a link between leg patterning, sex determination, and sensory organ development.

GBS is a major cause of death and disability in Asia, and is a particular problem in the tropics. Human GBS is caused by either bacteria from the human intestine, or the kidneys of animals, such as fish. Humans are exposed to GBS when they eat raw freshwater fish. There is no treatment for GBS and the bacteria are usually thought to be only produced in the intestine. In 2015, Singapore had the first and only reported foodborne outbreak of invasive disease caused by GBS; the outbreak was linked to a fish disease in the East Coast. Disease, predominantly septic arthritis and meningitis, was associated with sequence type ( ST ) 283, acquired from eating raw freshwater fish. While disease was linked to sequence type 283, there was a large proportion of GBS collected from humans in Southeast Asia and the USA. We conducted a literature review and analysis of the existing GBS research literature to look for outbreaks in Asia, and found ST283 was found in almost all invasive Asian collections, including 38 ( 4/13 ) human isolates, and 100 ( 1/38 ) fish isolates, from 14 outbreak sites in Malaysia and Vietnam, 167 ( 23% ) in Singapore. We found ST283 in 62/62 ( 100% ) tilnea from 14 outbreak sites in Malaysia and Vietnam, 102/139 ( 73% ) in Thailand, and 167/739 ( 23% ) in Singapore. We conclude that ST283 was causing disease in humans and animals in Southeast Asia. This finding suggests that prevention needs to be initiated across borders and that control measures need to be coordinated across countries.

The “splashed white” pattern is a classic example of horse-specific hair pigmentation. Horses with this pattern are mostly deaf and show very little phenotypic variation. However, some horses are completely blind and show a wide range of phenotypic variation. We analyzed a large group of horses with the “Splashed white” phenotype and identified mutations in the PAX3 gene. We then used this information to gain insight into the genetic basis of the “splashed white” phenotype and identified several potential variants in the PAX3 promoter. We finally identified two additional non-synonymous mutations in the MITF gene that cause a similar phenotype. We therefore conclude that these three mutations together explain a large proportion of horses with the more extreme white spotting phenotypes.

Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ) is a mosquito-transmitted virus that causes global epidemics of a debilitating polyarthritis in humans. There are no licensed vaccines or antiviral drugs for CHIKV, and no licensed vaccine is currently available. We screened 230 new mouse monoclonal antibodies ( MAbs ) for their ability to inhibit infection of all three genotypes of CHIKV. Four of 36 neutralizing MAbs ( CHK-102, CHK-152, CHK-166, and CHK-263 ) provided full protection against lethality as prophylaxis in highly susceptible immunocompromised mice lacking the type I IFN receptor ( Ifnar−/− ) and mapped to distinct epitopes on the E1 and E2 structural proteins. In post-exposure therapeutic trials, administration of a single dose of a combination of two neutralizing MAbs ( CHK-102+CHK-152 or CHK-166+CHK-152 ) limited the development of resistance and protected immunocompromised mice against disease when given 24 to 36 hours before CHIKV-induced death. Our results suggest that selected pairs of highly neutralizing MAbs may be a promising treatment option for CHIKV in humans.

Infections with non-typeable Hemophilus influenzae ( NTHi ) are a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in the United States. Little is known about the host immune responses to NTHi infection. We have developed animal and cell culture models to examine the effects of RV on NTHi-induced cytokine production, neutrophil recruitment and bacterial clearance. Mice infected with RV1B were superinfected with NTHi and lung bacterial density, chemokines and neutrophil counts determined. Mice were also infected with RV, TLR2 agonists or TLR5 agonists. Chemokine levels were measured by ELISA and expression of IRAK-1, a component of MyD88-dependent TLR signaling. While sham-infected mice cleared NTHi from the lungs, RV-infected mice showed bacteria up to 72 h post-infection. Delayed bacterial clearance in RV/NTHi-infected mice was associated with suppressed chemokine production and neutrophil recruitment. RV-infected BEAS-2B and MH-S cells showed attenuated chemokine production after challenge with either NTHi or TLR agonists. Attenuated chemokine responses were associated with IRAK-1 protein degradation. Inhibition of RV-induced IRAK-1 degradation restored NTHi-stimulated IL-8 expression. Knockdown of TLR2, but not other MyD88-dependent TLRs, also restored IRAK-1, suggesting that TLR2 is required for RV-induced IRAK-1 degradation. In conclusion, we demonstrate for the first time that RV infection delays bacterial clearance in vivo and suppresses NTHi-stimulated chemokine responses via TLR-dependent degradation of IRAK-1.

The Polycomb group ( PcG ) proteins are evolutionarily conserved protein complexes that regulate the expression of hundreds of genes and play a key role in development. PcG proteins are recruited to DNA elements called Polycomb response elements ( PREs ). PcG response elements are often short, and their location within the genome is often predicted based on the DNA sequence. Previous reports have shown that PcG proteins can bind to short DNA fragments, but that this does not necessarily imply the presence of a short DNA motif. In this work, we have identified that the four most strongly bound PREs in the genome do not disrupt the binding of PcG proteins to DNA. These results suggest that the presence of strong PREs does not necessarily imply the presence of short DNA sequences. We also show that the domains of PcG proteins that bind to short DNA fragments are stable over many millions of years of evolution. The 3D structure of the domain that contains the most strongly bound PRE is only marginally altered by the deletion of the strongly bound PREs. Our results suggest that the 3D structure of the domain is a signature of the recruitment of PcG proteins to Drosophila genes via interactions with multiple, weak PREs spread throughout the domain.

Caves are complex cavities that are formed by a variety of interacting proteins. Caveolae are one of the most abundant groups of mammalian cell types, and they form the functional units of the plasma membrane. The function of caveolae is to sequester the majority of the cell population of the body, and to provide an efficient route for energy transfer. Many of the proteins that comprise the caveolae are conserved across a wide range of species. However, it is not known how the proteins interact with each other to form a protein complex. We have determined that the proteins in the caveolae are not bound together in isolation, but rather in a complex. This complex is composed of at least 80 different proteins that can form a functional unit. We show that one of the caveolae proteins, cavin 1, is involved in forming a complex with many other proteins. We also show that another caveolae protein, EHD2, is involved in forming a complex with cavin 1, but that it does not interact with cavin 2. We also present evidence that the caveolar coat complex is composed of individual units that are connected by a unitary interface.

In response to various environmental stimuli, small non-coding RNAs ( sRNAs ) are employed to regulate the expression of genes and are involved in the regulation of transcription and post-transcriptional processes. In this work, we report that a sRNA of the model plant alpha-proteobacterium S. meliloti, EcpR1, is induced under various stress conditions. We present evidence that EcpR1 contributes to the regulation of cell cycle progression and cell elongation.

Plasmodium vivax is a major cause of malaria morbidity and mortality in the developing world. An improved understanding of the biology of this parasite will facilitate vaccine development. Glycan masking is an emerging vaccine design strategy to focus the antibody response to specific epitopes, but has mostly been evaluated on the already heavily glycosylated HIV gp120 envelope glycoprotein. Here we use four different variants of P. vivax Duffy Binding Protein ( PvDBP ) to demonstrate that glycan masking does not increase the binding affinity for its cognate DARC receptor for chemokines. Instead, we find that addition of N-glycan sites distant from DARC binding sites may enhance inhibitory antibody responses. Our results suggest that glycan masking may be an attractive and feasible tool to investigate protein structure-function, and may contribute to P. vivax vaccine development.

Human learning about values and actions is thought to be strongly dependent on “action-value learning. ” We investigated human learning about the values of both states and actions by investigating the neural activity of reward-prediction errors ( i. e., signals that indicate the value of one action in relation to the other ). We developed a task to measure the activity of brain regions involved in reward-learning. The task is optimized to enable dissociation of the subtypes of reward-prediction errors that function as the key computational signatures of two distinct classes of learning models: “actor/critic” models and “action-value-prediction models. ” We performed functional magnetic resonance imaging ( fMRI ) and scanned human participants with a high-resolution method for measuring brain activity as well as the striatal areas to which it projects. In keeping with the “actor/critic” model, the reward-prediction error signal was detected in the substantia nigra. However, alongside these purely state-value-based computations, we also found evidence for action-value-prediction signals throughout the striatum. These results suggest that the human brain can learn about values and actions by employing distinct mechanisms that operate in parallel with each other.

Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) is a herpesvirus that causes multiple human diseases, including B-cell lymphomas and epithelial cancers. Epstein-Barr virus is a gammaherpesvirus and expresses its structural proteins as part of the viral particle. While the protein BZLF1 ( Z ) is expressed on the viral particles and functions to activate the expression of the viral proteins BRRF1 and BRRF2, it is the only known virus promoter that is methylated. We now demonstrate that Z is also able to activate the methylated form of BRRF1, and that this activity requires two methylation sites on the Z protein. These methylation sites are critical for the activity of Z. We also show that the two sites on Z are required for the induction of the expression of the viral protein Ngn1. Our results indicate that methylation on Z is important for the reactivation of EBV from latency, and suggest that methylation may also be important for the establishment of latency following infection.

The JAK/STAT ( Janus Kinase/Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription ) pathway is a conserved signaling pathway that regulates a variety of physiological activities in the adult intestinal epithelium. The JAK/STAT pathway is controlled by the Wing and Wasp signaling molecules. However, it remains poorly understood how JAK/STAT signaling activity is regulated in these processes. In this study, we have identified the wdp gene as a novel component of the JAK/STAT pathway. We demonstrate that wdp is positively regulated by JAK/STAT signaling in Drosophila intestinal epithelia. wdp loss causes the disruption of midgut homeostasis under normal and regenerative conditions. Conversely, ectopic expression of wdp inhibits JAK/STAT signaling activity. Importantly, we show that Wdp interacts with the receptor Domeless ( Dome ), and promotes its internalization for subsequent lysosomal degradation. Together, these data led us to propose that Wdp acts as a novel negative feedback regulator of the JAK/STAT pathway in regulating intestinal homeostasis.

Trichodysplasia spinulosa is a human polyomavirus that causes trichodysplasia, a chronic skin disease that can lead to severe immunosuppression and complications. We have previously shown that TSPyV interacts with sialic acid, which is present on the surface of most mammalian cells, including immune cells. While sialic acid is a key receptor for TSPyV, the precise molecular recognition event is still unknown. In this study, we show that TSPyV interacts with sialic acids through a novel glycan recognition site on the VP1 protein. We also provide evidence that glycolipids play an important role during TSPyV infection. Our findings provide new insights into the molecular recognition and receptor usage by polyomaviruses, and also suggest that glycolipids may be an important target for antiviral drugs.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ), a neglected tropical disease, is a major public health concern, particularly in the poorest countries of the world. In recent years, numerous CL trials have been conducted and reported. However, the methodologies used to assess treatment effects in clinical trials have been inconsistent. To address this, we conducted a consensus review of clinical trial methodologies for CL. Our results demonstrate that the two distinct CL sites, Old World and New World, are characterized by distinct properties and outcomes. Our consensus approach will help standardize future clinical trials for CL and facilitate the evaluation of candidate treatments. We encourage CL researchers to adopt and adapt as required the proposed parameters and outcomes in their future trials and provide feedback on their experience.

Biological membranes are elastic, bilayer-rich organelles that are responsible for many cellular functions, such as cell shape maintenance and cell motility. The biophysical properties of biological membranes are characterized by a variety of mechanical parameters, such as stiffness and conductance. These parameters have been quantified to a level that allows for detailed comparison across different species. We have examined the effects of mechanical properties on protein structure and dynamics. We show that a particular mechanical parameter, elastic forces, have a strong effect on the stability of the protein. Specifically, elastic forces cause cooperative gating, i. e., the simultaneous activity of two or more proteins is altered such that one protein binds to both of the other proteins. We also show that the spatial organization of proteins into functional units, such as complexes or nanostructures, is also dependent on mechanical properties. Specifically, we find that the spatial organization of the protein can have a profound effect on the stability of the protein, as well as on the dynamics of the protein, in a particular case. These results provide important insight into the roles of mechanical properties on protein structure and dynamics, and into the organization of biological membranes.

In 2014–2016, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia in West Africa experienced the largest and longest Ebola epidemic since the discovery of the virus in 1976. During the epidemic, incidence data were collected and published at increasing resolution. We develop a novel spatiotemporal analysis method that combines a local model for time-varying effective reproduction numbers with a gravity-type model for spatial dispersion of the infection. We test this method in simulations and apply it to the weekly incidences of confirmed and probable cases. Our results indicate that, of the newly infected cases, only a small percentage, between 4% and 10%, migrates to another district, and a minority of these migrants, between 0% and 23%, leave their country. The epidemics in the three countries are found to be similar in estimated effective reproduction numbers, and in the probability of importing infection into a district. The countries might have played different roles in cross-border transmissions, although a sensitivity analysis suggests that this could also be related to underreporting. The spatiotemporal analysis method can exploit available longitudinal incidence data at different geographical locations to monitor local epidemics, determine the extent of spatial spread, reveal the contribution of local and imported cases, and identify sources of introductions in uninfected areas. With good quality data on incidence, this analysis method can help to effectively control emerging infections.

In addition to the production of viral particles, the herpes simplex virus 1 ( HSV1 ) also packages its genome into a replication-competent particle. While it encodes only 13 viral proteins, HSV1 utilizes an additional 60–70 proteins to regulate the expression of the viral genome and the production of new particles. The viral genome is packaged into particles by a process termed viral particle assembly. We have recently shown that one of the viral proteins, virion host shutoff ( vhs ), is also active against viral mRNAs, thereby preventing their uncontrolled degradation. In this study, we have performed a dual transcriptomic analysis and single-cell mRNA FISH to study the mechanism of action of vhs. We have found that vhs is involved in the regulation of the host cell transcriptome in two ways. First, vhs is involved in maintaining the nuclear retention of viral mRNAs. Second, vhs appears to regulate the transcription of viral mRNAs. Our data suggest that the late expression of viral mRNAs is regulated by vhs and that the cellular mRNA cycle and the nuclear retention of these mRNAs are coordinated to allow efficient and robust expression of viral proteins.

In order to maximize the amount of information that can be processed by the sensory system, neurons must be selectively tuned to the relevant sensory information. However, it is unclear how the brain distinguishes the information that is relevant to the task from the distracting information that is not. Here, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging ( fMRI ) to measure brain electrical activity in response to visual stimuli and to examine the relationship between this activity and brain function. We recorded the electrical activity of 16 participants, each with a visual stimulus and a sound that differs in the left and right hemifields. One participant was selectively tuned to the left hemifield, while the others were not. We then used brain electrical activity in the same regions to measure the brain response to the right hemifield and the left hemifield. Our results demonstrate that neuronal activity in the brain during attention is essential for distinguishing between the relevant and distracting information.

Nonsense mutations in human NARS2 cause human deafness and hearing loss. Here we show that the mitochondrial respiratory chain deficiency associated with the human NARS2 mutation, p. Val213Phe, is the primary cause of this phenotype. The NARS2 mutation p. Tyr323* is found in patients with a compound heterozygous mutation in NARS2, which shows no effect on NARS2 oligomerization. p. Val213Phe and p. Tyr323* are the same type of mutation, but differ in the type of lesion they cause. The severity of the genetic lesions and their effects on NARS2 protein structure cosegregate with the phenotype. We show that NARS2 oligomerization is decreased in the presence of the NARS2 mutation. Additionally, we show that dimerization is also affected in fibroblasts from the patients with the hearing loss mutation. Our findings establish lesions in NARS2 as a new cause for nonsyndromic hearing loss and Leigh syndrome.

Infections of macrophages and dendritic cells ( pDC ) with intracellular pathogens trigger production of type I interferons ( IFN-I ), a family of proteins that act as antiviral defense mechanisms. IFN-I are secreted proteins that are responsible for the production of antibodies. IFN-I are also involved in the regulation of the immune response to other intracellular pathogens. Type I IFN-I are produced by a specialized “interferon-producing cell” ( IPC ), which has been shown to belong to the lineage of plasmacytoid dendritic cells ( pDC ). It is unclear whether production of systemic IFN-I is generally attributable to pDC irrespective of the nature of the infecting pathogen. We have addressed this question by studying infections of mice with the intracellular bacterium Listeria monocytogenes. Mice infected with L. monocytogenes are weakened by IFN-I activity. In contrast, in vitro–differentiated pDC infected with L. monocytogenes needed TLR9 to transcribe IFN-I mRNA. Synthesis of serum IFN-I did not require TLR9. In vitro–differentiated pDC infected with L. monocytogenes needed TLR9 to transcribe IFN-I mRNA. Based on these data, we propose that the engagement of pDC, the mode of IFN-I mobilization, as well as the shaping of the antimicrobial innate immune response by IFN-I differ between intracellular pathogens.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) is the most deadly bacterial pathogen worldwide. It has been estimated that one-third of the world's population is infected with Mtb, and 1. 5 billion people are at risk of infection. Despite a dramatic increase in new tuberculosis cases in the past 30 years, the number of new cases remains low, suggesting that Mtb remains a successful host-pathogen interaction. Understanding how the immune system controls Mtb infection is crucial to developing better vaccines and the development of effective drugs to prevent Mtb infection and the resulting burden of disease. The major Vγ2Vδ2 T-cell subset that recognizes Mtb antigen is highly restricted to primates. Here, we show that expansion of Vγ2Vδ2 T cells that is induced during Mtb infection can significantly increase the pulmonary defense against Mtb infection. This is the first study to show that Vγ2Vδ2 T-cell expansion induced by Mtb infection can increase the pulmonary defense against Mtb. This study suggests that expanding Vγ2Vδ2 T cells during Mtb infection could increase the immune response to Mtb infection and increase the probability of developing protective immunity to tuberculosis.

Burkholderia pseudomallei is a Category B select agent and the cause of melioidosis. Research funding for vaccine development has largely considered protection within the biothreat context, but the resulting vaccines could be applicable to populations who are at risk of naturally acquired melioidosis. Here, we discuss target populations for vaccination, consider the cost-benefit of different vaccination strategies and review potential vaccine candidates. We review the safety and efficacy of candidate vaccines in animal models and identify the most promising candidates. Possible candidates included live attenuated, whole cell killed, sub-unit, plasmid DNA and dendritic cell vaccines. Live attenuated vaccines were not considered favorably because of possible reversion to virulence and hypothetical risk of latent infection, while the other candidates need further development and evaluation. Melioidosis is acquired by skin inoculation, inhalation and ingestion, but routes of animal inoculation in most published studies to date do not reflect all of this. We found a lack of studies using diabetic models, which will be central to any evaluation of a melioidosis vaccine for natural infection since diabetes is the most important risk factor. Vaccines could represent one strand of a public health initiative to reduce the global incidence of melioidosis.

Oxidative phosphorylation is an important mechanism for energy reprogramming of mitochondrial tRNAs. Defects in mitochondrial tRNA modification can cause several diseases such as heart failure and oxidative phosphorylation ( OXPHOS ). Here we use the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans to investigate the role of the different genes in the mitochondrial tRNA modification pathway. We found that, although the inactivation of each C. elegans gene is associated with a mild OXPHOS dysfunction, mutations in mtcu-1 or mtcu-2 cause changes in the expression of metabolic and mitochondrial stress response genes that are quite different from those caused by mttu-1 mutations. Our data suggest that retrograde signaling promotes defect-specific metabolic reprogramming, which is able to rescue the OXPHOS dysfunction in the single mutants by stimulating the oxidative tricarboxylic acid cycle flux through complex II. However, this adaptive response appears to be associated with a biological cost since the single mutants exhibit decreased fertility and long reproductive cycle. We further show that mttu-1; mttu-1 and mtcu-2; mttu-1 double mutants display severe growth defects and sterility. Our work highlights the important association of the defect-specific metabolic rewiring with the pathological phenotype, which must be taken into consideration in exploring specific therapeutic interventions.

Schistosomiasis is a disease caused by parasitic worms that are transmitted by the blood fluke, S. mansoni. The parasite infects the liver and the kidneys of the human host and causes a chronic infection in the liver, which can progress to a life-threatening disease. It is transmitted through the feces of the parasite carrier, the snail, and the intermediate host snail, and the snail is the vector. The parasite lives in the snail, and in the human host, it can infect the liver and the kidneys, and in some cases, the spleen. The snail can be up to 100 times more important. There are no vaccines available and there are no drugs that kill the parasite. In order to control the disease, it is important to know the prevalence of the disease in the population at risk, which is important for the decision of the control program. In this study, we have shown that the prevalence of the disease is much higher than anticipated. This is important as it suggests that there is an urgent need to implement effective control measures.

The bacterial PhoQ two-component system is a transmembrane histidine kinase conserved from Gram-negative bacteria to humans. PhoQ is the histidine kinase chemoreceptor of this signaling complex and assembles in a homodimer conformation spanning the bacterial inner membrane. Currently, a full understanding of the PhoQ signal transduction is hindered by the lack of a complete atomistic structure. In this study, an atomistic model of the key transmembrane ( TM ) domain is assembled by using molecular simulations, guided by cross-linking data. The formation of a polar pocket involving Asn202 in the lumen of the tetrameric TM bundle is crucial for the assembly and solvation of the domain. Moreover, a concerted displacement of the TM helices at the periplasmic side is found to modulate a rotation at the cytoplasmic end, supporting the transduction of the chemical signal through a combination of scissoring and rotational movement of the TM helices.

Gambiense Human African Trypanosomiasis ( HAT ) is a vector-borne disease affecting largely rural populations in West Africa. It is transmitted by tsetse flies, and has been shown to result in large reductions in the global incidence of the disease over recent decades. Currently, the majority of HAT patients are detected by active case finding and treated by passive case detection. Strategies based on active case finding and treatment have drastically reduced the global incidence of the disease over recent decades. However, little is known about the impact of passive case detection. We analysed data from the period between active screening sessions in hundreds of villages that were monitored as part of three HAT control programmes run by Médecins Sans Frontières in Southern Sudan and Uganda in the late 1990s and early 2000s. We found heterogeneity in incidence across villages, with a small minority of villages found to have much higher rates of transmission than the majority. We further found that only a minority of the prevalent cases in the first stage of the disease were detected passively, whereas around 50% of patients in the second stage were detected. Our results suggest that passive case detection has a potential to reduce transmission in affected areas, suggesting that there is great potential value in improving the quality of passive case detection.

This paper describes a novel, next-generation retinal cell–tailored optogenetic tool. We introduce a chimeric protein consisting of the intracellular domain of the ON-bipolar cell–specific metabotropic glutamate receptor mGluR6 and the light-sensing domain of melanopsin, which overcomes the low light sensitivity of the cell–tailored retinal transgenic mice. The protein is expressed in the ON-bipolar retinal cells, which are the primary targets of light-induced degeneration in humans. This chimeric protein is shown to reliably recovers vision at the retinal, cortical, and behavioral levels under moderate daylight illumination.

Genomic aberrations are typically associated with cancer progression and are often considered important prognostic markers. Aberrations are typically studied in a single sample; however, in some cases multiple samples can be used to study the presence and nature of aberrations. This is especially important for certain cancer types where multiple samples are used to study the presence and nature of aberrations. We have developed a method that can be used to detect and characterize such multiple samples, and to assess the significance of these aberrations. The method can be used to identify regions of the genome that are associated with multiple samples, and is validated on synthetic data. We apply our method to a dataset of breast cancer samples and find that our method is able to accurately detect aberrations, and identify regions of the genome that are likely to be important for the progression of the disease. We also apply our method to other important problems in biology.

How the developmental system resists the inevitable noise to acquire developmental reproducibility is a fundamental question in developmental biology. Toward this end, we focused on vertebrate somitogenesis as a representative system, because somites are repeatedly reproduced within a single embryo whereas such reproducibility is lost in segmentation clock gene-deficient embryos. The present study presents a novel theoretical model of ERK-mediated somitogenesis, in which bistable ERK activity is regulated by an FGF gradient, cell-cell communication, and the segmentation clock, subject to the intrinsic noise. Simulations were performed to explore the effects of noise on developmental reproducibility, in particular the effects of noise intensity. The results show that the clock reduces the inherent somite irregularity and reproducibility, resulting from the presence of an irregular stepwise shift of the ERK activity.

DnaA is a conserved key regulator of replication initiation in bacteria, and is homologous to ORC proteins in archaea and in eukaryotic cells. The ATPase binds to several high affinity binding sites at the origin region and upon an unknown molecular trigger, spreads to several adjacent sites, inducing the formation of a helical super structure leading to initiation of replication. Here, we show that DnaA is bound to oriC with a half-time of 2. 5 seconds. DnaA shows similar turnover at the replication machinery, showing a half-time of 2. 5 seconds. The absence of YabA increases the half time binding of DnaA to oriC, showing that YabA plays a dual role in the regulation of DnaA, as a tether at the replication forks, and as a chaser at origin regions.
