Likewise, a deletion of soj ( encoding a ParA protein ) leads to an increase in residence time and to overinitiation, while a mutation in DnaA that leads to lowered initiation frequency, due to a reduced ATPase activity, shows a decreased residence time on binding sites. Finally, our single molecule tracking experiments show that DnaA rapidly moves between chromosomal binding sites, and does not arrest for more than few hundreds of milliseconds. In Escherichia coli, DnaA shows low residence times in the range of 200 ms and oscillates between spatially opposite chromosome regions in a time frame of one to two seconds, independently of ongoing transcription. Thus, DnaA shows extremely rapid binding turnover on the chromosome including oriC regions in two bacterial species, which is influenced by Soj and YabA proteins in B. subtilis, and is crucial for balanced initiation control, likely preventing fatal premature multimerization and strand opening of DnaA at oriC.

Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, remains a serious health concern in Latin America. The parasite is highly polymorphic and escapes the host immune response by antigenic variation. The Trypanosoma genome encodes a large family of genes, including Mucin-Associated Surface Proteins ( MASP ), with highly conserved regions. MASP molecules display a ‘mosaic’ structure, with variable combinations of highly conserved regions and variable domains. MASP molecules are expressed in mammalian stages of the parasite and may be involved in parasite-host interactions. Here, we profiled MASP molecules during chronic infection using serum samples from humans infected with T. cruzi. We identified 86 MASP antigenic motifs, each one likely representing a single linear B-cell epitope, which were mapped to 69 different MASP polypeptides. The MASP antigenic motifs were also further characterized, including identification of co-occurrence of several motifs within MASP polypeptides. We also evaluated the potential involvement of these MASP antigenic motifs in the evolution of their coding genes. This is the first high-resolution profiling of linear B-cell epitopes from T. cruzi MASP molecules during human infection.

Cognitive stability and flexibility are core functions in successful behavioral goals. While there is evidence for a common frontoparietal network underlying both functions, the exact neurocomputational mechanisms underlying those executive functions and their adaptation to environmental demands are still unclear. In this work, we study the neurocomputational mechanisms underlying cue based task switching ( flexibility ) and distractor inhibition ( stability ) in a task that probes both functions. We develop a physiologically plausible, explicit model of neural networks that maintain the currently active task rule in working memory and implement the decision process. By fitting our model to individual subjects’ behavioral data, we can reproduce their full behavior in terms of decisions and reaction time distributions in baseline as well as distractor inhibition and switch conditions. Furthermore, we predict the individual hemodynamic response timecourse of the rule-representing network and localize it to a frontoparietal network including the inferior frontal junction area and the intraparietal sulcus. We estimate the subject-specific stability of the rule-representing states in terms of the minimal action associated with a transition between different rule states. This stability measure correlates with switching-specific thalamocorticostriatal activation, i. e., with a system associated with flexible working memory updating and dopaminergic modulation of cognitive flexibility.

Although a recent study showed that chronic inflammation led to a loss of renewal in the taste system, the molecular effect of this inflammatory process on the taste system has not been investigated. We demonstrate that chronic inflammation leads to a drastic reduction in the number of taste buds in the gustatory tissues of mice, and a consequent decrease in renewal. These results indicate that chronic inflammation, while enhancing renewal, can also inhibit renewal and thereby prolong the life span of the taste system.

Telomerase-independent ALT ( alternative lengthening of telomeres ) cells are characterized by high frequency of telomeric homologous recombination ( HR ), C-rich extrachromosomal circles ( C-circles ) and C-rich terminal 5' overhangs ( C-overhangs ). However, underlying mechanism is poorly understood. Here, we show that both C-circle and C-overhang form when replication fork collapse is induced by strand break at telomeres. We find that collapsed forks could be rescued by replication fork regression leading to telomeric homologous recombination, while those unresolved are converted to C-circles and C-overhang at lagging and leading synthesized strand, respectively. Meanwhile, multiple hallmarks of ALT are provoked, suggesting that strand break-induced replication stress underlies ALT. Our findings provide a molecular basis underlying telomeric HR and biogenesis of C-circle and C-overhang, thus implicating the specific mechanism to resolve strand break-induced replication defect at telomeres in ALT cells.

Circadian clocks are known to be synchronized with the day-night cycle primarily by light. The fish represent fascinating models for deciphering the light input pathway to the vertebrate clock since fish cell clocks are regulated by direct light exposure. Here we have performed a comparative, functional analysis of the circadian clock involving the zebrafish that is normally exposed to the day-night cycle and a cavefish species that has evolved in perpetual darkness. Our results reveal that the cavefish retains a food-entrainable clock that oscillates with an infradian period. However, this clock is not regulated by light. This comparative study pinpoints the two extra-retinal photoreceptors Melanopsin ( Opn4m2 ) and TMT-opsin as essential upstream elements of the peripheral clock light input pathway.

Respiratory paramyxoviruses are important causes of morbidity and mortality in infants and elderly. Th2 immune responses to these infections are associated with increased disease severity, however the endogenous regulators of these responses are unknown. IL-27 is a cytokine that regulates Th2 responses and is produced in the lungs during parainfluenza infection. To determine whether IL-27 limits the development of Th2 responses during paramyxovirus infection, IL-27-deficient or control mice were infected with the murine parainfluenza virus Sendai virus. Infected IL-27-deficient mice experienced increased weight loss, more severe lung lesions, and decreased survival compared to controls. IL-27 deficiency led to increased pulmonary eosinophils, alternatively activated macrophages ( AAMs ), and the emergence of Th2 responses. Elimination of STAT6 signaling in IL-27-deficient mice reduced Th2 responses and decreased disease severity. These data indicate that endogenous IL-27 limits the development of pathology during parainfluenza virus infection by regulating the quality of CD4+ T cell responses and therefore may have therapeutic potential in paramyxovirus infections.

Causal relationships between phenotypes are often established by constructing a network in which all causal relationships are explicitly stated. Such network models are called causal inference. Caused changes in gene expression levels are known to be causal, but the effect of gene expression changes on the network itself is not well understood. We have used data from a population of Arabidopsis leaves and simulated data from metabolic models to show that causal inference is not well suited to metabolic networks with known stoichiometry. We conclude that non-genetic residual variation is necessary to reliably infer causal relationships, and that causal networks can be inferred using causal inference alone if the underlying causal relationships are to be inferred reliably.

Leptospirosis is an important zoonosis caused by pathogenic spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. It is an important public health problem in tropical and subtropical countries, including Thailand, Lao PDR, Vietnam, and Japan. The currently available diagnostic methods are based on the detection of pathogenic spirochetes in urine. However, these methods are time-consuming and are only applicable to a limited number of clinical samples. This study proposed to use matrix assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry ( MALDI-TOF MS ) as rapid and accurate tool for the identification of leptospires. The whole cell protein spectra of 116 Leptospira isolates including 15 reference Leptospira spp. ( pathogenic, n = 8; intermediate, n = 2; non-pathogenic, n = 5 ) and 101 Leptospira spp. clinical isolates was created as an in-house MALDI-TOF MS database. Ninety-seven clinical isolates from Thailand and Laos were validated with these protein spectra and revealed 98. 9% correct identification when compared with 16S rRNA gene sequences method. Moreover, MALDI-TOF MS could identify spiked leptospires whole cell in urine. Biomarkers for differentiation of leptospires phylogeny and specific protein spectra for most found Leptospira spp. in this area ( L. interrogans, L. kirschneri, L. borgpetersenii ) based on MALDI-MS algorithm were demonstrated.

Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide, and the global prevalence of trachoma is currently 1. 4 billion. As a district moves toward eliminating trachoma as a public health problem, national programs conduct trachoma impact surveys ( TIS ) to assess whether to stop preventative interventions and trachoma surveillance surveys ( TSS ) to determine whether the prevalence of active trachoma has rebounded after interventions have halted. In some contexts, programs also conduct trachomatous trichiasis ( TT ) -Only surveys. A few costing studies of trachoma prevalence surveys exist, but none examine TIS, TSS, or TT-only surveys. We assessed the incremental financial cost to the national program of TIS, TSS, and TT-only surveys, which are standardized cluster-sampled prevalence surveys. We conducted a review of expenditures and grant disbursementments for TIS and TSS in 322 evaluation units in 11 countries between 2011 and 2018. We also assessed the costs of three pilot and five standard TT-only surveys in four countries between 2017 and 2018. The median cost of TIS and TSS was $8, 298 per evaluation unit [interquartile range ( IQR ) : $6, 532–$10, 111, 2017 USD]. Based on a linear regression with bootstrapped confidence intervals, after controlling for country, costs per survey did not change significantly over time but did decline by $83 per survey implemented in a single round ( 95% CI: -$108–-$63 ). Of total costs, 80% went to survey field work; of that, 58% went towards per diems and 38% went towards travel. Within a given country, within a given district, they cost a median of $9, 707 ( IQR: $8, 537–$11, 635 ) ; within a district, within a given health district, or across the district, they cost a median of $10, 000–$25, 000 ( IQR: $8, 000–$25, 000 ). These results provide the first estimates of the costs of TIS, TSS, and TT-only surveys in 322 evaluation units. We also provide guidance on how these expenditures are distributed and how they compare to other types of expenditures.

Cerebral malaria is the most fatal complication of malaria infection, with mortality rates approaching 90%. It is caused by Plasmodium falciparum parasites, which are transmitted by mosquitoes. Every year, more than 1. 5 billion people are at risk of being infected. Malaria, which is the most important infectious cause of mortality worldwide, is caused by parasites that invade and multiply in the liver. Malaria parasites are taken up by mosquitoes when they bite humans and they invade the brain. The liver becomes the site of pathology, including the brain and the spleen. In the murine model of cerebral malaria, we previously demonstrated that parasite-infected mice, which are susceptible to being infected with the parasite, cross-present parasite antigens to CD8+ T lymphocytes, a component of the immune response. CD8+ T cells are specialized effector cells that kill parasites and can kill infected cells. Here, we show that brain endothelial cells, which line the blood vessels in the brain, are responsible for cross-presenting parasite antigens to CD8+ T cells. We also show that parasites do not induce the antigen in these cells. Finally, we show that malaria parasites that do not invade the brain can be taken up by these cells. Our work suggests that interfering with merozoite phagocytosis or antigen processing may be effective strategies for cerebral malaria intervention.

In the field of assisted reproductive techniques ( ART ), computer-assisted sperm analysis systems have proved their utility and potential for assessing sperm quality, improving the prediction of the fertility potential of a seminal dose. Although most laboratories and scientific centers use commercial systems, in the recent years several open-source alternatives have emerged that can reduce the costs that research groups have to face. However, these open-source alternatives cannot analyze sperm kinetic responses to different stimuli, such as chemotaxis, thermotaxis or rheotaxis. In addition, the programs released to date have not usually been designed to encourage the scalability and the continuity of software development. We have developed an open-source software, called OpenCASA, which allows users to analyze three classical sperm quality parameters: motility, morphometry and membrane integrity. This software has been released in a Version Control System at Github. This platform will allow researchers not only to download the software but also to be involved in and contribute to further developments. Additionally, a Google group has been created to allow the research community to interact and discuss OpenCASA. For validation of the OpenCASA software, we analysed different simulated sperm populations.

The spread of a pathogen in a population can depend on the rate at which individuals come in contact with the pathogen. This is known as the “pathogen's eye view”, and is important for designing and evaluating strategies to control outbreaks. Pathogen phylogenies, which describe the evolutionary history of a pathogen within a host, also show how the host contact network influences pathogen evolution. In this paper, we develop a novel method for relating network structure to pathogen evolution, by comparing the epidemic spread and evolution of pathogen phylogenies on different host networks. We find that networks with more heterogeneous network structure also show greater diversity of cluster numbers, shorter mean branch lengths, and somewhat higher tree imbalance than networks with relatively homogeneous structure. However, we find that these effects are relatively modest, and that the role of the epidemic trajectory, the dynamics of the network, and the inherent variability of metrics such as cluster size must each be taken into account when trying to understand characteristics about the underlying host contact network.

Recent X-ray and mutagenesis experiments ( Chen, et al 2009, 459, 1146 ) of the AMP-activated protein kinase ( AMPK ) have provided a structural and energetic framework for understanding the dynamic mechanism of auto-inhibition, which is a conformational transition of the inactive unphosphorylated open state to the catalytic closed state. In this study, we investigate the dynamical mechanism of auto-inhibition by using a novel normal mode analysis of an elastic network model drawn from microsecond molecular dynamics simulations. We show that the auto-inhibitory domain ( AID ) inhibits AMPK activity by restraining the kinase domain ( KD ) into an unproductive open conformation, thereby limiting local structural rearrangements, while mutations that disrupt the interactions between the KD and AID prevent both local structural rearrangements and global interlobe conformational transition. Our results further suggest that AID also impacts the structuring and mobility of the activation loop.

Formation of amyloid-like fibrils is involved in numerous human protein deposition diseases. Despite the importance of amyloid in the development of neurodegenerative diseases, it is also an intrinsic property of polypeptide chains in general. Recent progress has allowed the development of predictive algorithms to analyze the propensity of proteins to form amyloid-like fibrils. We have used a previously developed predictive algorithm to analyze the propensity of the 34, 180 human protein sequences to form amyloid-like fibrils. We show that long proteins have, on average, less intense aggregation peaks than short ones. Human proteins involved in protein deposition diseases do not differ extensively from the rest of the proteome, further demonstrating the generality of protein aggregation. We were also able to reproduce some of the results obtained with other algorithms, demonstrating that they do not depend on the type of computational tool employed. Our results emphasize the existence of intimate links between the propensity of proteins to form aggregates with β-structure and their biology. In particular, they emphasize the existence of a negative selection pressure that finely modulates protein sequences in order to adapt their aggregation propensity to their biological context.

The control of transcriptional activity by proteins that bind to DNA, such as transcription factors, is a major focus of biology. In eukaryotes, there are hundreds of such proteins called transcription factors that control gene expression by binding to DNA. In this study, we describe a novel mechanism whereby a transcription factor called KRAB can control transcription by spreading heterochromatin, which is a repressive chromatin structure. By targeting a gene involved in human development to a drug-controllable repressor, we show that KRAB and its corepressor KAP1 can silence the transcription of hundreds of genes. We also provide evidence that this long-range repression is initiated by the long-range spreading of a histone modification, H3K9 trimethylation, and heterochromatin protein 1 β ( HP1β ). Together, our data support a model in which KRAB and its corepressor KAP1 recruit heterochromatin and long-range spreading to control transcription in the repression of hundreds of genes. This work opens up new avenues for interpreting future genome-wide DNA binding data of KRAB–ZFPs and KAP1.

Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) infection is characterized by a chronic infection that cannot be eradicated even with antiretroviral therapy ( HAART ). Persistent infection is thought to be the result of a reservoir of CD4+ T cells that are able to sustain virus replication for years. It is thought that the stability of the latent reservoir is due to low-level viral replication that continuously replenishes the reservoir despite HAART. Here, we offer the first quantitative study to our knowledge of inflow of newly infected cells into the latent reservoir due to viral replication in the setting of HAART. We make use of a previous observation that in some patients on HAART, the residual viremia is dominated by a predominant plasma clone of HIV-1 not found in the latent reservoir. Our results show that the magnitude of the maximum daily inflow rate is small compared to the size of the latent reservoir, and therefore any inflow that occurs in patients on HAART is unlikely to significantly influence the decay rate of the latent reservoir. Thus, intensification of standard HAART regimens should have minimal effects on the decay of the latent reservoir.

Obesity is a complex problem that is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Current therapies for obesity are only partially effective, and there is an urgent need to develop new therapeutic approaches. Recent advances in genetic and pharmacological research have identified the importance of a large number of genes in maintaining normal physiological states, and there is increasing evidence that a number of genes also contribute to aberrant physiological activity in disease states. Here, we use the fruit fly model to identify genes that are critical to normal physiological function. We find that manipulating the expression of a single gene, Spen, has a profound effect on larval fat levels. Deletion of Spen in mice results in major changes in the levels of metabolic enzymes and metabolites involved in β-oxidation. Spen also counteracts Spen’s role in fat regulation. Spen and Spenito transcript levels are conserved in human cells, and our results suggest that this is a conserved function of Spen. These results demonstrate that Spen is a key regulator of energy balance and provide a molecular context to understand the metabolic defects that arise from Spen dysfunction.

HIV-1 is a chronic virus infection that continues despite ART. This persistence is thought to be associated with the ability of virus to escape from immune control mechanisms such as CD4+ T lymphocytes and macrophages. Although there are several reports describing the role of CD4+ T lymphocytes in HIV persistence, there are still many questions regarding the role of other types of immune cells in HIV persistence. The lymph node ( LN ) is a major cell reservoir for HIV-1 and T lymphocytes, but the mechanisms by which these immune cells are involved in HIV-1 persistence remain to be clarified. Here, we demonstrate that lymph node resident dendritic cells can suppress HIV-1 transcription in vitro in the presence of viral antigens. Our results also suggest that lymph node resident dendritic cells may be important in vivo in controlling HIV-1 transcription in vivo. These results provide new insights into how immune control mechanisms may be used to prevent HIV-1 persistence.

High-risk human papillomaviruses ( HPVs ) are the most common viral infections worldwide and are associated with the development of several malignancies. Sirtuin 1 ( SIRT1 ) is a protein deacetylase that controls the acetylation of cellular proteins. We have shown previously that SIRT1 is activated by oncogenic E6 and E7 oncoproteins and that this activation is required for efficient viral replication. Here, we show that SIRT1 levels are increased in cells with HPV genomes containing high-risk HPVs and that SIRT1 is required for the viral life cycle. SIRT1 binds to the viral genomes and regulates the acetylation of two histone proteins ( Lys26 and H4 ) bound to the viral genomes. The differentiation-dependent replication of high-risk HPVs requires activation of factors in the Ataxia Telangiectasia Mutated ( ATM ) pathway and SIRT1 regulates the recruitment of both NBS1 and Rad51 to the viral genomes. These observations demonstrate that SIRT1 is a critical regulator of multiple aspects of the high-risk HPV life cycle.

APOBEC3 proteins are proteins that block HIV-1 replication by deamination of the viral DNA. However, some studies have argued that APOBEC3 proteins also induce G-to-A mutations in viral genomes. APOBEC3 proteins are generally believed to inhibit HIV-1 replication by deamination of the viral DNA. However, some studies have found that APOBEC3 proteins can induce G-to-A mutations in viral genomes, which can significantly increase HIV-1 genetic diversity and evolution. Here, we demonstrate that hypermutation induced by APOBEC3 proteins does not significantly affect the rate of recombination, and it does not significantly affect the frequency of viral mutations in the viral genomes. We also show that hypermutation induced by APOBEC3 proteins does not significantly contribute to HIV-1 genetic variation in vivo since it is very rare for the viral genomes to copackage with hypermutated sequences in vivo. We conclude that APOBEC3-induced hypermutation plays a significant role in HIV-1 genetic diversity but is much less important than mutations induced by error-prone replication.

Intrinsically disordered proteins are involved in many important biological processes. They are often involved in various biological functions including cell signaling pathways and regulation of protein stability. The lack of ordered structure in these proteins hampers experimental approaches aimed at studying their functions and molecular recognition. The prediction of disordered regions is important for the development of effective strategies to control the function of these proteins. In this work, we have analyzed the statistical analysis of disordered residues in 34, 464 unique protein chains. The analysis revealed 109 disordered patterns of different lengths. Each of them has disordered occurrences in at least five protein chains with identity less than 20%. The vast majority of all occurrences of each disordered pattern are disordered. This allows one to use the library of disordered patterns for predicting the status of a residue of a given protein to be ordered or disordered.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne disease that presents a significant burden to endemic countries and recent outbreaks have demonstrated a need for effective prevention strategies. An effective anti-viral treatment is currently unavailable, yet control programmes must be effective in the face of limited resources. In this study, we explored the perceptions of dengue control in caregivers’ of children under 5 years in Peru, to help direct future mosquito control programmes and strategy. Our study showed that community cooperation was important and that participants perceived a lack of community responsibility as a key factor explaining why community members did or did not participate in preventive practices. We also found that community members viewed dengue control as a problem of community responsibility. Our results show the need to address the community perception of dengue control in order to improve prevention strategies.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an important human pathogen responsible for life-threatening systemic infections in immunocompromised patients and those with AIDS. The pathogenesis of this fungus is governed by its unique sexual reproductive strategy, wherein the male and female gametes ( α cells ) fuse to produce diploid progeny. The two α cells from different serotypes are identical, yet the mating system differs, with some strains ( αA and αD ) being diploid while others ( αE and αH ) are haploid. This raises the question of how the two α cells can generate new diploid progeny. In this study, we report that C. neoformans can undergo same-sex mating in the laboratory, giving rise to diploid intermediates and haploid recombinant progeny. This novel sexual style occurs in all α serotypes, but is absent from all αA and αD serotypes. The majority of diploid C. neoformans isolates, however, are of two copies of the α MAT locus allele, suggesting that they originated via endoreplication or clonal mating. Our findings highlight the importance of same-sex mating in shaping the population structure of this important human pathogenic fungus, with implications for mechanisms of selfing and inbreeding in other microbial pathogens.

Gene expression is tightly regulated not only at the transcriptional level but also post-transcriptionally via RNA binding proteins ( RBPs ). While the importance of post-transcriptional regulation is well established, the importance of post-transcriptional regulation in the control of gene expression is still poorly understood. In this study, we integrated a multivariate linear regression model with gene expression data to predict the abundance of a given mRNA or protein from the matched transcript and protein datasets. We found that the level of the mRNA significantly predicted the level of the protein. We also found that the upstream translation initiation sites ( uTISs ) near the mRNA 5’ untranslated regions are strongly associated with improved predictive accuracy. Our results suggest that the uTISs are a novel substrate of post-transcriptional control mediated by RBPs.

Many bacteria deploy a contractile nanomachine known as the Type VI secretion system ( T6SS ) to kill other cells, including those of human cells. T6SSs are often targets of the host innate immune system, which acts to kill bacteria and phage viruses by recognising and degrading foreign DNA. T6SSs are also deployed by human cells against bacteria. However, T6SSs fire at different rates and can use different regulatory pathways. Here, we show that a T6SS of Serratia marcescens, which is used by competitors against bacteria, is regulated by the cellular protein phosphatase PpkA. PpkA activates the kinase which phosphorylates another T6SS component, PpkA. This activation triggers a switch in regulatory strategy which allows the T6SS to fire at all-comers, but only if the T6SS is triggered to fire at an incoming attack. Our study provides new insights into how T6SSs are regulated and deployed. We show that the T6SS of S. marcescens is deployed by a novel regulatory pathway, which is conserved between T6SSs that fire against bacteria and T6SSs that fire against host cells. This work has implications for our understanding of how bacteria deploy T6SSs and how they are regulated.

The diversity of HIV-1 and HIV-2 ( human immunodeficiency virus 1 and 2 ), which have collectively caused over 35 million deaths, is the result of multiple cross-species transmission ( CST ) from chimpanzees, gorillas, and sooty mangabeys. While the immediate history of HIV is known, there are over 45 lentiviruses that infect specific species of primates, and patterns of host switching are not well characterized. We analyzed a large viral phylogeny to infer host species as a discrete character trait on the viral phylogeny, and used this to identify novel, well-supported, ancient cross-species transmission events. We also find that lentiviral lineages vary widely in their ability to infect new host species: SIVcol ( from colobus monkeys ) is evolutionarily isolated, while SIVagms ( from African green monkeys ) frequently move between host subspecies. We also examine the origins of SIVcpz ( the predecessor of HIV-1 ) in greater detail than previous studies, and find that there are still large portions of the genome with unknown origins. Observed patterns of CST are likely driven by a combination of ecological circumstance and innate immune factors.

Neurons are highly variable in their shape, ion channels, synaptic inputs, and spiking output. We investigated the effects of ion channel variability on the spike train response of single neurons and on the response of interneurons. We simulated the activity of a set of biophysically accurate single cell models with intrinsic electrophysiological properties consistent with experimental findings. The results suggest that the set of ion channel specific conductances expressed in any given neuron may be considered as belonging to two groups: one subset is responsible for the major characteristics of the firing behavior in each population and the other is responsible for a robust degeneracy. Analysis of the model neurons suggests several experimentally testable predictions related to the combination and relative proportion of the different ion channels that should be expressed on the membrane of different types of neurons.

Sonic Hedgehog ( Shh ) is a highly conserved protein that, like all members of the Hedgehog ( Hh ) family of proteins, play a vital role in animal development. Shh is a representative of the closely related class of Hedgehog proteins that have essential signaling functions. The N-terminal domain ( ShhN ) is also assigned to the group of LAS proteins ( LAS = Lysostaphin type enzymes, D-Ala-D-Ala metalloproteases ), which are known to cleave other proteins. One of the unique features of ShhN is its dual- center structure, which is unusual in the LAS family. In this study, we have studied the effect of calcium ions on ShhN structure, dynamics, and interactions. We find that the presence of calcium has a marked impact on ShhN properties, with the more strongly bound calcium ion stabilizing the overall structure. Surprisingly, the binding of the second calcium ion switches the putative catalytic center from a structure similar to LAS enzymes to a structure that probably is catalytically inactive. We have studied in detail the mechanics of the switch, including the effect on substrate co-ordinating residues and on the putative catalytic water molecule. Our results provide a structural basis for the activity of ShhN, and also for the study of the role of zinc in ShhN.

Viruses are a major threat to public health. While numerous studies have been conducted to study the interaction of viral components with the host, very little is known about the interaction of the viral capsid protein and the host cytoplasmic RNA genome. This is the first study to identify the cytoplasmic interactions of the viral capsid protein and the host genomic RNA during the viral replication cycle. We have shown that the interaction of the capsid protein and the host cytoplasmic RNA is important for the viral capsid protein to efficiently interact with the viral RNA genome, leading to viral particle assembly. This is the first report of the interaction of the viral capsid protein and host cytoplasmic RNA, and this interaction is not essential for the viral particle assembly. The identification of the host cytoplasmic RNA interaction site ( s ) as a virulence determinant in the context of the viral capsid protein interaction provides a better understanding of the function of the capsid protein during the viral replication cycle.

Fungal infections are a major health problem, particularly for immunocompromised patients. Candida albicans, the most prevalent fungal species causing human infections, is also a normal inhabitant of our bodies, but can also cause life-threatening disease. It is well established that the immune system is the primary defense against this pathogen, but we still know very little about how the organism interacts with the immune system. Here, using in vivo infection models, we show that the requirement for the innate immune system Dectin-1 in controlling infections with Candida albicans is strain-specific, and that this difference in strain-dependent immunity is due to variable adaptation of the fungal cells to Dectin-1. This results in substantial differences in the composition and nature of the cell walls of C. albicans, which have important consequences for the interaction with the immune system. We also established that differences in the levels of cell-wall chitin influence the function of Dectin-1, and that these effects can be modulated by antifungal drug treatment. Our results therefore provide substantial new insights into the interaction between C. albicans and the immune system, and have significant implications for our understanding of susceptibility and treatment of human infections with this pathogen.

Hbs1 has recently been shown to be a central component of the translational quality control machinery in yeast, but its human ortholog ( Hbs1L ) has not been characterized. Here we describe a novel human phenotype characterized by facial dysmorphism, severe growth restriction, axial hypotonia and global developmental delay. We demonstrate Hbs1L is absent in human fibroblasts, and that the lack of Hbs1L in mouse tissues causes reduced levels of 80S monosomes and upregulation of mTOR and 4-EBP protein expression. Furthermore, we have developed a mouse model to demonstrate Hbs1L-mediated downregulation of the mTOR pathway in vivo and restoration of Pelota levels. This work demonstrates Hbs1L is required for the translation of ribosomal RNA in human cells, and that the mTOR pathway is mTOR-dependent. Thus, Hbs1L is required for translation of ribosomal RNA, and its function is mTOR-dependent.

Stray and free-roaming cats can be exposed to a wide spectrum of micro- and macro-organisms, including commensal and pathogenic agents. This survey investigated the distribution of various intestinal parasites and vector-borne pathogens in stray and free-roaming cats living in four regions of Greece. A total of 135 and 94 cats ( 90% and 91% respectively ) were positive for one or more intestinal parasites and/or pathogens transmitted by ectoparasites. The most frequently recorded helminths were roundworms ( Toxocara cati ) and Dipylidium caninum ( 2% ), while a high number of examined animals ( 58. 8% ) had seroreaction for Bartonella spp., followed by Rickettsia spp. ( 43. 2% ) and Leishmania infantum ( 6. 1% ). DNA-based assays revealed Bartonella henselae, Bartonella clarridgeiae, Rickettsia spp., Bartonella clarridgeiae, L. infantum, and R. rickettsiae as potential vectors for zoonotic disease agents. Our results show that free-ranging cats living in areas of Greece under examination may be exposed to a plethora of internal parasites and vector-borne pathogens, some of them potentially able to infect humans. Therefore, epidemiological vigilance and appropriate control measures are crucial for the prevention and control of these infections and to minimize the risk of infection for people.

Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of death in western countries, and our understanding of its pathogenesis is still limited. The gene encoding neuropeptide Y ( NPY ) is a strong candidate gene for coronary artery disease ( CAD ). To test the role of NPY in atherosclerosis pathogenesis, we have previously identified genetic linkage to familial CAD in the genomic region of NPY. In the current study, we use a case/control approach to study the role of NPY in early-onset CAD. We found increased microsatellite linkage to chromosome 7p14 in 97 earliest age-of-onset families. NPY genetic variation was associated with a 6-SNP block ( p = 0. 02 ), and stronger linkage to CAD in the earliest age-of-onset families. A promoter SNP ( rs16147 ) within this 6-SNP block was associated with higher plasma NPY levels. To assess a causal role of NPY in atherosclerosis, we applied the NPY1-receptor–antagonist BIBP-3226 adventitially to endothelium-denuded carotid arteries of apolipoprotein E-deficient mice; treatment reduced atherosclerotic neointimal area by 50% ( p = 0. 03 ). Thus, NPY variants associate with atherosclerosis in two independent datasets ( with strong age-of-onset effects ) and show allele-specific expression with NPY levels, while NPY receptor antagonism reduces atherosclerosis in mice.

Mitochondria are the cellular factories that drive energy production and are essential for many other cellular functions. The mitochondrial functions are tightly controlled by a complex network of interacting proteins. To ensure the viability and proper function of this network, the length and connectivity of the mitochondrial network must be tightly regulated. In this paper, we describe a novel algorithm that can be used to accurately measure the length and connectivity of mitochondrial networks from confocal images. We applied this algorithm to measure the changes in mitochondrial length and connectivity induced by starvation or inhibition of mitochondrial function. In addition, we successfully used this algorithm to measure changes in mitochondrial inner membrane structure induced by complex III inhibitors. We found that the changes in mitochondrial connectivity and length induced by these compounds are similar to those induced by starvation or inhibition of mitochondrial function. As the changes in mitochondrial length and connectivity induced by these compounds can be rapidly and accurately determined, this will allow us to screen for compounds that affect mitochondrial function. Our algorithm will thus provide a rapid tool to dissect the molecular mechanisms underlying the key roles of mitochondria in the regulation of cell fate.

Onchocerciasis is a neglected tropical disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is the second leading infectious cause of blindness world-wide. The current control strategy relies on the use of drugs to kill the microfilariae ( larval stage ) that are present in the worm. There are currently no drugs available for the treatment of the adult worm ( adult female ), which makes the use of insecticides a difficult option for control programs. There is a need to develop new macrofilaricide drugs to replace the current drugs and to be more effective at killing the adult worm. This study aimed to develop and validate a novel gerbil adult male worm model for testing the efficacy of new macrofilaricide drugs. The model was developed in order to study the efficacy of oxfendazole, a new candidate drug for treatment of onchocerciasis, in the wild-type gerbil population. The results show that oxfendazole is effective in killing adult worms and shows promise as a novel drug for the treatment of onchocerciasis.

Coronavirus ( CIV ) infection causes severe acute respiratory tract disease ( SARS ), which is a global public health concern. SARS-CoV is a non-enveloped negative-stranded RNA virus that can infect human cells, including epithelial cells, macrophages, and endothelial cells, and has a unique 5′-cap structure, which is important for viral RNA stability, protein translation and viral immune escape. nsp16 and nsp10 are two viral methyltransferases that function in a complementary manner to catalyze the 5′-end of viral mRNAs, and methylates the 5′-cap structure of mRNAs. Here we report the biochemical characterization of nsp16 and its interaction with the nsp10 protein complex. We found that nsp16 uses a unique combination of structural and biochemical approaches to execute its methylation activity. We also determined the crystal structure of nsp16/nsp10 complex bound with methyl donor SAM. Our results provide important insight into the mechanism of SARS-CoV mRNA modification by nsp16/nsp10, and may be a basis for the development of highly specific anti-coronavirus drugs.

Buruli ulcer is a neglected skin disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, a mycobacteria found in West Africa. It is characterized by painless, ulcerative lesions of large size and extensive tissue destruction. The exact transmission mechanism remains unknown. Several arguments indicate a possible role for insects in its transmission. In the present case-control study, we investigated whether adequate wound care and use of bed nets ( appropriate protection against Buruli ulcer ), were associated with the risk of Buruli ulcer. We found that the use of bed net was associated with a 32% reduction in the risk of Buruli ulcer, and with a 34% reduction in the proportion of cases able to be prevented by adequate wound care. The study confirms that adequate wound care and use of bed nets are essential to prevent Buruli ulcer, and should be investigated further. Involvement of insects in the household environment, and the relationship between wound hygiene and M. ulcerans infection should now be investigated.

In some plant species, adult plant resistance ( APR ) is an enigmatic phenomenon in which the ability of plant immune receptors to protect seedlings from disease is suboptimal. Here we describe a maize mutation that decreases the plant hormone HC-toxin, which is responsible for the disease resistance conferred by the hypomorphic allele of Hm1A, at the HM1 locus. The genetic defect in the hypomorphic allele is that the gene encodes an NADPH-dependent reductase, which inactivates HC-toxin, the key virulence effector of the plant pathogen Cochliobolus carbonum race 1 ( CCR1 ). The hypomorphic allele encodes a partial loss-of-function mutation, Hm1A, at the HM1 locus. This mutation reduced HC-toxin reductase activity, leading to less accumulation of HC-toxin and reduced resistance in the adult plant. We also show that the hypomorphic allele has undergone relatively conservative missense changes that partially reduce its enzymatic activity. No difference in accumulation of the gene product was observed between adult and juvenile plants, suggesting that the susceptibility of seedlings derives from a greater need for HCTR activity, not reduced accumulation of the gene product. We demonstrate that the energy status of the host has a dramatic effect on resistance afforded by the hypomorphic alleles, demonstrating a link between the energetic or metabolic status of the host and disease resistance.

Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness and is caused by ocular infection with the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. While the majority of the global disease burden is found in sub-Saharan Africa, the Western Pacific Region has been identified as trachoma endemic. In this study, the authors describe a population-based survey of trachoma in the Western Division of Fiji. They found that the prevalence of active trachoma in children aged 1–9 years was 3. 4%. The unadjusted prevalence of ocular Ct infection in 1–9 year-olds was 1. 9%, and the median DNA load was 41 Ct plasmid copies per swab ( min 20, first quartile 32, mean 6665, third quartile 161, max 86354 ). There was no association between current infection and follicular trachoma. No cases of trachomatous trichiasis were identified. The Western Division of Fiji has a low prevalence of clinical trachoma. Ocular Ct infections were observed, but they were predominantly low load infections and were not correlated with clinical signs. The authors conclude that trachoma does not meet the WHO definition of a public health problem in this Division of Fiji, but the inconsistency with previous studies warrants further investigation.

Mycobacterium ulcerans ( MU ) is the agent responsible for Buruli Ulcer ( BU ), an emerging skin disease with dramatic socioeconomic and health outcomes, especially in rural settings. BU emergence and distribution is linked to aquatic ecosystems in tropical and subtropical countries, especially to swampy and flooding areas. Aquatic animal organisms are likely to play a role as host reservoirs or vectors of the bacilli. However, information on MU ecological dynamics, both in space and time, is still limited. As a result, the ecology of the disease agent, and consequently its mode of transmission, remains largely unknown. We studied the spatio-temporal dynamics of MU ecological distribution and colonization of aquatic organisms through long-term sampling of 32 communities of aquatic macro-invertebrates and vertebrates from different environments in Cameroon. Our study showed a broad distribution of MU in all ecosystems and taxonomic groups, with important regional variations in its occurrence. Colonization dynamics fluctuated along the year, with the highest peaks in August and October. The large variations observed in the colonization dynamics of different taxonomic groups and aquatic ecosystems suggest that the trends shown here are the result of complex ecological processes that need further investigation.

The human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) is responsible for over 100 million new infections annually, and no effective vaccine exists to prevent HIV infection. An important aspect of HIV infection is the ability of the virus to establish chronic infection in the host, which can lead to a wide range of clinical outcomes, including neurological disease, immune activation, and disease progression. Here, we show that a group of viruses called pegiviruses can protect HIV-infected people from a variety of pathogenic outcomes. These results expand our understanding of the role of pegiviruses in HIV infection, and have important implications for the development of new vaccine strategies to prevent HIV infection.

Ribosomes are complex macromolecular machines that synthesize proteins in all living organisms. The nucleolus is a cellular organelle that serves as the site of ribosome assembly and is often associated with cell growth and development. In Caenorhabditis elegans, the size of the nucleolus varies widely across different cell types. The size of the nucleolus is often coordinated with cell growth and development, however how this relationship is controlled in a cell type specific manner is poorly understood. Here, we demonstrate that a genetic cascade controls the size of the nucleolus and the abundance of a major nucleolar pre-rRNA processing protein FIB-1/fibrillarin. This genetic cascade is regulated by a molecular circuitry that targets the 3’UTR of ncl-1, a major nucleolar pre-rRNA processing protein, and the translation repressor NCL-1. Consequently, the abundance of FIB-1 is tightly controlled and correlated with the nucleolar size. Our findings reveal a novel genetic cascade by which post-transcriptional regulators interplay in developmental control of nucleolar size and function.

AIDS vaccine must be both well tolerated and effective in the face of a complex virus like HIV. To address these issues, the design and testing of gene therapy-based vaccine combinations is an important approach. Here we used the rhesus macaque model to optimize delivery of naturally-arising, autologous anti-SIV antibodies expressed by Adeno-Associated Virus 8 ( AAV8 ) vectors. We found that the AAV8-mediated delivery of anti-SIV antibodies was efficient at varying doses and numbers of injections, and that this efficacy was associated with a robust antibody response and with protection against SIV challenge. These results demonstrate feasibility of a gene therapy-based passive immunization strategy against infectious disease, and illustrate the potential of the nonhuman primate model to inform clinical AAV-based approaches to passive immunization.

Amphibian species are threatened by a climate change that is supposed to result in more severe outbreaks of chytridiomycosis. Although the impacts of climate change have been well documented, there is still much to be learned about the role of climate change in triggering disease outbreaks in amphibian species. We review the evidence for the role of climate change in triggering disease outbreaks of chytridiomycosis, and assess the current patterns of decline in Amphibium species from South America and Australia. We present evidence that climate change has been driving disease outbreaks of chytridiomycosis in South America and subsequently spread into new areas of the Andes. We also show that, although some climate change effects are seen in climate-sensitive species, they are unlikely to have been responsible for disease outbreaks in other regions of the Andes. We also show that other factors, including climate change, may be responsible for amplifying the impacts of climate change on disease outbreaks. Our results provide the basis for future studies to determine the role of climate change in triggering disease outbreaks of chytridiomycosis.

Eukaryotic DNA polymerases play critical roles in DNA synthesis, maintenance of genomic integrity, and cell proliferation. In this study, we present evidence that the only DNA polymerase from the parasite protozoan E. histolytica ( EhDNApolA ), which is the sole family A DNA polymerase in E. histolytica, is involved in translesion DNA synthesis. We also demonstrate that this polymerase is active in primer elongation, is poorly processive, and does not contain 3′–5′ exonuclease or editing activity. Our results suggest that EhDNApolA may be involved in translesion DNA synthesis in this protozoan. These data provide novel insight into the biochemical properties and functions of this important DNA polymerase from E. histolytica.

How the mitochondrial arrangement affects cardiac bioenergetics is a long-standing question in cardiac cell biology. Recent electron microscopy data have revealed that cardiac mitochondria are not arranged in crystalline columns but are organised with several mitochondria aggregated into columns of varying sizes spanning the cell cross-section. This raises the question—how does the mitochondrial arrangement affect the metabolite distributions within cardiomyocytes and what is its impact on force dynamics? Here, we employ computational meshes to explore the role of mitochondrial organisation on cardiac bioenergetics. Our results indicate that heterogeneous mitochondrial distributions can lead to significant spatial variation across the cell in concentrations of inorganic phosphate, creatine ( Cr ) and creatine phosphate ( PCr ). However, our model predicts that sufficient activity of the creatine kinase ( CK ) system, coupled with rapid diffusion of Cr and PCr, maintains near uniform ATP and ADP ratios across the cell cross sections. This homologous distribution of ATP and ADP should also evenly distribute force production and twitch duration with contraction. These results suggest that the PCr shuttle and associated enzymatic reactions act to maintain uniform force dynamics in the cell despite the heterogeneous mitochondrial organisation. However, our model also predicts that under hypoxia activity of mitochondrial CK enzymes and diffusion of high-energy phosphate compounds may be insufficient to sustain uniform ATP/ADP distribution and hence force generation.

Infection with bacteria and viruses that enter the mosquito hemocoel often triggers the release of small peptide hormones from the mosquito hemocoel that stimulate hemocytes to increase in abundance. This increase in hemocyte numbers is thought to be a key defense mechanism against pathogens that enter the hemocoel. However, it is unknown how hemocytes regulate this process. Here, we determined that hemocytes express insulin receptors and that the A. aegypti insulin receptor is required for hemocyte proliferation. We then showed that hemocytes stimulated by insulin-like peptide 3 ( ILP3 ) rescued proliferation of hemocytes after they were infected with E. coli. Surprisingly, however, non-blood fed females were better able to clear the bacterial infection at lower levels of infection than blood fed females. Taken together, our results reveal that hem feeding stimulates hemocyte proliferation and that this increase in hemocyte abundance is important for resistance to E. coli infection.

Infection with gamma-herpesviruses, such as Murid Herpesvirus-4 ( MuHV-4 ), can cause severe disease in immunocompromised hosts, mainly in CD4+ T cell-deficient hosts. However, clinical disease occurs mainly in CD4+ T cell-deficient hosts. MuHV-4 infection in mice is controlled by both CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. In CD4+ T cell-deficient hosts, CD8+ T cells control acute but not chronic infection. We show that acute and chronic infections differ in the distribution: most acute infection was epithelial, whereas most chronic infection was in myeloid cells. CD8+ T cells controlled epithelial infection, but CD4+ T cells and IFNγ were required to control myeloid cell infection. CD8+ T cell evasion led to niche-specific immune control, and an essential role for CD4+ T cells in limiting chronic infection. Thus, viral CD8+ T cell evasion led to niche-specific immune control, and an essential role for CD4+ T cells in controlling chronic infection.

In this work, we describe a novel framework for analysis of next generation sequence data in families. Our framework can identify variant sites accurately and to assign individual genotypes, and can handle de novo mutation events.

Cutaneous dirofilariosis is a neglected tropical disease caused by the filarial nematodes Onchocercidae and Wuchereria bancrofti and Wuchereria bancrofti. The present study compared the mitochondrial genomes of the three species that cause cutaneous dirofilariosis in Hong Kong, Candidatus Dirofilaria ( Nochtiella ) hongkongensis, and the two species that cause cutaneous dirofilariosis in India, C. Dirofilaria ( C. D. ) hongkongensis and D. repens. We also compared the mitochondrial genomes of these species and obtained three mitochondrial genomes from these parasites. Our results indicate that these three species are not closely related and that the mitochondrial genome of the three species can be separated. We also compared the mitochondrial genome of D. repens and the two Thai samples from Vietnam, Thailand and India and found that C. D. hongkongensis is the most divergent species among the three species. The Thai samples from Vietnam, Thailand and India were all genetically quite divergent from the C. D. repens samples. These results suggest that D. repens is a species of zoonotic origin, and that the Thai samples represent another species of cryptic species, Candidatus Dirofilaria sp. ‘Thailand II’ or C. D. hongkongensis.

Human social behavior is exquisitely complex, and social cognition is thought to be underpinned by a set of brain circuits that have the ability to “interpret” behavior from a variety of sensory and motor inputs. One such set of brain circuits is the anterior forebrain pathway ( AFP ), which is thought to reflect a “-performance” state, and the effects of social context on behavior are thought to be mediated by alterations in the neural activity of the forebrain. Here, we investigate how the social context of a female zebra finch affects the way she responds to her mate's song, and we find that both mated and socially naive females can distinguish between directed and undirected song. Furthermore, we find that this social perception is mediated by specific neural activity in the caudomedial mesopallium ( CMM ), which is thought to be involved in the processing of speech. These results show that female behavior is sensitive to the social context of its mate and provide new insight into the neural mechanisms of social cognition.

Infectious disease outbreaks are often associated with high uncertainty in their progression. If forecasts of the spread of a pathogen are reliable but not precise, then there is an urgent need for assessing the accuracy and completeness of forecasts. We analysed the performance of real-time forecasts generated in West Area, Sierra Leone, during the 2013–16 Ebola epidemic. We found that accurate forecasts could only be obtained at short time horizons of one or two weeks ahead. This suggests that forecasts may have been of good enough quality to inform decision-making based on predictions a few weeks ahead of time but not longer, reflecting the high level of uncertainty in the processes driving the trajectory of the epidemic. Comparing forecasts based on the semi-mechanistic model to simpler null models showed that the best semi-mechanistic model variant performed better than the null models with respect to probabilistic calibration, and that this would have been identified from the earliest stages of the epidemic. As forecasts become a routine part of the toolkit in public health, standards for evaluation of performance will be important for assessing quality and improving credibility of mathematical models, and for elucidating difficulties and trade-offs when aiming to make the most useful and reliable forecasts.

Recent research has shown that many important behaviors are regulated by a system of two distinct types of control: a fast, automatic system and a slow, deliberative system. The distinction between these systems is not always clear, and it has been hard to assess the relative advantages of each system. Here, we show that the task that best characterizes the two types of control is to obtain accurate estimates of the value of each action. We show that the task that best characterizes the two types of control can be achieved by a novel task that formalizes the distinction between these two types of control. We also show that humans spontaneously update their reliance on the model-based strategy when the task we describe here is accurate, and that this behavior is mediated by the neuronal activity of the model-based task. Our results provide a framework for understanding how humans make decisions under uncertainty.

Mosquitoes transmit human pathogens such as malaria, dengue, Zika, and chikungunya viruses. Control of mosquito populations is the primary method of controlling these diseases. Currently, insecticides are the primary means of controlling mosquito populations. There is an urgent need to develop new, safer insecticides. We investigated blood meal alternatives to whole blood as a method of maintaining mosquito populations in the presence of mosquitoes. We found that whole blood was highly stable, compatible with storage for extended periods, and highly stable, both in water and lipid media. An artificial blood diet of plasma ATP was effective in maintaining mosquito populations. It was also effective in rearing Aedes mosquitoes.

Myopathies are a group of genetic diseases that affect muscle structure, function, and motility. We have discovered that mutations in the gene flapwing result in a hyperphosphorylation of myosin, a molecular motor required to integrate muscle fiber attachments. These mutations also result in muscle hypercontraction, a phenotype that resembles muscle hyperactive injury. The genetic defect in these mutant muscles is not due to a single defective gene, but rather to mutations in a panel of adhesion molecules, such as integrins. Using a panel of adhesion proteins, we show that elevated expression of the integrin-associated protein PINCH is a key factor in the rescue of muscle hyperactive injury. We further show that PINCH is present in limiting amounts within integrins, with increasing expression reinforcing existing adhesions or allowing for the assembly of new adhesion complexes. Moreover, in myopathies that exhibit hypercontraction, strategic expression of PINCH may have therapeutic potential in preserving muscle structure and function.

Malaria, a disease caused by Plasmodium falciparum parasites, is a leading cause of death and morbidity worldwide. Current control programs are successful at killing the adult parasites in the human host, but are not always effective against the mosquito vector, which can transmit the disease. This is because the mosquito vector is highly resistant to insecticides, making vector control a key intervention tool. Unfortunately, vector control programs are often unsuccessful, and the reasons for this vary depending on the area of application. For example, while malaria control programs are effective in some areas, they are less successful elsewhere. This study examined the impact of vector control on mosquito populations, using data collected from 13–15 microsatellite markers for mosquitoes from multiple locations in Guinea, West Africa. We found that vector control dramatically reduced mosquito population sizes in some areas, but had no effect in others. In contrast, control programs that have no effect on mosquito population sizes did not have an impact on mosquito population sizes. This study is the first to consistently link anti-vector intervention programs in Africa to sharply reduced effective population sizes of malaria vectors.

Microbes of the plant–microbe symbiosis arbuscular mycorrhization ( AM ) are widespread in eukaryotes. Despite their beneficial effects, they also have been shown to influence the evolution of host genomes. However, the impact of beneficial symbionts on the evolution of host genomes remains poorly characterized. Here we used the most common plant–microbe symbiosis, AM, as a model to investigate the effect of AM on host gene evolution. We found that loss of AM results in the loss of many genes involved in the regulation of plant growth and development. Our results suggest that, in addition to beneficial effects on the host, symbionts also influence the evolution of the host genome.

In this study we investigated mutations in the FLVCR1 gene, which are present in all humans and are linked to a variety of human genetic diseases, such as congenital loss of pain perception and posterior column ataxia. Although mutations in the FLCR1 gene have previously been linked to vision impairment and posterior column ataxia in humans, we found that these mutations do not affect the FLCR1 gene itself. Instead, we show that they control the cytosolic level of heme, which is an essential molecule for the maintenance of cell life. We also show that these mutations cause enhanced sensitivity to programmed cell death and reduce heme export. Our data suggest that heme metabolism may be a novel mechanism for sensory neuron maintenance and that heme overload may be a common cause of early-onset degeneration of pain-sensing neurons in humans.

Memory is a complex phenomenon and a central topic in neuroscience. It is known that memory is not a property of the network itself, but rather of the synaptic connection between two neurons. One of the crucial components of memory is the strengthening of synapses in the synaptic connections. The strength of a synapse is determined by the number of times the inputs and the number of times the outputs of the inputs are delivered to the synapse. This so-called soft-bound plasticity is a well-known phenomenon that has been shown to increase information capacity in synaptic plasticity. We show that soft-bound plasticity increases the storage capacity of synapses. This so-called information theoretic framework can be used to analyse memory storage in an online learning setting.

Clostridium perfringens ε-toxin ( ETX ) is a pore-forming toxin that is responsible for a central nervous system ( CNS ) disease in ruminant animals with characteristics of blood-brain barrier ( BBB ) dysfunction and white matter injury. The receptor for ETX is unknown. We show that both binding of ETX to mammalian cells and cytotoxicity require the tetraspan proteolipid Myelin and Lymphocyte-Associated Protein ( MAL ). ETX is known to bind specifically and with high affinity to intestinal epithelium, renal tubules, brain endothelial cells and myelin. We show binding of ETX to these structures and also binding to retinal microvasculature and the squamous epithelial cells of the sclera in wild-type mice. In contrast, there is a complete absence of ETX binding to tissues from MAL knockout ( MAL-/- ) mice. Furthermore, MAL-/- mice exhibit complete resistance to ETX at doses in excess of 1000 times the symptomatic dose for wild-type mice. We conclude that MAL is required for both ETX binding and cytotoxicity.

Allosteric proteins are ubiquitous molecules that bind a single effector molecule at one site and result in a functional change at another site. We hypothesize that allosteric communication in proteins relies upon networks of quaternary ( collective, rigid-body ) and tertiary ( residue–residue contact ) motions. We have developed a computational approach to identify networks of quaternary motions that underlie allosteric communication among all substrate and effector sites in 15 multidomain and multimeric proteins, while tertiary and quaternary networks exhibit such communication in only 4 and 3 of these proteins, respectively. Furthermore, in 7 of the 15 proteins connected by the GCN, 50% or more of the substrate-effector paths via the GCN are “interdependent” paths that do not exist via either the tertiary or the quaternary network. We argue for broad applicability of allosteric communication based on structural changes and demonstrate the utility of the GCN. Our results provide a framework for allosteric communication based on structural changes and demonstrate the utility of the GCN.

Most plant viruses are transmitted by insects. Some plant viruses can be transmitted from female parent to offspring usually through eggs, but the mechanism of this transovarial transmission remains unclear. Rice stripe virus ( RSV ), a Tenuivirus, is one of the most important pathogens in rice production and is transmitted by the small brown planthopper ( Laodelphax striatellus ). We investigated the mechanism of transovarial transmission of RSV by using the RSV–planthopper system as a model to investigate the mechanism of virus transport into the eggs. Our data showed that the vitellogenin ( Vg ) of L. striatellus can bind to pc3 in vivo and in vitro and colocalize in the germarium. RSV particles accumulated in the terminal filaments and pedicel areas of the germarium prior to Vg expression, which was also observed in the oocytes. Our results indicate that Vg of L. striatellus played a critical role in transovarial transmission of RSV and shows how viruses can use existing transovarial transportation systems in insect vectors for their own purposes.

Schistosomiasis is an infectious disease caused by a parasite that lives in the liver and affects more than 200 million people worldwide. Hepatitis is the most common manifestation of schistosomiasis. Hepatic liver injury results in fibrosis and causes bleeding into the liver. In some patients, fibrosis leads to liver cirrhosis and liver cancer. Patients with liver fibrosis and cancer have low platelet counts, which may predispose them to gastrointestinal bleeding. We compared blood, liver, and function testing in patients with liver fibrosis and in patients with liver fibrosis without liver damage. We found that liver function and blood coagulation were associated with fibrosis. The blood coagulation abnormalities were increased in patients with liver fibrosis, which may predispose them to gastrointestinal bleeding. Furthermore, we found that liver function and blood coagulation are also increased in patients with liver fibrosis. Finally, we found that a quarter of patients with liver fibrosis and advanced periportal fibrosis have hyperfibrinolysis, which may predispose them to gastrointestinal bleeding.

This paper discusses a method for predicting disease risk using genomic information. We show that a method called BootRank, which uses a ranking algorithm based on the p-values of SNPs, can be used to predict disease risk for several large-scale disease studies. We also show that using this method in a well-known case-control study improves predictive accuracy and increases our understanding of disease biology.

Leishmaniasis is a neglected disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania. It is estimated that 1. 5 million people are exposed to the parasite worldwide and 350 million people are infected. The parasite invade various cell types of the immune system, including dendritic cells, macrophages and fibroblasts. We show that Leishmania infection interferes with the maturation of dendritic cells and the maturation of macrophages. Interestingly, dendritic cells deficient in the ability to respond to antigen were unable to present antigen to T cells, thus suggesting the importance of this antigen for the development of an efficient immune response. Collectively, our data reveal a novel mechanism by which Leishmania parasites interfere with the maturation of dendritic cells, leading to an impaired antigen presentation in dendritic cells, and consequently to a compromised immune response against the parasite.

In Australia, the human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) is endemic among indigenous people of Melanesian descent, but the molecular epidemiology of HTLV-1 infection remains poorly documented. Studying a series of 23 HTLV-1 strains from indigenous residents of central Australia, we analyzed coding and non-coding genomic regions to gain insights into the molecular epidemiology of HTLV-1 infection. Our results revealed that all HTLV-1 strains belong to the HTLV-1c subtype with a high genetic diversity. At least two Australian clades exist, one derived from the north and the other derived from the south of central Australia. The HTLV-1c subtype is endemic to central Australia where the Indigenous population is infected with diverse subtype c variants. At least two Australian clades are found, which cluster according to the geographic origin of the human hosts. These molecular variants are probably of very ancient origin. Further studies could provide new insights into the evolution and modes of dissemination of these retrovirus variants and the associated ancient migration events through which early human settlement of Australia and Melanesia was achieved.

RNA interference ( RNAi ) is a post-transcriptional silencing process, triggered by double-stranded RNA ( dsRNA ). A distinction has been made between endogenous RNAi–related pathways and the exogenous RNAi pathway, the latter being essential for the experimental use of RNAi. In Caenorhabditis elegans, a complex containing the enzymes Dicer and the Argonaute RDE-1, is responsible for dsRNA cleavage and the generation of short interfering RNAs ( siRNAs ). RDE-1 acts as the siRNA acceptor. Here, we show that RDE-1 functions as a scavenger protein, taking up small RNA molecules from many different sources, including the microRNA pathway. This is in striking contrast to Argonaute proteins functioning directly in the miRNA pathway, ALG-1 and ALG-2: these proteins exclusively bind miRNAs. While playing no significant role in the biogenesis of the main pool of miRNAs, RDE-1 binds endogenous miRNAs and triggers RdRP activity on at least one perfectly matching, endogenous miRNA target. The resulting secondary siRNAs are taken up by a set of Argonaute proteins known to act as siRNA acceptors in exogenous RNAi. Our results show that RDE-1 in an endogenous setting is actively screening the transcriptome using many different small RNAs, including miRNAs, as a guide, with implications for the evolution of transcripts with a potential to be recognized by Dicer.

Herpesviruses are the cause of several human malignancies, including Kaposi’s sarcoma and nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal cancers. Herpesviruses infect cells through membrane penetration and budding into cellular compartments, which is initiated by a set of viral proteins. These proteins are candidates for the recognition of viral budding sites on cellular membranes and induction of budding and final envelopment. We have found that ORF45, a protein found on the outer membrane of Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ), interacts with lipid rafts ( LRs ) of cellular membrane. In addition, we have found that ORF45 associates with the lipid rafts of cellular membrane, and that the ability of ORF45 to target LR is dependent on the mono-ubiquitylation of ORF45 at Lys297. Our results reveal a new function of KSHV tegument protein ORF45 in targeting LR of host cell membrane, promoting viral particles co-localization with trans-Golgi and endosomes, and facilitating the maturation and release of virion particles, suggesting that ORF45 plays a role in bringing KSHV particles to the budding site on cytoplasmic vesicle membrane and triggering the viral budding process for final envelopment and virion maturation.

Aedes aegypti is the most important vector of human arboviruses and is highly invasive. Recent outbreaks of dengue and other Aedes aegypti-borne arboviruses highlight the need for a rapid response to control outbreaks. Understanding the mechanisms by which insecticide resistance develops and spreads is essential for outbreak preparedness. In the present study, we investigated the levels and mechanisms of insecticide resistance and resistance mechanisms in Aedes aegypti collected from contrasting settings within and around Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. Larval dose-response assays indicated susceptibility to the organophosphates. Adult females were also susceptible to organophosphates but resistance to carbamates was suspected in urban and semi-urban localities. Larval dose-response assays indicated that adult females were susceptible to pyrethroids but resistance to carbamates was suspected in urban and semi-urban populations. Environment was also associated with susceptibility: adult females reared from larvae collected in tires from the semi-urban site were significantly less resistant to pyrethroids than those collected from large outdoor drinking water containers. P450 gene analysis detected limited over-expression of single candidates but significantly elevated average expression in the semi-urban site compared to both a susceptible laboratory colony, and females from the other collection sites. Our results reveal pyrethroid resistance and paired kdr mutations in both urban and semi-urban sites at levels that are unprecedented for mainland Africa. However, organophosphate insecticides are still active against both larvae and adults of Ae. aegypti, providing useful insecticidal options for control and resistance management.

To unravel the cellular functions of proteins and their interactions, a comprehensive map of the protein interactome is required. However, existing interactome maps are far from complete. Thus, methods for protein-protein interaction discovery have been developed to resolve this deficiency. However, these methods often result in large-scale misannotation and are not highly accurate. To address this issue, we conducted a rigorous analysis of genomic data integration methods for protein-protein interaction recovery across a large number of co-migration datasets. We found that genomic data integration leads to a decrease in the power of the method to detect novel interactions, while it comes at the expense of a decrease in the accuracy of the resulting interactome maps. Our results reveal a widespread limitation in the use of genomic data integration to map the interactome of humans and model organisms.

During spermatogenesis, a specialized cell division program enables the production of spermatozoa, the gametes responsible for sexual reproduction. piRNAs are a class of small non-coding RNAs that play important roles in regulating this process. piRNAs are important for normal germ cell function and are known to be involved in the repression of transposable elements ( TEs ), a class of mobile genetic elements that have been shown to play a central role in maintaining TE repression in germ cells. Here, we show that HENMT1, a member of the HEN methyltransferase 1 ( HENMT1 ) family, is required for the 2’ O-methylation of mammalian piRNAs. HENMT1 loss leads to piRNA instability, reduced piRNA bulk and length, and ultimately male sterility characterized by a germ cell arrest at the elongating germ cell phase of spermatogenesis. HENMT1 loss-of-function, and the concomitant loss of piRNAs, resulted in TE de-repression in adult meiotic and haploid germ cells, and the precocious, and selective, expression of many haploid-transcripts in meiotic cells. HENMT1 loss-of-function, and the concomitant loss of piRNAs, resulted in a deregulation of the haploid germ cell gene expression, elevated levels of DNA damage and a catastrophic deregulation of the haploid germ cell gene expression. Collectively these results define a critical role for HENMT1 and piRNAs in the maintenance of TE repression in adult germ cells and the spermatogenic program.

Herpesviruses have evolved numerous mechanisms to evade detection by cytotoxic T lymphocytes. We show that the human herpesvirus-7 ( HHV-7 ) U21 gene product, for example, binds to the NK activating ligand ULBP1 and reroutes it to the lysosomal compartment. U21 also interferes with NK recognition by downregulating the surface expression of the NK activating ligands MICA and MICB. These results suggest that this single viral protein may interfere both with CTL-mediated recognition through the downregulation of class I MHC molecules as well as NK-mediated recognition through downregulation of NK activating ligands.

Norway rats are a large and highly important reservoir of zoonotic leptospirosis, and their population density is considered high risk for human infection.
