Nevertheless, little is known about the epidemiological parameters of the disease in Norway rats, especially regarding the age of the population, prevalence of carrier and the risk of human infection. Our study, conducted in Salvador, Brazil, established the average load of leptospires in positive kidneys to be 5. 9 x 106 per ml ( range 3. 1-8. 2 x106 ) genome equivalents ( GEq ), similar to the 6. 1 x 106 per ml ( range 2. 2-9. 4 x106 ) average obtained from paired urines, with a significant positive correlation ( R2=0. 78 ) between the two. Based on bivariate and multivariate modeling, we found leptospiral loads increased with age of rats ( based on the index of body length to mass ), MAT titer and the presence of wounding/scars, and varied with site of capture. Some associations were modified by sex but trends were apparent. Complementing data on the demographic properties and prevalence of leptospiral carriage in rat populations in Salvador, we estimated that daily leptospiral loads shed in the urine of a population of 82 individuals exceeded 9. 1 x 1010 leptospires. These factors directly influence the risk of leptospiral acquisition among humans and provide essential epidemiological information linking properties of rat populations with risk of human infection.

A variety of cancer cell types exist, and their behavior in response to drug treatment is complex. Recently, we have shown that the heterogeneous mixture of cell types in triple-negative breast cancer ( TNBC ) can result in drug resistance. Understanding how the heterogeneity in cell type behavior impacts drug response could be important for the development of more effective therapeutic regimens for this subtype. In this work, we develop computational models to predict how cell type heterogeneity affects drug response. We show that these differential equations can accurately predict changes in drug response induced by targeted therapies. We use this model to predict the effect of drug therapy on the expression of a cellular marker for drug resistance, which we show can be used to identify drug-induced changes in cell type behavior. We validate these predictions on an independent cell division and cell death data. Our work provides a framework for modeling the response of cancer cell populations to drug treatment and for identifying changes in cell type behavior that may be important for the design of improved therapeutic regimens for these cancers.

Following the initial recognition of the virus by the anti-HIV antibody 4E10, a broad spectrum of non-antibody antibodies subsequently elicited, including 4E10, have the unusual property of broadness of neutralization. Such antibodies must recognize diverse circulating HIV variants to achieve broad spectrum neutralization. In this study, we delineated the mechanism of 4E10 recognition and found that, while structural and biophysical differences between the 4E10 subtypes are widely recognized by the antibody, the conformational changes induced by the antibody are not. These findings suggest that the ability of 4E10 to elicit conformational changes distant from its binding site is not the primary mechanism of recognition by this broadly neutralizing antibody.

Cysteine proteases are essential enzymes in the parasite life cycle that play key roles in parasite survival and evasion of host antiparasitic immune responses. Therefore, these proteins represent attractive targets for the development of antiparasitic drugs. Here we describe the screening of a unique cathepsin inhibitor library against the five parasite cysteine proteases thought to be involved in tropical parasitic diseases. Compounds active against parasite enzymes were subsequently screened against mammalian cells. The end products of this effort include the identification of sub-micromolar cell-active leads as well as the elucidation of structure-activity trends that can guide further optimization efforts.

Angiogenesis is the growth of new blood vessels from existing vasculature, a process that is important for the development of the organism. In this study, we used a panel of inbred mouse strains to identify genes that regulate angiogenesis. We found that the expression of a gene called peptidyl arginine deiminase type II ( Padi2 ), which is involved in metabolic pathways, was significantly correlated with a genetic variant shared by multiple high angiogenic strains. To investigate its role in vivo, we knocked down the expression of Padi2 in zebrafish embryos, demonstrating that it was involved in angiogenesis. Our study is the first to identify the potential role of Padi2 as an angiogenesis-regulating gene. This knowledge may provide novel insights into angiogenesis regulation and novel targets for the diagnosis and treatment of a wide variety of angiogenesis-related diseases.

Drought and salt stress are serious threats to food security in many important crops. Although plants have developed sophisticated stress response mechanisms to cope with these threats, the underlying molecular mechanisms of how these mechanisms are regulated is still unclear. In this study, we demonstrated that DCA1, a previously unknown transcription factor gene in rice, interacts with itself and is a co-activator of Drought and Salt Tolerance ( DST ). We also found that DCA1 is a positive regulator of the H2O2 scavenger Prx 24 and its expression is negatively regulated by DCA1 and positively regulated by its interaction with DST. Our findings establish a framework for plant drought and salt tolerance through the DCA1-DST-Prx24 pathway. Moreover, due to the evolutionary and functional conservation of DCA1 and DST in plants, engineering of this pathway has the potential to improve tolerance to abiotic stress in other important crop species.

Malaria parasites export hundreds of proteins into the host cell to manipulate and exploit the host cell, including many that may be involved in the process of invasion. The PEXEL/HT motif, a common motif found in many exported proteins, has been used to predict the exportome. However, several proteins that are exported into the host cell still lack the exported motif and it is unclear if all exported proteins are in fact part of the exportedome. We report the identification of new PNEPs in the most virulent malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum. This includes proteins with a domain structure deviating from previously known PNEPs and indicates that PNEPs are not a rare exception. Unexpectedly, we found that some new PNEPs are related to the related Plasmodium protein MSP-7. Analyzing regions mediating export of selected new PNEPs, we show that the first 20 amino acids of PNEPs without a classical N-terminal signal peptide are sufficient to promote export of a reporter, confirming the concept that this is a shared property of all PNEPs of this type. We also took advantage of newly found soluble PNEPs to show that this type of exported protein requires unfolding to move from the parasitophorous vacuole ( PV ) into the host cell. This indicates that soluble PNEPs, like PEXEL/HT proteins, are exported by translocation across the PV membrane ( PVM ), highlighting protein translocation in the parasite periphery as a general means in protein export of malaria parasites.

Cardiomyocytes are vulnerable to hypoxia in the adult, but adapted to hypoxia in utero. Current understanding of endogenous cardiac oxygen sensing pathways is limited. Here we show that hypoxia-controlled expression of the transcription factor Hand1 determines oxygen consumption by inhibition of lipid metabolism, which shifts from glycolysis to lipid oxidation soon after birth, and is re-expression of several “fetal” genes whose role in disease phenotypes remains unknown. Our findings provide new insight into the mechanisms that underlie hypoxia adaptation in the fetal heart. We show that Hand1 expression controls cardiomyocyte oxygen consumption by direct transcriptional repression of lipid metabolism. This leads, in turn, to increased production of lactate from glucose, decreased lipid oxidation, and reduced inner mitochondrial membrane potential. Our results suggest that Hand1 is part of a novel regulatory pathway linking cardiac oxygen levels with oxygen consumption. Understanding hypoxia adaptation in the fetal heart may allow development of strategies to protect cardiomyocytes vulnerable to ischaemia, for example during cardiac ischaemia or surgery.

Differentiated T helper ( Th ) cell lineages are thought to emerge from alternative cell fate decisions. However, recent studies indicated that differentiated Th cells can adopt mixed phenotypes during secondary immunological challenges. Here we show that natural primary immune responses against parasites generate bifunctional Th1 and Th2 hybrid cells that co-express the lineage-specifying transcription factors T-bet and GATA-3 and co-produce Th1 and Th2 cytokines. The integration of Th1-promoting interferon ( IFN ) -γ and interleukin ( IL ) -12 signals together with Th2-favoring IL-4 signals drives the development of the hybrid Th1/2 phenotype. Specifically, IFN-γ signals are essential for T-bet+GATA-3+ cells to develop in vitro and in vivo by breaking the dominance of IL-4 over IL-12 signals. The hybrid Th1/2 phenotype is stably maintained in memory cells in vivo for months. It resists reprogramming into classic Th1 or Th2 cells by Th1- or Th2-promoting stimuli, which rather induces quantitative modulations of the combined Th1 and Th2 programs without abolishing either. Thus, we propose the self-limitation of effector T cells based on the stable cell-intrinsic balance of two opposing differentiation programs as a novel concept of how the immune system can prevent excessive inflammation.

Plasmids are mobile genetic elements that are essential for the survival of many bacteria. They are constantly being discovered and analyzed, and this is the focus of many research groups, mostly in bacteria such as E. coli, Bacillus subtilis, and Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium. We have developed a new method, named PLACNET, which identifies plasmids by creating a network of interactions between the genome, the cell, and the plasmid. This network is then used for analysis of the entire genome, which allows the identification of the most important genes and the identification of plasmids that have facilitated the evolution of the organism. We applied this method to the genome of E. coli ST131, which is widely distributed among extraintestinal pathogenic E. coli ( ExPEC ) strains. ST131 is a globally spread bacterial pathogen that infects the intestine of approximately 50% of the world's population. Our results show that the diversity of the bacterial genome allows the analysis of this organism in different evolutionary scenarios, and that plasmids play an important role in the evolution of this species.

Most biological nitrogen fixation is catalyzed by molybdenum-dependent nitrogenase, an enzyme complex comprising two component proteins that contain three different metalloclusters. Diazotrophs contain a common core of nitrogen fixation nif genes that encode the structural subunits of the enzyme and components required to synthesize the metalloclusters. In this study, we identified a minimal nif gene cluster consisting of nine nif genes in the genome of Paenibacillus sp. WLY78, a gram-positive, facultative anaerobe isolated from the rhizosphere of bamboo. We demonstrate that the nif genes in this organism are organized as an operon comprising nifB, nifH, nifD, nifK, nifE, nifN, nifX, hesA and nifV and that the nif cluster is under the control of a σ70 ( σA ) -dependent promoter located upstream of nifB. To investigate genetic requirements for diazotrophy, we transferred the Paenibacillus nif gene cluster to Escherichia coli. The minimal nif gene cluster enables synthesis of catalytically active nitrogenase in this host, when expressed either from the native nifB promoter or from the T7 promoter. Deletion analysis indicates that in addition to the core nif genes, hesA plays an important role in nitrogen fixation and is responsive to the external oxygen concentration.

African trypanosomes have a complex life cycle that alternates between the bloodstream form, which is responsible for human disease, and the insect procyclic form, which is responsible for the tsetse fly vector. A cell cycle regulator is essential for maintaining the integrity of the cell cycle and for coordinating cell division with growth and differentiation. In this study, we have used RNA interference to knock down the function of 190 predicted cell cycle regulators in T. brucei. We then assessed the effects of their depletion on the parasite and found that 42 of these regulators are required for normal bloodstream form proliferation. We also identified two novel regulators of cell cycle progression. We also found that one of these is a membrane-associated protein kinase and the other is a neuropeptide receptor. We show that the depletion of one of these two kinases results in bloodstream to procyclic form differentiation. This study provides a valuable resource for functional analysis of cell signalling pathways in African trypanosomes as well as identification of cell signalling pathways in African trypanosomes.

Cleavage of the tyrosine residue 41 ( cle41 ) and 44 ( tdr ) is a conserved regulatory motif present in two plant CLE peptide genes, CLE10 and CLE13. In Arabidopsis, CLE10 and CLE13 function as ligands of plant A-type CLE peptides, which activate the Procambial meristem ( PM ) cell proliferation pathway, which is required for plant development. However, CLE peptides have been shown to act as ligands of tdr-1, which is involved in tdr-1-mediated PM cell proliferation. Here we report the identification of a new type of CLE peptides from cyst nematodes, which we named TRAF-1 ( TDR-1 ), which is involved in tdr-1-mediated PM cell proliferation. The TRAF-1-mediated PM cell proliferation is also activated in the presence of CLE peptides, suggesting that CLE peptides may regulate PM cell proliferation through tdr-1. The TDR-1 pathway is also activated in the presence of CLE peptides, suggesting that CLE peptides may regulate PM cell proliferation in a similar manner as tdr-1. These results highlight an important role of the PM cell proliferation pathway in cyst nematode feeding site formation.

Recombination is an important mechanism by which viruses can rapidly generate new, potentially more virulent, variants of their genome. This process is thought to be influenced by the environment and host genome. However, the underlying factors that influence recombination are poorly understood. Here, we utilize a combination of genome sequencing, gene expression, and cellular function to identify the genes and motifs that modulate recombination in the poliovirus genome. We find that recombination frequency is modulated by several factors, including the composition of the predicted secondary structure and the presence of nucleotide bases that alter their base composition. We also show that artificial sites can be used to re-design the genome to modify the frequency of recombination, thus providing a means to design recombination-deficient strains of poliovirus.

Tsetse flies transmit African trypanosomes, a family of parasites causing human sleeping sickness. These parasites are transmitted by tsetse flies, a blood-sucking insect, and they must be controlled in order to prevent transmission. Currently, tsetse flies are controlled by the use of insecticide-spraying traps. However, it is becoming apparent that tsetse flies may be attracted to compounds other than those used for trap traps. Here, we present the genome of five tsetse fly species collected across sub-Saharan Africa. We identified several hundred genes that are important for the tsetse fly's ability to be attracted to compounds other than those used for trap traps. These genes are scattered across different parts of the genome, but are relatively close together in the genomes of different tsetse fly species. We also found that these genes are important for tsetse mating behaviour, which has implications for the development of novel control methods. Our study provides a platform for further studies of the language of tsetse communication with their environment and the development of new control strategies.

Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes significant disease in immunocompromised patients. It has been shown that the fungal cell wall is a primary target of host defenses, and that this physical barrier is important for the fungus to survive attack by the innate immune system. Previous studies have indicated that copper, an important antimicrobial metal, kills C. albicans by a mechanism distinct from the known resistance mechanisms. Here we show that this mechanism is conserved in mutants lacking the plasma membrane, a component of the cell wall that resides in punctate membrane domains. We identify new mutants that have altered plasma membrane architecture due to defects in membrane trafficking, cortical actin, and morphogenesis. Our results reveal that the plasma membrane plays a critical role in protecting the fungal pathogen C. albicans from attack by the immune system, and suggest a novel mechanism by which this host defense mechanism protects the fungal cell wall from being attacked by the immune system.

Infectious diseases spread in societies in constant danger to individuals and populations. Disease spread may be reduced if individuals are aware of the health status of their social contacts, allowing them to avoid contact with disease-causing individuals and to remain in touch with the healthy. Here we study disease spread in networks of people that have a personal contact ( a close relative ) and a close non-patient relative ( a health worker ). We use some of the most widely used epidemiological models to study the effect of the network structure on the disease dynamics. We find that for a wide range of network structures, the infectiousness of a disease to a given individual depends on both the population size, the number of infected in the population, and the capacity of the healthy individuals to sever contacts with the infected. We show how using available information improves the spread of infectiousness.

Glutathione ( GSH ) is an essential molecule for maintaining a reduced cellular environment. The inhibition of GSH by the cellular GSH biosynthesis inhibitor, BSO, has been shown to strongly interfere with the morphogenesis of several viruses. However, the role of GSH in the growth of enteroviruses has not been studied. Here we show that the growth of poliovirus type 1 ( PV1 ) and coxsackievirus A20 ( CAV20 ) are strongly inhibited by BSO and can be partially reversed by the addition of GSH. BSO has no effect on viral protein synthesis or RNA replication but it strongly inhibits the accumulation of 14S pentamers in infected cells. GSH directly interacts with capsid precursors and mature virus particles, and deletion of GSH reduces the 14S pentamers accumulation and does not affect the capsid stability. BSOr mutants, mapping to VP1 and VP3 capsid proteins, are more heat resistant and need less GSH to be protected from heat inactivation. Our results suggest that the role of GSH during enterovirus morphogenesis is to stabilize capsid structures by direct interaction with capsid proteins both during and after the formation of mature virus particles.

Plasmodium vivax is the most common malaria parasite outside Africa and is responsible for an estimated 2. 6–3 million cases of malaria each year. P. vivax is a difficult to control due to its ability to evade the human immune response and to cause multiple relapses. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop vaccines to prevent this parasite. One of the most promising malaria vaccine candidates is the P. vivax Apical Membrane Antigen 1 ( PvAMA1 ). The P. vivax genome is highly variable and this diversity can potentially be exploited to generate an effective vaccine. However, it remains unclear which regions of the genome are targeted by host immunity and whether this diversity can be effectively exploited to generate an effective vaccine. Here we show that the diversity of PvAMA1 is large and that it is highly polymorphic. However, this diversity is geographically restricted, suggesting that it may be possible to generate a vaccine that can cover the diversity of PvAMA1. Furthermore, we show that the genetic diversity of PvAMA1 is not high and that it is not necessarily beneficial, suggesting that it may be possible to exploit the diversity of PvAMA1 in order to generate an effective vaccine.

Vaccines are a significant health care and economic burden, and are based on the induction of a specific type of immune response. However, the molecular pathways that regulate the strength and quality of the immune response remain largely uncharacterized. Toll-like receptor ( TLR ) signaling is an important pathway that enables the detection of pathogens by the immune system, but its effect on the control of a model retroviral pathogen, Friend virus ( FV ), remains to be addressed. In this study, I generated mice in which the TLR signaling adapter Myd88 was selectively deleted in dendritic cell ( DC ) or in B cell lineages. Deletion of Myd88 in DCs had little effect on immune control of FV, while B cell-specific deletion of Myd88 caused a dramatically increased number of viral infectious centers and a significantly reduced antibody response, indicating that B cell-intrinsic TLR signaling plays a crucial role, while TLR signaling in DCs is less important. I then identified the single-stranded RNA sensing protein TLR7 as being required for antibody-mediated control of FV by analyzing mice deficient in TLR7. B cells in infected TLR7-deficient mice upregulated CD69 and CD86 early in infection, but failed to develop into germinal center B cells. CD4 T cell responses were also attenuated in the absence of TLR7, but CD8 responses were TLR7 independent, suggesting the existence of additional pathways for detecting retroviral particles. Together these results demonstrate that the vertebrate immune system detects retroviral infection via TLR7 and that this pathway regulates a key checkpoint controlling development of germinal center B cells.

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus ( MRSA ) are bacteria that are resistant to most antibiotics. These bacteria can be found in the environment, in hospitals, or in the human body. The bacteria are difficult to eradicate, and the main way to prevent infection is by screening for the presence of bacteria. Different strategies have been proposed for the screening and isolation of these bacteria. We used a computer model to study the effect and costs of different strategies. We found that the most cost-saving strategies are universal screening and isolation of patients with MRSA who are sick, but not with patients who are healthy. Universal screening is predicted to prevent hardly more infections than S&I of previously documented carriers ( “flagged” patients ) and S&I of freely admitted patients. Our results suggest that universal screening may be cost-saving.

Circadian clocks govern daily rhythms in physiology and behavior in animals and plants, but the mechanisms of how they are controlled remain enigmatic. Circadian clocks are often controlled by a master circadian clock that drives the timing and amplitude of peripheral clocks throughout the body. One mechanism of controlling circadian clocks is by tuning the relative amount of each peripheral clock component, such as ion channels and peptides, such that faster rhythms are produced by faster peripheral clocks. Here we show that a nocturnal, energy-efficient fish such as the cobra, Sterolus aquaticus, rapidly increases the amplitude of its peripheral clock by 40% at night and during social encounters. S. macrurus thus maintains a circadian rhythm in signal amplitude and adapts within minutes to environmental events by increasing signal amplitude through the rapid and selective trafficking of voltage-gated sodium channels into the excitable membranes of its electrogenic cells, a process under the control of pituitary peptide hormones and intracellular second-messenger pathways.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a bacterial pathogen that is responsible for the majority of cases of hospital-acquired infections. In immunocompromised patients, P. aeruginosa is also an important cause of mortality due to the emergence of multi-drug resistant pathogens. In this work, we investigated the role of environmental contamination in P. aeruginosa transmission and its impact on two ICUs of the University hospital in Besançon. We found that P. aeruginosa transmission is mediated by a combination of environmental and infection-related factors. The importance of the combined effect was highlighted by analyzing the impact of the two factors on the two ICUs, and we found that only 1% of the total transmissions were due to environmental contamination after discharge.

Aerial dispersal is a fundamental issue in science. The physical mechanism of aerial dispersal of spiders, “ballooning behavior, ” is still unclear because of the lack of serious scientific observations and experiments. Therefore, as a first step in clarifying the phenomenon, we studied the puff addership spiders ( Sp. balidar ), which are larger than any other spider in the world. Large spiders spin up to flight speeds and then take a flight simulator to see what physical properties of these spiders’ cocoons can induce their flight speed. We observed that large spiders spin up to flight speeds with a characteristic length of about 3. 22 ± 1. 31 m. The length of these threads was 3. 22 ± 1. 31 m. These physical properties of balloon-shaped spiders can explain the illusion of airflow, i. e., the illusion of wind speed, that spiders spin up when the wind speed is slower than 3 m s−1. This regime is strongly correlated with lower wind speeds.

Human and macaque monkeys are widely used models to study the brain mechanisms of attention. Attention is generally thought to be critical for the processing of sensory information, but the role of attention in higher brain areas is still debated. Here, we investigate the neuronal mechanisms underlying attentional remapping in monkeys, a form of attentional shift in which sensory information is shifted from the periphery to the central region. We recorded from two monkeys while they made eye movements in order to control attention to one of two locations. We show that the responses of some neurons in the central region, the temporal lobe, are modified by attention to one of the two eye movements. We also show that top-down attention is required to efficiently modify the responses of other neurons. Our data provide the first demonstration of the influence of top-down attention on the memory trace, anywhere in the brain, and provide important information on the perisaccadic representation of visual stimuli in the dorsal stream.

Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus Brucella. In animals brucellosis can cause severe and chronic infections resulting in abortion, pregnancy loss, and loss of affected livestock. B. abortus and B. melitensis are widely distributed in the world and have been reported in several studies in animals in Zimbabwe but the extent of the disease remains poorly known. In this study we investigated strains from Zimbabwe collected in the Central Veterinary laboratory from various hosts. We characterized the strains using a set of diagnostic methods to identify the species, biovar, and individual strain level. Sixteen strains were identified and characterized using all or some of these methods. The strains were identified as B. ovis, B. abortus, B. canis and B. suis. We further characterized the strains using whole genome sequencing and closely related strains were identified as B. suis and B. abortus. Our findings demonstrate the range of tests that can be run in laboratories lacking sophisticated instrumentation to whole genome analyses that currently require substantial expertise and infrastructure often not available in the developing world.

Human use of the land has a substantial negative effect on biodiversity worldwide. However, not all species are adversely affected by land use, and some benefit from the creation of novel habitat. Here we show that disturbed habitats have more widespread species on average, especially in urban areas and the tropics. Our results are very important for biodiversity conservation because narrow-ranged species are typically at higher risk of extinction than widespread species. Additionally, the shift to more widespread species may also affect ecosystem functioning by reducing both the contribution of rare species and the diversity of species’ responses to environmental changes among local assemblages.

Dengue is a re-emerging infectious disease of humans that rapidly grows from endemic areas to dengue-free regions. In recent decades, Guangzhou has again suffered from several big outbreaks of dengue; as have its neighboring cities. This study aims to examine the impact of dengue epidemics in Guangzhou, China, and to develop a predictive model for Zhongshan based on local weather conditions and Guangzhou dengue surveillance information. Our results showed that weekly dengue cases in Zhongshan were significantly associated with dengue cases in Guangzhou after the treatment of a 5 weeks prior moving average ( Relative Risk ( RR ) = 2. 016, 95% Confidence Interval ( CI ) : 1. 845–2. 203 ), controlling for weather factors including minimum temperature, relative humidity, and rainfall. We also identified a 3-fold increase in the probability of dengue cases in 2014, and validated our results using a 4-fold cross-validation. Our study findings suggest that the occurrence of dengue outbreaks in Guangzhou could impact dengue outbreaks in Zhongshan under suitable weather conditions. Future studies should focus on developing integrated early warning systems for dengue transmission including local weather and human movement.

DNA methylation is a fundamental epigenetic mark which influences gene expression and development. DNA methylation is particularly important in the mammalian genome, where it influences about one quarter of all human DNA methylation changes. DNA methylation is predominantly associated with cytosines, in the context of CpG dinucleotide sequences. Although the primary sites of DNA methylation in vertebrates are cytosines in the CpG dinucleotide context, little is known about DNA methylation targeting CpA, CpT, and CpC ( non-CpG ) dinucleotides. Here, we report a comprehensive analysis of non-CpG methylation in 76 genome-scale DNA methylation maps across human cell types. We confirm that non-CpG methylation is predominantly present in pluripotent cell types and show that it is highly variable and show little conservation between different pluripotent cell lines. We also show that knockdown of DNMTA and DNMT3 in human ESCs results in a global reduction of non-CpG methylation. Finally, non-CpG methylation appears to be spatially correlated with CpG methylation. In summary, these results contribute further to our understanding of cytosine methylation patterns in human cells using a large representative sample set.

Human infertility and reproductive problems are a major cause of concern in the U. S. population. Failure of meiosis, the process that generates haploid gametes, is a major contributor to this problem. Meiotic defects in humans have been linked to the loss of sperm and to the aneuploidies resulting from inappropriate chromosome segregation. Crossover formation between homologous chromosomes is a critical step during meiosis, as it ensures proper homolog segregation and proper formation of haploid gametes. We have shown that the Mre11 complex, a meiosis-specific protein, is essential for crossover formation and the repair of double strand breaks in yeast. We also show that the mouse Mre11 ortholog, ZIP4H, is required for crossover formation in mouse germ cells. To our knowledge, this is the first time that such a protein has been studied in the context of the mouse, and our results indicate that the Mre11 complex and ZIP4H are conserved functions in mammals.

Large whole-genome sequencing projects have provided access to much rare variation in human populations, which is highly informative about population structure and recent demography. Here, we show how the age of rare variants can be estimated from patterns of haplotype sharing and how these ages can be related to historical relationships between populations. We investigate the distribution of the age of variants occurring exactly twice ( variants ) in a worldwide sample sequenced by the 1000 Genomes Project, revealing enormous variation across populations. The median age of haplotypes sharing variants is 50 to 160 generations across populations within Europe or Asia, and 170 to 320 generations within Africa. Haplotypes shared between continents are much older than those shared between Europe and Asia ranging from 320 to 670 generations. The distribution of the ages of haplotypes is informative about their demography, revealing recent bottlenecks, ancient splits, and more modern connections between populations.

The immune response to viral infections is driven by a specific type of immune cell called the cytotoxic CD8+ T cell. These cells can recognize and kill virus-infected cells using a receptor called PD-1. However, it has recently been shown that virus-specific CD8+ T cells may also recognize virus-infected cells that are not producing PD-1. In these cases, the PD-1 pathway is activated and the cell becomes resistant to killing by the immune system. In this study we examined the role of PD-1 signaling in the recognition and killing of virus-infected cells. We found that the expression of PD-1 is increased on retrovirus-infected cells that are being targeted by cytotoxic CD8+ T cells. The increased PD-1 expression on virus-infected cells enhances the immune response to the virus, but can also cause an immune escape mechanism. Thus, our study provides evidence for a novel mechanism of CD8+ T cell immune escape after viral infection.

Many proteins are built from repetitive units called structural repeats. These repeats are often involved in the regulation of protein function. In this work, we present a method to analyze the symmetry and structural repeats of proteins, and to report the type of symmetry. We also report the type of internal repeats, and the way they are arranged with respect to the protein sequence. Finally, we compare the similarity of all the internal repeats at the residue level.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection that causes an estimated 100 million cases each year. The 2C7 epitope is a conserved oligosaccharide ( OS ) on N gonorrhoeae, a bacterium that resides in the human genital tract. The 2C7 epitope is expressed by 94% of gonococcal isolates and is expressed by 95% of first passaged isolates. Absence of the 2C7 epitope shortens the time of gonococcal carriage in a mouse model of genital infection. To circumvent the limitations of saccharide immunogens in producing long lived immune responses, previously we developed a peptide mimic ( called PEP1 ) as an immunologic surrogate of the 2C7-OS epitope and reconfigured it into a multi-antigenic peptide ( MAP1 ). To test vaccine efficacy of MAP1, female BALB/c mice were passively immunized with a complement-dependent bactericidal monoclonal antibody specific for the 2C7 epitope or were actively immunized with MAP1. Mice immunized with MAP1 developed a TH1-biased anti-LOS IgG antibody response that was also bactericidal. Length of carriage was shortened in immune mice; clearance occurred in 4 days in mice passively administered 2C7 antibody vs. 9 days in mice immunized with control peptide. Mice vaccinated with MAP1 cleared infection in 5 days vs. 9 days in mice immunized with control peptide ( p = 0. 0001 and p = 0. 0002, respectively ). Bacterial burden was lower over the course of infection in passively immunized vs. controls in both experiments ( p = 0. 008 and p = 0. 0005 ). The OS epitope defined by mAb 2C7 may represent an effective vaccine target against gonorrhea.

The environmental reservoirs for the bacterium Vibrio cholerae are natural aquatic habitats where it colonizes the chitinous exoskeletons of copePod mollts. Growth of V. cholerae on a chitin surface induces competence for natural transformation, a mechanism for intra-species gene exchange. O-serogroup genes are encoded by a genetic cluster that is flanked on either side by chromosomal regions that are conserved between different serogroups. Here we describe a novel mechanism of natural transformation that involves a single-step exchange of large fragments of DNA that occurs as a single-step exchange of large fragments of DNA. The process is mediated by O-antigenic determinant, which is encoded by a large genomic DNA segment that is flanked by a motif conserved between different serogroups, and is transferred to an O1 strain by a virulent O1-specific phage. Serogroup conversion of O1 recipient by the O139 donor was demonstrated by comparative genomic hybridization, biochemical and serological characterization of the O-antigenic determinant, and resistance of O1 transformants to bacteriolysis by a virulent O1-specific phage. Serogroup conversion is shown to have occurred as a single-step exchange of large fragments of DNA. Crossovers were localized to regions of homology common to other V. cholerae serogroups that flank serogroup-specific encoding sequences. This result and the successful serogroup conversion of an O1 strain by O37 genomic DNA indicate that chitin-induced natural transformation might be a common mechanism for serogroup conversion in aquatic habitats and for the emergence of V. cholerae variants that are better adapted for survival in environmental niches or more pathogenic for humans.

Cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) is a herpesvirus that establishes life-long infection in humans. HCMV infection during pregnancy can cause severe disease, including encephalitis, is immunocompromised, and is associated with fetal abnormalities. HCMV is known to inhibit T cell immunity, which is important for the outcome of many viral infections. HCMV expresses several proteins that function to prevent immune cell lysis, but the mechanism of action is not well understood. Here, we show that the UL18 glycoprotein of HCMV is able to block the cell immune response by two mechanisms. First, UL18 suppresses the ability of TAP, a molecule required for T cell activation, to interact with MHC class I molecules at the cell surface. Second, UL18 together with US6 interferes with the physical association between MHC class I molecules and TAP that is required for optimal peptide loading. Thus, UL18 represents a unique immune evasion protein that has evolved to evade both the NK and the T cell immune responses.

Phylodynamics is a field that seeks to integrate evolutionary and ecological dynamics of rapidly evolving populations like those of RNA viruses. For example, it seeks to predict how rapidly and how widely virus populations spread. In the field, the process of phylodynamics employs population dynamic models, which incorporate past demographic history to make predictions about the future dynamics. Typically, these models are used in isolation, without any regard to how they relate to the particular system under investigation. Here, we present a new method that allows for the use of both genealogical and time series data to inform the parameters that best describe the past dynamics of the populations under study. Our method employs a recently developed method known as particle MCMC to fit mechanistic models for complex population dynamics to gene genealogies and time series data. We show that our method provides accurate estimates of past disease dynamics and key epidemiological parameters from genealogies with or without accompanying time series data.

Oomycetes represent one of the most devastating plant and animal pathogens worldwide, with more than 1. 5 billion members in the world. Control of oomycete pathogens is difficult, especially in the aquaculture industry. In recent years, there has been a surge in research activities aiming at understanding the interactions between the cell wall and the components of the cell wall constituents. The identification of and characterization of the chitin synthases is a challenging task due to their high levels of sequence conservation across species. In this work, we have investigated the function of the chitin synthases from Saprolegnia, a major fish pathogen. Our results show that these chitin synthases are involved in tip growth of Saprolegnia cells. Our results also demonstrate the potential of targeting chitin synthases for the development of anti-oomycete drugs.

Trypanosoma cruzi is the etiologic agent of Chagas cardiomyopathy ( CHC ), a neglected disease affecting approximately 6 million people worldwide. The molecular mechanisms of T. cruzi induced cardiac fibrosis remain to be elucidated. Primary human cardiomyoctes ( PHCM ) exposed to T. cruzi infection were used for transcriptome profiling and downstream bioinformatic analysis to determine fibrotic-associated genes regulated early during infection process ( 0 to 120 minutes ). The identification of early molecular host responses to T. cruzi infection can be exploited to delineate important molecular signatures that can be used for the classification of Chagasic patients at risk of developing heart disease. Our results show that the parasite induces both TGF-β dependent and independent fibrotic pathways, providing an early molecular foundation for Chagasic cardiomyopathy. Examining the very early molecular events of T. cruzi cellular infection may provide disease biomarkers which will aid clinicians in patient assessment and identification of patient subpopulation at risk of developing Chagasic cardiomyopathy.

Rift Valley fever virus ( RVFV ) is a viral disease that can be transmitted to humans or livestock via mosquito bites or direct contact with tissues or fluids from animals. Humans and livestock are exposed to RVFV through direct contact with infectious tissues or fluids, which can vary by different behaviors. We analyzed data from multiple field surveys in Kenya with the aim of associating RVFV infection to raw milk exposures from common animal species. Of those with evidence of previous RVFV infection by serology ( n = 267 ), 77. 2% of those with milking livestock were seronegative and 86. 5% of seropositive individuals consumed raw milk compared to 33. 4% seronegative individuals ( p < 0. 001 ). Individuals who milked and also consumed raw milk had greater odds of RVFV exposure than individuals whose only contact to raw milk was through milking. Increased risks were associated with exposure to milk sourced from cattle, sheep, and goats, but not camels. Our data suggest that exposure to raw milk may contribute to a significant number of cases of RVFV, especially during outbreaks and in endemic areas, and that some animal species may be associated with a higher risk for RVFV exposure.

Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a parasitic disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an insect vector and the disease is fatal if not treated. The standard treatment is pentavalent antimonials ( PAM ), but these are not available in many endemic areas, including East Africa. Paromomycin sulphate ( PM ), which is efficacious in India, is also efficacious in East Africa. Here we report a multi-centre randomized controlled trial comparing efficacy and safety of PM and PM plus sodium stibogluconate ( SSG ) combination treatments for VL in East Africa. Patients aged 4–60 years were enrolled, excluding contraindications. In our study, the PM versus SSG combination was significantly less efficacious than SSG. We also assessed safety using adverse event ( AE ) data. The SSG and PM regimens were similar in efficacy and safety. Our data indicate that the 17 day SSG & PM combination treatment had a good safety profile and was similar in efficacy to the standard 30 day SSG treatment, suggesting suitability for VL treatment in East Africa.

Vaccinia virus, the vaccine used to eradicate smallpox, is a poxvirus that replicates in the nucleus of host cells. In order to synthesize new DNA, the viral polymerase holoenzyme is composed of E9, the DNA polymerase D4, and A20, a protein with no enzymatic activity. The D4/A20 heterodimer is essential for DNA synthesis. Genetic and biochemical data have established that A20 residues located in the N-terminus of D4 are critical for binding to D4. However, the residues of D4 involved in A20 binding are yet to be identified. Here we expressed and purified the complex formed by D4 and A20. We showed that, while D4 forms dimers when expressed alone, D4/A201–50, the D4 dimer subunit, is a heterodimer. The D4/A20 interface ( including residues 167 to 180 and 191 to 206 of D4 ) partially overlaps the previously described D4 dimer interface. The D4/A20 dimer interface is mediated by an α-helical domain with important leucine residues located at the very N-terminal end of A20 and a second stretch of residues containing Trp43 involved in stacking interactions with Arg167 and Pro173 of D4. Interestingly, small molecule inhibitors that interfere with D4/A20 binding could reproduce several key features of the D4/A201–50 interaction. Our data give new insights into the assembly of the poxvirus DNA polymerase cofactor and may be useful for the design and rational improvement of antivirals that target the D4/A20 interface.

Cyclic di-adenosine monophosphate ( c-di-AMP ) is a universally conserved molecule that is essential for survival in diverse bacteria. However, c-di-AMP has been studied almost exclusively in the Bacillus subfamily, a group of bacteria that have been studied for decades. Despite this, we have characterized the molecular mechanism of c-di-AMP synthesis and its role in survival of darkness in the model photosynthetic cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus PCC 7942. The results demonstrate that c-di-AMP is produced by an enzyme of the diadenylate cyclase family, CdaA, which was previously unexplored experimentally. We also developed a high-throughput genetic interaction screen to determine pathways where the signaling nucleotide is active. We found that c-di-AMP is produced by an enzyme of the diadenylate cyclase family, CdaA, which was not previously known to function in the context of c-di-AMP. The cdaA-null mutant experiences increased oxidative stress and death during the nighttime portion of day-night cycles, which suggests that c-di-AMP is biologically active in cyanobacteria.

Japanese encephalitis virus ( JEV ) is a flavivirus causing encephalitis and a life-threatening neuroinvasive infection in humans. β-oxidation breaks down fatty acids for ATP production in mitochondria, and impaired β-oxidation can induce pro-inflammatory cytokine expression. In this study, we found that JEV nonstructural protein 5 ( NS5 ) interacted with mitochondrial cofactor α and β subunits, two components of the mitochondrial trifunctional protein ( MTP ) involved in β-oxidation. Inhibition of LCFA β-oxidation and induction of pro-inflammatory cytokine expression by NS5 protein association with MTP. Moreover, mice challenged with JEV with NS5-M19A showed less neurovirulence and neuroinvasiveness. Our findings demonstrated a novel function of JEV NS5 in viral pathogenesis by impairing LCFA β-oxidation and inducing cytokine expression by association with MTP.

Influenza A virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans and animals. Vaccination is the most effective method of protection against influenza A virus infection and is the only available vaccine. However, the number and efficacy of influenza A virus-specific antibodies generated by vaccination is very low. Recent advances in influenza A virus vaccine design have resulted in the production of highly immunogenic, broadly neutralizing antibodies. Recently, the influenza hemagglutinin ( HA ) glycoprotein has been shown to be a major determinant of neutralizing antibody production, as well as the efficiency of these antibodies at stimulating B cells. Here, we show that the hemagglutinin ( HA ) gene is highly conserved among all influenza A virus isolates, and that a relatively small number of amino acid substitutions can suffice to trigger highly potent neutralizing antibody production. These results indicate that HA proteins are promising vaccine antigens. However, the mechanism of antigen recognition by B cells is less understood. Using a combination of structural and biochemical approaches, we show that the HA protein can utilize multiple amino acid substitutions to elicit potent neutralizing antibody production. Our findings have important implications for influenza A virus vaccine design, and may provide important insights for the development of future influenza A virus vaccines.

Species are defined by their ecological adaptations and diversity. Species that have a large range of ecological adaptations can be found in very different ecological niches, ranging from the tropical rainforests to temperate and boreal forests. Species that have small ecological adaptations are the most species-rich, and they comprise an extremely diverse group of organisms. The reason why some lineages diversify more rapidly than others is poorly understood. We show that variation in seed size and the rate at which these species evolve are strongly correlated with variation in speciation rates. This suggests that rapid change in seed size and morphology may contribute to the ecological adaptations that species have evolved.

Chagas' heart disease is the most important infectious cause of cardiac disease in Latin America. It is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi ( T. cruzi ), a parasite that replicates inside the heart of the insect vector, the vector of the disease. Patients with chronic Chagas' heart disease have high levels of antibodies against the carboxyl-terminal end of the ribosomal protein P2ß ( a protein that is translated into the ribosome ). These antibodies, as well as the murine monoclonal antibody ( mAb ) 17. 2, recognize the last 13 amino acids of TcP2ß ( called the R13 epitope: EEEDDDMGFGLFD ) and are able to cross-react with, and stimulate, the ß1 adrenergic receptor ( ß1-AR ). Indeed, the mAb 17. 2 was able to specifically detect human β1-AR, stably transfected into HEK cells, by flow cytometry and to induce repolarisation abnormalities and first degree atrioventricular conduction block after passive transfer to naïve mice. Our crystal structure of the Fab region of the mAb 17. 2 alone and in complex with the R13 peptide provides an understanding of the molecular basis of cross-reactive antibodies induced by chronic infection with T. cruzi.

Lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) is a disabling and deforming chronic infection that affects the limbs and scrotum. It is caused by infection with filarial parasites and transmitted by mosquitoes. LF is a major cause of morbidity in many tropical countries, including Papua New Guinea. Mass drug administration is currently the only available method for controlling LF, and it is expected that this and other interventions will be feasible in the future as a long-term solution to this infection. Here, we examine the impact of mass drug administration on the morbidity of acute filariasis in people living in Papua New Guinea. We show that mass drug administration reduces acute morbidity by 92% in people with acute filariasis morbidity. This reduction in morbidity correlates with a decrease in transmission intensity in people with acute filariasis infection, suggesting that acute infections may be a component of the pathogenesis of acute filariasis morbidity.

The sst1 gene has previously been shown to be a genetic determinant of host resistance to infection with the intracellular pathogen, Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Chlamydia pneumoniae is a highly adapted obligate intracellular bacterium that can be transmitted from one cell to another and the majority of the human population. Although C. pneumoniae can be recovered from patients with chronic infection, infection frequently occurs with asymptomatic or mild symptoms. Here we examined the role of the sst1 locus in the host response to infection with C. pneumoniae. We found that although mice carrying the sst1 susceptible ( sst1S ) locus were not impaired in their ability to clear the acute infection, they were dramatically more tolerant of the induced immune response. This was due, at least in part, to increased production of type I interferon ( IFN ) pathway cytokines, which were induced by infection. We also observed that macrophages from sst1S mice were unable to support normal chlamydial growth, resulting in arrested development and failure of the organism to complete its infectious cycle. We conclude that the sst1 locus regulates a shared macrophage-mediated innate defense mechanism against diverse intracellular bacterial pathogens.

Plants are able to regulate floral development through the expression of key transcription factors and microRNAs. However, the mechanisms underlying the coordination of these two pathways are still poorly understood. In this study, we identified a novel role for a SANT-domain-containing protein, POWERDRESS ( PWR ), in the transcription of three of the five MIR172 members and the expression of the miR172 gene family, which are co-regulated. We also demonstrated that PWR is required for the transcription of the floral stem cell network. The findings provide new insight into the regulatory network of floral development.

A single founder virus in the blood of the donor, or multiple viruses in the body, can cause infection with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ). The virus that causes infection in the body is usually present in the vaginal tract. In rare cases, the virus may be transmitted to the cervix, which can lead to infection in the cervix and the mucosa of the vagina. We recruited women from Uganda and Zimbabwe within seven months of HIV-1 infection to study the genetic diversity of HIV-1 in the vaginal tract. We then compared the genetic diversity of HIV-1 in the blood, cervix, and vagina at three and seven months of infection. We found that early HIV-1 isolates in the blood are more diverse than those in the vaginal tract. We also found that the genetic diversity of HIV-1 in the blood is similar to that of HIV-1 in the vaginal tract. These results suggest that mucosal immunity may play a role in the development of HIV-1 infection.

In this study, we determined the clinical as well as laboratory factors and outcome of children with Shigella encephalopathy. We identified that the patients had shorter duration ( 1. 2 ± 0. 4 day ) of diarrhea prior to admission, dehydrating diarrhea, sepsis and hyponatremia ( p = 0. 05 for all ). The case-fatality rate was significantly higher among the children with Shigella encephalopathy compared to those without encephalopathy. Early identification and aggressive management of simple risk factors for Shigella encephalopathy may help to reduce morbidity and deaths in such children especially in resource-limited settings.

Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania. Leishmania infantum is the most prevalent species causing human visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) in Europe. It is endemic in most Southern European countries where the disease has been reported in the past and in the present, as well as in other Southern European countries. In France, the disease has been reported from the south of France, in the Pyrénethylene-Orientales ( Cévennes ) and in the Mediterranean coast ( Provence ). In the present study, 270 L. infantum strains were analysed from 1978 to 2011 from the four endemic areas of France, the two cities of Nice ( AM ) and Marseille ( P ), the two Mediterranean coast ( MCL ) and the Corsica ( CO ) province. We found a strong genetic differentiation between the Leishmania populations from AM and P. However, exchanges were observed between these two endemic areas in which it seems that strains spread from AM to P. Our results shed light on the transmission dynamics of parasites in humans.

A fundamental question in biology concerns the mechanisms that control the cellular state of a cell, a process known as cell differentiation. The molecular mechanisms of cell differentiation are often thought to involve gene transcriptional regulation. Differentiation can also be triggered by repressors, proteins that are recruited to the chromosome. How these regulators influence cell differentiation, however, remains largely unclear. In this work, we have investigated the role of chromatin-based epigenetic effects in controlling the expression of a single gene and the expression of a set of genes. Our experiments confirm that recruitment of repressor and activator proteins permits a plastic form of control; the stability of gene expression is determined by the spatial distribution of nucleation sites along the chromosome. The unveiled regulatory principles will help to understand the mechanisms of cell differentiation and to design synthetic genetic networks that combine transcriptional regulatory motifs and chromatin-based epigenetic effects.

Typhoid fever ( TF ), caused by the bacterium Salmonella Typhi, is a life-threatening disease, particularly in young children, elderly patients, and immunocompromised individuals. In recent years, resistance to antibiotics has increased and treatment of TF has become challenging. Recently, a single-drug therapy has been shown to be effective in treating the disease in both hospital settings and community settings. In this study, we have evaluated the efficacy of combining a third-generation cephalosporin ( Cen ) and azithromycin ( Aza ) for FCT treatment in patients living in an endemic region. Patients were divided based on the results of blood culture analysis and treated according to a single- or a combined-therapy regimen. The study showed that FCT and the secondary outcome of treatment was significantly shorter for the latter, and this effect was exhibited in both the hospitalized and the outpatient sub-groups. Repeat blood cultures, drawn on day 3, were positive for 17% of the patients after monotherapy, versus 2/51 ( 4% ) after combination therapy ( p = 0·045 ). No severe complications or fatalities occurred in any of the groups. Combined therapy of third-generation cephalosporins and azithromycin for TF may surpass monotherapy in terms of FCT and time to elimination of bacteremia.

In order to carry out their functions, most cells are organized in three-dimensional structures such as sarcomeric Z-lines or actin filaments. In order to maintain tissue integrity, the orientation of these structures is maintained by a set of molecular and cellular cues. To date there are no available metrics to quantify the correlation of orientation of these two types of cellular structures. We have developed the co-orientationational order parameter ( COOP ), which was based on the mathematical framework of a classical parameter, the orientational order parameter ( OOP ). Theorems were proven to prove to be useful for quantifying the correlation of orientation of constructs such as actin filaments and sarcomeric Z-lines. We showed the COOP to be useful for quantifying the consistency of construct orientation within cells of the same shape. The COOP provides a quantitative tool to characterize tissues beyond co-localization or single construct orientation distribution. In the future, this new parameter could be used to represent the quantitative changes during maturation of cardiac tissue, pathological malformation, and other processes.

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the developing world. The mosquito Anopheles coluzzii, a competent vector of human malaria in West Africa, is expanding its range and habitat as a result of anthropological activities promoting exposure to human pathogens. Here, we used the genetic variation of two sister species, A. gambiae and A. coluzzii, to design a screen for genes involved in immune response. We found evidence that genes that show patterns of genetic variation characteristic of natural selection can be used to predict immune function. We also used this screen to identify new genes involved in immune response, and used the information to assign new functions to known factors. Our results suggest that adaptation of A. coluzzii to new pathogens may have involved the evolution of new immune responses. We also found that most immune genes with characteristics similar to those of natural selection do not protect against human malaria, suggesting that additional mechanisms are required to protect against this disease.

HIV-1 causes an estimated 25 million deaths per year worldwide, and no effective vaccine exists to protect against the infection. An improved understanding of the mechanism of HIV-1 infection and development is crucial for the development of an effective vaccine. As a first step towards this, a range of HIV-1 subtypes have been evaluated in the context of spike mimetics and novel vaccine candidates. We found that the well-structured, stable form of the spike mimetic antigen is more stable than the uncleaved, covalently linked form. We also found that the stability of the uncleaved form is more important in eliciting neutralizing antibodies than the stable form. We also observed that the stable form of the spike mimetic antigen is more resistant to unfolding at temperatures of 37°C and 60°C. Our results provide important insights into the design of novel HIV-1 vaccines and the role of stability in eliciting neutralizing antibodies.

Mass spectrometry ( MS ) is the most widely used approach to characterize the structure of small molecules. The number of available mass spectrometry datasets is huge, and the number of published results grows exponentially with the number of data molecules. The increasing amount of data has resulted in a growing demand for efficient methods to analyze and annotate the results of these experiments. We show how the use of in silico predictions to improve the accuracy of predictions and the consistency of predictions with experimental data can be done. In this work, we present a novel method for using the structure of a small molecule as a reference to improve the predictions of in silico predictions.

The bunyaviruses are the largest family of arboviruses worldwide and include important human pathogens such as the causes of dengue fever and hemorrhagic fever viruses. New World hantaviruses, such as Andes virus, are emerging as a significant cause of human morbidity and mortality and represent a major public health concern in the Americas. Despite the need for therapeutics, there are currently no licensed vaccines or drugs available to protect humans from infection. Our work has identified components of the sterol regulatory pathway as critical for infection by Andes virus. These results suggest that drugs targeting sterol regulatory components may prove to be useful for controlling and treating Andes virus infection.

The relationship between two individuals is an essential problem in genetics. The resolution of this relationship depends on the number of markers that are assayed and the length of the chromosomes that each of the individuals is bound to the same marker. The relationship between two individuals can be determined either by identifying the region of the genome that contains the markers, or by determining the extent of polymorphisms in the region. Whole-genome sequencing ( WGS ) has the potential to enable both approaches. However, WGS introduces new complexities that must be addressed in order to achieve relationship detection. In this study, we estimated the relationship between 258 individuals from WGS data and compared it with existing approaches. We found that WGS data could be used to identify genomic regions with substantial SNP heterogeneity that may lead to false-positive relationships among controls. We then developed a new method to identify and mask genomic regions with excess SNP heterogeneity. Our results show that WGS data provides a 5% to 15% increase in relationship detection power relative to high-density microarray data for distant relationships. Our results also indicate that WGS may be useful for detecting 1st and 2nd degree relationships.

Yellow fever is a vector-borne disease endemic in tropical regions of Africa, where 90% of the global burden occurs. It is notoriously under-reported with uncertainty arising from a complex transmission cycle including a sylvatic reservoir and non-specific symptom set. We investigate the most likely transmission routes in Africa by comparing two established models of transmission within a Bayesian model averaging framework. Our models assume contrasting scenarios of the yellow fever transmission cycle in Africa. One takes the force of infection in each province to be static across the observation period; this is synonymous with a constant infection pressure from the sylvatic reservoir. The other model assumes the majority of transmission results from the urban cycle; in this case, the force of infection is dynamic and defined through a fixed value of R0 in each province. We compare these contrasting descriptions of transmission through a Bayesian framework and trans-dimensional Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling in order to assess each model’s evidence given the range of uncertainty in parameter values. Our results show strong support for the static model which suggests a higher proportion of yellow fever transmission occurs as a result of infection from an external source such as the sylvatic reservoir. However, the model comparison highlights key data gaps in serological surveys across the African endemic region. Our approach provides a robust framework for model comparison and predicting yellow fever burden in Africa.

Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli ( EAEC ) is a leading cause of acute and persistent diarrhea worldwide. A recently emerged Shiga-toxin-producing strain of EAEC resulted in significant mortality and morbidity due to progressive development of hemolytic-uremic syndrome. The attachment of EAEC to the human intestinal mucosa is mediated by a highly conserved proteinaceous complex, the Aggregative Adherence Fimbriae ( AAF ). Using X-ray crystallography and NMR structures, we present atomic resolution insight into the structure of AAF variant I, and propose a mechanism for AAF-mediated adhesion and biofilm formation. Our work shows that AAF subunits recognize a common receptor, fibronectin, by employing clusters of basic residues in the pilus. Binding experiments using wild type and mutant subunits ( NMR and SPR ) and bacteria ( ELISA ) revealed that AAF-fibronectin attachment is based primarily on electrostatic interactions, a mechanism not reported previously for bacterial adhesion to biotic surfaces.

Influenza A virus remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In recent years, the emergence of oseltamivir-resistant influenza viruses has caused outbreaks with high morbidity and mortality. There are no approved neuraminidase ( NA ) inhibitors to treat influenza. Recently, a new neuraminidase inhibitor, R-125489, and its prodrug, CS-8958, have been developed. Here, we demonstrate that R-125489 is highly efficacious against seasonal influenza viruses, including oseltamivir-resistant and different clade strains. A single dose of CS-8958 given to mice 2 h post-infection with H5N1 influenza viruses produced a higher survival rate than did the five-day course of oseltamivir. In addition, we demonstrated that CS-8958 was highly efficacious against highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus and oseltamivir-resistant variants. Our results indicate that CS-8958 is highly effective for the treatment and prophylaxis of infection with H5N1 influenza viruses.

Cooperation is a ubiquitous behavior in nature, which often relies on individuals to benefit others at a personal cost. This dilemma can also arise in spatially structured populations, where individuals typically have low mobility and limited dispersal. While assortment is a well-known phenomenon in these populations, it is unknown how individuals acquire cooperation. Here we employ a spatially-explicit evolutionary simulation to investigate the consequences of different mechanisms of mobility on the evolution of cooperation. We find that, despite lacking information about others’ traits or payoffs, individuals with higher cooperative tendencies are more mobile, which facilitates the evolution of cooperation. In particular, the combination of different mechanisms for assortment can overcome selection against cooperators within groups, and results in an oscillatory pattern of cooperation and defection that maintains cooperation even in the absence of well known mechanisms such as kin interactions, reciprocity, local dispersal or conditional strategies that require information on others’ strategies or payoffs. Our results offer insights into differential adhesion mechanisms and the possibility of cooperation in spatially structured populations.

Cyclic AMP is a second messenger that augments glucose-induced insulin secretion. However, its downstream targets in pancreatic β-cells have not been unequivocally determined. In this work, we design cAMP analogues as Epac2-selective agonists. These analogues activate Epac2 about two orders of magnitude more potently than cAMP. The high potency arises from increased affinity and activation. Crystallographic studies demonstrate that this is due to unique interactions. At least one of the Epac2-specific agonists, Sp-8-BnT-cAMPS ( S-220 ), enhances glucose-induced insulin secretion in human pancreatic cells. Selective targeting of Epac2 is thus proven possible and may be an option in diabetes treatment.

A collection of predictions from computational methods can be used to guide experimental investigations. However, validation of these predictions is difficult, as we often lack sufficient information to make reliable predictions. Here we present the results of an extensive experimental comparison of predictions from three different computational approaches. We show that the predictions are broadly applicable, and that the diversity of approaches greatly influences the biological scope and breadth of the predictions. Our results also highlight that, while the predictions are largely consistent across methods, they can be strongly influenced by the genomic background. We also show that the results can be used to guide experimental investigations, and that the analysis techniques can be used to reliably compare predictions from different computational approaches.

Circadian clocks are a fundamental component of the cell-autonomous circadian clock system that drives daily oscillations in behavior and physiology in anticipation of daily environmental change. We developed a new approach termed Gene Dosage Network Analysis ( GDNA ) to systematically analyze the circadian clock network in the presence of genetic perturbations. We systematically depleted known clock components and observed that circadian oscillations are maintained over a wide range of disruptions. We also developed a novel strategy termed siRNA–based gene association analysis ( GWA ) that used small interfering RNA ( siRNA ) –induced changes in gene expression to construct gene association networks consistent with known biochemical constraints. Our results uncover several novel network features of the circadian clock, including proportional responses and signal propagation through interacting genetic modules. We also observed several examples where a gene is up-regulated following knockdown of its paralog, suggesting the clock network utilizes active compensatory mechanisms rather than simple redundancy to confer robustness and maintain function. Our results suggest that these network features act in concert as a genetic buffering system to maintain clock function in the face of genetic and environmental perturbation.

African tsetse flies transmit a variety of diseases, including dengue, Rift Valley fever, and malaria, which are the most important vector-borne diseases in the world. Control of these diseases is currently based on vector control programs targeting the mosquito vector, but there is an urgent need for new approaches to vector control. Identifying the mosquito species that feed on a given host plant is an important step toward understanding vector biology. This study has identified that two mosquito species, Aedes aegypti and Aedes mcintoshi, feed on the same plant, but that only one of them, Ae. aegypti, is capable of feeding on multiple plant species. We also identified that these mosquito species use different chemical signals to locate host plants. These results provide valuable information for designing vector control strategies that rely on the plant–plant interaction.

Eukaryotic cells have developed a variety of systems to protect them from invading pathogens. In mammals, a group of proteins called Rho GTPases inactivate immune signaling molecules and thereby allow bacteria to survive. These proteins are also used by eukaryotic cells to inactivate other proteins involved in immune responses. Some bacterial pathogens use RhoGAP toxins to inactivate immune signaling molecules and target the same immune pathways as eukaryotes. However, other pathogens use a different class of RhoGAP proteins, e. g., the ones that protect the insect egg against the immune response. We demonstrate that eukaryotic parasites, and their wasp parasitic relatives, can use RhoGAPs as virulence factors to target the same immune pathways as eukaryotes. The eukaryotic RhoGAPs act similarly to bacterial toxins, and both share common structural features. Our results suggest that endogenous RhoGAPs may be a general strategy used by both eukaryotes and bacteria to manipulate mammalian cells.

Strongyloidiasis is a zoonotic disease that is caused by the human infective nematodes Strongyloides stercoralis, Strongyloides fuelleborni subsp. fuelleborni and Strongyloides fuelleborni subsp. kellyi. The zoonotic potential of S. stercoralis and the potential role of dogs in the maintenance of strongyloidiasis transmission has been a topic of interest and discussion for many years. We performed a survey of Strongyloides genotypes in Australian populations of dogs and humans, using molecular techniques. We identified S. stercoralis and S. fuelleborni genotypes in Australian faeces, Australian sputum, and a human sputum sample. These loci were amplified from DNA extracted from Australian human faeces, and one human sputum sample. Our results confirm for the first time that potentially zoonotic S. stercoralis populations are present in Australia, suggesting that dogs represent a potential reservoir of human strongyloidiasis in remote Australian communities.

The myelin sheath is the insulating sheath that surrounds axons and prevents demelination, which is a major cause of peripheral neuropathy. The myelin sheath is a composite of two membranes that surround axons, one from the myelin sheath and one from the axonal membrane. It is a very tight seal that prevents demelination by myelin junctions. This myelin seal is also required to fasten the action potential propagation in the nervous system. In the present study, we have demonstrated the disruption of myelin junctions in a mouse model of hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies ( HNPP ). We observed that the myelin junctions were disrupted in the absence of demyelination, which was present long before the demyelination was completed. Moreover, we observed that the increase of F-actin levels correlated with an enhanced activity of p21-activated kinase, which is known to regulate actin polymerization. Pharmacological inhibition of PAK prevented the progression of the myelin junction disruption and nerve conduction failure in HNPP mice. Our results provide a novel mechanism upstream to the actual stripping of myelin that is responsible for impaired action potential propagation in the absence of demyelination.

Brain development requires the elaborate extension and branching of dendritic processes, which require secretory trafficking through the Golgi apparatus. The mechanisms that govern Golgi function in neuronal development in the brain have remained largely unexplored. In this study, we have uncovered that the E3 ubiquitin ligase Cul7Fbxw8 regulates Golgi morphogenesis and dendrite elaboration. We also show that the cytoskeletal adaptor protein OBSL1 is required for Cul7Fbxw8 to function in Golgi morphogenesis and for the elaboration of dendrites. Finally, we demonstrate that the Golgi protein Grasp65 is a novel substrate of Cul7Fbxw8 in the control of Golgi and dendrite morphogenesis in neurons. Collectively, these findings define a novel OBSL1-regulated Cul7Fbxw8 ubiquitin signaling mechanism that orchestrates the morphogenesis of the Golgi apparatus and patterning of dendrites, with fundamental implications for our understanding of brain development.

Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ), a vector-borne disease, is an important public health problem, especially in Brazil. It is a disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania, a complex of 12 species, and it can affect the poorest populations in the world, including rural workers. In the past, the urbanization of VL and the concurrent movement of the HIV infection to rural areas in Brazil are possible mechanisms associated with an increased number of Leishmania/HIV coinfected people. This study aimed to describe the clinical and epidemiological profile of VL/HIV coinfected patients and compare this profile to non-coinfected VL patients. We retrieved 760 cases of VL/HIV coinfection, most prevalent in adult males, and incidence ranged from 0. 01 to 0. 07 cases per 100. 000 population. Case-fatality rates were 27. 3% in 2001 and 23. 2% in 2010. The results found herein contribute to the increase of knowledge of the epidemiological situation of VL/HIV coinfection in Brazil and reinforce the necessity of implementing specific strategies to improve early case detection and efficacious and less toxic treatment in order to achieve lower case-fatality rates.

Transposable elements ( TEs ) are selfish sequences that are capable of copying themselves into host genomes. These selfish mobile elements have been shown to cause genomic instability, genome degeneration, and even death. Organisms have evolved mechanisms to silence TEs, either by modifying the host genome or by making copies of host genes that prevent TEs from copying themselves into host genomes. The piwi-interacting RNA ( piRNA ) pathway, which evolved to protect the germline of animals from selfish transposons, has recently been shown to also function as a mechanism to silence TEs in the germline. However, we find that the piRNA pathway of Drosophila melanogaster is also capable of derepressing TEs from both maternally and paternally inherited copies, and that these two types of TEs are not functionally distinct.
