Rather, the piRNA pathway of D. melanogaster appears to be a functionally more complex pathway, with many genes involved in TE regulation. Therefore, the piRNA pathway of D. melanogaster appears to have evolved to protect the germline of a wide variety of animals from selfish transposons.

Hepatitis B virus ( HBV ) is a major risk factor for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma, a highly prevalent and highly lethal liver cancer. HBV replicates from a covalently closed circular DNA ( cccDNA ) that remains as an episome within the nucleus of infected cells and serves as a template for the transcription of HBV RNAs. The regulatory protein HBx has been shown to be essential for cccDNA transcription in the context of infection. Here we identified Spindlin1, a cellular Tudor-domain protein, as an HBx interacting partner. We further demonstrated that Spindlin1 is recruited to the cccDNA and inhibits its transcription in the context of infection. Knockdown of Spindlin1 induced an increase in HBV transcription and in histone H4K4 trimethylation at the cccDNA, suggesting that Spindlin1 impacts on epigenetic regulation. Spindlin1-induced transcriptional inhibition was greater for the HBV virus deficient for the expression of HBx than for the HBV WT virus, suggesting that HBx counteracts Spindlin1 repression. Importantly, we showed that the repressive role of Spindlin1 is not limited to HBV transcription but also extends to other DNA virus that replicate within the nucleus such as Herpes Simplex Virus type 1 ( HSV-1 ). Taken together our results identify Spindlin1 as a critical component of the intrinsic antiviral defense against incoming HBV and HSV-1, and shed new light on the function of HBx in HBV infection.

The ability to interpret daily and seasonal alterations in light and temperature signals is essential for plant survival. Photoreceptors activate photosynthetic pigment production when light is detected. Phytochromes accomplish this by the negative effects of light and temperature on chlorophyll biosynthesis. While the bZIP transcription factorLONG HYPOCOTYL 5 ( HY5 ), a potent PIF antagonist, regulates photosynthetic pigment accumulation in response to light, here we demonstrate that it can also direct transcriptional control of genes involved in photosynthesis and photoprotection. HY5 and the bZIP transcription factor PIFs form a dynamic regulatory module that is responsive to light and temperature cues. HY5 and PIFs do not operate alone, but with the circadian clock. However, sudden changes in light or temperature conditions can trigger changes in HY5 and PIFs abundance that adjust the expression of common target genes to optimise photosynthetic performance and growth.

HIV infected individuals who are receiving antiretroviral therapy ( ART ) have a heightened sensitivity to opportunistic infections. In fact, these individuals are more vulnerable to death from an opportunistic pathogen than HIV infected individuals who do not receive the therapy. Here we have identified two mutations within the HIV protease that result in enhanced susceptibility to cell death. These mutations alter the ability of the HIV protease to cleave the cell death machinery of the cell. We have also identified that these mutations also result in impaired induction of T cell cell death. These data demonstrate that while HIV replication is unaffected by the mutations in HIV protease, cell death is significantly reduced in patients with these mutations. This suggests that the clinical impact of these mutations in HIV infected patients may be the result of the virus adapting to survive in the presence of these mutations.

Fisheries are a major sector in many developing countries, but managing them effectively is a challenge. As a result, several initiatives have sought to improve management and prevent overexploitation, while helping to maintain biodiversity and a sustainable food supply. Although these initiatives have received broad acceptance, the extent to which corrective measures have been implemented and are effective remains largely unknown. Using surveys to assess the current effectiveness of fisheries management regimes, we also calculated the probable sustainability of reported catches to determine how management affects fisheries sustainability. Our survey shows that 7% of all coastal states undergo rigorous scientific assessment for the generation of management policies, 1. 4% also have a transparent and participatory process to convert scientific recommendations into policy, and 0. 95% also provide for robust mechanisms to ensure the compliance with regulations. None is also free of the effects of excess fishing capacity, subsidies, or access to foreign fishing. We also compared fisheries management attributes with the sustainability of reported fisheries catches and found that the conversion of scientific advice into policy, through a transparent and participatory process, is at the core of achieving fisheries sustainability, regardless of other attributes of the fisheries.

Muscles consist of a highly organized system of sarcomeres, each containing a bundle of myosin filaments and a bundle of actin filaments. Myosin filaments are responsible for muscle contraction and myosin motor proteins are responsible for muscle relaxation. Myosin filaments are assembled from immature sarcomeres, which must be linked to each other by titin filaments to form long chains. While the order of myosin filaments within each sarcomere is known, it is difficult to determine the order of myosin filaments within muscle cells. Here, we used polarization-resolved microscopy to analyze myosin filaments during myofibril formation in vivo. We show that myosin motor activity is important for the assembly of myosin filaments to the order of sarcomeres. Myosin filaments also increase in myofibrils to a high myosin order, which is a key feature of muscle. These results suggest that myosin motor activity is important for maintaining the order of myosin filaments during muscle development.

Host–pathogen coevolution is widely observed in nature, yet its underlying genetic mechanisms and associated trait functions are largely unknown. We show that the selective benefit of virulence and the underlying toxin genes during the adaptation process is unique to host–pathogen coevolution. We show that high virulence in the Bacillus thuringiensis–Caenorhabditis elegans–infected host populations is specifically favoured during pathogen–host coevolution rather than pathogen one-sided adaptation. Furthermore, high virulence in the BT-679–dominated populations was correlated with elevated copy numbers of the plasmid containing the nematocidal toxin genes. The nematocidal toxin genes were also reconstituted by genetic reintroduction and external addition of the toxins. Our results show that sustained coevolution is distinct from unidirectional selection in shaping the pathogen's genome and life history characteristics. This is the first animal host–pathogen coevolutionary adaptation to a nematode host.

Microsporidia are a class of microorganism that invade and replicate inside host cells. They are known to cause severe disease in humans, animals and animals, and are also regarded as bioterrorism agents. In order to replicate inside host cells, microsporidia utilize a specialized organelle, the polar tube, to deliver their genetic information into the cell nucleus. These organelles are unique, they are small, and they are difficult to study. To better understand the mechanism of microsporidian infection, we have identified a protein that is important for the formation of the polar tube. This protein, which we have called PTP4, is able to bind to host cell membranes and is present in the cell membranes of all cells. Blocking PTP4 function reduces microsporidian infection of host cells. These results indicate that PTP4 is important for the function of the polar tube and that it is an important target for anti-microsporidian drug development.

The presence of multiple copies of the same gene on different chromosomes ( a phenomenon called hybrid inviability ) is a major cause of human disease. In Drosophila hybrids, which have only one X chromosome, it is known that genes causing hybrid inviability have deleterious effects on male and female hybrid fitness. In this study, we have studied the effects of a small panel of small fragments of the D. melanogaster X-chromosome on hybrid viability in three kinds of hybrid males. D. melanogaster and D. santomea are the two most divergent groups of D. melanogaster, while D. melanogaster and D. mauritiana are the two most divergent groups of D. melanogaster. We find that the X-chromosome from D. melanogaster carries dominant alleles that are lethal in hybrids, and more of these alleles are revealed in the most divergent cross. Our results reveal the existence of dominant alleles on the X-chromosome of D. melanogaster that cause lethality in three different interspecific hybrids. These alleles only cause inviability in hybrid males, yet have little effect in hybrid females. Our results suggest that X-linked elements that cause hybrid inviability in males might not do so in hybrid females due to differing sex chromosome interactions.

Prostate cancer is the most common cancer diagnosed in men worldwide. It is estimated that 27. 6% of the world population is infected with the bacterium Helicobacter pylori. However, only 15% of the infected people progress to develop the most common cancer, prostate cancer. SAM-pointed domain-containing ETS transcription factor ( SPDEF ) is expressed in normal prostate epithelium and is required for the progression of prostate cancer in vivo. SPDEF is known to function as a tumor suppressor. In the present study, we generated transgenic mice with the loss- or gain-of-function of SPDEF in prostate epithelium to demonstrate that SPDEF functions as tumor suppressor in prostate cancer. Over-expression of SPDEF in prostate epithelium inhibited the progression of the cells and reduced their proliferation. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the crosstalk between SPDEF and Foxm1, a transcription factor critical for tumor cell proliferation, was required for the progression of prostate cancer in vivo. We also demonstrated that Foxm1 over-expression repressed the cellular proliferation of prostate tumor cells. Altogether, our study has identified novel crosstalk between SPDEF and Foxm1 and demonstrated that this crosstalk is required for the progression of prostate cancer in vivo.

The pterosaur dinosaurs were once thought to be extinct but a new pterosaur species was discovered in Australia, Australia II, which appears to have been previously overlooked. Other pterosaur species are now known to have been extinct but the question of whether they were really dead or whether they were just a dead end has remained controversial. Several pterosaur species are used as a method to draw conclusions about the living world from fossils and other skeletal and biological data. Using physical and mathematical models of Rynchops, a pterosaur species that is extinct, and a mathematical model of the Rynchops' bones and wings, we show that skimming is considerably more energetically costly than previously thought and that pterosaur species that have been suggested to be extinct were not always the skimming bird. Our results illustrate the pitfalls involved in extrapolating from limited morphological convergence.

Genome-wide gene expression profiling has been used for many years to generate biological hypotheses based on differential expression levels. Recently, microarrays have been used for genetic association mapping, a study referred to as expression QTL ( eQTL ) mapping. This study used this approach to analyze gene expression data from 28 inbred mouse strains. We focused on “trans-eQTL bands”, defined as instances in which the expression patterns of many genes were all associated to a common genetic locus. Genes comprising trans-eQTL bands were screened for enriched functional gene sets representing known biological pathways, and genes located at associated trans-eQTL band loci were considered candidate transcriptional modulators. We demonstrate that these patterns were enriched for known relationships between known upstream transcriptional regulators and their downstream target genes. Moreover, we used this approach to identify both novel regulators and novel members of known pathways. Finally, based on a putative regulatory relationship identified in our analysis, we identified and validated a novel role for cyclin H in the regulation of oxidative phosphorylation. We believe that the specific molecular hypotheses generated in this study will reveal many additional pathway members and regulators, and that the analysis approaches described herein will be broadly applicable to other eQTL data sets.

The highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus subtype H5N1 continues to emerge in both humans and animals. Since 2009, Egypt has unexpectedly had the highest number of human cases of H5N1 virus infection, with more than 50% of the total human cases, but the basis for this high incidence has not been elucidated. A change in receptor binding affinity of the viral hemagglutinin ( HA ) from α2, 3- to α2, 6-linked sialic acid ( SA ) is thought to be necessary for H5N1 virus to become pandemic. In this study, we conducted a phylogenetic analysis of H5N1 viruses isolated between 2006 and 2009 in Egypt. The results showed that recent human isolates clustered into several new H5 sublineages suggesting that their HAs have changed their receptor specificity. Using reverse genetics, we found that these H5 sublineages have acquired an enhanced binding affinity for α2, 6 SA in combination with residual affinity for α2, 3 SA, and identified the amino acid mutations that produced this new receptor specificity. These findings correlated with enhanced virulence of the mutant viruses in mice. Interestingly, these H5 viruses, with increased binding to α2, 6 SA, emerged during viral diversification in bird populations and subsequently spread to humans. Our findings suggested that emergence of new H5 sublineages with α2, 6 SA specificity caused a subsequent increase in human H5N1 influenza virus infections in Egypt, and provided data for understanding the virus's pandemic potential.

Leprosy is a neglected infectious disease that still causes severe disabilities and deformities. It is caused by Mycobacterium leprae, an obligate intracellular bacterium that infects humans. Ticks are known to be important vectors of the disease, transmitting Mycobacterium leprae from one individual to another. In this study, we developed a cell culture system to grow M. leprae and to transform it into an infectious bacillus. We found that ticks were able to support the growth of the bacteria and that this process was dependent on tick cell lines. These results suggest that ticks may be a reservoir for the transmission of this infectious agent and that they may be used to produce infectious bacteria.

In this study, we investigated the transcriptional regulation of carbohydrate metabolism in the human fungal pathogen Candida albicans. We found that two transcription factors, Tye7p and Gal4p, are important for the metabolism of C. albicans. Under hypoxic growth conditions, these factors are required for the induction of carbohydrate metabolism and the expression of genes involved in carbohydrate metabolism. We also found that Tye7p and Gal4p control unique carbohydrate metabolic genes. This suggests that Tye7p represents the key transcriptional regulator of carbohydrate metabolism in C. albicans and that the metabolic flux between respiration and fermentation pathways is regulated by these factors.

Tissue morphogenesis critically depends on the coordination of cellular growth patterns. In plants, many organs are composed of clonally distinct cell layers, such as the epidermis. The developmental control of such planar growth is poorly understood. Here we report the identification of the Arabidopsis AGC protein kinase UNICORN ( UCN ) as a central regulator of this process. Plants lacking UCN activity show spontaneous formation of ectopic multicellular protrusions in integuments and malformed petals indicating that UCN suppresses uncontrolled growth in those tissues. In the current model UCN regulates planar growth of integuments in part by directly repressing the putative transcription factor ABERRANT TESTA SHAPE (ATS ). Here we identify 3-PHOSPHOINOSITIDE-DEPENDENT PROTEIN KINASE 1 ( PDK1 ) as a novel factor involved in UCN-mediated growth control. Furthermore, our data indicate that PDK1 is an evolutionarily conserved growth factor that regulates cellular growth in a broad range of organisms. We present evidence that UCN controls ectopic growth of integuments through two independent mechanisms: attenuation of the protein kinase PDK1 in the cytoplasm and repression of the transcription factor ATS in the nucleus.

Steroid hormones are key components of the body's steroid-regulating system, and their levels are determined by a complex network of interacting genes. Variation in steroid levels has wide implications for health and disease. The genes encoding the proteins involved in steroid disposition represent key determinants of interindividual variation in steroid levels and ultimately, their effects. Here, we investigated the role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24, in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies. Our results suggest that SLC22A24 is involved in the reabsorption of organic anions, and in particular, anionic steroids. Phenome-wide analysis showed that functional variants of SLC22A24 are associated with human disease such as cardiovascular diseases and acne, which have been linked to dysregulated steroid metabolism. Collectively, these functional genomic studies reveal a previously uncharacterized protein involved in steroid homeostasis, opening up new possibilities for SLC22A24 as a pharmacological target for regulating steroid levels.

Visual system homeobox ( VSX ) proteins are highly conserved across evolution, and mutations in human VSX2 cause microphthalmia. Here we investigated the potential functional impact of the CVC domain mutation in mouse Versx2. The CVC domain is required for high-affinity DNA binding and ocular retardation, but the phenotypic impact of the mutation is not known. We show that the CVC mutant has the phenotypic consequences of the mutation on eye development and eye progenitor cell proliferation. Furthermore, we show that the phenotypic impact of the mutation is not due to a loss of DNA binding activity, which is likely due to a compensatory transcriptional feedback loop involving the transcription factors Mitf and Otx1. Our data suggest that the phenotypic impact of the CVC mutation is due to a loss of DNA binding activity elicited by the CVC mutation, which is required for eye development and must be repressed to allow the expression of the homeodomain in the retina. Our data also suggest that the CVC mutation has the characteristics of a recessive neomorph, a rare type of genetic allele.

Glycosylation is a major component of many biological processes, including the biosynthesis of glycoproteins and their maturation. As newly synthesized glycoproteins move through the secretory pathway, the asparagine-linked glycan ( N-glycan ) undergoes extensive modifications involving the sequential removal and addition of sugar residues. These modifications are critical for the proper assembly, quality control and transport of glycoproteins during biosynthesis. Rhodopsin is a glycoprotein that is unique among the N-glycan-modifying enzymes of Drosophila melanogaster. However, the molecular pathway of N-glycosylation for Rh1, the only rhodopsin in Drosophila, remains unknown. We have characterized mutant alleles of four Drosophila glycosyl hydrolases, namely α-mannosidase-II, α-mannosidase-IIb, a β-N-acetylglucosaminidase, and hexosaminidase 1. We have demonstrated that these four enzymes play essential and unique roles in a highly coordinated pathway for oligosaccharide trimming during Rh1 biosynthesis. Our results provide new insights into the functions of glycosyl hydrolases in the secretory pathway.

RNA viruses take advantage of cellular resources such as membranes and lipids to assemble viral replicase complexes ( VRCs ) that drive viral replication. The host lipins ( phosphatidate phosphatases ) are particularly interesting because they play key roles in cellular decisions about membrane biogenesis versus lipid storage. Therefore, we examined the relationship between host lipins and viral replication by analyzing yeast model host. We show that deletion of the host phosphatidic acid phosphatase PAH1 ( phosphatidic acid phosphohydrolase ), which is the single yeast homolog of the host lipin gene family, facilitates robust RNA virus replication. We document increased tombusvirus replicase activity in pah1Δ yeast due to the efficient assembly of VRCs. We show that the ER membranes generated in pah1Δ yeast is efficiently subverted by this RNA virus, thus emphasizing the connection between host lipins and RNA viruses. Our findings are relevant in a plant host, since the Arabidopsis Pah2p ortholog also inhibits the ER-based replication of another plant RNA virus. Over-expression of the Arabidopsis Pah2p also inhibited the ER-based replication of another plant RNA virus, suggesting that the role of lipins in RNA virus replication might include several more eukaryotic viruses.

Fusarium graminearum is a pathogen that causes fungal head blight of major cereal crops. Fusarium graminearum produces mycotoxins that are toxic to humans and animals. Fusarium graminearum is a complex organism that contains many genes with conserved gene products, and many of these genes encode putative transcription factors ( TF ) that are involved in controlling many aspects of fungal growth, development, stress response, pathogenesis, and toxin production. Here, we describe a systematic analysis of 17 phenotypes in 657 Fusarium graminearum genes encoding TFs, resulting in a database of over 11, 000 phenotypes. This study provides a comprehensive insight into how this cereal pathogen regulates traits important for growth, development, stress response, pathogenesis, and toxin production. It also provides a resource that will be a valuable resource for characterizing how this important fungal pathogen has evolved to control various cellular processes at the transcriptional level.

The nuclear lamina is a major obstacle encountered by herpesvirus nucleocapsids in their passage from the nucleus to the cytoplasm ( nuclear egress ). We found that the human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) -encoded protein kinase UL97, which is required for efficient nuclear egress, phosphorylates the nuclear lamina component lamin A/C on sites targeted by Cdc2/cyclin-dependent kinase 1, the enzyme that is responsible for breaking down the nuclear lamina during mitosis. Quantitative mass spectrometry analyses, comparing lamin A/C isolated from cells infected with viruses either expressing or lacking UL97 activity, revealed UL97-dependent phosphorylation of lamin A/C on the serine at residue 22 ( Ser22 ). Transient treatment of HCMV-infected cells with maribavir, an inhibitor of UL97 kinase activity, reduced lamin A/C phosphorylation by approximately 50%. Phosphorylation of lamin A/C during viral replication was accompanied by changes in the shape of the nucleus, as well as thinning, invaginations, and discrete breaks in the nuclear lamina, all of which required UL97 activity. As Ser22 is a phosphorylation site of particularly strong relevance for lamin A/C disassembly, our data support a model wherein viral mimicry of a mitotic host cell kinase activity promotes nuclear egress while accommodating viral arrest of the cell cycle.

Many important cellular functions such as migration, cell division, and growth are regulated by proteins that move inside of cells. While there are many mathematical models of the effects of proteins on cell movement, there are still many important aspects of cell movement and how these affect the function of the cell. In this paper, we study the effect of cell shape on the dynamics of proteins that are important for cell movements. We focus on the effects of cell shape on the movement of Cdc42, a protein that regulates the cell cycle. We find that the spatial organization of the cell inside the cell is important for the effects that Cdc42 have on cell movement. Our results also show that Cdc42 dynamics are not always stable, and that some forms of actin dynamics are able to overcome this effect.

A serological assay system was developed to simultaneously measure the individual levels of plasma antibodies ( IgG ) against 8 antigens derived from 6 pathogens: Entamoeba histolytica ( C-IgL ), Leishmania donovani ( KRP42 ), Toxoplasma gondii ( SAG1 ), Wuchereria bancrofti ( SXP1 ), HIV ( gag, gp120 and gp41 ), Vibrio cholerae ( cholera toxin ), and V. cholerae ( V. cholerae ). The assay system was applied for 3411 blood samples collected from the general population randomly selected from two health and demographic surveillance system ( HDSS ) cohorts in the coastal and western regions of Kenya. The results showed that the assay system can be used to rapidly determine the seroprevalence distribution for each pathogen, which will be very important for estimating the disease burden, particularly in low-resource settings. The results also showed that the results of the immunological cross reactions between W. bancrofti and S. lipoxin ( a drug used in some countries ) and other parasitic infections, will affect the seroprevalence distribution.

Severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome ( SFTS ) is an emerging infectious disease that is characterized by severe hemorrhage and a high fatality rate. Currently, no specific vaccine or treatment has been approved for this disease. In this study, we isolated antibodies from a patient who recovered from SFTS virus ( SFTSV ) infection. One of the antibodies, designated as Ab10, was reactive to the Gn envelope glycoprotein of SFTSV and protected host cells and A129 mice from infection in both in vitro and in vivo experiments. Notably, Ab10 protected 80% of mice, even when injected 5 days after inoculation with a lethal dose of SFTSV. Using cross-linker assisted mass spectrometry and alanine scanning, we located the non-linear epitope of Ab10 on the Gn glycoprotein domain II and an unstructured stem region, suggesting that Ab10 may inhibit a conformational alteration that is critical for cell membrane fusion between the virus and host cell. Ab10 reacted to recombinant Gn glycoprotein in Gangwon/Korea/2012, HB28, and SD4 strains. Additionally, based on its epitope, we predict that Ab10 binds the Gn glycoprotein in 247 of 272 SFTSV isolates previously reported. Together, these data suggest that Ab10 has potential to be developed into a therapeutic agent that could protect against more than 90% of reported SFTSV isolates.

Systems biology seeks to understand the complex systems behavior that underlies all biological processes. Quantitative computational models are increasingly used to predict the behavior of these systems. However, the predictive nature of such models depends on their ability to fit their underlying biochemical parameters. We show that in many systems, including growth-factor-signaling models, models can have very many free parameters that are difficult to measure directly. In addition, models that are well constrained can also have many parameters that are difficult to measure directly. We show that this “sloppy” spectrum of parameter sensitivity is universal in systems biology, and that models with many free parameters that are difficult to measure directly are on average more likely to be accurate than models with fewer free parameters.

Chlamydomonas reinhardtii is a unicellular green alga that causes several diseases in humans and animals. It is a well known model to study chloroplast biology and is used to study the pathogenesis of various human diseases. One of the most interesting questions in the photosynthetic world is the mechanisms of fusion of the chloroplast membranes. While it is known that the Dynamin-like protein family of GTPases regulate the fusion of chloroplast membranes, the mechanism of fusion of thylakoids, the organelles that are targeted by the GTPases, is poorly understood. We found that the fission yeast C. reinhardtii encodes an F Zelda family protein that is localized in the chloroplast. This protein is required for the fusion of thylakoids. Moreover, CRISPR/Cas9 technology was used to generate multiple fission yeast strains and identified the fission yeast CRFZAL as the gene responsible for the phenotypic requirement for fission yeast fission. Together, our results suggest that fission yeast fission is necessary for resistance to light stress.

Trypanosoma cruzi is an important human pathogen that causes Chagas' disease in Latin America, and is the second most common parasitic infection in the United States. The current drugs available to treat this infection are limited to a small number of drugs that are toxic and can cause serious side-effects. One potential new target for Chagas' disease therapy is sterol 14α-demethylase ( CYP51 ), a cytochrome P450 enzyme involved in biosynthesis of membrane sterols. We previously identified N-[4-pyridyl]-formamide moiety as a building block capable of delivering a variety of chemotypes into the CYP51 active site. In this work, we show that two compounds derived from a mycobacterium tuberculosis CYP51 screen hit inhibit T. cruzi. One of the compounds bound tightly to CYP51 and inhibited the growth of the parasite in vitro. CYP51Tc, the inhibitor bound to CYP51 with variable results, and the two compounds were discriminated by the variability of a single residue in the active site. We also show that CYP51 Mt-based structure analysis provides the opportunity to distinguish the functional groups of the two inhibitors in the CYP51 active site, thus opening the possibility of using a third generation of compounds to achieve more potent and selective inhibition of CYP51Tc.

Biological traits are controlled by genes that are regulated by environmental inputs. One way that a gene can be regulated is by modification, such as by changing the hormone or signaling pathway that the gene is exposed to. Such modification can be particularly important in the development of body parts, such as the skin, that are made of repeated units such as the eye or body segments. We study how modification affects the regulation of the levels of a hormone that is important for body development, called ecdysone. By analyzing the expression of the ecdysone receptor in forewing and hindwing eyespots of the butterfly Bicyclus anynana, we show that the degree to which the gene is expressed in these two body parts can vary. Our results provide a novel signaling pathway that, during development, can regulate the levels of this ecdysone receptor in the body. Interestingly, the level of this receptor is regulated by the temperature experienced by the larvae during the wandering stages of development, which is one of the most important developmental transitions during this time period. This suggests that modification of the ecdysone receptor in these sequential homologs is an important mechanism that underlies the variation in levels of plasticity that is observed across these body parts.

The role of a cell is defined by its behavior and its interaction with its environment. The expression profile of a cell provides information on the molecular components of the cell. Microarray data on the expression profile of cells are accumulating and have become the gold standard to study biological processes. However, they are not easily accessible in the form of web applications. We built a free and easy-to-use web tool GenomicScape for analyzing the expression profile of different cell types. We show how easily GenomicScape makes it possible to create a molecular atlas of the differentiation of B cells into plasma cells.

In the past, it has been estimated that a large dose of radiation can cause a large increase in the cellular resistance to radiation. Cellular responses to low dose radiation are known to be quite different from those to high dose radiation. These differences are important in determining how radiation doses influence the efficacy of radiation therapy and the design of radiation therapy regimens. The consequences of low dose radiation on cellular responses have remained unclear. We show that different mechanisms have been suggested to account for the observed dose-response relationships. We also show that the mechanism of low dose protection can be mediated by the inter-cellular communication and the modulation of cellular responses by the local cellular environment. These results provide important information for understanding how different types of cellular responses to low dose radiation are connected.

The human immune response to HIV infection is highly complex and includes both innate and adaptive immune cells. An important component of the innate immune response is the ability of CD8+ T lymphocytes ( CTL ) to detect and kill infected cells. The role of this immune response is to limit the spread of HIV to neighboring cells and thus reduce the probability of infection. The efficacy of this immune response is governed by the quality and specificity of the immune response. A particular strength of CTL immunity is the ability of CTL to respond to antigen derived from a wide variety of viruses. However, this immune response is imperfect and can select for mutations that reduce the efficacy of this response. Here, we assessed the fitness impacts of mutations that have emerged in a subset of CTL epitopes over the course of acute HIV infection. We found that several mutations conferred reduced replication fitness, whereas others conferred no or increased replication fitness. Some of these mutations were associated with high viral fitness costs. Our results suggest that the immune response to HIV is complex and that a balance must be maintained between replication and function.

When we hear a musical instrument playing on a flute, a sound traveling from the flute to the ear is reflected in a difference in time between the two and the perceived location of the instrument. The difference in time is called an intereraural time difference ( ITD ). It is an important cue for localizing sounds and is usually detected by a population of neurons in the brainstem. The response of individual neurons, however, changes with other stimulus properties like the spectral composition of sound. The influence of stimulus frequency is very different across neurons and thus it is unclear how ITDs are encoded independently of stimulus frequency by populations of neurons. Here, we fitted a statistical model to single-cell response of the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus. We found a rough correspondence between the measured characteristics and those predicted by computing mutual information. Furthermore, we studied two readout mechanisms, a linear classifier and a two-channel rate difference decoder. The latter turned out to be better suited to decode the population patterns obtained from the fitted model.

Burkholderia dermatitidis is a common cause of fungal infection in humans and animals. B. dermatitidis expresses a surface protein called Blastomyces adhesin-1 ( BAD-1 ) that is important for infection because it prevents the immune response of the host. We show here that the structure and function of BAD-1 is similar to that of the mammalian protein TSP-1, which is used by mammals to bind to proteins involved in blood clotting. Like TSP-1, BAD-1 blocks activation of T cells, which is an important mechanism by which the immune system prevents infection. We also show that a small region of BAD-1 is necessary for its binding to a host molecule called heparin, which is a common component of blood. Like TSP-1, BAD-1 blocks activation of T cells by a mechanism that requires its interaction with a cell surface protein called CD47, which is an important regulator of the immune system. Finally, we show that putative heparin-binding motifs are found both at the N-terminus of BAD-1 and within each of its 17 tandem repeats. These results suggest that the tandem repeats of BAD-1 mimic those of mammalian TSP-1, which are important for host colonization.

A novel technique was developed to study the response of individual ants to the concentration of a pheromone. The resulting response function is known as the “ Weber's law”, and the results are consistent with a previously reported law in the classical model of decision making. The law also predicts that the magnitude of the turning angle in a colony of ant workers is proportional to the difference between the amount of pheromone on the two sides of the ant, and the magnitude of the turning angle follows a Weber's law. Our results reproduce the results reported in the literature and show that ant workers are sensitive to the concentration of pheromone they live in.

Shigellosis is a bacterial disease that affects more than 200 million people per year worldwide. Treatment of shigellosis is complicated by the appearance of multidrug-resistant strains, which are resistant to most of the most commonly used antibiotics. In recent years, the World Health Organization has recommended ciprofloxacin as the recommended treatment for shigellosis. This is based on the observation that ciprofloxacin kills bacteria at a much lower rate than its parent drug, nalidixic acid. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of ciprofloxacin versus gatifloxacin in the treatment of uncomplicated shigellosis in children living in Vietnam. We found that the efficacy of both treatments was similar. We also assessed the ability of ciprofloxacin to stop the growth of the bacteria, and found that it could do so well enough that patients treated with ciprofloxacin still had a low bacterial burden at the time of treatment. Our study suggests that ciprofloxacin and gatifloxacin are equally effective for the treatment of uncomplicated shigellosis in children.

Hepatitis B virus ( HBV ) infection is a leading cause of liver cancer worldwide. One of the most important steps in the development of liver cancer is the integration of viral DNA into the host genome. This process is poorly understood in most liver cancers, including those due to HBV. In this study, we developed a technique to identify HBV integration events in liver cancer by analyzing the HBV–Human DNA in pairs of liver cancer cells. We found 296 HBV integration events in 40 pairs of liver cancer cells, corresponding to 286 unique integration sites ( UISs ). Our study is the first to describe the HBV–human DNA in liver cancer. We identified 14 additional target genes of HBV that were previously unknown to be integrated in human cells. Our findings provide a global understanding of HBV integration events, including integration into the host genome, and the identification of viral–host interactions that drive liver cancer.

Many fungi are able to enter into a pathogenic state in their hosts, in which they proliferate and produce spores. Once inside the host cells, the pathogen must evade the immune system of the host, such as the innate immune system of the plant, in order to proliferate. The fungal wheat pathogen Mycosphaerella graminicola causes septoria tritici blotch, a disease that greatly reduces the yield and quality of wheat. Understanding how the fungus evades host defenses is important to designing strategies to control the disease. Here, we have sequenced the genome of M. graminicola. This genome is very different from that of the other sequenced plant-pathogenic fungi and has a number of features, such as high rate of intra-chromosomal rearrangement, that have been observed in only a few species. Surprisingly, the M. graminicola genome contains very few genes for enzymes that break down plant cell walls, which is very different from other organisms. This suggests that the stealth pathogenesis of M. graminicola involves degradation of proteins rather than carbohydrates to evade host defenses during the biotrophic stage of infection.

The transcription machinery plays a central role in the initiation of transcription and is responsible for the synthesis of all proteins in eukaryotic cells. The termination of transcription, which is achieved by cleavage of the transcript at the 3′ end, is a critical step for the correct termination of transcription. The cleavage factor 1A ( CF1A ) complex, which is required for the termination of transcription in budding yeast, occupies the 3′ end of transcriptionally active genes. We recently demonstrated that CF1A subunits also crosslink to the 5′ end of genes during transcription. The presence of CF1A complex at the promoter suggested its possible involvement in the initiation/reinitiation of transcription. In this study, we demonstrate that the CF1A complex is required for the recruitment of RNA polymerase II onto the promoter for reinitiation of transcription. Simultaneously, an increase in the synthesis of promoter-initiated divergent antisense transcript was observed in the clp1 mutant, suggesting that CF1A complex is involved in the regulation of directionality to the promoter-associated transcription. Chromosome conformation capture analysis revealed a physical interaction of the promoter and terminator regions of a gene in the presence of a functional CF1A complex.

Bacteria have evolved many strategies for protection against antibiotics, including horizontal gene transfer ( HGT ). The bacterial phylum Firmicutes is especially apt for the spread of antibiotic resistance genes, and is the most prevalent cause of antibiotic resistance worldwide. HGT is initiated by the recognition of the presence of a new type of DNA molecule, the single-stranded DNA molecule, which is transferred from donor to recipient cell via a specific channel. The active site of the bacterial relaxase, named RelLS20, is located on the template strand of the conjugation genes. This is the first report of a bacterial family of the same kind. Our results show that RelLS20 is essential for conjugation and is located near the template strand of the conjugation genes. Surprisingly, the RelLS20 is not related to any other known proteins of bacterial phyla. We further show that RelLS20 is encoded almost exclusively in Firmicutes bacteria. Thus, this novel family of relaxases will have an important impact in different aspects of future research in the field of HGT in Gram-positive bacteria in general, and in gut microbiome research.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( M. tb ), the causative agent of tuberculosis ( TB ), is an extremely successful pathogen that causes one of the world's most devastating infectious diseases. The evolution of M. tb has been studied for decades, yet it remains poorly understood. We have used genomic data from within and between hosts to gain insight into the mechanisms shaping genetic diversity of this pathogen. Our results suggest that the amount of M. tb genetic diversity can vary dramatically depending on disease severity. We found that genes involved in the regulation, synthesis, and transport of immunomodulatory cell envelope lipids appear repeatedly in the extremes of various statistical measures of diversity. Many of these genes are specific to pathogenic mycobacteria and appear to be targets of natural selection.

The search engine is a powerful tool for detecting and estimating disease prevalence in epidemiological surveys. However, the search engine can be affected by the lack of knowledge of the disease distribution and the presence of different disease types. Moreover, the search engine cannot be used in geographically diverse countries or regions due to the limited information on the disease. In this study, we have explored new ways to reduce the search engine bias level in disease information extracted from the search engine. Our results showed that the number of real cases was more important than the number of false positives in the estimated results. Our results also showed that the number of false negatives can be reduced by including geographic information in the search engine.

Epistasis is a phenomenon in which the effects of a mutation in one gene are dependent on its context in the genome. When mutations occur in genes that are evolutionarily related, they are often epistatic, and their effects are typically greater than those of mutations that are independent of each other. It has long been known that mutations in some types of immune epitopes are much more strongly adaptive than mutations in others, but it has been difficult to determine the underlying forces driving this effect. Here we show that human influenza is subject to strong natural selection against a number of sites in its genome that are known to be targets of human immune cytotoxic T lymphocytes. These sites are enriched with epitopes that are also targets of human immune system evolution. Our results suggest that epistasis is an important force in protein evolution, and that the prevalence of epistasis is dependent on the evolutionary forces at play.

In this work, we describe the biochemical function of a plastidial protein, PROTEIN TARGETING TO STARCH SYNTHASE ( PTST ), in the synthesis of amylose, a major component of the plant starch. We show that PTST is required for the biosynthesis of amylose by plants, and that it interacts with the plant starch granule. Furthermore, we show that PTST is required for the synthesis of amylose by Arabidopsis, as plant growth requires its presence. We show that Arabidopsis ptst mutants do not synthesise amylose and that the function of PTST is to target the plant hormone to the plant granule. Our results show that PTST is involved in the targeting of glucose biosynthetic enzymes to sub-cellular sites where their action is required. Importantly, PTST represents a promising new gene target for the biotechnological modification of starch composition.

Transposable elements ( TEs ) are selfish genetic elements that have the potential to move within a genome. Although TEs are abundant and can be viewed as a mere copy of the genome, they can also have a substantial impact on the expression of genes. The level of DNA methylation in flanking regions and the modifications of DNA methylation that are associated with TEs can affect the expression of genes. Recent studies have shown that the level of DNA methylation is determined by the activity of the TE insertions. However, the effect of TE activity on the DNA methylation is not well understood. In this study, we show that TE insertions can alter the level of DNA methylation in flanking regions. We have used a set of nearly 70, 000 TE polymorphisms from different maize genomes to monitor the effect of TE insertions on the methylation of flanking regions. We show that TE insertions in highly methylated regions can affect the methylation of flanking regions, suggesting that TE insertions may condition altered methylation in conserved regions of the genome.

The functions of many proteins depend on their interactions with other proteins. This is especially apparent for large protein complexes which are composed of many thousands of protein pairs, and which are highly dynamic. The dynamics of protein complexes are tightly coupled to the functions they perform, and it is important to understand their possible conformations. Here, we describe a novel computational method that can predict the dynamics of protein complexes, and that can be used to identify the hidden dynamics of protein complexes. The method is based on a Markov Chain Monte Carlo simulation that is constrained by the physical resolution of the assay. The simulation is used to predict the dynamics of a protein complex composed of 7 core proteins and 11 associated regulators. We generated 20, 480 structures and identified conformational states using principle component analysis. We interrogated the conformation landscape and found evidence of symmetry breaking, a mixture of likely active and inactive conformational states and dynamic exchange of the core protein Arc15 between core and regulatory components. Our method provides a novel tool for prediction and visualization of the hidden dynamics within protein interaction networks.

Cellular networks are highly conserved and function in a similar way as the metabolic networks of the cell. In this work, we investigate the dynamics of the cell-cell adhesion network, which is a central node of cell-cell communication. The network is composed of a large number of molecules with varying cell context and time-dependent levels of expression. As a consequence, it is difficult to track the dynamics of the network in detail. In this work, we develop a mathematical model of this network to quantify the fold-change in concentration of any molecule included in the mathematical representation of the network in response to different cellular stimuli. We show that the cellular regulation of the network is very complex and involve many factors. We validate the model by inhibiting β-catenin-mediated activation of the enzyme that is responsible for the formation of the N-glycosylation-reversing adhesion. Our results provide a more detailed understanding of the regulation of cellular networks dynamics and may be useful for the design of therapeutic strategies to prevent cancer epithelial cell invasion.

Visceral leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by sand flies. It is a serious public health problem in many developing countries including Ethiopia. Control strategies are based on the use of drugs or vaccines against the parasites and are often based on the assumption that the parasite populations are homogeneous. However, in the case of L. donovani, the diversity of the parasite population can be different from that of the vector population, which is the assumption for control strategies. In this study, we analysed the genetic diversity of L. donovani strains isolated from different regions of Ethiopia, Sudan, India and Kenya, and compared them with those obtained from other parts of the world. We found that the diversity of L. donovani in these countries is not homogeneous. We also found that the genetic diversity of the parasite is influenced by host background and vector species. This study provides insights into the population structure of L. donovani in Ethiopia and will help to design effective control strategies against the disease.

Prostate cancer is the most common cancer diagnosed in men worldwide, and recent research has demonstrated that it is a leading cause of death in men. However, the majority of men who get diagnosed with prostate cancer remain uninfected. Thus, there is a need for new diagnostic tools to help men get infected with the disease. We have identified a single DNA change that is associated with increased risk of developing prostate cancer in men. This change, ALKBH7, is a protein called “ALKBH7”, and it is well known to be involved in many other biological processes. We have also developed computer simulations that show that this change in the protein causes a significant alteration in its structure and ability to bind to its substrate. We then tested the modified ALKBH7 protein in a test tube and confirmed that the changes in structure and function were associated with the disease.

Cancer is a disease that is characterised by cells accumulating genetic changes that confer a fitness advantage over the majority. In each cancer, a small number of cells can form a distinct sub-population of cells, which are referred to as tumor heterogeneity. Understanding the functional consequences of heterogeneity is essential to understand the mechanism behind drug resistance and to design therapies to target it. However, methods for estimating and quantifying heterogeneity are currently lacking. Here, we present a method that estimates heterogeneity in a cancer sample and an evolutionary pathogen strain by a novel approach based on the phylogenetic analysis of DNA changes. We show that the method is highly accurate, able to reconstruct ancestral genomes, and is able to quantitatively estimate the heterogeneity of a sample. We also provide a computational tool to reproduce the method and to test its accuracy on a variety of biological data sets.

Cells are complex biological units that function in a highly complex and dynamic manner. Their development and differentiation are regulated by a complex set of genes and proteins that are expressed in a highly localized fashion. In order to elucidate the spatio-temporal gene expression profiles of individual cells, we generated a high-resolution atlas of the transcriptome in the developing mouse embryo. The atlas was generated by hybridizing cell-type-specific RNA with a global cell-type coverage that encompasses the entire organism. This information can be used by other researchers to better understand or predict the function of genes of interest. We found over 18, 000 genes that are expressed in a tissue-specific manner and over 400 microRNAs that are involved in tissue-specific development. We were able to identify 1, 002 tissue-specific genes that are a source of novel tissue-specific markers for 37 different anatomical structures. The quality and the resolution of the data revealed novel molecular domains for several developing structures, such as the telencephalon, a novel organization for the hypothalamus, and insight on the Wnt network involved in renal epithelial differentiation.

Virus populations are complex, and represent a significant barrier to the development of effective antiviral drugs and vaccine strategies. In this paper, we present computational methods for the analysis of viral sequence data obtained from high-throughput sequencing technologies, providing an estimation of the population structure of the sample from the pyrosequencing reads. Our results are based on a statistical approach to error correction, followed by a combinatorial algorithm for constructing a minimal set of haplotypes that explain the data. We also apply a statistical model to infer the frequencies of the haplotypes in the population via an expectation–maximization algorithm. We demonstrate the use of such data to estimate the population structure of a viral population within a patient and compare the results with sequences obtained directly from clonal sequencing of four independent, diverse HIV populations.

Humans and many other species are able to sense the presence of objects in the visual field ( foveation ). They are able to actively sample the surrounding scene to reach a region of interest in a scene. The efficient processing strategy to such a task has been studied in detail for fovea-based methods. But what are the performance costs of such processing strategy relative to a scheme that processes the visual field at high spatial resolution? Here we develop a foveated object detector that combines object detectors from computer vision and a recent model of peripheral pooling regions found at the V1 layer of the human visual system. We show that the foveated object detector can approximate the performance of the object detector with high spatial resolution while bringing significant computational cost savings. Additionally, we show that the computational cost savings brought to the brain can be estimated from the computational model of eye movements. Together, our results might help explain the evolution of foveated visual systems with eye movements as a solution that preserves perceptual performance while resulting in computational and metabolic savings to the brain.

Influenza is a contagious respiratory disease that kills millions of people each year. Influenza has a very high mortality rate, and this mortality is a major risk factor for the emergence and spread of resistance in the population. Recently, the use of neuraminidase inhibitors ( NI ) has become the most important anti-influenza drug, and the most effective treatment for influenza. However, recent studies have reported the fraction of patients from which resistant strains could be isolated. Unfortunately, those results strongly depend on the details of the experimental protocol. Additionally, knowing the fraction of patients harboring resistance is not too useful by itself. Instead, we want to know how likely it is that an infected patient can generate a resistance in a secondary host, and how likely it is that the resistant strain subsequently spreads. We show how these parameters are influenced by changes in drug efficacy, timing of treatment, immunity to the disease, and details of virus and immune system dynamics. Our study provides estimates for parameters that can be directly used in mathematical and computational models to study how NI usage might lead to the emergence and spread of resistance in the population.

The most common mutation in Wilms tumours is a loss of function mutation in the TRIM28 gene. Although these mutations have been associated with the development of certain cancers, the biological significance of this association has not been determined. We show that loss of function mutations in TRIM28 are a characteristic feature of Wilms tumours, and that inactivation of this gene occurs in both germline and somatic cells. These data suggest that loss of function mutations in TRIM28 provide the molecular basis for defining a previously described subtype of Wilms tumour, which has an excellent prognosis.

The 20S proteasome is a major cellular protease responsible for the cleavage of peptides ( peptides ) of interest ) in the 3′-most exon of the transcript. In the cell, the 20S proteasome is present on all mRNA transcripts and cleaves the peptide at one end, leading to the generation of a mature peptide. While it is well established that the 20S proteasome cleaves peptides that are important for the function of the cell, the majority of the proteasome-catalyzed peptide products have not been identified so far. Here we have developed a novel computational algorithm for the identification of spliced peptides generated by the 20S proteasome and applied it to the analysis of four different substrate molecules. We identified fifteen new spliced peptides generated by the 20S proteasome, all of them by combining in vitro proteasomal degradation assays and mass spectrometry. Our data suggest that 20S proteasomes represent a molecular machine that, due to its catalytic and structural properties, facilitates the generation of spliced peptides, thereby providing a pool of qualitatively new peptides from which functionally relevant products may be selected.

Ectodomain of actin reorganization and phagocytosis are critical for protozoan survival and virulence. The 14-3-3 family of proteins are widely conserved in eukaryotes and are involved in a large range of cellular processes. Although these proteins are well known to regulate actin dynamics in eukaryotes, their biological functions in protozoan parasites are poorly characterized. In this study, we have investigated the role of 14-3-3 protein 3 ( EhP3 ) in the regulation of actin dynamics, phagocytosis and cytokinesis in the protozoan protist Entamoeba histolytica. Our results revealed that EhP3 is involved in actin reorganization and phagocytosis and plays a critical role in regulating actin dynamics and actin remodeling.

Neural activity has long been thought to be a passive process that is not structured for optimal sensory input. Yet, experimental evidence has shown that neural activity is structured and can be optimized for the task at hand. Here we present a computational approach that optimizes the neural code of retinal waves, a prominent neural activity pattern in the developing visual system. We show that our retinal coding strategy leads to cells that are similar to the cortical cells that are known to be important for visual processing. The results are consistent with the idea that retinal waves share relevant temporal and spatial properties with natural visual input.

Snakebite is a public health problem in Laos, a country that is far from developing country. Most of the population in the country earn their living from agricultural activities. Under these circumstances the incidence of snakebites is expected to be high. We performed a community-based survey in two rural district of the Lao PDR ( Laos ) to estimate the number of snakebites per 100, 000 people per year. The estimated incidence is 355 snakebites per 100, 000 persons per year and 1105 per 100, 000 in the two districts. The majority of the victims received treatment by traditional healers or self-treatment at home. The calculated incidence is much higher than that reported by hospital statistics. We also found that the majority of snakebite victims received only treatment by traditional healers or self-treatment in their village. There is an urgent need to train medical staff and students in management of snakebite patients and make snake antivenom available to cope effectively with this important public health problem in order to prevent fatalities and disabilities.

Fungal pathogens are common and can cause life-threatening infections in immunocompromised individuals. Candida albicans is the most prevalent fungal pathogen worldwide and is resistant to most of the antifungal drugs currently in use. We show that diploid strains exposed to the antifungal drug fluconazole undergo an unexpected intermediate form of aneuploidy. Instead of having a normal cell cycle, these cells undergo a series of abnormal cell divisions, resulting in “trimeras, ” three daughter cells that are composed of a mother, daughter, and granddaughter cell. Once aneuploid cells are formed, the abnormal cell cycle resumes and chromosomes undergo segregation, yielding a tetraploid cell with an extra spindle. In subsequent cell cycles, this abnormal cell division results in a cell that is more susceptible to DNA damaging agents such as those used in chemotherapy, resulting in an increased chance of aneuploidy. This is reminiscent of the tumor formation in early human neoplastic development in which aneuploidy is thought to be a critical event.

Bacterial cells perceive their environment through the use of two-component systems, composed of a sensor histidine kinase and an effector response regulator. These systems transduce environmental cues into cellular decision processes, such as the competence, sporulation, or biofilm formation. Phr peptides, produced by Rap proteins, are a large family of bacterial toxins that inhibit these systems, but the mechanism of action is still not known. We used X-ray crystallography to solve the structure of RapF, the anti-activator of competence RR ComA, alone and in complex with its regulatory peptide PhrF. Our data reveal that PhrF blocks the RapF-ComA interaction through an allosteric mechanism. PhrF accommodates in the C-terminal tetratricopeptide repeat domain of RapF by inducing its constriction, a conformational change propagated by a pronounced rotation to the N-terminal ComA-binding domain. This movement partially disrupts the ComA binding site by triggering the ComA disassociation, whose interaction with RapF is also sterically impaired in the PhrF-induced conformation of RapF. Sequence analyses of the Rap proteins, guided by the RapF-PhrF structure, unveil the molecular basis of Phr recognition and discrimination, allowing us to relax the Phr specificity of RapF by a single residue change.

Spectrin is a large protein involved in many important biological processes, such as cell migration, neurotransmitter release, and cell adhesion. It is structurally well defined, but the molecular basis for its biological shape change, whereby the molecular length can increase three-fold, is still not understood. In this study, we employ a combination of structural and biochemical data to describe the molecular shape of spectrin. We also use electron microscopic data to show that the molecular shape change is a result of the conformational change of the primary, secondary, and tertiary structures of spectrin. The proposed model is consistent with all known physical properties of spectrin, including its rest length, dynamic shape, and hollow cylinder-like structure. The model is further supported by zero-length chemical crosslink data, which indicate that spectrin is hollow at its biological length of ~55-65 nm. The domain-domain interactions in our model are entirely consistent with those present in the prototypical linear antiparallel heterotetramer as well as recently reported inter-strand chemical crosslinks. The model is consistent with all known physical properties of spectrin, and upon full extension our Chinese Finger Trap Model reduces to the ~180-200 nm molecular model currently in common use.

Dopamine is the most important neurotransmitter in the brain. Parkinson’s disease ( PD ) is the most common neurodegenerative movement disorder affecting more than 5 million people worldwide. The dopamine neurons primarily function in movement control and reward processing. Dysfunction of dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta and the dopaminergic terminals of the striatum, which are the major input structures of the dopamine system, is the principal lesion in PD. The dopamine cell line neurotrophic factor ( GDNF ) has been suggested to be involved in brain function, and to be upregulated in the dopaminergic system. However, the physiological role of GDNF in the dopamine system is not known. Here, we report that the spatial expression of GDNF in the Gdnf endogenous locus yields GDNF hypermorphic mice. We show that the spatially unregulated GDNF treatments protect dopamine neurons and dopaminergic neurons from loss and dysfunction. We also show that the expression of GDNF in the striatum is increased by the reduction in striatal dopamine and dopamine transporter activity. Our results reveal the physiological role of GDNF in the nigrostriatal dopamine system postnatal development and adult function, and highlight the importance of correct spatial expression of GDNF. Furthermore, we suggest that 3’UTR targeting may constitute a useful tool in analyzing gene function.

What causes bacteria to be so different? One way bacteria can differ is by recombination, in which bacterial genomes are shuffled with other bacteria. This process, however, is not a universal process, and bacteria sometimes recombine with more bacteria than with others, forming distinct subpopulations of bacteria. Why bacteria recombine is a fundamental question in evolutionary biology. To address this question, we developed a model of bacterial evolution in habitat space. We show that the amount of habitat overlap determines the outcome for a pair of clusters, which may range from fast clonal divergence with little interaction between the clusters, to a stationary population structure, where different clusters maintain an equilibrium distance between each other for an indefinite time. We fit our model to two bacterial species. We find a subpopulation of bacteria that maintains an equilibrium with the other cluster over an indefinitely long time. This approach may predict and define speciation trajectories in multiple bacterial species.

Influenza epidemics pose a significant burden to society, yet are difficult to study in their human hosts due to the lack of granular disease data. Here, we analyze medical claims data from the US during 2002–2010, and identify the spatial and temporal drivers of influenza spread. We find that seasonal influenza epidemics tended to originate in cities that have been well established with a large number of susceptible individuals. While influenza is typically transported via air travel, our data indicate that influenza may also move by other routes. We find that influenza epidemics tend to originate in cities that have a shorter history of influenza transmission. Our analysis also identifies key spatial and temporal characteristics of influenza spread, including the speed and routes of spread, that vary by season.

Wetlands are the most productive ecosystem on the planet and they are critical for the production of energy, metals, and pharmaceuticals. Over half of the world's wetlands were eliminated from their habitats 50, 000 years ago. Even today, the restoration of wetlands has been widely attempted, but the degree of actual recovery of ecosystem function and structure from these efforts remains uncertain. Here we analyze 621 wetland sites from throughout the world, including almost all known locations and years of recovery, to compare the effects of restoration to the recovery of ecosystem structure and function. We find that even after many decades of restoration, biological structure ( driven mostly by plant assemblages ) and biogeochemical functioning ( driven primarily by the storage of carbon in wetland soils ) remained on average 26% and 23% lower than in reference sites. Either recovery has been very slow, or postdisturbance systems have moved towards alternative states that differ from reference conditions. Also, wetlands experiencing more ( riverine and tidal ) hydrologic exchange recovered more rapidly than those of other wetlands. Restoration as currently practiced fails to recover original levels of wetland ecosystem function, even after many decades. If restoration as currently practiced is used to justify further degradation, global loss of wetland ecosystem function and structure will spread.

Organismal growth depends on the ability of animals to sense nutrient availability, which is sensed through a variety of sensory neurons. When animals are starved, only a small subset of these neurons become stimulated, and this subset is called the sensory neurons. These neurons secrete peptide hormones, which are detected by conserved cell-surface receptors. Food availability is sensed by a number of neurons, including the cilia, which are the projections of the cell that extend to the environment. Here, we show that a calcium-regulated channel ( TRPV ) in cilia mediates the sensation of food availability. When this channel is inactivated, the survival of C. elegans first larvae is significantly increased, but this extension extends only to a small subset of neurons. Furthermore, when this channel is inactivated, the lifespan of the first larva is also significantly increased. Interestingly, although insulin signaling modulates lifespan and food availability in a variety of organisms, these mechanisms do not appear to affect C. elegans neurosecretion. We propose that TRPV channels modulate the neurosecretion of peptides that are sensed by these neurons and are used to sense food.

Leprosy is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It is transmitted from person to person, although the bacillus can be transmitted from the environment to human by skin to skin contact, or via aerosols. In Colombia, leprosy is in a stage of post-elimination; however, the disease is still present in some regions, and there is an important social burden associated with it. We evaluated the transmission of M. leprae in four Colombian departments. We studied 159 rural residents, of which 45 had a second contact with M. leprae and 18 had new cases of leprosy. We also studied 20 ( 4. 1% ) of these 543 rural residents. We studied the M. leprae strains from these patients and from their households. We found that the two new cases were from the same strain, indicating that transmission is by the same strain, and not by new strain, and that this strain has been maintained in the community for a long time. We also found that the two strains, and the index case, are closely related, suggesting that transmission is direct or indirect. Our results confirm that people with leprosy are at high risk of contracting the disease, and that follow-up of these high-risk groups is a good strategy to diagnose and control the disease.

Heart failure ( HF ) is the most common cause of death worldwide. The underlying etiology of HF remains unclear. MicroRNAs ( miRNAs ), including miR-29 family, have been identified as important modulators of gene expression and function in the heart. Here, we studied the role of miR-29 in the cardiovascular system and its contribution to HF development. Using a conditional knock-out approach, we found that the absence of miR-29 in mice results in the development of vascular remodeling and systemic hypertension, as well as HF with preserved ejection fraction ( HFpEF ). We also demonstrated that miR-29 regulates mitochondrial biogenesis, and that the lack of miR-29 triggers the up-regulation of its target, the master metabolic regulator PGC1α, which in turn generates profound alterations in mitochondrial biogenesis, leading to the accumulation of small mitochondria in mutant animals that contribute to cardiac disease. Finally, we demonstrated that systemic hypertension and HFpEF can be rescued by PGC1α haploinsufficiency, which reduces cardiac mitochondrial accumulation and extends longevity of miR-29–mutant mice. In addition, PGC1α is overexpressed in hearts from patients with HF. Collectively, our findings demonstrate the in vivo function of miR-29 in the cardiovascular system and identify a novel miR-29/PGC1α regulatory circuitry of functional relevance for cell metabolism under normal and pathological conditions.

How do cells coordinate migration in the presence of a moving environment? While extensive research has been done, the mechanisms of collective migration are still poorly understood. We develop an analytical framework for analyzing spatiotemporal data sets generated by multiple experiments and use it to detect and quantify the emergence of new modes of coordinated migration in a monolayer. We show how the emergence of collective migration propagates from the wound edge and is amplified by Met activation with hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor. Our data suggest a mechanism of coordinated migration by acceleration and stretching that seems to increase directionality by temporarily decreasing the velocity components orthogonal to the direction defined by the monolayer geometry.

Influenza pandemics emerge unexpectedly and wreak global devastation. However, each of the six pandemics since 1889 emerged in the Northern Hemisphere just after the flu season, suggesting that pandemic timing may be predictable. Using a simple model fit to seasonal flu surveillance data from the United States, we find that seasonal flu leaves a transient wake of heterosubtypic immunity that impedes the emergence of novel flu viruses. This refractory period provides a simple explanation for not only the spring-summer timing of historical pandemics, but also early increases in pandemic severity and multiple waves of transmission. Thus, pandemic risk may be seasonal and predictable, with the accuracy of pre-pandemic and real-time risk assessments hinging on reliable seasonal influenza surveillance and precise estimates of the breadth and duration of heterosubtypic immunity.

Retroviral vectors have been successfully used for clinical gene therapy and are associated with increased risks of insertional mutagenesis. However, the mechanisms of viral integration into the human genome are incompletely understood. We provide a new method to identify genomic regions where viral integration is more or less frequent. We found 100 significant integration hotspots distributed throughout the human genome. The viral integration hotspots were wider and contained more genes than MLV ones. We also found that the viral integration hotspots are enriched with genes involved in antigen processing and presentation. These results suggest that viral integration patterns may be guided by different epigenetic and nuclear three-dimensional structures.

African trypanosomiasis ( AT ) is a neglected tropical disease affecting millions of people in sub-Saharan Africa. It is caused by Trypanosoma brucei species, which can infect both the blood and heart tissues and cause severe pathology in the heart. We have previously shown that Trypanosoma brucei can interact with heart muscle cells ( cardiomyocytes ) to induce ventricular arrhythmias in ex vivo adult rat hearts. However, it is not known whether the cardiac dysfunction observed in vivo is also present during in vivo infection in experimental animal models. Here we show for the first time the characterisation of cardiac dysfunction in two animal models of AT using electrocardiographic ( ECG ) monitoring. The first model used a commonly used laboratory strain, Trypanosoma brucei Lister 427, whilst the second model used a pleomorphic laboratory strain, T. b. brucei TREU 927, which demonstrates a similar chronic infection profile to clinical cases of AT. The frequency of ventricular arrhythmias and heart rate were significantly increased in the TREU 927 infection model in vivo, but not in the Lister 427 infection model. At the end of infection, hearts from both models were isolated and Langendorff perfused ex vivo with increasing concentrations of the β-adrenergic agonist isoproterenol. Interestingly, the increased frequency of arrhythmias observed in vivo in the TREU 927 infection model was lost upon isolation of the heart ex vivo, but re-emerged with the addition of isoproterenol. Our results demonstrate that TREU 927 infection modifies the substrate of the myocardium in such a way as to increase the propensity for ventricular arrhythmias in response to a circulating factor in vivo or β-adrenergic stimulation ex vivo. The TREU 927 infection model provides a new opportunity to accelerate our understanding of AT-related cardiac pathophysiology and to identify future treatment strategies.

Plasmodium falciparum is the most widely distributed species of malaria parasites worldwide, responsible for more than 1. 5 million deaths per year. Drug resistance is a major concern in the control of this disease. In Southeast Asia, falciparum malaria is primarily caused by P. falciparum, the most prevalent species of the human malaria parasite. The Thai-Cambodia border is the epicenter for the emergence of drug-resistant falciparum malaria. Previous studies have shown that the chloroquine and pyrimethamine resistance alleles in this region and in Africa have originated from the same genetic background, and subsequently spread to other Asian countries and Africa. However, there is a dearth in understanding the origin ( s ) of the different types of resistant alleles in this region. Here, we present the complete sequence of 234 Cambodian P. falciparum isolates for the three different types of resistant alleles associated with sulfadoxine resistance. We also assess the genetic relationships among these resistant alleles and compare them with those prevalent in Africa and South America. Our data suggest that the triple mutant alleles originated on the SGKGA background, whereas the double and single mutations originated on multiple, although limited, genetic backgrounds. The microsatellite data suggest that the triple mutant alleles originated on the SGKGA background, whereas the single and double mutations originated on several, although limited, genetic backgrounds.
