In addition, the presence of OSP-specific IgG memory B cell responses in peripheral blood on study entry was also associated with a decreased risk of infection ( 44% reduction; 95% CI: 31. 1 to 99. 8 ) in contacts. No protection was associated with cholera toxin B subunit ( CtxB ) -specific memory B cell responses. These results suggest that immune responses that target OSP, both in plasma and memory B cell responses, may be important in mediating protection against infection with V. cholerae O1.

Entamoeba histolytica is the most prevalent protozoan parasite worldwide. It has been shown that the parasite can survive in both the extracellular and intracellular environments. The extracellular environment is thought to be the major determinant for the parasite, whereas the intracellular environment is thought to be a major factor affecting the parasite growth. The parasite’s ability to undergo changes in growth conditions is also believed to be an integral part of the parasite’s life cycle. The parasite can switch from extracellular to intracellular growth conditions and vice versa. However, the nature of the re-association of the parasite with its host and the impact of changes in growth conditions are still unclear. We have compared the nuclear DNA content and the changes in the nuclear DNA content of E. histolytica trophozoites growing in axenic and xenic cultures. Our results show that the nuclear DNA content of E. histolytica trophozoites grown in axenic cultures is 10-fold higher than that in xenic cultures. In addition, the nuclear DNA content changes during the growth conditions in both cultures was found to be similar. We also found that the DNA content in the cyst stage of the parasite changes significantly during excystation, leading to a 40-fold increase in the nuclear DNA content. Our results demonstrate the plasticity and dynamic nature of the Entamoeba genome.

Bacterial flagella are molecular propellers that propel bacterial cells and are involved in many important functions such as antibiotic resistance, virulence, motility and virulence. Flagella are assembled by a complex, multi-protein nanomachine. The components of this complex are transported across the inner-membrane to the outer-membrane in a proton motive force-dependent manner. We have previously demonstrated that a small cytoplasmic protein, FliO, is required for flagellar export. However, how FliO functions in vivo remained unknown. Here, we show that FliO is involved in the assembly of the flagellar export apparatus. We also show that FliO is not part of the flagellar export gate complex. In summary, our results provide new insights into the function of FliO, which is a novel, flagellar T3SS-specific chaperone.

Cancer is a disease of systems, not of individual cells, but of an organism. The development of cancer cells is accompanied by an accumulation of abnormal proteins and metabolites. While this feature is generally used to diagnose and treat cancer, its quantitative and predictive value is still difficult to quantify. Computational models have the potential to bridge this gap between data and biological functionality. Here, we introduce single-cell RNA-seq as a novel computational framework to integrate transcriptomes of single cells into population models. We show that the integration of single-cell transcriptomes into multi-scale stoichiometric models of a cancer cell population can significantly reduce the space of feasible single-cell fluxomes. We also identify clusters of cells with different growth rates within the population. We also point out the possible metabolic interactions among cells via exchange of metabolites. The scFBA suite of MATLAB functions is available to the public under a GNU General Public License v3, which allows to reproduce our results and to integrate the scFBA into other popular software packages.

Fungal infections pose a serious threat to human health and the medical care industry has a heavy burden to treat these infections. Azole drugs, which target the sterol biosynthetic pathway, are used to treat a range of fungal infections. Azole resistant strains are emerging and are threatening to be lost for clinical use. Azole tolerance is governed by the sterol regulatory element binding protein ( SrbA ), which is regulated by the CCAAT binding complex ( CBC ). In this study we show that the CBC acts to repress the expression of multiple genes involved in sterol biosynthesis including those coding for HMG-CoA-synthase, HMG-CoA-reductase and sterol C14-demethylase. We also show that inactivation of the CBC increases the tolerance of these strains to a range of different classes of drugs targeting ergosterol biosynthesis including the azoles, allylamines ( terbinafine ) and statins ( simvastatin ). Our study provides insight into the mechanism underpinning the sterol tolerance of azole resistant strains and into the effects of a clinically relevant mutation in HapE ( P88L ), which may explain why a cyp51A null mutant is severely attenuated for pathogenicity in an animal model of aspergillosis.

Proteins are synthesized by ribosomes that translate a single messenger RNA into a complex of 13 amino acids. While each mRNA contains multiple coding and stop codons, only one of the stop codons is used. The choice of stop codon is determined by a single codon in the mRNA itself. The current model states that the choice of stop codons is exclusively regulated by intrinsic control elements. However, we discovered, using a reporter that measures the levels of individual tRNA genes in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, that eight tRNA genes, 100% identical in sequence, are expressed in different tissues and change their expression dynamically. Furthermore, the expression of the sup-7 tRNA gene at day 6 was found to predict the animal’s lifespan. We discovered that the expression of tRNAs that reside within introns of protein-coding genes is affected by the host gene’s promoter. Pairing between specific Pol II genes and the tRNAs that are contained in their introns is most likely adaptive, since a genome-wide analysis revealed that the presence of specific intronic tRNAs within specific orthologous genes is conserved across Caenorhabditis species.

In eukaryotes, heterochromatin is a specialized chromatin structure characterized by the repression of transcription from heterochromatic loci to maintain heterochromatin maintenance. In animals, heterochromatin is maintained by the activity of heterochromatin-specific silencing factors, including RRP1 and RRP2. RRP1 and RRP2 are involved in the processing of heterochromatin-associated non-coding RNAs ( ncRNAs ), and the degradation of these RNAs is essential for heterochromatin maintenance in both Drosophila and mammals. The heterochromatin structure is maintained by heterochromatin-associated RNA polymerase II and heterochromatin-associated proteins that recruit the RRP proteins to the heterochromatin loci. RRP proteins are involved in RNA surveillance and are involved in heterochromatin maintenance in plants, yeasts and flies. In this study, we show that a fraction of RRP6 is associated with heterochromatin, and that the heterochromatin structure contributes to the tethering of RRP6 to a subset of heterochromatic loci. Our results also suggest that SU ( VAR ) 3-9, a heterochromatin-associated protein that binds to heterochromatic transcripts and degrades them, is a necessary component of the heterochromatin maintenance pathway.

Schistosomes are parasitic flatworms that infect hundreds of millions of people worldwide. The snail Biomphalaria glabrata is the only animal host of the disease that can survive for many years. In this paper, we describe the cloning, characterization, and functional analysis of a new eukaryotic β pore-forming toxin ( β-PFT ) from Biomphalysin, which we call Biomphalysin. We show that Biomphalysin is a new β-PFT from a snail and that its gene was horizontally transferred from one organism to another. We show that Biomphalysin is highly toxic toward S. mansoni sporocysts and that Biomphalysin binds to parasite membranes. Finally, we show that Biomphalysin has a strong ability to kill the parasite, likely by forming pores in the plasma membrane. These results provide the first functional description of a mollusk immune effector protein involved in killing S. mansoni.

Eukaryotic genomes are packaged into specific chromatin structures that ensure their coordinated expression. Examples of such multi-gene chromatin domains are well-documented, but a global view of the chromatin organization of eukaryotic genomes is lacking. Here, we systematically identify multi-gene chromatin domains in the genome of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. We constructed a compendium of genome-scale binding maps for a broad panel of chromatin-associated proteins. We then computationally analyzed this compendium for evidence of multi-gene chromatin domains using a novel statistical segmentation algorithm. Our results indicate that at least 50% of all fly genes are organized into chromatin domains, which often consist of dozens of genes. The domains are characterized by various known and novel combinations of chromatin proteins. Furthermore, during evolution fewer chromosomal rearrangements occur inside chromatin domains than outside domains. Our results provide the first global view of the chromatin organization of multi-gene chromatin domains in eukaryotes.

CRISPR-Cas system provides the host of a prokaryotic cell with an adaptive immune defense against viral infections. It consists of two components: Cas-proteins that cleave the foreign DNA and the CRISPR array that suits as a virus recognition key. Here, we estimate the number of spacers in a CRISPR array of a prokaryotic cell which maximizes its protection against a viral attack by using optimization techniques from the competition between two trends: too few spacers make the host vulnerable to an attack by a virus with mutated corresponding protospacers, while an excessive variety of spacers dilutes the number of the CRISPR complexes armed with the most recent and thus most useful spacers. We find that depending on such parameters as the concentration of CRISPR-Cas interference complexes and its preference to arm with more recently acquired spacers, the rate of viral mutation, and the number of viral species, the predicted optimal number of spacers lies within a range that agrees with experimentally-observed values.

Brain networks support many important functions, including sensory perception, motor execution, and decision-making. However, the brain has to overcome the intrinsic limitations of the brain anatomy and physiology to execute a coherent behavior on the time scale of seconds. How the brain can overcome this hurdle is an open question. Here we show that excitable neuronal assemblies can serve as a building block for rapid and reliable execution of neural circuit function. These assemblies can flexibly adjust the speed of execution of neural circuit function in order to support reliable behavior on this time scale. We argue that the propagation speed of neuronal circuits is slower than the speed of action potential propagation, and that this difference is a fundamental difference between neural circuits and motor circuits. We show in simulations and in vivo experiments that the propagation speed of neuronal circuits is slower than the speed of action potential propagation, and show how various patterns of activity propagation can be explained.

African swine fever virus ( ASFV ) is a highly pathogenic zoonotic virus responsible for the severe disease in animals and humans. ASFV is also highly infectious in humans, causing an estimated 40, 000 deaths per year. ASFV replicates in the cytoplasm of infected cells. ASFV modulates the host cell to facilitate viral replication and spread, and it is known that this process is modulated by viral proteins. Here, we show that a number of viral proteins, including eIF4G, eIF4E, eIF4B, eIF4E, 4E-BP1 and 4E-BP2, are involved in the regulation of the host translation machinery. In particular, eIF4F and eIF4E are involved in the modification of the host translation machinery, thereby affecting the viral protein synthesis. In addition, eIF4F and eIF4E are localized in the periphery of viral factories, and this organization is correlated with the presence of viral late mRNAs. Our results demonstrate that the host translation machinery, which is involved in viral protein synthesis, is also involved in the inhibition of host protein synthesis, thereby facilitating ASFV protein production.

Schistosomiasis is a chronic parasitic disease caused by a single-celled parasite, Schistosoma japonicum. More than 200 million people are infected worldwide, of whom 90% live in endemic areas. The only available drug for treatment of schistosomiasis, praziquantel, has led to increasing concerns about drug resistance. We have identified and confirmed the ligand binding specificity for each of the four PDZ domains of SjS Scribble protein, which is a major target of drug development. The results also suggest that all the PDZ domains of SjS Scrib bind to specific motif sequences in its human ortholog, and that the differences in ligand binding specificity between SjS Scrib and its human ortholog are largely determined by the differences in the structural basis of these motifs. Our study may provide a basis for the rational design of novel anti-schistosomal drugs.

Achilles heel tendon is a highly complex tissue that connects the tendon to muscles and tendon to ligaments that control the movements of the body. The tendon is a highly complex organ that is composed of many different cell types, including muscle and tendon cells, and a large array of connective tissue and cell types. How tendon regrow after injury is a question of great interest in the field of mechanics. The most popular method to study tendon regrow is to apply physical forces to the tendon tissue. In this study, we used computer modeling to investigate the effects of tendon loading on a cell scale model of the rat tendon. We found that the tendon tissue can be compressed by physical loading, and that this physical loading can be converted to a force force by a cellular response curve based on tendon tissue. We then integrated the tissue response curve with the cellular response curve to predict the local concentration of collagen, the most abundant tissue protein in the tendon. Our results provide a framework to compare experimental data from various studies of tendon healing.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes the sexually transmitted disease gonorrhoea by evading innate immunity. Colonizing the mucosa of the reproductive tract depends on the bacterial outer membrane porin, PorB, which is essential for ion and nutrient uptake. PorB is also targeted to host mitochondria and regulates apoptosis pathways to promote infections. Here, we show that N. gonorrhoeae secretes PorB via outer membrane vesicles ( OMVs ). Purified OMVs contained primarily outer membrane proteins including oligomeric PorB. The porin was targeted to mitochondria of macrophages after exposure to purified OMVs and wild type N. gonorrhoeae. This was associated with loss of mitochondrial membrane potential, release of cytochrome c, activation of apoptotic caspases and cell death in a time-dependent manner. Consistent with this, OMV-induced macrophage death was prevented with the pan-caspase inhibitor, Q-VD-PH. This shows that N. gonorrhoeae utilizes OMVs to target PorB to mitochondria and induce apoptosis in macrophages, thus affecting innate immunity.

Chagas disease is an important public health problem in the Americas, and there is an urgent need for improved surveillance, control and diagnosis. In Venezuela, the disease is caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, which is endemic in humans and dogs. In this manuscript we analyze the genetic diversity of T. cruzi in Venezuela, and report the results of the analysis from 1988–2016, from 778 samples collected from wild and domestic mammals and from human disease cases. We show that the parasite can be classified into six major genetic groups ( TcI – TcVI ) based on the six major T. cruzi subtypes previously described in the Americas. The TcI group is most commonly found in Venezuela, and is thought to be the cause of the American trypanosomiasis. We also show that the TcIV group is a new genetic group previously thought to be rare in humans. Finally, we were able to relate our results with several epidemiological, ecological and pathological characteristics of Chagas disease and to evaluate the impact these traits have on the control of the disease.

The WHO is aiming to eliminate filarial infections by 2020, a target that has yet to be achieved. The drug of choice in the fight against these infections is diethylcarbamazine ( DCA ), the use of which is associated with undesirable side effects. There are currently no drugs that are approved for use in humans. The search for new drugs is long, and a range of compounds are being tested in the laboratory. One of the first compounds tested for inhibition of the human target of DCA, Hsp90, is a small molecule called purine-scaffold, which has been shown to inhibit the human target of DCA. We have developed a fluorescence-based assay to screen small molecules for inhibition of Hsp90 in adult filarial worms. We have used this assay to test a series of compounds against Hsp90, including members of known DCA binding sites. The results showed that the assay is sensitive, and thus can be used for screening of a range of potential inhibitors of Hsp90. This assay can also be used to identify compounds that are effective against other targets in parasitic worms.

Reproduction in sexually dimorphic animals relies on successful gamete production, executed by the germline and aided by somatic support cells. Somatic sex identity in Drosophila is instructed by sex-specific isoforms of the DMRT1 ortholog Doublesex ( Dsx ). Female-specific expression of Sex-lethal ( Sxl ) causes alternative splicing of transformer ( tra ) to the female isoform traF. In turn, this leads to a collapse of germline differentiation and male infertility. Here, we show that the transcriptional and post-transcriptional repressor Chinmo in male somatic stem cells ( CySCs ) of the testis causes a collapse of germline differentiation and male infertility. Our data reveal the need for transcriptional regulation of tra in adult male stem cells and highlight a previously unobserved Sxl-independent mechanism of traF production in vivo. In sum, transcriptional control of the sex determination hierarchy by Chinmo is critical for sex maintenance in sexually dimorphic tissues and is vital in the preservation of fertility.

Fibrosis is a leading cause of death worldwide. While fibrosis is a complex process, the underlying genetic causes are largely unknown. Previous studies have shown that both NOTCH and JAG1/NOCSF signaling pathways play important roles in fibrosis. In this study, we identified that NOTCH2 and JAG1 expression levels were higher in human kidney tissue from patients with tubule fibrosis. We also determined that NOTCH2 and JAG1 expression levels were higher in all analyzed kidney fibrosis models. Furthermore, we identified that NOTCH2 and JAG1 expression levels were higher in all analyzed fibrosis models. In vitro cellular and biochemical experiments showed that NOTCH2 and JAG1 expression levels were directly reprogrammed by the mitochondrial transcription factor A ( Tfam ). We also determined that NOTCH2 and JAG1 expression levels were higher in tubule cells than in fibroblasts, which is important for establishing that JAG1 and NOTCH2 are key regulators in fibrosis. In summary, our study demonstrated that NOTCH2 and JAG1 expression levels were higher in all analyzed kidney fibrosis models. In vitro cellular and biochemical experiments demonstrated that NOTCH2 and JAG1 act as direct targets of Tfam. Re-expression of Tfam prevented NOTCH2 and JAG1-induced metabolic reprogramming and prevented tubule fibrosis. In summary, our study demonstrated that NOTCH2 and JAG1 expression levels were higher in all analyzed kidney fibrosis models, which is important for establishing that JAG1 and NOTCH2 are key regulators in fibrosis.

The DNA repair protein BRCA2 is a large protein composed of three domains ( RAD51, RAD51A and RAD51B ) that are involved in the repair of DNA double strand breaks. We have created fusions composed of different domains to study how the interaction of these domains affects BRCA2 activity. These fusions revealed that the interaction of the DNA binding domain is critical for BRCA2 activity, whereas the interaction of the RAD51A and RAD51B domains is not. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the C-terminal domain is essential for BRCA2 activity in some contexts. Finally, we show that the small peptide DSS1 is essential for BRCA2 activity, but not for its absence. Our results reveal that different domains of BRCA2 have distinct roles in DNA repair and that the function of the DNA binding domain is largely determined by the interactions with its cellular partner. These results provide insight into the complex nature of the BRCA2 protein and the nature of its interactions with other proteins in the DNA repair pathway. Finally, our results provide a framework for future studies investigating how alterations in BRCA2 function may lead to disease.

Huddling is a complex property exhibited by groups of animals. Huddling is a puzzle for evolutionary biology, since it is thought that complex thermal properties of groups can emerge spontaneously through simple interactions between individuals. Yet, rodent huddling is a complex system, being described by a set of differential equations known as the huddle. Each individual in the group combines a huddle of four rodent pups into a complex structure. Computer simulations show that this system can reproduce the first emergent property of huddling—the transition from a ‘phase transition’ to a ‘pup flow’. However, the model tends to produce a huddle in which the group does not behave as a system, but rather as a system, like the two emergent properties we have described. We show that including an additional homeostatic term recovers the transition to a huddle, whereas inclusion of an additional homeostatic term recovers the transition to a large huddle. Our model therefore provides an explicit testable prediction: increasing the capacity of the individual to generate or conserve heat will increase the range of ambient temperatures over which adaptive thermoregulatory huddling will emerge.

Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, causes a potentially fatal infection in humans and animals. Nuclear translocation of the transcription factor, NF-κB, is the central initiating cellular event in the antimicrobial response. Here, we show that NF-κB p65 nuclear accumulation and NF-κB-dependent transcription are inhibited in O. tsutsugamushi infected HeLa cells and/or primary macrophages, even in the presence of TNFα. O. tsutsugamushi modulates p65 subcellular localization by neither degrading it nor inhibiting IκBα degradation. Rather, it exploits host exportin 1 to mediate p65 nuclear export, as this phenomenon is leptomycin B-sensitive. Two ankyrin repeat-containing effectors, Ank1 and Ank6, each of which possess a C-terminal F-box and exhibit 58. 5% amino acid identity, are linked to the pathogen’s ability to modulate NF-κB. When ectopically expressed, both translocate to the nucleus, abrogate NF-κB-activated transcription in an exportin 1-independent manner. Flag-tagged Ank1 and Ank6 also bind importin β1, a host protein that is essential for the classical nuclear import pathway. Importazole, which blocks importin β1 activity, abrogates Ank1 and Ank6 nuclear translocation. The Ank1 and Ank6 regions that bind importin β1 also mediate their transport into the nucleus. Yet, these regions are distinct from those that bind p65/exportin 1. Our data reveal a novel mechanism by which O. tsutsugamushi modulates the activity and nuclear transport of NF-κB p65 and identify the first microbial proteins that co-opt both importin β1 and exportin 1 to antagonize a critical arm of the antimicrobial response.

Pyrophosphate ion ( PPi ) release is a signature step in each nucleotide addition cycle of transcription elongation. The kinetics and energetics of the process as well as how it proceeds with substantial conformational changes of the polymerase complex determine the mechano-chemical coupling mechanism of the transcription elongation. Here, we investigated detailed dynamics of the PPi release process in a single-subunit RNA polymerase ( RNAP ) from bacteriophage T7, implementing all-atom molecular dynamics simulations. We obtained a jump(from-cavity kinetic model of the PPi release utilizing extensive nanosecond MD simulations. We found that the PPi release in T7 RNAP is initiated by the PPi dissociation from two catalytic aspartic acids, followed by a comparatively slow jump-from-cavity activation process. Combining with a number of long MD simulations, we also found that the activation is hindered by charged residue associations as well as by local steric and hydrogen bond interactions. On the other hand, the activation is greatly assisted by a highly flexible lysine residue Lys472 that swings its side chain to pull PPi out. The mechanism can apply in general to single subunit RNA and DNA polymerases with similar molecular structures and conserved key residues. Remarkably, the flexible lysine residue or arginine residue appears to be a universal module that assists the PPi release even in multi-subunit RNAPs with charge facilitated hopping mechanisms. Our study thus supports the Brownian ratchet scenario of the mechano-chemical coupling in the transcription elongation of the single-subunit polymerase.

Gene regulatory networks are typically encoded by short DNA sequences that are recognized by proteins that bind to them ( transcription factors ). Each DNA sequence contains a unique motif, usually composed of a pair of positively charged residues that contact the DNA sequence. The sequence-specific binding of a transcription factor to a short DNA sequence motif can either enhance or inhibit its function. The precise nature of this interaction is often difficult to determine experimentally. We have developed a computational method, called dinucleotide weight tensor ( DWT ), that allows users to model the effect of transcription factor binding on a motif using arbitrary weights, or a set of weights, in a flexible way. We show that DWTs capture the interactions between transcription factors and DNA sequences more accurately than previous methods. This makes DWT a practical tool for the computational analysis of gene regulatory networks.

The complement system is an evolutionarily conserved complex of proteins that protects the host against infection by microbes. Deficiency of complement components can lead to increased susceptibility to infection and the development of severe complement-mediated pathology. In this study, we investigated how loss of complement components in mice affect the control of the pandemic influenza A ( H1N1 ) 2009 virus infection. We found that the complement system is important in conferring protection against the pandemic virus infection. In particular, the cross-talk between complement components was important for the efficient neutralization of the virus. The complement-mediated protection was mediated by both the complement pathway ( i. e., the classical and alternative pathways ) and the interaction between the complement and antigen presenting cells. Together, these results highlight the importance of complement cooperation in the protection against influenza infection.

In vertebrates, gene duplication is a major driver of evolutionary divergence. The duplication event is often assumed to have occurred in an ancestral genome, but the biological significance is not well understood. We have used the zebrafish model to investigate gene duplication and to investigate the functional significance of duplicated genes. We find that the duplicated genes are similar to one another, but have diverged in the control sequences that regulate the expression of the duplicated genes. These findings suggest that gene duplication has involved subfunctionalization of already duplicated genes.

In recent years, tick-borne diseases have been reported in Turkey, and tick species have been found to be able to transmit several tick-borne pathogens to humans. We aimed to investigate the presence of and the distribution of tick-borne pathogens affecting humans in Turkey. Ticks were collected from different parts of Ankara, the capital city of Turkey, in order to determine the presence of several tick-borne pathogens and their distribution. We detected two human pathogenic rickettsia species, R. velidum and R. slovaca, which are distributed in different tick species, and B. burgdorferi sensu stricto, which is very pathogenic for dogs. We also detected B. rossi, which is very pathogenic for dogs, and H. marginatum and H. excavatum, Hyalomma spp. ( nymph ) and Ha. parva. These results demonstrate the presence of several tick-borne pathogens affecting humans and animals, and they suggest that tick-borne pathogens should be taken into consideration in patients who had a tick bite in Turkey.

Abdominal fat is a highly heterogeneous tissue with subcutaneous and visceral fat components. We performed a genome-wide association study for body fat distribution among 5, 560 women and 4, 997 men from 4 population-based studies. Our results show that genetic variants are associated with body fat distribution in both subcutaneous and visceral fat. The most significant finding was in the FTO gene, which was previously associated with waist–hip ratio. We validated our findings in two independent cohorts, the European-American and the Japanese cohorts, and demonstrated that body fat distribution in both populations is sex-specific. We further validated our findings in the GIANT consortium data, and we detected a new genetic variant that is associated with visceral fat.

Enteroviruses ( EVs ) infecting African Non-Human Primates ( NHP ) are still poorly documented. This study was designed to characterize the genetic diversity of EVs among captive and wild NHP in Cameroon and to compare this diversity with that found in humans. We collected stool specimens in April 2008 in NHP housed in sanctuaries in Yaounde and neighborhoods. Moreover, stool specimens collected from wild NHP from June 2006 to October 2008 in the southern rain forest of Cameroon were considered. We found that EVs were genetically distinct from all existing types and were thus assigned as new types. One chimpanzee-derived virus was tentatively assigned as EV-J121 in the EV-J species. Two EVs from wild monkeys provisionally registered as EV-122 and EV-123 were found to belong to a candidate new species. Our study indicates that the genetic diversity of EVs among NHP is more important than previously known and could be the source of future new emerging human viral diseases.

The immune response to a wide variety of microbial pathogens requires activation of a variety of innate immune effectors. This activation requires integration of multiple inputs, including pathogen sensing, anti-pathogen immune responses and metabolic cues. To address how the innate immune system distinguishes between infectious and non-infectious insult, we used the intracellular bacterial pathogen Chlamydia trachomatis, an important human pathogen that causes sexually transmitted disease. Using primary murine bone marrow derived macrophages or human monocyte derived dendritic cells, we report that live, replicating Chlamydia trachomatis stimulates the host innate immune response by activating inflammasomes, a process which we demonstrate involves STING, an important transcription factor. Interestingly, exogenous delivery of a bacterial metabolite and STING ligand—cyclic di-AMP, recovered inflammasome activation to attenuated bacteria in a STING dependent manner thus indicating that a bacterial metabolite is a key factor initiating inflammasome activation through STING, independent of cGAS. These data provide insight into the mechanism of how the innate immune system can distinguish between infectious and non-infectious insult and the potential therapeutic use of bacterial metabolites.

Species interactions can be strongly influenced by environmental factors such as water availability. For example, plant–ant species interactions are often stronger when resources are limited. However, it is unclear whether the effects are indirect: water stress, which is a common environmental factor, can affect plant–ant symbioses. Here we show that the partners' investments in a widespread ant–plant symbiosis increase with water stress across 26 sites along a Meso Rican precipitation gradient. Under lower precipitation levels, Cordia alliodora trees invest more carbon in Azteca ants via phloem-feeding scale insects that provide the ants with sugars, and the ants provide better defense of the carbon-producing leaves. Under water stress, the trees have smaller carbon pools. A model of the carbon trade-offs for the mutualistic partners shows that the observed strategies can arise from the carbon costs of rare but extreme events of herbivory in the rainy season. Thus, water limitation, together with the risk of herbivory, increases the strength of a carbon-based mutualism.

Neurons of the statoacoustic ganglion ( SAG ) are responsible for transmitting auditory and vestibular information from the inner ear to the hindbrain. SAG neuroblasts originate in the floor of the otic vesicle. New neuroblasts soon delaminate from this site and migrate to the hindbrain while continuing to proliferate, a process called “transit-amplifying”. Regulation of these events is only partially understood. Fgf is known to be important for neuroblast specification within the ear, but how it is coordinated with Notch signaling is unknown. Here we describe a novel pathway that regulates neurogenesis in the zebrafish inner ear. We find that the transcription factor Tfap2a coordinates multiple signaling pathways to promote neurogenesis in the zebrafish inner ear. Blocking either Fgf or Notch signaling causes less dramatic acceleration of SAG neural development without neuronal death, whereas blocking both pathways mimics all observed effects of Tfap2a overexpression, including apoptosis of mature neurons. Directly blocking either Fgf or Notch signaling causes less dramatic acceleration of SAG neural development without neuronal death, whereas blocking both pathways mimics effects that are reversed by overexpression of Tfap2a. Our results suggest that Tfap2a, through Bmp7a, modulates Fgf and Notch signaling to control the duration, amount and speed of SAG neural development.

The gammaherpesviruses are a large subfamily of human and animal pathogens. This subfamily includes the human oncogenic viruses Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ) and the rhesus monkey rhadinovirus ( RRV ). Lytic infection with RRV results in the production of infectious virions and viral gene expression. During lytic infection, RRV activates the pERK/ERK signaling pathway, which is critical for many cellular processes including cell growth and differentiation. Although pERK and ERK have been shown to be essential for RRV pathogenesis, the precise mechanism by which these two pathways cooperate to promote viral gene expression remains unclear. Here, we demonstrate that pERK2, a protein that is activated by RRV, and the RRV protein, ORF45, form a complex that promotes the nuclear accumulation of pERK2 and its downstream targets, thereby promoting lytic gene expression and viral gene expression. We also show that pERK2 and ERK1 are co-localized in the nucleus during infection, and that activation of pERK downstream targets is preserved throughout infection. Our data suggest that pERK2 may have the potential to serve as a molecular bridge between the nuclear and cytoplasmic ERK pathways, promoting lytic gene expression while also preserving robust activation of pERK downstream targets.

Chromatin is a complex structure composed of DNA and histones, which are the building blocks of chromatin. The structure and function of chromatin is highly dynamic and tightly regulated. In particular, chromatin structure affects transcription and gene expression. Recent work has shown that changes in chromatin structure affect the levels of several chromatin-associated proteins. One such protein is the DNA-binding factor 2 ( BDF2 ). Previous work showed that BDF2 expression is regulated through splicing and post-transcriptional mechanisms. However, it was unclear whether other nuclear mechanisms, such as nuclear RNA degradation, regulate BDF2 expression. Here we show that BDF2 is subject to an additional level of nuclear RNA degradation through the RNA destruction pathway. We show that the RNA destruction pathway is hyper-activated by salt stress and repressed by DNA damage, and that mutations that reverse this hyper-activation also repress the RNA destruction pathway. We also show that the specific levels of BDF2 mRNA are important for determining its function. Finally, we show that the RNA destruction pathway is important for cell survival in a specific environmental condition, and that its activity is controlled by splicing.

Aedes aegypti is the most important vector of human arboviruses such as dengue, zika, and chikungunya viruses. Indoor residual spraying ( IRS ) has been used effectively to control Ae. aegypti populations in humans and vectors, but insecticide resistance in vector populations has been found to compromise control efficacy. This study evaluates the efficacy of IRS against Ae. aegypti populations in houses with either deltamethrin ( to which local Ae. aegypti express a high degree of resistance ) or bendiocarb ( to which local Ae. aegypti are fully susceptible ) as compared to untreated control houses in Merida, Mexico. A randomized controlled trial was used to quantify the efficacy of IRS against Ae. aegypti infestation during 3 months post-spraying. Results demonstrate that vector control efficacy can be significantly compromised when the insecticide resistance status of Ae. aegypti populations is not taken into consideration.

Honduras is the country with the highest burden of soil-transmitted helminthiasis ( STH ) worldwide. The country is also the country with the highest burden of malaria. The present study was done to estimate country-wide STH prevalence and intensity and malaria prevalence and nutritional status of school going children. A cross-sectional study was conducted following PAHO/WHO guidelines to select a sample of school going children of 3rd to 5th grades, representative of ecological regions in the country. A survey questionnaire was filled; anthropometric measures, stool sample for STH and blood sample for malaria were taken. A total of 2554 students were studied of which 43. 5% had one or more STH. Trichuriasis was the most prevalent ( 34% ) followed by ascariasis ( 22. 3% ) and hookworm ( 0. 9% ). Ecological regions II ( 59. 7% ) and VI ( 55. 6% ) in the north had the highest STH prevalence rates while IV ( 10. 6% ) had the lowest. Plasmodium vivax was detected by PCR in only 5 students ( 0. 2% ), all of which belonged to the same municipality; no P. falciparum infection was detected. The majority of children ( 83% ) had normal body mass index for their respective age but a significant proportion were overweight ( 10. 42% ) and obese ( 4. 35% ). Deworming campaigns would be necessary in ecological regions II and VI, where STH prevalence is >50%. High prevalence of obesity in school going children is a worrying trend and portends of future increase in obesity related diseases. Malaria prevalence, both symptomatic and asymptomatic, was low and provides evidence for Honduras to embark on elimination of the disease.

Hepatitis B virus ( HBV ) infection causes serious liver disease in humans, and a large proportion of HBV-infected individuals develop chronic liver disease. The HBV genome is organised in a multigene family, comprising 17 genes that encode proteins with various functions. Some of these genes show striking association with autoimmune diseases, whereas others appear to be important in antigen presentation. In chickens, a single gene, B12, which is part of the major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ), is associated with one or two autoimmune diseases. Here, we use whole genome sequence analysis and a combination of functional and biochemical analyses to show that the B12 gene family is dynamic expanding and contracting. This expansion is likely driven by two major evolutionary forces—combination and/or deletion—of the B12 gene region, which may be driven by other major evolutionary forces. Our analysis also suggests that the B12 gene family in chickens is undergoing much more rapid evolution than in mammals.

Acute gastroenteritis (AGE ) is a common illness affecting all age groups worldwide, causing an estimated three million deaths annually. Viruses such as rotavirus, adenovirus, and caliciviruses are a major cause of childhood illness, but in many patients a causal agent cannot be found despite extensive diagnostic testing. We investigated a case-control study of pediatric disease caused by viruses found in the Bocavirus genus, to identify a novel virus. We used molecular testing to amplify viral DNA from fecal specimens, and then sequenced the DNA to determine its origin. A novel virus was detected in one of the children. We have named this novel virus HBoV2. HBoV2 prevalence was greater than that of rotavirus in children, and it was higher than that of adenovirus in children with signs of disease. The prevalence of HBoV2 was also greater than that of rotavirus in children with signs of disease, and it was not associated with age. We have detected HBoV2 in two additional cases of childhood disease. These findings provide new insight into the biology of Bocavirus, and may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies for this important group of viral infections.

The human immune response to pathogens is driven by complex and highly regulated pathways that are initiated by genetic and environmental factors. Recent advances in modern molecular techniques now allow the identification of highly conserved axes of peripheral blood gene expression. Starting with a comparison of microarray gene expression profiles for a new dataset of 189 healthy adult participants in the Emory- Georgia Tech Center for Health Discovery and Well-Being ( CHDWB ) cohort, with a previously published study of 208 adult Moroccans, we identify nine axes each with between 99 and 1, 028 strongly co-regulated transcripts in common. Each axis is enriched for gene ontology categories related to sub-classes of blood and immune function, including T-cell and B-cell physiology and innate, adaptive, and anti-viral responses. We show that environmental factors, including lifestyle differences in Morocco and infection leading to active or latent tuberculosis, significantly impact specific axes, but that there is also significant heritability for the axis scores. In the context of personalized medicine, reanalysis of the longitudinal profile of one individual during and after infection with two respiratory viruses demonstrates that specific axes also characterize clinical incidents. This mode of analysis suggests the view that, rather than unique subsets of genes marking each class of disease, differential expression reflects movement along the major normal axes in response to environmental and genetic stimuli.

Zika virus ( ZIKV ) is a mosquito-borne virus that has emerged as a major public health concern in the New World. A growing number of studies have reported vector competence ( VC ) for Aedes mosquitoes from several areas of the world for ZIKV transmission. Some studies have concluded that Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus have a relatively low ability to transmit ZIKV. Our analysis of ten collections of Aedes aegypti and three collections of Ae. albopictus from Mexico shows that transmission rates are highly variable across collections, geographic regions and vector collection sites. Mexican Ae. aegypti had high rates of midgut infection, dissemination and salivary gland infection but low transmission rates. Mexican Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus are competent vectors of ZIKV. There is however large variation in vector competence among geographic sites and regions. At 14 days post infection, transmission rates varied from 8–51% in Ae. aegypti and from 2–26% in Ae. albopictus.

In this study, we used a task in which rats discriminated the rapid, dense microvibration sequences of the rat's whisker from the variable sequences of those sequences. We first showed that the temporal integration of those sequences is important for discriminating the sequences, and then used this temporal integration to gain insight into the neural representation of the sequences. Our results suggest that the whisker's input is not temporally integrated but rather combines the information from the sequences in a way that is not important for discriminating the sequences. Thus, the whisker's input is not temporally integrated but rather combines information from the sequences to guide the decision to enter a behavioral response.

Influenza A virus, one of the most common causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide, is maintained in a cycle involving virus assembly and release, viral antigenic particle production, and subsequent infection of a host cell. The influenza virus genome is composed of eight to ten gene segments, each of which is composed of a single or more viral genes. Thus, influenza A virus is composed of a genetic pool that comprises all influenza A viruses, and the influenza A virus genome is comprised of the complete viral genome, the hemagglutinin ( H18 ), and the neuraminidase ( NMDA ). The hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes are highly conserved among all influenza A viruses, but the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes are divergent among influenza A viruses. This unique mode of influenza A virus infection is likely to result in host adaptation and the evolution of influenza A virus strains with novel biological properties. Using a combination of molecular and virological methods, we have identified the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of a new influenza A virus from Central American fruit bats. We show that the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of this virus are highly divergent among all other influenza A viruses, suggesting that these viruses may represent an important reservoir for influenza A virus evolution.

Schistosomiasis is a severe disease caused by parasitic worms of the genus Schistosoma. The parasites infect an estimated 250 million people worldwide, most of whom live in developing countries. There are no vaccines to prevent schistosome infection, and the only way to prevent infection is to give deworming to people living in endemic areas. We have previously shown that a gut-derived cysteine peptidase, cathepsin B1, is highly protective against both schistosome challenge and infection of hamsters. Here we show that another gut-derived cysteine peptidase, S. mansoni cathepsin L3, induces highly significant immune responses and is much more protective than SmCB1 alone. We also show that combining the two schistosome peptides in a single vaccine does not induce significantly stronger immune responses or increased protection than using each schistosome antigen alone. This suggests that a combination of the two schistosome peptides may be much more protective than each schistosome antigen alone. The cysteine peptidases have important roles in both schistosome and other blood-dwelling parasites. The results suggest that these cysteine peptidases should be advanced to clinical trials in humans.

West Nile virus ( WNV ) is an important human pathogen causing outbreaks in the United States, Canada, and the Caribbean. Currently, there are no licensed vaccines or antiviral drugs available for human use. The NS3 protease ( NS3pro ) is an essential viral protein that is critical for the virus lifecycle. NS3pro is a highly conserved and multifunctional protein that is necessary for the NS3 replication cycle. NS3pro has been successfully used as a target for drug development against other viruses, including dengue viruses, yellow fever virus, and Zika virus. In this work, we have identified a small molecule inhibitor of NS3pro, and validated its activity by multiple means. The inhibitor has a good molecular recognition and binding affinity for NS3pro. It is further validated by a variety of biological assays. The inhibitor has great potential as a lead compound for the development of new drugs against WNV and dengue viruses.

In the present study, we report that Bacillus anthracis ( the Bacillus anthracis toxin ) can induce a novel form of functional anergy in NKT cells and that this anergy is mediated by the toxin, which targets TCR signaling pathway. The toxin disrupts TCR-induced cytokine secretion and reduces MAP kinase signaling in NKT cells, which in turn leads to decreased TCR-induced MAP kinase signaling. The results suggest that Bacillus anthracis can inhibit TCR signaling pathway in NKT cells and that this inhibition contributes to immune evasion by the pathogen.

Progressive cystic kidney degeneration underlies diverse renal diseases, including the most common cause of kidney failure, autosomal dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease ( PKD ). Genetic analyses of patients and animal models have identified several key drivers of this disease. The precise molecular and cellular changes underlying cystogenesis remain, however, elusive. We show here that the Drosophila translational regulator Bicaudal C ( BicC, the fly ortholog of vertebrate BICC1 implicated in renal cystogenesis ), binds to Drosophila ( d- ) myc mRNA in tubules. Elevated d-Myc protein levels were a cause of tubular degeneration in BicC mutants. Activation of the Target of Rapamycin ( TOR ) kinase pathway, another common feature of PKD, was found in BicC mutant flies. Rapamycin administration substantially reduced the cystic phenotype in flies. We propose that Drosophila may serve as a genetically tractable model for dissecting the evolutionarily-conserved molecular mechanisms of renal cystogenesis.

Schistosomes are parasitic flatworms that cause a chronic, debilitating disease in humans and animals. They invade human skin when cercariae penetrate the skin. Cercariae are released into the skin, penetrate the epidermis, and penetrate the dermal layers to reach the gut. Little is known about the molecules released by the parasite and the host response to invasion. We analyzed the proteins released by cercariae and host skin cells from the skin, and found that a large number of proteins were released. These included proteins involved in cell killing, as well as proteins proposed to control immune responses. Some of these proteins were also implicated in protecting the parasites against oxidative stress, and thus may be important for host survival. We also identified specific proteins from the skin cells that were invaded by cercariae, allowing us to further investigate the role of these proteins in host defense against the parasite.

Identifying the mutations that have beneficial effects on fitness is critical for predicting adaptation. Here, we investigate how beneficial mutations are distributed on the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a major opportunistic pathogen of humans and animals. We find that the beneficial effects of mutations are exponential with the fitness of the wild type. This result is consistent with theory and has several important implications. First, it indicates that beneficial mutations are distributed exponentially, rather than in a constant distribution as previously predicted by theory. Second, it shows that beneficial mutations are much more common than expected based on theory alone. Finally, it demonstrates that there is no population genetic explanation to the observation that beneficial mutations are not common in the wild type and that most mutations have large effects on fitness.

Biological membranes are composed of a lipid bilayer mixed with proteins. The lipid bilayer component flotillin is a paradigm for such a mixed component. It is present in vertebrates and is associated with the type of so-called detergent-resistant microdomains. Detergent-resistant microdomains are a common feature of bacterial and eukaryotic membranes. They have also been shown to be involved in several important functions of bacteria, such as virulence and antibiotic resistance. We show that bacterial flotillin structures are based on their ability to self-oligomerize. However, bacterial flotillin structures are very different from those of eukaryotic organisms. We also show that two bacterial flotillins, FloA and FloT, form complexes with other proteins in a similar way. However, we also show that these bacterial flotillin structures do not colocalize in a common microdomain, and consequently do not move together. We further show that these bacterial flotillin structures can be detected by electron microscopy. The analysis of their dynamics shows that FloA and FloT are not able to colocalize. Our data therefore reveal that the bacterial membrane contains defined-sized domains rather than functional microdomains dependent on flotillins.

In the context of replication fork arrest, recombination between homologous chromosomes may be induced by the loss of DNA topological constraint, such as the formation of collapsed replication forks. The resolvase Mus81p is involved in the repair of UV-induced DNA damage, and its activity is required for the repair of the UV-induced DNA breaks. In this study, we show that unprocessed pyrimidine dimers also induce recombination between homologs. In the context of replication fork arrest, Mus81p is required for most of the UV-induced inter-homolog recombination events. Our results also suggest that the Mus81p-associated cleavage of replication forks may play a role in recombination between sister chromatids.

In this study, we used sequencing technology and bioinformatics to identify somatic mitochondrial DNA mutations across 527 human tumors and 14 cancer types. We identified somatic mutations in the genomic region around genes, but also in the transcriptomic region. Our results indicate that somatic mutations in the genomic region around genes are a major source of functional mitochondrial DNA mutations in cancer cells. Additionally, we found a strong mutational bias in RNA transcripts. This bias is consistent with the endogenous source of mutations, but it is explained by errors in the processing of polycistronic tRNA transcripts. Our study gives insights into the role of mitochondrial DNA in cancer and answers questions regarding mitochondrial tRNA biogenesis that are difficult to address in controlled experimental systems.

Chlamydia pneumoniae is a major cause of human and animal illness. Despite its public health importance, the biology of this bacterial pathogen remains poorly understood. We investigated the genetic diversity of 30 C. pneumoniae isolates from diverse geographical locations, from both human and animal origin. We show that the animal isolates are significantly more diverse than the isolates of human origin. Furthermore, we show that C. pneumoniae isolates could be grouped into five major genotypes, A-E, with A, B, D and E genotypes linked by geographical location, whereas genotype C was found across multiple continents. Our evidence strongly supports two separate animal-to-human cross species transfer events in the evolutionary history of this pathogen. The C. pneumoniae human genotype identified in the USA, Canada, Taiwan, Iran, Japan, Korea and Australia ( non-Indigenous ) most likely originated from a single amphibian or reptilian lineage, which appears to have been previously geographically widespread. We identified a separate human lineage present in two Australian Indigenous isolates ( independent geographical locations ). This lineage is distinct and is present in Australian amphibians as well as a range of Australian marsupials.

A variety of model systems, from single-cell to whole-cell organisms, are used to investigate the cellular basis of chemotaxis. The most popular model for chemotaxis is the Escherichia coli model, which describes a network of six-component chemoreceptors and an adaptation process driven by the mixed input signal. The model is simple and well-posed, and has been used to investigate the response to different inputs in different cell types. We have extended the model to incorporate the adaptation process and to investigate the effect of different inputs on bacterial chemotaxis. Our results show that optimal chemotaxis is observed in a narrow range of CheA kinase activity. We also show that the CheB phosphorylation feedback improves chemotaxis by shifting the average CheY-P concentration to fit the motor operating range. Our results suggest that in liquid media the variability in adaptation times among cells may be evolutionary favorable to ensure coexistence of subpopulations that will be optimally tactic in different gradients. However, in a pore-forming medium such variability appears to be less important, because structure may be the main factor in the selection against subpopulations with low levels of adaptation enzymes. RapidCell is available from the authors upon request.

Biological networks are often asymmetric, i. e., smaller networks tend to be more efficient at carrying out their functions. Why organisms exhibit this phenomenon is a long-standing question in systems biology. The West, Brown, Enquist ( WBE ) model postulates that the evolution of metabolic networks is driven by selection to maximize how vascular networks can “fill” space yet minimize internal transport distances and resistances. The WBE model provides a simple way to predict how networks evolve and how they can be influenced by evolution. However, a key problem is that, in some cases, the underlying assumptions are not necessary or sufficient to predict how networks will evolve. Here, we develop a general network model that incorporates asymmetry into the WBE model and show how it can be used to predict how networks evolve.

The visual system is composed of a network of excitatory and inhibitory neurons whose connections are not specific at the time of eye opening, but become specific later on. The recurrent activity of the network, which is thought to enhance function, is a consequence of the Hebbian plasticity that modifies connectivity in this network. Previous studies have mostly focused on simple models, and have been unable to capture the specific connectivity in large-scale networks. Here, we show how recurrent connectivity can be established in large-scale networks, and how the specificity of activity guides the process of Hebbian learning. Our results demonstrate the cooperation between Hebbian plasticity and network dynamics in the emergence of specificity in large-scale networks with synaptic plasticity.

When a gash or gestures was made in a confluent layer of epithelial cells, the cells moved to fill in the “wound. ” In some cases, such as in wounded embryonic chick wing buds, the movement of the cells is driven by cortical actin contraction ( i. e., a purse string mechanism ), which is thought to be regulated by cell signaling. In adult tissue, though, cells apparently crawl to close wounds. At the single cell level, this crawling is driven by the dynamics of the cell's actin cytoskeleton, which is regulated by a complex biochemical network, and cell signaling has been proposed to play a significant role in directing cells to move into the denuded area. However, wounds made in monolayers of Madin-Darby canine kidney ( MDCK ) cells still close even when a row of cells is deactivated at the periphery of the wound, and recent experiments show complex, highly-correlated cellular motions that extend tens of cell lengths away from the boundary. These experiments suggest that wound healing is predominantly a mechanical process that is modified, but not produced, by cell-cell signaling.

Group A streptococcus ( GAS, Streptococcus pyogenes ) is the cause of a variety of clinical conditions, ranging from pharyngitis to autoimmune disease. Peptide-major histocompatibility complex class II ( pMHCII ) tetramers have recently emerged as a highly sensitive means to quantify pMHCII-specific CD4+ helper T cells and evaluate their contribution to both protective immunity and autoimmune complications induced by specific bacterial pathogens. In lieu of identifying an immunodominant peptide expressed by GAS, a surrogate peptide ( 2W ) was fused to the M1 protein on the surface of GAS to allow in-depth analysis of the CD4+ helper T cell response in C57BL/6 mice that express the I-Ab MHCII molecule. Following intranasal inoculation with GAS-2W, antigen-experienced 2W:I-Ab-specific CD4+ T cells were identified in the nasal-associated lymphoid tissue ( NALT ) that produced IL-17A or IL-17A and IFN-γ if infection was recurrent. The dominant Th17 response was also dependent on the intranasal route of inoculation; intravenous or subcutaneous inoculations produced primarily IFN-γ+ 2W:I-Ab+ CD4+ T cells. IL-17A production by 2W:I-Ab-specific T cells and the capacity of mice to survive infection depended on the innate cytokine IL-6. IL-6-deficient mice that survived infection became long-term carriers despite the presence of abundant IFN-γ-producing 2W:I-Ab-specific CD4+ T cells. Our results suggest that an imbalance between IL-17- and IFN-γ-producing CD4+ T cells could contribute to GAS carriage in humans.

Enzymes are biological macromolecules that catalyze a large number of reactions in the cell. They are thus essential for living organisms. An important task of enzymes is to catalyze a specific reaction. An important question in enzyme biology is to understand how an enzyme makes specific activity. The sequence-specific binding site of an enzyme can be inferred from the amino acid sequence of the protein in the cell. However, the binding sites of many enzymes do not differ much from each other. We present a general probabilistic framework that can be applied to predict the substrate specificity of different enzymes. We design our framework to be easy to use and to be applicable to different organisms and enzymes. We use several biological and structural properties of a yeast methyltransferase to predict its substrate specificity. Our results show that the majority of the predicted substrates are confirmed experimentally. Our approach can be applied to predict the substrate specificity of other enzymes and is not tied to any particular enzyme sequence. We also show that our method can be used to predict general substrate specificity of other enzymes.

A majority of cell-surface receptors are formed by proteins interacting with other proteins. Such interactions are mediated by a large number of residues in the protein, and the charge of these residues is typically determined by their side-chains. The interaction between a protein and another molecule is carried out by a charged residue that must be protonated to reach its functional state. The protonation state of the ionizable residue is dependent on the pH conditions of the proteins and local protein side-chains. In this work, we present a computational docking approach that can sample the local protonation states of five ionizable residues on the surfaces of proteins and other biomolecules in a flexible manner. The method is computationally very efficient and can be applied to a large number of proteins. It can be used to improve the prediction of pH-dependent binding affinities for other proteins of interest. We also demonstrate that it can be used to guide protein design to fit the local protonation state.

The nervous system of the vertebrate brain consists of a network of neuronal cells that communicate with each other using specialized cell–cell junctions. This network is formed by the precise assembly of neuronal circuits into layers of synapses. A crucial step in this process is the formation of the synaptic connections between the neurons. These connections are mediated by the binding of a specific protein, which is expressed on the surface of the neuronal cell, to a specific receptor on the cell surface. This binding event is mediated by matching recognition molecules between the two cell surfaces. Although these recognition molecules are known to be involved in the formation of synapses, the mechanisms that regulate their expression remain poorly understood. In this work, we use the Drosophila visual system, which is highly tractable and evolutionarily conserved, to study the role of the transcription factor Otd in regulating the expression of a group of proteins that control neuronal activity. We show that Otd is required for the expression of the proteins that control neuronal activity. We further show that otd is involved in the regulation of the synaptic targeting of the R8 photoreceptor, which is involved in detecting the colour of a stimulus. Our results suggest that otd is a key component of the gene regulatory network that controls the synaptic targeting of neurons in the vertebrate nervous system.

Protein–DNA interactions are crucial for many cellular processes. The characterization of these interactions has been extensively studied, but the characterization of the protein–DNA interactions is still challenging. Here we report a network view of the protein–DNA interaction space that can be used to investigate protein–DNA interactions. The present network representation provides a holistic view of the interacting surface and has been reported here for the first time. The second part of the study involves the analyses of the network in terms of clusters of interacting residues and the identification of highly connected residues ( hubs ) along the protein–DNA interface. A predominance of deoxyribose–amino acid clusters in β-sheet proteins, distinction of the interface clusters in helix–turn–helix, and the zipper-type proteins would not have been possible by conventional pairwise interaction analysis. Additionally, we propose a potential classification scheme for a set of protein–DNA complexes on the basis of the protein–DNA interface clusters. This provides a general idea of how the proteins interact with the different components of DNA in different complexes.

Inter-protein interactions are often mediated by flexible loops that experience conformational dynamics on the microsecond to millisecond time scales. Nuclear magnetic resonance ( NMR ) relaxation studies can map these dynamics. However, defining the network of inter-converting conformers that underlies the relaxation data remains generally challenging. Here, we combine NMR relaxation experiments with simulation to visualize networks of inter-converting conformers. We demonstrate our approach with the apo Pin1-WW domain, for which NMR has revealed a flexible loop in the millisecond range. We sample and cluster the free energy landscape using Markov State Models ( MSM ) with major and minor exchange states with high correlation with the NMR relaxation data and low NOE violations. These MSM are hierarchical ensembles of slowly interconverting, metastable macrostates and rapidly interconverting microstates. We found a low population state that consists primarily of holo-like conformations and is a “hub” visited by most pathways between macrostates. Our results suggest that conformational equilibria between holo-like and alternative conformers pre-exist in the intrinsic dynamics of apo Pin1-WW. Analysis using MutInf, a mutual information method for quantifying correlated motions, reveals that WW dynamics not only play a role in substrate recognition, but also may help couple the substrate binding site on the WW domain to the one on the catalytic domain.

Schistosomiasis is a chronic, debilitating disease caused by parasitic worms of the genus Schistosoma. Current control strategies focus on prevention rather than on drug or vaccine development. Understanding the biology of the parasite and the interaction of the parasite with the human host is therefore crucial for developing and refining new drugs and vaccines. In this study, we used a bioinformatic method to identify genes essential for parasite development. Our results provide a comprehensive description of the gene expression profile of S. mansoni during the development of three different life cycle stages in freshwater snails, and also reveal the potential involvement of various parasite-specific gene products in the regulation of schistosome development. We identified a group of genes, sharing no known sequence similarity outside the Platyhelminthes, which are likely to be essential for parasite survival. Our results provide a basis for further investigations into the roles of these genes in schistosome development, which may lead to the identification of novel drug and vaccine targets.

Hookworm is one of the most common parasitic worms in humans. Infection with hookworm is widespread in southern Lao PDR and can be severe and long lasting, especially in children and young adults. Previous research in the southern part of Lao PDR revealed high prevalence rates of hookworm infection. This study investigated the spatial distribution of hookworm infection and intensity, and to investigate risk factors in the province of Champasack, southern Lao PDR. We found a high prevalence of hookworm infection and intensity in the province, and that there was little evidence for spatial clustering. Infection risk was also associated with higher socioeconomic status. Women aged 50 years and above harbored the heaviest hookworm infection intensities. Our results suggest that control efforts should be intensified in the Champasack province, particularly in mountainous areas.

Streptococcus pneumoniae ( the pneumococcus ) is one of the most important bacterial pathogens worldwide, causing 1. 5 million annual hospital-acquired infections. The emergence of multi-resistant strains has made the need for novel antibiotic approaches to treat pneumococcal infections urgent. A deeper understanding of the mechanisms of ribosome assembly and the roles of the post-transcriptional factors in the regulation of translation is a prerequisite for the development of successful antimicrobial drugs. The present study has shown that the dual enzymatic activities of RlmCD are established by structural features of the full-length protein. Notably, the structural rearrangement of the side-chain of the mRNA substrate containing U43 was observed to play an important role in the determination of the dual enzymatic activities of RlmCD. Furthermore, the in-vitro methyltransferase assay and the electrophoretic mobility shift assay were performed to validate the findings. Overall, our complex structures allow for a better understanding of the dual functional mechanism of RlmCD, suggesting useful implications for the evolution of the RumA-type enzyme and the potential development of antibiotic drugs against S. pneumoniae.

Malaria is a disease that kills thousands of people each year. The two main agents of human malaria, Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum, can induce severe anemia and provoke strong, complex immune reactions. Which dynamical behaviors of host immune and erythropoietic responses would foster control of infection, and which would lead to runaway parasitemia and/or severe anemia? Here we developed differential equation models of interacting parasite and red blood cell populations modulated by host immune and erythropoietic responses. We found that simulated infections with the highest parasitemia tended to be those with ineffective innate immunity even if antibodies were present. We also compared infections with dyserythropoiesis ( reduced red blood cell production during infection ) to those with compensatory erythropoiesis ( boosted RBC production ) or a fixed basal RBC production rate. Dyserythropoiesis tended to reduce parasitemia slightly but at a cost to the host of aggravating anemia. Our simulations suggest that P. vivax can induce severe anemia as readily as P. falciparum for the same type of immune response, though P. vivax attacks a much smaller subset of RBCs. Since most P. vivax infections are nonlethal clinically, this suggests that P. falciparum adaptations for countering or evading immune responses are more effective than those of P. vivax.

We have developed a new method, named GISMO, to identify conserved regions among diverse sequences and to use this information to infer the presence of protein insertions or deletions ( indels ). The method is based on a top-down strategy, first identifying regions that are shared by all the input sequences, then aligning closely related subgroups in tandem. We show that the method is more accurate than existing methods. In particular, it infers gap penalties between indels and insertions in each sequence. This is the first time that a method based on a Bayesian statistical framework has been shown to be able to discriminate the relative positions of indels from insertions. We also show that the method is able to discriminate between conserved domains present in a large number of sequences, which is a useful feature to identify conserved protein domains. The method is widely used in the literature and is currently being applied to other protein sequences. We have used the method to analyze 408 protein sequences from NCBI Conserved Domain Database.

The innate immune response provides a critical defence against microbial infections, including viruses. This response includes the recognition of virus-derived RNA by pattern recognition receptors ( PRRs ) and the production of type I interferons ( IFNβ ), which are crucial for the initiation of an anti-viral state. The induction of IFNβ is governed by a complex network of signalling cascades, including the PRRs and the RIG-I-like helicases ( RLHs ). In this study, we demonstrate that the Nemo-related protein, optineurin ( NRP/FIP2 ), has a role in the inhibition of virus-triggered IFNβ induction. Optineurin blocked IFNβ induction by several means, including the formation of a protein complex with TBK1 and TRAF3, and ubiquitination, which is essential for the correct sub-cellular localisation and the inhibitory function of optineurin. This work identifies optineurin as a critical regulator of antiviral signalling and potential target for future antiviral therapy.

Dengue is the most common mosquito-borne viral disease in humans, with 50–100 million cases annually. It is caused by four serotypes of dengue virus, DENV1 through DENV-4. Infection by a DENV serotype is assumed to provide life-long protection against re-infection by that serotype. We investigated the validity of this fundamental assumption during a large dengue epidemic that occurred in Iquitos, Peru, in 2010–2011. We estimated the age-dependent prevalence of DENV-2 neutralizing antibodies from longitudinal cohort studies conducted between 1993 and 2010. In contrast to previous estimates, we found that DENV-2 cases were older than expected. We also estimated the age distribution of DENV-2 cases and found that the DENV-2 cases had a younger age distribution than the inapparent cases. We also found evidence of pre-existing DENV-2 antibodies being associated with an incomplete reduction in the frequency of symptoms. Our data indicate that incomplete protection against homologous DENV re-infection may be incomplete in some circumstances, which provides context for the limited vaccine efficacy against DENV-2 in recent trials.

Chromatin, a complex of DNA and histone proteins, is a fundamental unit of chromatin in all eukaryotic cells. Histone proteins are essential components of chromatin, but the roles of many histone proteins during the cell cycle are poorly understood. Linker histones are a highly conserved histone family across eukaryotic cells and are important for maintaining genome compaction and repressing gene expression. Here, we have analyzed linker histone H1. 5 in human differentiated cells from all three embryonic germ layers but not embryonic stem cells. H1. 5 binds to both intergenic and genic regions of the genome in differentiated human cells, and we found that H1. 5 binds to genes that encode membrane and membrane-related proteins. Strikingly, H1. 5 binds to gene families that encode key components of chromatin. H1. 5 is required for repressing genes that encode membrane and membrane-related proteins. H1. 5 enrichment is also required for H3K9me2 enrichment, and is required for chromatin compaction. H1. 5 depletion results in loss of SIRT1 and H3K9me2, increased chromatin accessibility, deregulated gene expression, and decreased cell growth. Our data reveal for the first time a specific and novel function for linker histone H1. 5 in maintaining condensed chromatin at defined gene families in differentiated human cells.

Cancer is characterized by aberrant gene expression that underlies the disease process. However, the complex nature of gene expression leads to the generation of a highly diverse set of cellular alterations, each with different prognostic potential. Identifying those alterations that are responsible for the disease process and determining the cellular and molecular basis of these alterations are important to provide a more complete understanding of cancer and its associated disease. In this study, we used a combined approach of functional and genomic approaches to identify genes that are involved in the disease process. We used the colorectal cancer cell line MEK/ERK pathway as a target pathway for analysis of the global transcriptome alterations that occur in colorectal cancer cells. We identified a set of genes that show a correlation with the expression of the MAPK pathway. We validated the association of one of these genes, Y-box binding protein 1 ( YBX1 ), with poor prognosis in colorectal cancer patients. Our study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the disease process in colorectal cancer and provides a valuable resource to further study this disease.

Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi ( S. Typhi ) causes typhoid fever, a severe diarrheal disease, whereas S. Tyhimurium ( S. Tyhimurium ) causes localized gastroenteritis in humans. We used a novel Salmonella–S. Typhi chemotaxis assay to investigate the role of the virulence-associated ( Vi ) polysaccharide, capsule biosynthesis genes, in the induction of bacterial-guided chemotaxis by S. Typhi in the presence of Salmonella. Surprisingly, we found that S. Typhi chemotaxis is dependent on the presence of complement component 5a ( C5a ) and C5a receptor ( C5aR ). Deletion of capsule biosynthesis genes markedly enhanced the chemotactic response of neutrophils in vitro. Furthermore, deletion of capsule biosynthesis genes heightened the association of S. Typhi with neutrophils in vivo through a C5aR-dependent mechanism. Collectively, these data suggest that expression of the virulence-associated ( Vi ) polysaccharide of S.
