Typhi obstructs bacterial-guided neutrophil chemotaxis.

The most common form of bacteria is the bacterium Bacillus subtilis, and it is well established that it is able to colonize a wide range of environmental niches. However, not all bacteria are as good at colonizing soil as some are, and the reasons for this are not well understood. We have previously shown that the Pseudomonas fluorescens genome encodes ten genes that are involved in environmental adaptation. In this work, we present a new set of genes, which we designate ‘non-predicted’ or ‘hidden’. These genes are not predicted to encode proteins, but encode a general protein sequence, and we show that this protein is important for efficient colonization of soil. In addition, we have identified one of these hidden genes, iiv14, as an important factor for soil colonization. This work demonstrates that P. fluorescens is able to utilize a hidden gene for environmental adaptation, and that the presence of this gene is important for the ability of the bacteria to colonize soil.

Dengue is the most important mosquito-borne viral disease in humans, and it is a major health concern in areas such as Hanoi, Vietnam. Following a dengue outbreak in 2009, Hanoi was the only dengue endemic area in Vietnam. We used a temporal and spatial analysis of 25, 983 dengue cases notified in Hanoi between 1998 and 2009. We found a significant increase in the incidence of dengue cases over the period 1999–2008 ( incidence rate ratio = 1. 38, 95% confidence interval = 1. 20–1. 58, p value = 0. 002 ). The age of notified dengue cases in Hanoi is high, with a median age of 23 years ( mean 26. 3 years ). After adjusting for changes in population age structure, there was no statistically significant change in the median or mean age of dengue cases over the period studied. We found that districts in the central, highly urban, area of Hanoi are the most dengue-endemic area in Vietnam. This trend needs to be confirmed with serological surveys, followed by studies to determine the underlying drivers of this emergence.

Chagas disease is a chronic illness affecting millions of people in South America. The drugs currently available to treat the disease are toxic and are associated with a range of side effects. There is an urgent need for new drugs against this disease. In this work, we used X-ray crystallography to determine the structure of the active site of an essential enzyme of Trypanosoma cruzi, Proline Racemerase, which is the only enzyme with structural homology to the human counterpart. The structure of the protein bound to its inhibitors allowed us to design a highly potent compound, NG-P27. The inhibitor bound to the enzyme in a specific way, with the Cys300 sulfur atom of the catalytic site acting as an irreversible trap. This allowed us to design a model of the enzyme that could be used to design inhibitors that trap the enzyme in a specific manner. Our results support the use of a strategy that allows to link structure to function, including a model of the catalytic site in the active site, and drug design.

Transposons, or “jumping genes, ” are mobile genetic elements that have the capacity to move within the genome. They are known to cause genetic instability, which is the basis for many genetic diseases. Cells have evolved mechanisms to silence transposons, which is referred to as “Small interfering RNA silencing, ” or “silencing in trans. ” An important mechanism for silencing transposons is the telomeric trans-silencing effect, which was discovered in 1953. This mechanism is unique to Drosophila melanogaster, a species that is widely used in genetics. We show here that the telomeric trans-silencing effect is a result of a repressive epigenetic mechanism that involves a maternal factor and a small RNA silencing pathway, which was recently discovered in the fruit fly. Our results support the hypothesis that this mechanism was originally proposed to silence transposons in the germline, and we propose that it was co-opted by a telomeric transposon to repress its own insertion in the genome. This study provides insight into the genetic properties of a germline-specific small RNA silencing pathway.

A major challenge in biology is to understand how genetically heterogeneous populations arise and how these populations respond to selective forces. It has been shown that clonal dominance, a phenomenon where a large number of cells are dominated by one clone, arises when selection favors a specific genotype in a population. We studied this phenomenon in vitro by growing tumor cells in the presence of mutation and selection. We developed a computational model that accurately simulated the clonal dominance that develops in the experiments, and we found that this model can reproduce the clonal dominance that develops in the experiments. We also examined whether there was a mechanism that could explain the clonal dominance phenomenon, and found that clonal dominance is indeed a result of selection on clones with fast-dividing properties. Our results thus provide important insight into the mechanisms that underlie clonal dominance in a variety of biological scenarios.

Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a leading cause of arboviral diseases in humans worldwide. After the largest dengue outbreak in Taiwan in the past three decades, there has been a substantial increase in the number of dengue cases. In this study, we investigated the seroprevalence of DENV infection in two districts of Kaohsiung City, a metropolis in southern Taiwan, after the dengue outbreak of 2015. The DENV seroprevalence was 12. 4% based on the InBios DENV IgG ELISA kit. The ratios of clinically inapparent to symptomatic infections were 2. 86 and 4. 76 in Sanmin and Nanzhi districts, respectively. The DENV seroprevalence increased from 2. 1% ( in the 30–39-year age group ) to 17. 1% ( 60–69 ) and 50% ( 70–79 ), and correlated with a dramatic increase in the proportion of clinically severe DENV infections among total dengue cases in that age group. This differed from observations in the Americas and Southeast Asia and suggested that a large proportion of monotypically immune individuals together with other risk factors may contribute to clinically severe dengue among the elderly in Taiwan.

Human Cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) is a herpesvirus that infects about 50% of the world's population. Infection can cause severe symptoms such as neurological disease in the immunocompromised population and is associated with congenital abnormalities of the central nervous system ( CNS ). We used HCMV-infected human brain tissue and neural stem cells from the human embryo to investigate the role of PPARγ, a key regulator of brain development. We found that HCMV infection dramatically impaired the rate of neuronogenesis and strongly increased PPARγ levels. Consistent with this finding, exposure of uninfected neural stem cells to 9-HODE, a known PPARγ agonist, recapitulated the effect of infection on PPARγ activity. PPARγ also increased the rate of cells expressing the IE antigen, a key regulator of neurogenesis. Furthermore, pharmacological activation of ectopically expressed PPARγ was sufficient to induce impaired neuronogenesis of uninfected neural stem cells, and treatment with 9-HODE restored a normal rate of differentiation. These results reveal a key role for PPARγ in neurogenesis and in the pathophysiology of HCMV congenital infection. They also pave the way to the identification of PPARγ gene targets in the infected brain.

Transcriptional regulation is the most direct link between gene expression and transcription. The evolution of transcriptional regulation is often studied in the context of evolution of the regulatory relationships between a transcription factor ( TF ) and its target genes. In this study, we have developed a quantitative evolutionary model of transcription networks ( TNs ), subjecting the phylogenetic distance and the evolutionary changes of cis-regulatory sequence, gene expression and network structure to one probabilistic framework. We have used this model to analyze the pre-implantation development of three mammalian species, including the conserved and re-wired components of the TNs downstream to a set of TFs including Oct4, Gata3/4/6, cMyc and nMyc. We identified the conserved and re-wired components of the TNs downstream to a set of TFs including Oct4, Gata3/4/6, cMyc and nMyc. Evolutionary events on the DNA sequence that led to turnover of TF binding sites were identified, including a birth of an Oct4 binding site by a 2nt deletion. In contrast to recent reports of large interspecies differences of TF binding sites and gene expression patterns, the interspecies difference in TF-target relationship is much smaller. The data showed increasing conservation levels from genomic sequences to TF-DNA interaction, gene expression, TN, and finally to morphology, suggesting that evolutionary changes are larger at molecular levels and smaller at functional levels.

Cells have evolved mechanisms to protect themselves from the outside world, including suicide ( programmed cell death ), which is an effective way to eliminate defective cells. Apoptosis is one of the most conserved suicide mechanisms in eukaryotes and has been shown to play a key role in eliminating defective cells. Apoptosis is initiated by sensing and responding to external signals, including DNA, cell death, and external factors, such as toxins and growth factors. Apoptosis is a complex process that is triggered by a wide variety of external signals. Apoptosis is initiated by the protein GAAP ( Golgi anti-apoptotic protein ), which is present in all human tissues and plays an important role in eliminating defective cells. The protein is located in the Golgi and is called VACV ( viral variant of apoptosis protein ). We describe a new inhibitor of apoptosis that is highly conserved from plants to humans, amphibians, mammals, and poxviruses. We show that deletion of the v-GAAP gene from vaccinia virus does not affect replication of the virus in cell culture, but affects virulence of the virus in a murine infection model. This study identifies a new regulator of cell death that is highly conserved in evolution from plants to insects, amphibians, mammals, and poxviruses.

Cancer is a disease of the genome, which manifests itself by accumulating mutations in cells. The tumor suppressor p53 is a central player in this process. In its absence, cells are unable to repair DNA damage and, thus, are subject to genotoxic stress. Here, we show that the transcription factor USF1 is responsible for the p53 function and its loss causes inappropriate cell proliferation. Moreover, we demonstrate that USF1 is required for the stabilization of the p53 protein and for a transient cell cycle arrest. Consistently, loss of USF1 compromises p53 stability and its function. These results suggest that p53 is regulated by USF1 and underscore the new role of USF1 in regulating p53 function. Finally, they are of clinical relevance because they provide new therapeutic prospects in stabilizing and reactivating the p53 pathway.

The extracellular matrix ( ECM ) is a complex of proteins that support the growth of plants. Plants have evolved mechanisms to sense the integrity of the ECM, which in turn helps them coordinate cell wall integrity with the internal growth machinery. One of the most important examples of such coordination mechanisms is found in the pollen tube. Pollen tube growth is controlled by the ANXUR receptor-like kinases ( RLKs ), which bind to NADPH oxidases. Previously, we showed that loss of NADPH oxidase activity in the pollen tube leads to severe growth arrest. Here, we report that over-expression of the ANXUR RLKs inhibits growth by over-activating exocytosis and the over-accumulation of secreted cell wall material. Moreover, we show that the ANXUR RLKs function upstream of these NADPH oxidases. Our findings support a model where ECM-sensing receptors regulate reactive oxygen species production, Ca2+ homeostasis, and exocytosis to coordinate ECM-performance with the internal growth machinery.

The chaperonin subunits of the ATP dependent molecular chaperone GroEL are involved in the regulation of the nucleotide-dependent conformational changes that occur during the ATP binding reaction cycle. We have performed extensive molecular dynamics simulations that probe the allosteric response of the subunits to ATP. These simulations provide a global view of the interplay between the nucleotide and the allosteric effect, and we have identified the mechanisms involved in the nucleotide-induced transitions. Our results show that the allosteric effect is mediated by a shift in the structure of the subunit. We have also identified changes in a set of unique intrasubunit interactions potentially important for the conformational transition.

Influenza A virus causes annual epidemics and sporadic pandemics that cause significant morbidity and mortality. Vaccination is the most effective method of preventing the emergence of influenza. Thus, there is a great deal of interest in determining which viral variants cause disease in natural hosts and which are most likely to cause disease. The hemagglutination inhibition assay is used to assess the ability of influenza viruses to evade the host immune response. Here, we used this assay to identify amino acid substitutions that cause changes in hemagglutination inhibition. We used a model that predicted the effects of these substitutions on the hemagglutination inhibition assay. The ability to predict the effects of these substitutions directly from viral sequence data would greatly assist in the development of novel vaccines. These techniques have great potential to be extended to other antigenically variable pathogens and should lead to better vaccine selection.

It has been shown that many types of cortical microcircuit models can perform complex real-time computations, provided they can be rapidly fault-free. We investigate the computational capability of generic cortical microcircuit models in the more realistic case where not only readout neurons, but in addition a few neurons within the circuit, have been trained for specific tasks. We show that this model overcomes the limitation of a rapidly fading memory. In fact, we prove that in the idealized case without noise it can perform any conceivable digital or analog computation on time-varying inputs. We demonstrate the computational implications of feedback both theoretically, and through computer simulations of detailed cortical microcircuit models that are subject to noise and have complex inherent dynamics. We show that the application of simple learning procedures ( such as linear regression or perceptron learning ) to a few neurons enables such circuits to represent time over behaviorally relevant long time spans, to integrate evidence from incoming spike trains over longer periods of time, and to process new information contained in new spike trains in diverse ways according to the current internal state of the circuit.

Lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) is a mosquito borne parasitic disease that affects millions of people worldwide, causing a significant health burden and economic loss. LF is targeted for elimination as a public health problem by the year 2020. For this purpose, mass drug administration ( MDA ) is the primary method for LF control. The primary purpose of MDA is to interrupt transmission of the parasite and prevent the infection. MDA coverage is usually assessed by reporting the number of people receiving the medicine. The purpose of this study is to assess the performance of MDA and the impact of the implementation of the MDA program on the health district level. We report the results of surveys conducted in 2015 and 2016 in 58 districts from Mozambique and the Democratic Republic of Congo ( DRC ). The results show that, although the surveys showed good agreement with the national program, there was an inadequacy in assessing the impact of MDA on the health district level. The results from the surveys will help improve the assessment of MDA coverage and the implementation of MDA programs in endemic countries.

Eutherian mammalian embryos are critically dependent on the selective bi-directional transport of molecules across the placenta. Here, we uncover two independent and partially redundant pathways that include membrane-anchored serine proteases, matriptase and prostasin, and the G protein-coupled receptor PAR-2 that mediates the establishment of a functional feto-maternal barrier. In the absence of PAR-2, matriptase and prostasin double deficiency leads to the absence of the placenta, a severe placental disease, and embryonic death. The combined loss of matriptase and PAR-2 also results in the absence of the placenta, a placental-like tissue, and embryo survival. Embryos with the combined loss of PAR-2 and matriptase or PAR-2 and the matriptase partner protease, prostasin, uniformly die on or before embryonic day 14. 5. Despite the extensive co-localization of matriptase, prostasin, and PAR-2 in embryonic epithelia, the overall macroscopic and histological analysis of the double-deficient embryos did not reveal any obvious developmental abnormalities. In agreement with this, the combined deletion of matriptase from the embryo proper does not affect the prenatal development or survival of PAR-2-deficient mice, indicating that the critical redundant functions of matriptase/prostasin and PAR-2 are limited to extraembryonic tissues. Indeed, placental epithelium showed decreased vascularization, and the ability of placental epithelium to establish a functional feto-maternal barrier was severely diminished. Molecular analysis suggested that the barrier defect was associated with a selective deficiency in the expression of the tight junction protein, claudin-1. Our results reveal unexpected complementary roles of matriptase-prostasin- and PAR-2-dependent signaling pathways in placental morphogenesis and mouse embryonic survival.

Rift Valley Fever virus ( RVFV ) is an acute viral disease that affects ruminants and humans in Sub-Saharan Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. We used a combination of phylogenetic and epidemiological approaches to reconstruct the history of RVFV, including the timing of first RVFV introduction into East Africa, the dates of its first emergence in Madagascar, the dates of its first arrival in Egypt, and the dates of its first RVFV introduction into Saudi Arabia. Results revealed broad circulation of the virus in East Africa, with many lineages originating from Kenya. The two major outbreaks in Egypt since 1977 probably resulted from a long-distance introduction from Zimbabwe during the 1970s, and a single introduction took RVFV from Kenya to Saudi Arabia. Viral populations in West Africa appear to have resulted from a single introduction from Central African Republic. The overall picture of RVFV history is thus one of considerable mobility, and dynamic evolution and biogeography, emphasizing its invasive potential, potentially more broadly than its current distributional limits.

Burkholderia pseudomallei ( B. pseudomallei ) is a Gram-negative bacterium and the causative agent of melioidosis. Melioidosis is a life-threatening infection caused by this pathogen that affects the lungs, liver and spleen. Melioidosis is still a neglected tropical disease that is still a major health concern in many developing countries. The bacteria are thought to reside in the cytoplasm of the host cell, but it is unclear where they are. Using transmission electron microscopy ( TEM ), we have shown that the bacteria are found in the nucleus of the host cell, and that the nucleus is an occult or transient niche for intracellular survival of B. pseudomallei.

How humans recognize and remember scenes from the past is an open question in neuroscience. Here, we show that the brain automatically encodes a scene into memory based on its sensory input at behavioral relevant points in time. These results are consistent with the popular hypothesis that the brain can “remember” a scene from the past by detecting its presence in the current scene. Our results also suggest that, in order to be useful, a scene should not be remembered if it is not of interest to the task at hand.

There is a clear genetic component to many human diseases, including many of the most common and difficult to diagnose. When we look at the genomes of unrelated individuals, we find evidence for genetic differences between them, and these differences can be detected by using a method known as autozygosity. These differences are usually seen in the genomes of individuals of European descent. In our analysis, we show that these differences between individuals have actually been seen more frequently than previously thought. In particular, we show that the frequency of genetic differences between individuals has decreased over time, and that this trend has had a profound effect on the way we can detect these differences in the genome. This trend has been particularly dramatic in the past 50 years, when the frequency of genetic differences between individuals has decreased dramatically. This trend is expected to have an important effect on how we can detect and treat genetic differences in humans.

The importance of regulation of DNA–dependent protein modification, such as ubiquitylation, is widely recognized, but the molecular mechanism of the regulation of protein ubiquitylation is poorly understood. Here, we report that the histone H2BK123 ubiquitin protease Ubp10 deubiquitylates the sliding clamp PCNA. Interestingly, we show that the deubiquitylation of PCNA by Ubp10 is important for DNA polymerase ζ–associated protein Rev1 and accessory subunit Rev7 binding to the sliding clamp, and therefore for the DNA–dependent control of DNA repair. Finally, we show that Ubp10 counteracts Rad18 E3-ubiquitin ligase activity on PCNA at lysine 164 in such a manner that deregulation of Ubp10 expression causes tolerance impairment and MMS hypersensitivity.

Malaria parasites must differentiate from a primary human form ( the mosquito ) to a blood-form stage ( the gamete ) prior to transmission. This differentiation is triggered by a blood meal that triggers the activation of a mosquito-derived molecule, xanthurenic acid ( XA ). However, the signalling events controlling this process in the human malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum are largely unknown. Here we show that Zaprinast, a drug currently in clinical trials as a malaria drug, is responsible for triggering gametogenesis in the absence of XA. We also show that Zaprinast acts downstream of cGMP-dependent protein kinase ( PKG ), a G-protein-coupled receptor ( GPCR ) that is required for the activation of cGMP-dependent signalling events. This work thus demonstrates the crucial role of PKG in gametogenesis and identifies cGMP-dependent protein kinase as a potential target for antimalarial drugs.

This paper describes a new method for detecting new noncoding RNAs by searching for RNAs in a given genomic region. This method is based on the comparison of sequences from different genomes. The basic idea is to consider all possible pairwise alignments between two RNA sequences and use them to compute the probability that a given alignment is either identical ( pre-folding ) or similar ( pre-aligning ). We present the method in a series of algorithms that consider the three different possible types of alignments: ( i ) pre-folding and ( ii ) pre Aligning. In each of these algorithms, we have developed a new algorithm that considers all possible pairs of alignments. The algorithm is fast and computationally efficient, and has been implemented into a new FOLDesan algorithm. We have applied the algorithm to search for new ncRNAs in human and mouse cells. We have found several interesting new ncRNAs in these cells. We also provide an algorithm to divide the structure of the RNA into smaller unbranched segments. With these improvements in the algorithm, the FOLDesan algorithm package provides the molecular biologist with an efficient and user-friendly tool for searching for new ncRNAs.

Chagas’ disease is a neglected disease that affects millions of people in Latin America. The emergence of resistant vectors has increased the need to develop new control strategies. Among the most promising strategies is the development of resistance management strategies. These strategies are based on the analysis of the insecticide susceptibility mechanisms present in the vectors, in order to decrease the probability of resistance development. Three families of enzymes are known to mediate detoxification of xenobiotics, including insecticides. We have performed comparative analysis of gene expression patterns between the three triatomine families that have evolved high levels of resistance to pyrethroid insecticides. Our results indicate that several insecticide resistance related gene families are reduced or lacking in triatomines from the Gran Chaco ecoregion, an area in which pyrethroid resistant vectors have failed. We also show that metabolic resistance may be a cause of pyrethroid resistance in wild Triatomine populations. Our results provide new information on the potential insecticide resistance mechanisms in vectors of Chagas’ disease.

Several human neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of 8-oxo-7, 8-dihydroguanine ( 8-oxodG ) in the DNA of affected neurons. This can occur either through direct oxidation of DNA guanine or via incorporation of the oxidized nucleotide during replication. Hydrolases that degrade oxidized purine nucleoside triphosphates normally minimize this incorporation. To investigate whether the incorporation of oxidized nucleic acid precursors contributes to neurodegeneration, we constructed a transgenic mouse in which the human hydrolase 8-oxodGTPase is expressed. We show that the expression of the human hMTH1 gene confers dramatic protection against the symptoms of Huntington's disease. We also show that an in vitro genetic model for Huntington's disease is used. We demonstrate that oxidized nucleic acid precursors are toxic in the huntingtin cell model, and that the toxicity is due to the expression of the mutant huntingtin gene. Our results implicate oxidized nucleic acid precursors in the neuropathological features of Huntington's disease and identify the utilization of oxidized nucleoside triphosphates by striatal cells as a significant contributor to the pathogenesis of this disorder.

The chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis ( Bd ) is a pathogenic fungus of amphibians that causes severe disease in humans and has been linked to amphibian extinctions worldwide. Bd is the only known member of its clade to attack vertebrates. Here we use the genome of a non-pathogenic relative of Bd to investigate the molecular basis of pathogenicity. We find that Bd's closest relative, a non-pathogenic chytrid from the related tree group, shares significant genomic and proteomic properties with Bd. We also show that these genes were recently recently diverged from a common ancestor and that they were specifically enriched in the Bd gene family. Finally, we demonstrate that the timing of the gene family expansions predates the emergence of Bd as an important global pathogen of amphibians.

Map-based estimates of the spatial distribution of infectious diseases are required for guiding public health policy from local to global scales. Recent advances in geostatistical mapping have allowed these estimates to be generated in a formal statistical framework, providing robust metrics of map uncertainty that enhance their utility for decision-makers. Existing methods have not been adapted for estimating large areas such as the mean prevalence within a country or population. We describe a new efficient algorithm for estimating large areas with spatial aggregation, and present its implementation in conjunction with a model for Plasmodium falciparum, the deadliest of the 21st century, allowing robust estimates of mean prevalence at any specified level of spatial aggregation.

A novel bioassay method has been developed and validated for evaluating the efficacy of Bacillus thuringiensis toxin Cyt2Ba in the control of Aedes mosquito larvae. This recombinant strain is significantly more virulent than the original strain in the field and can be used to evaluate the efficacy of the bioassay method. However, the B. thuringiensis toxin gene is not expressed in the fungus in the absence of the bioassay method, which hinders the assessment of its role in the control of the fungus. Therefore, the B. thuringiensis toxin Cyt2Ba was incorporated into the genome of the B. bassiana strain and the resulting recombinant strain, Bb-Cyt2Ba, was tested against the two mosquito species Aedes aegypti and Ae. albopictus. The Bb-Cyt2Ba strain exhibited significantly lower levels of mortality and fecundity than the original strain. The Bt toxin gene Cyt2Ba was also demonstrated to significantly improve the virulence of B. bassiana against Ae. albopictus and Ae. aegypti, which suggested that this recombinant B. bassiana strain has great potential for use in mosquito control.

Human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ) is a parasitic disease that has a long treatment and follow-up ( 24 months ), and the only available drugs are toxic and expensive. The current control strategy is based on mass drug administration ( MDA ), and it is not available in many areas of the world, especially in the poorest countries. There is an urgent need for improved and better treatment strategies that will be available in the near future. We assessed different algorithms to predict the outcome of treatment. We analyzed patient data from 12 programs conducted by Médecins Sans Frontières in Uganda, Sudan, Angola, Central African Republic, Republic of Congo and Democratic Republic of Congo. Patients analyzed had confirmed second-stage disease and had CSF leucocyte counts ( CSFLC ) at 6 months. We found that the 6-month CSFLC can predict outcome with some limitations. The best algorithm was established at 6 months with < = 5 leucocytes/µL and the relapse with > = 50 leucocytes/µL at 12 months. The 6-month CSFLC can predict outcome with some limitations. Several options exist that can be used according to priorities.

Trypanosoma brucei is a unicellular parasite that causes human African trypanosomiasis, or sleeping sickness. The parasite is transmitted to humans by tsetse flies, which are highly efficient vectors. The parasites cycle between the insect host ( procyclic form ) and mammalian host ( bloodstream form ). While the genes and proteins of both forms are highly similar, they differ only in their sequence and expression patterns. The genes are subject to regulation by factors that induce the unfolded protein response ( UPR ), a conserved protein stress response pathway. UPR induces a protective protein, spliced leader RNA ( SL RNA ), that is cleaved by the 5′ end exonuclease Cenricleucine ( Cen ). SL RNA silencing ( SLS ) elicits shut-off of spliced leader RNA transcription by perturbing the binding of Cen to its cognate promoter, thus eliminating trans-splicing of all mRNAs. Here, we show that ER stress induces SLS, leading to up-regulation of genes involved in protein translocation across the ER membrane. This mechanism is dependent on differential stabilization of mRNAs. When ER stress persists, SLS induces programmed cell death ( PCD ), evident by exposure of phosphatidyl serine, DNA laddering, increase in reactive oxygen species production, increase in cytoplasmic Ca2+, and decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential, as well as typical morphological changes observed by transmission electron microscopy ( TEM ). ER stress response is also induced in the bloodstream form and if the stress persists it leads to SLS. We propose that the ER stress response is a unique mechanism to induce SLS, which serves as a unique death pathway.

Spinal cystic echinococcosis ( CE ) is a parasitic disease which affects the spine and is caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia solium. In humans, the parasite eggs are excreted in the feces of a small number of tapeworm hosts. The parasite eggs induce inflammation in the spinal cord and, as a consequence, the parasite eggs are trapped in the spinal cord, leading to cysts. The currently used treatment for CE is limited to surgery and the use of a combination of anti-parasitic drugs. Despite the development of new diagnostic techniques and the use of anti-parasitic drugs, the incidence of CE remains high. We reviewed the available literature to update and summarize the currently existing data on treatment, follow-up and outcome of spinal CE.

When an organism has to adapt to a new environment, natural selection favors mutations that change the amino acid sequence of the protein. Such mutations are biased, because they cause the encoded protein to fold back to its characteristic structure. However, mutations that change the encoded protein's structure can also change the encoded protein's function. Here, we demonstrate that the existence of a set of synonymous DNA sequences that can explore different regions of the protein's adaptive landscape, in addition to their ability to change the protein's structure, can be an important feature for manipulating the evolution of natural proteins. We applied our algorithm to a gene that is responsible for antibiotic resistance and found that, when synthesized with multiple versions of the gene, the resulting variants were able to synthesize new functions that are different from the original gene. Our results provide conclusive evidence that, even in the case of a protein with a very high mutation rate, there are regions of the protein's adaptive landscape that are effectively constrained by the DNA sequence.

Glycosylation of immunoglobulin G ( IgG ) is a key component of the binding of Fc receptors to Fc receptors on the surface of the antibodies. This process is modulated by the N-glycosylation of IgG, which can be controlled by genetic factors. In this study, we used a combined approach of genome-wide association study and functional follow-up experiments to identify genetic loci that control IgG glycosylation. We found evidence of association of a number of loci with human disease. However, the majority of the identified loci were involved in autoimmune and inflammatory diseases. We also identified that one of the loci, IKZF1, was associated with multiple immunoglobulin G N-glycans. This finding suggests that functional studies of the IKZF1 locus may provide insight into its role in autoimmune diseases and cancer.

Leprosy is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which affects skin, nerves, and peripheral nerves. Genome wide association studies ( GWASs ) have revealed multiple genetic variants associated with leprosy in the Chinese population. The aim of our study was to utilize the genetic variants to construct a risk prediction model through a weighted genetic risk score ( GRS ) in a Chinese set and to further assess the performance of the model in identifying higher-risk contact individuals in an independent set. The highest prediction accuracy, with an area under the curve ( AUC ) of 0. 743 ( 95% confidence interval ( CI ) : 0. 729–0. 757 ), was achieved with a GRS encompassing 25 GWAS variants in a discovery set that included 2, 144 people affected by leprosy and 2, 671 controls. Individuals in the high-risk group, based on genetic factors ( GRS > 28. 06 ), have a 24. 65 higher odds ratio ( OR ) for developing leprosy than those in the low-risk group ( GRS≤18. 17 ). The model was then applied to a validation set consisting of 1, 385 people affected by leprosy and 7, 541 individuals in contact with leprosy. The GRS cut-off value was found to be 22. 38, which yielded a discriminatory ability with an AUC of 0. 707 ( 95% CI: 0. 691–0. 723 ).

Signaling networks are dynamic regulatory systems that control diverse cellular functions. Each cell receives its external environment, which is, in the case of cancer, frequently perturbed, and must be taken into account in order to survive. We have developed a powerful experimental-computational technique, which uses a drug perturbation library of systematically varying perturbations to systematically explore all possible signaling networks in a given cell type. The resulting network models are used to gain insight into the nature of the perturbation response, and to gain a priori knowledge of the network's role in cellular function. These networks can be used to predict the response of cells to perturbations in new drugs, and to design new drugs.

Congenital heart disease ( CHHD ) is a leading cause of childhood morbidity and mortality. Left-ventricular outflow tract obstructions ( LV sinoal ) are a diverse spectrum of malformations which frequently cluster in families. Here, we perform exome sequencing of 182 individuals from 51 families with LVasoal obstruction. This study is unique in using a multidisciplinary approach that includes family members, a reference to identify the disease phenotype, and a family specific mutation. Our results reveal the multifaceted role of the Notch signaling cascade in LVasoal obstruction. We identified novel disease associated and co-segregating variants in 12 families. Our study provides a resource for identifying disease-associated variants and disease mechanisms in patients with LVasoal obstruction.

The nervous system of vertebrates is composed of a complex network of interconnected cell types, each of which is thought to have originated from a common ancestor. In vertebrates, the nervous system comprises a few types of neurons, the axons, which carry information to the brain, and the peripheral nervous system, which includes the kidneys, heart, and nervous system components. These neurons are interconnected by specialized channels, the voltage-gated sodium and potassium channels, which have been assembled from a common precursor in all vertebrates. The vertebrate nervous system is thought to have evolved from a common ancestor of all vertebrates. We have analyzed the evolution of the sodium channels that generate action potentials at the site of Ranvier, a key event in vertebrate nervous system evolution. We show that sodium channels acquired an anchor motif early in the chordate lineage ( a cephalochordate ), and then co-evolved with the cytoskeleton adaptor protein ankyrin-G, to form the sodium channel clusters that are present in most vertebrates. These early channel innovation appears essential to the complex nervous system, as vertebrates and other chordates lack myelin or myelin-like membranes, and to allow the rapid generation of action potentials.

Reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) are the most studied of environmental toxins. Despite their potential as therapeutic agents, they are also responsible for host defense mechanisms. An important source of ROS is hydrogen peroxide ( H2O2 ), generated by dual oxidases ( DUOXs ). In mammals, H2O2 is important for the thyroid hormone biosynthetic pathway. DUOX is a large protein complex and its activity is regulated by the conserved tetraspanin protein. Using Caenorhabditis elegans as a model, we demonstrated that tetraspanin is required for induction of the DUOX signaling pathway. Genetic mutations of DUOX ( brewer's yeast ), DUOXA ( peroxidase's yeast ), and TSP-15 ( dual oxidase ) in C. elegans caused the same defects as those in the current study, representing the first evidence for a regulatory role of tetraspanin in ROS generation.

C. parvum is an opportunistic protozoan parasite that infects the gastrointestinal epithelium and causes a diarrheal disease. Toll-like receptor ( TLR ) - and NF-κB-mediated immune responses from epithelial cells, such as production of antimicrobial peptides and generation of reactive nitrogen species, are important components of the host's defense against cryptosporidial infection. Here we report data demonstrating that C. parvum infection activates NF-κB signaling in epithelial cells and upregulates the expression of miR-27b, and downregulation of KH-type splicing regulatory protein ( KSRP ). Meanwhile, upregulation of miR-27b and downregulation of KSRP caused reciprocal alterations in iNOS mRNA stability. Functional manipulation of KSRP or miR-27b caused reciprocal alterations in iNOS mRNA stability in infected cells. Moreover, forced expression of KSRP and inhibition of miR-27b resulted in an increased burden of C. parvum infection. Downregulation of KSRP through upregulating miR-27b was also detected in epithelial cells following LPS stimulation. These data suggest that miR-27b targets KSRP and modulates iNOS mRNA stability following C. parvum infection, a process that may be relevant to the regulation of epithelial anti-microbial defense in general.

In this study, we generated gene deletion mutants of A. brassicicola to study regulatory mechanisms of pathogenesis. We identified three important genes in the biosynthesis of melanin, which is an important anti-fungal compound. We also disrupted the function of one gene ( Amr1 ) to generate mutants. We found that Amr1 is a homolog of Cmr1, which regulates melanin biosynthesis in several fungi. The deletion mutants of Amr1 showed a two-fold larger diameter than the wild type, which was consistent with the higher level of expression of the Amr1 gene in the mutants. Our results showed that deletion of Amr1 was important for the ability of A. brassicicola to survive in nature. Our results also suggested that the function of the Amr1 gene is important to the success of A. brassicicola as a competitive saprophyte and plant parasite.

Brain activity is highly complex, and the dynamics of cortical activity have been shown to vary across different sleep-wake cycles. It was suggested that the brain may be able to reach a critical point, which would allow for precise control of activity. However, it was not known whether this phenomenon would be observed in the brain of awake and of cat subjects. Here, we analyzed the spontaneous spiking activity in the primary visual cortex ( V1 ) of the cat and the monkey and found evidence of criticality. Spontaneous activity was characterized by brief, synchronous bursts of electrical activity, which were followed by prolonged activity periods. We analyzed the spiking activity of the cortex in anesthetized cat and in the wakeful monkey and found that criticality was associated with the synchronization of cortical activity. We also analyzed the spiking activity of cortical neurons in the primary visual cortex and found that the criticality in cortical dynamics was strongly dependent on collective synchrony among neurons, LFP fluctuations, and behavioral state. Our results show that criticality in cortical dynamics is not stationary, but fluctuates during anesthesia and between different vigilance states.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It is still a major cause of mortality and leads to physical and social disabilities. Early diagnosis is the most important and essential treatment and is currently based on clinical examination. However, it is not easily done and there are many laboratory tests available that are still used in many countries. In this study, we compared the performance of fluorescent Auramine O ( AO ) and the polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) with other standard methods in diagnosis of leprosy. Our results showed that AO staining was significantly better than other methods, especially in the diagnosis of leprosy in lower health facilities such as health centres and district hospitals. Additionally, PCR was more sensitive than other routine diagnostic tests and is more user friendly. These findings indicate that AO staining should be used in the diagnosis of leprosy in lower health facilities and PCR should be performed with more efficiency.

During the gamete ( sperm ) cell-fate decision in many animals, including the hermaphrodite, Caenorhabditis elegans, a genetic program controls the expression of the genes required for gamete formation. Previous work has shown that this genetic program is essential for the proper execution of the cell cycle, as well as for the production of haploid gametes. However, the mechanisms that control the expression of genes required for gamete formation are largely unknown. We identified spe-44 as a critical transcriptional regulator of the C. elegans germ cell-fate decision. spe-44 is required for the expression of hundreds of genes that are specifically required for the formation of gametes. The spe-44 protein is restricted to the sperm-producing germline and is absent from the X chromosome, which is absent in other animals. The function of spe-44 is to control the expression of several hundred genes required for the proper execution of the cell cycle and for the production of haploid gametes. The spe-44 protein is present in all other germ cells, and thus is likely to be a conserved regulator of gene expression in a wide range of organisms.

Interferon lambda 4 gene ( IFNL4 ) is a member of the IFN-λ family, of antiviral proteins that have antiviral activity against a variety of viral pathogens. Interferon lambda 4 gene ( IFNL4 ) is truncated by a polymorphic insertion in the 5′ untranslated region ( UTR ) of the gene. This truncated IFN-λ4 protein is associated with a high rate of spontaneous mutations in humans, but the mutation rate is not high enough to account for the strong antiviral activity of IFN-λ4. Our study provides a clear example of evolutionary adaptation in which selection drives a rapid change in the frequency of a functional variant. We show that the pseudogene associated with IFN-λ4 has been strongly selected in the human genome and that its frequency is highly variable among populations in Africa, America, and Europe. In fact, the pseudogene has reached high frequency in Asia, the region from which the gene originated, and is strongly associated with a recent increase in the frequency of positive selection. Our results support a model in which the human genome has been shaped by natural selection leading to the selection of functional variants in the human genome.

Autism spectrum disorders ( ASDs ) are neurodevelopmental disorders that affect one in every 88, 000 individuals. The genetic component of ASDs is complex, and it is difficult to identify the genes that underlie the disease. One approach to identify the genes involved in ASDs is to search for genetic variants that affect multiple genes. Such genetic variants are called “epistasis, ” and we previously found a region of the genome that is associated with increased ASD symptoms in a subset of individuals. In this study, we performed a genetic screen in order to identify genetic variants that affect brain development. We found that genetic variants that affect genes in the Ras/MAPK pathway, a genetic pathway that is known to be important in brain development, also affect brain function in ASD individuals. We then performed a genetic mapping analysis in these individuals to identify the gene that is likely to be responsible for the genetic component of ASDs. This approach can be used in other phenotypes to identify genes that may be important in complex traits.

The CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing system has generated much excitement in recent years owing to its ability to cut targeted genes and genomic regions that are complementary to a programmed single guide RNA ( sgRNA ). However, the efficacy of a given sgRNA to cut a given genomic region is not uniquely defined by exact sequence homology to the target site, thus unintended off-targets might also be cleaved. Here, we introduce CRISTA, a novel algorithm for predicting the propensity of a genomic site to be cleaved by a given sgRNA. We show that CRISTA is more accurate than other existing methodologies. We further demonstrate that the occurrence of bulges is not a rare phenomenon and should be accounted for in the prediction process. Beyond predicting cleavage efficiencies, the learning process provides inferences regarding the mechanism of action of the CRISPR-Cas9 system.

Inflammasome-mediated allergic airway inflammation is a common feature of allergic airway diseases. The clinical manifestations vary from mild to severe disease. The immune mechanisms of allergic airway inflammation are still not fully understood. CD4+CD25+Foxp3+T ( Treg ) cells are one of the most important mechanisms for dampening immune responses. In this study, we compared the effects of Treg cells from Trichinella spiralis-infected mice and uninfected mice on experimental allergic airway inflammation in order to understand the functions of parasite-induced Treg cells. After four weeks of T. spiralis infection, we isolated Foxp3-GFP-expressing cells from transgenic mice using a cell sorter. We injected CD4+Foxp3+ cells from T. spiralis-infected [Inf ( + ) Foxp3+ ) or uninfected [Inf ( - ) Foxp3+] mice into the tail veins of C57BL/6 mice before the induction of inflammation or during inflammation. Inflammation was induced by ovalbumin ( OVA ) -alum sensitization and OVA challenge. The concentrations of the Th2-related cytokines IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 in the bronchial alveolar lavage fluid and the levels of OVA-specific IgE and IgG1 in the serum were lower in mice that received intravenous application of Inf ( + ) Foxp3+ cells [IV ( inf ) :+ ( + ) group] than in control mice. Some features of allergic airway inflammation were ameliorated by the intravenous application of Inf ( + ) Foxp3+ cells [IV ( inf ) :+ ( + ) group], but the effects were less distinct than those observed in the IV ( inf ) :+ ( + ) group. We found that Inf ( + ) Foxp3+T ( Treg ) cells migrate to the inflammation site and suppress immune responses more effectively than non-parasite-induced Treg cells. The adoptive transfer of Inf ( + ) Foxp3+ cells is an effective method for the treatment and prevention of allergic airway diseases in mice and is a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of allergic airway diseases.

Cytomegalovirus is a herpesvirus that infects most humans worldwide. It hijacks host cell metabolism to produce progeny virus, but the mechanisms involved are not well understood. We performed an unbiased genetic screen to identify host enzymes required for the production of infectious cytomegalovirus progeny. The screen predicted that very long chain acyl-CoA synthetases and fatty acid elongases are needed during infection, and the levels of RNAs encoding several of these enzymes were upregulated by the virus. Roles for acyl-CoA synthetases and elongases during infection were confirmed by using small molecule antagonists. Consistent with a role for these enzymes during infection, mass spectrometry-based fatty acid analysis with13C-labeling revealed that malonyl-CoA is consumed by elongases to produce very long chain fatty acids, generating an approximately 8-fold increase in C26-C34 fatty acid tails in infected cells. The virion envelope was yet further enriched in C26-C34 saturated fatty acids, and elongase inhibitors caused the production of virions with lower levels of these fatty acids and markedly reduced infectivity. These results reveal a dependence of cytomegalovirus on very long chain fatty acid metabolism.

African Animal Trypanosomosis is a parasitic disease of animals caused by a tsetse fly vector. The parasite is transmitted to humans and animals by tsetse flies. It is a disease of public health concern in sub-Saharan Africa, where it has a considerable impact on the economy of the affected country. It is also a public health concern in areas of the world where the climate has been changing at a rate greater than the usual 24-h daily cycle. We used data from various projects to estimate the risk of the disease in Burkina Faso and Ghana, two countries that are highly endemic for the disease. We then predicted the risk of the disease using a one layer-one model that incorporates environmental data. The model showed a good prediction of the disease in space and a poor prediction of the disease in time. These results are a first step towards a more accurate prediction of the disease, and could be used for a better planning of vector control activities.

H3K9 methylation is a mark of heterochromatin and plays a key role in regulating chromatin dynamics and gene expression. H3K9 demethylation is crucial for mouse sex determination. The H3K9 demethylase Jmjd1a deficiency leads to increased H3K9 methylation at the Sry locus in embryonic gonads, thereby compromising Sry expression and causing male-to-female sex reversal. In this study, we identify the GLP/G9a H3K9 methyltransferase complex as the enzyme catalyzing H3K9 methylation at the Sry locus. Based on this finding, we try to rescue the sex-reversal phenotype of Jmjd1a-deficient mice by modulating GLP/G9a complex activity. A heterozygous GLP mutation rescued the sex-reversal phenotype of Jmjd1a-deficient mice by restoring Sry expression. The administration of a chemical inhibitor of GLP/G9a enzyme into Jmjd1a-deficient embryos also successfully rescued sex reversal. Our study not only reveals the molecular mechanism underlying the tuning of Sry expression but also provides proof on the principle of therapeutic strategies based on the pharmacological modulation of epigenetic balance.

Helicobacter pylori is a bacterium that infects the stomach of half the world's population and is thought to be the most common cause of stomach disease in industrialized nations. However, H. pylori is difficult to obtain in large parts of the world, and the genetic diversity of the bacteria is much greater than that of most other bacteria. Here, we have studied the genetic relationships of H. pylori among members of a rural community of South Africa and members of urban families in the United Kingdom, the United States, Korea, and Colombia. We found that members of urban families were infected with H. pylori more frequently than members of rural families. In addition, we found evidence that H. pylori from different parts of the world are transmitted vertically from parent to child, and that some members of the South African families are infected with H. pylori from different parts of the world. Our results provide important insight into how H. pylori spreads in the developing world and show that transmission is likely to differ between rural and industrialized countries.

Proteins are synthesized by a complex of ribosomes and their associated proteins. When a ribosome encounters a stop codon, it is precluded from translating the protein sequence. In this situation, the stop codon is recognized and a signal is induced to induce degradation of the misfolded protein. Here, we have investigated the mechanisms involved in the initial steps of protein degradation after the stop codon is recognized. We have found that a family of E3 ubiquitin ligases, called K63, can function in several distinct manners to control the degradation of the misfolded protein. These findings not only provide novel information regarding the detailed molecular mechanisms of the initial steps involved in protein degradation, but also have important implications for the classification of protein degradation pathways.

A protein structure is a complex of amino acids and must fold into a complex of similar amino acids. The process of folding is energetically expensive and involves a large number of steps. The folding reaction is driven by an inherent preference of the structure for a particular conformation, a phenomenon referred to as energetic frustration. In this work, we study the effects of energetic frustration on the folding of a protein structure, SH3. Our results show that the entropy of the chain is not responsible for the folding mechanism. Instead the preferred folding route arises from a cooperative energetic effect. Off-pathway structures are penalized by excess distortion in local backbone configurations and contact pair distances. This energy cost is a new ingredient in the malleable balance of interactions that controls the choice of routes during protein folding.

Abnormal oscillations in the beta band ( 10–35 Hz ) are observed in patients with the neurodegenerative movement disorder, Parkinson's disease, and are correlated with movement impairments, but the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Using an integrative modelling approach, we show that alterations in brain connectivity underlies beta oscillations and that the compensatory mechanisms are mediated by changes in indirect pathways. This study provides novel insight into the neural basis of these oscillations and predicts potential therapeutic targets for therapeutic interventions.

Phagocytosis is the process by which a cell engulfes a cell or organism and digests it. It is a complex process and requires multiple proteins and membranes to facilitate uptake. Phagocytosis occurs in a variety of cellular compartments, including the phagosome, the cellular enclosure that allows the uptake of intracellular pathogens. Phagosomes are often formed in the plasma membrane, a lipid-rich compartment, and their maturation is thought to be an essential event in phagocytosis. Phagosome maturation is initiated by the formation of a phosphoinositide ( PI ) 3, 5’ 2”, which is produced by a number of enzymes. Here, we show that the PI 3, 5’ 2”-associated phosphoinositide 5-kinase PIKfyve is essential for the delivery of two types of hydrolases to the phagosome: the V-ATPase and proteases. Lack of PIKfyve impairs the efficiency of the V-ATPase and protease delivery to the phagosome, leading to the inability of cells to acidify newly formed phagosomes and digest their contents. This defect is accompanied by a defect in the ability of cells lacking PIKfyve to efficiently kill captured bacteria. In summary, our results show that PIKfyve is required for the efficient delivery of hydrolases to the phagosome to ensure the efficient clearance of intracellular pathogens.

Apoptosis is a conserved mechanism used by cells to eliminate damaged tissue or cell populations. Recent work has shown that apoptotic cells are able to stimulate neighboring surviving cells to proliferate, a phenomenon known as apoptosis-induced proliferation. While it is known that the Jun N-terminal kinase ( JNK ) pathway, a serine/threonine kinase that is activated in apoptotic cells, can induce the activity of Jun N-terminal kinase ( JNK ), the mechanism by which JNK activates apoptosis-induced proliferation is largely unknown. Here we describe a genetic screen for genes that act upstream of JNK to mediate apoptosis-induced proliferation. We have identified a subset of genes acting upstream of JNK and show that JNK signaling occurs both in apoptotic cells as well as in neighboring surviving cells. We also demonstrate that JNK activation occurs downstream of JNK signaling, a finding that implicates EGFR signaling as an important mediator of apoptosis-induced proliferation. We further show that the EGFR pathway is required for apoptosis-induced proliferation acting downstream of JNK signaling. These data underscore the importance of genetic screening and promise an improved understanding of the mechanisms of apoptosis-induced proliferation.

Symbiosis with bacteria is widespread in animals. Many organisms, including humans, harbor bacterial infections that protect them against natural enemies. This is often the case for the symbionts that protect insects against parasitic wasps. We investigated the role of a class of proteins, ribosome-inactivating proteins ( RIPs ), in protection by defensive symbionts against parasitic wasps in two species of fruit fly. We show that, in these species, we find strong evidence for a role for RIPs in protection against parasitic wasps. We also show that a specific RNA, called 28S rRNA, from parasitic wasps, Leptopilina, can be cleaved by ribosome-inactivating proteins. Interestingly, we find that a fly lineages called Pachycrepoideus inside the gut of a moth, which are known to be resistant to parasitic wasps, also escapes protection by ribosome-inactivating proteins. We also show that the genome of the Pachycrepoideus line encodes a diverse repertoire of RIP genes. This work suggests that specificity of defensive symbionts against different natural enemies may be driven by the evolution of toxin repertoires, and that toxin diversity may play a role in shaping host-symbiont-enemy interactions.

Developing a drug-protein connectivity map enables researchers to integrate experimental measurements of genes, proteins, metabolites, and drug compounds under similar biological conditions. Such an approach can help identify potential therapeutic targets for diseases. However, it is very challenging to generate a large number of disease-specific connectivity maps, which are required for the development of effective therapeutic approaches. We describe an approach that is complementary to the existing state-of-the-art approaches. We first incorporated molecular interaction network information and literature mining into the development of the AD connectivity map. We then incorporated the data from several literature databases into the development of the AD connectivity map. We showed that the resulting map can be used to explore the differences between drugs with different disease properties. We then used the developed map to search for drugs that are likely to be involved in AD. The results of this search indicated that diltiazem and quinidine may be investigated as potential drugs for AD treatment. The developed molecular connectivity map can help study the differences between different classes of drugs in specific disease contexts.

Eukaryotic genomes contain large amount of genealogies and genomic plasticity. While some studies revealed important genomic changes in allopolyploids, others detected a strong parental legacy and more subtle changes. Here, we sequenced the genomes of the allotetraploid C. bursa-pastteri and its parental species, C. grandiflora and C. orientalis, and compared the expression of genes and the genomic changes between the two subgenomes. Our results indicated that the two subgenomes diverged in expression and regulation, which suggests that they have different functional capacities. However, we found that a large proportion of genes that were differentially expressed between the two subgenomes, were under trans-regulation reflecting the establishment of a new regulatory pattern. Parental dominance varied among tissues: expression in flowers was closer to that of C. orientalis and expression in root and leaf to that of C. grandiflora. Since deleterious mutations accumulated on the C. orientalis subgenome, the bias in expression towards C. orientalis seen in flowers indicates that expression changes could be adaptive and related to the selfing syndrome, while biases in the roots and leaves towards the C. grandiflora subgenome may be reflective of the differential genetic load.

Cryptococcus neoformans is a pathogenic fungus that causes life-threatening disease in immunocompromised individuals. It is a highly successful organism in the mammalian host, and the ability to adapt to the host environment is a major determinant of its disease outcome. The ability of the pathogen to uptake iron is a major determinant of its pathogenicity. Here, we report the identification and characterization of a mutant of the Sec1/Munc18 ( SM ) protein Vps45, which was impaired in endocytosis and was also defective in transport of the Cfo1 ferroxidase of the high-affinity iron uptake system from the plasma membrane to the vacuole. Remarkably, we also found that Vps45 contributes to mitochondrial function, as a Vps45-Gfp fusion protein associated with mitotracker, and a vps45 mutant showed enhanced sensitivity to inhibitors of electron transport complexes as well as changes in mitochondrial membrane potential. Consistently, the vps45 mutant was also impaired in calcium homeostasis. These results indicate that Vps45-mediated trafficking, iron uptake and mitochondrial function are important for the virulence of C. neoformans.

The small RNA-based immune response is a key component of the host response to viral infection. In plants, small RNA-mediated degradation of experimentally targeted mRNA targets is mediated by the RNA interference ( RNAi ) pathway. In mammals, small RNAs have also been shown to be essential for the initiation of the interferon ( IFN ) pathway. While it is well established that both viruses and their hosts use small RNAs to modulate the immune system, the role of these small RNAs in mammalian host-virus interactions remains to be characterized. We have used high-throughput sequencing to characterize changes in small RNA populations that occur during viral infection in animal cells. We identified virus-derived small RNAs from all six different viruses, with total abundance varying from “vanishingly rare” ( less than 0. 1% of cellular small RNA ) to highly abundant ( comparable to abundant micro-RNAs “miRNAs” ). We also found evidence for populations of vsRNAs that exist as duplexed siRNAs with zero to three nucleotide 3′ overhangs. Using populations of cells carrying a Hepatitis C replicon, we observed strand-selective loading of siRNAs onto Argonaute complexes. These experiments define vsRNAs as one possible component of the interplay between animal viruses and their hosts.

KSHV is a herpesvirus that establishes a persistent infection in the majority of humans worldwide. It can also cause KSHV-associated cancers. During latency, KSHV is able to escape the host immune response by establishing a state of permanent persistence called latency. During this process, the virus persists in a quiescent form known as an epiblast. During the latent-to-lytic switch, the viral genome is reorganized to rekindle expression of viral genes and to escape the host immune response. We found that KSHV LANA is a multifunctional protein that is used to evade host immune responses. During viral infection, the LANA protein is cleaved into two distinct fragments that are processed by the viral protease, caspase-1 and caspase-3. Using a cell-permeable peptide that spans both fragments, we demonstrated that cleavage of LANA is inhibited by a cell-permeable peptide. Furthermore, we show that LANA is cleaved into two fragments that function to prevent apoptosis of host cells undergoing cell death. These findings reveal a novel mechanism by which LANA is used to escape host immune responses and provide a new insight into how KSHV subverts host defenses.

In the Indian subcontinent, the incidence of Leishmaniasis ( VL ) has been decreasing over the past decade due to improved health care facilities, human migration, and vector control. With the emergence of antimonials-resistant VL, the need to preserve the existing drugs to control the infection has become urgent. In the Indian subcontinent, the antimonials are the primary drugs used for the treatment of leishmaniasis. With the lack of drugs, there is an urgent need for the development of novel treatment options. We evaluated the susceptibility of L. donovani parasites to two drugs, miltefosine ( MIL ) and paromomycin ( PMM ), both of which have been used to treat leishmaniasis in the Indian subcontinent. The results indicate that miltefosine is more susceptible to PMM than the other drug. We also investigated the resistance of L. donovani parasites to miltefosine and PMM in patients with leishmaniasis. We found that the parasites were uniformly susceptible to PMM, regardless of the drug used. Further, our results indicate that miltefosine is more tolerant in PKDL compared with VL isolates. Our results provide the basis for the development of novel treatment options for leishmaniasis.

Scrub typhus is a potentially life-threatening disease, which is caused by the obligately intracellular bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. The disease is endemic in Asia, and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in rural areas of the world. Unfortunately, there are no effective therapeutic strategies for scrub typhus. Here, we show that immune alterations play an important role in the development of severe scrub typhus, and identify potential therapeutic targets. Our studies suggest that severe disease development in the first 24 hours post-infection is accompanied by a strong activation of the type 2 immune response. This activation is accompanied by a significant elevation in the expression of genes for multiple immune regulators in the liver, lungs, and spleen. These results suggest that excessive activation of immune responses may contribute to the pathogenesis of severe scrub typhus. This is the first report of the effects of immune regulators on a panel of immune regulators during early O. tsutsugamushi infection in an intravenously inoculated mouse model.

Epithelial ovarian cancer ( EOC ) is the most common type of ovarian cancer worldwide, and is the second leading cause of cancer-related death. This tumor is also the most prevalent and lethal gynecologic cancer. While genome instability has been implicated in the development of EOC, the role of chromosomal instability ( CIN ) in disease progression and drug resistance has not been addressed. In this study, we quantified the association and dynamics of CIN within serial samples collected from the ascites of five EOC patients, and in two well-established ovarian cancer cell models of drug resistance ( PEO1/4 and A2780s/cp ). We show that CIN is associated with every sample evaluated and that many EOC samples exhibit a large degree of nuclear size and CIN score value heterogeneity. Importantly, we also show that CIN is dynamic and generally increases within resistance. Finally, we show that both drug resistance models ( PEO1/4 and A2780s/cp ) exhibit heterogeneity, albeit to a much lesser extent. Surprisingly, the two cell line models exhibit remarkably similar levels of CIN, as the nuclear areas and CS values are largely overlapping between the corresponding paired lines.

Schistosomes are parasitic worms that live in the liver of their snail hosts. The World Health Organization ( WHO ) has recently called for elimination of schistosomiasis as a public health problem by 2025. Use of molluscicides to control snails is likely to increase in the coming years. The molecular mechanisms of action of niclosamide, the active ingredient in the most widely used molluscicides, remain largely unknown. In this study, we investigated the effect of sublethal exposure to niclosamide on the transcriptional responses of Biomphalaria glabrata, the snail Biomphalaria glabrata, relative to untreated snails. We found that most of the genes upregulated by exposure of snails to niclosamide are involved in biotransformation of xenobiotics, including genes encoding cytochrome P450s ( CYP ), glutathione S-transferases ( GST ), and drug transporters, notably multi-drug resistance protein ( efflux transporter ) and solute linked carrier ( influx transporter ). Niclosamide also induced stress responses. Genes encoding ADP-ribosylation factor ( ARF ), cAMP response element-binding protein ( CREB ) and coatomer, all of which are involved in vesicle trafficking in the Golgi of mammalian cells, were also upregulated. Lastly, a hemoglobin gene was downregulated, suggesting niclosamide may affect oxygen transport. Our results show that snails mount substantial responses to sublethal concentrations of niclosamide, at least some of which appear to be protective. The topic of how niclosamide’s lethality is determined requires further study. Given that niclosamide has been used as an anthelmintic drug for decades and has been found to have activity against several types of cancer, our results may be of relevance in understanding how both parasites and neoplastic cells respond to this compound.

In flowering plants, organs such as leaves, flowers, and stamens are generated from a common underlying developmental program. However, it is unclear how this developmental program is modulated under different selective constraints to generate the diversity of forms observed. Here we show that the developmental program involved in generating the diverse forms of Arabidopsis flowers is similar to that involved in the control of leaf development. However, we show that the diversity of floral form is determined by a divergent polarity field, which is generated by the interaction of growth factors with the plant hormone auxin. We also show that JAGGED ( JAG ), a key growth factor that is involved in the control of auxin dynamics during leaf initiation, is directly repressed by JAG. These results provide a clear example of how simple modifications of an underlying developmental system may generate distinct forms, providing flexibility for the evolution of different organ functions.

Endurance training has been shown to have beneficial effects on health and skeletal muscle function, and can be used to prevent and treat common diseases such as cardiovascular disease, type II diabetes and obesity. The molecular adaptation mechanisms regulating these effects are incompletely understood. In this study, we obtained comprehensive and comprehensive biological samples from subjects who received regular exercise training. We also obtained a second set of samples from subjects who received training only once. Our results showed that training altered the expression of 3, 404 gene isoforms, mainly associated with oxidative ATP production. Fifty-four genes had isoforms that changed in opposite directions. Training altered expression of 34 novel transcripts, all with protein-coding potential. After nine months of detraining, no training-induced transcriptome differences were detected between the previously trained and untrained legs. These results suggest that training altered the expression of thousands of isoforms and several novel transcripts from unannotated regions of the genome. It is likely that the observed isoform expression changes reflect adaptational mechanisms and processes that provide the functional and health benefits of regular physical activity.

Many viruses are known to cleave mRNAs to facilitate the expression of viral proteins and/or to degrade cellular mRNA. Here, we identify sites in the mRNA transcriptome that are targeted by the Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ) SOX protein, an endoribonuclease that cleaves cellular mRNAs. We show that SOX cleaves mRNAs with a high degree of sequence specificity, despite the fact that a large portion of cellular transcripts are cleaved by SOX. SOX cleavage sites are defined by a degenerate sequence motif, which is typically conserved among all KSHV mRNAs. We show that the degenerate motif is well represented in both human and KSHV mRNA, and that its presence correlates with RNA destabilization by SOX. This represents a new endonuclease targeting strategy, in which use of a degenerate targeting element enables RNA cleavage at specific locations without restricting the range of targets. Furthermore, it shows that strong target selectivity can be achieved without a high degree of sequence specificity.

Hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) is one of the most important causes of chronic hepatitis and hepatocellular carcinoma worldwide. The envelope proteins E1 and E2 are major targets for neutralizing antibodies and can be used as viral antigens for vaccine development. Here we expressed the ectodomains of the E1E2 heterodimer with either an Fc-tag or a de novo designed heterodimeric tag and were able to isolate soluble E1E2 heterodimer suitable for functional and structural studies. We also characterized the E1E2 heterodimer by electron microscopy and model the structure based on the coevolution based modeling strategy with Rosetta. Moreover, the E1E2 heterodimer is also used for examining the interactions with the known HCV receptors, neutralizing antibodies as well as the inhibition of HCV infection. We believe that the E1E2 heterodimer would be a valuable target for both viral studies and vaccination against HCV.

Aging is a fundamental problem in biology, but is poorly understood at the molecular level. Studies of aging in simple animal models, such as the roundworm C. elegans, have revealed that the DAF-16 transcription factor regulates a large number of genes involved in growth, metabolism and aging. DAF-16 directly activates genes encoding the AMP-activated protein kinase ( AMPK ), a subunit of the Protein-Activated Protein Kinase ( AMPK ) complex. The AMPK is an important metabolic regulator that controls the activity of numerous downstream kinases, which then activate or inhibit the activity of other kinases. We investigated the role of DAF-16 in the regulation of genes encoding AMPK. We found that DAF-16 regulates the expression of aakg-4, a gene that encodes a subunit of the AMPK complex. In addition, we found that DAF-16 directly activates expression of aakg-4, and we show that this activation is required for the effects of DAF-16 on longevity. These results demonstrate that DAF-16 is a direct upstream regulator of AMPK activity. Our results also suggest that activation of AMPK by DAF-16 is evolutionarily conserved.

Rabies remains a significant zoonotic and economic burden in rabies endemic areas of Bhutan. The disease is transmitted from animals to humans through bites from infected animals. In the present study, we conducted a KAP survey among cattle owners in selected rural areas of the southern rabies high-risk zone and low-risk zone in eastern Bhutan. We found that although cattle owners in the south and east of Bhutan had a good knowledge of rabies, there were no substantial gaps in knowledge about rabies among the participants. The participants residing in the east were two times more likely to have a favorable attitude towards rabies control and prevention programs. We also observed that cattle farmers had high levels of knowledge about rabies and were more likely to use protective equipment while undertaking these activities. Our study highlights the need to strengthen rabies education programs in rural communities to address the knowledge gaps that have been identified.

The increasing use of gene-trap mutagenesis has enabled the systematic screening of cellular genes that are essential for replication of a given virus. This approach is powerful in identifying cellular factors required for the replication of a given virus, but not for host cell survival. Here, we applied this methodology to discover cellular genes that are essential for replication of 10 different cytotoxic mammalian viruses, 1 gram-negative bacterium, and 5 toxins. We report the identification of 712 candidate cellular genes, characterizing distinct topological network and evolutionary signatures, and occupying central hubs in the human interactome. Cell cycle phase-specific network analysis showed that host cell cycle programs played critical roles during viral replication ( e. g. MYC and TAF4 regulating G0/1 phase ). Moreover, the viral perturbation of host cellular networks reflected disease etiology in that host genes ( e. g. CTCF, RHOA, and CDKN1B ) identified were frequently essential and significantly associated with Mendelian and orphan diseases, or somatic mutations in cancer.
