Computational drug repositioning framework via incorporating drug-gene signatures from the Connectivity Map into the virus-host interactome identified 110 putative druggable antiviral targets and prioritized several existing drugs ( e. g. ajmaline ) that may be potential for antiviral indication ( e. g. anti-Ebola ).

Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli ( EPEC ), enterohemorrhagic E. coli ( EHEC ), and Citrobacter rodentium are important causative agents of foodborne diseases worldwide. Upon infection, a variety of effector proteins encoded by these pathogens interfere with host cell signaling pathways, in particular the nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-κB ) signaling pathway that orchestrates both innate and adaptive immune responses for host defense. Among the effector proteins, NleC, a metalloprotease, has been recently shown to modulate host NF-κB signaling by cleaving NF-κB Rel subunits. However, it remains elusive how NleC recognizes NF-κB Rel subunits and how the NleC-mediated cleavage impacts on host immune responses in infected cells and animals. In this study, we show that NleC specifically cleaves p65/RelA through an interaction with a unique N-terminal sequence in p65. NleC cleaves p65 in intestinal epithelial cells, albeit a small percentage of the molecule, to generate the p651–38 fragment during C. rodentium infection in cultured cells. Moreover, the NleC-mediated p65 cleavage substantially affects the expression of a subset of NF-κB target genes encoding proinflammatory cytokines/chemokines, immune cell infiltration in the colon, and tissue injury in C. rodentium-infected mice. Mechanistically, the NleC-mediated p65 cleavage-generated p651–38 fragment interferes with the interaction between p65 and ribosomal protein S3 ( RPS3 ), a ‘ specifier’ subunit of NF-κB that confers a subset of proinflammatory gene transcription, which amplifies the effect of cleaving only a small percentage of p65 to modulate NF-κB-mediated gene expression. Thus, our results reveal a novel mechanism for A/E pathogens to specifically block NF-κB signaling and inflammatory responses by cleaving a small percentage of p65 and targeting the p65/RPS3 interaction.

Human tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which has a complex life cycle that includes both humans and animals. The purpose of this study was to determine how the human population and demography have influenced the evolution of the bacterial population. We analyzed the genomes of seven strains from around the world to determine the extent to which the human population has altered the bacterial genome. We found that the human population is significantly more diverse than generally assumed, and that this diversity is likely to be linked to human demographic and migratory events. We also show that the bacterial population is under extremely reduced purifying selection and that, as a result of increased genetic drift, much of this genetic diversity is likely to have functional consequences. Our findings suggest that the current increases in human population, urbanization, and global travel could contribute to the emergence and spread of drug-resistant tuberculosis.

Snakebite is a significant cause of death and disability in subsistent farming populations of sub-Saharan Africa. In this study we aimed to assess, at the pre-clinical level, to what extent the most commonly used antivenom, the EchiTAbG antivenom, which is specifically designed to treat envenoming by the most medically important snakes in Africa, neutralised the lethal effects of venom from two other African species, E. pyrantum leakeyi and E. coloratus. Under restricted conditions of this assay, the antivenom was ineffective against the lethal effects of venom from the non-African Echis species, E. carinatus sobara soila, so far only known to neutralise the venom-induced mortality and morbidity in the African horse, which was not effective against the venom from E. ocellatus. Using WHO-recommended pre-clinical tests we have demonstrated that the new anti-E. ocellatus antivenom, developed in response to the considerable snakebite-induced mortality and morbidity in Nigeria, neutralised the lethal effects of venom from the non-African Echis species, E. carinatus soila, so far only known to neutralise the venom from the African tsetse, E. ocellatus. This shows that this antivenom has potential to treat envenoming by most, if not all, African Echis species.

During mammalian evolution, the yolk of the egg was lost and replaced by the vitellogenin, a nutrient required for egg development. The yolk of all vertebrates is the product of the interaction between the mother embryo and the milk. The two types of milk are similar to the yolk, and the two types of milk are the products of the same biochemical transformation. However, the transition from yolk to milk, which is needed for early mammalian embryo development, was accompanied by a transition from the yolk to the milk. This transition was accompanied by the loss of a gene, caseins, which are similar to vitellogenins. Here we show that caseins appeared in the common ancestor of mammals ∼200–310 Mya. Caseins and vitellogenins are evolutionarily related proteins, and our results suggest that the transition from yolk to milk was accompanied by the loss of caseins and the yolk-dependent nutrient. Our data are compatible with the hypothesis that the emergence of lactation in mammals and the development of placentation in eutherian and marsupial mammals were the result of the loss of yolk-dependent nourishment during mammalian evolution.

Dengue virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality throughout the tropics and sub-tropics. A novel dengue virus is currently emerging in the Western Hemisphere, and the mosquito Aedes aegypti, the primary vector of dengue viruses, has developed an immune defense system against a variety of viruses. Previous studies have shown that dengue virus infection triggers the mosquito's innate immune system to ward off a variety of pathogens, including some that can cause disease in humans. Here, we have used the recently released whole-genome sequence of the Ae. aegypti mosquito, in combination with high-throughput gene expression and RNA interference ( RNAi ) -based reverse genetic analyses, to characterize the response of the mosquito to dengue virus infection in different body compartments. We have further addressed the impact of the mosquito's endogenous microbial flora on virus infection. Our results indicate that the Toll pathway, which is known to play a role in regulating resistance to a variety of viruses, is also involved in modulating the dengue virus infection, possibly through basal-level stimulation of the Toll immune pathway.

Human norovirus ( NoV ) is a leading cause of acute gastroenteritis worldwide, and can be life threatening in immunocompromised patients. Each of the two major genogroups ( GI and GII ) of human NoVs recognizes a unique set of histocompatibility antigenic peptides through a distinct binding interface. Here, we characterize a new human Lewis a ( Lea ) antigen binding strain ( OIF virus ), which does not share the conserved GII binding interface, revealing a new evolutionary lineage with a distinct HBGA binding interface. Sequence alignment showed that the major residues contributing to the new HBGA binding interface are conserved among most members of the GII. 21, as well as a closely related GII. 13 genotype. In addition, we found that glycerol inhibits OIF binding to HBGAs, potentially allowing production of cheap antivirals against human NoVs. Taken together, our results reveal a new evolutionary lineage of NoVs with a distinct HBGA binding interface.

The type III interferon response ( IFN-λ ) exhibits antiviral activity against a variety of pathogens, including viruses, bacteria, and parasites, but is restricted to epithelial cells. Thus, IFN-λ exhibits important tissue-specific antiviral activity. Here, we demonstrate that the histone deacetylase ( HDAC ) repression machinery mediates transcriptional silencing of the IFN-λ receptor subunit ( IFNLR1 ) in a cell-type specific manner. Importantly, blockade of HDAC activity renders nonresponsive cells susceptible to the pro-apoptotic activity of IFN-λ, revealing the combination of HDAC inhibitors and IFN-λ to be a potential antitumor strategy. These results demonstrate that the type III IFN response may be therapeutically harnessed by epigenetic rewiring of the IFN-λ receptor expression program.

Cells rapidly alter gene expression in response to environmental stimuli such as nutrients, hormones, and drugs. During the imposed “remodeling” of gene expression, changes in the levels of particular mRNAs do not necessarily correlate with those of the encoded proteins, which could in part rely on the differential recruitment of mRNAs to translating ribosomes. To systematically address this issue, we have established an approach to rapidly access the translational status of each mRNA in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae by affinity purification of endogenously formed ribosomes and the analysis of associated mRNAs with DNA microarrays. Using this method, we compared changes in total mRNA levels ( transcriptome ) with ribosome associations ( translatome ) after the application of different conditions of cellular stress. We found that many of the regulated messages code for functionally related proteins, thus reflecting logical responses to the particular stress. In contrast, mild stress provoked by addition of Calcofluor-white and menadione altered the translatome of approximately 1% of messages with marginal effects on total mRNA. Our results suggest the presence of highly sensitive translational regulatory networks that coordinate functionally related messages.

A network's wiring constraints constrain its dynamics, yet neural structures often overlook the specific wiring patterns formed by their neurons. We constructed a set of anatomically realistic neuronal models for the principal neurons of the striatum, a brain region important for reward processing. We used these models to reconstruct the GABAergic microcircuit formed by the medium spiny neurons ( MSNs ) and fast-spiking interneurons ( FSIs ) of the adult rat striatum. We found that half of all dendritic spines are within 100µm of the soma. The probability of the two neurons intersecting given their inter-somatic distance, and that of their inputs from FSIs to MSNs, is consistent with current estimates. Our models also predict that FSIs should be at most 1% of the striatal population. We show that the striatum is sparsely connected: FSI-PET and MSN-PET contacts respectively form 7% and 1. 7% of all possible connections. Our models also show that the dominant GABAergic input to a MSN arises from neurons with somas at the edge of its dendritic field. FSIs are inter-connected on two different spatial scales: locally by gap junctions and distally by synapses. Our models thus intimately link striatal micro-anatomy to its dynamics, providing a biologically grounded platform for further study.

Reoviruses are important agents of human gastroenteritis and are a significant cause of diarrheal disease. However, it is not known how bacteria affect reovirus infection of the host. In this study, we show that reovirus virions physically interact with bacterial cells and that bacterial envelope components such as lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) and peptidoglycan ( PG ) enhance reovirus infectivity. This interaction increases the thermal stability of the reovirus particle and enhances its interaction with host cells. Our results indicate that bacterial envelope components do not affect the ability of the virus to neutralize its host antibody response. These data suggest that bacteria enhance reovirus infection of the host by increasing the thermal stability of the reovirus particle. These findings may have important implications for the design of vaccines that target reovirus infection.

Infection with the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus ( CE ) can lead to the development of cysts in the liver, which can affect the liver and the lungs and can cause a variety of complications. While cysts can be treated successfully with benzimidazoles, in some cases cysts progress to active disease. There are very few studies on the treatment of cysts in patients who have never received benzimidazoles. In this study, we followed a cohort of patients over a 5 year period from a national reference treatment center in Madrid, Spain. We then followed up the patients for 5 years and observed how the cysts responded to treatment. We found that the cysts that did not respond to treatment are not in fact stable in the long term. We recommend to the watch & wait ( watch and wait ) group that is based on the long term monitoring of the cysts. The watch & wait group can be used to monitor the cysts stability for a longer period of time ( 5 years ). The watch & wait group can also be used to verify the efficacy of benzimidazoles.

Age-related changes in the reproductive system are an important aspect of aging because reproductive success is the major determinant of evolutionary fitness. Here, we use the roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans to study the mechanisms that control reproductive aging. We monitored the duration and level of progeny production in the presence of a mutant that does not become sperm depleted and found that it exhibits an age-related decline in progeny production. We identified factors that influence reproductive aging in C. elegans. Dietary restriction delayed reproductive aging, indicating that nutritional status and a signaling pathway that responds to environmental stress influence reproductive aging. Cold temperature delayed reproductive aging. The anticonvulsant medicine ethosuximide delayed reproductive aging, indicating that neural activity can influence reproductive aging. There is no consistent relationship between early progeny production and reproductive aging in strains with an extended lifespan. To directly examine the effects of early reproduction on reproductive aging, we used sperm availability to modulate the level of early reproduction. Early progeny production neither accelerated nor delayed reproductive aging, indicating that reproductive aging is not controlled by use-dependent mechanisms. Our results provide new insight into the mechanisms that control reproductive aging in C. elegans.

Follicular dendritic cells ( FDC ) are the primary antigen presenting cells for CD4+ T cells, yet their role in HIV replication is controversial. We found that FDC can maintain infectious HIV for extended periods, suggesting that FDC can play a role in the persistence of HIV. We also found that FDC can transmit infectious HIV to uninfected CD4 T cells in vitro. Our results suggest that FDC may be a viable target for therapy in HIV-infected individuals.

Giardiasis is a diarrheal disease that is common in children living in developing countries, but the biological basis for this is still unclear. We examined the effects of various nutritional interventions on diarrhea in children who were not receiving multi-nutrients. We also assessed the impact of multi-nutrients on Giardia levels in the stool, and we assessed whether Giardia was associated with diarrhea symptoms or without such effect. We found that children who received multi-nutrients had a lower rate of diarrhea and fever than children who did not receive these compounds. This was independent of the age, HAZ-scores and distance to the research dispensary. Our results suggest that multi-nutrient supplementation is a protective intervention that may be used to decrease the burden of diarrhoea in developing countries, and that Giardia might be a target for this purpose.

In addition to the well-known double-stranded RNA ( dsRNA ) motifs, the human transcriptome also contains hundreds of additional, uncharacterized, RNA sequences. These sequences are termed Alu elements. The majority of Alu elements are found in the non-coding region of the human genome, presumably to serve as a “silencer” that prevents the expression of the flanking sequences. The human transcriptome contains hundreds of Alu elements that flank different exons, and we show that these Alus can alter the splicing of their flanking exons. Interestingly, Alu elements that were inserted in an exon in an opposite orientation also affect the splicing of the downstream exon. This implies that Alu insertions may influence the mode of splicing of the flanking sequences. Our results suggest that Alu elements are an important component of the transcriptome shaping the human transcriptome.

How can the central nervous system make accurate decisions on short times on the basis of the noisy responses of nerve cell populations? It has been suggested that spike time latency is the source of fast decisions. Here, we propose a simple and fast readout mechanism, the temporal Winner-Take-All ( tWTA ), and undertake a study of its accuracy. We find that the tWTA is a good approximation of the response of a nerve cell population to a given stimulus, provided that the stimulus is chosen such that it is the preferred stimulus of the cell that fired the first spike. We then propose a generalization of the tWTA, the n-tWTA, which estimates the stimulus by the identity of the group of cells firing the first n spikes and show how this generalization can overcome the detrimental effect of baseline firing.

Leishmaniasis is a neglected vector-borne disease that has caused many epidemics throughout the world. Although the epidemiology of leishmaniasis is well known in many countries, there are still many questions concerning the ecology and epidemiology of the disease in many countries, including Peru. In Peru, the disease is caused by several species of Leishmania parasites. Among them, the species Leishmania amazonensis, which is present in most of the countries in the Americas, is the only one identified to be causative of human leishmaniasis. Here, we present the results of a study on the distribution of L. amazonensis in Peru. Our results indicate that this species is widely distributed in southern Amazonian areas of Peru, and it is not only present in the country of Huanuco, the only place reported, but also in other areas of Peru, such as Corinoco, Bucaramanga, Cucuta and Cucuta, which are located along the Andes mountain range, and Lutzó, Bucaramanga, Corinoco, Bucaramanga and Cucuta, which are along the Pacific coast.

Human driven selection during domestication and subsequent breed formation has likely left detectable signatures within the genome of modern cattle. We used over 15 million DNA sequences from 43 Fleckvieh cattle to identify genes that have been under selection during domestication. We find over 106 candidate selection regions, many of which are harboring genes related to phenotypes relevant in domestication, such as coat coloring pattern, neurobehavioral functioning and sensory perception including KIT, MITF, MC1R, NRG4, Erbb4, TMEM132D and TAS2R16, among others. We further investigate the relationship between genes with signatures of selection and genes identified in QTL mapping studies, and show that the selection signals we identify are associated with traits known to be affected by selection during domestication. Results also provide further evidence regarding the complexity of the genetics underlying coat coloring in cattle. This study illustrates the potential of population genetic approaches for identifying genomic regions affecting domestication-related phenotypes and further helps to identify specific regions targeted by selection during speciation, domestication and breed formation of cattle.

APL1 is a gene that encodes a protein that is essential for mosquitoes to survive malaria parasites. The gene has been shown to be involved in the natural resistance of the mosquito vector to the human malaria parasite, Plasmodium falciparum, which kills nearly 1 million people a year. APL1 is highly polymorphic, with the exception of an “M” chromosomal inversion, which is strongly subdivided between the “M” and “S” chromosomal forms. The two M chromosomal forms are known to interact physically and genetically, and are thought to have evolved to separate the ancestral form. We show that the two M chromosomal forms differ only at the APL1 locus in diverse populations of A. gambiae. This suggests that a recent selective sweep at the APL1 locus may have driven these differences. In particular, the recent sweep at APL1 in M form mosquitoes is distinct from the recent selective sweep at the Lep1 locus, which only affects the M form. The two chromosomal forms are also found in other mosquito genes involved in the immune response to malaria, suggesting that epistasis may be a mechanism by which these loci influence the immune response to malaria parasites.

Human and animal Animal Trypanosomiasis are significant causes of human and animal morbidity and mortality, respectively. Trypanosomes are protozoan parasites that cause a chronic infection in humans and a chronic infection in animals, which can result in severe anemia and chronic sequelae. In the present study, we investigated the effect of isometamidium, the most commonly used prophylactic drug against Animal African Trypanosomiasis. We generated two isometamidium resistant Trypanosoma brucei clones, one of which was highly resistant to all available isometamidium drugs ( isometamidium ethidium, isometamidium pentamidine, and dimethylcarbamazine ). Both resistant lines were sensitive to cross-resistance to the other two drugs, ethidium bromide and dinazene, but also to the recently discovered sub-species ethidium that is cross-resistant to pentamidine. We demonstrate that the mitochondrial membrane potential of both resistant lines was significantly reduced. Subsequent exposure to isometamidium or ethidium gave rise to highly resistant trypanosomes, depending on sub-species. The crucial mutation is in the F1 ATPase γ subunit, which allows loss of kDNA and results in a reduction of the mitochondrial membrane potential.

Reduced representation sequencing methods such as genotyping-by-sequencing ( GBS ) enable low-cost measurement of genetic variation without the need for a reference genome assembly. These methods are widely used in genetic mapping and population genetics studies, especially with non-model organisms. Variant calling error rates, however, are higher in GBS than in standard sequencing, in particular due to restriction site polymorphisms, and few computational tools exist that specifically model and correct these errors. Here, we develop a statistical method to remove errors caused by restriction site polymorphisms, implemented in the software package GBStools. We evaluate its performance in several simulated data sets, varying in sample size, mean coverage and population mutation rate, and in two empirical human data sets. We show that GBStools improves genotype accuracy more than commonly used filters such as Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium p-values. We also demonstrate the utility of GBS and GBStools for human population genetic inference in Argentine populations and reveal widely varying individual ancestry proportions and an excess of singletons, consistent with recent population growth.

Fermentation of xylose is an essential step in the production of ethanol from lignocellulosic biomass sources. Although it has long been thought that the native yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae cannot ferment xylose, population surveys have uncovered a few strains that are weakly xylose-positive, and some S. cerevisiae strains have been genetically engineered to ferment xylose, but no strain has yet been reported to ferment xylose as efficiently as glucose. Here, we describe the first genetic strain that can increase in optical density when xylose is presented as the sole carbon source. We identified 38 strains that have this xylose utilization phenotype, including strains of S. cerevisiae, other sensu stricto members, and hybrids between them. All the strains we identified are wine yeasts, and for those that could produce meiotic progeny, the xylose phenotype segregates as a single gene trait. We mapped this gene by Bulk Segregant Analysis ( BSA ) using tiling microarrays and high-throughput sequencing. The gene is a putative xylitol dehydrogenase, which we name XDH1, and is located in the subtelomeric region of the right end of chromosome XV in a region not present in the S288c reference genome. We further characterized the xylose phenotype by performing gene expression microarrays and by genetically dissecting the endogenous xylose utilization pathway.

Atrx is a tumor suppressor in sarcomas, gliomas and other malignancies. Loss of atrx function promotes the alternative lengthening of telomeres ( ALT ) in tumor cells, while it also silences PRC2 genes and thereby affects Polycomb repressive complex 2 ( PRC2 ) gene silencing. To further define the role of inactivating ATRX mutations in carcinogenesis, we knocked out atrx in our previously reported p53/nf1-deficient zebrafish model that develops malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors and gliomas. In this study, we demonstrate that complete inactivation of atrx using CRISPR/Cas9 results in the development of various tumors that are not observed in their atrx+/+ siblings. We also show that down-regulation of telomerase and the expression of polycomb repressor complex 2 ( PRC2 ) in atrx-mutant samples is consistent with a role for ATRX in tumor development. Our zebrafish model provides a valuable and unique system to study the role of ATRX in cancer progression.

How cells are able to differentiate into different cell types is a fundamental question in cell biology. In this study, we show that the fungal pathogen Candida tropicalis exhibits multipotency, undergoing stochastic and reversible switching between three distinct cellular states. The three states exhibit unique cellular morphologies, growth rates, and global gene expression profiles. We show that these cell states are regulated by transcription factors that are controlled by synergistic genetic cues. Specifically, we show that the transcription factors Wor1 and Efg1 can drive transitions between all three cell states. We also show that the induced state is a combination of two distinct states, which has the potential to form novel cell types. We show that stable cell state transitions require genetic and epigenetic cues and that stable differentiation events require ectopic gene expression in combination with chromatin-based cues. Our results therefore suggest that transcriptional circuits act synergistically with chromatin-based changes to drive cell state transitions.

Humans can effortlessly describe, imagine, and predict the motions of rigid bodies such as spheres, hearts, and even larger objects. These descriptions, however, are not based on exact physical laws; they are based on intuition and are often overly precise. Here, we propose a computational model of how people perceive and predict such rigid motions, based on coarse approximate simulations as collections of interacting particles. We find that the model is able to accurately describe human intuitions about the motions of rigid bodies. This result indicates that the physical basis for our model is the assumption that the behavior of rigid bodies can be understood in terms of a game of the same sort.

Cells in a multi-cellular organism arise from a common cell population, the progenitor, which proliferates into a diverse array of differentiated cell types. Understanding how these cells differentiate over many generations of cells is essential for the proper design and interpretation of experimental systems. To address this question, we developed a set of models to describe the variability of cell lineages. The models are based on a simple graph, analogous to the tree of life, which has been traditionally used to describe biological networks. The models can be applied to a wide range of experimental data sets to reveal the dynamics of cell differentiation. We show how to use these models to infer cell fate in a given lineage. This requires only a few sample sets of a size of only a few generations. This shows that many parameters such as the number of differentiated cells and the size of the progenitor are not easily inferred from the available data. The results of this paper demonstrate how this approach can be applied to more complex experimental data sets.

The perception of pitch is one of the most important auditory features of a musical instrument. The pitch sensation is modulated by the physical properties of the instrument, such as its length, amplitude, and resolution. It is known that different physical properties affect the perception of pitch. However, since pitch perception arises from the activity of the auditory nerve fibers, it is still unclear how this activity relates to a given stimulus. Here, we develop a new approach to model pitch perception using sparse coding. It is based on a novel representation of the pitch cue by a small set of spatiotemporal atoms from among a large set of possible ones. The representation is optimized to match the activity of the auditory nerve fibers. We show that the method is able to cope with different pitch phenomena. We show that the method is able to extract the pitch cues from the auditory nerve fibers, even when the stimulus is missing a fundamental pitch cue ( e. g., a high-pitched harmonic rhythm ) or if the stimulus is presented with a low-pitched one.

Circadian clocks are timekeepers that allow organisms to anticipate daily environmental changes and to align physiological and behavioral activities with respect to the most important time of the day. The mechanisms underlying the assembly and function of circadian clocks are still poorly understood. We investigated the role of p38 MAPK in the Drosophila clock neurons. p38 is a conserved protein kinase that has been shown to be important for the control of stress-induced and daily rhythms in animals. Here, we show that p38 is expressed in clock neurons and that it is activated in a circadian-dependent manner. p38 is also inactivated by light, and its effects on clock activity and behavioral rhythms were confirmed by locomotor recordings. We also found that p38 is essential for a wild-type timing of evening activity and for maintaining ∼24 h behavioral rhythms under constant darkness. Moreover, nuclear translocation of clock protein Period was significantly delayed on the expression of a dominant-negative form of p38b. Our results suggest that p38 is an integral component of the core circadian clock of Drosophila in addition to playing a role in stress-induced pathways.

Influenza A virus ( IAV ) is a major human pathogen that produces significant morbidity and mortality. To explore the contribution of alveolar macrophages ( AlvMΦs ) in regulating the severity of IAV infection we employed a murine model in which the Core Binding Factor Beta ( CB ) gene is disrupted in myeloid cells. These mice exhibit a selective deficiency in AlvMΦs. Following IAV infection these mice develop severe diffuse alveolar damage, lethal respiratory compromise, and consequent lethality. Further analysis indicated that these mice are deficient in the alveolar macrophages' ability to inhibit infection of Type-1 Alveolar Epithelial cells ( T1AECs ), a major target of IAV infection. The results further indicated that this defect in T1AEC inhibition is due to a failure of the alveolar macrophages to inhibit cysteinyl leukotriene ( cysLT ) pathway genes in T1AECs. Furthermore, these data indicate that the cysLT pathway enzymes and the receptors for cysLT metabolites represent potential therapeutic targets in severe IAV infection.

Synaptic plasticity rules are the building blocks of learning in neural networks. In the central nervous system, a type of synapse is known as the top-down connection. Top-down synapses are highly plastic, changing their strength depending on the state of pre-synaptic activity. It is thought that different forms of top-down plasticity ( top-down short-term plasticity [TGP] and long-term [LTP] ) are required at top-down synapses to achieve stable learning. Here, we investigate which forms of top-down plasticity rules are required at synapses that are distant from the cell body. We present a two-layer model of a synapse and show that only depression-biased top-down plasticity rules, but not classical, can stabilize the activity of top-down synapses. We also show that the results do not change if homeostatic mechanisms are added or if external input to top neurons is added. We conclude that the plasticity rule at top-down synapses is not a universal learning rule. Instead, our results support the existence of a new plasticity rule in synapses that are more distal from the cell body.

The human papillomaviruses ( HPV ) are the causative agents of cervical cancer. The infectious life cycle of HPV is linked to the differentiation state of the host epithelia. HPV DNA synthesis, late gene expression and virion production are confined to suprabasal cells, which are maintained by the viral genome. The E6 and E7 proteins provide an environment conducive to DNA synthesis upon differentiation, but little is known concerning the mechanisms that regulate productive viral genome amplification. Using keratinocytes that stably maintain HPV-31 episomes, and chemical inhibitors, we demonstrate that viral proteins activate the ATM DNA damage response in differentiating cells. This activation is necessary for viral genome amplification, as well as for formation of viral replication foci. In contrast, inhibition of ATM kinase activity in undifferentiated keratinocytes had no effect on the stable maintenance of viral genomes. Our results demonstrate that caspase cleavage is induced upon differentiation of HPV positive cells through the action of the DNA damage protein kinase CHK2, which may be activated as a result of E7 binding to the ATM kinase. These findings have important implications for the development of anti-viral therapies to treat HPV infections.

Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a vector-borne disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania infantum. The disease is a major public health concern in the Indian subcontinent ( ISC ), where the disease burden is greatest in India. This paper describes the process of the Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases ( TDR ), which is co-ordinated by the World Health Organization ( WHO ) and other stakeholders. TDR has played a critical role in the evaluation and subsequent use of the 39-aminoacid–recombinant kinesin antigen ( rK39 ) rapid diagnostic test ( RDT ) as a confirmatory test for VL in the national program. TDR has engaged with in-country researchers, national programme managers, and partners to generate evidence-based interventions for early detection and treatment of VL patients. TDR has supported the clinical research and development of miltefosine and single-dose liposomal amphotericin B as a first-line treatment against VL. TDR has also engaged with in-country researchers, national programme managers, and partners to generate evidence-based interventions for early detection and treatment of VL patients. TDR’s engagement with country policy makers, scientists, and clinicians in the development of effective diagnosis, treatment, case detection, and vector control represents an important example of TDR’s stewardship toward the elimination of VL in the Indian subcontinent.

The necrotrophic pathogen Botrytis cinerea infects living plant cells and undergoes massive cell death ( apoptosis ) to establish disease. This process is controlled by the host innate immune system. We show here that the necrotrophic response in Botrytis is dependent on a specific anti-apoptotic machinery. When the fungal response was activated by exposure to a plant defense molecule, the fungal response was found to be enhanced, and the fungus was more virulent. When this anti-apoptotic response was inhibited, the fungus was found to be less virulent. These results suggest that the anti-apoptotic machinery of Botrytis is essential for the fungus to survive first contact with living host tissue and initiate infection. These findings have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies to control fungal infections.

P. nigriventer is the spider responsible for most accidents by venomous snakes in Brazil. This spider bite causes severe pain that may last for years. The frequency of accidents with this spider genus has increased, and poisoning due to bites from P. nigriventer is the second most frequent source of such accidents. Intense local pain is the major symptom reported after bites of P. nigriventer. However, the mechanisms involved are poorly understood. Therefore, the aim of this study was to identify the mechanisms involved in nociception induced by the venom of P. nigriventer. We used a rodent model to detect the effects induced by the venom of P. nigriventer on the mouse paw. We found that the venom of P. nigriventer produced spontaneous nociception. This nociception is not dependent on glutamate or histamine receptors or on mast cell degranulation, but it is mediated by the stimulation of sensory fibres that contain serotonin 4 ( 5-HT4 ) and vanilloid receptors ( TRPV1 ). We also found a kallikrein-like kinin-generating enzyme activity in tissue treated with P. nigriventer venom, which also contributes to nociception. We also found that both low- and high-molecular-weight toxins of P. nigriventer produce spontaneous nociception through direct or indirect action of kinin B2, TRPV1, 5-HT4 or ASIC receptors and voltage-dependent sodium channels present in sensory neurons but not in mast cells. Understanding the mechanisms involved in nociception induced by P. nigriventer venom are of interest not only for better treating poisoning by P. nigriventer but also appreciating the diversity of targets triggered by PNV toxins.

Aedes mosquitoes have recently expanded their geographical distribution and have been reported to establish themselves in Turkey, a country with an expanding borders with other countries. The recent reports of Aedes aegypti and Ae. albopictus populations in Turkey, in parallel with the territorial expansion identified in several countries, have raised concerns about the establishment and re-establishment of these invasive Aedes mosquitoes in Turkey. The purpose of this study was to detect Aedes aegypti and Ae. albopictus in regions of recent incursions, and screen for viruses known to be transmitted elsewhere by these species. Mosquitoes were collected at several locations in the Black Sea region, and identified via genetic and/or specific nucleic acid amplification assays. The study group comprised 791 specimens. Aedes albopictus was the most abundant species in all locations ( 89. 6% ), followed by Ae. aegypti ( 7. 8% ) and Culex pipiens ( 2. 5% ). In 4 ( 6. 2% ) and 6 ( 9. 2% ) pools, respectively, cell fusing agent virus ( CFAV ) and Aedes flavivirus ( AEFV ) sequences were characterized. In 3 ( 3. 6% ) and 6 ( 9. 2% ) pools, respectively, WNV was detected as strain “MERDLVT”, a newly described rhabdovirus, which was also co-detected in a Cx. pipiens pool. In our study, we show that these invasive Aedes species are established in certain locations of northeastern Turkey. This study provides the first evidence for the role of these species in WNV circulation in Turkey.

Plants sense pathogens through dynamic regulation of plasma membrane signaling pathways. We show that the plant plasma membrane is involved in the plant immune response to the potato virus. The plant plasma membrane is organized into a nanodomain organization and plays an essential role in the plant immune response to the virus. We show that the Arabidopsis thaliana CALCIUM-DEPENDENT PROTEIN KINASE 3-interacts with group 1 REMORINs in vivo, phosphorylates the intrinsically disordered N-terminal domain of the Group 1 REMORIN REM1. 3, and restricts PVX cell-to-cell movement. We also show that the plasma membrane nanodomain organization of REM1. 3 is crucial for REM1. 3-dependent restriction of PVX cell-to-cell movement by regulation of callose deposition at plasmodesmata. This study unveils plasma membrane nanodomain organization as a crucial regulatory event of the plant immune response to viruses.

Rickettsial infections are emerging as a public health concern in Latin America, particularly in countries such as Colombia. In this work, we investigated the epidemiology of incident cases of spotted fever group ( SFG ) rickettsial infection in humans and equines from rural areas of Urabá region, Colombia. Our results showed that the incidence of rickettsial infection was 6. 23% in humans and 32. 31% in equines. Most of the patients were females, and the median age of cases was 41. 02 years. A higher incidence of infection occurred in people who reported fever in the last year. These results showed recent circulation of SFG rickettsiae in areas where previous lethal outbreaks have been reported, supporting the implementation of preventive measures to halt rickettsial transmission in the studied communities.

Aberrant Wnt signaling drives colorectal cancer, which most frequently results from truncation of the tumor suppressor Adenomatous polyposis coli ( APC ). Wnt signaling directs intestinal stem cell ( ISC ) proliferation during homeostasis, but its precise role in this process remains unclear. Using the Drosophila model, we show that Wnt signaling overproliferation requires the transcription cofactors Earthbound and erect wing. In the adult intestine, Ebd and EWG cooperate to induce the Wnt-dependent hyperactivation of Wnt target gene expression, excess number of ISCs, and hyperplasia of the epithelium. In contrast, only Ebd, but not EWG, mediates the Wnt-dependent regulation of ISC proliferation during homeostasis. Our data reveal that differentially utilized transcription cofactors may offer new opportunities for the selective targeting of Wnt-driven cancers.

Clonorchiasis is a neglected tropical disease in China that affects more than 50, 000 people in 25 endemic areas. The prevalence, incidence and re-infection rates in these areas have been increasing in recent years. An efficacious vaccine has recently been licensed in China, but the disease incidence in these areas has not been reduced. The prevalence of infection has also been increasing. A control strategy was recently implemented in Heilongjiang Province, China, in which the prevalence of infection was reduced by three doses of 25 mg/kg praziquantel from 5-hour-intervals in one day. The study aimed to assess the effectiveness of various chemotherapy strategies on prevalence, incidence and re-infection of clonorchiasis in these areas. We found that repeated treatments with the three doses of praziquantel were highly effective in reducing the prevalence of infection and re-infection. These results suggest that repeated treatment of residents with the three doses of praziquantel is effective in controlling the infection. In contrast, in the moderate endemic areas, we found that one or two treatments with health education are effective. These findings are important for the control of clonorchiasis in China.

Herpes simplex virus-2 ( HSV-2 ) causes genital herpes and is a leading infectious cause of genital morbidity and recurrent shedding episodes in the United States. HSV-2 is a reactivating virus, which establishes a chronic infection in the host. A minority of episodes are prolonged, and associated with development of painful ulcers. However, currently, available tools poorly predict viral trajectories and timing of reactivations in infected individuals. In this study, we utilized principal components analysis ( PCA ) and singular value decomposition ( SVD ) to analyze HSV-2 shedding time series data, and used a spatial mathematical model to predict the dynamics of HSV-2 shedding. We found that, although modeling and clinical HSV-2 episodes had equivalent dynamics, model-derived and clinical episodes had equivalent dynamics. We also found that local immune cell density at the viral reactivation site had a predictive effect on episode duration, though longer term shedding suggested chaotic dynamics and could not be predicted based on spatial patterns of immune cell density. These findings suggest that HSV-2 shedding patterns within an individual are impossible to predict over weeks or months, and that even highly complex single HSV-2 episodes can only be partially predicted based on spatial distribution of immune cell density.

In order to reach a target, the nervous system must make multiple adjustments, including sensory inputs, motor outputs, and the appropriate commands for subsequent movements. Many studies have investigated the role of the primate sensorimotor system in computing the direction of movement, but it is unclear whether this role extends to other movement destinations. I have built a model to explain the ability of monkeys to compute movement commands and to predict movement trajectories based on these computations. The model provides a simple account of how the primate sensorimotor system might be involved in processing information, and it also makes predictions about how the primate sensorimotor system might be involved in movement control.

In eukaryotes, chromatin is organized into a complex structure that is dynamic during development. During this process, the organization of the chromatin fiber is tightly linked to transcription and, in some cases, to modifications of the underlying DNA. In this work, we studied histone H3. 3. A class of histone H3. 3 variants that are enriched at active genes and their promoters. We show that H3. 3 enrichment is functionally linked to gene activation. We also show that the dynamic changes of H3. 3 profiles are associated with the extensive remodeling of the transcriptome during cell differentiation. We propose that H3. 3 dynamics are linked to transcription and are involved in resetting covalent histone marks at a genomic scale during plant development.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ) is a vector-borne disease transmitted by sand flies. It is an important public health problem in Morocco, particularly in the West, and it has represented a major health threat over the past 20 years. Leishmaniasis is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected sand fly. The main objective of this study was to identify relevant sand fly species and detect Leishmania infection in the most relevant species and patient skin samples in Taza, a focus of CL in North-east Morocco. A total of 3672 sand flies were collected by CDC miniature light traps. Morphological identification permitted the identification of 13 species, namely 10 Phlebotomus species and 3 Sergentomyia species. P. longicuspis was the most abundant species, comprising 64. 08% of the total collected sand flies, followed by P. sergenti ( 20. 1% ) and P. perniciosus ( 8. 45% ). Using nested-kDNA PCR, seven P. sergenti were positive to Leishmania tropica DNA, whereas 23 P. longicuspis were positive to Leishmania infantum DNA. Infection of P. perniciosus by L. infantum was identified for the first time in Morocco. This study underlined the predominance of L. infantum and its vector in this region, in which L. tropica has been considered the causative agent of CL for more than 20 years.

Insect vectors are responsible for transmission cycles of many diseases including malaria, dengue fever and Zika, which are emerging worldwide. Understanding the transmission cycle and the host-specific blood meal is essential to better understand the life cycle of insect vectors and the epidemiology of these diseases. Insect vector identification is difficult and relies on various methods, such as biochemical, serological and molecular methods. We developed a novel method for blood meal identification using peptide mass mapping ( PMM ) analysis of host-specific hemoglobin peptides from abdomens of engorged sand flies. This method provided correct host identification of 100% experimentally fed sand flies until 36h post blood meal and for 80% samples even 48h post blood meal. In females fed on two hosts, both blood meal sources were correctly assigned for 60% of specimens until 36h post blood meal. The method yielded unambiguous host determination for 96% of specimens. PMM-based MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry analysis targeting host specific hemoglobin peptides represents a sensitive and cost-effective method with a fast and simple preparation protocol. As demonstrated here on phlebotomine sand flies and mosquitoes, it allows reliable and rapid blood source determination even 48h PBM with minimal material input and provides more robust and specific results than other currently used methods.

Schistosome infections are a major health problem affecting over 200 million people worldwide, primarily in Africa, Asia, and the Western Pacific. Although a large number of studies have been conducted on the impact of schistosome infections on children aged 1–10 years, relatively little is known about the burden of schistosomiasis in preschool aged children ( ≤5 years ) who have been neglected in terms of control efforts. In this study, the authors compared the utility of currently available point-of-care ( POC ) morbidity diagnostic tools in children aged 1–5 years and in children aged 6–10 years. The POC diagnostic tools were administered on a panel of urine markers that are known to be associated with schistosome infection in the field. The results show that urine dipstick microhaematuria and proteinuria are the most reliable indicators of schistosome-related morbidity, followed by dipsticks, visual urine inspection, questionnaires, and lastly clinical examination.

Chlorophyll is an essential molecule for photosynthesis and its degradation is critical for the development of leaf senescence. The sensitivity of chlorophyll degradation to the presence of endogenous and environmental cues is well documented in plants, but the molecular mechanisms underlying the direct regulation of chlorophyll degradation in plants are poorly understood. In this study, we found that the transcription factor EIN3 and its downstream target ORE1 positively regulate the expression of chlorophyll catabolic genes ( CCGs ) in Arabidopsis. This is the first report describing the direct regulatory network involved in the physiological response to endogenous chlorophyll degradation.

Malaria remains a significant global public health concern. More than 1. 5 million people are infected with Plasmodium falciparum, the deadliest of human malaria parasites. Despite this, the majority of infected individuals remain asymptomatic, while the disease manifestations of malaria are variable, ranging from fever to severe disease such as malaria hemorrhagic fever or falciparum. Understanding the mechanisms that control immune response and inflammation to malaria is critical for developing improved therapeutic strategies. In this study, we investigated the role of the spleen, a major organ involved in the elimination of extracellular parasites, in the development of experimental cerebral malaria. Our data show that blockade of the IP-10 molecule in mice lacking the ability to migrate to the spleen results in significant reduction in cerebral intravascular inflammation and parasite load. Furthermore, our results demonstrate that this phenotype is associated with an expansion of parasite-specific T cells in the spleens of infected animals. These findings indicate that modulating IP-10 function is a critical mechanism for the control of host immune response and the outcome of malaria infection.

Acentriolar microtubules ( aMTOCs ) are formed during meiosis and mitosis in several cell types, but their function and assembly mechanism is unclear. Here we show that aMTOCs can form in acentriolar Drosophila somatic cells in vivo via an assembly pathway that depends on Asl, Cnn and, to a lesser extent, Spd-2—the same proteins that appear to drive mitotic centrosome assembly in flies. We also show that aMTOCs are required, however, for robust microtubule array assembly in cells lacking centrioles that also lack microtubule nucleation from around the chromatin. Importantly, aMTOCs are also essential for dynein-dependent acentriolar spindle organization and robust cell proliferation in the absence of centrioles and HSET ( a kinesin essential for acentriolar spindle organization in many organisms ). We propose an updated model for acentriolar spindle pole coalescence by the molecular motors Ncd/HSET and dynein in conjunction with aMTOCs.

Kawasaki's phenylalanine ( KFP ) -based time series profiling ( KFP ) is a method developed to measure the relative changes of metabolite fluxes. While KFP can be used for a variety of applications, most of them are focused on a single application such as the analysis of metabolic flux distributions. To generalize its applicability, we introduce a new extension of KFP that estimates the relative changes of fluxes using only relative quantitation of 13C-labeled metabolites. We call our extension rKFP. Moreover, we examine the effects of common missing data and common modeling assumptions on ( r ) KFP, and provide practical suggestions. We then apply rKFP to 13C-labeled glucose time series data collected from cells under normal and glucose-deprived conditions, estimating the relative flux changes of glycolysis and its branching pathways. We identify an adaptive response in which de novo serine biosynthesis is compromised to maintain the glycolytic flux backbone.

The role of endogenous slow-oscillating calcium channels in the onset of midbrain dopaminergic neurons ( MHC ) activity has been controversial. Indeed, the experimental evidence is conflicting. In particular, the blockade of sodium channels has led to conflicting results, in the context of the apparently paradoxical conclusion that endogenous slow-oscillatory calcium channels are necessary for the onset of MHC activity. A standard model for the function of these channels has been successfully fitted to experimental data. However, the same model can lead to completely different results in the presence of two different experimental conditions. We show that the two conditions can be reproduced in a very similar way, and that the differences in their behavior are due to a different effect of the simultaneous blockade of two different sodium channels.

Chagas disease is a chronic, debilitating, and neglected parasitic disease transmitted to humans by insects called triatomines. In Latin America, where the disease is endemic, the Triatominae family includes nine species, which infest humans in 20–30% of households. However, few studies have looked into the epidemiology, vectors and transmission risks associated with Triatominae infestation in southern Ecuador. In this study we describe the triatomine household infestation in southern Ecuador, determine the rate of Trypanosoma cruzi infection in triatomines and study the risk factors associated with infestation. We found 92 rural communities infested with Triatominae species. We found that established colonies of P. chinai ( 175 to 2003 Masl ) and P. rufotuberculatus ( 404 to 1613 Masl ) and other domiciles were found in the house where the triatomines were most frequently found. Vegetation type was a determinant of infestation and vector control program insecticide spraying was a protective factor. In addition to the limited vector control efforts, we found that Triatominae infestation was associated with surrogate poverty indicators such as poor sanitary infrastructure. Together, these results show that an estimated 100, 000 people living in rural areas of southern Ecuador are at high risk for T. cruzi infection.

During the course of their life cycles, Neisseria gonorrhoeae undergo a recombination process that enables the generation of high diversity populations of variant pilin proteins. The molecular mechanism of the recombination event is poorly understood. Using a small RNA that is required for recombination, we have identified a novel mechanism of pilin variation. The small RNA is required for the initiation of transcription of a promoter sequence that is required for a small RNA to form the G4 structure. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the initiation of recombination events in N. gonorrhoeae.

In mammals, the brain's internal timer, the circadian clock, is composed of a network of cells that drive daily rhythms in physiology and behavior. The circadian clock has been studied extensively in individual cells, but less is known about how the clock is synchronized and regulated at the cellular level. We developed a computational model to investigate how daily rhythms in physiology and behavior are coordinated at the cellular level. We found that rhythms are synchronized in individual cells by calcium-dependent changes in membrane potential and ion conductances. The model predicted that intracellular calcium accumulation is an important mechanism for synchronizing cells. Blocking calcium accumulation by various means, mimicking drug effects, reproduced experimentally observed rhythms in gene expression and physiological rhythms. The model predicted a novel relationship between the timing of daily rhythms and the amplitude of gene expression, suggesting that other intracellular calcium mechanisms may contribute to synchronizing cells.

Gene knockdown technologies are widely used to study gene function. The purpose is to target specific gene sequences to inhibit gene function. However, these technologies can cause undesirable effects. In this study, we have used several model genes to study the effects of knockdown technologies. We used the zebrafish embryo as a template, and using several different knockdown technologies, we show that these technologies induce distinct effects on gene expression. We also show that p53 activation is one of the most important effects induced by gene knockdown technologies. The major effect of p53 activation is mediated through direct transferase-mediated dUTP nick end labeling assay, acridine orange, and p21 transcriptional activation assays. Consistent with the effects induced by knockdown, p53 activation is also induced by microarrays and whole-mount in situ hybridization assays. p53 inhibition could potentially be applicable to other gene knockdown technologies to suppress off-target effects caused by other knockdown technologies.

Necrotrophic plant pathogens are capable of killing a large range of crop plants, but are much more prevalent in natural ecosystems than in agricultural production systems. These fungi are particularly important for plant production in low resource environments, and are a major source of economic losses. They are difficult to study genetically, which makes it difficult to gain insight into the biology of these pathogens. We have sequenced the genomes of two strains of S. sclerotiorum and B. cinerea and compared them to other fungal genomes. We find that the genomes share a large number of genes, and the genomes of the two strains are similar in overall structure and function. However, a small number of genes are found in the genomes of the two species, and these genes are likely involved in specific functions. In particular, B. cinerea produces a diverse array of secondary metabolites that are known to affect plant growth. We have also identified the genes responsible for secondary metabolism in S. sclerotiorum and found many new genes that might be involved in the specific processes that these fungi use to kill plants. This study provides a starting point for functional studies designed to better understand what makes these important plant pathogens such as S. sclerotiorum and B. cinerea effective at killing plants.

Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a mosquito-borne virus that infects humans and can cause severe disease. Infection of humans and mosquitoes is confined to a narrow range of tissues, including the midgut and salivary glands. DENV, however, can also infect cells outside of these tissues, such as the heart, kidneys, and central nervous system. DENV infection occurs in a process called cell-to-cell spreading, in which a virus particle infects a cell and then spreads from cell to cell. DENV infection is known to cause high virulence in humans and is linked with the development of DENV-induced hemorrhagic fever in humans. Here, we demonstrate that DENV can also infect and spread between cells that are in direct contact, such as the C6/36 cell. We show that this mode of transmission does not depend on the “ liberation and entry” mode, but is mediated by a membrane-bound compartment that is formed by tetraspanin C189. This novel finding presumably accounts for the rapid and efficient infection of DENV after its initial replication within tissues of the mosquito.

Molluscan shells are an ideal model system for understanding the morpho-elastic basis of morphological evolution of invertebrates’ exoskeletons. During the formation of the shell, the mantle tissue secretes proteins and minerals that calcify to form a new incremental layer of the exoskeleton. Most of the existing literature on the morphology of mollusks is descriptive. The mathematical understanding of the underlying coupling between pre-existing shell morphology, de novo surface deposition and morpho-elastic volume growth is at a nascent stage, primarily limited to reduced geometric representations. We propose a general, three-dimensional computational framework to explain the stepwise morphogenesis of seashells during growth: new material surfaces are laid down by accretive growth on the underside of the morpho-elastic growth. Calcification of the newest surfaces extends the shell as well as creates a new scaffold that constrains the next growth step. We study the effects of surface and volumetric growth rates, and of previously deposited shell geometries on the resulting modes of mantled growth.

Bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) is a ubiquitous component of bacterial cell wall components and is detected in the plasma of mammals, including humans, animals, and plants. The presence of LPS in bacterial infections triggers the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and mediators in a variety of organs, including the heart, lung, liver, spleen, and kidney. A better understanding of the complex spatiotemporal dynamics of LPS-induced inflammation is important for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of bacterial infections. In this study, we use a computational analysis to analyze the time-dependent kinetics of LPS-induced inflammation in mice. Our results suggest that LPS-induced inflammation is a dynamic process, which is characterized by a temporal hierarchy of organ-specific inflammation. We also use a novel approach to define the point at which organ-localized inflammation spills over systemically. Thus, we have a novel perspective on the time- and organ-specific components in the propagation of acute systemic inflammation.

Most current bacterial studies focus on the dynamics of the growth rate of the bacteria. However, unbalanced growth rates are generally considered undesirable in quantitative studies of bacterial physiology. Under well-controlled experimental conditions, however, unbalanced growth dynamics arise naturally from the interplay between growth and the growth environment. In this work, we present a method to identify “phenotypic signatures” by time-frequency analysis of unbalanced growth curves measured with high temporal resolution. The signatures are then applied to differentiate amongst different bacterial strains or the same strain under different growth conditions, and to identify the essential architecture of the gene network underlying the observed growth dynamics.

Cellular differentiation and division are two fundamental processes that are essential to cell life. During cell differentiation, a mother cell that has never been subjected to a cell wall stress, engulfs the forespore compartment of the cell. Once the septum is cut, the mother cell is ready for subsequent cell wall synthesis and differentiation. However, some bacteria, such as Bacillus subtilis, show a fast cell wall stress-induced transition, resulting in a very rapid engulfment of the forespore in the absence of cell wall. In this paper, we use a combination of fluorescence image analysis and stochastic Langevin simulations to explore the mechanisms underlying this fast engulfment. Our results suggest that the fast cell wall stress-induced transition is the product of a novel cell-wall independent mechanism that, in the absence of cell wall, engages the mother-cell protein SpoIIIAH to generate zipper-like engulfment. Our simulations also predict that a threshold-like membrane property can explain fast engulfment in other cell types, e. g. during phagocytosis in eukaryotes.

Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a major public health concern in Latin America. The epidemiology of Chagas disease is poorly understood and there is no vaccine available. The role of wild mammals as sentinels of epidemiological risk of the disease has been questioned. The distribution of T. cruzi infection in dogs is heterogeneous. The risk of infection is higher in dogs with lower numbers of small wild mammals. This is the first study that evaluates the distribution of T. cruzi infection in wild mammal species. We developed a method that combines spatial and ecological data to assess the distribution of T. cruzi infection risk in wild mammal species. The results indicate that the lower richness of small mammal species and the positive hemocultures in wild mammals are associated with higher parasitemia in dogs. We also show that dogs are an efficient indicator of the risk of infection in small wild mammals. The lower richness of small mammal species is discussed as a risk factor for the re-emergence of Chagas disease.

Blood protozoan parasites cause a wide range of diseases in humans, animals, and vectors. Accurate diagnosis and treatment of blood protozoan infections is important for appropriate patient management and the control of the diseases. In this study, we have assessed a novel DNA microarray assay for the detection of Plasmodium, Leishmania, Trypanosoma, Toxoplasma gondii and Babesia in humans, animals, and vectors, in comparison with microscopy and PCR data. Developing a rapid, simple, and convenient detection method for protozoan detection is an urgent need. The microarray assay simultaneously identified 18 species of common blood protozoa based on the differences in their target genes. A total of 20 specific primer pairs and 107 microarray probes were selected according to conserved regions which were designed to identify 18 species in 5 blood protozoan genera. The positive detection rate of the microarray assay was 91. 78% ( 402/438 ). Sensitivity and specificity for blood protozoan detection ranged from 82. 4% ( 95%CI: 65. 9% ~ 98. 8% ) to 100. 0% and 95. 1% ( 95%CI: 93. 2% ~ 97. 0% ) to 100. 0%, respectively. Positive predictive value ( PPV ) and negative predictive value ( NPV ) ranged from 20. 0% ( 95%CI: 2. 5% ~ 37. 5% ) to 100. 0% and 96. 8% ( 95%CI: 95. 0% ~ 98. 6% ) to 100. 0%, respectively. The concordance rate between microarray data and DNA sequencing results was 100%. Overall, the newly developed microarray platform provides a convenient, highly accurate, and reliable clinical assay for the determination of blood protozoan species.

Biliary atresia is a rare, but severe childhood disease that causes fibrosis of the extrahepatic bile ducts and leads to liver failure. The etiology of biliary atresia remains unknown, although it is thought to be influenced by environmental, inflammatory, infectious, and genetic risk factors. To identify genetic variants associated with biliary atresia, we performed a genome-wide association study in a European-American cohort of 343 isolated biliary atresia patients and 1716 controls. A second genome-wide association study was performed in an independent European-American cohort of 156 patients with biliary atresia and 212 controls. We identified three genetic variants on 2p16. 1 ( rs10865291, rs6761893, and rs727878; P < 5×10−8 ) in the EFEMP1 gene that encodes a secreted extracellular matrix protein implicated in extracellular matrix remodeling, cell proliferation, and organogenesis. RNA expression analysis demonstrated that EFEMP1 is expressed in cholangiocytes and vascular smooth muscle cells in liver specimens from patients with either biliary atresia or other cholestatic diseases, but is absent from cholangiocytes in normal control liver samples. EFEMP1 transcripts had higher expression in cholangiocytes and portal fibroblasts as compared with other cell types in normal rat liver. The identification of a novel BA-associated locus, and implication of EFEMP1 as a new biliary atresia susceptibility gene, could provide new insights to understanding the mechanisms underlying this severe pediatric disorder.

Chromosomal break repair is a highly conserved process that repairs damaged DNA. It is also implicated in many cancers, including those caused by chromosomal aberrations such as those resulting from DNA translocations. When cells repair DNA double-strand breaks, a subset of the breaks can be bypassed using a non-homologous end joining repair pathway called c-NHEJ. Alternatively, in some cases, the breaks can be healed using a complementary DNA repair pathway called DNA crosslink repair ( Alt-EJ ). While it is known that both pathways are important for repairing DNA double-strand breaks, the mediators of such repair pathways are poorly understood. Here, we describe the first comprehensive analysis of factors important for c-NHEJ repair and identify several that are also important for Alt-EJ. These factors are from diverse pathways and are also found in the context of DNA crosslink repair. We further show that several of these factors are required for both repair pathways, and we find that loss of one factor can significantly alter the effect of others. Our data suggest that several DNA repair pathways are important for the repair of DNA double-strand breaks and that c-NHEJ and resection are both important for the repair of these lesions.

How humans communicate during physical interactions is an open question in systems biology. Previous work has focused on hard or soft elastic interactions, but how humans communicate over these physical domains is still unclear. We investigated how pairs tracked a target using flexion-extension of their wrist, which were coupled by a stiffer band. Tracking performance increased with the strength of the coupling, which suggests that the worse partner followed the skilled one’s lead, but simulations show that the results are better explained by a model where partners share movement goals through the forces, whilst the coupling dynamics determine the capacity of communicable information. This model elucidates the versatile mechanism by which humans can coordinate during both hard and soft physical interactions to ensure maximum performance with minimal effort.

Differences in body shape and size among humans in different populations are likely to be driven by evolutionary pressures due to variation in climate. We tested the hypothesis that genes involved in energy metabolism are likely to be central to this process. To test the hypothesis, we developed a novel method for testing the hypothesis that the genetic variation that is observed in humans in the 52 human populations is correlated with variation in climate. We genotyped the 52 in the human genome and the 210 carefully matched control genome for a variety of climatic conditions to show that the genetic variation in the genes that we tested is significantly correlated with climatic variation. The strongest signals were several SNPs ( e. g., LEPR R109K, FABP2 A54T ) that had previously been associated with phenotypes directly related to cold tolerance. Since variation in climate may be correlated with other aspects of environmental variation, it is possible that some of the signals that we detected reflect selective pressures other than climate. Nevertheless, our results are consistent with the idea that climate has been an important selective pressure acting on candidate genes for common metabolic disorders.

The effects of maternal environment on the progeny of an organism are poorly understood. We investigated the effects of a common environmental restriction, dietary restriction, on the size of progeny in the roundworm C. elegans. Worms cultured in dietary restriction produce fewer but larger progeny. We also investigated the effects of dietary restriction on the growth of the progeny. Worms with dietary restriction grow slower and produce fewer progeny than controls. We identified that the effects of dietary restriction on progeny growth and size are mediated through insulin-like signaling. In addition, worms with dietary restriction produce more offspring than control progeny. We also investigated whether dietary restriction and insulin signaling control the growth of the progeny. Worms with dietary restriction grow slower and produce fewer progeny than control worms. We conclude that maternal environmental conditions regulate intergenerational growth and plasticity.

Cystic echinococcosis ( CE ) is a globally distributed zoonosis caused by parasitic worms called cysts. CE is the most important cause of death due to parasitic zoonosis worldwide. In recent years, a number of human CE cases have been reported in Mongolia. We investigated the distribution of CE in the country, and found that the disease was very common in children. The most important species was E. canadensis, the most prevalent of the species in Mongolia. Interestingly, a high percentage of patients were infected by other species of cysts. This finding is of interest because it suggests that a high prevalence of the same species in humans may lead to different disease outcomes. These findings may be of interest in designing control measures.

Infection with Salmonella Typhi causes typhoid fever, a major cause of fever in children in low- and middle-income countries. Diagnosis and treatment are usually presumptive, and hence usually presumptive, owing to the lack of quick and accurate tests at an initial consultation. Using a rapid diagnostic test ( RDT ) for typhoid fever diagnosis in children in a remote health centre setting in Cambodia, we evaluated the cost-effectiveness of using a rapid diagnostic test ( RDT ) in comparison with the clinical diagnosis. The decision was to use a model of the disease and to make decisions based on the results. We estimated the cost-effectiveness of the IgMFA to be $5700; therefore, the incremental cost of the IgMFA was $1579. The key drivers for the cost-effectiveness were the relative sensitivity of IgMFA versus clinical diagnosis, the cost of IgMFA, and the prevalence of typhoid fever or multi-drug resistant strains.

Changes in gene expression levels are a fundamental cellular response to environmental cues. In eukaryotes, mRNA decay is a major component of gene expression control, and the RNA degradation pathway has emerged as a central node in this response. Many genes are degraded via the RNA degradation pathway, and the signals that control this process are largely unknown. In this study, we have characterized the complete transcriptome-wide impact of the RNA degradation signal, dsRNA specific ribonuclease III ( Rnt1p ). We have determined that the sequence and structural context of the Rnt1p signal are linked to its impact on transcriptome expression. Our results suggest that the impact of the RNA degradation signal depends on the dynamic nature of the gene.

The mammary gland is a complex organ that contains epithelial and stromal cells that are organized in a highly polarized manner. This is important for normal mammary function but loss of polarity leads to tumour formation. Here we show that Scrib is an essential component of the mammary gland and that its loss in mice results in defects in the mammary gland, including the development of the progenitor cells that form the mammary gland. We also show that Scrib is important for the control of the early steps of breast cancer progression. In particular, loss of Scrib leads to the induction of a signalling pathway that promotes cell proliferation and induces the development of atypical luminal cells. We also show that Scrib is required for the proper orientation of the mitotic spindle, which is critical for preventing apoptosis and has the potential to induce cell death. Finally, we show that Scrib is essential for the development of the mammary gland and that this process is regulated by the MAPK/Fra1 signalling pathway. These findings provide important new insights into the role of Scrib in regulating the development of the mammary gland and the control of mammary tumourigenesis.

The use of ivermectin ( IVM ) to control parasitic nematodes is an important preventive measure in both humans and animals. However, the development of IVM resistance has resulted in significant economic losses in livestock, companion animals, and human populations. Understanding the mechanisms involved in the adaptation of IVM to IVM-resistant nematodes would help to develop new treatments that can increase the efficacy of IVM against resistant parasites. In this study, we have identified NHR-8, a nuclear hormone receptor involved in the xenobiotic response in Caenorhabditis elegans, as a new target of IVM resistance. Our results show that NHR-8 is involved in the development and function of the cellular detoxification network that contributes to IVM resistance in C. elegans. Importantly, NHR-8 was also shown to be involved in the development and function of the parasitic nematode Haemonchus contortus, which shares the major parasitic nematode of humans. We also provide evidence that Hco-nhr-8, a nuclear receptor previously shown to be involved in the response to anthelmintic macrocyclic lactones ( e. g., ivermectin ), is also involved in the development and function of the NHR-8-mediated IVM detoxification network in H. contortus. Thus, our results provide novel insights into the molecular basis of IVM resistance and open perspectives for the development of new compounds with NHR-8 antagonist activity to potentiate IVM efficacy.

Plant resistance ( R ) proteins are a highly conserved defense system that protects plants against a broad range of pathogens. Despite their importance in plant immunity, relatively few of the ∼170 R proteins in Arabidopsis have well-characterized resistance specificity. Here, we identify the Arabidopsis R protein HOPZ-ACTIVATED RESISTANCE 1 ( ZAR1 ) as the gene responsible for recognition of the Pseudomonas syringae type III secreted effector ( HopZ1a ) effector. ZAR1 is a member of the coiled-coil ( CC ) family of nucleotide binding site and leucine-rich repeat ( NBS–LRR ) containing R proteins. However, the phylogenetic analysis indicates that ZAR1 is not related to other Arabidopsis R proteins. In addition, we demonstrate that ZAR1–mediated immunity is independent of several genes required by other R protein signaling pathways, including NDR1 and RAR1, suggesting that ZAR1 possesses distinct signaling requirements.
