Also, we show that HopZ1a promotes Pseudomonas growth indicative of an ancestral virulence function for this T3SE family prior to the evolution of recognition by the host resistance protein ZAR1. Our results demonstrate that the Arabidopsis resistance protein ZAR1 confers allele-specific recognition and virulence attenuation of the Pseudomonas syringae T3SE protein HopZ1a.

Lyme disease is the most common vector-borne illness in North America, and B. burgdorferi is the Lyme disease agent. Both Lyme disease and other vector-borne diseases are caused by exposure to toxic compounds in both the tick vector and the vertebrate host. B. burgdorferi is exposed to a variety of oxidative and nitrosative agents, and the mechanisms of resistance to these agents are poorly understood. Here, we used transposon mutagenesis to screen for genes involved in resistance to at least one of the stressors. We identified 66 genes whose disruption resulted in increased susceptibility to at least one of the stressors. These genes include previously characterized mediators of ROS and RNS resistance, as well as new putative resistance candidates. One of the new genes, identified in this screen, is predicted to function in the inner membrane, and is identified to be involved in the maintenance of B. burgdorferi manganese homeostasis. Our data provide insight into how B. burgdorferi responds to ROS and RNS and suggests that this response is relevant to the in vivo success of the organism.

Sporotrichosis is a chronic infection caused by fungal pathogens. There are many species of fungi that can infect humans, animals, and plants, causing sporotrichosis in humans, animals, and plants. The fungus that causes sporotrichosis is known as Sporothrix, and it is often associated with a particular geographic location. However, the genus Sporothrix is complex, and members cause disease in humans, animals, and plants. Currently, the species responsible for sporotrichosis is difficult to distinguish from other fungi, and the identification of the species is difficult. We developed a panel of novel molecular diagnostic tools that detect and distinguish clinically relevant members of the Sporothrix genus. We employed a murine model of disseminated sporotrichosis and identified a simple, direct PCR assay that could detect and distinguish the three species responsible for the disease in clinical specimens. We used the method to test clinical samples collected in Brazil and China, and we found that S. brasiliensis, S. schenckii, S. globosa, S. mexicana, S. pallida, and O. stenoceras were successfully detected in spleen, liver, lungs, heart, liver, and feces of infected animals. Our method could be used to detect the sporotrichosis in clinical specimens.

Microbial infections pose a serious threat to human health and animals, but the mechanisms by which animals resist infection are poorly understood. Using the model organism Drosophila melanogaster, we investigated the molecular mechanisms that underlie tolerance to RNA virus infection. We found that the histone H3 methyltransferase G9a is a key factor in regulating the sensitivity of the Jak-Stat pathway to viral infection. In the absence of G9a, the Jak-Stat pathway fails to induce a robust adaptive response and, consequently, the flies are more sensitive to viral infection than wild-type controls. We also found that hyperactivated Jak-Stat responses are associated with early lethality in virus-infected flies. Our results demonstrate that the epigenetic mechanisms that underlie tolerance to viral infection are distinct from those that underlie resistance to other microbial infections.

Human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) is the only human retrovirus associated to a human T-cell lymphotropic virus ( HTLV-2 ). We assessed the prevalence of HTLV-1 among the population living in Gabon, central Africa, 30 years after the first epidemiological analysis was performed. The prevalence of HTLV-1 was of 7. 3% among the rural Gabonese population, with 5. 4% for men and 9. 0% for women. The prevalence of HTLV-1 differed by province, ranging from 2. 3% to 12. 5% into the rain forest. Being a woman older than 51 years represented a high risk for HTLV-1 acquisition. In addition, 0. 1% of samples were found as HTLV-2 positive, while 12. 0% had an indeterminate HTLV serological pattern. HTLV-3 and HTLV-4 were not found. Phylogenetic analysis was performed on 87 samples and demonstrated that HTLV-1 present in Gabon belongs mostly to subtype B, however the rare subtype D was also found. Our results demonstrate that almost thirty years after the first epidemiological study prevention of HTLVs infection is still an issue in Gabon.

Animals and other organisms have evolved specific behaviors to adapt to their environment. Odors are important for this process, as animals use them to locate food sources, mating sites, and resting sites. Odors are detected by olfactory receptors, which are expressed in the brain. Odor-induced behaviors are tightly coupled to brain areas controlling movement. However, the neuronal mechanisms controlling these behaviors remain largely unknown. We have studied the olfactory-motor output pathway in the sea lamprey brain. We found that olfactory stimulation induced large excitatory responses in the reticulospinal cells, the command neurons for locomotion. Activation of this olfactory-motor pathway generated rhythmic ventral root discharges and swimming movements. We have also identified the anatomy and physiology of this circuit. We have also identified the olfactory input was relayed in the medial olfactory bulb, in the posterior tuberculum, in the mesencephalic locomotor region, to finally reach reticulospinal cells in the hindbrain. Activation of this olfactory-motor pathway generated rhythmic ventral root discharges and swimming movements. Our study bridges the gap between behavior and neural mechanisms in vertebrates.

Portal-systemic encephalopathy ( PSE ) is a severe neurological disease caused by infection with the liver fluke Schistosoma mansoni. Infection with S. mansoni can cause various clinical manifestations in patients, including hepatic and brain atrophy, encephalopathy, and hypotonia. The most common clinical manifestation of PSE in patients is chronic liver disease. In the case of chronic hepatitis C infection ( HCC ), PSE is caused by infection with the liver fluke Taenia solium. In patients with chronic hepatitis C and chronic schistosomiasis, PSE is caused by infection with the liver fluke Ascaris lumbricoides, which is thought to be the most common liver fluke infection. The prevalence of PSE in chronic hepatitis C and schistosomiasis japonicum is high, and in endemic areas, PSE is the most frequent cause of death in patients. In this study, we have investigated whether magnetic resonance ( MRS ) could be used for the diagnosis of PSE in patients with suspected PSE or in patients with no clinical symptoms. The results obtained from our study showed that MRS could be a useful tool for the diagnosis of PSE in patients with suspected PSE or in patients with no clinical symptoms.

The neural crest is the specialized cell type that generates the body's various cell types. The neural crest is induced at the neural plate border during gastrulation, a process that requires the activity of a complex signaling network. While intermediate BMP levels are critical for neural crest induction, secreted inhibitors of BMP are largely absent from the neural plate border. Here, we have developed a model in which attenuation of BMP signaling sets the required intermediate levels to maintain neural crest induction. We show that the scaffold protein casein kinase interacting protein 1 ( CKIP-1 ) and ubiquitin ligase Smurf1 are coexpressed with BMP4 at the neural plate border. Knockdown of CKIP-1 during a critical period between gastrulation and neurulation causes neural crest loss. Consistent with specific BMP modulation, CKIP-1 loss suppresses phospho-Smads 1/5/8 ( pSmad1/5/8 ) and BMP reporter output, whereas overexpression of Smurf1 acts similarly. Epistasis experiments further show that CKIP-1 rescues Smurf1-mediated neural crest loss. Taken together, our results support a model in which CKIP-1 suppresses Smurf1-mediated degradation of Smads, uncovering an intracellular mechanism for attenuation of BMP signaling to the intermediate levels required for maintenance of neural crest induction.

In this study, we compared two related fungal species, Cladophialophora Carrionii and Fonsecaea, and compared the genomes of these strains with those of C. Carrionii, the agent of human chromoblastomycosis in arid climates of Africa, Asia, Australia, Central-and South-America. We found evidence of gene flow between these species, and this gene flow was especially strong in South American populations. This gene flow was also observed in African populations, suggesting that these species have an evolutionary history that is longer than that of C. Carrionii. This pattern of gene flow among strains of these three species differed significantly from that of C. Carrionii, indicating that the two species differ in their ability to colonize the host, which may be due to a different host range.

In Brazil, yellow fever ( YF ) outbreaks may indicate circulation of YF virus in non-human primates, and provide early warning of risk to humans. From October 2008 through June 2009, the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil’s largest municipality, analyzed epizootic surveillance data and assessed YF vaccine coverage, timeliness of implementation of vaccination, and the impact of vaccination in unvaccinated human populations. From October 2008 through June 2009, YF virus was detected in 67 municipalities in Rio Grande do Sul State; vaccination was recommended in 23 ( 34% ) prior to the outbreak and in 16 ( 24% ) within two weeks of first epizootic report. In 28 ( 42% ) municipalities, vaccination began more than two weeks after first epizootic report. In 11 ( 52% ) of 21 human YF cases ( 21 were in two municipalities with delayed vaccination ), timely response to epizootic events is critical to prevent human yellow fever cases.

Melioidosis is an infectious disease caused by the gram-negative Gram-negative bacillus Burkholderia pseudomallei. It is well known to cause severe morbidity and mortality in Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand. However, it remains poorly reported in surrounding areas such as Cambodia, where the disease is thought to be much less frequent. In this study, we report a case series of melioidosis in seven patients from Takeo Province, Cambodia. The patients, aged 24–65 years, were enrolled from May 2014 to May 2015 during a one year prospective study of sepsis at Takeo Provincial Hospital. They presented with fever, rigors, dyspnea, fatigue, diaphoresis, productive cough, and skin abscesses. Six of the seven patients were also hyponatremic. We provide a detailed description of the clinical presentation, case management and laboratory confirmation of B. pseudomallei, as well as discuss the difficulties of identifying and treating melioidosis in low resource settings.

Regeneration of a single cell is an important biological process that underlies tissue regeneration and tissue homeostasis. The zebrafish provides an excellent model system for the study of regeneration because of the ease of ablating the various cell types that form in the adult animal. Previously, we have demonstrated that regeneration of the melanocyte cell type occurs in the absence of a small molecule, MoTP. The ease of ablating melanocytes by MoTP allows us to investigate the genetic mechanisms specific to regeneration from stem cells. We identified two novel mutants that affect the development of the melanocyte cell type. One, earthaj23e1, is a nonsense mutation in theGF-activated protein 1 (GF-1 ), the rate-limiting enzyme in glucose-6-phosphate biosynthesis. The other, jul jej24e1, is a splice-site mutation in the super killer viralicidic activity 2 ( Skiv2 ), a predicted RNA helicase. Our analysis suggests that the mutation in skiv2l2 causes defects in cell proliferation and melanocyte differentiation in a late stage of regeneration. These findings are consistent with previously described role of cell division during larval melanocyte regeneration. These results demonstrate that mechanisms of regeneration identified in this mutant screen may reveal fundamental differences between the mechanisms that establish differentiated cells during embryogenesis, and those involved in larval or adult growth.

Fungal infections are a serious health problem, including infections of the eye and the brain. The fungi that cause these infections are typically thought to be extremely harmful and are often resistant to antibiotics. In the current study we demonstrate that the host immune response and the iron uptake can be used to inhibit fungal growth. We show that Dectin-1, a receptor that detects iron, is also responsible for the iron uptake in Aspergillus and Fusarium. We further show that the iron uptake can be blocked by topical iron or lactoferrin, a natural product found in the skin. Finally, we demonstrate that fungal growth can be reduced by topical iron or lactoferrin. Our work demonstrates that fungal iron uptake can be blocked to reduce fungal growth in the host and identifies a novel mechanism by which fungal iron can be added to the host during infection. This is a new way that the host immune system may be able to inhibit fungal growth and may be a new therapeutic strategy to treat fungal infections.

Neuropeptides are a diverse group of proteins that function as neurotransmitters and hormones that orchestrate many physiological and behavioral functions in the brain. Neuropeptides are produced by dense core vesicles ( DCVs ), which are formed by a complex of clathrin-mediated membrane remodeling events. This maturation process is required for efficient processing of neuropeptides and removal of factors that would otherwise interfere with DCV release. We previously identified a GTPase, RAB-2, and its effector, RIC-19, that is required for DCV maturation in C. elegans motoneurons. In rab-2 mutants, specific cargo is lost from maturing DCVs and missorted into the endosomal/lysosomal degradation pathway. Cargo loss could be prevented by blocking endosomal delivery. This suggests that RAB-2 is involved in retention of DCV components during the sorting process at the Golgi-endosomal interface. To understand how RAB-2 activity is regulated at the Golgi, we identified a potential RAB-2 GAP, TBC-8, which is exclusively expressed in neurons and which, when depleted, shows similar defects as rab-2 mutants. We could demonstrate that RAB-2 binds to its putative GAP, TBC-8. Interestingly, TBC-8 also binds to the RAB-2 effector, RIC-19. This interaction appears to be conserved as TBC-8 also interacts with the human ortholog of RIC-19, ICA69. Therefore, we propose that a dynamic ON/OFF cycling of RAB-2 at the Golgi induced by the GAP/effector complex is required for proper DCV maturation.

A new human oral challenge model with wild-type Salmonella Typhi ( S. Typhi ) was recently developed. In this model, ingestion of 104 CFU of Salmonella resulted in 65% of subjects developing typhoid fever ( referred here as typhoid diagnosis -TD- ) 5–10 days post-challenge. TD criteria included meeting clinical ( oral temperature ≥38°C for ≥12h ) and/or microbiological ( S. Typhi bacteremia ) endpoints. One of the first lines of defense against pathogens are the cells of the innate immune system ( e. g., monocytes, dendritic cells -DCs ). Various changes in circulating monocytes and DCs have been described in the murine S. Typhimurium model; however, whether similar changes are present in humans remains to be explored. To address these questions, a subset of volunteers were evaluated for changes in circulating monocytes and DCs. We show that monocytes and DCs from NoTD volunteers show increased binding to S. Typhi one day after challenge. These monocytes showed increased activity and migration to the S. Typhi-containing LPS micelles. These results show that monocytes and DCs from TD volunteers are activated and migrate to the S. Typhi-containing LPS micelles. This is the first study to describe different activation and migration profiles, as well as differential signaling patterns, in monocytes and DCs which relate directly to the clinical outcome following oral challenge with wild type S. Typhi.

Previous studies have shown that D. melanogaster exhibits variable phenotypes in the face of a common environmental stress, such as starvation. However, the mechanisms underlying the differences in disease phenotypes are not well understood. In this study, we used bacterial load and gene expression measurements to study how natural genetic variation influences immune function in D. melanogaster. We found that variation in bacterial load is controlled by genes near the top of the immune system signaling cascade. In addition, we found that transcriptional induction of effector proteins is a significant predictor of bacterial load.

Infection with HTLV-1 is an important public health concern in Central Africa, but the risk factors remain poorly understood. We conducted an epidemiological survey in Gabon, the largest HTLV-1 endemic area in Central Africa. Epidemiological data were obtained and blood samples were collected after informed consent. We recruited 2, 060 individuals over 15 years old, including 1, 205 men and 855 women ( mean age: 49 years ). Of these, 299 were found to be ELISA HTLV-1/2 seropositive. According to WB criteria, 136 were HTLV-1 ( 6. 6% ), 25 HTLV-1/2 ( 1. 2% ) and 9 HTLV seroreactive ( 0. 4% ). PCR results showed that 146 individuals were positive for at least one PCR: 104 for the env gene and 131 for the LTR region. Based on both serological and molecular results, 179 individuals were considered infected with HTLV-1, leading to an overall prevalence of 8. 7%. The distribution of HTLV-1 infection was heterogeneous across the country. Based on multivariable analyses, female gender, increasing age, ethnicity, and multiple hospitalizations were found to be independent risk factors for HTLV-1 infection. Moreover, a non-human primate bite appeared to be marginally associated with a higher risk of HTLV-1 infection.

Proteins are complex molecules that are composed of multiple polypeptides that are linked by short linear polymers, called spliceosomes, which are responsible for the removal of introns from mRNAs and for the joining of coding and non-coding sequences. In addition to this basic role, spliceosomes influence the expression of other genes. In this study, we investigated the role of RSR-2, the only spliceosomal component in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, in the development of this organism. Our results show that RSR-2 influences development by influencing transcription, suggesting a novel role for this protein.

The evolution of plants is a complex process that involves both the formation of new species, as well as the diversification of existing species. The evolutionary relationships between species' lineages are poorly understood, largely because of the lack of high-throughput genomic data. We have developed a novel phylogenomic approach that allows the accurate reconstruction of the relationships among 22, 833 sets of orthologs from the genomes of 101 land plant genera. Our results demonstrate that, in addition to the traditional methods of phylogenomics, we can obtain a global view of the evolution of plant genomes by studying the relationships among the 101 groups of orthologs. We have also used this approach to identify genes that are likely involved in the evolution of the plant kingdom. Our results provide a comprehensive view of the evolution of plant genomes, and also reveal the evolutionary relationships among the 101 groups of orthologs.

Typhoid fever is a bacterial disease caused by Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi ( S. Typhi ), transmitted through contaminated food or water, and can cause severe symptoms, such as typhoid fever. The bacterium has been isolated from the intestine of people with typhoid fever who have been vaccinated against the protein in their blood, but some people have not been vaccinated. We conducted a survey of the blood of people in Fiji, an upper-middle income country in the Pacific Ocean, to measure the prevalence of antibodies to the protein in the blood of the people who had never been vaccinated against the protein in the past. The results show that people who have never been vaccinated against the protein are more likely to have been infected with the bacteria in the past, which suggests that exposure to the protein may be a cause of illness in those who did not receive vaccination. The presence of a pit latrine, a septic water, or a small town or village also increases the probability that people are exposed to the protein. Improving sanitation where pit latrines are used and addressing potential transmission routes in settlements may reduce exposure to the protein to S. Typhi.

FTO is a gene associated with obesity in humans. Studies using rodent models have demonstrated a role for FTO in energy balance and body composition. We generated mice with loss of Fto expression and found that these mice were healthy and had no signs of obesity. We also studied mice with loss of Fto in the body and found that these mice had lower body weight at birth than their normal litter. We then used a viral approach to show that this phenotype can be explained by loss of Fto in the body, but not changes in food intake or body composition. Our data suggest that Fto may have a critical role in the control of lean mass, independent of its effect on feeding.

P-loop NTPases ( P-Ls ) are known to be important regulators of cell division and differentiation in a wide variety of eukaryotes, and a key role for P-Ls in plant development has been shown to be under the control of the P-loop NTPase APP1. In the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, the P-loop NTPase regulates the identity of the root apical meristem ( AM ) cell and the distal stem cell ( DSC ) niche. In this study, we found that the P-loop NTPase regulates ROS homeostasis in the apical meristem and the DSC niche in the root apical meristem. The P-loop NTPase-mediated ROS level is required for the regulation of cell division and the maintenance of the DSC niche in the apical meristem. Interestingly, the P-loop NTPase-regulated ROS level and the maintenance of the DSC niche are dependent on the level of protein SHORTROOT ( SHR ). These results indicate that the P-loop NTPase-regulated ROS signaling controls the identity of the root QC and the DSC niche.

How cells coordinate cell division and chromosome replication with cell division is a fundamental question in cell biology. Cells of the rod-shaped bacterium Myxococcus xanthus coordinate cell division with chromosome replication and segregation. This coordination is essential, but the molecular mechanism is still poorly understood. In this work, we have analyzed the arrangement of the circular chromosome ( a circular DNA molecule ) and the dynamics of its subcellular localization and replication. We show that, in newborn cells, the chromosome is arranged between two subpolar regions, each containing only one copy of the chromosome, and each separated from the nearest subpolar region by approximately 1 µm. The bulk of the chromosome is arranged between the two subpolar regions, thus leaving the two large subpolar regions devoid of DNA. Upon replication, one subpolar region remains in the original subpolar region while the other copy segregates unidirectionally to the opposite subpolar region. In parallel, the ter region of the mother chromosome relocates to midcell, where it is replicated. Consequently, after completion of replication and segregation, the two chromosomes show an arrangement that combines features from previously described systems with new features leading to a novel spatiotemporal arrangement pattern.

A central issue in science and medicine is how to allocate resources to the many scientific questions that require attention. In recent years, a variety of funding schemes have been developed for science, but the details of their impact on science remain poorly understood. In this study, we use the economic theory of contests to analyze how efficient a currently available funding program can be when compared to alternative mechanisms such as lotteries. We find that the effort researchers spend a lot of money in writing proposals, which can be a burden to the funder if the proposed science is not used. But, if the outcome of the competition is to receive funding for reasons other than promotion, then the entire program can actually hamper scientific progress when the number of awards is small. Our results suggest that losses in funding may be restored either by partial lotteries for funding or by funding researchers based on past scientific success instead of proposals for future work.

DNA is a molecule that can be transferred directly from one cell to another via physical contact. This process is called DNA transfer, and it is important to study how bacteria evolve to become able to actively transfer DNA. Some bacteria employ a mechanism to take up DNA and incorporate it into their genome, a process called transformation. The donor cell actively pushes out DNA and the recipient cell employs the natural competence system to take up the DNA, in a process called conjugation. While the DNA uptake machinery is well known as in other species that undergo transformation, the pushing step of conjugation remains to be characterized. We have found that the TdtA protein, which is involved in DNA uptake, is also required for DNA pushing but not for DNA pulling. Purified TdtA shows ATPase activity and oligomerizes as hexamers with a central opening that can accommodate double-stranded DNA. The tdtA gene was found to belong to a mobile 14 kbp-long DNA element inserted within the 3′ end of a tRNA gene, flanked by 47 bp direct repeats. The insertion also encoded a type II restriction endonuclease and a NurA-like nuclease, whose activities were required for efficient transjugation. All these data support that TdtA belongs to a new type of Integrative and Conjugative Element which promotes the generalized and efficient transfer of genetic traits that could facilitate its co-selection among bacterial populations.

Autism Spectrum Disorder and Schizophrenia are two very common neurobehavioral disorders that are caused by a variety of genes and environmental factors. Genetic studies have shown that many of the disease-causing mutations are rare, but it is unclear which genes are associated with this rare disease. Here, we use a large-scale resequencing ( n = 285 patients ) study to identify genes associated with these two complex disorders. We find that three genes, MAP1A, GRIN2B, and CACNA1F, are consistently identified by different methods. We also find that these genes explain a large part of the phenotypic variance of these two neurobehavioral disorders. This study demonstrates that these genes can be mapped using resequencing, and identifies a large number of rare mutations that cause both autism and schizophrenia.

Alcohol use disorder ( AUD ) is a complex disease caused by genetic factors. Although many genetic variants have been identified, there are still many unknown genes and genes with a strong effect on AUD. One way of identifying new genes is to use animal models, such as rats, where the effects of individual genes can be studied in a controlled way. We have recently published a new set of rats for which we have sequenced the genome, enabling us to study the effects of natural variation on rat behavior. In this paper, we use this new set of rats to analyze genetic variation for alcohol preference in the context of other biological traits. We identify the genes that are most important for alcohol preference and the genetic variants that control this trait. We have also found genes that are involved in other complex traits, suggesting that these genes are likely to be involved in a large number of biological functions.

The identification of genetic variants associated with complex diseases is a major challenge in human genetics. With recent advances in genome-wide association studies, thousands of genetic variants have been discovered that can be used to develop a diagnostic tool to predict disease risk. However, these variants are often affected by many genetic variants with small or moderate effects, which makes the identification of disease risk variants difficult. Here, we propose a novel statistical framework, graph-GPA, to integrate a large number of genetic variants for multiple phenotypes using a hidden Markov random field approach. We show that graph-GPA improves statistical power to identify risk variants compared to statistical methods based on smaller number of GWAS datasets. In addition, graph-GPA also promotes better understanding of genetic mechanisms shared among phenotypes, which can potentially be useful for the development of improved diagnosis and therapeutics.

C. H. E. is a severe inherited disease that is characterized by retinal degeneration and blindness. The disease is caused by mutations in the CLCC1 gene, which encodes a chloride channel that is expressed in the retina. CLCC1 is highly expressed in the retina and mutations in CLCC1 cause autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa ( arRP ), an inherited disease that is characterized by degeneration of the photoreceptors ( the light sensing cells of the retina ) and blindness. We discovered that CLCC1 mutations in the retina result in a nonfunctional phenotype that can be rescued by injection of normal CLCC1 mRNA into zebrafish embryos. The mutant CLCC1 mice show abnormal development and reduced expression of the photoreceptor rod and cone opsins. Our results suggest that CLCC1 is important for survival and function of retinal cells.

The use of oral cholera vaccines ( OCV ) has recently been shown to be effective in cholera endemic countries such as India, and to be safe and effective when administered as a supplement to traditional vaccines. However, evidence on the use of OCV in mass cholera control programs is limited. The objective of this study was to assess the feasibility of mass vaccination with a new, less expensive OCV ( Shanchol ) in Odisha, India, as a model. The vaccine was administered as a supplement to existing public health infrastructure in this country. The vaccine and delivery costs were estimated using review of project expenditure records and by interviewing key personnel. The results indicate that mass vaccination can be feasible and requires detailed micro-planning. The vaccine and delivery cost is affordable for resource poor countries.

The Drosophila heart is a classic model for organogenesis, as its development is under the control of the steroid hormone ecdysone. Here, we have investigated the role of genomic approaches in providing new insights into the molecular pathways involved in heart development. We applied the most comprehensive set of 8 time-points that cover the entire developmental process of the adult heart to a novel genomic approach that combines transcriptional profiling and functional analysis. We uncovered a highly dynamic temporal map of gene expression through 13 transcript clusters with distinct expression kinetics. We also found evidence that the ecdysone cascade is involved in the regulation of key components belonging to a few evolutionarily conserved signalling pathways. Furthermore, we uncovered the functional significance of the Wnt signalling pathway in inflow tract and cardiomyocyte differentiation. Our results provide new insights into heart development and show that the role of specific transcriptional pathways in heart formation can be inferred by genomic approaches.

The presence of the recently introduced primary dengue virus vector mosquito Aedes aegypti in Nepal, in association with the likely indigenous secondary vector Aedes albopictus, raises public health concerns. Here, we report the results of a study on the risk factors for the presence of chikungunya and dengue virus vectors, their elevational ceiling of distribution, and climatic determinants of their abundance in central Nepal. Our results show that Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus are present but rarely found from 1, 750 to 2, 100 m asl in Dhunche ( highest altitude sampled: 2, 100 m asl ). The lymphatic filariasis vector Culex quinquefasciatus is commonly found throughout the study transect. The climatic variables rainfall, temperature, and relative humidity were significant predictors of chikungunya and dengue virus vectors abundance. We conclude that chikungunya and dengue virus vectors have already established their populations up to the High Mountain region, previously considered non-endemic for dengue and chikungunya fever, and that this may be attributed to the environmental and climate change that has been observed over the decades in Nepal.

Animals show remarkable ability to quickly and flexibly change behavior in response to social interactions. These behavioral changes are thought to be mediated by genetic changes in the brain, but the underlying molecular mechanisms are still unclear. Here, we show that the genome dynamically responds to social interactions with multiple waves of transcription associated with distinct molecular functions in the brain of male threespined sticklebacks, a species famous for its behavioral repertoire and evolution. Some biological functions peaked soon after a brief territorial challenge and then declined, while others peaked hours afterwards. We identify transcription factors that are predicted to coordinate waves of transcription associated with different components of behavioral plasticity. We also show that a brief territorial intrusion was sufficient to rapidly and dramatically alter the epigenome, and that changes in gene expression also accompany changes in chromatin accessibility. Finally, we integrate time course brain gene expression data with a transcriptional regulatory network and link gene expression to changes in chromatin accessibility. This study reveals rapid and dramatic plasticity in behavioral responses to a brief, highly consequential social interaction.

Ubiquitination is a protein modification process that regulates the activity of many proteins through targeting of a small protein called ubiquitin to a peptide chain. It is important for the cell to maintain homeostasis and the rapid response to external and internal danger. Ubiquitination is involved in almost all cellular processes, and is implicated in cancer development. In this study, we used X-ray crystallography to determine the structure of a region of the immediate-early protein ICP0, which is involved in the regulation of cellular genes and is a therapeutic target for cancer therapy. We found that ICP0 interacts with human ubiquitin-like proteins, including UHRF1 and USP7, through a region of the protein that is similar to that of the USP7 peptide. We were able to show that ICP0 uses the same mechanism of binding to USP7 as other known ubiquitinating proteins. Moreover, we were able to determine the structure of a near full-length USP7 protein and show that it could bind the same region of ICP0 as USP7, thus providing further evidence for the importance of this interaction for regulation of viral genes.

Melioidosis is a tropical infectious disease caused by the Gram-negative bacillus Burkholderia pseudomallei. It is associated with early septic shock and a high case fatality rate, and there are no approved treatments. We reviewed published case reports from Malaysia to identify those with melioidosis. We found that cases of melioidosis reported from Malaysia generally presented with liver abscesses, lung abscesses, or septic shock. Abscesses of the liver, spleen, lung, and skin were the most common clinical presentations, and were associated with high rates of secondary bacterial infections. The presence of bacteria in the blood was associated with increased risk of septic shock. In Malaysia, the clinical presentation of all cases was similar to those reported in South and Southeast Asia, and no difference was found among children. The most important risk factor for developing septic shock was diabetes. Early recognition of the disease is the cornerstone of management. In clinical situations of community-acquired sepsis and/or pneumonia, where laboratory bacteriological confirmation is not possible, empirical treatment with antimicrobials for B. pseudomallei is recommended.

Cyclic expansion of a CGG repeat within the FMR1 gene causes intellectual disability. We studied families with FRA2A expression in the FMR1 gene that have neurodevelopmental phenotypes in the range of several hundred repeat units. We identified a polymorphic CGG repeat in an alternative promoter of the AFF3 gene, a gene of unknown function. We found that FRA2A-expressing individuals have mosaic expansions of the AFF3 CGG repeat in the range of several hundred repeat units. Furthermore, we show that AFF3 is expressed in several tissues during development and that its expression is delayed in FRA2A-expressing individuals. We also show that the mouse AFF3 ortholog, the FMR1 ortholog, is expressed in the developing brain, limb buds and somites. These results provide evidence that FRA2A is a CGG repeat expansion associated with a functional impairment of the AFF3 gene in the developing brain. However, additional cases are required to firmly establish a causal relationship.

Molecular evolution is the process of change in DNA sequence. It can be used for evolutionary inference, inference of species history, and the estimation of evolutionary times. For a long time, evolutionary biologists have used a simple mutation rate to estimate evolutionary times, assuming that the mutation rate is constant across species. Now, with new genomic sequencing technologies, it is possible to directly measure the mutation rate of a DNA region, the mitochondrial genome of Drosophila melanogaster. We compared the mutation rate of the mitochondrial genome in D. melanogaster lines that had undergone about 200 generations of spontaneous mutation accumulation. We estimate the mutation rate of the mitochondrial genome to be about 6. 2×10−8 per site per fly generation, which is 30 times higher than the nuclear mutation rate. The mitochondrial mutation rate per base pair per fly generation is about 10× higher than the nuclear rate, but the mutation rate per base pair per fly generation is about 70× higher than the nuclear rate. These findings suggest that, besides being a useful way to infer evolutionary times, mitochondrial DNA mutation rates are also useful for understanding the extreme mutation bias towards A+T and silent sites.

Human inherited diseases are characterized by pathologic mutations in genes. Single nucleotide variations ( SNVs ), which are single point mutations, are responsible for most of the disease variability. In humans, exome sequencing has been widely used to detect pathogenic SNVs, but many questions remain. Most of them, however, are based on applications of traditional statistical methods, such as multiple testing and adjustment. Here, we propose a novel approach, called SPRING, which integrates information from various genomic sources to predict disease-causing SNVs. We show that it is effective for diseases with known genetic bases and for diseases with unknown genetic bases. We also provide an online implementation of the method to predict causative SNVs for 5, 080 diseases.

Hendra, Nipah, and Hendra viruses are henipaviruses that cause severe respiratory and neurological disease in humans that can be fatal. The pathogenesis of henipavirus infection is poorly understood. To characterize the pathogenic mechanisms of henipavirus infection in vivo, we infected ferrets with genetically distinct Hendra, Nipah-Bangladesh, and Nipah-Malaysia strains. The Hendra virus caused severe respiratory and neurological disease with animals succumbing around 7 days post infection. Despite the presence of abundant viral shedding, infection did not occur. The host gene expression profiles of the lung tissue showed early activation of interferon responses and subsequent expression of inflammation-related genes that coincided with the clinical deterioration. Additionally, the lung tissue showed unchanged levels of lymphocyte markers and progression of cell cycle genes and extracellular matrix components. Infection in the brain resulted in a limited breadth of host responses, which is in accordance with the immunopriv privileged status of this organ. Finally, we propose a model of the pathogenic mechanisms of henipavirus infection that integrates multiple components of the host responses.

Inherited generalized hypertrichosis ( HG ) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by excessive hair growth that does not result from androgen stimulation. HG is associated with additional birthmarks, congenital abnormalities and a variety of extragenic malformations. HG is caused by mutations in the ABCA5 gene, which encodes a lipid transporter. We identified a single base pair substitution in the 5′ donor splice site of intron 32 in the ABC transporter gene ABCA5 that leads to an aberrant splicing of the transcript and a decrease in protein levels throughout patient hair follicles. The homozygous recessive disruption of ABCA5 leads to reduced lysosome function, which results in an accumulation of autophagosomes, autophagosomal cargos as well as increased endolysosomal cholesterol in CGHT keratinocytes. In an unrelated sporadic case of CGHT, we identified a 1. 3 Mb cryptic deletion encompassing ABCA5 and found that ABCA5 levels are dramatically reduced throughout patient hair follicles. Collectively, our findings support ABCA5 as a gene underlying the CGHT phenotype and suggest a novel, previously unrecognized role for this gene in regulating hair growth.

Anthrax is a potentially fatal bacterial disease caused by Bacillus anthracis. The outcome of infection is determined by the virulence factor, lethal toxin, as well as by genetic variation within the host. Using a collection of congenic mice, we found that strains of B. anthracis with different virulence factors showed altered susceptibility to lethal toxin. The genetic variation in one or more of these genes increased the inflammatory response to lethal toxin in mice and contributed to increased resistance to B. anthracis infection. We also identified multiple other genetic variants that contributed to increased susceptibility to B. anthracis infection in mice. Our data suggest that allelic variation of one or more genes in addition to Nlrp1b contributes to the host response to multiple inflammatory stimuli and contributes to resistance to B. anthracis Sterne. These data provide the basis for future genetic and pharmacological studies aimed at modulating the immune response to B. anthracis infection.

Oligodendrocyte precursor cells ( OPCs ) are the most abundant cell population in the adult normal brain and they are at the origin of gliomas, which are highly prevalent brain tumors. They are strongly suspected to be at the origin of gliomas when their equilibrium is disrupted. We present a model of the dynamics of OPCs, first in a normal tissue. This model is based on a cellular automaton and its rules are mimicking the ones that regulate the dynamics of real OPCs. The model is able to reproduce the homeostasis of the cell population, with the maintenance of a constant and uniform cell density. We show that there exists a fair quantitative agreement between the simulated and experimental parameters, such as the cell velocity, the time taken to close a lesion, and the duration of the cell cycle. We present three possible scenarios of disruption of the equilibrium: the appearance of an over-proliferating cell, of a deadless/non-differentiating cell, or of a cell that lost any contact-inhibition. We show that an over-proliferating cell is sufficient to trigger the growth of a tumor that has low-grade glioma features. The results of our model contribute to the body of evidence that identify OPCs as possible cells of origin of gliomas.

Filariae are parasitic nematodes that cause debilitating diseases in humans and animals. These parasites are unique among parasitic nematodes in having fully developed digestive tracts and reproductive organs. Little is known about the biological functions of these organs. We have used a proteomic approach to identify proteins present in the different body wall, digestive tract, and reproductive tract of Brugia malayi, a causative agent of lymphatic filariasis. We identified several hundred proteins, and analyzed the functions of each. In total, we identified 4, 785 proteins. While 1, 894 proteins were identified in all three anatomical fractions, 396 were present only within the digestive tract. We also found that several proteins are present only within the digestive tract, suggesting that the intestine of adult filariae is functional and important for nutrient uptake or waste removal. As expected, the body wall exhibited increased frequencies of cytoskeletal proteins, and the reproductive tract had increased frequencies of proteins involved in nuclear regulation and transcription. We identified 106 proteins that are enriched in the digestive tract and are predicted to localize to the surface of cells in the digestive tract. Some of these proteins are on the luminal surface and may be accessible by antibodies ingested by the worm. A subset of 27 of these proteins are found in only one or two transmembrane domains.

The cytomegalovirus ( CMV ) is a herpesvirus that infects most people worldwide, and can cause severe disease, ranging from encephalitis to heart disease, in individuals with weakened immune systems. CMV is a herpesvirus that establishes a latent infection in the majority of the population in which it remains as an asymptomatic latent infection. In immunodeficient individuals, CMV can reactivate and cause a life-threatening disease. We have previously shown that a viral gene called M36 is necessary for CMV to reactivate and cause disease in mice, but it is not known whether the same mechanism can also protect the human CMV from immune-mediated killing. Here, we show that in mice lacking M36, a viral gene called TNFα is able to inhibit the cell death program, and that this function is required for the survival of CMV in macrophages. We also show that activated macrophages, the first cell target of CMV infection, are able to inhibit the growth of M36-deficient cells. Thus, our data show that in the immunocompromised host, CMV can avoid immune-mediated elimination by suppressing antiviral signaling pathways of the infected cell, thereby protecting it from immune-mediated killing.

During development, cells are often exposed to secreted signaling factors. In this study, we use the Drosophila wing epithelium to investigate the mechanism of Wnt1 secretion. We show that Wnt1 is secreted from a small region of cells at the dorsal-ventral boundary. However, the mechanism of Wnt1 secretion is poorly understood and key proteins involved in this process are still unknown. Here, we identify members of the exocyst complex to be required for apical Wnt1 secretion. Blocking apical Wnt1 secretion leads to reduced downstream signaling. Our results further indicate that apically secreted Wnt1 activates signaling in the target genes required for high signaling activity. Our results demonstrate that the exocyst is required for an apical route of Wnt1 secretion.

Parkinson disease is a complex neurodegenerative disorder with largely unknown genetic mechanisms. While the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in Parkinson disease ( PD ) mainly takes place in the substantia nigra pars compacta ( SN ) region, other brain areas, including the prefrontal cortex, develop Lewy bodies, the neuropathological hallmark of PD. We analyzed expression profiles from the prefrontal cortex to identify genes that might be involved in the development of PD. One of the genes with significantly increased expression in PD was the forkhead box O1 ( FOXO1 ) transcription factor. Notably, genes carrying the FoxO1 binding site were significantly enriched in the FDR–significant group of genes ( 177 genes covered by 189 probes ), suggesting a role for FoxO1 upstream of the observed expression changes. Further examination of the FOXO1 region in a meta-analysis of six available genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) showed two SNPs associated with age at onset of PD. These results implicate FOXO1 as a PD–relevant gene and warrant further functional analyses of its transcriptional regulatory mechanisms.

Onchocerciasis is a neglected tropical disease caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus. It can result in blindness, itching and skin lesions. Previous research has focused on blindness. A cutaneous onchocerciasis was used for the first time in an endemic region of northern Nigeria, within the context of an early ivermectin drug trial. We performed skin examinations in 6, 790 individuals aged 5+ years in endemic communities and 1, 343 individuals in nonendemic communities. There was increased risk for all forms of onchocercal skin disease in endemic communities with the most common finding being the presence of nodules ( 1, 438 individuals, 21. 2% ), followed by atrophy ( 367, 6. 1% of those < 50 years ), acute papular onchodermatitis, APOD ( 233, 3. 4% ), depigmentation ( 216, 3. 2% ) and chronic papular onchodermatitis, CPOD ( 155, 2. 3% ). APOD was more common in males whereas atrophy, hanging groin and nodules were more common in females. After controlling for age and sex, we found a significant association of onchocercal skin disease with itching with the most common finding being the presence of nodules.

A long-standing problem in neuroscience is how memories can be stored for very long times despite the volatile nature of the underlying neural substrate. One important class of memories are long-term memory of the stimulus, where the information is initially stored in the network of synapses between neurons. The information is then rapidly forgotten, so that it can be reused to a new task. To address this problem, here we develop a simple probabilistic model for the creation and removal of synapses. We show that information can be stored for several months when the network is in a state of its functional capacity. In such systems, the information can be stored despite the high turnover of synapses, which is a hallmark of biological neural function. The model also accounts for recent experimental data from mice supporting the assumption of multiple-synapse connections as the basis for long-term storage.

Severe malaria, caused by Plasmodium falciparum, can be due to either infection of the placenta, the falciparum mosquito, or other organ systems. Binding of P. falciparum infected red blood cells ( RBCs ) to gC1qR is a key event in the pathogenesis of severe malaria, and is associated with high levels of parasitemia and organ damage. Here, we analyzed the cytoadhesion of P. falciparum infected RBCs to gC1qR from Mozambican children with severe malaria and uncomplicated malaria, as well as a P. falciparum 3D7 ( Pf3D7 ) selected for binding to gC1qR. We show that Pf3D7gC1qR overexpressed DC8, a cytoadhesion molecule type, mediates binding to gC1qR through a conserved surface domain in DBLβ12. Our results also show that the parasite ligand used in this study, PFD0020c, can inhibit binding to gC1qR of Pf3D7gC1qR and four P. falciparum isolates by 50%. These findings are important for understanding the interaction between gC1qR and P. falciparum infected RBCs and for designing interventions against severe malaria caused by this specific binding.

A new control strategy, based on the release of Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes, has emerged as a novel approach to dengue fever control. This strategy uses a long-term social research process to enable participation and the design of an engagement strategy tailored to the sociopolitical setting of a potential dengue release site. The research findings show that different communities are likely to have divergent expectations, concerns and cultural sensibilities with regard to participation, engagement and authorization. This paper provides an example of how the results obtained from a long-term social research process can inform the development of new public health strategies to address existing issues and to develop new ones.

Lassa fever is an acute viral illness caused by Lassa virus ( LASV ), an Arenavirus which is maintained in nature and frequently transmitted to humans by Mastomys natalensis. The purpose of this study was to better define the geographic distribution of LASV-infected rodents in sub-Saharan Mali. Small mammals were live-trapped at various locations across Mali for the purpose of identifying potential zoonotic pathogens. Serological and molecular assays were employed and determined LASV infected rodents were exclusively found in the southern Mali near the border of Côte d'Ivoire. Overall, 19. 4% of Mastomys natalensis sampled in this region had evidence of LASV infection, with prevalence rates for individual villages ranging from 0 to 52%. Full-length genomic sequences were determined using high throughput sequencing methodologies for LASV isolates generated from tissue samples of rodents collected in four villages and confirmed the phylogenetic clustering of Malian LASV with strain AV. The risk of human infections with LASV is greatest in villages in southern Mali. Lassa fever should be considered in the differential diagnosis for febrile individuals and appropriate diagnostic techniques need to be established to determine the incidence of infection and disease in these regions.

In animals, gas exchange between blood and tissues occurs in narrow vessels, whose diameter is comparable to that of a red blood cell. Red blood cells must deform to squeeze through these narrow vessels, transiently blocking or occluding the vessels they pass through. Although the dynamics of vessel occlusion have been studied extensively, it remains an open question why microvessels need to be so narrow. We show that pressure feedbacks created when red blood cells enter the finest vessels of the trunk network act together to uniformly partition red blood cells through the microvasculature. Using mathematical models as well as direct observation, we show that these occlusive feedbacks are tuned throughout the trunk network to prevent the vessels closest to the heart from short-circuiting the network. Thus occlusion is linked with another open question of microvascular function: how are red blood cells delivered at the same rate to each micro-vessel? Our analysis shows that tuning of occlusive feedbacks increase the total dissipation within the network by a factor of 11, showing that uniformity of flows rather than minimization of transport costs may be prioritized by the microvascular network.

Magnaporthe oryzae, an invasive fungal pathogen that causes the most devastating damage to rice and other staple crops, is able to develop a complex life cycle in both a vegetative and an invasive filamentous state. The conidia, the spores that convert to an infectious yeast, are produced by a chitin synthase ( a family of enzymes that synthesize chitin ) gene. Plant pathogenic fungi have multiple chitin synthase genes and are able to synthesize chitin by different mechanisms. To determine the roles of chitin synthase genes in development and plant infection, we functionally characterized all seven chitin synthase genes in M. oryzae. Three of them, CHS1, CHS6, and CHS7, were important for plant infection. Our results indicate that each chitin synthase gene has distinct roles in hyphal growth, conidiation, appressorium development, and appressorium penetration in M. oryzae, and they may have overlapping functions in maintaining polarized growth in vegetative and invasive hyphae. Our results also provide potential new leads in the control of this devastating plant pathogen by targeting specific chitin synthases.

Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, remains a global threat and kills 3–5, 000 people each year. The bacterium is maintained in nature in a cycle involving rodent and flea hosts, where the bacterium replicates in the spleen and the lungs of the host. It then is transmitted to humans by fleas that bite humans. The bacterium is maintained in nature in a cycle involving rodent and flea hosts, and humans. It has been suggested that the bacterium can also be transmitted by airborne route. The bacterium can also be present in the environment, and in the environment, it can be present in very different forms. It is not known which bacterium is present in humans, but the one that infects humans, Y. pestis, is considered one of the most dangerous bacteria. It is thought that a small amount of the bacterium can be present in humans as a spore, which can then germinate and cause disease. Y. pestis is present in fleas, rodent and flea hosts, but it is unknown whether it can survive in humans. To test if it can survive in humans, we used a rodent nonhuman primate model of bubonic plague, a disease that kills 20, 000 people each year. We used a bactericidal drug, called valine, and a nonhuman primate route to treat infection. We found that this bactericidal drug was effective at killing the bacteria in both rodent and flea hosts, and that it was effective in curing infection in animals that had been infected with Y. pestis. We also found that the bactericidal drug could be used to treat other forms of plague, which have a similar bactericidal effect. Our data suggest that the bactericidal drug may be effective in treating human infections.

Parasitic worms are among the most common neglected tropical diseases, causing an enormous impact in global health and the socioeconomic growth of developing countries. Despite the fact that helminth infections are not well understood, there is an urgent need for a better understanding of the host-parasite interaction. In this context, the role that antibody responses have on helminth infections is still not well understood. Here, we report a new mechanism of immune evasion for the intestinal helminth E. caproni. In this model, antibodies are trapped in the parasite surface, resulting in the continuous entrapment of bound antibodies with newly secreted products. This mechanism of immune evasion may be used to understand the limited effect that antibody responses have in helminth infections, and may contribute to the basis for vaccine development against these highly prevalent diseases.

Staphylococcus aureus is an important cause of hospital-acquired infections. Clinical isolates of S. aureus express biofilms, which are structures composed of highly adherent cells attached to a surface. These biofilms are often associated with antibiotic resistance and virulence. Some methicillin-resistant S. aureus strains express biofilm phenotypes, which are thought to be linked to the ability of these bacteria to adapt to the host immune response. We have found that methicillin resistance in S. aureus alters its biofilm production. Methicillin-resistant S. aureus bacteria express a R602H substitution in the GdpP c-di-AMP phosphodiesterase that has important roles in resistance to β-lactam antibiotics. We have also found that the mecA protein is involved in biofilm formation and that it reduces virulence in a mouse model of device infection. These results suggest that methicillin resistance may have a key role in the adaptation of healthcare-associated methicillin-resistant S. aureus strains to the host immune response.

The human cohesinopathy diseases are thought to stem not from defects in chromosome segregation but rather from gene expression. We have used budding yeast strains bearing mutations analogous to the human cohesinopathy disease alleles to study gene expression. We show that many of the targets of the transcriptional activator Gcn4 are induced in the eco1-W216G mutant background. This observation suggests protein translation is reduced. We demonstrate that the cohesinopathy mutations eco1-W216G and smc1-Q843Δ are associated with defects in ribosome biogenesis and a reduction in the actively translating fraction of ribosomes, e. g., the 35S-methionine incorporation, which indicates a deficit in protein translation. The production of ribosomal RNA from an individual repeat is reduced while copy number remains unchanged. Our data suggest that cohesin proteins normally facilitate production of ribosomal RNA and protein translation, and this is one way they can influence gene expression. Reduced translational capacity could contribute to the human cohesinopathies.

Burkholderia pseudomallei is a Gram-negative bacterium responsible for melioidosis, a serious and often fatal infectious disease that is poorly controlled by existing treatments. Due to its inherent resistance to the major antibiotic classes and its facultative intracellular pathogenicity, an effective vaccine would be extremely desirable, along with appropriate prevention and therapeutic management. One of the main subunit vaccine candidates is flagellin of Burkholderia pseudomallei ( FliCBp ). Here, we present the high resolution crystal structure of FliCBp and report the synthesis and characterization of three peptides predicted to be both B and T cell FliCBp epitopes. All three epitopes were shown to be immunoreactive against human IgG antibodies and to elicit cytokine production from human peripheral blood mononuclear cells. Furthermore, two of the peptides were shown to be dominant immunoreactive epitopes, and their antibodies enhanced the bactericidal activities of purified human neutrophils. The epitopes derived from this study may represent potential melioidosis vaccine components.

Microtubules are ubiquitous structures that are found in most organisms, from single-celled bacteria to complex eukaryotes. They play important roles in cell division, and are therefore important drug targets. Most microtubules are composed of a string of 13 microtubule-associated proteins ( or protofilaments ), and the functions of these proteins are not well understood. We have identified two microtubulin-like protofilaments in the bacterial cell division protein FtsZ, which are structurally and functionally similar to the microtubules that are found in eukaryotes. FtsZ and its related microtubule homologs form filaments called tubulins in bacteria and are thought to be ancient tubulins. Our results suggest that bacteria have used a tubulin homolog to build a microtubule homolog, and that this microtubule homolog is structurally and functionally similar to its eukaryotic counterpart. This microtubule homolog can be produced in vitro without chaperones, and thus may be useful for tubulin research and drug screening.

Calcium is an important element in cell signaling, acting as a signal for synaptic transmission. Calcium flow is regulated by cytoplasmic and intracellular calcium sources. Calcium flow is primarily controlled by diffusing calcium ions through cytoplasmic channels and microtubules. In dendritic spines, calcium diffusion is restricted by the cytoplasmic crowding, which is mainly due to the presence of high ion gradients across the cytoplasmic membrane. To account for this effect, we developed a computational model that incorporates the molecular crowding as a factor in the diffusion process. We show that the diffusion constant is strongly regulated by the cytoplasmic concentration of calcium, and by the cytoplasmic spines and the synaptic inputs. We show that for moderate cytoplasmic concentration of calcium, the diffusion constant is mainly regulated by the cytoplasmic concentration, and not by the cytoplasmic ion gradients. Finally, we propose a reduced reaction-diffusion equation to model calcium dynamics in a dendrite under the presence of additional buffers, pumps and synaptic inputs.

Plasmacytoid dendritic cells ( pDC ) are essential innate immune system cells that are lost from the circulation in human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) -infected individuals associated with CD4+ T cell decline and disease progression. Although it has been suggested that pDC loss is caused by migration to tissues or cell death, few studies have addressed this directly. We used precise methods of enumeration and in vivo labeling with 5-bromo-2′-deoxyuridine to track recently divided pDC in blood and tissue compartments of monkeys with acute pathogenic simian immunodeficiency virus ( SIV ) infection. We show that pDC are lost from blood and peripheral lymph nodes within 14 days of infection, despite a normal frequency of pDC in bone marrow. Paradoxically, pDC loss masked a highly dynamic response characterized by rapid pDC mobilization into blood and a 10- to 20-fold increase in recruitment to lymph nodes relative to uninfected animals. Within lymph nodes, pDC had increased levels of apoptosis and necrosis, were uniformly activated, and were infected at frequencies similar to CD4+ T cells. Nevertheless, remaining pDC had essentially normal functional responses to stimulation through Toll-like receptor 7, with half of lymph node pDC producing both TNF-α and IFN-α. These findings reveal that rapid recruitment of pDC to inflamed lymph nodes in lentivirus infection has a pathologic consequence, bringing cells into close contact with virus, virus-infected cells, and pro-apoptotic factors leading to pDC death.

Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) is a herpesvirus associated with a variety of human malignancies, including B-cell lymphomas and epithelial cell carcinoma. EBNA3C is a multifunctional nuclear antigen that is implicated in the maintenance of the latent state and is responsible for B-cell immortalization. Here, we show that EBNA3C efficiently blocks the anti-proliferative activity of E2F1, a p53 target, and also its DNA-induced apoptosis through p53-independent mechanisms. Mechanistically, EBNA3C blocks E2F1 DNA-binding activity and its p53-independent transcriptional activity. Moreover, EBNA3C represses E2F1 transcriptional activity by directly interfering with its DNA-binding domain. Importantly, we show that EBNA3C can block the DNA-induced apoptosis through its p53-independent pathway, as well as its p53-independent pathway, which is important for the control of DNA damage induced E2F1-mediated apoptosis. Our findings provide novel insights into the biology of EBV and the mechanism of E2F1-mediated apoptosis induced by DNA damage.

Spondweni and Zika viruses are mosquito-transmitted viruses that cause febrile illness in humans and animals, respectively. ZIKV was first detected in the United States in 1947. Following the emergence of the Asian genotype in the Americas, ZIKV has been associated with human disease and has been linked to human sexual transmission. In this study, we show that male mice inoculated with ZIKV strains from the Asian genotype were susceptible to ZIKV infection. However, ZIKV strains collected from the African genotype were not detected in the same inoculated mouse. We also show that ZIKV infection in these mice is dependent on the presence of an intact immune response. Therefore, future studies should be undertaken to assess the role of viral genetic determinants and host tropism in dictating the differential sexual transmission potential of ZIKV and SPONV.

When outbreaks occur, transmission can occur via three different routes: needle sharing, sexual transmission, and small droplet aerosol. These routes are often spread via different routes simultaneously, and therefore transmission can occur via multiple transmission routes. Thus, controlling an epidemic often requires characterizing the risk associated with multiple transmission mechanisms. Here, we show that current methods to quantify risk of transmission for these three routes are either under- or over-estimate the risk of transmission. Our results suggest that current methods do not accurately estimate the risk of transmission for sexual or other transmission routes. We develop a novel mathematical approach that can accurately estimate the risk of transmission for sexual transmission and show that our method can provide a much stronger estimate than current approaches. This suggests that current risk assessments should be reconsidered as a function of transmission mechanisms.

In our current work, we show that the immune system can rapidly discriminate between antigenic molecules presented by antigen-presenting-cells and are able to discriminate between them based on the kinetics of the T cell receptor-antigen recognition system. However, the ability of the T cell receptor system to discriminate between antigenic molecules is not evident when the T cell receptor system is kept in an all-or-nothing mode. We show that this is because the T cell receptor system is allowed to rebind after a brief unbinding event. The recombination rate must be sufficiently slow for the overall system to react quickly. We also show that requiring recombination to be functional for the recognition of antigen is crucial for the ability of the T cell receptor system to discriminate between antigenic molecules.

Transcription factors are a family of proteins that bind to DNA and regulate the expression of other genes. These proteins can be modified by a variety of means, one of which is the addition of a polyalanine residue to the protein sequence. It is thought that this modification causes misfolding of the protein, leading to a loss of function. However, it is unclear whether this alteration is important for disease development in vivo. To investigate this issue, we generated mice with a mutation in the transcription factor SOX3 that is associated with X-linked Hypopituitarism. By investigating both cells and chimeric mice, we show that the mutation does not form aggregates in vivo but rather is present at dramatically reduced levels within the nucleus of mutant cells. Furthermore, the residual mutant protein is able to rescue a block in gastrulation but is not sufficient for normal development of the hypothalamus, a region that is functionally compromised in SOX3 null embryos and individuals with XH. Together, these data provide the first example of a disease-relevant PA mutant protein that is both nuclear and functional.

NK and γδ T cells are the most important effectors against virus infections in vivo. CD8+ αβ T cells are regarded as the main effectors in anti-tumor immunity. Polyomavirus ( PyV ) induces tumors in neonatally infected mice of susceptible strains and in adult mice with certain immune deficiencies, and CD8+ αβ T cells are regarded as the main effectors in anti-tumor immunity. Here we report that adult TCRβ knockout ( KO ) mice that lack αβ but have γδ T cells remain tumor-free after PyV infection, whereas TCRβ×δ KO mice that lack all T cells develop tumors. In addition, E26 mice, which lack NK and T cells, develop the tumors earlier than TCRβ×δ KO mice. Our observations implicate γδ T and NK cells in the resistance to PyV-induced tumors. Our findings demonstrate a protective role for NK and γδ T cells against naturally occurring virus-induced tumors and suggest the involvement of NKG2D-mediated mechanisms.

Infection by virus or virus-like particles can trigger the production of interferons ( IFN ), a family of anti-viral proteins that induce a wide spectrum of antiviral effects, including anti-viral interferon responses. Type I IFN and its relative interferon regulatory factor ( IRF-1 ) are the two main IFN induced families. While type I IFN is generally antiviral, IRF-1 has been shown to mediate antiviral action in a variety of cell types, including neurons. Although both antiviral functions of IRF-1 are mediated by overlapping IFN induced genes, the role of IRF-1 in the context of viral infection in vivo remains unknown. Here, we show that IRF-1 is essential to protect against fatal viral infection with vesicular stomatitis virus ( VSV ). IRF-1 is induced with delayed kinetics and controls viral replication in neurons and viral spread through the CNS, which leads to fatal inflammatory responses in the CNS. These data support a temporal, non-redundant antiviral function of type I IFN in the context of viral infection in vivo.

RNA granules are important structures for mRNA translation, storage, and degradation. Viral RNA granules have been shown to play a role in viral RNA silencing and to be essential for viral RNA replication. However, the role of RNA granules in plant viral infections is poorly understood. We have used Potato virus A ( PVA ) as a model potyvirus and demonstrate that the helper component-proteinase ( HCpro ), the potyviral suppressor of RNA silencing, induces the formation of RNA granules. We show that HCpro and varicose, components of potyviral RNA granules, stimulate VPg-promoted translation of the PVA, whereas UBP1 inhibits this process. Hence, we propose that PVA translation operates via a pathway that is interrelated with potyviral RNA granules in PVA infection. Our results also allow us to propose that the potyviral RNA granules are formed during infection, and the mechanism of viral RNA silencing is also established by potyviral RNA granules.

RHDV ( rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus ), a virus closely related to the agent of human rabies, is highly pathogenic in rabbits and, without vaccination, is lethal in all wild rabbits. The disease is caused by the synthesis of specific glycan antigens, which are recognized by the viral surface antigens. Synthesis of these glycan structures requires an α1, 2fucosyltransferase. In mammals, these genes evolved through two rounds of duplications. In most mammals, the two genes, called Sec1, Synaptotagmin II, and Synaptotagmin I, synthesize different glycan structures. In contrast, we found that rabbit Sec1 is highly conserved and that its protein is dominant in the small intestine. We also showed that rabbits are highly variable in the expression of these genes and that the high expression of a dominant-negative version of Sec1 is correlated with low binding of RHDV to the small intestine. This suggests that the protein is dominant in rabbits, where it inhibits the synthesis of a glycan structure that is recognized by RHDV. Together, these results show that Sec1 has gained a new function and that this function is dominant in rabbits. In addition, our results also show that the expression of the Sec1 protein is highly variable among rabbits and that this variation is correlated with the high expression of the dominant-negative version of the protein.

A major challenge in HIV-1 research is to understand the mechanisms by which the virus persists in the face of antiretroviral therapy. Low-level viral loads are often difficult to detect in patients undergoing therapy because of the fact that viremia is usually below the detection limit. One way that the virus can persist in the face of therapy is by periodically switching to a drug-resistant state. In this paper, we develop a mathematical model to describe the mechanisms by which latently infected cells can reemerge and persist in the face of therapy. We show that the low-level persistent viremia can be induced in a variety of ways, and that the virus can escape elimination by periodic drug administration. We also show that a small fraction of latently infected cells can revert to a drug-sensitive state and thus, provide a potential to replenish the latent reservoir. Finally, we develop a simple model that can reproduce the multifaceted responses observed in clinical studies and make them consistent with the latent reservoirs' persistence in the face of therapy. Our results suggest that the mechanisms of viral persistence and intermittent viral blips are not fully understood and can be explained by periodic drug administration.

Infection with hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) or human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) causes a chronic inflammatory response in the liver resulting in significant liver damage and cancer. HCV and HIV can stimulate macrophages, the primary target cells in the liver, and several studies have shown that macrophages can be infected and may be able to amplify and/or inhibit host inflammatory responses. Here we show that macrophages and Kupffer cells ( KCs ), which are macrophages that reside in the liver, are activated by HIV or HCV and that macrophages can upregulate expression of TREM1, a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily of receptors. TREM1 is a member of the TRAIL receptor family and it has been reported to play a role in chronic inflammation. Our data show that stimulation of KCs with HIV or HCV induces the upregulation of TREM1. Additionally, HIV viral proteins stimulate TREM1 expression through NFkB signaling. Finally, silencing TREM1 dampened inflammatory immune responses elicited by HIV or HCV stimulation. Finally, we show that HIV and HCV infected patients exhibit higher expression and frequency of TREM1 and CD68 positive cells. Thus, TREM1 induction by HIV contributes to chronic inflammation in the liver and targeting TREM1 signaling may be a therapeutic option to minimize HIV-induced chronic inflammation.

Cells have evolved sophisticated antiviral defense systems against viruses. One class of antiviral proteins, restriction factors, recognize viral capsids and interfere with infection. TRIM5α is a restriction factor that recognizes the capsids of retroviruses, such as HIV, and blocks retroviral infection. The TRIM5α SPRY domain is a highly conserved protein domain and is a good candidate for antiviral drug development. However, the mechanism by which the SPRY domain interacts with the viral capsid is not well understood. Here, we used a combination of biochemical and biophysical experiments to show that the SPRY domain is flexibly linked to the coiled-coil domain, and that the linker segment connecting the two domains adopts an α-helical fold. Targeted mutations were generated to disrupt the putative packing interface between the two domains, and we identified mutant proteins that were nevertheless deficient in capsid binding in vitro and restriction activity in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic insight into antiviral drug development, and demonstrate that substantial avidity gains during assembly-mediated capsid recognition by TRIM5α come in part from tailored spacing of tethered recognition domains.

Cigarette smoking is known to adversely affect lung function, but the full extent of the impact of smoking on lung function is not known. Here, we examined genetic variants that are known to influence lung function, and we assessed their joint effects on FEV1 and FEV1/FVC in 19 studies. We identified three novel loci that are not previously associated with pulmonary function: SNPs in D Maver and HLA-DQA2, and KCNJ2 and SOX9. We also found evidence of differential expression in human lung tissue from smokers compared to non-smokers that are novel loci. The HLA region has been widely implicated for autoimmune and lung phenotypes, but its role in complex traits that are missed when only considering the genetic main effects, has not been implicated in lung phenotypes.
