Our findings demonstrate that joint testing of SNP and SNP-by-environment interaction identified novel loci associated with complex traits that are missed when considering only the genetic main effects.

The functions of the urinary bladder are supported by a complex network of ion channels, pumps, and exchangers. The precise function of these channels is unknown, but they are thought to be involved in the regulation of urinary function. We have developed a biophysically detailed computational model of the small DRG neuron soma of the urinary bladder, which is the functional unit of the urinary tract. We have validated our model against a large number of recent physiological data and have been able to reproduce the effect of Ca2+-activated K+ ( Ca2+ ) ion channels on these neurons. We have further used our model to investigate the role of Ca2+-activated K+ ( SKCa ) ion channels in these neurons. We found that SKCa inward rectification is an important parameter regulating the repetitive firing and that its absence reduces action potential ( AP ) firing frequency. Moreover, we show that SKCa is more potent at reducing AP spiking than the large-conductance Ca2+-activated K+ ( BKCa ) channel. Moreover, we have identified a slow Ca2+-activated K+ channel ( slow KA ) current which is composed of an initial fast inactivating ( time constant ∼ 25-100 ms ) and a slow inactivation ( time constant ∼ 200-800 ms ) current. We discuss the implications of our findings, and how our detailed model can help further our understanding of the role of C-fibre afferents in the physiology of urinary bladder.

CD8+ T cells are the most potent antigen-specific cells of the immune system. CD8+ T cell responses to viruses are mediated by antigen-presenting cells that recognize structures on the surface of pathogens. Vaccinia virus ( VACV ), the smallpox vaccine, induces robust CD8+ T cell responses, which recognize the VACV envelope glycoproteins. In some individuals, this type of immunity is enhanced after the intravenous route of immunization, but the mechanism is not understood. Here, we examined a panel of 15 VACV epitopes and four routes to investigate how the virus induces CD8+ T cell responses. We found that the immunodominant response occurs more readily when priming is in lymph nodes. We also demonstrated that immunodominance is increased by VACV-based vaccines expressing costimulatory molecules. Our results shed light on immunodominance and provide a basis for future studies investigating CD8+ T cell immunity to viruses.

The septum is the structure that divides a cell into two daughter cells. During septum formation, cells regulate the activity of genes controlling cell division and cell polarity. Eukaryotic cells contain three different signaling pathways that are coordinately regulated during septum formation. In fungi, these pathways are represented by two major groups of regulators: the septation initiation ( SIN ) and the morphogenesis ( MOR ). In mammals, these two pathways are connected by a signaling node that is regulated by the germinal centre kinase ( GC ). Here, we identify a third GC kinase, MST-1, which is involved in the cross-regulation between these two pathways. Genetic and biochemical data show that MST-1 is involved in the control of the SIN pathway, which is known to be important for the regulation of cell division and polarity. In addition, the data show that MST-1 is involved in the regulation of the MOR pathway, which is known to be important for the control of the septum. In addition, we show that MST-1 is required for the proper formation of the actomyosin rings that are required for proper constriction of the septum. Finally, we show that MST-1 is also involved in the regulation of the MOR pathway. These results suggest that the two pathways are coordinately regulated by diverse signaling molecules, which may be relevant to the cross-regulation between the two pathways in eukaryotes.

The choice of antimicrobial drug to treat an infection is often guided by the activity of the drug against the pathogen. However, pharmacokinetics and the pharmacodynamics of the antimicrobial agents have been traditionally studied as separate entities. A novel approach to quantify the pharmacodynamic effects of antimicrobial agents is proposed to fill this unmet need. In this work, we propose a computational method to describe the interaction of a typical antimicrobial agent and a pathogen. Our results show that a wide range of antimicrobial agents can be assessed by a more flexible computational tool to support dosing selection.

In order to form organs of the right size and shape, a concentration gradient of secreted molecules called morphogens must be generated and maintained. In this work, we investigate the dynamics of the first step of morphogen gradient formation in the developing fruit fly embryo. We used the fluorescent Bicoid morphogen gradient that elicits a rapid step-like transcriptional response in young fruit fly embryos. By removing 36 putative Zelda binding sites unexpectedly present in the original reporter, we show that the 750 bp of the Bicoid promoter are sufficient to recapitulate endogenous expression at the onset of zygotic transcription. While the time period required to reach the plateau is proportional to the distance to the anterior pole, we show that it only takes 3 minutes at each interphase for the MS2 reporter loci to distinguish subtle differences in Bicoid concentration and establish a steep ( Hill coefficient ~ 7 ) expression boundary. Our results suggest that a simple model based only on the cooperative binding of Bicoid is not sufficient to describe the spatiotemporal dynamics of early hb expression.

Speciation results from the progressive accumulation of mutations that decrease the probability of mating between parental populations or reduce the fitness of hybrids—the so-called species barriers. The so-called "species genomic literature" is a collection of case studies, each with its own approach and specificities, which has been largely overlooked in the past. Here, we explore the continuum of speciation by combining genomic data from 61 pairs of populations/species of animals with variable levels of divergence. We show that the intermediate "grey zone" of speciation, in which taxonomy is often controversial, spans from 0. 5% to 2% of net synonymous divergence, irrespective of species life history traits or ecology. Our analysis also uncovers a number of cryptic species and highlights the intrinsic difficulty, both statistical and conceptual, in delineating species in the grey zone of speciation.

How do animals determine when they perceive the most important auditory event in a sensory scene? One of the most difficult questions in neuroscience is to answer this question when we can hear a bird in our midst. The answer depends on how our brain can distinguish between many competing sounds. Here, we address this question in the nucleus of the nidopallium ( Nif ), which is known as the organ of Corti. The Nif is a crucial organ for birdsong production, and the organ also provides the main input to the motor output system that drives our vocal production. We show that the Nif output is delayed relative to the response in the auditory cortex. This delay is correlated with the time delay between successive syllables: syllables that are spoken by a single syllable before one syllable can be understood are preceded by a similar delay. Our results suggest that the Nif output is delayed relative to the response in the auditory cortex, and this delay is correlated with its sensory consequences.

Infection with Cryptosporidium is a major cause of childhood diarrhea in developing countries. In Cambodia, the prevalence of Cryptosporidium infection is as high as 40% in some regions. One of the most common species of Cryptosporidium is Cryptosporidium hominis, which is transmitted from infected animals to humans through contact with animals or water. In this study, we examined the distribution of Cryptosporidium species and subtypes in children from a rural area of northwest Cambodia, where the majority of children spend their time in the home. We detected Cryptosporidium oocysts and Giardia duodenalis in 2. 2% ( 11/498 ) and 18. 9% ( 94/498 ), respectively, and in 8 ( 21. 1% ) and 5 ( 13. 2% ), respectively. We also detected Cryptosporidium hominis and C. parvum in 13 ( 34. 2% ) samples, followed by C. melearded and C. parvum in 9 ( 23. 7% ), Cryptosporidium canis and C. suis in 5 ( 13. 2% ) and 8 ( 138/498 ), respectively. The use of soap was protective against Giardia infection. These results show that there are at least two Cryptosporidium species and subtypes in Cambadian children and that both Cryptosporidium hominis and C. parvum are associated with the presence of birds. We propose that interventions to improve sanitation, increase hand washing after defecation and before preparing food and promote drinking boiled water may reduce the burden of these two parasites.

In animals and yeast, position effects have been well documented. In animals, the best example is Position Effect Variegation ( PEV ) in Drosophila melanogaster. PEV is a striking example of how the activity of a gene is affected by the presence of an element in its cis-regulatory region. PEV is caused by the insertion of a transgene into heterochromatic sequences. A similar phenomenon is observed in fission yeast. We have identified an exceptional position at which the PEV element is associated with silencing of its own transcriptional element. However, after it is segregated away, element activity is restored. This restoration is accompanied by a reversal of DNA methylation. To our knowledge, this is the first documented example of a position effect that is associated with the reversal of epigenetic silencing. This observation suggests that there are cis-acting sequences that alter the propensity of an epigenetically silenced gene to remain inactive. This raises the interesting possibility that an important feature of local chromatin environments may be the capacity to erase previously established epigenetic marks.

During the cell cycle, the cohesin complex, which is responsible for holding sister chromatids together until they attach to the spindle, is replicated and then segregated to the two daughter cells. In many cancers, the cohesin complex is found in regions called heterochromatin that are normally thought to be “junk. ” In this study, we show that this “junk”, or heterochromatin, is enriched at chromosomal regions that are not near the centromere. The presence of heterochromatin at these sites, and the resulting chromatin stretching, is required for the proper segregation of chromosomes. We also show that, as a result of its enrichment, chromosomes containing ectopic heterochromatin have an increased rate of chromatin stretching during anaphase. These results provide a mechanistic understanding of how heterochromatin contributes to the fidelity of chromosome segregation.

Retroviruses have evolved multiple strategies to subvert cellular restriction factors, which act to prevent infection by their own production. One of these mechanisms is the binding of viral proteins to cellular receptors, which activate the accessory protein Vpu to counteract the restriction factor BST2. Here, we show that Rab7A, a factor that mediates trafficking of cellular proteins into the endocytic pathway, is required for efficient HIV-1 replication. We also show that Rab7A modulates the late steps of the HIV-1 replication cycle, including the processing of Env glycoproteins into infectious particles, and the HIV-1 infectivity. Our results suggest that Rab7A contributes to the mechanism by which Vpu counteracts the restriction factor BST2/Tetherin and rescues HIV-1 release.

One of the primary findings of Mendelian randomization is that a single genotype can be responsible for a large range of phenotypic differences. We used this observation to search for genetic variants that affect body mass index, a phenotype thought to be affected by body mass index. We identified variants with a strong effect on body mass index and many of these effects were confirmed in subsequent large-scale studies of UK Biobank participants. Some of these variants were also found in other studies, and our findings have implications for our understanding of how genetic variation affects complex traits such as body mass index. We also found novel effects, some of which were confirmed in other studies, suggesting that body mass index may be a modifiable risk factor for outcomes where there is no prior reason to suggest that a causal effect exists.

African trypanosomes cause “sleeping sickness” in humans and “wasting disease” in domestic animals. There are three major quantitative trait loci ( QTL ) in humans that have been identified in two independent crosses between susceptible A/J and BALB/c mice, Tir1 and Tir3, and the resistance QTL ( RQTL ), which has been identified in a third cross. In this paper, we present a strategy to generate a short list of polymorphisms in candidate QTL genes that can be functionally tested. We have chosen to study T. congolense infection response in mice because these are genetically tractable and amenable to genetic mapping. We have identified a novel candidate QTL gene in T. congolense infection response, PML-RAR alpha-regulated adaptor molecule 1 ( PML-RAR alpha-regulated adaptor molecule 1 ). We have developed a strategy to generate a short list of polymorphisms in candidate QTL genes that can be functionally tested.

Prion diseases are transmissible neurodegenerative disorders caused by unorthodox infectious agents. According to the prion hypothesis, the infectious agent in transmissible spongiform encephalopathies ( TSEs ) is an unorthodox protein conformation based agent. However, whether the pathogenic properties of synthetically generated prion ( rec-Prion ) recapitulate those of naturally occurring prions remains unresolved. Using end-point titration assay, we showed that rec-Prions have infectious titers of around 104 LD50 / μg. In addition, inoculation of wild-type mice with rec-Prion caused prion disease with an average survival time of 210 – 220 days post inoculation. Detailed pathological analyses revealed that the nature of rec-Prion induced lesions, including spongiform change, disease specific prion protein accumulation ( PrP-d ) and the PrP-d dissemination amongst lymphoid and peripheral nervous system tissues, the route and mechanisms of neuroinvasion were all typical of classical rodent prions. Our results revealed that, similar to naturally occurring prions, rec-Prion has a titratable infectivity and is capable of causing prion disease via routes other than direct intra-cerebral challenge. More importantly, our results established that rec-Prion caused disease is pathogenically and pathologically identical to naturally occurring contagious TSEs, supporting the concept that a conformationally altered protein agent is responsible for the infectivity in TSEs.

The rat’s ability to explore the environment is crucial for survival, and it is a particular challenge when examining the interactions between the rat’s body and its environment. To examine how rats determine the orientation and position of surfaces relative to their head, we constructed a computational model of the rat’s whisker array. We used this model to determine which of the vibrissae, the smallest, most common, and most conspicuous whiskers in the array, could be involved in determining the angle at which each vibrissa first touches the surface, and we found that this angle varied across the array, depending on the whisker’s position relative to its head orientation. The results demonstrate that vibrissae are not interchangeable sensors, but rather functionally grouped to acquire particular types of information about the environment.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis and the human thread-like filarial nematode are highly prevalent in the world. Both infections are considered to be responsible for the burden of tuberculosis, which is a major public health concern. There are currently no vaccines available for either infection and it is not known why both infections share the same host response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Our work shows that both infections share the same immune response to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigen, TLR1. We also show that TLRs are significantly diminished in filarial infection and that this is due to the parasite infecting the host being able to suppress the host response. We finally show that treating individuals with filarial infection and antifilarial chemotherapy can restore the TLR responses to Mycobacterium tuberculosis in the individuals. Our study provides new insight into the biology of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and the immune response to infection.

Insects must undergo a complex developmental transition during the larval stage, which is critical for survival and reproduction. The timing of this transition is under the control of two hormonal pathways, juvenile hormone ( JH ) and ecdysteroids. In mammals, the JH pathway is regulated by the POU domain protein, Ventral veins lacking ( Vvl ) /Dränder. In this study, we examined the function of Vvl in the red flour beetle, Tribolium castaneum ( Tenebrionidae ). Knockdown of vvl expression delayed the onset of metamorphosis and inhibition of larval growth, indicating that Vvl acts upstream of JH signaling. Accordingly, ecdysone titer and the expression of ecdysone response gene were reduced in vvl knockdown larvae. The expression of the ecdysone biosynthesis gene phantom ( phm ) and spook ( spo ) were reduced in vvl knockdown larvae in the anterior and posterior halves, respectively. Injection of 20-hydroxyecdysone ( 20E ) into vvl knockdown larvae could restore the expression of HR3, the ecdysone response gene. Our findings suggest that Vvl coordinates both JH and ecdysteroids as well as molting behavior to influence molting and the timing of metamorphosis. Thus, in both vertebrates and insects, POU factors modulate the production of major neuroendocrine regulators during sexual maturation.

Leprosy is a chronic disease affecting the peripheral nerves and is characterized by an irreversible impairment of nerve function. Despite its prevalence, there is still a paucity of information on the biological interactions between host and pathogen. We examined the metabolome of leprosy patients before and immediately after the conclusion of multidrug therapy ( MDT ) to identify biomarkers of disease progression. We found that the metabolome showed distinct alterations between the two groups, with key metabolic changes contributing to the alterations in disease progression. Our results suggest that polyunsaturated fatty acids ( PUFAs ), derived from the metabolic activity of the enzymes that synthesize them, contribute to the metabolic alterations that occur during leprosy disease. In particular, we show that PUFAs are metabolites of the type 3 PUFA pathway, which has recently been shown to be a key determinant of host disease. Our findings provide new insights into the metabolic interactions that occur during leprosy disease, which may be useful in the development of new therapeutic strategies to improve the quality of life of leprosy patients.

Systemic lupus erythematosus ( SLE ) is a chronic autoimmune disease affecting approximately 1% of the population. SLE is characterized by immune system–mediated destruction of the body's tissues, often resulting in organ damage. SLE and other autoimmune diseases ( ADs ) are complex genetic traits and are influenced by a number of genes. Previous studies have identified a number of shared genes involved in the development of SLE and ADs. However, the shared genetic variants have not been fully explored, particularly in cases such as SLE. In this study, we have found genetic variants that are shared between SLE and other autoimmune diseases, and have identified new shared genetic variants. We also found evidence that some of these variants are also associated with other autoimmune diseases. Our study provides important new information on the genetic basis of SLE.

Herpes simplex virus type 1 ( HSV-1 ) infects over half the human population. Infection can occur in any cell type and can lead to a wide spectrum of diseases, ranging from mild cold sores to potentially deadly cancers. HSV-1 replicates in the nucleus of cells, and much of the infectious cycle occurs there, where the virus has evolved mechanisms to alter host processes for the production of virus. HSV-1 is also capable of replicating in a cell-free form and can be transmitted via viral vector or viral gene transfer. In this study, we identify proteins that associate with the replication forks of HSV-1, and find that several of these proteins are recruited to the replication forks. We also show that the initiation of viral DNA replication is sufficient to allow late gene expression. Our data provide insight into the mechanisms that couple HSV-1 DNA replication with transcription and repair for the coordinated expression and maintenance of the viral genome.

A/E pathogenic bacteria are responsible for a wide range of human diseases. However, the pathogenic mechanisms and crucial host-pathogen interactions during A/E pathogen infections remain elusive. We performed a functional screening by infecting IL-22-/- mice with a library of CR strains. Our screen reveals that the epihein A/E-type protein EspF is crucial for the high mortality rates in CR-infected IL22-/- mice. Chromosomal deletion of espF in CR recapitulates the avirulent phenotype without compromising colonization and proliferation of CR, and the expression levels of the espF gene are elevated during CR infection. Moreover, we found that CR-induced disruption of the tight junction ( TJ ) strands in colonic epithelium is mediated by EspF. Distinct from EspF, chromosomal deletion of other TJ-damaging effector genes map failed to inhibit CR virulence in IL22-/- mice. Our findings reveal a critical pathophysiological function for EspF during CR infection in the immunocompromised host and provide new insights into the complex pathogenic mechanisms of A/E pathogens.

Evolutionary theory suggests that the functional organization of gene regulatory sequences is important for biological functions. While sequence variation can be sufficient to explain evolutionary change, the relationship between functional evolution and organismal evolution is often overlooked. One of the major challenges in evolutionary biology is to relate sequence evolution to function. We are studying this problem by studying the organization of gene regulatory sequences that have evolved in parallel across many species. Here, we use the Drosophila melanogaster model system to investigate the relationship between sequence evolution and the organization of gene regulatory sequences. We show that the individual regulatory sequences of the three divergent species have independently evolved adaptations to compensate for lineage-specific developmental and/or genomic changes. Furthermore, we show that the organization of these regulatory sequences has been finely tuned by distinct, lineage-specific selection pressures in each of the three divergent species. Thus, our study demonstrates that evolutionary change can act on regulatory sequences to fine-tune morphogen gradient threshold readouts. Our results suggest that a well-established method of functional analysis can be used to identify lineage-specific adaptations in other systems.

Phosphorus is a major growth factor for all living organisms. Phosphorus is also a major yield constraint for agricultural crops, such as soybeans, and it is thus important to understand the genetic bases of plant growth and yield. Phosphorus efficiency is a complex quantitative trait that is determined by multiple genes, and the mechanisms underlying P efficiency are largely unknown. In this study, we used linkage analysis and candidate gene association analysis to identify a soybean gene related to P efficiency. We then used a combination of functional markers and genetic mapping approaches to identify the haplotypes of the identified marker region and the candidate gene GmACP1. We found that the haplotype of GmACP1 was favorable and its haplotype was strongly associated with soybean growth and yield. The discovery of the optimal haplotype of GmACP1 will now enable the precise selection of soybeans with higher P efficiencies.

Iron is an essential nutrient for all living organisms. An important process of iron metabolism is the release of iron from the macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system. Macrophages recognize and phagocytose damaged or senescent erythrocytes. Then, they process the heme iron, which is returned to the circulation for reutilization by red blood cell precursors during erythropoiesis. Iron release from macrophages depends on the level of iron present in the cell as a positive feedback mechanism. A currently accepted model of iron release assumes a passive-gradient with free diffusion of iron ( Fe2+ ) through ferroportin ( FPN ), the transporter on the plasma membrane. Outside the cell, a multi-copper ferroxidase, ceruloplasmin ( Cp ) oxidizes ferrous to ferric ion. According to the passive-gradient model, the removal of ferrous ion from the site of release sustains the gradient that maintains the iron release. Subcellular localization of FPN may be more complex. We have investigated the detailed mechanism of iron release from macrophages focusing on the roles of the Cp, FPN and apo-Tf. The facilitated-transport model is quantitatively analyzed using a mathematical model for the first time. A comparison of experimental data with model simulations shows that the passive-gradient model cannot explain macrophage iron release. However, a facilitated-transport model associated with FPN can explain the iron release mechanism. According to the facilitated-transport model, intracellular FPN carries labile iron to the macrophage membrane. Extracellular Cp accelerates the oxidation of ferrous ion bound to FPN. Facilitated-transport model can correctly predict cellular iron efflux and is essential for physiologically relevant whole-body iron metabolism.

Chromatin is a dynamic structure that can be altered through multiple mechanisms including chromatin remodeling, gene expression, and DNA repair. Here, we describe a new role for the proteasome in DNA repair. The proteasome is a complex of proteasome subunits that are essential for many cellular functions. Proteasome subunits are required for the repair of double strand breaks, a type of DNA damage that can lead to genome instability. We show that the proteasome is required for DNA repair and that its activity is essential for the repair of double strand breaks. We show that the DNA repair protein Mms22 is recruited to chromatin and its subsequent degradation is necessary and sufficient for cell cycle progression through the G2/M arrest induced by DNA damage. Our results demonstrate that a double strand break repair protein is a proteasome target, and thus link nuclear proteasomal activity and chromatin remodeling.

Bacteria frequently evolve under antibiotic stress, allowing them to acquire new traits from other bacterial species and other sources of gene flow. In bacteria, the exchange of genes ( homologous recombination ) has long been considered to play a central role in the adaptation of bacteria to environmental stress. We used a simulation model to investigate the contribution of homologous recombination to bacterial evolution and to determine conditions under which it will provide a bacterial population a selective advantage over non-recombining populations. We find that bacterial populations that have recombined, or have recombined more slowly, will have higher rates of adaptive evolution than populations that have not. We also find that the extent of adaptation that bacteria are able to achieve is dependent on the rate of recombination. Our results indicate that, under realistic conditions, homologous gene recombination will be the key mechanism that promotes the rate of adaptation in bacterial populations. Also, our results suggest that, in addition to its role in gene flow, homologous recombination will not be the dominant selective pressure responsible for the evolution of transformation.

Transcranial magnetic stimulation ( TMS ) is a neurotreatment method in which a magnetic field is applied to a subject's brain. It is currently used to treat motor symptoms and has been shown to have efficacy in several other brain areas. The mechanism of action of TMS, however, remains unclear. In this paper, we develop a novel combination of biophysical modeling and compartmental modeling to investigate the biophysical mechanism of TMS of the central nervous system ( CNS ). We show that TMS induces an electric field that is localized in the periphery of the central nervous system ( CNS ). The induced field is inversely proportional to the diameter of the stimulated compartment. Our results suggest that, unlike other TMS protocols, TMS does not directly trigger dendritic regenerative mechanisms. Our results also suggest that, unlike other TMS protocols, TMS does not directly trigger dendritic regenerative mechanisms. These insights into the mechanism of TMS may be relevant for the design of multi-intensity TMS protocols, may facilitate the interpretation of results from TMS of the CNS, and may aid the interpretation of results of TMS of the CNS.

Rhizobia is a group of bacteria that are symbionts of leguminous plants. These bacteria have evolved an intimate relationship with the host plant and are thought to fix nitrogen to the plant. Under this condition, the symbiosis can be either beneficial or parasitic. We have investigated the evolution of the symbiosis in S. meliloti and S. medicae. We sequenced the genomes of both species and determined that their genomes are 1. 5–2. 5 times more similar than those of a common ancestor. We also show that the symbiosis is confined almost exclusively to plasmid genes. Interestingly, the level of diversity on the plasmids is much higher in S. meliloti than in S. medicae, suggesting that the symbiosis is maintained by natural selection. Based on the ratio of plasmid to chromosome diversity, we conclude that the plasmid is more important in determining the symbiosis than the chromosome. Frequency-spectrum based tests identified 82 genes with a signature of adaptive evolution in one species or another but none of the genes were identified in both species. Several genes identified as targets of selection are likely to alter the symbiosis with the host plant.

Theileria annulata is the only eukaryotic protozoan parasite that transforms another eukaryotic cell. This transformation is essential to the invasive and motile properties of the parasite. This transformation is mediated by the parasite secreted protein TNFα, which promotes host cell membrane rearrangements and cell motility. Here, we dissect the mechanisms by which TNFα promotes cell motility and invasiveness of parasitized host cells. We show that TNFα promotes the formation of polar, F-actin-rich invasion structures by targeting expression and function of the host ser/thr kinase MAP4K4. MAP4K4 is activated by TNFα and MAP4K4 expression is also induced by TNFα signaling and MAP4K4 expression in infected cells. We show that TNFα-induced MAP4K4 activity is essential for the formation of polar F-actin-rich structures and cell motility in 3D. MAP4K4 expression is induced by TNFα signaling and MAP4K4 expression is also induced by MAP4K4 signaling. MAP4K4 is inhibited by the host anti-inflammatory signaling MAP4K4E and MAP4K4R and the effects are parasite dependent. Thus, MAP4K4 promotes invasive motility of infected cells through the activation of MAP4K4, an evolutionary conserved kinase that couples inflammatory signalling to cytoskeletal dynamics and cell motility.

Schizophrenia is a complex neurobehavioral disorder, with many genes involved in the disease biology. Recent advances in genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have identified more than 100, 000 disease-associated variants across the genome, with each variant lying in a genetic context. However, very few of these variants are known to be causative for the disease, leaving the majority of the genetic contribution to the disorder unexplained. One of the major challenges in schizophrenia research is to integrate genetic information, genomic annotations, and epigenetic information ( epigenetics ) information, to find the causative genetic variants. Here, we present a novel method that allows us to infer causal genetic variants by combining information from multiple sources. Our method is particularly important when integrating genomic annotations and epigenetics information, as our method incorporates both information from multiple sources to more accurately estimate replication probabilities for the same genetic variant. We demonstrate the power of this method on a recent GWAS cohort of 82, 315 individuals, and we show that our method can be used to identify the causal variants in GWAS.

Rice, a staple cereal worldwide, is also a major source of energy, and is responsible for half the world's population estimated to be at risk of disease. Plants have evolved an immune response to protect themselves from pathogen infection. This immune response is initiated by the detection of pathogen molecules at the site of infection. Plants also respond to secondary, and often occurring, pathogen attacks. In this study, we identified a gene called Snl6 that is required for the detection of the secondary pathogen, Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae, in rice. We also show that Snl6 is required for full pathogenesis. In contrast to previous studies, we found that Snl6 does not affect the growth of plants, suggesting that the gene may have other important roles in immunity.

The human genome has a remarkable ability to respond to environmental challenges, including diet, drugs, and genetic variation. While numerous genetic variants that influence human metabolism have been identified, few are known to influence human metabolism in a specific organ, such as the blood. Here, we have taken advantage of recent technical and methodological advances to examine the genetics of human metabolism. We have examined over 4, 000 people from three different ethnic groups, and have identified a number of genetic variants that affect blood metabolism. We then replicated the same variants in large numbers of people of different ethnic backgrounds to identify which genetic variants are specific to blood. Our results suggest that these genetic variants affect specific biological processes that regulate blood homeostasis. We also show that some of these variants are associated with chronic disease, such as hypertension or ischemic stroke, but that other disease risk variants have not previously been associated with these biological processes. Our study is the largest to date to examine the genetic influence on human metabolism. We believe that this large number of variants will provide novel insight into the etiology of disease.

Chemical genetics has been used to study the action of small molecules that alter biological processes. By screening large libraries of small molecules, researchers have identified conserved cellular pathways targeted by a diverse group of chemical probes. These compounds can now be used to investigate the mechanism of action of a small molecule in vivo. Here, we show that imidazole[1, 2-a]pyridines and imidazole[1, 2-a]pyrimidines have distinct mechanisms of action in yeast cells. We have also discovered that imidazole[1, 2-a]pyridine is toxic to yeast cells that are defective in mitochondrial functions and nuclear DNA repair. We have also found that imidazole[1, 2-a]pyrimidine has a DNA-damaging effect in human cells, suggesting that this chemical–genetic profile is recapitulated in cultured cells. These results support the idea that chemical–genetic profiles obtained in yeast can be used to understand the action of small molecules and that they are largely conserved in mammalian cells.

Domestication has led to similar changes in morphology and behavior in several animal species, raising the question whether similarities between domestication and wild animal evolution also exist at the molecular level. We analyzed genome-wide gene expression levels in the brain of three pairs of domesticated and wild animals. We compared the expression differences with those between domesticated guinea pigs and a distant wild relative as well as between two lines of rats selected for tameness or aggression towards humans. We found that, although there were fewer gene expression differences between domesticated and wild animals, the genes with the most significant changes in expression between the different domestication events differed only for a small number of genes. There was almost no overlap between gene expression in domesticated and the tame and aggressive rats. However, two of the genes with the strongest expression changes between the rats ( DLL3 and DHDH ) were located in a genomic region associated with tameness and aggression. In summary, the majority of brain gene expression changes in domesticated animals are specific to the given domestication event, suggesting that the causative variants of behavioral domestication traits may also be different.

Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium that alternates between two metabolically different developmental forms. We performed fluorescence lifetime imaging ( FLIM ) of the metabolic coenzymes, reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotides [NAD ( P ) H ) ], by two-photon microscopy for separate analysis of host and pathogen metabolism during intracellular chlamydial infections. NAD ( P ) H autofluorescence was detected inside the chlamydial inclusion and showed enhanced signal intensity on the inclusion membrane as demonstrated by the co-localization with the 14-3-3β host cell protein. An increase of the fluorescence lifetime of protein-bound NAD ( P ) H [τ2-NAD ( P ) H] inside the chlamydial inclusion strongly correlated with enhanced metabolic activity of chlamydial reticulate bodies during the mid-phase of infection. Inhibition of host cell metabolism that resulted in aberrant intracellular chlamydial inclusion morphology completely abrogated the τ2-NAD ( P ) H increase inside the chlamydial inclusion. Furthermore, a significant increase in τ2-NAD ( P ) H and a decrease in the relative amount of free NAD ( P ) H inside the host cell nucleus indicated cellular starvation during intracellular chlamydial infection. Our findings suggest that intracellular chlamydial metabolism is directly linked to cellular NAD ( P ) H signaling pathways that are involved in host cell survival and longevity.

The social network of a population has a major influence on the spreading process of an epidemic. Methods to collect social network information to predict the spread of an epidemic are numerous, but their analysis presents several challenges. First, their data are often collected using different methodologies and are often analysed using different techniques. Second, their analysis requires numerical simulations to describe the epidemic dynamics. Here, we show how these different data sets can be used to yield accurate predictions of the epidemic risk. We investigate how the social network of a population can be described when only the contact data is considered, and show that it can be used to obtain an approximation of the epidemic risk that is comparable to that obtained by using the social network data.

Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ), a disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani, is a significant cause of mortality in many regions of the world. In recent years, there has been a surge in the discovery of compounds that inhibit the function of the parasite enzyme that synthesizes the amino acid trypanothione, or as potential anti-leishmanial drugs. The present study identifies the first nitro-compound drug candidate that is capable of activating the trypanocidal compound NADPH oxidase ( NTR2 ), and provides evidence that this drug is able to activate both the active compound ( nifurtimox ) and the drug-resistant form ( fexinidazole sulfone ). Our findings provide novel insight into the mode of action of NTR2, and open up the possibility of developing new drugs that can be activated independently of trypanocidal effect, and can be used as anti-leishmanial compounds.

Xeroderma pigmentosum ( XP ) is a genetically heterogeneous disease that is caused by defects in the repair of DNA damage. Patients suffering from XP exhibit exquisite sun sensitivity, high incidence of skin cancer, and in some cases neurodegeneration. XP is caused by mutations in the XPF-ERCC1 protein. This protein is essential for DNA repair and therefore mutations in XPF can result in a variety of human diseases. We have previously shown that a progeria-causing mutation ( XPFR153P ) in XPF can result in a similar phenotype in vitro and in vivo, and that this mutation results in mislocalization of XPF-ERCC1 in cells. Here we show that mislocalization of XPF-ERCC1 in cells from an XFE progeroid patient can partially reverse the phenotype of the mutation, suggesting that this mislocalization may be a factor that underlies the diverse symptoms associated with mutations in XPF. We also show that mislocalization of XPF-ERCC1 can be reconstituted in cells lacking XPF by injection of the mutant protein. This study provides new insight into the molecular basis of mislocalization of XPF-ERCC1 and the potential impact of mislocalization of XPF-ERCC1 on DNA repair.

Ciliopathies are a group of rare genetic diseases that are characterized by abnormality in the development of the head, trunk, and colon. The most common gene mutated in ciliopathies is Zfp423, which encodes a transcription factor that is predicted to bind to DNA and influence the expression of numerous genes. To better understand the mechanism of Zfp423 action, we generated a series of mice lacking Zfp423 specifically in the brain, and studied the effects of its loss on embryonic development. We found that Zfp423 is required for proper function of the primary cilium, a structure that is present in most cell types, and that loss of Zfp423 leads to defects in the primary cilia, the projections of cells that transmit signals between cells. This defect can be suppressed by overexpression of the gene Tulp3, which encodes a component of the primary cilium. We also found that loss of Zfp423 causes mislocalization of Smoothened, a gene that is important for normal development. These results suggest that loss of Zfp423 causes mislocalization of Smoothened and a loss of Tulp3, which is a critical component of the primary cilium. Our results suggest that Zfp423 may be necessary for the proper function of the primary cilium in the head, trunk, and colon.

The brain and the nervous system are often thought to work in isolation. We show that a single neural mechanism, a feed-forward inhibition pathway, can control feeding behavior in animals. This mechanism consists of a single positive feedback loop that turns itself off when the animal is hungry. When this mechanism is interrupted, eating begins. We present data on the consequences of interrupted feeding and the role of the neural circuitry. The model suggests that this mechanism could be used by the nervous system to control behavioral data that are not directly controlled. We show that the model is fit to experimental data on rats eating in meals and that its elements can be identified with neurophysiological processes. We then show that the model can also account for behavioral data on eating in multiple phases. In this way, the model can explain short-term behavioral data and long-term behavioral data, which are both indicative of activity-dependent learning.

Activation of the IκB kinase ( IKK ) is a central event in NF-κB signaling. In response to growth factor, IKKs transmit the extracellular signal to intracellular receptors to induce transcription of the IKK gene and the expression of a variety of downstream genes. The precise mechanism by which IKKs gain the ability to induce NF-κB transcription is poorly understood. Here, we report a 4 Å x-ray crystal structure of human IKK2 ( hIKK2 ) in its catalytically active conformation. We demonstrate that, like in the case of Xenopus IKK2 ( xIKK2 ), hIKK2 adopts an open conformation that permits high oligomerization within the crystal. We also identify two surfaces that mediate oligomerization, which are critical for the process of hIKK2 activation. We propose that IKK2 dimers transiently associate with one another through these interaction surfaces to promote trans auto-phosphorylation as part of their mechanism of activation. This study supports recent structural data that implicate strand exchange as part of a mechanism for IKK2 activation via trans auto-phosphorylation. Moreover, oligomerization through the interfaces identified in this study and subsequent trans auto-phosphorylation account for the rapid amplification of IKK2 phosphorylation observed even in the absence of any upstream kinase.

Multidrug-resistant bacteria often evolve by the accumulation of plasmids and chromosomal mutations. Typically, these resistant determinants are costly to the bacterial cell. Yet, it has been found that, in Escherichia coli bacterial cells, a mutation conferring resistance to an antibiotic can be advantageous to the bacterial cell if another antibiotic-resistance mutation is already present, a phenomenon called sign epistasis. Here we study the interaction between antibiotic-resistance chromosomal mutations and conjugative ( i. e., self-transmissible ) plasmids and find many cases of sign epistasis ( 40% ) —including one of reciprocal sign epistasis where the strain carrying both resistance determinants is fitter than the strain carrying only one of the determinants. This implies that acquisition of an additional resistance plasmid or of a resistance mutation often increases the fitness of a bacterial strain already resistant to antibiotics. We further show that there is an overall antagonistic interaction between mutations and plasmids ( 52% ). These results further complicate expectations of resistance reversal by interdiction of antibiotic use.

Invasive candidiasis is the most common bloodstream infection in patients with AIDS, but there are no standard treatments. The immune response that drives host defense against this pathogen includes neutrophils and macrophages, which are recruited to the target organ by their migratory potential. However, neutrophils are also responsible for the excessive immunopathology seen in fatal invasive candidiasis. Here, we describe a new role for the chemokine receptor Ccr1 in promoting neutrophil accumulation in the kidney and increasing renal function in mouse models of invasive candidiasis. Consistent with this, neutrophils from wild-type mice in blood and kidney switched from Ccr1lo to Ccr1high at late time-points post-infection, when Ccr1 ligands were produced in the kidney and were chemotactic for kidney neutrophils ex vivo. When a 1∶1 mixture of Ccr1+/+ and Ccr1−/− donor neutrophils was adoptively transferred intravenously into Ccr1+/+ recipient mice, neutrophil trafficking into the kidney was significantly skewed toward Ccr1+/+ cells. Thus, neutrophil Ccr1 amplifies late renal immunopathology and increases mortality in invasive candidiasis by mediating excessive recruitment of neutrophils from the blood to the target organ.

A significant proportion of the extracellular matrix ( ECM ) fibers are composed of highly polymers of fibronectin ( Fn ). Fn fibers are known to be highly flexible and undergo a range of conformational changes as the proteins are loaded with force. These changes have been extensively studied and used to provide insights into the mechanical properties of the ECM, yet it is not known how these changes relate to the properties of the bulk fiber, which is composed of a large number of fibers. In this work, we have used a novel microstructural modeling approach to compare the mechanical properties of Fn fibers with those of other types of ECM fibers. We have found that this approach is able to predict the mechanical properties of Fn fibers with a level of detail not possible with single molecule measurements. Comparing the properties predicted by single molecule measurements to in vitro measurements of Fn fibers allowed us to show that the ability of Fn fibers to stretch to a high extension is largely determined by their inherent conformational properties. These findings have important implications for understanding the mechanics of other ECM fibers and may also be relevant to fibronectin-based biotherapeutics.

Infections with parasites that cause both infections ( co-infections ) and the combined infections ( multiple co-infections ) are a common cause of morbidity and mortality in coastal Kenya. Spatial patterns of co-infections and transmission risk factors are largely unknown. We assessed the distribution of these infections in rural coastal Kenya, including over 5, 700 individuals. We found that more than 50% of individuals were infected with at least one parasite, and many of them had co-infections. Our results indicate that spatial and socio-economic factors are important risk factors for infection and co-infection. We also found that single and co-infections are heterogeneous in space, spatially overlapping, and associated with lower socioeconomic status and crowding. Our study provides evidence that multiple co-infections are not independent, and that spatial clustering of co-infections is common. These findings have important implications for designing surveillance and intervention strategies.

Recombination is the process of mixing genetic information between chromosomes of different origins. It is widespread in eukaryotes, allowing virus populations to adapt quickly by providing direct access to new areas of a genome space. This process, though, is highly complex and not understood at the molecular level. Here we present a detailed analysis of unique recombination events detectable in the DNA-A and DNA-A-like genome components of bipartite and monopartite begomoviruses. We demonstrate that recombination breakpoint hot- and cold-spots are conserved between the two groups of viruses, and that patterns of sequence exchange amongst the genomes are obviously non-random. Using a computational technique designed to predict structural perturbations in chimaeric proteins, we demonstrate that observed recombination events tend to be less disruptive than sets of simulated ones. Purifying selection acting against natural recombinants expressing improperly folded chimaeric proteins is therefore a major determinant of natural recombination patterns in begomoviruses.

M. tuberculosis, the causative agent of human tuberculosis, is one of the most successful intracellular pathogens, and is responsible for 1. 5 million new cases of tuberculosis per year. The ESX-1 secretion system, one of the most important virulence factors of M. tuberculosis, represents the major virulence determinant of this pathogen. Here, using a combination of genetic and high-throughput approaches, we show that the ESX-1 protein EspL is essential for mediating ESX-1-dependent virulence and for stabilization of EspE, EspF and EspH protein levels. Interestingly, the latter is a key factor for ESX-1-dependent virulence, and its stabilization is also a major determinant of host-pathogen interaction.

A long-term relationship with its partner is necessary for HIV-1 to remain a persistent infection. Sexual transmission is a major route of HIV-1 acquisition. However, the immunological consequences of natural exposure to HIV-1, which is achieved through unprotected sexual intercourse with an HIV-1 infected person, have to our knowledge never been reported. We measured the immune response of 49 HIV-1 infected individuals to HIV-1 epitopes, directly assessed by IFN-γ enzyme linked immuno-spot assay, and to the cytokine flow cytometry. We also assessed the progression of HIV-1 specific T cell responses to virus in response to long-term, antiretroviral therapy ( HAART ), and in response to viremic ( >9000 copies/ml ) individuals. Our results show that individuals who continued to have regular sexual contact with a HIV-1 infected person had significantly higher frequencies of HIV-1 specific T cell responses compared to individuals with aviremic partners. Interestingly, the magnitude of the HIV-1 specific T cell response was strongly influenced by the level and route of exposure.

Malaria and dengue are two of the most common vector-borne diseases in the world, but co-infection is rarely described. We collected symptom histories and blood specimens from subjects in a febrile illness surveillance study conducted in Iquitos and Puerto Maldonado, Peru, between 2002–2011. Nineteen symptoms and 18 immune markers were compared among those with co-infection with Plasmodium/dengue virus ( DENV ), Plasmodium mono-infection, and DENV mono-infection. Seventeen subjects were identified as having Plasmodium/DENV co-infection and were retrospectively matched with 51 DENV mono-infected and 44 Plasmodium mono-infected subjects. Those with Plasmodium mono-infection had higher levels of IL-4, IL-6, IL-10, IL-12, IL-13, IL-17A, IFN-γ, and MIP1-α/CCL3 compared with DENV mono-infection or co-infection. No symptom was more common and no immune marker level was higher in the co-infected group. Our results indicate that Plasmodium/DENV co-infection is not associated with worse disease and resembles DENV mono-infection in both symptom frequency and immune marker level.

Cytomegalovirus ( CMV ) is a herpesvirus that causes a life-long infection in the majority of the human population. The virus is also present in animals and causes disease in humans. CMV is the most common viral infection in newborns, predominantly affecting African Americans and Native Americans. While it is important to know the burden of congenital CMV infection in the US, there are no estimates from the national population. We measured the impact of CMV on the mortality of children in the US over a 17-year time period. We found that 71. 7% of the deaths occurred in infants ( age less than 1 year ). We also calculated the impact of CMV on age-adjusted rates for all race/ethnicity groups. We found that Native Americans and African Americans had a 2. 34 and 1. 89 times higher rate of death from congenital CMV than whites. Our data suggest that CMV infection causes significant mortality in the US and that surveillance and vaccination programs in this population should be increased.

In this study, we examined DNA methylation profiles of primary breast tumors from 162 ( AJCC stage I–IV ) women from the Kaiser Division of Research Pathways Study and the Illumina GoldenGate methylation bead-array platform. We found that tumors from patients who were diagnosed with breast cancer and those who were not, were associated with different methylation profiles than patients who were uninfected. Using a recursive partitioned mixture model, we also found that patient age, tumor size, estrogen and progesterone receptor status, and triple negative status were significantly associated with altered methylation of 209, 74, 183, 69, and 130 loci, respectively. Using all of the 1, 413 DNA methylation loci in a large panel of samples, we found eight distinct methylation classes. Methylation class membership was significantly associated with patient race ( P<0. 02 ) and tumor size ( P<0. 001 ) in univariate tests. Using multinomial logistic regression to adjust for potential confounders, patient age and tumor size, as well as known disease risk factors of alcohol intake and total dietary folate, were all significantly ( P<0. 0001 ) associated with methylation class membership. Our results suggest that, in addition to tumor and patient characteristics, there is also a strong genetic component to breast cancer disease progression.

Picornaviruses are non-enveloped RNA viruses that cause many diseases in humans, animals, and plants. To deliver their genomes to the cell, picornaviruses must penetrate the lipid membranes of the cell and cross the membrane of the cell. In the case of poliovirus, one of the most extensively studied members of the Picornaviridae family, endocytosis of the viral RNA genome has been proposed to release the RNA from the particle. However, it has been difficult to determine the exact mechanism of genome release and the role of cellular membranes for the release of viral RNA. In this study, we have investigated the role of cellular membranes and the function of the cellular RNA helicase RNase A in genome release of poliovirus. We show that the internalization of the viral RNA is inhibited by RNase A, suggesting that the RNA is protected from cleavage by the endocytic machinery. We also show that the infectivity of poliovirus is not reduced by co-internalized RNase A, suggesting that this is the only intracellular event that may regulate the release of viral RNA.

Replication stress is a major cause of cell cycle arrest and death during DNA replication. DNA damage can also block replication, which poses a major challenge in the cell. DNA damage checkpoint proteins are essential for detecting replication stress, and they coordinate DNA repair with cell cycle control. Proliferating cell nuclear antigen ( PCNA ) is a DNA damage–associated protein that plays a central role in DNA repair. Here, we identify human SDE2 as a new DNA damage–associated factor. SDE2 is ubiquitously expressed and can be cleaved by PCNA. We show that the cleaved SDE2 is required for DNA replication and replication stress resistance. SDE2 is a proteolysis product, and its cleavage is mediated by PCNA interaction. Furthermore, we show that the cleaved SDE2 is degraded by the CRL4CDT2 ubiquitin E3 ligase, which is responsible for maintaining genomic integrity and cell cycle control. Collectively, our findings demonstrate a novel function for PCNA-associated SDE2 and its regulation by PCNA, which has important implications for understanding how PCNA regulates DNA repair and cell cycle control.

The hTERT locus is a human cancer susceptibility locus, which is associated with multiple cancers including breast and ovarian cancer. The genetic risk variant that causes the disease is a single-nucleotide polymorphism in the hTERT locus, which encodes a telomerase reverse transcriptase. Telomerase is a multi-protein enzyme that is essential for maintaining a telomere structure, and mutations in components of the telomerase machinery are associated with cancer. Several cancer-associated genetic variants in the hTERT locus have been identified, including the minor allele ( A ) at rs10069690, which causes an additional splice site in the hTERT gene and a mutation in the hTERT RNA subunit. We previously demonstrated that the presence of the risk allele in the hTERT locus results in co-production of full-length ( FL ) -hTERT and an alternatively spliced, INS1b transcript. Here we show that the minor allele, which is associated with an increased cancer risk, encodes a dominant negative inhibitor of telomerase, and that the expression level of the INS1b transcript is reduced. We also show that the expression level of the hTERT locus is reduced due to an increased DNA damage response, resulting in a decreased ability to maintain the telomere structure. Our results provide the first detailed mechanistic insights into a cancer risk-associated SNP in the hTERT locus.

Pteropine orthoreovirus ( PRV ) is a rodent-borne virus that causes fatal disease in humans and bats in Southeast Asia. The clinical course of PRV infection is poorly understood. The virulence, pathology, and pathogenesis of two PRV strains, a human-borne PRV strain ( isolated from a patient, who returned to Japan from Bali, Indonesia in 2007 ) and a bat-borne PRV ( isolated from a bat [Eonycteris spelaea] in the Philippines in 2013 ) were investigated in BALB/c mice using virological, pathological, and immunological methods. The intranasal inoculation of BALB/c mice with human-borne PRV caused respiratory infection, similar to that of the bat-borne PRV. The BALB/c mouse model might be useful for the development of new therapeutic agents for the treatment and prevention of PRV infection.

African trypanosomes are the etiological agents of major diseases in cattle, including sleeping sickness in humans and nagana in cattle. Trypanosome species are complex, and the identification of species-specific molecules is important for laboratory- and field-based research into epidemiology and disease diagnosis. Caused by the protozoan parasites Trypanosoma congolense and Trypanosoma cruzi, trypanosome species are prevalent in Africa and have become an increasing cause of human and animal disease. There are no species-specific trypanosome molecules currently available for diagnostic assays that can be used to differentiate the various trypanosome species. The T. congolense-specific monoclonal antibody Tc6/42. 6. 4 is responsible for the current gold standard for serodiagnosis of cattle infections. In this study, we identified a protein from T. congolense that is recognized by Tc6/42. 6. 4 and show that this molecule is unique to T. congolense. While Tc6/42. 6. 4 is conserved among different species of African trypanosomes, our results show that T. congolense calflagin has potential as a laboratory tool for identifying T. congolense. Calflagin is a flagellar calcium-binding protein that is involved in calcium signaling in eukaryotic cells. The protein from T. congolense has potential as a serodiagnostic antigen for use in serodiagnostic assays for the diagnosis of cattle infections.

Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli ( EHEC ) is a diarrheagenic bacterium that is responsible for over 1 million human infections per year worldwide. The most devastating consequence of EHEC infection is the development of adhesive actin structures called pedestals on the bacterial surface that allow the bacteria to stick to host cells and to form adhesive structures that facilitate the bacteria’s survival and proliferation. The mechanism of actin assembly is poorly understood in EHEC, but it is well known from studies of other bacterial pathogens. One of the most important steps in actin assembly is the assembly of a protein complex called actin-binding protein ( Abp ), which recruits actin polymerization to the cell surface. Here, we show that the Abp–EHEC effector Tir and the actin-binding protein WIP form a complex and are both necessary for actin assembly in cultured cells. Moreover, we find that the Abp–EHEC effector complex stimulates actin assembly by activating the Abp–WIP complex. These results provide the first evidence that the N-WASP-Arp2/3–Abp signaling pathway is required for actin assembly in vivo, and they also show that the N-WASP–Abp–WIP complex can be recruited to the surface of bacteria by interacting with host proteins involved in actin polymerization.

Cells monitor DNA replication errors and mutations, and delay the cell cycle progression until those errors are fixed. Many organisms, including humans, have evolved DNA damage response and spindle assembly checkpoint proteins to monitor DNA replication errors and delay the cell cycle progression. Here, we show that both DNA damage response and spindle assembly checkpoint function together to ensure genomic integrity in C. elegans germ cells. During the cell cycle, the DNA damage response and spindle assembly checkpoint are required to repair replication perturbations, thereby relocalize replication apparatus components to the periphery of the cell cycle. Cells deficient in DNA damage response or spindle assembly checkpoint components fail to repair DNA damage. These results suggest that DNA damage response and spindle assembly checkpoint function are conserved throughout the cell cycle, and that the DNA damage response and spindle assembly checkpoint have diverged to fulfill distinct functions.

The heart is a major organ involved in controlling blood lipid levels and has emerged as an important organ in the regulation of systemic lipid metabolism. However, the underlying mechanism remains poorly understood. Here, we show that the Drosophila cardiomyocytes regulate systemic lipid metabolism by producing apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins ( apoB-lipoproteins ), essential lipid carriers that are so far known to be generated only in the fat body. In a Drosophila genetic screen, we discovered that when haplo-insufficient, microsomal triglyceride transfer protein ( mtp ), required for the biosynthesis of apoB-lipoproteins, suppressed the development of diet-induced obesity. Inhibition of the Drosophila apoB homologue, apoLpp, also protects against the gain in systemic TG levels. Thus, we showed that the heart- and fat body-derived apoB-lipoproteins serve similar roles in regulating whole-body lipid metabolism. We also demonstrated that the Drosophila apoB-lipoproteins, but not the mtp, in the cardiomyocytes, are responsible for systemic TG reduction on high fat diet, likely by increasing the expression of apoLpp. Our findings reveal a novel and significant function of heart-mediated apoB-lipoproteins in controlling lipid homeostasis.

Osteosarcoma is a devastating disease of the bones and joints that is characterised by tumours in bone, called osteoblasts, which are the bone-forming cells. Recql4 mutations are associated with several benign skeletal abnormalities, such as Rothmund-Thmun syndrome ( RTS ) and RAPADILINO syndrome ( RAPADILINO syndrome ). The function of RECQL4 in normal adult bone development is largely uncharacterised. We have therefore investigated the role of Recql4 in bone development using mouse models. In the case of RTS, we have found Recql4 is required for normal bone development and normal bone formation. In contrast, in the case of RAPADILINO syndrome, we have found Recql4 is required for normal osteoblast function and bone formation. However, we have found that the Recql4 deletion in the bone-forming cells did not cause a detectable phenotype. Further, the Recql4 deletion in bone-forming cells did not cause a detectable phenotype in the bone-forming cells, but did cause a significant increase in the length of the survival of mice. Our data therefore provide a mechanism for the benign skeletal phenotypes of RECQL4 mutation syndromes. We propose that tumor suppression and osteosarcoma susceptibility are most likely a function of mutant, not null, alleles of RECQL4.

Why do people help an unfamiliar person in need and why do they do it only in our selfish selfishness? The ‘Theory of Mind’ is a relatively new field of research that aims to explain how people reason about themselves in a way that is distinct from those of other scientists. One important component of the theory is the assumption that individuals have value systems that are distinct from each other and that they should be treated as separate entities. In this paper, we introduce a mathematical model of ‘game theory of Mind’ and show how to use it to infer the sophistication of each other's value system. We show how to quantify this sophistication and show how the sophistication is related to the amount of effort each other is ready to contribute to. Our model is thus a valuable tool for other scientists working on a range of important questions in the fields of biology, neuroscience, and finance.

MicroRNAs are small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression by complementary complementary base pairing. They are involved in the control of many physiological processes, including development and function of the nervous system. In the Central Nervous System, Wnt1 is a key developmental regulator that directs proliferation, survival, and neurogenesis. Wnt1 is expressed from the midbrain, and its function depends on a transcription factor called Lmx1b. Here, we show that the expression of Lmx1b and a newly characterized microRNA, miR135a2, are regulated by Wnt1. Loss of Lmx1b results in severe alterations in Wnt1/Wnt signaling and expansion of the dopamine progenitor domain, while loss of miR135a2 does not have a similar effect. Loss of miR135a2 results in a significant reduction in Wnt1/Wnt signaling in the midbrain, and a reduction in the size of the dopamine progenitor domain. These findings suggest that the microRNA-mediated control of Wnt1/Wnt signaling could have important implications for the design of microRNA-based strategies to control Wnt signaling.

Salmonella enterica serovar Agona is a bacterial pathogen that causes gastroenteritis in humans and other mammals. In 1952, S. enterica was isolated from a foodborne outbreak in the United States, and it underwent a major population expansion in the 1960s. During this time, a new epidemic strain emerged in Europe, resulting in multiple foodborne outbreaks. We analyzed the genomes of 73 strains of S. enterica from around the world, comparing five distinct outbreaks with sporadic infections as well as food contamination and the environment. We found that S. enterica is highly genetically diverse, with 3, 164 additional genetic changes in the genome. These mutations were introduced into the genomes of other S. enterica strains from the same clade, suggesting that these mutations arose neutral rather than adaptive. Each outbreak was caused by an independent clade, without universal, outbreak-associated genomic features, and none of the variable genes in the pan-genome seemed to be associated with an ability to cause outbreaks.

Autism spectrum disorder ( ASD ) is a common neurodevelopmental disorder with a strong genetic component. However, the mechanisms by which ASD causes the disease are still not well understood. In this study, we profiled the co-expression network of 26 autism genes in the mouse brain. The network formed by the autism-associated genes showed a higher degree of co-expression connectivity than other genes in this dataset ( Kolmogorov–Smirnov P = 5×10−28 ). We also identified two cliques of co-expressed genes that were significantly enriched with autism genes ( A Bonferroni corrected P = 0. 05 ). Genes in both these cliques were significantly over-expressed in the cerebellar cortex ( P = 1×10−5 ) suggesting possible implication of this brain region in autism. Our study provides a detailed profile of co-expression patterns of autism genes in the mouse brain, and provides a new candidate list of genes that could be involved in autism etiology.

In recent years, researchers have found that the cortex is capable of representing sensory input in a rich manner, which suggests that the cortex has a generative model in place. However, the nature of this model remains unclear. One condition that could be informative here is Charles Bonnet syndrome ( CBS ), where loss of vision leads to complex, vivid visual hallucinations of objects, people, and whole scenes. CBS could be taken as indication that there is a generative model in the brain, specifically one that can synthesise rich, consistent visual representations even in the absence of actual visual input. Here, we argue that a neural network model based on a recent artificial neural network ( deep Boltzmann machine [DBM] ) can capture the relevant aspects of ( hypothetical ) generative processing in the cortex. We show that homeostatic plasticity could serve to make the learnt internal model robust against e. g. degradation of sensory input, but overcompensate in the case of CBS, leading to hallucinations. We demonstrate how a wide range of features of CBS can be explained in the model and suggest a potential role for the neuromodulator acetylcholine.

Neurocysticercosis is a parasitic infection that can cause severe clinical manifestations in patients with poor access to diagnosis and appropriate treatment. It is a neglected disease and its diagnosis is based on clinical symptoms, imaging and histopathology features. Although, neurocysticercosis is a neglected tropical disease, accurate diagnosis using brain imaging remains poorly accessible and too costly in endemic countries. In this study, we aimed to test if blood monocyte gene expression could distinguish patients with neurocysticercosis ( NCC ) from patients with idiopathic epilepsy and/or headaches. We recruited 18 to 51 patients with NCC, 10 recovered NCC ( RNCC ), 29 idiopathic epilepsy and 17 idiopathic headaches patients. We identified 1411 upregulated and 733 downregulated genes in patients with NCC compared to other groups. Fifteen genes were selected based on possible relevance to NCC, and analyzed by qPCR. qPCR analysis of 15 selected genes showed generally higher gene expression among NCC patients, followed by RNCC, idiopathic headaches and single cyst granulomas. Our results suggest that blood monocyte gene expression may be a useful biomarker for the diagnosis and prognosis of neurocysticercosis.

Replication stress ( DRS ) leads to the accumulation of stalled DNA replication forks leaving a fraction of genomic loci incompletely replicated, which is a source of chromosomal rearrangements during mitosis. Here, we demonstrate that the endonucleases ARTEMIS and XPF-ERCC1 are recruited to chromatin to promote replication fork restart, and that the rapid chromosomal breakage induced by these two DNA replication stress pathways is important to limit chromosomal instability and mitotic segregation defects.

In mammals, many aspects of cellular physiology and metabolism are coordinated by the circadian timing system. In mammals, molecular clocks are thought to rely on negative feedback loops in clock gene expression that engender daily rhythms in the accumulation of transcriptional regulatory proteins such as the orphan receptor REV-ERBα. To gain insight into clock output functions of REV-ERBα, we carried out genome-wide gene expression profiling experiments with liver RNA from wild-type mice, Rev- erbα knock-out mice, or REV-ERBα overexpressing mice. On the basis of these genetic loss- and gain-of-function experiments, we concluded that REV-ERBα participates in the circadian modulation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein ( SREBP ) activity, and thereby in the daily expression of SREBP target genes involved in cholesterol and lipid metabolism. We show that this control acts via the stimulation of LXR nuclear receptors by cyclically produced oxysterols. In conclusion, our study suggests that rhythmic cholesterol and bile acid metabolism is not just driven by alternating feeding–fasting cycles, but also by REV-ERBα, a component of the circadian clockwork circuitry.

Hedgehog proteins are secreted proteins that are critical for embryonic development and diseases such as cancer and birth defects. They are covalently modified by the lipid palmitate and the glycosidic molecule palmitate. This modification leads to multimerization of the protein and long-range signaling potency. However, the biological impact of lipid modification of Hh proteins and their role in human testicular development remains unclear. In the present study, we report a unique case of autosomal recessive syndrome of sex development ( DSD ) with testicular dysgenesis and chondrodysplasia. The affected individual was a homozygous G287V missense mutation in the Hedgehog acyl-transferase ( HHAT ) gene. We demonstrate that loss of function of HHAT leads to testicular dysgenesis and chondrodysplasia, and that this mutation is responsible for the observed phenotypes in humans. In addition, we show that HHAT is required for somatic cells to support the production of testis-derived Sertoli cells. We also show that HHAT is necessary for the formation of the testis cord and for the differentiation of testis stem cells. Altogether, our results shed new light on the biological function of Hh proteins.

Ferritin is a protein involved in iron storage and homeostasis. It is an essential component in the cell, but its concentration is also highly toxic, and iron is an important component in host–pathogen interactions. In this study, we demonstrate that iron is a major factor in the interaction between the symbiont Wolbachia and the host insect Drosophila simulans. Wolbachia inhibits iron uptake and increases the expression of ferritin, which forms a complex involved in iron storage. We also show that the presence of Wolbachia inhibits the host iron metabolism, thus affecting its homeostasis. Our results indicate that Wolbachia may interfere with iron metabolism, and hence the ability of the bacterium to survive and replicate within host cells. Finally, we demonstrate that iron metabolism is influenced by the presence of Wolbachia, showing that Wolbachia may also respond to the concentration of iron, thus allowing the symbiont to persist in the organism by reducing the labile iron concentration, thus protecting the cell from oxidative stress and apoptosis. Our results provide novel insights into the role of iron in the interaction between symbionts and host cells.

Nephrolithiasis is a common chronic kidney disease affecting 1 in 5, 000 people. It is a complex genetic disease, and there is no effective treatment. To identify the genetic factor ( s ) for this disease, we performed a genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) using a large collection of 5, 892 nephrolithiasis cases and 17, 809 controls of Japanese origin. We found three novel loci for nephrolithiasis: RGS14-SLC34A1-PFN3-F12 on 5q35. 3 ( rs11746443; P = 8. 51×10−12, odds ratio ( OR = 1. 19 ), INMT-FAM188B-AQP1 on 7p14. 3 ( rs1000597; P = 2. 16×10−14, OR = 1. 22 ), and DGKH on 13q14. 1 ( rs4142110; P = 4. 62×10−9, OR = 1. 14 ). Our findings elucidated the role of genetic variations for the pathogenesis of nephrolithiasis.

A common cause of late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is the progressive degeneration of the brain’s capacity to function. While the causes of this disease are known, the specific genetic variants that predispose to this disease are still unknown. In this study, we identify a new variant in the gene TM2D3 as a gene that may predispose to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease. We then evaluate the potential effect of this variant in a variety of models, and show that it is likely to cause neuronal degeneration and, therefore, early onset of Alzheimer’s disease.

In 2011, a World Health Organization-recommended vaccine based on the Bacillus Calmette-Guérin ( BCG ) was introduced into the United States and was registered as the first broad-spectrum vaccine ever produced. BCG is widely used as a preventive vaccine against tuberculosis and as a treatment for certain cancers. In addition to its effects against tuberculosis, BCG vaccination also induces beneficial effects against certain forms of cancer and infections with unrelated pathogens. It is well known that BCG induces a reprogramming of the immune system, a process that is referred to as “trained immunity”. In the present study, we demonstrate that autophagy, a process that degrades cellular components, contributes to trained immunity induced by BCG. Pharmacologic inhibition of autophagy blocked trained immunity induced by stimuli such as β–glucans or BCG.
