Furthermore, pharmacologic or genetic inhibition of autophagy blocked the epigenetic reprogramming of monocytes, a process that influences the level of gene expression. Finally, we demonstrate that the polymorphisms in the autophagy-related protein 2 ( ATG2B ) gene correlate with the progression and recurrence of bladder cancer after BCG intravesical treatment. These findings identify a key role of autophagy for the nonspecific protective effects of BCG.

Parasitic worm infections are a major cause of morbidity and mortality in low- and middle-income countries, including Côte d’Ivoire. Integrated control programs, emphasizing preventive chemotherapy along with health education, can reduce the incidence of soil-transmitted helminthiasis and schistosomiasis. The purpose of this study was to develop an educational Animation to improve school-aged children’s awareness regarding parasitic worm infections, diarrheal diseases, and hygiene practices in Côte d’Ivoire. We conducted a preliminary research to assess the knowledge, attitudes, practices, and beliefs of school-aged children regarding parasitic worm infections and hygiene practices. Based on the results of the preliminary research, we produced a revised version of the story of a kichocho, a popular and easy-to-use health message. We used the version of the story to create an animated cartoon, which included the story’s initial version and an additional version. We then evaluated the performance of the animated cartoon. The children who were shown the cartoon reported to like it. The results of our pilot tests showed that, in the short term, children grasped and kept key messages. The messaging was tailored to improve knowledge and practices for prevention of helminthiasis and diarrheal diseases through prior identification of knowledge gaps. Integration of such education tools into the school curriculum, along with deworming campaigns, might improve sustainability of control and elimination efforts against helminthiases and diarrheal diseases.

Antibodies are the main immune system mechanisms for fighting against infectious organisms. They bind to antigens at sites referred to as B-cell epitopes. However, mapping of the exact location of B-cell epitopes is not always possible due to the experimental mapping methods. Therefore, to date, the reported performance values for mapping B-cell epitopes have been moderate. Several issues regarding the evaluation data sets may however have led to the performance values being underestimated: all potential epitopes have been mapped on an antigen, and antibodies are generally raised against the antigen in a given biological context not against the antigen monomer. Improper dealing with these aspects leads to many artificial false positive predictions and hence to incorrect low performance values. To demonstrate the impact of proper benchmark definitions, we here present an updated version of the disco-tope method, which is the first to predict B-cell epitopes under the complete antibody coverage. We show that the updated version of the method performs significantly better than other state-of-the-art methods.

Plants have evolved sophisticated mechanisms to restrict pathogens infection. At the onset of infection, plants activate cell death to kill the microorganism. Cell death is also an effective way for plants to respond to necrotrophic bacterial pathogens, which thrive on dead tissue and are resistant to cell death-induced defense mechanisms. We have identified the PIGMENTASE2-TYPING-GYF DOMAIN-CONTaining PROTEIN 1 ( PSIG1 ), which is involved in the regulation of the cell death response. Our results show that PSIG1 helps to restrict cell death induction during plant-pathogen interaction. Inactivation of PSIG1 does not result in spontaneous lesions, and enhanced cell death in psig1 mutants is independent of salicylic acid ( SA ) biosynthesis or reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) production. Moreover, PSIG1 interacts with SMG7, which plays a role in nonsense-mediated mRNA decay ( NMD ), and the smg7-4 mutant allele mimics the cell death phenotype of the psig1 mutants. Interestingly, the psig1 mutants display enhanced susceptibility to the hemi-biotrophic bacterial pathogen. These results demonstrate the existence and importance of the SA- and ROS-independent cell death constraining mechanism as a part of the plant immune system.

Filarial infections are a public health concern, particularly in the tropics and sub-tropics. In the past, mass drug administration ( MDA ) has been used to eliminate filarial nematode infections in affected countries, but this strategy has been unsuccessful in some areas, and is not always effective in the germline, which is the infective stage of the filarial nematodes. Here we show that two proteins from the filarial nematode B. malayi ( rBm-FAR-1 and rBm-FAR-2 ) are similarly rich in lipid-binding structure, but have different lipid binding activities. These two proteins are targets of strong IgG1, IgG3 and IgE antibody in infected individuals and individuals who were classified as endemic normal or putatively immune. Immunization with rBm-FAR-1 and rBm-FAR-2 elicited high levels of IgG1, but only gerbils immunized with rBm-FAR-1 formulated with the latter produced a statistically significant reduction in adult worms following challenge with B. malayi. These results suggest that these proteins may play important roles in the survival of filarial nematodes in the host, and represent potential candidates for vaccine development against lymphatic filariasis and related filarial infections.

Development of the mammalian thymus involves the differentiation of a single population of cells, the thymic epithelial cells ( TEC ). Foxn1 is a forkhead transcription factor that is indispensable for thymus development, but the mechanism by which it mediates TEC differentiation is poorly understood. To examine the cellular and molecular basis of Foxn1 function, we generated a novel and revertible hypomorphic Foxn1 variant. By varying levels of its expression, we show that Foxn1 is a powerful regulator of TEC differentiation and is required at multiple intermediate stages of TE lineage development in the fetal and adult thymus. We show that Foxn1 is required for stable entry into both the cortical and medullary TEC differentiation programmes and for progression through successive differentiation states in both cortical and medullary TEC. We further demonstrate regulation by Foxn1 of a suite of genes with diverse roles in thymus development and/or function, suggesting it acts as a master regulator of the core thymic epithelial programme rather than regulating a particular aspect of TEC biology. Our novel system may be applied to analyzing other regulators of development.

Heterochromatin is a condensed chromatin structure that is essential for many processes, including transcriptional regulation and DNA repair. Heterochromatin contains many repetitive DNA elements and few protein-encoding genes, yet it is essential for chromosome organization and inheritance. In this work, we have identified heterochromatin mutants that lack the Su ( var ) 3-9 histone H3K9 methyltransferase. These animals show elevated levels of spontaneous DNA damage in both somatic and germ-line cells. Our data indicate that these heterochromatin mutants are defective in DNA repair and mitotic checkpoints. Similar effects were also observed in animals that lack the RNA interference pathway component Dcr2. Our results suggest that the H3K9 methylation and RNAi pathways ensure heterochromatin stability.

In South Africa, infection with the parasite Schistosoma haematobium is a major cause of genital morbidity and may cause lesions, bleeding, pain, discharge, and the damaged surfaces may pose a risk for HIV. In a cross-sectional study of 1057 school-girls, we interviewed 22% of them for genital symptoms, and examined three urines from each of them for the presence of S. haematobium eggs. One third of the girls reported to have a history of genital symptoms. In regression analysis the genital symptoms were significantly associated both with urinary schistosomiasis and water contact. Even before sexually active age, a relatively large proportion of the participating girls had similar genital symptoms to those reported for adult genital schistosomiasis previously. Anti-schistosomal treatment should be considered at a young age in order to prevent chronic genital damage and secondary infections such as HIV, sexually transmitted diseases and other super-infections.

While the immune system has to function continuously, the innate immune system has to work with a multitude of different pathogens, and it must coordinate the response to these infections. In this work, we demonstrate that aging in the worm C. elegans causes the innate immune system to malfunction, leading to an increased susceptibility to bacterial infection. We find that this effect is mediated by the conserved PMK-1 pathway, a pathway that is known to regulate a variety of cellular processes. Our data suggest that an altered function of this pathway, which has to function continuously, can lead to the increased susceptibility of C. elegans to bacterial infection. Our work defines the phenomenon of innate immunosenescence in C. elegans in terms of the age-dependent dynamics of the PMK-1 pathway, and it suggests that an altered function of the PMK-1 pathway may lead to the increased susceptibility of C. elegans to bacterial infection.

Large biomolecular assemblies are often built as intricate molecular machines, yet their architecture is well known from their atomic structure. Computer models offer a valuable way of describing their dynamics, and at the same time they offer a powerful way of designing synthetic systems. Computer models are often constructed of thousands of elements and millions of parameters, and have thus far been largely tuned for a single purpose. We have developed a computer model that addresses an important issue in computer vision, the use of ambient light to illuminate molecular features. Our approach is to use the knowledge of the molecular features to make a series of computer models that have different sizes, shapes, and contents. We then compare these models, and show how their features differ from each other and from the features of the human body. The methods we have developed allow the computer models to be tailored to fit the eye view of a user-defined size.

Ribosomal profiling is a technique that allows monitoring the speed and the ribosomal density of translation along genes at a resolution of single nucleotides. Its application has been used to analyze the mRNA folding capacity of different species of ribosomes. Here, we focused on ribosomal density profiles of mouse embryonic stem cells. Our analysis suggests, for the first time, that even in mammals such as M. musculus the elongation speed is significantly and directly affected by determinants of the coding sequence such as: 1 ) the adaptation of codons to the tRNA pool; 2 ) the local mRNA folding of the coding sequence; 3 ) the local charge of amino acids encoded in the codon sequence. Our analysis also suggests that in general, the translation velocity of ribosomes is slower at the beginning of the coding sequence and tends to increase downstream. Finally, a comparison of these data to the expected biophysical behavior of translation suggests that it suffers from some unknown biases. Specifically, the ribosomal flux measured on the experimental data increases along the coding sequence; however, according to any biophysical model of ribosomal movement lacking internal initiation sites, the flux is expected to remain constant or decrease. Thus, developing experimental and/or statistical methods for understanding, detecting and dealing with such biases is of high importance.

Hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) is a major cause of chronic liver disease worldwide and is a leading cause of liver transplantation. Infection of the liver is initiated by HCV particles that are taken up by the HCV receptor clathrin, which recognizes a series of glycan side chains present on the surface of the virus. Once internalized, HCV particles interact with clathrin receptors, culminating in fusion of clathrin-containing HCV particles with endosomal membranes. Although the interaction of clathrin with the HCV receptor has been well studied, the importance of the interaction with another host cell factor, the tight junction receptor SR-BI, has not been investigated. Here, we demonstrate that knockdown of PDZK1, a component of the tight junction, significantly decreases the susceptibility of HCV particles to HCV infection, and that this effect can be reversed by overexpression of full-length PDZK1. Furthermore, we show that overexpression of a green fluorescent protein chimera of the cytoplasmic carboxy-terminus of SR-BI results in its interaction with PDZK1 and reduced susceptibility to HCV infection. Our results indicate that PDZK1 is involved in HCV entry via its direct interaction with SR-BI, which provides a rationale for the importance of SR-BI in HCV infection.

When people learn to live in a complex society, they learn to associate abstract concepts and ideas with concrete reality. In a social learning task, however, this abstract concept can be either helpful or detrimental, depending on the social context. People's ability to associate abstract concepts and ideas with concrete reality is called “adaptive social learning” and is essential for learning in all societies. Yet, the neurobiological basis of this adaptation is largely unknown. In this study, we used computer simulations to analyze the neural mechanisms underlying adaptive social learning. We found that people's preference to come from a favorable social context increases the strength of their negative feedback after the social context is presented. Importantly, the strength of this feedback is correlated with the brain's ability to associate abstract concepts and ideas with concrete reality. Our results indicate that following advice is a rewarding outcome and that the brain's internal signal of reward is interpreted as positive. Our results provide a neurobiological understanding of social learning by linking the computational model to brain activity.

Aging is the most important biological process in the human life. Genetic diseases are known to be closely related with the aging process. In this study, we constructed a human disease-aging network integrating human protein-protein interactions, disease-gene associations, aging-gene associations, and physiological system–based genetic disease classification information. We found that ( 1 ) human disease genes are much closer to aging genes than expected by chance; and ( 2 ) diseases can be categorized into two types according to their relationships with aging. We also characterized the topological characters of the disease-aging network from a systems perspective. Our findings indicate that the genes of type I diseases are in a central position of a protein-protein interaction network, while the genes of type II are not. Furthermore, we also show that the disease-aging network contains a type of asymmetric closeness based on the protein-protein interaction network to describe relationships among diseases. In conclusion, the disease-aging network provides not only evidence for the intricate relationship between the aging process and genetic diseases, but also biological implications for prying into the nature of human diseases.

Dengue is a re-emerging disease of the tropics, affecting 50 to 100 million people annually. It is caused by the flavivirus dengue virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. There are no licensed vaccines for dengue, so prevention relies on early detection and treatment of patients with suspected dengue infection. Early diagnosis and treatment can reduce the risk of severe disease. This requires the identification of early signs and symptoms that are most indicative of dengue infection. In this study, we have developed a computational algorithm that can differentiate dengue from other febrile illnesses based on clinical, blood and urine samples. Our algorithm is based on analysis of all three clinical and laboratory data to predict disease severity in an automated way. We have shown that our algorithm can be used differently in different disease prevalence to yield clinically useful positive and negative predictive values. Furthermore, we have shown that our algorithm is associated with haemorrhage and shock in adults with dengue fever. This study provides a proof-of-concept that computational algorithms using simple clinical and haematological parameters can predict diagnosis and prognosis of dengue disease.

The mechanisms of animal lifespan determination are crucial for the survival and reproduction of organisms. This is particularly important for insects, as their lifespan is highly variable across species. In the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, the activity of FoxO ( dFOXO ), a forkhead box transcription factor ( TF ) family member, regulates lifespan determination. FoxO controls a number of other TFs, but how these TFs in turn might mediate the anti-ageing programmes orchestrated by FoxOs in vivo is unclear. Here, we identify a novel dFOXO target, the E-twenty six ( ETS ) -family transcription factor ( AOP ), as regulated by the single Drosophila FoxO ( dFOXO ). AOP, the functional orthologue of the human Etv6/Tel protein, binds numerous genomic sites also occupied by dFOXO and counteracts the activity of an ETS activator, PNT, to prevent the lifespan-shortening effects of co-activation of dFOXO and PNT. This detrimental synergistic effect of dFOXO and PNT appears to stem from a mis-regulation of lipid metabolism. At the same time, AOP activity in another fly organ, the fat body, has further beneficial roles, regulating genes in common with dfoxo, such as the secreted, non-sensory, odorant binding protein ( Obp99b ), and robustly extending lifespan. Our study reveals a complex interplay between evolutionarily conserved ETS factors and dFOXO, the functional significance of which may extend well beyond animal lifespan.

Gliding motility is crucial for parasite survival and host cell invasion. A better understanding of the mechanism by which gliding motility is achieved is of paramount importance. Here, we investigated the role of gliding associated proteins GAP40 and GAP50 as well as members of the GAPM family during intracellular replication of Toxoplasma gondii. Deletion or disruption of these genes resulted in the rapid collapse of parasites after initiation of the cell cycle and led to redistribution of other gliding proteins. These results demonstrate that core elements of the gliding complex, the gliding associated proteins GAP40 and GAP50 as well as members of the GAPM family, play essential roles in the biogenesis of the inner membrane complex ( IMC ) during intracellular replication.

Filarial nematodes are parasitic worms that can cause chronic infections in humans and mosquitoes, and are the cause of elephantiasis and onchocerciasis. Current filarial control strategies are based on mass drug administration ( MDA ) programs that target the microfilariae that are released from adult female worms, which can be killed by immune effectors such as antibodies. This strategy, however, is not a cure and may be problematic if the parasite has developed the ability to evade immune effectors and/or survive for many years. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop vaccines against these parasites. Here we have developed a strategy for DNA vaccination against filarial nematodes that targets parasite-induced immunosuppression while concurrently enhancing Th2 immune responses and parasite antigen presentation by dendritic cells. Our results show that DNA vaccination against filarial nematodes, which are highly prevalent in the developing world, can be used to enhance Th2 immune responses and also protect against microfilariae.

Typhoid fever is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in low- and middle-income countries. Vaccines are commonly used to protect against typhoid fever, however there are few examples of such programs being implemented in endemic countries. Here we have used whole genome sequencing to characterise the genetic diversity of Salmonella Typhi bacteria collected before and after the introduction of a national typhoid immunization program in Thailand in 1977. We found that the majority of S. Typhi genotypes were not observed following the national immunization program, and therefore were likely to be absent following it. In contrast, we detected evidence for the local persistence of a number of novel genotypes and also for the importation of common genotypes from neighbouring countries into Thailand, suggesting that typhoid immunization may be a long-term process. These data show the value of using whole genome sequencing in understanding the effects of vaccination on pathogen populations and provide support for the proposal that large-scale vaccination programs in endemic areas could result in lasting local disease elimination.

Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a necrotizing, ulcerative, and infectious disease of the skin, subcutaneous tissue and soft tissue. BU is the second most common mycobacterial infection after tuberculosis. BU usually starts with a painless ulcer on the skin that progresses to a large necrotizing lesion. BU is difficult to treat, because it is often difficult to treat patients with antibiotics. In recent years, the treatment of BU has shifted from surgery to a combination of streptomycin and rifampin. However, the effectiveness of this combination regimen is still unknown. We compared the efficacy of rifampin, rifapentine, and clarithromycin, on the mouse model of BU. We found that treatment with rifampin alone and the combination therapy of rifampin +clarithromycin was more effective than treatment with rifapentine alone. However, treatment with all other drugs reduced the median time to footpad swelling by approximately 2 or 3 log10. Medically important signs of disease progression, namely the maximal serum concentration ( Cmax ) and the AUC of the serum concentration-time curve ( AUC ) of rifampin, were not significantly affected by treatment with rifapentine alone. Co-administration of rifapentine with rifampin may be at least as effective as the currently recommended combination of streptomycin + rifampin.

Recent developments in cancer immunotherapy have resulted in a dramatic increase in the incidence of cancer in young adults. It is therefore important to understand the factors and mechanisms underlying cancer initiation and progression. One of the most common cancer types and for which there is no cure is the myeloproliferative neoplasms ( MPNs ), which are thought to reflect transformation of an hematopoietic stem cell ( HSC ) and the majority harbor an acquired somatic mutation in the JAK2 tyrosine kinase. Here, we show that this somatic mutation results in a defect in the ability of HSCs to self-renew, and that this defect is intrinsic to individual HSCs and their progeny are biased toward proliferation and differentiation as evidenced by single cell and transplantation assays. Our results also indicate that JAK2V617F reduces the ability of individual HSCs to differentiate and proliferate, which is critical for the development of MPNs. Together, our data suggest that acquisition of JAK2V617F alone is insufficient for clonal expansion and eventual disease progression. Moreover, our results show that clonal expansion of progenitor cells provides a window in which collaborating mutations can accumulate to drive disease progression.

Neurons in the brain are connected by local connections that can be either excitatory or inhibitory. We show that the way these connections are connected strongly influences the overall neuronal activity, in particular the emergent properties of large-scale neural network models. Our results suggest that a particular form of neuronal avalanches, which is a phenomenon that has been proposed in the 1970s, results from an underlying instability in the connective connectivity of local neural connections. In the case of a large-scale model, we show that the avalanches and their corresponding fluctuation exponents can be calculated from a single ordinary differential equation equation, given by the M/EEG formalism. In a narrow region of parameter space, the avalanches have a power-law exponent, which can be reproduced by a simple relation on the connective connectivity parameters. Our results can also be reproduced by the same formalism for large-scale models. We show that in this region, the power-law exponent for the connective connectivity parameters is not identical to the one for the mean-field directed percolation exponents, as expected.

Pneumonia is a major cause of mortality in infants and young children. Pneumonia occurs when bacteria invade the lung and spread to other tissues causing life-threatening diseases. There are many different types of immune cells in the lung and each has a distinct role in fighting pneumococcal infection. However, the role of each type of immune cells is not well understood. We show that a particular type of immune cells called T regulatory cells are important in fighting pneumococcal pneumonia. Blocking the function of T regulatory cells makes mice more susceptible to infection and death due to pneumococcal pneumonia. In contrast, transferring T regulatory cells to mice that are naturally resistant to infection increases the survival of mice with pneumococcal pneumonia. These results suggest that targeting the function of T regulatory cells might be a novel strategy for treating pneumococcal pneumonia.

A popular assumption in comparative genomics is that orthologous genes share greater functional similarity than do paralogous genes ( the “ortholog conjecture” ). Many methods used to computationally predict protein function are based on this assumption, even though it is largely untested. Here we present the first large-scale test of the ortholog conjecture using comparative functional genomic data from human and mouse. We use the experimentally derived functions of more than 8, 900 genes, as well as an independent microarray dataset, to directly assess our ability to predict function using both orthologs and paralogs. We find that paralogs are often a much better predictor of function than are orthologs, even at lower sequence identities. Among paralogs, those found within the same species are consistently more functionally similar than those found in a different species. We also find that paralogous pairs residing on the same chromosome are more functionally similar than those on different chromosomes, perhaps due to higher levels of interlocus gene conversion between these pairs. In addition to offering implications for the computational prediction of protein function, our results shed light on the relationship between sequence divergence and functional divergence.

Infections with Cryptosporidium are widespread in developing countries. One of the most important of these diseases is cryptosporidiosis. It is estimated that there are 2–3 million cryptosporidiosis cases per year in the United States, and Cryptosporidium oocysts are the only Cryptosporidium species causing life-threatening diarrhea in young children. C. oocysts are difficult to count, both in animals and in human samples. We developed a method for purifying C. oocysts from stool and intestine and applied it to two different types of oocysts. The method was shown to be a high-throughput technique that can be applied to large numbers of samples without the need for costly antibody-based techniques. We also applied this method to study the biology of Cryptosporidium oocysts. The method can be applied to a variety of samples and can be adapted for studies that are difficult to conduct due to sample volumes and cost.

Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a re-emerging mosquito-borne virus and has become a global public health concern, especially in the tropics and subtropics. The microRNA-30e* protein is a newly identified host factor which regulates the IκBα/β and NF-κB signaling pathways and interferon ( IFN ) response. In this study, we found that DENV infection could induce expression of miR-30e* and that this overexpression of miR-30e* upregulated IFN-β and the downstream IFN-stimulated genes ( ISGs ) such as OAS1, MxA and IFITM1, and suppressed DENV replication. Furthermore, IκBα mediated the enhancing effect of miR-30e* on IFN-β-induced antiviral response. Our findings support the hypothesis that miR-30e* is a modulatory factor of IFN-β response in DENV infection.

Staphylococcus aureus is an important cause of hospital-acquired methicillin-resistant infections worldwide. The F region downstream of the mecI gene in the SCCmec element contains two bidirectionally overlapping open reading frames ( ORFs ), the fudoh ORF and the psm-mec ORF. The psm-mec ORF encodes a cytolysin, phenol-soluble modulin ( PSM ) -mec. Transformation of the F region into a methicillin-sensitive S. aureus ( MSSA ) strain, which is a methicillin-sensitive S. aureus ( MSA ) strain, or into the MW2 ( USA400 ) and FRP3757 ( USA300 ) strain, which is community-acquired MRSA ( CA-MRSA ) strain, attenuated their virulence in a mouse model. By producing mutations into the psm-mec ORF, we revealed that both the transcription and translation products of the psm-mec ORF suppressed colony-spreading activity and promoted biofilm formation. This is the first report of the role of the psm-mec transcript in the regulation of S. aureus virulence.

Visceral Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by protozoan protozoa transmitted by sand flies. The VL elimination strategy requires cost-effective tools for case detection and management. We compared the yield, feasibility and cost of 4 different active case detection strategies in VL endemic districts of India, Nepal and Bangladesh. We also evaluated the cost-effectiveness of the strategies for detecting new cases in the neighborhood of index cases. We found that the 2nd screening round was the most cost-effective at identifying new cases. We also found that the house screening was the most cost-effective way to identify cases. Our findings provide guidance for cost-effective strategies for case detection and management in VL elimination programmes.

HIV viral loads are inversely correlated to the time taken for the first peak viremia after infection. We investigated the effect of different antiretroviral drug classes on the first phase dynamics of HIV plasma virus. In particular, we examined the role of drugs acting at stages closer to viral production, such as the integrase inhibitor raltegravir. We found that raltegravir is more efficient at slowing the first phase decay of HIV plasma virus than raltegravir alone. The effect of raltegravir is primarily due to an immune clearance that occurs in the productive stage of the viral infection cycle. We also found that the slowing of phase IA to phase IB at day 2 to 4 of monotherapy is a result of new rounds of infection. The level at which this slowing occurs is a better indicator of drug efficacy than the initial decay of the first phase.

When bacteria encounter viruses, they evolve rapidly enough to acquire short DNA sequences ( spacers ) that can protect them from viruses. This process is mediated by the CRISPR/Cas9 system, which has been shown to be highly efficient at targeting specific DNA sequences in viruses. We present a computational model that describes the interplay between these two processes. We show that spacers can be acquired with different efficiency, and that their effectiveness in conferring protection depends on the amount of DNA sequence in the target virus. Our results provide insights into how bacteria and phages interact in the population.

Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a neglected tropical disease caused by a protozoan parasite. Infection with this parasite is acquired through the bite of an insect vector, and is transmitted to the human host by the bite of an infected sand fly. The disease is widespread in the poorest regions of the world and is considered a major health concern. Current treatments for VL are expensive, are poorly tolerated, and have a high rate of resistance. There is an urgent need for new and better treatments. A large number of researchers are working on VL to develop new treatments and to assess their potential effectiveness. We reviewed the available clinical trial data on VL to see if any studies could be used to combine data from different researchers to form a unified clinical trial. The results indicate that some clinical trials can be used to inform other researchers on VL. We also provide data that can be used to establish a data sharing platform that would allow other researchers to share their results and experiences with VL.

Nucleoporins are integral components of the nuclear pore complex and are involved in the trafficking of numerous proteins into and out of the nucleus. The large nucleoporin Nup358 has been implicated in the HIV-1 life cycle and is also involved in regulating the trafficking of other proteins along the cytoplasmic pathway. RNAi has shown that Nup358 has a role in regulating HIV-1 infection. Nup358 and its homolog Nif in Drosophila melanogaster, form filaments that project from the nuclear pore into the cytoplasm. These filaments bind to receptors on the surface of the cell that are required for viral nuclear export. Here we show that Nup358 can be depleted in human cells, but that the effects on viral replication are not. We also show that Nup358 can be used in human cells to rescue replication after depletion of the host protein TNPO3, which is involved in the regulation of nuclear transport functions. Our results suggest that Nup358 and its homolog in Drosophila, CypA, are required for the nuclear transport functions of the host cell. We also show that Nup358 can support the replication of HIV-1 in human cells, but that the cyclophilin homolog, SUMO E3 ligase, does not have a direct role in this process.

The miRNA network is an important player in gene regulation. However, it is still unclear how the network has evolved and how it contributes to the organism. Evolutionary analysis of the miRNA network has been challenging because of the large number of potential interactions between miRNAs and their targets. We present a novel analytical method that combines a phylogenetic model with a Bayesian analysis to identify conserved target sites. Our analysis identifies a network of miRNA targets that share conserved regulatory functions. We also find that network interactions are not independent of each other, and that co-targeting of functionally related sets of miRNAs is a common trend in the miRNA network. Our approach can be easily applied to other genomic datasets and to analyze a large data set in a fast and efficient manner. We believe our method can help to understand the evolution of the miRNA network and the organism.

The most mineralized tissue of the mammalian body is tooth enamel. Especially in species with thick enamel, three-dimensional ( 3D ) tomography data has shown that the distribution of enamel varies across the occlusal surface of the tooth crown. Differences in enamel thickness among species and within the tooth crown have been used to examine taxonomic affiliations, life history, and functional properties of teeth. Before becoming fully mineralized, enamel matrix is secreted on the top of a dentine template, and it remains to be explored how matrix thickness is spatially regulated. To provide a predictive framework to examine enamel distribution, we develop a computational model of enamel matrix secretion that maps the dentine topography to the enamel surface topography. Starting from empirical enamel-dentine junctions that have markedly different dentine and enamel surface topologies, we show how diffusion-limited free boundary mechanisms account for both the process of matrix secretion and the final enamel distribution. Simulations reveal how concave and convex dentine features have distinct effects on the final enamel surface, thereby explaining why the enamel surface is not a straightforward extrapolation of the dentine template. Our results suggest that even subtle variations in dentine topography can lead to dramatic changes in the occlusal surface of the tooth crown.

Cancer is a genetic disease, driven by aberrations in the genome. Chromosomal aberrations are a hallmark of tumor development and progression, and are a well-documented clinical feature of colorectal cancer. However, the frequency of chromosomal aberrations and their clinical relevance remain largely unknown. We assessed the level of intra-patient genetic heterogeneity using a heterogeneity score based on pair-wise genetic distances among tumor deposits, and assessed the prognostic effect of genomic complexity on the survival of patients after surgical resection of liver metastatic lesions. We observed that heterogeneity is a strong prognostic factor, stronger than known clinicopathological prognostic parameters. Patients with a low level of heterogeneity ( below the median level ) had a three-year survival rate of 23% and 66% respectively, versus 5% and 18%, respectively. A low patient-wise level of genomic complexity was also a favorable prognostic factor. However, the prognostic association of intra-patient heterogeneity was independent of genomic complexity in multivariable analyses. In conclusion, our results show that intra-patient inter-metastatic genetic heterogeneity is a pronounced feature of metastatic colorectal cancer, and the strong prognostic association reinforces its clinical relevance and places it as a key feature to be explored in future patient cohorts.

Tuberculosis is the leading cause of death due to a single infectious agent worldwide. In 2015, 1. 8 million people died from the disease, and the fatality rate is 1. 6%. The fatality rate is caused by the complex interaction between the bacillus and the immune system. This complex has a major impact on the host’s response to the infection. It is known that inflammation contributes to the pathology in many chronic inflammatory diseases. In the case of tuberculosis, several reports have shown that the inflammation contributes to the fatality rate, but the underlying mechanism remains unknown. In this study, we have analyzed the biogenesis of macrophages, which are the primary cells of the immune system. We found that the biogenesis of macrophages is distinct from the biogenesis of atherosclerosis macrophages. We also show that the biogenesis of macrophages is disease-specific and that the mechanism of macrophage biogenesis is distinct from that of atherosclerosis macrophages. Our findings provide important information for the understanding of the mechanisms involved in the initiation of the host’s inflammatory response during a chronic inflammatory disorder such as tuberculosis.

HIV-1 is a chronic virus infection that cannot be eradicated even if the infected individuals are regularly exposed to the virus. The virus can hide in the body for many years, but if the immune system is attacked, the virus can be rapidly killed. This is particularly important for the immune system to prevent viral persistence and for the host to avoid immune-mediated pathology. The cell type called the natural killer ( NK ) cell is an important component of the immune response that is activated by viruses. One way the NK cells recognize viruses is by recognizing a cell surface molecule present on the surface of the infected cell. This molecule is called the ligand. When the cell is infected with HIV-1, the ligand is also induced. We have recently shown that NK cells recognize human immunodeficiency virus type-1 ( HIV-1 ) ligands on the surface of the infected cell. In this study we demonstrate that the cell uses a specific protein, Vpr, to induce the expression of the human immunodeficiency virus type-1 ( HIV-1 ) ligand on the surface of the infected cell. When the NK cells are infected with a vpr-deficient virus, they are unable to kill the infected cell. Our study reveals how NK cells recognize viruses and how they can kill infected cells.

Leishmaniasis is a vector-borne disease transmitted by sandflies that is responsible for the development of a spectrum of diseases in humans. It is caused by the Leishmania parasite and is transmitted by the bite of an infected sandfly. There are three main clinical manifestations of leishmaniasis, which are: visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis. The last one is asymptomatic. The former is a major public health concern in the world, due to the increasing incidence of HIV co-infection. The latter is a major health concern in the developing countries, with more than 1. 5 million people infected with Leishmania in the world. Asymptomatic immune responders to Leishmania are rare, but this is the result of the development of an effective vaccine. The current study aimed to investigate the use of cytokine release assays in the detection of asymptomatic immune responders to Leishmania among HIV+ patients with no previous leishmaniasis or current symptomatology. The results of this work show that cytokine release assays are 100% reliable for detecting asymptomatic immune responders to Leishmania among HIV+ patients.

HIV-1 is a highly successful pathogen that infects and kills millions of people worldwide. Despite the existence of effective anti-HIV-1 drugs, the virus rapidly escapes treatment and causes significant disease burden and economic losses. Because of the difficulty of treating HIV-1, there is an urgent need for better ways to control the virus. Gene therapy is a promising new approach, but its utility depends on the ability of the virus to rapidly mutate to escape treatment. While the use of gene therapy may be effective in some settings, it presents a critical challenge to consider in designing effective treatments for HIV-1. In this work, we develop a novel computational model to study how gene therapy can improve control of HIV-1. Our results highlight the importance of mutationally-induced viral fitness losses in cells that are not genetically modified, as these can severely constrain the replication of resistant virus. We also suggest a novel treatment strategy that leverages upon gene therapy's unique capacity to deliver different genes to distinct cell populations, and we find that such a strategy can dramatically improve efficacy when used judiously within a certain parametric regime.

In the developing embryo, cells must integrate signals received from different sources to determine what they should do. How cells integrate these signals is largely unknown. Previous work has shown that the transcriptional coactivator Yorkie ( Yki ), which is induced by the Warts/Hippo ( Wts/Hpo ) tumour suppressor pathway, controls organ growth. Yki activity is regulated by the Wnt/Insulin-like peptides ( ILPs ) pathway. In this study, we show that TOR, a conserved nutrient-sensing pathway, regulates Yki activity by a separate mechanism in the Drosophila wing. We find that TOR regulates Yki by allowing it to access its target genes after it enters the nucleus. When TOR is inhibited, Yki accumulates in the nucleus but is sequestered from its normal growth-promoting target genes—a phenomenon we term “nuclear seclusion. ” Hence, we posit that in addition to its well-known role in stimulating cellular metabolism in response to nutrients, TOR also promotes wing growth by liberating Yki from nuclear seclusion, a parallel pathway that we propose contributes to the scaling of wing size with nutrient availability.

Pulse of cGMP in the nucleus induces cGMP-dependent PKG activation that is generally known to regulate transcription. In mammals, PKG has been shown to activate many genes. However, PKG is a multifunctional protein that is able to carry out diverse functions in the cell nucleus, which is the site of cGMP synthesis, as well as in other cell types. It is thus important to identify downstream effectors of PKG activation. Here, we show that EGL-4, the Caenorhabditis elegans PKG ortholog, recruits a conserved histone deacetylase complex to regulate gene expression via one of its targets. We also identify a novel gene that is sensitive to EGL-4 activity and show that EGL-4 controls egg laying via one of its target genes. Our results demonstrate that EGL-4 regulates gene expression via recruitment of a conserved histone deacetylase complex to regulate transcription.

HIV-1 is an infectious virus that is capable of replicating in both the absence and presence of its host cell. The viral particles are formed by a virus particle that contains viral RNA and viral protein and must be packaged into a spherical core. There is a large amount of structural information available for the HIV-1 particle, but it is difficult to relate this structural information to the process of maturation. We have used structural analysis to investigate the conformation of the viral polyprotein Gag at different stages of the maturation process. We have found that the immature Gag lattice can be folded into a conical core that is surrounded by a hexameric lattice containing the Gag N-terminal region. We have also determined the structure of the mature Gag lattice and found that it can be incorporated into the viral particle. Our findings provide a detailed description of the structural intermediates of the maturation process.

Schistosomiasis is a serious parasitic disease that causes morbidity and mortality in the developing world. The disease is caused by the worm Schistosoma mansoni, which can be found in the liver, lung, and skin. The parasite has a complex life cycle, alternating between an intermediate snail host and an intermediate human host. The transmission cycle requires freshwater snails, and the transmission is facilitated by the development of snails in the liver and the bladder. The eggs of the snails are released into the environment, and the larvae in the snails are ready for transmission. The transmission is initiated in the human host when the snails ingest the S. mansoni eggs, which then develop into larvae in the liver. The snails release the larvae into the environment, and the adult worms develop in the liver. In the first few years of infection, the snails produce a small number of eggs, which are released into the environment. The snails, therefore, can be observed in the snails' tissues, but the results are often difficult to interpret. The current method, the Kato-Katz technique, has low sensitivity for very light infections, and sensitivity for the presence of large numbers of eggs in the snail is very low. The widespread use of the Kato-Katz technique to map schistosomiasis prevalence is a major health care concern, and it is recommended for mapping, control, and surveillance programs. In this study, we show that the use of the Kato-Katz technique, when the prevalence is intermediate, can be useful for estimating the intensity of infection. We also show that the POC-CCA is a promising rapid diagnostic test for schistosomiasis, which is simple to use and requires only minimal laboratory equipment.

Parasitic infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Despite this, no vaccine exists for human use. The intestinal tract is a major target for vaccine development. We investigated the ability of three purified antigens from the intestinal tract to induce immunity to the intestinal nematode Heligmosomoides polygyrus. In the mouse model, vaccination with these antigens induces sterilising immunity that relies upon antibody-mediated effector cell infiltration. We show that in the presence of protective antibodies, there is enhanced cellular infiltration in the gut wall. Intra-vital imaging of infected intestinal tissue revealed a four-fold increase in the infiltration of immune cells. Mice deficient in complement component or FcRγ-mediated effector cell infiltration, or IL-4/IL-25-dependent inflammatory monocytes, remain fully immune. Our data provide the first evidence that vaccine-induced immunity to intestinal helminths involves IgG1 antibodies that are induced by antigens secreted in concert with IL-25-dependent myeloid effector populations.

In order to infect cells, viruses must penetrate a membrane bilayer barrier, the fusion pore, to enter the cell. This process is facilitated by a process termed “pore formation”, which requires a high curvature of the fusion pore rim to expose the hydrophobic interior of the membrane to water. How proteins breach this thermodynamic barrier to pore formation is unclear. Here, we identified a novel lipid packing sensor ( FLiPS ) in the cytosolic domain of the FAST protein, which is essential for pore formation during cell-cell fusion and syncytiogenesis. The p15 FLiPS preferentially partitions into membranes with high positive curvature, and is impaired by a small molecule that inserts into hydrophobic defects in membranes. Most notably, the p15 FLiPS can be functionally replaced by heterologous amphipathic lipid packing sensors ( ALPS ), but not by other membrane-interactive amphipathic helices. Furthermore, a previously unrecognized amphipathic helix in the cytosolic domain of the reptilian reovirus p14 FAST protein can functionally replace the p15 FLiPS, and is itself replaceable by a heterologous ALPS motif. Anchored near the cytoplasmic leaflet by the FAST protein transmembrane domain, the FLiPS is perfectly positioned to insert into hydrophobic defects that begin to appear in the highly curved rim of nascent fusion pores, thereby lowering the energy barrier to stable pore formation.

Chagas disease is a chronic infection of the heart and digestive system caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Infection is acquired when people consume blood meal contaminated with the parasite. The parasite can be transmitted by insect vectors, blood transfusion, organ transplantation, or by ingestion of food or juice contaminated with the parasite. Treatment for infection is limited to 1–2 drugs and vector control is the only method to prevent transmission. Treatment can be difficult to diagnose in the chronic infection because the parasite can live for many years in the body. In the chronic stage of infection, children are often missed as they may be infected prior to treatment. We conducted a serological survey in children living in an area of Peru with T. cruzi transmission. We used a novel method to collect information about the infection status of children in order to determine which children are most likely to be infected. Our results show that more than 83% of infected children could be identified while testing only 22% of eligible children. This method can be used in low-resource settings to identify children at high risk of infection.

Retroviruses, including herpesviruses, are known to infect target cells by binding to a receptor protein on the cell surface. This triggers a conformational change in the viral envelope glycoprotein ( Env ) that mediates virus fusion to cell membranes. Here, we investigated the role of a viral receptor, Tva, in the induction of a conformational change in Env. We found that Tva binding induced the formation of a reactive thiolate on Cys38 ( Cys38-S− ) in Env. This isomer is not formed by the normal route and is not required for Tva-induced activation of Env, including pre-hairpin association with membranes and low pH assembly of helical bundles. These findings indicate that, contrary to current models, receptor activation of Env is not sufficient for ALV fusion and infection. We also show that Cys38-S− does not mediate isomerization of the SU-TM disulfide bond and is not required for Tva-induced activation of TM, including pre-hairpin association with membranes and low pH assembly of helical bundles. These findings indicate that, contrary to current models, receptor activation of TM is not sufficient for ALV fusion and infection and that formation of a reactive thiolate is an additional receptor-dependent step.

Legionella pneumophila is a pathogen that replicates inside the intracellular niche of host macrophages. It is known that L. pneumophila replicates within a specialized membrane-bound compartment known as the Legionella-containing vacuole ( LCV ). The LCV is defined as a highly protected compartment that prevents host defenses and immune responses. During infection, the metabolic pathways of L. pneumophila are rapidly reprogrammed to support replication and host survival. In this study, we found that the metabolic reprogramming of the LCV is controlled by the transcription factor MTOR. During infection, the metabolic reprogramming of the LCV is dampened by the Toll-like receptor ( TLR ) adaptor protein Myeloid differentiation primary response gene 88 ( Myd88 ), which dampens MTOR signaling. In the absence of MTOR, LCV expansion and the host cell death response are enhanced. In addition, we show that L. pneumophila has evolved to reprogram the intracellular lipid metabolism for optimal replication and host survival. Our findings provide new insights into how L. pneumophila replicates inside a host membrane-bound compartment.

Over the last decade, the number of human papillomaviruses ( HPV ) has increased dramatically, due to the continued global expansion of the virus’ range and the human population at risk. As a consequence, the need for new antiviral drugs to treat HPV infections has become more urgent. Here, we describe a novel high-throughput assay that is used to screen for small molecules that can inhibit the replication of HPV genomes in all three stages of the virus life cycle. We discovered several dozen small molecules that are able to inhibit the function of at least five cellular proteins, which have been identified as essential for HPV replication. We believe that the assay may be useful for screening for new antiviral drugs against both HPV and possibly HPV-related cancers.

Prion diseases are a group of infectious, invariably fatal, neurodegenerative diseases that affect people worldwide. A cure is still elusive, but several attempts have been unsuccessful. To be successful, a vaccine must combine elements of the host immune response and the ability of the pathogen to evade the immune system. The latter is particularly important in prion diseases, since the main difficulty is to overcome the tolerance of the host immune system to the prion protein, which is not very toxic. Unfortunately, passive antibody therapy has proven effective only during early, asymptomatic disease, before the onset of symptoms. Therefore, it is crucial to understand precisely how the immune system may overcome prion problems and which effector pathways may delay disease progression. We have developed a transgenic mouse that expresses the same receptor as the human immunodeficiency virus type I, but with only one of the two receptor chains. We show that the transgenic mice are eliminated during ontogeny, but then proliferate more extensively in a prion-infected host. We also show that, even though the immune response can be suppressed by this TCR-mediated cell-mediated pathway, partial protection may be achieved through a cell-mediated pathway involving IL-4 production. These findings support the idea that cell-mediated immunity in neurodegenerative conditions may not be necessarily detrimental and may even contribute, when properly controlled, to the resolution of pathological processes.

When a species divides into two populations, natural selection acts to preserve the fitness of the fittest individuals and eliminate deleterious mutations. When the species splits into two populations, natural selection acts to increase the frequency of beneficial mutations and to decrease the frequency of deleterious mutations. We introduce a new method to estimate the effects of natural selection on levels of genetic diversity in the genome, and we use it to infer parameters of distinct modes of selection, notably background selection and selective sweeps, from genome-wide diversity data, functional annotations, and genetic maps. This method is particularly useful when analyzing genomic regions under strong natural selection, and it allows us to distinguish between the contribution of sweeps and other modes of selection around amino acid substitutions and to uncover evidence for pervasive sweeps in untranslated regions ( UTRs ).

Inflammation, endoplasmic reticulum expansion, and misfolded proteins are common features of many human diseases, including cystic fibrosis ( CF ). We sought to test whether a stressed subcellular environment, such as a chronic inflammatory environment or a stressed cellular environment mimicking chronic CF, could affect infection efficiency by an adeno-associated virus. Using this model, we show that AAV infection was enhanced. Since AAV was an order of magnitude more efficient at transducing cells expressing ΔF508-CFTR than in cells expressing wild-type CFTR, we then explored the mechanism underlying this phenomenon. We show that AAV is able to exploit subcellular stress, and that the presence of misfolded proteins increases AAV efficacy. We also demonstrate that AAV can reach the endoplasmic reticulum and that this infection pathway is necessary for AAV to reach the microtubule organizing center and for AAV to replicate. Thus, our data support a model in which AAV exploits a compromised secretory system and that the presence of a stressed subcellular environment, under internal or external insults, can impact infection efficiency.

The spastic paraplegia associated with hereditary spastic paraplegia ( HSP ) is characterized by weakness and spasticity of the legs. It is caused by degeneration of the corticospinal axons, leading to progressive retrograde degeneration of the spinal cord. HSP is characterized by loss of midline neurons, spasticity of the legs, and weakness of the legs. Spastin is a conserved microtubule ( MT ) -severing protein, involved in processes requiring rearrangement of the cytoskeleton in concert to membrane remodeling, such as neurite branching, axonal growth, mid-body abscission, and endosome tubulation. Here, we show that spastin can sort from the endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ) to lipid droplets ( LDs ). Mutation of arginine 65 to glycine abolishes LD targeting. Increased expression of spastin reduced the number of LDs, while overexpression of Dspastin increased LD number. Downregulation of Dspastin and expression of a dominant-negative variant decreased LD number in Drosophila nerves, skeletal muscle and fat bodies, and reduced triacylglycerol levels. Moreover, we found reduced amount of fat stores in intestinal cells of worms in which the spas-1 homologue was either depleted by RNA interference or deleted. Taken together, our data uncovers an evolutionarily conserved role of spastin as a positive regulator of LD metabolism and open up the possibility that dysfunction of LDs in axons may contribute to the pathogenesis of HSP.

Feeding state and food availability can dramatically alter an animal's ability to sense chemicals in its environment. These changes are mediated by dynamic changes in the expression of chemoreceptor genes. Here, we show that the chemoreceptor gene expression profile is regulated by integration of sensory and internal feeding state signals. We also show that the insulin-like receptor and neuropeptide receptor act upstream of the chemoreceptor gene to mediate the effects of these signals on chemoreceptor gene expression. Finally, we show that the neuropeptide receptor, which is known to regulate food and glucose homeostasis, can also influence chemoreceptor gene expression via the MEF-2 ( MEF2 ) and DAF-16 ( FOXO ) transcription factors. We propose that sensing and internal feeding state signals are integrated via multiple signaling pathways to allow animals to precisely regulate and fine-tune their chemosensory responses as a function of internal and external conditions.

The human epidermal growth factor receptor ( EGFR ) signaling pathway is a known regulator of skin pigmentation, but its role in skin pigmentation is not well understood. The epidermal growth factor receptor ( EGFR ) is a transmembrane protein that is expressed in the epidermis and the dermal and mesenchymal compartments of the skin. Mutations in the human epidermal growth factor receptor ( HEGFR ) gene have been associated with a variety of skin disorders, such as skin cancer, but the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood. We have identified ADAMTS20 as a member of the HEGFR family that is required for the proper development of the epidermal growth factor receptor ( EGFR ) in the skin. We show that ADAMTS20 is required for the development of the epidermal growth factor receptor ( EGFR ) in mice, as well as in mice lacking all functional ADAMTS20. Furthermore, we show that ADAMTS20 is required for the proper development of a skin-specific cell type that is important for the pigmentation of the skin. Our findings suggest that ADAMTS20 is a novel member of the HEGFR family and provide insights into the biology of the epidermal growth factor receptor.

The process of transcription initiation is the first step of gene expression and it is not well understood. Regulation of this process allows tuning both the rate and stochasticity of RNA production. We used time-lapse, single-RNA microscopy measurements in live E. coli to study the rate-limiting steps of transcription initiation in Escherichia coli. We found that the rate limiting steps are not equal, with temperature affecting the rate of transcription initiation in the Plac/ara-1 promoter and in the PtetA promoter. Our analysis also revealed that the rate limiting step configuration is influenced by temperature, such that the rate of transcription initiation is either insensitive or reciprocally regulated by changes in the other steps. We then used the derived models to explore a possible cause for why the identified steps are preferred as the main cause for behavior modifications with temperature: we find that transcription dynamics is either insensitive or responds reciprocally to changes in the other steps. Our results suggests that different promoters employ different rate limiting step patterns that control not only their rate and variability, but also their sensitivity to environmental changes.

The [PSI+] prion is a pathogenic protein that can cause fatal neurodegenerative disease in humans and animals. [PSI+] is maintained by a special class of proteins called Hsp70s. Genetic screens using yeast have identified many Hsp70 mutants that are unable to propagate the [PSI+] prion. One of these, the Ssa1 L483W mutant, is located in the substrate-binding domain of the protein. Here we use steered molecular dynamics simulations to demonstrate that Ssa1-21 is predicted to bind substrate more avidly than wild-type DnaK. Additionally, we demonstrate that the larger tryptophan side chain is predicted to cause a conformational change in the peptide-binding domain that physically impairs substrate dissociation. Additionally, we show that the DnaK L484W variant exhibits chaperone-substrate interactions that are similar to those observed in wild-type proteins. Our computational analysis fits well with previous yeast genetics studies regarding the functionality of the Ssa1-21 protein and provides further evidence suggesting that modulation of the Hsp70 ATPase cycle to favor the ADP/substrate-bound form impairs prion propagation. Furthermore, we demonstrate how SMD can be used as a computational tool for predicting Hsp70 peptide-binding domain mutants that impede prion propagation.

Shigella are bacteria that invade intestinal epithelial cells of the intestine and cause diarrhea. Shigella uses a battery of virulence factors to subvert the intestinal epithelial defenses. The guanine nucleotide exchange factor H1 ( GEF-H1 ) is a key effector of Shigella that functions as a sensor of the intracellular environment. Surprisingly, GEF-H1 is required for the activation of the host innate immune response in response to Shigella infection. GEF-H1 interacts with the adaptor molecule NOD1 and is required for the activation of the host transcription factor NF-κB by the Shigella effectors IpgB2 and OspB. Our results demonstrate that GEF-H1 is critical for sensing the bacterial effectors during cell invasion by pathogens. This work contributes to our understanding of how Shigella subverts the intestinal epithelial cell defenses.

Stem cells are defined by their capacity to self-renew and generate progeny of multiple lineages. Stem cell characteristics are regulated by a variety of transcription factors including SOX2. SOX2 is known to bind to DNA sequences enriched in a limited number of transcription factors and to bind to specific target regions in stem cells. However, whether SOX2 regulates the same cell-type-specific transcriptional program in different types of stem cells is not known. To address this question, we performed RNA-seq and SOX2 ChIP-seq on embryonic mouse cortex, spinal cord, stomach and lung/esophagus. We demonstrate that, although SOX2 binds a similar motif in the different cell types, its target regions are primarily cell-type-specific and enriched for the distinct binding motifs of appropriately expressed interacting co-factors. Furthermore, we demonstrate that SOX2 binding in endodermal and neural stem cells is found around genes specifically expressed in the corresponding tissue. Consistently, SOX2 binding sites found in both endodermal and neural tissues are associated with genes regulating general stem cell features such as proliferation. Together, these findings demonstrate how SOX2 simultaneously regulates cell-type-specific, as well as core transcriptional programs in neural and endodermal stem cells.

Individual helminth infections are common in the tropics, with prevalence estimates as high as 90% in some areas. Co-infections with other pathogens are common, as well as the potential for host interactions. Despite this, studies of helminth infections have been predominantly studied in isolation, and there is no consensus on the extent to which co-infections and host interactions may impact host health. We performed meta-analyses of published data to determine the potential impact of co-infections and host interactions on the health of individuals with different infections. We found that co-infections are significantly more common than single infections for some parasites, and that the associated negative health effects are not dependent on the combination of pathogens. Most significant associations between parasite pairs are also positive in direction, i. e., one parasite species may influence the other. Our findings confirm that helminth infections are common in the tropics, and that a multitude of factors acting at various hierarchical levels, such as interspecies interactions at the within-host community level and environmental variables at the higher host community level, could explain the observed positive associations.

Syntrophy, or breakage of cooperation, is a phenomenon in which a microbial community as a whole survives in an environment, even though individual microbes cannot. This phenomenon arises from the accumulation of mutations that impair the viability of the community. Although an alternative possibility is that syntrophy can emerge spontaneously in communities of organisms that did not co-evolve, this undergrowth must occur through new mutations. Here, we study this alternative possibility using experimentally validated computational techniques to predict an organism’s viability from its metabolic reactions. We show that pairs of metabolisms that are randomly sampled from a large space of possible metabolism and viable on specific primary carbon sources often become viable on novel carbon sources by exchanging metabolites. The same biochemical reactions that are required for viability on primary carbon sources also confer viability on novel carbon sources. Our observations highlight a new and important avenue for the emergence of metabolic adaptations and novel ecological interactions.

The mTOR kinase is a highly conserved serine/threonine protein kinase that regulates diverse cellular functions in both developmental and physiological settings. mTOR interacts with Raptor and Rictor proteins to form two distinct complexes, termed mTORC1 and mTORC2. In this study, we investigated the role of mTORC1 and mTORC2 in cranial neural crest cells ( NCCs ), which are a type of cells that originates from the ectoderm layer and migrate to the pharyngeal arches participating craniofacial development. mTOR deletion caused a proliferation deficit and excessive apoptosis of post-migratory NCCs, leading to growth arrest of the facial primordia along with midline orofacial clefts. Furthermore, NCC differentiation was impaired. Thus, NCC derivatives, such as skeletons, vasculatures and neural tissues were either rudimentary or malformed. We further demonstrate that disruption of mTOR caused P53 hyperactivity and cell cycle arrest in cranial NCCs, and lowering P53 activity by one copy reduction attenuated the severity of craniofacial phenotype in NCC-mTOR knockout mice. Our data demonstrate that mTOR functions mediated by mTORC1 are indispensable for multiple processes of NCC development including proliferation, survival, and differentiation during craniofacial morphogenesis and organogenesis.

Autimmune diseases are a large and diverse group of diseases which have a strong genetic component. Recent genome-wide association studies have identified numerous, replicable genetic associations between common single nucleotide polymorphisms ( SNPs ) and risk of common autoimmune and inflammatory ( immune-mediated ) diseases, some of which are shared between two diseases. We propose a novel approach to identify genetic variants that are associated to multiple, but not necessarily all, immune-mediated diseases, and we show its use in seven diseases. We find evidence that 47/107 ( 44% ) immune-mediated disease risk SNPs are associated to multiple, but not all, immune-mediated diseases. We also show that distinct groups of interacting proteins are encoded near SNPs which predispose to the same subsets of diseases; we propose these as the mechanistic basis of shared disease risk.

Integrin transmembrane receptors are crucial for many cellular functions. They are composed of two transmembrane and an α-subunit, which are held together by β-subunits. Integrin receptors transmit signals from the extracellular environment into the cell interior. Their function is regulated by an integrin activation mechanism, which involves the assembly of the hetero-dimeric transmembrane integrin α-subunit. We have investigated, for the first time, how the integrin structure influences its interaction with its ligands and the subsequent signaling pathway. Our results suggest that the β-subunit, which is responsible for the interaction of the α-subunit with the transmembrane integrin, is merely responsible for the transmembrane-cytoplasmic domain interaction, and that the α-subunit is merely responsible for the interaction with the transmembrane-cytoplasmic domain. We also investigated how the interaction of the β-subunit with the transmembrane integrin influences its structure and dynamics. The results show that if the transmembrane integrin is already activated, it may not be able to transmit the signal to the cytoplasmic domain, which may instead regulate its interaction with the transmembrane-cytoplasmic domain.

KSHV lytic infection produces PAN RNA, a highly abundant noncoding polyadenylated transcript that is retained in the nucleus. We recently demonstrated that PAN RNA can bind to several viral and cellular factors and can deregulate the expression of genes that modulate immune response. In an effort to define the role of PAN RNA in the context of the virus genome we generated a recombinant BACmid that delets the PAN RNA locus. This deletion causes the loss of the duplicated PAN RNA locus, which we used as a template to generate a recombinant BAC36ΔPAN. BAC36ΔPAN failed to produce supernatant virus and displayed a general decrease in mRNA accumulation of representative immediate early, early and late genes. K-Rta expression was decreased in lytically induced BAC36ΔPAN-containing cell lines at early and late time points post induction. Expression of PAN RNA in trans in BAC36ΔPAN containing cells resulted in an increase in K-Rta expression, however K-Rta over expression failed to rescue BAC36ΔPAN, suggesting that PAN RNA plays a wider role in virus replication. Consistent with the interaction with demethylases, PAN RNA interacts with demethylases JMJD3 and UTX, and the histone methyltransferase MLL2. Our data support a model where PAN RNA is a multifunctional regulatory transcript that controls KSHV gene expression by mediating the modification of chromatin by targeting the KSHV repressed genome.

How do individual genes coordinately regulate their expression? Understanding this phenomenon is important for the design of genetic programs that drive development. While a large body of work has focused on the molecular mechanisms by which transcription factors and their cofactors interact to control the expression of a gene, relatively little is known about how combinatorial binding drives the expression of a gene. Here, we use the Drosophila myogenic network to assess the role of combinatorial binding in the control of two essential transcription factors. Mef2 and lmd are two members of the Drosophila TGFβ family, whose activity is required for proper myoblast fusion. We show that the majority of Lmd bound enhancers are co-bound by Mef2, representing a subset of Mef2's transcriptional input during development. Expression profiling of loss-of-function mutants reveals that both Mef2 and lmd have divergent regulatory roles despite their shared transcriptional input. Systematic analyses of the regulatory contribution of both factors demonstrate that Lmd is a tissue-specific modulator of Mef2 activity. Our results indicate that Lmd has important implications for the development of the myoblast, and also demonstrate considerable flexibility in the regulatory output of these two transcription factors.

Information processing in the nervous system during sensorimotor tasks with inherent uncertainty has been shown to be consistent with Bayesian integration. However, there is a lack of quantitative evidence that supports this conclusion. Here we show that subjects exhibit Bayesian information integration when they infer the position of a target from noisy sensory feedback. This result is in accordance with risk-sensitive decision-making processes that allow for deviations from Bayes optimal decision-making in the face of uncertainty. Our results suggest that both Bayesian integration and risk-sensitivity are important factors to understand sensorimotor integration in a quantitative fashion.

In fungi, unisexual reproduction occurs when mating type alleles do not always complement each other, but can be used for gametes to develop into fertile products such as spores or spores. The frequency of unisexual reproduction and its impact on genome evolution has been well studied in several species, including the important human fungal pathogens Candida albicans and Cryptococcus neoformans. However, detailed quantifications of unisexual reproduction are still lacking, especially when it involves the two compatible mating type alleles. Here, we analyzed meiotic recombination during unisexual reproduction and a-α bisexual reproduction in the human fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans. We found that, like in a-α bisexual reproduction, meiotic recombination operates in a similar fashion during both sexual reproduction modes. Specifically, we observed that in both modes, meiotic recombination frequencies are similar between the two, and also between the two, and that this similarity is reflected by the fact that the number of crossovers along chromosomes, as well as recombination hotspots, are all similar to those observed during a-α bisexual reproduction. We also observed diploid progeny at similar frequencies in both modes, and transient chromosomal loss and duplication likely occur frequently and results in aneuploidy and loss of heterozygosity that can span entire chromosomes. Additionally, we observed biased allele inheritance in regions on chromosome 4, suggesting the presence of fragile chromosomal regions that might be vulnerable to mitotic recombination. Our results provide definitive evidence that α-α unisexual reproduction is a meiotic process similar to that observed during a-α bisexual reproduction.

Influenza B virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and it is a major public health concern for the United States. The virus replicates to high titers in human and animal cells, and a critical step during this process is the formation of an infectious virus particle. Influenza B virus encodes a protein, NS1, that blocks the replication of the viral genome and is therefore a major virus blocking factor. Activation of the influenza B virus latent kinase PKR is an important innate defense mechanism that vertebrates employ to protect themselves from viral infection, and a better understanding of this process may help us to develop new antiviral strategies. We have found that the viral RNA-binding protein NS1 can directly activate the antiviral kinase PKR. This interaction is unique to the NS1 protein, and we have also found that the viral RNA-binding domain of NS1 is required for activation of PKR. We have also shown that the antiviral kinase PKR is activated by viral RNA-binding proteins and that this activation is important for antiviral function of influenza B virus. Collectively, our study provides new insights into an important antiviral defense mechanism of vertebrates and suggests a new model of PKR activation by cytosolic RNA-binding proteins, a model which may also be applicable to other negative strand RNA viruses.

Zika virus ( ZIKV ) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes severe symptoms in humans. ZIKV infection in adults is associated with fetal malformations and newborn microcephaly. The possibility of perinatal transmission of ZIKV from infected mothers to their children has been heavily debated, and recent data indicate that transmission from infected mothers to their children occurs through the perinatal route. We reviewed the literature to assess whether women with ZIKV infection are exposed to ZIKV in their milk. We found that ZIKV was detected in all three lactating women, and that this detection was associated with the presence of ZIKV infection in their milk. We also found evidence of ZIKV infection in the milk of two women who were infected with ZIKV at three times in their lifecycles. This is the first systematic review to describe the presence of ZIKV in the milk of infected mothers. While ZIKV was detected in the milk of all three women, the data are not sufficient to conclude ZIKV transmission via breastfeeding.

The spore-forming bacterium Bacillus subtilis, the most prevalent foodborne pathogen, is capable of converting to a dormant, non-dividing state upon growth arrest.
