This process is governed by a phosphorelay that controls the expression of the spor0a gene, which encodes a master regulator of stationary phase development. We have monitored the rate of transcription of the Spo0A gene during growth in sporulation medium using promoter fusions to firefly luciferase. This rate increases sharply during transient diauxie-like pauses in growth rate and then declines as growth resumes. The growth pause-dependent bursts of Spo0A transcription reflect the activity of the Spo0A vegetative promoter, and we propose that they represent initial responses to stress that bring the average cell closer to the thresholds for transition to bimodally expressed developmental responses. Measurement of the numbers of cells expressing a competence marker before and after the bursts supports this hypothesis. Our data contradicts the hypothesis that sporulation is initiated when a ppGpp-induced decline in GTP pool relieves repression by CodY. We suggest that, while the programmed induction of sporulation that occurs in stationary phase is apparently provoked by increased flux through the phosphorelay, bet-hedging stochastic transitions to at least competence are induced by bursts in transcription.

During development, a specialized cell type called mesoderm gives rise to many different cell types, including the skeletal muscle cells that will later form skeletal muscles. To make these cells, mesoderm cells must divide and then differentiate into a specific cell type, which is achieved by controlling the expression of a small number of genes, which are then activated by transcription factors in a complex manner. It is not known how these genes are activated, or what role the transcription factors play in activating these genes. We used a cell-based system to study the role of the transcription factor Pax3 in activating a subset of genes in mesoderm cells. We identified that Pax3 activates skeletal myogenic commitment factors and that it does this by controlling the accessibility of DNA to transcription factors. Our work provides the first analysis of how Pax3 functions, and the first evidence that this function involves remodulating DNA accessibility.

UV exposure activates the innate immune system, which controls the growth and survival of infected cells. UV induced melanoma is the most common form of skin cancer worldwide, and an increasing number of cases in recent years. We have found that, in mice, UV exposure induces the loss of RXRs in dermal melanocytes, leading to altered expression of pro- and anti-apoptotic genes and decreased survival of surrounding dermal fibroblasts. This effect is independent of RXR-mediated activation of the innate immune system. Moreover, RXRs specifically mediate survival of dermal fibroblasts in a “non-cell autonomous” manner, without altering the growth and survival of neighboring cells. Our results identify RXRs as novel mediators of immune surveillance in mice, and suggest that RXRs may represent novel therapeutic targets against UV-induced skin cancer.

This paper reports on the results of the five yearly rounds of vaccination in India against Kyasanur Forest Disease ( KFD ). The vaccine, formalin-inactivated tissue-culture vaccine, is used to vaccinate all eligible individuals aged 7–65 years. In the study area, we collected data on the incidence of KFD and the vaccine effectiveness. We found that the vaccine effectiveness was only 62. 4% and the risk was 0. 38 and 0. 17 respectively. Our results show that the vaccine effectiveness was only 62. 4% and the risk was 0. 38 and the risk was 0. 17. We recommend that the incidence of KFD should be reduced to the minimum possible level.

Microdomains, which emerge from the spatial confinement of neurons, play a central role in neuronal computations. In particular, microdomains are involved in clustered synaptic plasticity and efficient information transfer. Dendritic voltage-gated ion channels are known to be important for microdomain propagation, but it is not known if these channels regulate the spatiotemporal spread of microdomains. We employed a multiscale, morphologically realistic, conductance-based model of the hippocampal pyramidal neuron that accounted for experimental details of calcium-dependent signaling. We activated N-Methyl-d-Aspartate receptors through threshold-burst stimulation ( TBS ) or pairing ( TBP ), and assessed microdomain propagation along a signaling pathway that included calmodulin, calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II ( CaMKII ) and protein phosphatase 1. We found that the spatiotemporal spread of the TBS-evoked microdomain in phosphorylated CaMKII was amplified by CaMKII. Next, we assessed the role of two dendritically expressed inactivating channels, one that suppressed the spread of pCaMKII microdomains by inhibiting the calcium influx without changing the voltage response to TBS, and another that enhanced this spread by modulating TBS-induced calcium influx without changing the voltage. Our results reveal that CaMKII amplification or suppression depends critically on dendritic voltage-gated ion channels and on the biochemical properties of microdomains. Our conclusions therefore have important implications for several synaptic plasticity and information transfer mechanisms.

In vaccinia virus, the vaccine used to eradicate smallpox, a virus that was responsible for the most devastating outbreak ever, the viral protein A49 is a 50 kDa protein that is able to bind to and inhibit the activity of the E3 ubiquitin ligase β-TrCP. This inhibition prevents ubiquitination and degradation of the NF-κBα subunit, which is a key factor for initiating an immune response against pathogens. Here we describe an inhibitor of NF-κB from vaccinia virus, a pathogen that causes smallpox, which is closely related to the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV ) and has a very similar biochemical structure to the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) NF-κBα. A VACV lacking A49 showed reduced virulence in vivo. We describe the mechanism of A49-mediated inhibition of NF-κB activation, which is essential for host defence against pathogens, and we demonstrate that it is the same mechanism used by A49 to inhibit the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) NF-κBα. This suggests that the ability of A49 to inhibit NF-κB activation is a common feature of its inhibition of HIV-1 NF-κBα.

The brain of anesthetized mice requires the coordinated activity of two different neuronal networks to ensure the survival of the animal and the proper transmission of sensory information to the brain. The olfactory bulb ( OB ) is a critical organ in this process, as it is the key to the detection of odor molecules by the mouse. In this study, we investigated the functional principles underlying the communication between the OB and the lateral entorhinal cortex ( LEC ) during the development of the mouse. Our results show that the mature maturation of the OB–LEC circuit depends on the presence of highly synchronous and prolonged electrical activity. Interestingly, the activity of the OB is gated by a special type of neurons in the LEC. This novel activity is dependent on the presence of a threshold concentration of odor molecules in the LEC, and the absence of odor is sufficient to elicit electrical activity in the OB. Chronic impairment of the maturation of the OB results in a loss of this electrical activity and leads to impaired odor detection. Our results highlight the importance of the maturation of the OB–LEC circuit and provide a novel mechanism for the regulation of odor detection by the mouse olfactory bulb.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) is the causative agent of tuberculosis ( TB ). This bacterium replicates inside macrophages, and escapes the cell cycle arrest by replicative stress-induced cell death. Mtb is known to manipulate macrophages to activate inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-1β and TNF-α, that are critical for the clearance of the bacteria. This activation is accompanied by upregulation of the transcription factor KLF4. In this work, we report that the microRNA-26a ( miR-26a ) and its target KLF4 are involved in regulation of macrophages inflammatory cytokine production. We show that both downregulation of miR-26a and upregulation of KLF4 facilitate upregulation of IL-1β and TNF-α, and thus promotes the activation of host signaling pathways. Furthermore, we show that the CREB-C/EBPβ signaling axis also favors M2 polarization. These results suggest that the miR-26a-mediated regulation of KLF4 and the CREB-C/EBPβ signaling axis, which is known to be involved in M2 polarization, is crucial for the regulation of macrophages inflammatory cytokine production.

Visceral leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease that affects more than 12 million people worldwide and is caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. The disease is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected sand fly, and is considered a disease of the poor. The control of the disease is based on the use of drugs. Until now, there is no vaccine available to prevent the infection. This work aimed at the evaluation of a new family of Leishmania antigenic proteins, the LiPABP proteins. Three members of this family have been described. Recombinant proteins were used for the coating of ELISA plates. The results obtained show that the three LiPABP proteins induce a Th1-like response and confer partial protection against Leishmania major infection in a mouse model. This partial protection was able to down-regulate the IL-10 mediated responses elicited by the three LiPABP proteins after infection in this mouse model. This modulation induced a partial protection against L. major infection. This partial protection was also accompanied by a decrease in parasite burdens, in antibody titers against Leishmania antigens and in the IL-4 and IL-10 parasite-specific mediated responses in comparison to control mice groups.

HAI-1 and HAI-2 are evolutionarily conserved proteins that regulate the development of the hepatocyte growth factor pathway. Inactivation of either HAI-1 or HAI-2 causes embryonic lethality in mice, which can be rescued by the simultaneous inactivation of the membrane-anchored serine protease, matriptase, thereby demonstrating that a matriptase-dependent proteolytic pathway is a critical developmental target for both protease inhibitors. Here, we used genetic epistasis analyses to identify additional components of this pathway by screening for genes that encode developmentally co-expressed candidate matriptase targets, and found that prostasin, the GPI-anchored serine protease, is critical for the activity of matriptase. Furthermore, we generated mice lacking the c-Met, PAR-2, and ENaC subunits, which were previously shown to be critical for matriptase activation, and found that matriptase activity is not required for the development of placental tissues. Our results suggest that the protease may not be critical for focal proteolytic activation of PAR-2 during neural tube closure. Finally, our results demonstrate that prostasin is required for conversion of the matriptase zymogen to active matriptase, whereas prostasin activation is matriptase-independent.

Chagas' disease is an important public health concern in Latin America. Despite intensive vector control efforts using insecticide chemicals, the elimination of Triatoma infestans has failed in the Gran Chaco region of Argentina, Paraguay, Bolivia and Brazil. The voltage-gated sodium channel is the target site of pyrethroid insecticides. In this paper, we report the identification and characterization of L925I, a new pyrethroid resistance-conferring mutation in T. infestans. The results indicate that the L925I mutation is found only in hemipterans. In T. infestans, L925I mutation occurs in a resistant population from the Gran Chaco region and is associated with inefficiency in the control campaigns. We also describe a method to detect L925I mutation in individuals from the field. The findings have important implications in the implementation of strategies for resistance management and in the rational design of campaigns for the control of Chagas' disease transmission.

Successful interaction with the environment requires flexible updating of our beliefs about the world. This can be achieved by different neuromodulators such as noradrenaline, acetylcholine, and dopamine. The precise nature of the effects of these drugs is not well understood, and it is unclear how different types of effects may be distinguished. Here we present a unified computational framework that links these three neuromodulators to a common type of uncertainty, namely the uncertainty of future events. We show that pharmacological manipulations of noradrenergic, cholinergic, and dopaminergic receptors can either slow or speed the processing of uncertainty. These effects depend on the type of experiment performed, and are not mutually exclusive. Using a computational model of uncertainty, we show that dopamine, but not noradrenergic and acetylcholine, is required for learning of uncertainty arising from unexpected changes in the environment. In contrast, noradrenergic and acetylcholine work together to enable fast, adaptive responses.

Legionella pneumophila ( L. pneumophila ) is a Gram-negative intracellular bacterium that replicates in human macrophages. It can cause severe pneumonia and is the causative agent of Legionnaires' disease. L. pneumophila replicates in macrophages in a process termed “infection”. In addition, L. pneumophila induces apoptosis in macrophages. The latter is a crucial host defense mechanism that protects macrophages from L. pneumophila infection. Recent in vitro experiments demonstrate that the enzyme caspase-1 is cleaved by the enzyme caspase-7. However, the biological role of caspase-7 activation downstream of the caspase-1 inflammasome is not known. Using the intracellular pathogen L. pneumophila, we show that, upon infection of macrophages, caspase-7 was activated downstream of the Nlrc4 inflammasome. Activation of caspase-7 was mediated by flagellin and required a functional Naip5. Such activation of caspase-7 was mediated by flagellin and required a functional Naip5. Remarkably, mice lacking caspase-7 and their macrophages allowed substantial L. pneumophila replication. Permissiveness of caspase-7−/− macrophages to the intracellular pathogen was due to defective delivery of the organism to the lysosome and to delayed cell death during early stages of infection. These results reveal a new mechanism for caspase-7 activation downstream of the Nlrc4 inflammasome and present a novel biological role for caspase-7 in host defense against an intracellular bacterium.

Dengue is a viral disease transmitted by mosquitoes. It is a significant public health problem in most of the world's countries. The economic and disease burden of dengue is not well quantified, but it is important for setting policy priorities and disease-control strategies. In this study, we estimated the economic and disease burden of dengue in 12 countries in Southeast Asia ( SEA ). We obtained reported cases from multiple sources—surveillance data, World Health Organization ( WHO ), and published studies—and adjusted for underreporting using expansion factors from previous literature. We also excluded costs such as prevention and vector control, and long-term sequelae of dengue. Over the decade of 2001–2010, we obtained an annual average of 2. 9 million ( m ) dengue episodes and 5, 906 deaths. The annual economic burden ( with 95% certainty levels ) was US$950m ( US$610m–US$1, 384m ) or about US$1. 65 ( US$1. 06–US$2. 41 ) per capita. The annual number of disability-adjusted life years ( DALYs ), based on the original 1994 definition, was 214, 000 ( 120, 000–299, 000 ), which is equivalent to 372 ( 210–520 ) DALYs per million inhabitants. Dengue poses a substantial economic and disease burden in SEA with a DALY burden per million inhabitants in the region. This burden is higher than that of 17 other conditions, including Japanese encephalitis, upper respiratory infections, and hepatitis B.

A variety of models are currently accepted regarding the way in which genome amplification is achieved. According to the classic model, the product of amplification is usually part of a linear or direct repeated sequence. According to the second model, the product of amplification is usually part of a genomic segment formed by a repeated sequence. In this work, we provide evidence that the Leishmania genome is continuously being rearranged at the level of these repeated sequences, which serve as a functional platform for constitutive and stochastic amplification. This process is adaptive as the copy number of advantageous extrachromosomal circular or linear elements increases upon selective pressure and is reversible when selection is removed. We also provide mechanistic insights on the formation of circular and linear amplicons through RAD51 recombinase-dependent and -independent mechanisms, respectively. The whole genome of Leishmania is thus stochastically rearranged at the level of these repeated sequences, and the selection of parasite subpopulations with changes in the copy number of specific loci is used as a strategy to respond to a changing environment.

Red blood cells are formed from immature progenitors during the maturation process, which requires the presence of an intricate cell-cell communication system. Here, we present a computational model to analyze the complex network of signaling interactions that control the maturation process. The model reproduces the developmental process of red blood cell formation and the endowment of mature red blood cells to give rise to mature mature red blood cells. We then use this model to analyze the role of negative autoregulatory feedback loops in the control of the developmental process. Our results show that the autoregulatory interactions between the death receptor FAS and the cell cycle regulator FASL are essential for the normal control of red blood cell development.

Transmission of influenza virus between hosts is a critical part of the viral lifecycle. Recent studies have used genome sequence data to evaluate the number of particles transmitted between hosts, and the role of selection as it operates during the transmission process. However, the interpretation of sequence data describing transmission events is a challenging task. We here present a novel and comprehensive framework for using short-read sequence data to understand viral transmission events, designed for influenza virus, but adaptable to other viral species. Our approach solves several shortcomings of previous methods for this purpose. We consider transmission as an event involving whole viruses, rather than isolated viral particles, rather than independent viral alleles. We demonstrate how selection during transmission and noisy sequence data may each affect inferences of the population bottleneck, accounting for these in our framework so as to achieve a correct inference. We identify circumstances in which selection for increased viral transmission may or may not be identified from data, and apply our method to experimental data in which transmission occurs in the presence of strong selection, showing that our framework provides more quantitative insight into transmission events than previous approaches. Our work provides new opportunities for studying transmission processes in influenza, and by extension, in other infectious diseases.

The ability to rapidly change flight trajectory under different conditions is essential for animal survival. However, it is still unclear how animals transform noisy sensory information into appropriate movement commands. Here we developed a simple neural network model of animal flight that explains why flying bats can fly differently in different conditions. We show that the model predicts trajectories in light and dark with high fidelity. In particular, the model explains why bats can change flight curves dramatically by changing the direction of movement. These results suggest a surprising link between sensory noise and movement dynamics. This work is the first to show that a sensory-motor control model is fundamental to motion control in flying animals.

Leishmania braziliensis is the major etiological agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ) in Latin America, and is associated with a high phenotypic and possibly genetic diversity that need to be more adequately defined. Here, we used whole genome sequences to evaluate the genetic diversity of ten L. braziliensis isolates from a CL endemic area from Northeastern Brazil, previously classified by Multi Locus Enzyme Electrophoresis ( MLEE ) into ten distinct zymodemes. Our results revealed a substantial level of diversity, with SNP counts ranging from ~95, 000 to ~131, 000. When the genome data were used to infer relationship between isolates, those belonging to zymodemes Z72/Z75, recovered from forested environments, were found to cluster separately from the others, generally associated with more urban environments. Among the remaining isolates, those from zymodemes Z74/Z106 were also found to form a separate group. Phylogenetic analyses were also performed using Multi-Locus Sequence Analysis ( MLEE ) from genes coding for four metabolic enzymes used for MLEE and the gene sequence coding for the Hsp70 heat shock protein. All 10 isolates were firmly identified as L. braziliensis, including the zymodeme Z26 isolate previously classified as Leishmania shawi, with the clustering into three groups confirmed. Aneuploidy was also investigated but found in general restricted to chromosome 31, with a single isolate, from zymodeme Z27, characterized by extra copies for other chromosomes. Our data is consistent with the existence of distinct evolutionary groups in the restricted area sampled and a substantial genetic diversity within L. braziliensis.

Two main approaches have been applied to explore causal relationships in biological systems using time-series data. The first approach involves the application of Dynamic Causal model and the second approach involves the application of Granger Causal model. While each approach has been extensively applied to brain imaging data, there has been little attempt to compare them. In this study, we have developed a novel approach which is an extension of Granger Causal model and shares the features of the bilinear approximation of Dynamic Causal model. We have applied this extended Granger Causal model to local field potential data from in vivo multi-electrode array experiments and have found that face discrimination learning-induced changes in inter- and intra-hemispheric connectivity and in the hemispheric predominance of theta and gamma frequency oscillations in sheep inferotemporal cortex. The results provide the first evidence for connectivity changes between and within separate inferotemporal cortexes as a result of face recognition learning.

Trypanosoma cruzi is the protozoan parasite responsible for Chagas disease, a serious health problem in Latin America. T. cruzi is transmitted by insects and the human population is at risk of infection. There is a great diversity of T. cruzi strains, named TcI-TcVI. In the Brazilian Amazon, the T. cruzi stocks TcI and TcIV are associated with different disease symptoms, which can be attributed to the genetic and biological characteristics of the circulating T. cruzi stocks. T. cruzi stocks from Brazilian Amazon are different from TcI and TcIV from other areas of the world. Here we report the biological and medical characteristics of T. cruzi stocks from Brazilian Amazon. Our results showed that TcI and TcIV stocks from Brazilian Amazon are different in terms of biological and medical properties in mice. In particular, TcI and TcIV stocks from Brazilian Amazon are different in terms of the duration of the pre-patent period and the onset of the chronic phase, which is associated with a lower mortality rate and a higher frequency of mice with inflammatory process and tissue parasitism.

Many organisms have evolved a mechanism to defend against genetic changes. For example, bacteria form biofilms and organisms with cancer cells can survive radiation radiation and mutagens such as UV irradiation. In addition, organisms are able to generate genetic variation even in environments that are rich in mutation. However, the ability to generate genetic variation has been shown to be a limiting factor in many traits, such as resistance to antibiotics and the ability to survive toxic chemicals. We used the yeast S. cerevisiae to investigate how a mutation could affect its ability to grow in various environments. We exposed the yeast to increasing doses of the mutagenic chemicals to different environments and found that the extent of immediate mortality varied. Surprisingly, the ability to grow well in these environments was correlated with high expression of genes involved in the oxidative energy metabolism. Our results suggest that the negative effect of mutations can be buffered if enough energy is available.

In plants, life history differences dictate how long plants live and how long they flower. In the case of Arabis thaliana, the life cycle is divided into two phases, annual and perennial, during which the life history is markedly different. Annual plants flower for only a limited period before they return to vegetative growth. In contrast, plants that never flower, like Arabis alpina, live for many years, continuously cycling through the life cycle. We have found that natural genetic variation in the Arabidopsis thaliana PEP1 gene influences the life cycle of A. alpina. PEP1 is a MADS-box transcription factor that is known to be involved in regulating flowering. We find that natural variation in PEP1 in A. alpina is distinct from that in A. thaliana, which has resulted in two PEP1 transcripts that are differentially expressed. We also find that in most natural A. alpina accessions, including Pajares, the PEP1 locus contains a tandem arrangement of a full-length and a partial PEP1 copy, which gives rise to two full-length transcripts that are differentially expressed. Our results provide a paradigm for how characteristic phenotypic variation might arise in plants.

Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ) is an alphavirus responsible for numerous epidemics throughout Africa and Asia, causing infectious arthritis and reportedly linked with fatal infections in newborns and elderly. Despite the potential efficacy of B-cell-driven intervention strategies, there are no virus-specific vaccines or therapies currently available. In addition, CHIKV has been reported to elicit long-lasting virus-specific antibodies in humans, and to establish long-term persistence in non-human primates, suggesting that the virus might evade immune defenses to establish chronic infections in man. However, the mechanisms of immune evasion potentially employed by CHIKV remain uncharacterized. Here, we have characterized two human monoclonal antibodies that potently neutralize CHIKV infection. Furthermore, for the first time, we have demonstrated direct cell-to-cell transmission as a mechanism that involves the E2 domain A and that is associated with viral resistance to antibody-mediated neutralization. Identification of sub-domains that are associated with human protective immunity, will pave the way for the development of CHIKV-specific sub-domain vaccination strategies. Moreover, the clear demonstration of CHIKV cell-to-cell transmission and its possible role in the establishment of CHIKV persistence, will also inform the development of future anti-viral interventions.

Visual information is compressed or expanded in grid cells of the medial entorhinal cortex. The precise nature of this compression is not well understood. Here, we present a model for differences in the response of grid cells to visual cues. We show that different mechanisms may underlie differences in the properties of visual cues that are used by different grid cell modules.

During gametogenesis, the oocyte nucleus is reprogrammed to contain a CCAAT-box containing DNA methyltransferase ( DNMT1 ). This reprogramming is critical for maintaining the methylation of cytosine at CG sites in the genome and is important for regulating the gene expression. In somatic cells, UHRF1, a maintenance methyltransferase, is responsible for reprogramming the CCAAT box-containing DNA to maintain the methylation. However, it was not known whether UHRF1 is also important for the maintenance of methylation in oocytes. To address this question, we studied the role of UHRF1 in oocytes and preimplantation embryos. We discovered that UHRF1 is localized in the cytoplasm of oocytes and preimplantation embryos. UHRF1 was also found to be important for de novo DNA methylation in oocytes and to be important for the maintenance of methylation in preimplantation embryos. Our study suggests that UHRF1 plays a critical role in reprogramming the CCAAT box-containing DNA to maintain the methylation of cytosine in oocytes and preimplantation embryos.

Plague is a disease that has a deadly impact in humans and animals. It is transmitted by fleas. The fleas are living in human habitations, and they are therefore able to spread the disease to other humans. In Madagascar, this disease is mostly transmitted by the fleas Xenopsylla cheopis and is responsible for 20, 000 deaths per year. Insecticide spraying is one of the control measures used to control the disease, but the effectiveness of this method varies amongst populations. In this study we tested the susceptibility of the main plague vector, X. cheopis, to 12 different insecticides. Our results showed that all insecticides are effective against the flea populations, but only one of them, dieldrin, is efficient against the others. Insecticide resistance is a concern and we suspect it may affect the effectiveness of the insecticides in the region. We propose at least three alternative insecticides to replace dieldrin during plague epidemic responses, but the most efficient insecticide may be different for each population studied. We highlight the importance of continuous insecticide susceptibility surveillance in the areas of high plague risk in Madagascar.

Chromatin organization is a complex, multi-scale feature, with topological associating domains ( TADs ) as the physical building blocks of chromatin. The relation between chromatin organization and gene regulation is a subject of much research, but the nature of the relationship remains poorly understood. To study the role of chromatin organization in gene regulation, we introduce a novel method to construct a bead-spring model based on the experimental data from chromosomal capture. The model permits exploring transient properties constrained by the statistics of the data. We proceed in two steps: first, we introduce a minimal number of random connectors inside restricted regions to account for the observed blocks of TADs. Second, we account for long-range specific genomic interactions. Using the constructed polymer, we find a large variability of the anomalous exponent, used to interpret live cell imaging trajectories. The present work provides a generic tool to study the steady-state and transient properties of chromatin constrained by some physical properties embedded in 5C data.

The X chromosome is a large segment of the genome that is inactivated in the gametes, the precursor cells for sexual reproduction. During the primordial germ cell ( PGC ) stage, epigenetic reprogramming occurs, including reactivation of the X chromosome and the erasure of genomic imprinting. It is well known that the X reactivation occurs over a prolonged period of time, but the exact timing is still unknown. Here, we show that the X reactivation in nascent PGCs takes place in a cell-type–specific manner. We also show that the X reactivation process does not occur in the absence of a known transcription factor. These results set the reactivation timing much earlier than previously thought and suggest that X reactivation may involve slow passive steps.

Eukaryotic DNA is packaged into chromatin structure through the complex formation of nucleosomes, which are the building blocks of chromatin. The compaction of DNA is tightly regulated to ensure efficient transcription and to maintain genome stability. Chromatin structure and dynamics are also tightly regulated by various factors, but the specific link between the structural and functional state of chromatin remains poorly understood. Imitation SWI ( ISWI ) is a chromatin remodeling factor that is implicated in a variety of processes, including transcriptional regulation. Imitation is a member of the ATP-dependent chromatin-remodeling complex, and its function is largely mediated through histone modifications. Recent studies have also implicated ISWI in the regulation of higher-order chromatin structure, but its role in this process remains poorly understood. Here we show that ISWI plays a global role in chromatin structure and dynamics by promoting the association of the linker histone H1 with chromatin. Our results suggest that ISWI plays a key role in chromatin structure and dynamics by promoting the association of H1 with chromatin.

New World alphaviruses, including Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus ( VEEV ), have caused major outbreaks in humans and equids, and have become significant causes of morbidity and mortality in humans and horses. VEEV is the most widely distributed arbovirus in the world and causes an estimated 40, 000 human infections annually. VEEV capsid structural protein, CRM1, is a major target of the host nuclear transport proteins importin α/β1 and CRM1. Novel selective inhibitor of nuclear export ( SINE ) compounds, KPT-185, KPT-335, and KPT-350, target the host’s primary nuclear export protein, CRM1, in a manner similar to the archetypical inhibitor Leptomycin B. We found that SINE compounds had no effect on VEEV TC83_Cm, which encodes a mutated form of capsid that is unable to enter the nucleus. Serially passaging VEEV in the presence of KPT-185 resulted in mutations within the nuclear localization and nuclear export signals of capsid. Finally, SINE compound treatment also reduced the viral titers of the related eastern and western equine encephalitis viruses, suggesting that CRM1 maintains a common interaction with capsid proteins across the New World alphavirus genus.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ) is a parasitic disease transmitted to humans by sand flies. Cutaneous leishmaniasis is a neglected disease that affects millions of people worldwide and it is of particular interest in countries such as Brazil, where the disease is also present in the Amazon region. The Peruvian region of Madre de Dios is one of the most endemic regions in South America, being located near the border with Brazil. In this study, we aimed to characterize the sand fly fauna in this endemic setting and to identify sand fly species potentially involved in transmission of Leishmania parasites. We collected sand fly samples from 2014 and 2015 in the communities of Flor de Acre, Mavila, Nifurtu and Arca Pacahuara, Peru. We identified 10, 897 sand fly species belonging to the genus Lutzomyia ( 58 species ) and Brumptomyia ( 2 species ). The most abundant sand fly species was Lu. yucumensis ( 14 species ). Based on our results, we propose that Lutzomyia ( Trichophoromyia ) spp., Lu. whitmani, Lu. walkeri, Lu. ( Trichophoromyia ) spp. and Lu. LLN are the most abundant sand fly species in Madre de Dios, and that differences in sand fly abundance and species composition may explain the high prevalence of CL cases in this region.

Gene expression is a complex phenotype, determined by many genes interacting in an individual genome, and can be predicted from genome sequence. While many studies have focused on gene expression variation across populations, relatively little is known about the genetic architecture of gene expression variation within populations. In this study, we used expression quantitative trait loci ( eQTL ) mapping in 233 Atherosclerosis subjects from diverse European-, Hispanic-, and African American origins to identify the genetic architecture of gene expression. We found that the genetic architecture of gene expression is determined by ancestry proportions across populations, and that the best gene predicted by ancestry proportions is similar across populations. However, the best gene predicted in each population is a subset of genes that are well-predicted in one population but poorly predicted in another. Our study demonstrates the need to use diverse population sampling to better understand the genetic architecture of complex traits.

The binding of bacteria to mammalian cells is an important mechanism in many infections. Many bacterial adhesins are tethered to the cell surface by a molecular bridge that connects them to the cytoskeleton. The tension generated by this bridge is called tensile force and is a major force determining the binding affinity. In this study, we use the fimbrial tip of type 1 fimbriae of Escherichia coli, which is the most commonly found bacterial adhesin in the human intestine, to demonstrate that the adhesin is able to sense tensile force and to force the tip extension and anchoring the bacteria to the cell surface. We show that the tip has two distinct functions: to act as a spring-like force sensor and to explore the interior of the protein in molecular detail. Comparison with related structures suggests that the property of the fimbrial tip is common among adhesins in bacteria and eukaryotes, and that the force sensing property is a common function of the adhesin core.

The leishmaniases are a group of diseases caused by the protozoan parasites Leishmania infantum and L. major. The third major problem in leishmaniases is the control of persistent infections. As a part of the innate immune system, natural antimicrobial peptides have a potential to be used as new generation of antibiotics especially after persistent resistance of conventional antimicrobial agents. Brevinin 2R, a member of Defensin families of host defense peptides, showed promising effects against bacterial and fungal infections as well as cancerous cell lines. In this work, the anti-leishmanial effect of Brevinin 2R and its lauric acid conjugate was investigated against Leishmania major ( L. major ) parasite. The data revealed that, conjugation of fatty acid to Brevinin 2R, strengthen its effect on L. major promastigotes as well as toxicity and hemolytic effect. No signs of apoptosis induction or caspase activation were detected. Despite its hemolytic and cytotoxic effect in in vitro conditions, lauric acid- Brevinin 2R ( L- Brevinin 2R ) did not show site specific adverse reactions in animal model. Treatment course with L- Brevinin 2R in the L. major infected mice exhibited decreased parasite load in the lymph nodes adjacent to the infected site despite cytokine production profile and footpad swelling data.

Learning and memory are central to human cognition. A popular model of learning is the persistent activity-dependent theory which postulates that learning is maintained by modifications of synapses that are induced by specific patterns of pre- and postsynaptic activity. The persistence theory assumes that the activity in the brain is taken up by synapses in such a way that, at any time in the past, the synapses can be modified to be active. In this paper, we investigate the time scales of memory maintenance in a calcium-based synaptic plasticity model that has been shown recently to be able to fit different experimental data-sets from hippocampal and neocortical preparations. We find that in the presence of background activity on the order of 1 Hz parameters that fit pyramidal layer 5 neocortical data lead to a very fast decay of synaptic efficacy, with time scales of minutes. We then identify two ways in which this memory time scale can be extended: ( i ) the extracellular calcium concentration used to fit the model are larger than estimated concentrations in vivo, and ( ii ) adding a bistability mechanism so that each synapse has two stable states at sufficiently low background activity. Our results are obtained first in a single synapse connecting two independent Poisson neurons, and then in simulations of a large network of excitatory and inhibitory integrate-and-fire neurons. Our results emphasise the need for studying plasticity at physiological extracellular calcium concentration, and highlight the role of synaptic bi- or multistability in the stability of learned synaptic structures.

Shigella flexneri is a cytoplasmic bacterial pathogen that causes bacillary dysentery and diarrhea in humans and animals. Although it is known that the cytoplasmic growth of this pathogen depends on IFNγ, the mechanisms by which IFNγ restricts S. flexneri growth remain to be identified. Here, we describe the first mechanism by which IFNγ restricts S. flexneri growth. We found that S. flexneri infection of IFNγ-stimulated mammalian cells is blocked in part by the cytoplasmic sensor RIG-I, and its downstream adaptor protein MAVS, which, in turn, inhibit S. flexneri replication. Our findings expand our understanding of how IFNγ recognizes, and ultimately restricts, bacterial pathogens within host cells.

The zebrafish ear is a complex organ composed of one row of inner ear and one row of outer ear. It contains a unique set of cell types, the inner ear cells, that form a highly regular pattern across the ear and a cell layer called the otic vesicle. The pattern is thought to be established early in embryogenesis, but how this is achieved is still unclear. We show that the anteroposterior patterning of the otic vesicle is regulated by a signalling pathway that is initiated by the fibroblast growth factor ( FGF ) and retinoic acid ( RA ) signalling pathways. In one case, RA signalling has opposing effects on the development of the inner ear cells; in another case, RA signalling acts in a feedback loop that restricts the expression of the otx1b gene, which is required for the formation of non-neural cells. These findings indicate that RA signalling is involved in the regulation of the anterior OV, which is critical for pattern formation in the ear.

Recent studies of the eukaryotic transcriptome have revealed that Pol II, the enzyme responsible for synthesizing most eukaryotic transcripts, is also involved in a complex process called “ termination” that removes introns from the transcript, or the first step of gene expression. While much has been learned about the molecular details of Pol II transcription and termination, much less is known about the mechanism of combinatorial control that controls the transcription of most eukaryotic genes. Here, we show that the combined effects of six essential proteins in the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae can explain the combinatorial control of transcription termination by Pol II. The results provide new insights into the regulation of eukaryotic gene expression, and the manner by which it is controlled.

Schistosomes are parasitic helminths that cause schistosomiasis in humans, cattle, livestock and companion animals. Schistosome worms are able to move in the blood stream, migrate through the skin, penetrate the intestinal wall, enter the liver and finally reach the final location in the liver, where they cause inflammation and organ failure. The mechanisms by which these organisms control their movement are not fully understood. Serotonin is a very important neurotransmitter in all parasitic helminths and serotonin is strongly myoexcitatory; it potentiates contraction of the body wall muscles and stimulates motor activity. This is considered to be a critical mechanism of motor control in the parasite, but the mode of action of serotonin is poorly understood. Here we provide the first molecular evidence of a functional serotonin receptor ( Sm5HTR ) in S. mansoni. Functional expression studies in transfected HEK 293 cells showed that Sm5HTR is a specific serotonin receptor and it signals through an increase in intracellular cAMP, consistent with a 5HT7 signaling mechanism. Immunolocalization studies with a specific anti-Sm5HTR antibody revealed that the receptor is abundantly distributed in the worm's nervous system, including the cerebral ganglia and the peripheral innervation of the body wall muscles and tegument. RNA interference was performed both in schistosomulae and adult worms to test whether the receptor is required for parasite movement. The results show that Sm5HTR is at least one of the receptors responsible for the motor effects of serotonin in S. mansoni.

Cytokinesis is the process by which a cell divides into two daughter cells. During this process, DNA is duplicated and then segregated into the two daughter cells. Entamoeba histolytica is a unicellular protozoan that causes the most common cause of acute and chronic liver disease worldwide. This unicellular organism has a remarkable ability to multiply and segregate multiple copies of the genome in a single cell. This property is unique to this organism, which has been shown to generate multiple copies of the genome in a single cell. In this study, we demonstrate that this unique mode of cell division event contributes to the genetic heterogeneity observed in E. histolytica. We demonstrate that the cell cycle of E. histolytica does not follow the nuclear division cycle, leading to the formation of genetically different daughter cells. We further show that the cell cycle of this organism does not follow the nuclear division cycle, leading to the formation of genetically different daughter cells. Finally, we demonstrate that this mode of cell division is conserved in other eukaryotes, including humans. Our study thus demonstrates that a unique mode of cell division is an inherent feature of this unicellular organism.

Strongyloidiasis, a neglected parasitic disease caused by the nematode Strongyloides stercoralis, is a frequent cause of septicemia in humans and immunocompromised patients. Strongyloidiasis is often underdiagnosed due to the low parasitic load and to the irregular larval output. We have used Phage Display technology to select peptides that mimic S. stercoralis antigens, capable of detecting a humoral response in patients with strongyloidiasis. The selected peptides were tested by Phage-ELISA through different panels of serum samples. We have successfully selected five peptides with significant immunoreactivity to circulating IgG from patients' sera with strongyloidiasis. The phage displayed peptides C9 and C10 presented the highest diagnostic potential with excellent specificity and sensitivity, suggesting that some S. stercoralis antigens trigger systemic immune response. These novel antigens are interesting serum biomarkers for routine strongyloidiasis screenings due to the easy production and simple assay using Phage-ELISA. Such markers may also present a promising application for therapeutic monitoring.

Human activities have profoundly altered the way we think and act in nature, but the ways we do this is often overlooked. One reason for this is that we have only a limited knowledge of what drives interest in nature. In this study, we provide the first broad exploration of patterns in interest in nature across many species and cultures. We show that seasonality plays an important role in how and when people interact with plants and animals online. In total, over 25% of species in our data set exhibited a seasonal pattern in at least one of their language-editing pages, and seasonality is significantly more prevalent in pages for plants and animals than it is in a random selection of Wikipedia articles.

Theiler's virus is a neurotropic picornavirus responsible for chronic infections of the central nervous system. The establishment of a persistent infection and the subsequent demyelinating disease triggered by the virus depend on the expression of L*, a viral accessory protein encoded by an alternative open reading frame of the virus. We discovered that L* potently inhibits the interferon-inducible OAS/RNase L pathway. The antagonism of RNase L by L* was particularly prominent in macrophages where baseline oligoadenylate synthetase ( OAS ) and RNase L expression levels are elevated. L* mutations significantly affected Theiler's virus replication in primary macrophages derived from wild-type but not from RNase L-deficient mice. L* counteracted the OAS/RNase L pathway through direct interaction with the ankyrin domain of RNase L, resulting in the inhibition of this enzyme. Interestingly, RNase L inhibition was species-specific as Theiler's virus L* protein blocked murine RNase L but not human RNase L or RNase L of other mammals or birds. Direct RNase L inhibition by L* and species specificity were confirmed in an in vitro assay performed with purified proteins. These results demonstrate a novel viral mechanism to elude the antiviral OAS/RNase L pathway.

During cell expansion, a fundamental response is triggered by the binding of the growth hormone auxin to receptors on the cell surface. At the same time, this binding triggers the phosphorylation of the receptor kinases, which then bind to and activate signaling cascades to ultimately induce cell growth. Plants respond to auxin signaling by activating signaling cascades, which induce the activation of growth hormone receptors. Thus, understanding the mechanisms of plant cell expansion and the plant hormone auxin is of great interest. We show that the Arabidopsis thaliana growth hormone AtRALF1 negatively regulates root cell expansion. AtRALF1 is a root-specific growth hormone that negatively regulates the activity of the auxin signaling pathway. At the same time, AtRALF1 induces an increase in the phosphorylation of its receptor BAK1. This suggests that AtRALF1 activates BAK1, which in turn triggers the activation of auxin signaling cascades. This study provides new insight into the mechanisms of plant cell expansion.

Cells must divide many times before they enter the final round of division, a process referred to as mitosis. Cell division is achieved through a complex network of cell cycle regulators and mitotic exit. While some pathways that control mitosis have been identified, others are poorly understood. Here, we describe a screen of a collection of 3762 single gene mutants in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to search for mutants that undergo an atypically high number of cell divisions. Many of the potential longevity genes map to cellular processes not previously implicated in mitotic senescence, suggesting that regulatory mechanisms governing mitotic exit may be broader than currently anticipated. We report that a chronic increase in ER protein load signals an expansion in autophagosome assembly in an ER-Golgi catabolic network, accelerates trafficking of high molecular weight protein aggregates from the cytoplasm to the vacuoles, and leads to a profound enhancement of daughter cell production. Our data provide evidence that catabolism of protein aggregates, a natural byproduct of high protein synthesis and turn over in dividing cells, is among the drivers of mitotic longevity in eukaryotes.

The premature fusion of paired frontal bones gives rise to a clinical phenotype called metopic craniosynostosis. This phenotype is well described in human patients with deletions of chromosome 9p22. 3, but the gene responsible for the disease is unknown. Here, we identified three new mutant alleles of FREM1 that associate with an increased risk of metopic craniosynostosis in humans and mice. We also determined the gene dosage for FREM1 in the human posterior frontal ( PF ) suture and demonstrated its role in the development of the pericranium and duraresher. Our findings demonstrate that CNVs involving FREM1 can be identified in a significant percentage of people with metopic craniosynostosis. We also present FREM1 mutant mice as the first bona fide mouse model of human metopic craniosynostosis and a new model for midfacial hypoplasia.

Major histocompatibility complex class I ( MHC-I ) proteins are critical to the immune response in vertebrates. Despite their high polymorphism, they are encoded by highly polymorphic genes. We show that the co-evolutionary constraints exerted by polymorphism may have driven the evolution of MHC-I proteins to avoid co-evolving residues and thereby increase their mutability.

One of the most important problems in biology and ecology is understanding the relationship between complexity, connectivity, and the stability of large biological systems. In the past decade, network theory has been used to gain a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying complex connectivity, network structure, and the relationships between them. In this work, we use a novel analytical approach to investigate the conditions under which dispersal of larvae, which are the offspring of a larval migration process, is controlled by network structure. We show that persistence depends crucially on the topology of cycles in the dispersal network which tend to enhance the effect of larvae. Our method clarifies the impact directly due to network structure, but this almost by definition can only be achieved by examining the simplified case in which dispersal is identical; an assumption that we later relax. The methodology reveals new insights regarding the determinants of persistence, stability, and thresholds in complex metapopulations. Our results should be of interest for many other scientific contexts that make use of network theory.

Polycomb and trithorax group proteins regulate cellular pluripotency and differentiation by maintaining hereditable states of transcription. Many Polycomb and trithorax group proteins have been implicated in the modification or remodeling of chromatin, but how they interact with each other and the general transcription machinery to regulate transcription is not well understood. We have studied the role of Kismet-L ( KIS-L ), a member of the CHD subfamily of chromatin-remodeling factors that plays a global role in transcription by RNA polymerase II ( Pol II ). We found that KIS-L acts downstream of P-TEFb recruitment to stimulate elongation by Pol II. The presence of two chromodomains in KIS-L suggested that its recruitment might be regulated by the methylation of histone H3 lysine 4 by the trithorax group proteins ASH1 and TRX. Our findings suggest that KIS-L promotes early elongation and counteracts Polycomb group repression by recruiting the ASH1 and TRX histone methyltransferases to chromatin.

The Notch3 pathway is thought to play a critical role in cancer development. In an effort to identify the molecular modulators of the Notch3 pathway, we screened for Notch3-intracellular domain ( N3-ICD ) interacting proteins using a human proteome microarray. Pathway analysis of the Notch3 interactome demonstrated that ubiquitin C was the molecular hub of the top functional network, suggesting the involvement of ubiquitination in modulating Notch3 signaling. Thereby, we focused on the functional characterization of an E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase, WWP2, a top candidate in the Notch3 interactome list. Co-immunoprecipitation experiments showed that WWP2 interacted with N3-ICD but not with intracellular domains from other Notch receptors. Wild-type WWP2 but not ligase-deficient mutant WWP2 increased mono-ubiquitination of the membrane-tethered Notch3 fragment, therefore attenuating Notch3 pathway activity in cancer cells and leading to cell cycle arrest. The ubiquitination by WWP2 may target an endosomal/lysosomal degradation fate for Notch3 as suggested by the fact that the process could be suppressed by the endosomal/lysosomal inhibitor. Furthermore, the majority of ovarian carcinomas harbored homozygous or heterozygous deletions in WWP2 locus, and there was an inverse correlation in the expression levels between WWP2 and Notch3 in ovarian carcinomas. Our results provide evidence that WWP2 serves as a tumor suppressor by negatively regulating Notch3 signaling in ovarian cancer.

Chagas disease is an important public health problem in Latin America. The control of the infection is based on the use of nitro derivatives, mostly nifurtimox and benznidazole. However, these compounds present some limitations, such as the need to enter the cell to perform their action and the possible development of resistance. Our group has been studying the trypanocidal effects of natural products and their derivatives, and naphthoimidazoles, derived from β-lapachone N1, N2 and N3. We applied quantitative proteomic techniques to analyze treated bloodstream trypomastigotes, which are the clinically relevant stage of the parasite. The approach consisted of quantification by 2D-DIGE followed by MALDI-TOF/TOF protein identification. We detected differentially abundant protein spots when comparing the control with each N1, N2 or N3 treatment, for 34 identified spots. Among the differentially abundant proteins were activated protein kinase C receptor, tubulin isoforms, asparagine synthetase, arginine kinase, elongation factor 2, enolase, guanine deaminase, heat shock proteins, hypothetical proteins, paraflagellar rod components, RAB GDP dissociation inhibitor, succinyl-CoA ligase, ATP synthase subunit B and methionine sulfoxide reductase. Our results point to different modes of action for N1, N2 and N3, which indicate a great variety of metabolic pathways involved and allow for novel perspectives on the development of trypanocidal agents.

The innate immune system is the first barrier of defense against invading pathogens and is critical for limiting the spread of infection. TLRs and RLRs on the cell surface and within the cytoplasm, respectively, sense infection and trigger the production of type I interferons ( IFNs ). IFNs are key mediators of anti-viral immunity. The recognition of viral RNA by TLRs is known to induce IFN production, which in turn activates the transcription factor, interferon regulatory factor 3 ( IRF-3 ), which induces IFN production by inducing the expression of the K63 ubiquitin ligase, TRAF3. Here, we show that this upregulation of TRAF3 is required for IFN induction in response to subsequent TLR signaling. This effect of TLR2 on macrophages is mediated by the selective upregulation of the K63 ubiquitin ligase, TRAF3. Thus, we provide a mechanistic explanation for the observed antiviral actions of TLR2 and further define the role of TRAF3 in viral innate immunity.

African trypanosomes are the causative agents of Human African Trypanosomosis ( HAT ) and Animal African Trypanosomosis ( AAT/Nagana ). The common hallmark of African trypanosome infections is inflammation, which manifests rapidly after infection and is manifested by an influx of myeloid cells in both liver and spleen, accompanied by a burst of serum pro-inflammatory cytokines. Within 48 hours after infection, acute anemia develops and the percentage of red blood cells drops by 50%. Using a newly developed in vivo erythrophagocytosis assay, we recently demonstrated that activated cells of the myeloid phagocytic system display enhanced erythrophagocytosis, causing acute anemia. Here, we show that IFNγ plays a crucial role in the recruitment and activation of erythrophagocytic myeloid cells, as mice lacking the IFNγ receptor were partially protected against trypanosomosis-associated inflammation and acute anemia. NK and NKT cells were the earliest source of IFNγ during trypanosomosis. Later in infection, CD8+ and to a lesser extent CD4+ T cells become the main IFNγ producers. Collectively, this study shows that NK, NKT and CD8+ T cell-derived IFNγ is a critical mediator in trypanosomosis-associated pathology, driving enhanced erythrophagocytosis by myeloid phagocytic cells and the induction of acute inflammation-associated anemia.

A major goal in computational biology is to understand the structural and energetic dynamics of proteins from their sequence. In order to do this, researchers use a variety of statistical approaches to determine the structure and function of proteins from their sequence. However, these approaches are not always able to provide a complete structural and energetic description of a protein, which is a challenging task. Here, we use a computational model of protein structures to assess the performance of several statistical approaches to determine the structure and function of proteins from sequence data. We find that, in particular, the inferred Potts Hamiltonian is able to provide complete new sequences with the desired structural and energetic features. Our results provide important guidelines for the design of new proteins by determining their sequence similarity, structural similarity and evolutionary relationship.

How organisms sense and respond to iron is incompletely understood. We provide evidence that in the phytopathogenic bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris, the two-component signaling system VgrS controls the expression of hundreds of genes that are involved in various physiological cascades, especially those associated with iron-uptake. We demonstrated that VgrR directly senses extracytoplasmic iron limitation in the periplasm, while its cognate response regulator, VgrR, detects intracellular iron excess. We also dissected the consensus DNA binding motif of the transcription factor VgrR and identified that it mediates the autophosphorylation and subsequent phosphotransfer to VgrR of the response regulator VgrR. These results reveal that the two-component system of X. campestris uses VgrR to sense and respond to iron, which controls bacterial adaptation to iron starvation and iron-uptake.

C. elegans is a model organism for the study of evolution because it has been possible to genetically dissect the mechanisms of evolution by manipulating gene expression. Previous work has focused on how gene expression is regulated in vivo. We have used C. elegans to understand how gene expression changes in the context of the cis-regulatory environment. We find that gene expression changes in the cis-regulatory elements of two different C. elegans species are preserved despite changes in the cis-regulatory environment. Such conservation may be facilitated by interactions between regulatory elements and cis-regulatory sequences. Our results offer a detailed picture of the evolutionary history of regulatory evolution in C. elegans.

Proteins are a class of biomolecules with remarkable sequence and structural flexibility. Proteins that evolve in the context of other proteins are often found in very different functional states. Protein tyrosine kinases ( PTKs ) are a group of proteins that evolve to perform very similar functions in different cellular processes. While the functions of PTKs are well understood, relatively little is known about how PTKs evolve to be different from other proteins. In this study, we investigate the structural and functional significance of key PTK-specific variations in the core of the kinase. We find that the nature of residues and interactions in the hydrophobic core of PTKs is strikingly different from other proteins. Furthermore, we find that mutations in the hydrophobic core of PTKs are significantly altered in both kinase activity and stability. Our results suggest that hydrophobic core variations provide a structural framework for evolution of PTKs and other proteins. We also find that the specific functional role of a conserved histidine in the regulatory spine of PTKs is structurally and functionally compensated by interacting with the regulatory spine. Our findings provide a structural framework for identifying and characterizing disease and drug resistance mutations in the kinase core.

The nervous system must be able to predict the environment even in the absence of sensory input. One of the most important principles of the nervous system is the creation of circuits that capitalize on this predictability. Previous work has identified differences in the distributions of basic visual features in natural images that are relevant to the encoding tasks of the visual system. We report that the well-established statistical distributions of visual features ( e. g., visual contrast, spatial scale, and depth ) differ between bright and dark image components. Following this analysis, we go on to trace how these differences in natural images translate into different patterns of cortical input that arise from the separate bright ( ON ) and dark ( OFF ) pathways. Our results indicate that there are regularities in visual cortical input beyond those that have previously been appreciated from the direct analysis of natural images. In particular, several dark/bright asymmetries provide a potential account for recently discovered asymmetries in how the brain processes visual features, such as violations of classic energy-type models.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis, is a leading cause of death worldwide. The Esx-1 secretion system is a major virulence factor of this pathogen, which is known to kill immune cells. However, the exact mechanism by which the Esx-1 secretion system kills mycobacteria in vivo remains unclear. Here we show that the Esx-1 secretion system promotes inflammation and disease in a mouse model of M. marium infection. Infection with Esx-1-deficient bacteria led to severe pathology, including the formation of granulomas similar to those observed in human tuberculosis. We also found that Esx-1-dependent inflammation required the host NLRP3 and ASC proteins. Infection of wild type and ASC-deficient mice demonstrated that these two factors are required to control inflammation. These findings suggest that the Esx-1 secretion system promotes disease and inflammation through its ability to activate the inflammasome.

In colorectal cancer cells, the APC protein is frequently mutated. The loss of APC function is believed to inhibit degradation of β—catenin, which is regulated by a multiprotein complex called the destruction complex. The destruction complex comprises APC, Axin, β—catenin, serine/threonine kinases, and other proteins. The kinases and, which are recruited by Axin, mediate phosphorylation of β—catenin, which initiates its ubiquitination and proteosomal degradation. Through formulation and analysis of a rule-based computational model, we investigated the mechanism of regulation of β—catenin degradation by the destruction complex and the role of truncation of APC in colorectal cancer. We found that the phosphorylated truncated form of APC can outcompete Axin for binding to β—catenin, provided that Axin is limiting, and thereby sequester β—catenin away from Axin and the Axin-recruited kinases and. Full-length APC also competes with Axin for binding to β—catenin; however, full-length APC is able, through its SAMP repeats, to bind Axin and to which is missing in truncated oncogenic forms of APC. Our results suggest that the positive effects of truncated APC on β—catenin levels depend on phosphorylation of APC, at the first 20-amino acid repeat, and that phosphorylation of this site is mediated by, and is a potential target for therapeutic intervention in colorectal cancer.

Intracellular bacteria have evolved mechanisms that promote survival within hostile host environments, often resulting in functional dysregulation and disease. Using the Anaplasma phagocytophilum–infected granulocyte model, we establish a link between host chromatin modifications, defense gene transcription and intracellular bacterial infection. Histone deacetylase 1 ( HDAC1 ) expression, activity and binding to the defense gene promoters significantly increased during infection, which resulted in decreased histone H3 acetylation in infected cells. HDAC overexpression enhanced infection, whereas pharmacologic and siRNA HDAC1 inhibition significantly decreased bacterial load. HDAC2 does not seem to be involved, since HDAC silencing by siRNA had no effect on A. phagocytophilum intracellular propagation. These data indicate that HDAC up-regulation and epigenetic silencing of host cell defense genes is required for A. phagocytophilum infection. Bacterial epigenetic regulation of host cell gene transcription could be a general mechanism that enhances intracellular pathogen survival while altering cell function and promoting disease.

Osteoporosis is a chronic, debilitating disease affecting millions of people worldwide. The skeletal elements of the face, skull, and jaw are derived from a common precursor, the mesenchyme, which is the tissue most closely associated with bone. We are studying how mesenchyme and osteoblast, the precursors of the skeletal elements of the face, are selected to form the bone and cartilage elements of the skull. Here, we show that the mesenchyme is supplied by the canonical Wnt effector molecule β-catenin, but that Wnt ligands are also supplied by another mesenchymal source, the epidermal growth factor ( EGF ) pathway. These two sources of Wnt ligands are essential for fate selection in both osteoblast and dermal fibroblast lineages. Thus, different Wnt ligands have distinct functions in bone and cartilage fate selection.

Our work describes a new condition that is required for the robustness of cortical networks. This condition is based on the balance of excitation and inhibition. When the excitation and inhibition are in close balance, the network is stable but only if the inputs are close to the critical point. When the inputs are not close to the critical point, the network is unstable. We show that the stability is determined by the time course of the oscillatory currents. We show that the presence of fast ( AMPA ) and slow ( NMDA ) oscillations in the network are required to keep the network in the fast-response regime. We also show that the presence of fast ( AMPA ) oscillations is necessary to keep the network robust when the stimulus is changing.

The central control of mammalian development is the maintenance of a retinal homeostasis. The mechanisms that underlie the transcriptional control of retinal development are not well understood. One of the major outstanding questions is the interplay between transcription factors that activate the expression of many retinal genes and the transcription factors that repress their expression. A well-known regulator of retinal gene expression is the transcription factor NRL, which is responsible for activating the expression of many retinal genes. Here, we report a comprehensive analysis of the transcription factor network that underlies rod photoreceptor function. Our analysis identified a network comprised of 300 direct NRL targets. We also investigated the function of a class of transcription factors that control the expression of many retinal genes. We found that these transcription factors are clustered into functional units called cis-regulatory modules, and that several of these transcription factor modules have been identified in prior studies. Our analysis also identified novel genes that are controlled by NRL. We also identified a novel function for one of these transcription factors, Kdm5b, and demonstrated that it regulates rod-expressed genes. Our studies provide the first global view of the transcription factor network that controls rod photoreceptor function and identify a network comprised of 300 transcription factor targets that are important for maintaining rod homeostasis.

During the course of an HIV-1 infection, the antibody antibody responses develop for years before the infection can be cleared. It is well established that antibody variable regions evolve rapidly, with changes occurring over time. However, the mechanism driving this evolution is not well understood. In this study, we show that the rate of evolutionary change in these regions is significantly slower than the rate at which changes occur. We also show that there is little change in the evolutionary rate of the antibody complementarity determining regions ( CDRs ), which are the most important functional regions for the immune system. Our results suggest that the slow rate of change in the CDRs, in turn, is caused by the slow rate of change in the antibody variable region. However, it is difficult to explain the slow evolutionary rate using only the CDRs. The correlation between the Darwinian selection strength and the evolutionary rate trended toward significance, but cannot fully explain the observed changes in evolutionary rate. The mutability of the antibody variable regions change only weakly with evolutionary rates. We also show that there is little correlation between the mutability of the antibody variable regions and the rate of change in evolutionary rates. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms driving the evolution of antibody neutralizing antibodies.

Buruli ulcer is a necrotising infection of skin and soft tissue caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. Buruli ulcer has a high rate of recurrence after treatment and there are currently no effective therapies. Mycolactone, a toxin with a high affinity for mycobacteria, causes cell death and a loss of immune function. We have shown that in some cases spontaneous healing of small ulcerative lesions can occur, suggesting that an immune response may be present during the initial lesion development. We describe a series of five patients who have spontaneously resolved small ulcerative lesions without treatment or surgery. The median duration of symptoms prior to diagnosis was 90 days and the median time to heal from diagnosis without treatment was 68 days. No recurrences were observed after a median follow-up of 16. 6 months. The study suggests that spontaneous healing may be possible in some cases and that it may be possible to obtain a similar outcome with antibiotics alone. Further research is required to determine what lesion and host factors are associated with spontaneous healing, and whether observation alone is an effective and safe form of management for selected small M. ulcerans lesions.

Chromatin, a complex of DNA, histone proteins, and other structural factors, is a fundamental unit of chromatin in all cells. The DNA sequences of a cell are organized in the nucleus such that the genome can be visualized in three dimensions ( 3D ). The 3D structure of chromatin has been linked to several biological functions, such as gene expression and DNA replication. Thus, determining the 3D structure of the genome sequence in the nucleus is a key challenge in biology. Recent advances in super-resolution microscopy in principle enable the mapping of specific molecular features with nanometer precision inside cells. We present a computational method, Chromo Trace, to reconstruct the sequence configuration of all human chromosomes in the nucleus from a super-resolution image of a set of fluorescent in situ probes. Our method uses suffix trees to assign a known linear ordering of in situ probes on the genome to an unknown set of 3D in-situ probe positions in the nucleus from super-resolved images. We find that ChromoTrack can accurately reconstruct the 3D DNA sequence and the 3D configuration of the majority of loci with high accuracy and reasonable sensitivity to specific DNA sequences.

In response to temperature, the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis can switch between yeast and mold forms. We identified a GATA transcription factor, SREB, important for the transition to mold. Null mutants fail to fully complete the conversion to mold and cannot properly regulate siderophore biosynthesis. To capture the transcriptional response regulated by SREB early in the phase transition ( 0–48 hours ), gene expression microarrays were used to compare SREB∆ to an isogenic wild type isolate. Analysis of the time course microarray data demonstrated SREB functioned as a transcriptional regulator at 37°C and 22°C. Bioinformatic and biochemical analyses indicated SREB is involved in diverse biological processes including iron homeostasis, biosynthesis of triacylglycerol and ergosterol, and lipid droplet formation. Integration of microarray data, bioinformatics, and chromatin immunoprecipitation identified a subset of genes directly bound and regulated by SREB in yeast ( 37°C ) and during the phase transition to mold ( 22°C ). Our results suggest SREB may be a novel transcriptional regulator important for the phase transition and that SREB may act upstream of HAPX, a bZIP transcription factor, in a negative regulatory circuit.

Chromatin, which consists of DNA and histone proteins, is often referred to as chromatin. This structure is important for gene regulation. Recent work has shown that gene expression can be regulated not only by histone modifications, but also by non-coding repetitive DNA. The importance of non-coding repetitive DNA is suggested by the presence of satellite DNA which has been shown to be able to affect gene expression. Here we show that the gene TCAST1 is associated with dispersed repetitive DNA elements which are located inside the nucleus in the pericentromeric heterochromatin. The presence of these elements influences the activity of the gene and the recovery of its activity after long-term heat stress. Our results reveal a novel role of repetitive DNA in gene regulation by using heat stress to induce heterochromatin formation.

The prevalence of ovarian cancer deaths in the United States is estimated to be 140, 000. The majority of cancer deaths occur in women seropositive for serous histological ovarian cancer, which is often missed before it has disseminated. We identified a recurrent gene fusion in serous ovarian tumors that joins the 5′ end of ESRRA to the 3′ end of C11orf20. The fusion transcript joins the 5′ end of ESRRA, which is predicted to interfere with nuclear hormone receptor superfamily signaling. Using sequencing technology and targeted resequencing, we confirmed the presence of the fusion transcript in 67 ovarian cancer cases. We also demonstrated that the genomic region from which the fusion transcript originates is located immediately upstream of the ESRRA gene. Our findings suggest that the novel gene fusion may play a role in pathogenesis of a substantial fraction of serous ovarian cancers and could provide a molecular marker for detection of the cancer.

Leptospirosis is an important emerging zoonotic disease, especially in tropical countries. It is a global disease, and the epidemiology varies from one country to another. In Brazil, the diagnosis of leptospirosis is based on serology and serosurveillance. However, these methods are not suitable for the diagnosis of leptospirosis in urban areas. We evaluated a real-time PCR assay for the detection of lipL32, a gene present only in pathogenic Leptospira, in patients with leptospirosis. This assay was able to detect leptospiral DNA in blood from 56% of serological non-confirmed cases. The real-time PCR assay may be a reliable tool for early diagnosis of leptospirosis, which is decisive for clinical management of severe and life-threatening cases and for public health decision making.

Synthetic lethal mutations are a powerful tool for discovering new targeted drugs to kill tumour cells. However, experimental validation of synthetic lethal mutations is difficult due to the limited number of synthetic lethal mutations and the need for screening large numbers of candidates.
