Here we describe a computational approach to predict synthetic lethal mutations that works by identifying and exploiting conserved patterns in protein interaction network topology both within and across species. Our results show that SLant ( Synthetic Lethal analysis via Network topology ) may provide useful guidance for future synthetic lethal drug screening efforts.

Tuberculosis ( TB ) is a serious health problem that is still a leading cause of death worldwide. The disease is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a bacterium that is transmitted to humans by aerosol. The bacillus replicates within cells of the granuloma, a tuberculous inflammation around the bacterial cell. Foamy macrophages ( FMs ), a type of mycobacterial-specific immune cells, have been described to be present in granulomas of TB patients, and are able to sequester the bacteria. We have analyzed the interaction of the TB bacillus with human macrophages, and have identified that oxygenated mycolic acids ( MA ), which are produced by macrophages, play a crucial role in the differentiation of these cells. Mycobacteria long chain fatty acids ( MA ) induce FMs, which migrate to macrophages and convert into FMs. In vitro culture of human macrophages, we have found that this process is mediated by the presence of MA in the bacterial cell, and that the mycobacteria enter the macrophages in association with the lipid droplets. We conclude that oxygenated MA plays a key role in the interaction of the TB bacillus with macrophages, and that FMs might be a relevant reservoir for the long-term persistence of the bacteria.

Proteins are assembled in complexes that sense and coordinate the correct assembly of their functional units. The co-chaperone BAG3, in complex with the heat shock protein HSPB8, has been shown to play a role in protein quality control during mechanical strain. We show here a novel function for the BAG3-HSPB8 complex in mitosis, a process that involves profound changes in cell tension homeostasis. BAG3 is hyperphosphorylated at mitotic entry and localizes to centrosomal regions. BAG3 regulates, in an HSPB8-dependent manner, the timely congression of chromosomes to the metaphase plate by influencing the three-dimensional positioning of the mitotic spindle. Deletion of BAG3 caused defects in cell rounding at metaphase and dramatic blebbing of the cortex associated with abnormal spindle rotations. Similar defects were observed upon silencing of the autophagy pathway, which is involved in the removal of defective proteins and damaged organelles. Our findings suggest the existence of a so-far unrecognized quality control mechanism involving BAG3, HSPB8 and p62/SQSTM1 for accurate remodelling of actin-based mitotic structures that guide spindle orientation.

The bacteria Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium cause foodborne diarrhea in humans and animals. We have previously shown that S. Typhimurium possesses an anaerobic respiration system that allows it to consume 1, 2-propanediol, a microbial fermentation product. Here, we show that this utilization is required by virulent S. Typhimurium for efficient growth in the intestinal lumen. We show that 1, 2-propanediol consumption by S. Typhimurium is mediated by the genes that are required by this pathogen to cause disease. We also show that this pathogen-derived carbon source is used by both S. Typhimurium and the resident intestinal microbiota. Our data suggest that intestinal inflammation drives S. Typhimurium to sidecompete for nutrients by respiring a microbiota-derived fermentable carbon source.

Cuticular layers and seeds are prominent plant adaptations to terrestrial life that appeared early and late during plant evolution, respectively. Cutin is the most abundant and studied cuticular component. Seeds are dry, metabolically inert structures promoting plant dispersal by keeping the plant embryo in an arrested protected state. In Arabidopsis thaliana seeds, the embryo is surrounded by a single cell endosperm layer itself surrounded by a seed coat layer, the testa. We identified cutin biosynthesis genes as regulatory targets of the phytohormones gibberellins ( GA ) and abscisic acid ( ABA ) signaling pathways that control seed germination. Cutin-containing layers are present in seed coats of numerous species, including Arabidopsis, where they regulate permeability to outer compounds. However, the role of cutin in mature seed physiology and germination remains poorly understood. Here, we identify in mature seeds a thick cuticular film covering the entire outer surface of the endosperm. This seed cuticle is defective in cutin-deficient bodyguard1 seeds, which is associated with alterations in endospermic permeability. Furthermore, mutants affected in cutin biosynthesis display low seed dormancy and viability levels, which correlates with higher levels of seed lipid oxidative stress. Our results support the notion that cuticular layers are key components in the evolution of cuticular structures.

In the model plant species Arabidopsis thaliana, which has oval-shaped leaves, a gene family called WUSCHEL-RELATED HOMEOBOX ( WUSCHEL-RELATED HOMEOBOX4 ) has been demonstrated to be important for the maintenance of the normal leaf shape and development. However, the function of the WUSCHEL-RELATED HOMEOBOX gene family in the grass species rice is poorly understood. In this study, we showed that WUSCHEL-RELATED HOMEOBOX4 is involved in the early development of the rice leaf. Loss of function of OsWOX4 results in the arrest of vascular differentiation, a partial defect in the early cell proliferation required for midrib formation, and a failure to maintain cellular activity in general parenchyma cells. Consistently, knockdown of OsWOX4 reduced the expression of two LONELY GUY genes, which function in the synthesis of active cytokinin, in developing vascular bundles. Our results suggest that OsWOX4 acts as a key regulator at an early stage of leaf development.

Gastroenteritis and stomach cancer are the most common forms of cancer worldwide. The genes responsible for these diseases are still largely unknown. Here, we screened a large family with a form of gastric cancer for mutations in the E-cadherin gene. We identified a germline mutation in mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase 6 ( MAP3K6 ). We then studied 115 unrelated individuals from Maritime Canada with a familial form of gastric cancer, and identified four additional rare variants in MAP3K6. We also investigated one of the variants in DNA obtained from a second individual, and found evidence of DNA hypermethylation within the MAP3K6 gene. Together, these findings, together with previous evidence from mouse models that MAP3K6 acts as a tumor suppressor, and studies showing the presence of somatic mutations in MAP3K6 in non-hereditary gastric cancers and gastric cancer cell lines, point towards MAP3K6 variants as a predisposing factor for familial gastric cancer.

Hepatocyte growth factor ( HGF ) signaling is a highly complex network that controls hepatocyte growth and homeostasis. Alteration of the complex signaling pathway is a major cause of liver disease. In this work, we present a novel mathematical modeling strategy to unravel the HGF signaling network at the system level. By integrating time-resolved quantitative experimental data generated in primary mouse hepatocytes with interaction graph and ordinary differential equation modeling, we identified and experimentally validated a network structure that represents the experimental data best and indicates specific crosstalk mechanisms. Combining the two models, we predicted the impact of combinatorial inhibition strategies on HGF signaling. Our results suggest that by capitalizing on the advantages of the two modeling approaches, we reduce the high combinatorial complexity and identify cell-context specific signaling networks.

Intrinsically disordered proteins ( IDPs ) are proteins that lack a well-defined structure and exist in a multitude of conformations. They are frequently found in the cell interior and are implicated in many important biological processes. Thus, the effects of protein crowding on the structure and dynamics of IDPs are often neglected. Here, we performed a comprehensive atomistic molecular dynamic analysis of the effects of protein crowding on the structure and dynamics of three proteins: an intrinsically disordered protein ( ACTR ), a molten globule conformation ( NCBD ), and a one-fold structure ( IRF-3 ) protein. We found that, in fact, crowding does not stabilize the native structure, and often prevents structural collapse. We also found that the impact of protein crowding on the structure and dynamics of a protein depends on its degree of disorder and results from two competing effects: the excluded volume, which favors compact states, and quinary interactions, which favors extended conformers. Thus, the protein crowders used here act as unspecific chaperons that modulate the protein conformational space, thus having relevant consequences for disordered proteins.

West Nile virus ( WNV ) is a mosquito-transmitted flavivirus that causes severe neurological disease in humans and other mammals. In recent years, WNV has emerged as a globally important pathogen. In this study we show that WNV can replicate to high titres in common marmosets, a natural host for WNV, and that this infection can be as severe as the one in rhesus macaques. We also show that WNV infection in these two species is similar to infection in monkeys, although they did not develop clinical signs of WNV disease. Our results show that both monkey species are promising animal models to study WNV infection.

Cells communicate with each other and with the surrounding environment. Communication is achieved by a network of secreted proteins that bind to receptors on the surface of target cells. The best studied example of such communication is the EGFR pathway, which is used for the formation of organs and tissues in all animals. EGFR is also involved in human diseases such as cancer. We show that EGFR controls the trafficking of two extracellular proteins in the Drosophila trachea, which are important for regulating organ growth. We show that EGFR controls the internalization and the transport of these proteins to the apical region of the cell. This is a first time that EGFR is shown to control the trafficking of extracellular proteins. Furthermore, we show that EGFR controls the transport of two intracellular proteins to the apical region of the cell, which is a crucial step for the initiation of organ formation. Our work shows how EGFR is able to influence intracellular trafficking and suggests that the regulation of intracellular trafficking can be a general outcome of EGFR activation.

Wnt signaling is an evolutionarily conserved cell polarity pathway that controls epithelial polarity and cell migration. Wnt signaling is also implicated in the specification of cell fates, including cell migration, in a variety of other cell types. While Wnt signaling is well known in vertebrates, little is known about how Wnt signaling may be regulated in unicellular organisms such as the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. In this study, we show that the Wnt pathway in C. elegans and the canonical Wnt/β-catenin pathway negatively regulate Wnt signaling in the Q neuroblasts, the progenitor cells of the C. elegans germ layer. Specifically, we show that the VANG-1/Vangl ortholog, VANG-1, negatively regulates Wnt signaling by interacting with and suppressing the binding of the Dishevelled ortholog MIG-5. Moreover, we show that VANG-1/Vangl and MIG-5 are evolutionarily conserved in mammals, and that the VANG-1/Vangl pathway is also involved in Wnt/β-catenin signaling in mammals. Thus, our data indicate that Wnt signaling may be regulated through a conserved mechanism in both worms and mammals.

This study demonstrates that HSV can stimulate homologous recombination, a novel mechanism by which HSV can recombine DNA in a single strand annealing ( SSA ) repair pathway. This finding provides insight into the formation of viral DNA during infection, and opens the possibility of developing therapeutic strategies that may inhibit recombination.

Glycans are glycan chains that decorate proteins, regulating their functions and their interaction. The glycan chains are synthesized by a large family of enzymes. In Drosophila, the glycan biosynthetic pathway has been shown to be required for the proper function of many proteins involved in a class of signaling known as the Wnt and BMP pathway. However, the molecular mechanism of how glycan biosynthetic enzymes control signaling in the cell is still unclear. Here, we have used a screen for glycan functions in synaptogenesis, the process of converting the precursor of the Wnt pathway into the functional form. We discovered that a Drosophila transgenic RNAi screen, targeting all N/O/GAG-glycan biosynthesis/modification enzymes, was used to identify novel glycan functions in synaptogenesis. As proof-of-product, we characterized functionally paired heparan sulfate ( HS ) 6-O-sulfotransferase (HS6st ) and sulfatase ( sulf1 ), which control HS proteoglycan ( HSPG ) sulfation. We found that WNT and BMP signaling is altered in HS6st and sulf1 mutants, explaining the bidirectional change in synaptic functional strength. Genetic correction of the altered WNT/BMP signaling restores normal synaptic development in both mutant conditions, proving that altered trans-synaptic signaling causes functional differentiation defects.

Metabolism is the process that allows organisms to convert nutrients into usable energy and carbon dioxide. Metabolism is particularly important for bacteria, which need to constantly adjust their metabolism to ensure growth and survival in the challenging environment of redox-stratified environments. Shewanella is a facultatively anaerobic bacterial genus that can live in redox-stratified environments. Metabolism comprises a large number of biochemical reactions and biosynthetic pathways. We have reconstructed the metabolic network of S. oneidensis MR-1, which is involved in aerobic metabolism, to facilitate the analysis of growth on different carbon sources. We then applied constraint-based modeling to investigate metabolic growth of MR-1. The resulting metabolic flux network was used to investigate the role of different metabolic pathways for growth on carbon sources and energy metabolism. We used experimental data to validate the predictions of the model and found that growth on lactate and malic carbon sources was coupled to proton motive force generation. Our results illustrate how integration of computational and experimental efforts facilitates the understanding of metabolism at a systems level.

Human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ) is a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma brucei. The parasite first enters the brain parenchyma in a process called neuroinvasion, during which the parasite replicates in the brain parenchyma, the precursors of the disease. The timing and nature of the neuroinvasion event is controversial, but the available data indicate that it occurs soon after the parasite has entered the brain. This means that the brain may be the target of the parasite and that the parasite may be present in the brain at the time of infection. We have shown that parasites, as well as T-cells, enter the brain parenchyma over time and that this event is followed by a slow increase in parasite load. Parasites and T-cells were also observed in the brain of the infected animals. In addition, the brain was shown to be affected by parasites as well as T-cells, indicating that the parasite may cross the blood-brain barrier, which is the first barrier to trypanosome infection. Finally, we showed that parasites that invade the brain at the time of infection produce a parasite-specific antigen, which can be detected in the brain, and can be used as a diagnostic marker.

In this work, we investigate how combining information from multiple types of data, such as genotypic and gene expression data, can help improve network reconstruction. We use a simulated data set to show that combining genotypic and gene expression data in a population of segregating mice improves network reconstruction, compared with networks reconstructed from only gene expression data alone. We also show that fewer subjects may be required to achieve the same level of network reconstruction accuracy. Our results demonstrate that combining genotypic and gene expression data can be used to gain more accurate network reconstructions, and that this approach can be used to save time and money in the process of network reconstruction.

People’s perceptions of poverty are often neglected, and many studies have focused on creating better access to healthcare. However, the link between poverty and disease is more complex, especially in the context of poor sanitation, hygiene practices and chronic diseases. This study examined how people’s health beliefs relate to diseases that cause illness among those who lived in poverty, including malaria. We found that people’s perceptions of poverty were strongly influenced by their living conditions and their health beliefs. Malaria, cholera and diarrhoea were the most important health concerns for the people, and their living conditions were the primary determinants of their health beliefs. We also found that people did not think that formal healthcare would be available to them and that they would use it formalised in the form of a health worker’s job. Our study demonstrates the need for improved health promotion, and for improved access to formal healthcare.

Nijmegen Breakage Syndrome ( NBS ) is a genetic disorder caused by loss of function of the nibrin gene. It is characterized by extreme sensitivity to DNA damaging agents and by high incidence of hematological malignancies. We have previously shown that the loss of nibrin in NBS cells is causative for the development of hematological malignancies. However, the exact mechanism by which loss of nibrin causes hematological malignancies is still unclear. In the present study, we have investigated the effects of loss of nibrin on the cellular level. We show that loss of nibrin in the absence of DNA damage leads to increased reactive oxygen species and oxidative stress. This is the first study to show that loss of nibrin in NBS cells is causative for the development of hematological malignancies.

Eukaryotic genomes contain repetitive sequences that are packaged into chromatin. These sequences are transcriptionally silenced, and heterochromatin, a specialized chromatin structure that packaging is a key feature of many genomes. A major challenge in biology is to understand how silencing mechanisms are maintained over many millions of years of evolution. While the epigenetic information that exists in chromatin is well known, much less is known about how silencing mechanisms are maintained. We have used the inducible mis-expression of a bantam microRNA in the fruit fly eye to recover new factors that affect silencing caused by the bantam mutation. We find that heterochromatin promotes silencing, and that the mechanisms involved are diverse. We also show that the bantam microRNA de-represses silencing when expressed in cycling cells. Our analysis reveals that heterochromatin is not necessary to maintain the cell cycle, and instead de-represses silencing when the cell cycle is held back. Surprisingly, continual over-expression of the crol microRNA accelerates the cell cycle, and this is required for de-repression of silencing. Our analysis reveals that chromatin states can be efficiently inherited through cell divisions, with implications for the stable maintenance of gene expression patterns through development.

Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a major public health concern in urban coastal communities of Ecuador, Bolivia, and Brazil. In this study, we assessed the impact of knowledge, attitudes, and practices ( KAPs ) and social-ecological factors on the presence or absence of DENV infections in the household. This study aimed to assess the impact of social-ecological factors on the presence or absence of DENV infections in the household. Our results suggest that knowledge, attitudes, and practices ( KAPs ) and social-ecological factors, such as proximity to abandoned properties, interruptions in piped water, and shaded patios, can help prevent DENV infection in the household. Specific actions that can be considered to decrease the risk of DENV infections in the household include targeting vector control in highly shaded properties, daily garbage collection, and reliable piped water inside houses. These findings can inform interventions to reduce the risk of other diseases transmitted by the Ae. aegypti mosquito, such as chikungunya and Zika fever.

A combination of high-throughput drug screening and anti-viral drug therapy has led to the rapid emergence of multi-drug resistant forms of HIV that are resistant to both drugs and cannot be readily eliminated by the immune system. Understanding the underlying mechanisms of recombination is an important prerequisite for developing new strategies to treat multi-drug resistant HIV infection. In this work, we develop a mathematical model that describes the dynamics of recombination in HIV-infected individuals. We use our model to study the effects of recombination on viral load changes in infected individuals. Our model predicts that, under some scenarios, recombination may dramatically influence viral load changes. We also show that our model can accurately predict the time evolution of uninfected, singly infected, and double-infected cells. Our model thus provides a framework to predict the emergence of multi-drug resistant forms of HIV in infected individuals.

We assessed the effects of insecticide application on the distribution of two target-site mutations in Culex quinquefasciatus, the most widely distributed insect vector of human African Trypanosomiasis ( HAT ), and the most important vector of Culex in the world. Our results show that the two target-site mutations exhibit heterogeneous frequencies, and that the two mutations are associated with different local selection pressures. In the face of intense gene flow among populations, disjunction in resistance frequencies arises due to intense local selection pressures despite an absence of insecticidal control interventions targeting Culex.

Amyloid precursor protein ( APP ) is a protein that, under certain circumstances, can cause the formation of insoluble aggregates in the brain. APP is associated with neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. APP is produced in the brain, and the function of this protein is unclear. Here we show that APP is regulated by a protein called FMRP, which is a mRNA binding protein. FMRP is also known to be involved in a cellular signaling pathway called metabotropic glutamate receptor activation. Inhibition of FMRP function increased APP translation. Furthermore, FMRP was found to be present in the synapse, a structure that allows nerve cells to communicate. We also found that the interaction between FMRP and metabotropic glutamate receptor was lost after glutamate treatment. Inhibition of FMRP increased APP translation in mice lacking the metabotropic glutamate receptor. Our results suggest that FMRP is a mediator of APP function, which could be a therapeutic target for treating Alzheimer's disease.

Schistosomiasis is a disease caused by the blood fluke Schistosoma japonicum. It is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in China, and is currently controlled by the use of two drugs ( praziquantel and diethylcarbam ). These drugs have a major drawback in their ability to cure the disease when the drug pressure in the community decreases. In order to reduce or eliminate the infection, the strategy of moving from low transmission to elimination is changing. We here investigate the two strategies that have been used to move from lower transmission to elimination. The first strategy focuses on the assessment of individual susceptibility to infection in the human population. The second strategy focuses on the detection of free-swimming larvae of the parasite in surface waters, which can be used to predict the probability of infection in the human population.

Mutation rates vary by orders of magnitude across biological systems, being higher for simpler genomes. The simplest known genomes correspond to viroids, subviral plant replicons constituting the only known examples of non-viral replicating subviral genomes. Previous work has revealed that the very simple viroid mutation rates, which are much higher than those of some RNA viruses, are not necessarily the same. We have used next generation sequencing to determine the mutation rate in a common host ( eggplant ) of two viroids: the chloroplastic eggplant latent viroid ( ELVd ) and the nuclear potato spindle tuber viroid ( PSTVd ). This revealed higher mutation frequencies in ELVd than in PSTVd, and marked differences in the types of mutations produced. Rates of spontaneous mutation, quantified in vivo using the lethal mutation method, ranged from 1/1000 to 1/800 for ELVd and from 1/7000 to 1/3800 for PSTVd depending on sequencing run. These results suggest that extremely high mutability is a common feature of chloroplastic viroids, whereas the mutation rates of PSTVd and potentially other nuclear viroids appear significantly lower and closer to those of some RNA viruses.

The production of blood cells is a tightly regulated process. While many of the cells are generated in the bone marrow, a small fraction ( 2–3% ) are capable of generating blood cells in other organs, such as the spleen and thymus. The cells are unique and they have the capacity to differentiate into all blood cell types. The rhesus macaque ( RM ) is an excellent model organism for the analysis of blood cell production because, during the last few decades, it has become possible to track the fate of hematopoietic stem cells ( HSCs ) that give rise to blood cells in the bone marrow. We have analyzed the time course of the hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells in RM and find large fluctuations in the number of cells. We show that the large fluctuations are due to random sampling of the blood and the cells’ demographic stochasticity. We show how the large fluctuations can be explained by a simple model of the production of blood cells.

Telomeres are the chromosome ends that are bound by telomerase, a complex of proteins that maintain chromosome stability and prevent cancer. TELA is a long noncoding telomeric repeat that is expressed at chromosome ends. TELA upregulation upon experimental manipulation or in ICF ( immunodeficiency, centromeric instability, facial anomalies ) patients correlates with short telomeres. We found that TELA promotes telomere shortening by interacting with the Exo1-inhibiting Ku70/80 complex. Deletion of EXO1 but not MRE11 fully suppressed the TELA–mediated short telomere phenotype in presence and absence of telomerase. We also found that TELA transcription facilitates the 5′-3′ nuclease activity of Exo1 at chromosome ends, providing a means to regulate the telomere shortening rate. Telomerase can also induce TELA transcription by de novo TELA synthesis. We propose that telomere transcription can regulate lifespan through modulation of chromatin structure, telomere processing and/or expression.

Proteins are the molecular workers of the cell. They are assembled from individual amino acids and are subsequently linked to form complexes. Thus, proteins are essential for all cellular functions. It is well established that proteins can be grouped by function, i. e., one protein can be related to many others. This is the case for the germ plasm, a large protein complex that is involved in many cellular processes. Here, we show that two proteins in the germ plasm, Oskar and Buc, which are closely related in sequence but functionally unrelated, also show similar activities during germ cell specification. We also show that Oskar and Buc are involved in similar biochemical pathways, but they do not seem to have similar structural organization. Surprisingly, Buc contains stretches of intrinsically disordered regions that are not found in Oskar, suggesting that these regions are involved in protein aggregation. We show that Buc interacts with the known Oskar interactors Vasa protein and nanos mRNA. These results provide a molecular framework for two proteins with unrelated sequence but with equivalent function to assemble a conserved core-complex nucleating germ plasm.

Ectodomain-containing transcription factors, including SOX11, are known to play critical roles in regulating the levels of secreted proteins that control cell fate and function. Here, we show that the zebrafish SOX11 protein is required to maintain specific levels of Hedgehog signaling during ocular development. Genetic ablation of Sox11 results in defects in eye development, coloboma, and microphthalmia. SOX11 is expressed in the developing eye, where it is required for the proper expression and function of the Hedgehog pathway. We also find that two novel heterozygous variants in SOX11 cause eye defects and cataracts in individuals with coloboma. We show that SOX11 is required for the expression and function of the Hedgehog pathway in zebrafish, and that its genetic ablation causes an elevated levels of Hedgehog signaling. Therefore, our study reveals a novel role for SOX11 in controlling Hedgehog signaling, and suggests that SOX11 variants contribute to eye diseases.

Immune cells, including natural killer ( NK ) cells, recognize the presence of an activating and inhibitory signal present on the surface of target cells. However, how the integration of activating and inhibitory signals relates to formation of the NK cell immune synapse remains a central question in our understanding of NK cell recognition. Here, we report that ligation of a receptor on NK cells induces asymmetrical cell spreading and migration. In contrast, ligation of the activating receptor NKG2D induces symmetrical spreading of a dynamic ring of f-actin, concurrent with polarization towards a target cell and a “stop” signal. Ligation of both LFA-1 and NKG2D together resulted in symmetrical spreading but co-ligation of inhibitory receptors reverted NK cells to an asymmetrical migratory configuration leading to inhibitory synapses being smaller and more rapidly disassembled. Using micropatterning of activating and inhibitory ligands, signals were found to be continuously and locally integrated during spreading. Together, these data demonstrate that NK cells spread to form large stable, symmetrical synapses if activating signals dominate, whereas asymmetrical migratory “kinapses” are favoured if inhibitory signals dominate. This clarifies how the integration of activating and inhibitory receptor signals is translated to an appropriate NK cell response.

A key question in evolutionary biology is to determine the extent to which genomic variation contributes to phenotypic variation and to the extraordinary phenotypic diversity of crops and their wild relatives. Whole-genome, comparative genomic hybridization ( CGH ) studies have previously revealed the extent of structural variation, i. e. differences in the number of copies of different genes, and the presence/absence variation ( PAV ) in the genomes of different species. These studies have provided important information on the evolutionary dynamics of plant genomes, but their application to the plant-specific genome has been limited due to the lack of a framework for interspecific comparison. Here we report an analysis of the genomic content of B73 and Mo17, two inbred lines derived from a recent founder event of maize that was characterized by a hybrid phenotype, and a third, inbred line derived from a non-implicated founder event that was characterized by no phenotype. We show that both genomic content and phenotypic variation in these lines are highly variable, with several hundred CNV sequences among the two genotypes and several thousand PAV sequences present in B73 but not Mo17. Many of the genomic variations may affect heterosis and/or contribute to the extraordinary phenotypic diversity of this important crop.

Buruli Ulcer is a chronic necrotizing skin disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. The toxin mycolactone is responsible for the destructive nature of the lesion, which is closely related to the pathogenesis of this disease. Currently, there are no effective measures to prevent the disease and, despite the availability of antibiotics, these therapeutic options are often associated with severe side effects. Therefore, alternative strategies are needed to overcome the current limitations in treatment options. Endolysins ( lysins ) are a class of bacterial enzymes that are responsible for the cleavage of bacterial cell wall components. They have been recently shown to display antibacterial activity against bacterial infections. In this study, we demonstrate for the first time that lysin B, a recombinant endolysin, has lytic activity against M. ulcerans. We also show for the first time that lysin B, when administered as a subcutaneous recombinant, prevents bacterial proliferation in mouse models of M. ulcerans footpad infection. These results highlight the potential use of lysins as a novel therapeutic approach against this neglected tropical disease.

While many genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have identified significant associations between a gene and a complex phenotype, the majority of these associations do not account for much of the heritability to such traits and, in general, do not lead to a better understanding of the biology underlying the associations. Using a web site we develop an approach to identify which genetic variants are significantly more likely to be eQTLs ( i. e., SNPs that are significantly more frequent in populations that are genetically similar than those in other populations ) than those that are significantly fewer. We show that genetic variants associated with complex traits are significantly more likely to be eQTLs than variants that are significantly less frequent in populations that are genetically similar to each other. Our results suggest that, in addition to identifying SNPs that increase risk of developing a complex phenotype, identifying SNPs that decrease risk of developing a complex phenotype may also help to explain why a genetic variant is not an eQTL.

The U1 small nuclear ribonucleoprotein ( snRNP ) -specific U1C protein plays a key role in 5′ splice site recognition and regulation of pre-mRNA splicing. Here, we show that a novel splicing switch mechanism that involves alternative splicing and U1 snRNP assembly is responsible for U1C and U1-70K expression homeostasis. In particular, alternative splicing of U1-70K pre-mRNA creates the normal ( exons 7–8 ) and a non-productive mRNA isoform, which is generated through a U1C-dependent alternative 3′ splice site, which requires an adjacent cluster of regulatory 5′ splice sites and binding of intact U1 snRNPs. As a result of the nonsense-mediated decay pathway, U1-70K mRNA and protein levels are down-regulated, and U1C incorporation into the U1 snRNP is impaired. U1-70K/U1C-deficient particles are assembled, shifting the alternative splicing balance back towards productive U1-70K splicing, and restoring assembly of intact U1 snRNPs. Taken together, we established a novel feedback regulation that controls U1-70K/U1C homeostasis and ensures correct U1 snRNP assembly and function.

Data integration procedures consider heterogeneous data sets and use them to infer biological knowledge. They are limited to data explicitly related to the target object type, such as genes. Collage is a new data fusion approach to gene prioritization. It combines diverse types of data, and incorporates a novel feature that compresses the data and aggregates it into a compact data structure. We tested Collage by prioritizing bacterial response genes in Dictyostelium as a novel model system for prokaryote-eukaryote interactions. We used 4 seed genes and 14 data sets, only one of which was directly related to the bacterial response, Collage proposed 8 candidate genes that were readily validated as necessary for the response of Dictyostelium to Gram-negative bacteria. These findings establish Collage as a method for inferring biological knowledge from the integration of heterogeneous and coarsely related data sets.

Neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ) are a group of diseases that affect the poorest populations in the world. There is a critical need for research to develop improved therapies and treatments for NTDs. We reviewed the World Health Organization’s ( WHO ) International Clinical Trials Registry Platform to assess research activity and treatment availability for NTDs in children. The burden of disease for each NTD was measured in terms of disability adjusted life years ( DALYs ), which was extracted from the Global Health Data Exchange. First- and second-line medications for each NTD were identified from WHO guidelines. We reviewed FDA drug labels for each medication to determine whether they were adequately labeled for use in children. Children comprised 34% of the 20 million DALYs resulting from NTDs, but pediatric trials contributed just 17% ( 63/369 ) of trials studying these conditions. Conditions that were particularly under-represented in pediatric populations compared to adults included rabies, leishmaniasis, scabies, and dengue. Of the 47 medications recommended by the WHO for the treatment of NTDs, only 47% ( n = 22 ) were adequately labeled for use in children. Under-studied medications with limited treatment options, such as malarial drug, are likely to be underrepresented in pediatric trials and contribute to the limited treatment options for NTDs. There is a substantial gap between the burden of disease for NTDs in children and research devoted to this population. We recommend that research activities for NTDs in children should be prioritized in order to increase their quality and effectiveness.

The recent rise in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus strains has highlighted the need to develop new therapeutic options. The pathogenesis of S. aureus is determined by a complex interaction of many genes, including methicillin resistance determinants. Here, we show that a novel methicillin resistance determinant is encoded on a mobile genetic element ( MGE ) found in many staphylococcal strains. We show that this novel gene, PSM-mec, is strongly expressed in many strains and has the pro-inflammatory and cytolytic properties typical of methicillin resistance determinants. In addition to providing high-level resistance to methicillin, acquisition of SCCmec elements encoding PSM-mec by horizontal gene transfer may also contribute to staphylococcal virulence by substituting for the lack of expression of methicillin resistance determinants. Thus, our study reveals a novel role of methicillin resistance clusters in staphylococcal pathogenesis and shows that important virulence and antibiotic resistance determinants may be combined in staphylococcal MGEs.

Intracellular signalling is a fundamental process that is essential to all living organisms. In bacteria, the most common form of intracellular signalling is mediated by a cell-surface receptor, Tsr, which binds to a cell-surface signal peptide at a site in the periplasmic domain of the protein. The signal peptide induces a conformational change in the receptor, changing the shape of the receptor from a cytoplasmic trimer to a periplasmic dimer. This causes the receptor to be “inhibited” and thus prevents downstream effectors from accessing the signal. In this work, we present a molecular model of the entire Tsr dimer and investigate how the receptor changes conformation. We use molecular dynamics simulations of the dimer to explore possible mechanisms of signal amplification. We find a mechanism in which small changes in the conformation of the dimer are amplified into a large conformational change in the receptor, which can then propagate downstream.

Toxocariasis is an intestinal worm infection that is common in the developing countries of the world, including the United States. The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey ( NHANES ) has been conducted to collect data on the prevalence of Toxocara spp. infection in the U. S. and assess whether this infection is associated with poverty and disease. We reviewed the data collected from 2011–2014 to determine the prevalence of Toxocara infection in the U. S. and to compare it with data collected from other countries. We found that the current national prevalence of Toxocara infection is 5. 1% in adults and 13. 9% in children. In adults, more than 80% of the population had been previously exposed to Toxocara. In children, prevalence was 15. 2% and 10172 adults. The findings suggest that there is a decrease in prevalence of Toxocara infection in the U. S. over the past 25 years. However, persistence disparities, such as poverty, gender, age, and ethnicity, appear to be associated with the current national prevalence of Toxocara infection.

Just as complex electronic circuits are built from simple Boolean gates, diverse biological functions often require biochemical switches, but are frequently used as functional modules. A relatively small number of such switches have been described in the literature, and they exhibit considerable diversity in chemical topology. We asked if biochemical switches are indeed rare and if there are common chemical motifs and family relationships among such switches. We performed a systematic exploration of chemical reaction space by generating all possible chemical configurations up to 3 molecules and 6 reactions and up to 4 molecules and 3 reactions. We found nearly 4, 500 reaction topologies, or about 10% of our tested configurations, that demonstrate switching behavior. We identified new reaction motifs that were likely to be found in switches. Furthermore, the discovered switches were related in that most of the larger configurations were derived from smaller ones by addition of one or more reactions. We also developed two tools: the “bistabilizer, ” which converts almost-bistable systems into bistable ones, and frequent motif mining, which helps rank untested configurations. Both of these tools increased the coverage of our library of bistable systems. Thus, our systematic exploration of chemical reaction space has produced a valuable resource for investigating the key signaling motif of bistability.

Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen 3C ( EBNA3C ) is a latent protein that is essential for EBV-induced B cell immortalization and the subsequent development of several cell types including B lymphocytes, epithelial cells, and hepatocytes. In this study, we have determined that EBNA3C interacts with Gemin3, a cellular protein that exhibits DNA binding and RNA metabolism functions. Through this interaction, EBNA3C directly interacts with Gemin3 and stabilizes its activity. We also show that EBNA3C induces Gemin3 to form complexes with p53, a DNA binding protein that is critical for apoptosis and cell proliferation. Our results suggest that EBNA3C promotes Gemin3 activity and p53 transcription activity in B lymphocytes through p53-mediated apoptosis.

Malaria is a major public health concern in many countries, including Panama, where it is responsible for more than 1 million deaths per year. Previous studies in Panama have indicated that mosquitoes and humans are at risk of malaria, although the exact mosquito species responsible for transmission is unknown. We conducted an analysis of all reported cases of malaria in Panama between 2000 and 2014. We compared these numbers with those of malaria cases occurring during the previous epidemic cycle ( 1996–2000 ) and those occurring during the current epidemic cycle ( 2013–2014 ). We found that the number of malaria cases reported per year varied significantly between years, particularly in indigenous comarcas. In comparison, the number of malaria cases reported per 1, 000 people at risk was much higher for Plasmodium falciparum ( 48, 000 people per year ). Our results suggest that Anopheles albimanus is the primary malaria vector in Panama, confirmed by identification of nine P. vivax-infected specimen pools. Future malaria eradication strategies in Panama should focus on indigenous comarcas and include both active surveillance for cases and comprehensive anopheline vector surveys.

In many plant-pathogenic fungi, mating is a key process, which initiates a parasitism by a morphological and physiological transition from saprobic yeast cells to pathogenic filamentous forms. Sexual identity is determined by specific genomic regions encoding allelic variants of a pheromone-receptor ( PR ) system and heterodimerising transcription factors. Both operate in a biphasic mating process that starts with PR–triggered recognition, directed growth of conjugation hyphae, and plasmogamy of compatible mating partners. We show that three highly syntenic PR alleles are prevalent among members of the Ustilaginaceae, favouring a triallelic determination as the plesiomorphic characteristic of this group. Furthermore, the analysis of PR loci revealed increased genetic diversity of single PR locus genes compared to genes of flanking regions. Performing interspecies sex tests, we detected a high potential for hybridisation that is directly linked to pheromone signalling as known from intraspecies sex. Although the PR system seems to be optimised for intraspecific compatibility, the observed functional plasticity of the PR system increases the potential for interspecific sex, which might allow the hybrid-based genesis of newly combined host specificities.

MicroRNAs ( miRNAs ) and Adenylate/uridylate-rich elements ( AMD ) are small RNAs that post-transcriptionally regulate the expression of target mRNAs. Here we report that the microdissected pituitary, a pituitary-specific organ, harbors a novel feedback loop involving miRNA– and AMD–dependent gene regulation. We find that the microdissected pituitary exhibits a significant increase in the expression of let-7b/c, a miRNA–associated gene, as well as the expression of αGSU, a hormone-specific mRNA. We also show that αGSU is stabilized by its own downregulation through the microdissected pituitary, and that its stability is positively correlated with the temporal relationship between KSRP and miRNA expression. Our results provide new insights into the mechanisms of miRNA– and AMD–dependent gene regulation in vivo.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a leading cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia in immunocompromised patients. The ability of P. aeruginosa to adapt to these diverse environments is facilitated by its ability to sense and respond to multiple extracellular cues. We have identified that deletion of a P. aeruginosa CdpR gene results in increased production of pyocyanin and biofilm, enhanced pathogenicity in a mouse model, and enhanced virulence. CdpR is an important QS regulator that can bind to the ClpAS-P signal system and interact with the adaptor protein ClpS to control the degradation of CdpR. Moreover, deletion of clpP or clpS/clpA results in enhanced bacterial survival in a mouse model of acute pneumonia infection. This study uncovers that CdpR is a novel QS regulator in P. aeruginosa and that its adaptor protein ClpS directly interacts with CdpR to control CdpR degradation. Our results reveal that CdpR is a novel QS regulator that can directly influence virulence gene expression and pathogenicity.

To survive, animals must be able to adapt to changes in their environment. To do this, animals must learn to associate multiple sensory signals in a noisy sensory environment with their internal state. While many models have been developed to predict the response to a given stimulus, they have not been able to incorporate variable response timing and/or state dependence of the neural code. We present a novel method for modeling variable response timing and state dependence. Our method, which we call response alignment, is based on a combination of information theory and Markov chain theory. We show that it is a more efficient method than previous approaches. We also apply our method to recorded data of birds on a variety of tasks, demonstrating how it can be used to learn the responses to complex stimuli.

Cholera is a potentially deadly diarrheal disease that is transmitted from person to person. In the Philippines, data on cholera in the past are sparse, making it difficult to determine areas at high risk for cholera. Here, we assessed the incidence of cholera in the Philippines using sentinel surveillance data and reported on the number of suspected cases from 2008–2013. Our results showed that the overall case fatality ratio was 0. 62%, but was 2% in outbreaks. The number of suspected cases varied by age group, with children under 6 being most affected. We also found that access to improved water supplies was associated with higher cholera incidence. Our findings confirm that cholera affects a large proportion of the provinces in the country. Identifying areas most at risk for cholera will support the development and implementation of policies to mitigate the morbidity and mortality due to this disease.

Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini are two parasitic flukes that have a major impact on the health of tens of millions of people in Asia. They are classified as Group 1 carcinogens by the World Health Organization ( WHO ). Despite their impact, little is known about these parasites and their interplay with the host at the molecular level. Recent advances in genomics and bioinformatics provide unique opportunities to gain improved insights into the biology of parasites as well as their relationships with their hosts at the molecular level. Here, we describe the use of next-generation sequencing and advanced in silico analyses to identify genes expressed in the parasites and their interplay with the host. The results of this study could assist in defining molecules that are essential for the development, reproduction and survival of liver flukes and/or that are linked to the development of cholangiocarcinoma.

Although recent research has shown that genetic variations play a major role in obesity risk, epigenetic variations, in particular methylation, play a key role in determining the individual susceptibility to obesity. Here we have identified a DNA methylation variant that is associated with childhood obesity. We found that the DNA methylation variant, which is a hypermethylation variant, interferes with binding of the transcription enhancer P300 and reduces the expression of the POMC transcript. We also show that the hypermethylation variant is located in the genomic vicinity of the POMC locus, a region known to be associated with methylation. The POMC locus is also located in the vicinity of the Alu element, a known to influence methylation in the promoter region. The hypermethylation variant thus results from an Alu element–triggered default state of methylation boundary definition. The POMC locus is a genetic polymorphism that is known to be under strong epigenetic control. Therefore, this methylation variant is a unique example of a single-nucleotide polymorphism that is associated with a complex phenotype.

The deoxycytidine deaminase APOBEC3G ( A3G ) inhibits HIV-1 replication by deaminating the viral genome. It has been known for over 30 years that APOBEC3G is present in human T cells and can inhibit HIV-1 replication. However, the specific deaminase activity of endogenous APOBEC3G in human T cells has not been examined directly. Here, we compared the deaminase activity of endogenous A3G in various human cell lines using a standard assay and a novel, quantitative, high-throughput assay. Exogenous A3G in epithelial cell lysates displayed deaminase activity only following RNase treatment, as expected given that A3G is known to form an enzymatically inactive RNA-containing complex. Surprisingly, endogenous A3G exhibited minimal deaminase activity, despite RNase treatment. Furthermore, we found that deaminase activity of endogenous A3G in human T cell lines and in resting or activated primary CD4+ T cells was reduced by up to 36-fold. Furthermore, RNase-treated T cell lysates inhibited epithelial cell lysates expressing enzymatically active A3G. These studies suggest that T cells, unlike epithelial-derived cell lines, express an unidentified RNase-resistant factor that inhibits A3G deaminase activity. This factor could be responsible for reduced levels of hypermutation in T cells, and its identification and blockade could offer a means for increasing antiretroviral intrinsic immunity of T cells.

Streptococcus pneumoniae ( the pneumococcus ) is a leading cause of life-threatening illness and death worldwide. Available conjugate vaccines target only a small subset of >90 serotypes of S. pneumoniae and, since their introduction, increases in non-vaccine serotypes have been recorded in several countries: a phenomenon termed Vaccine-Induced Serotype Replacement ( VISR ). In this study, we show that vaccination can cause changes in the metabolism and virulence-associated components of S. pneumoniae to transfer through recombination to non-vaccine serotypes: a phenomenon we term Vaccine-Induced Metabolic Shift ( VIMS ). Our results provide a novel explanation for changes observed in the population structure of the pneumococcus following vaccination, and have important implications for strain-targeted vaccination in a range of infectious disease systems.

The availability of large-scale protein-protein interaction networks for numerous organisms provides an opportunity to comprehensively analyze whether simple properties of proteins are predictive of the roles they play in the functional organization of the cell. We begin by re-examining an influential but controversial characterization of the dynamic modularity of the S. cerevisiae interactome that incorporated gene expression data into network analysis. We show that the dynamic modularity and modularity of the interaction networks of five organisms are inextricably linked, and that the functions and structural properties of hub proteins that are co-expressed with their interacting partners and those that are not, are strongly correlated with these properties. Our results demonstrate that in each of these organisms, simple topological measures are significantly correlated with the co-expression of a hub with its partners, independent of any classification, and hence also reflect protein intra- and inter- modularity. Furthermore, we also demonstrate that hub proteins tend to be conserved across organisms. Overall, we provide evidence that purely topological features of static interaction networks reflect aspects of the dynamics and modularity of interactomes as well as previous measures incorporating expression data, and are a powerful means for understanding the dynamic roles of hubs in interactomes.

NTDs are a heterogeneous group of infectious diseases that affect the poorest and the most marginalized populations in the world. There is considerable variation in the epidemiology of these diseases across settings, but little is known about the drivers of this variation. We describe a general contextual analysis of NTDs in rural Kenya, which uses multi-level statistical models to partition and quantify variation in individual NTD risk at multiple clustering levels. We show that there are important differences in the spatial distribution of NTDs and HIV risk across this population, with important differences in infection risk for the gastrointestinal helminths, Schistosoma mansoni, Taenia solium, Ascaris lumbricoides, and Trichuris trichiura. This spatial variation is not observed for HIV, but is correlated with other important NTDs, such as malaria and TB. The results of this study provide a foundation for understanding the complex ecology of NTDs and contribute to the targeting of interventions.

Helicobacter pylori ( H. pylori ) is a bacterium that chronically infects the stomach and causes ulcers and gastric cancer. H. pylori infection is initiated when H. pylori first interacts with gastric tissue, and is thought to be facilitated by a microenvironment that is provided by the gastric lining. We have previously shown that H. pylori preferentially colonizes the ulcerated area in the presence of gastric resident Lactobacillus spp. We investigated whether other bacterial factors are important to ulcer healing and gastric damage. We found that H. pylori motility ( chemotaxis ) and the ability to sense chemicals ( chemotaxis ) are important to ulcer healing and gastric damage. Our results provide important new insight into H. pylori pathogenesis, which is important for developing therapeutic strategies that target these pathogens.

HAP2 is a structurally conserved transmembrane protein that initiates membrane fusion with host cells via insertion of fusion loops into the host membrane. However, the functional conformation of the HAP2 fusion loops has remained unknown, as the reported X-ray structure of the model yeast Chlamydomonas reinhardtii HAP2 lacked this critical region. Here, we report the structure-guided alignment of the proposed HAP2 fusion loops. Our results reveal that in flowering plants, HAP2 has a single prominent fusion loop projecting an amphipathic helix at its apex, while in trypanosomes, three small nonpolar loops of HAP2 are poised to interact with the target membrane. A detailed structure-function analysis of the Arabidopsis HAP2 amphipathic fusion helix defines key residues that are essential for membrane insertion and for gamete fusion. Our study suggests that HAP2 may have evolved multiple modes of membrane insertion to accommodate the diversity of membrane environments encountered during eukaryotic evolution.

Dengue is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in the tropics and sub-tropics. The four DENV serotypes are the cause of a spectrum of clinical disease ranging from mild fever to potentially life-threatening haemorrhagic fever and hypovolemic shock. There is no licensed vaccine or antiviral therapy available to treat dengue disease. The lack of a vaccine has been a major impediment to dengue control and research. In recent years, the use of RNA interference ( RNAi ) has been shown to be effective at blocking dengue disease symptoms. In this study, we identified a conserved site in the 5′ non-translated region ( NTR ) of the viral genome that is targeted by short hairpin RNA ( shRNA ). We used a human adenovirus type 5 ( AdV5 ) vector to deliver a short-hairpin RNA ( shRNA ) targeting this site into cells. We show that this shRNA can inhibit the replication of all four DENV serotypes. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using AdV5-mediated delivery of shRNA targeting conserved sites in the viral genome to inhibit infection by all four DENV serotypes. This opens the way towards exploring RNAi as a therapeutic strategy to curtail dengue infection.

Differentiated cells are often structured in a hierarchical manner, with cells at the top of the hierarchy being more differentiated and more stem-like. Recent evidence suggests that tumors are structured in a very similar way, mirroring the hierarchical structure of the host tissue. In some tissues, differentiated cells can also revert to the stem cell phenotype, which increases the risk that mutant cells lead to long lasting clones in the tissue. However, it is unclear under which circumstances de-differentiating cells will invade a tissue. Here, we develop mathematical models to investigate how de-differentiation is selected as an adaptive mechanism in the context of cellular hierarchies. We find that de-differentiation is most likely to be favored provided stem cells having the largest effective self-renewal rate. Moreover, de-differentiation also provides a wider range of favorable conditions than stepwise de-differentiation. Finally, the effect of de-differentiation on the redistribution of self-renewal and differentiation probabilities also greatly influences the selection for de-differentiation.

Insects cuticle is composed of structural proteins and the polysaccharide chitin. There are three types of cuticle proteins in insects, which are named TcCPR1, TcCPR2 and TcCPR3. The TcCPR27 protein is one of the most abundant cuticle proteins ( CP ), which can be further divided into three subgroups based on the presence of one of the three sequence motifs denoted as Rebers-Riddiford ( R&R ) consensus sequence motifs RR-1, RR-2 and RR-3. In the present study, we investigated the function ( s ) of another CP, TcCPR4, which contains the RR-2 motif. We found that TcCPR4 is present in the rigid cuticles of the dorsal elytron, ventral abdomen and leg but not in the flexible cuticles of the hindwing and dorsal abdomen of adult T. castaneum. TcCPR4 protein is predominantly localized in pore canals and regions around the apical plasma membrane protrusions into the procuticle of rigid adult cuticles. RNAi for TcCPR4 resulted in an abnormal shape of the pore canals with amorphous pore fibers ( PCFs ) in their lumen. These results support the hypothesis that TcCPR4 is required for achieving proper morphology of the vertical pore canals and PCFs that contribute to the assembly of a cuticle that is both lightweight and rigid.

In order to adapt to their environment, plants use light-sensing receptors to perceive light signals from the environment. Phytochromes ( phyA to phyE ) are a large and diverse group of light-sensing receptors. The phytochrome N-terminal 651-amino acid domain binds to regulatory light signals in the cell nucleus and acts to perceive and transduce these signals. To define functional roles for these subdomains, we have mutated an Arabidopsis thaliana gene called N651 to generate a series of novel mutations. We found 14 mutations in the N651 domain that affect the function of this gene. We found that these mutations clustered into two classes: light-signal perception mutants and signaling mutants. Most spectral mutants were found in the N-terminal extension and the per-antennal region of the phytochrome and in the per-antennal region of the per-antennal region of the phytochrome. On the other hand, the signaling mutants were found in the per-antennal region and in the per-antennal region of the phytochrome. These observations indicate that the N-terminal extension and per-antennal region of the phytochrome are involved in signal transfer, but that the per-antennal region of the phytochrome is responsible for light perception.
